editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Bartholinus Anatomy; MADE From the Precepts of his Father, And from the Obervations of all Modern Anatomits, together with his own. With one hundred fifty and three Figures cut in Bras, much larger and better than any have been heretofore Printed in Englih. IN FOUR BOOKS AND FOUR MANUALS, Anwering to the aid BOOKS.
Book I. Of the Lower Belly.
Book II. Of the Middle Venter or Cavity.
Book III. Of the uppermot Cavities, Viz. The Head.
Book IV. Of the Limbs.
The Four Manuals Anwering to the four foregoing Books.
Manual I. Of the Veins, Anwering to the Firt Book of the Lower Belly.
Manual II. Of the Arteries, Anwering to the Second Book of the Middle Cavity or Chet.
Manual III. Of the Nerves, Anwering to the Third Book of the Head.
Manual IV. Of the Bones, Anwering to the Fourth Book of the Limbs.

div.head: The Introduction.
div.p: ANthropologia or the Doctrine of Mans Nature, is, though commonly, yet rightly divided into two Parts: Anatomia which treats of the Body and its Parts; and Pychologia, which treats of the Soul.

Anatomia therefore [more rightly called Anatomy, that is Section, which Sr. Ignatius reckons as a kind of Martyrdom, Caelius terms Apertio an opening, and Tertulianus Proectio a cutting up, whence the term Proector, a Cutter up] that I may come to that which is my buines; in as much as it is a part of Natural Philoophy [forThe Subject of Anatomy. Medicinal Anatomy how ever ueful and of which Galen treats in his Anatomical Adminitration, we mut leave to Phyitians] hath for its Subject the Body of any Animal or Live-wight whatoever, whether frequenting the Land or or Waters, flying in the Air, &c. and not only the Body of Man. But we are wont mot of all to earch into the tructure of Mans Body. 1. Becaue of the great Perfection thereof, whichWhy Anatomy treats chiefly of the Body of Man. is the Rule of Imperfection. 2. Becaue the undry orts of Animals are almot infinite, o that to diect and earch into all of them, the life of man in this Age of the World is not ufficient. 3. Becaue of the incredible profit which thereby redounds to every man, who deires perfectly to know himelf, and this Houe of his earthy Tabernacle, both the better to preerve Health and to cure Dieaes: Nor can any man be a Natural Philoopher or deerve o to be called, unles he have the Doctrine of Anatomy at his fingers end, above all other Parts of Natural Philoophy. Yet is not the Diection of other Creatures therefore unprofitable, or to beThe Diection of other Animals is ueful to an Anatomit and why? neglected by an Anatomit, partly by reaon of the Analogie and Correpondence they hold with the Body of Man, partly to attain to the Knowledg of the Motions of Living Creatures, and partly, to conclude, for the Exercie of an Anatomit and Surgeon. Democritus ought the Seat and Nature of Choler in Living Creatures. After him Galen diected Apes and other Living Creatures, as alo Severinus, Aldrovandus, Catellus, Br • nzerus, Panarolus and myelf have cut up divers Living Creatures. By the cutting up of Creatures alive Aellius found out the Ven • lacteae ••
milkie Veins, and Harvey and Walaeus found the motion of the Blood.

Moreover, becaue in regard of the vari •• of its Actions, the Body of Man does not conit of one part all alike, but of undry; therefore we mut know that the whole Body is dividedThe diviion of the whol Body of Man. •
into Parts containing, Parts contained, and Parts moving, according to the ancient Doctrine of Hippocrates: that is to ay, into olid Parts, Humors and Spirits. And in this large acceptation, all things are called Parts which make up and compleat the Body, even the Nails, Hairs, Fat and Marrow. But tricctly and properly that is called a Pa •• which partakes of the form, and life of the whole, and uch the Anatomits accounts <…> o • i • t Parts, And therefore
•… lius hath well defined a Part to be A Body <> to the whole, partaking of the common Life <…>
•… ted for the performance of ome Functions or Ue. But Galen accounts that a Part,What a Part is? which is a B •…
•• ome ort joyned to the whole, and hath in part its own proper Circumc •••
<…> part is properly;

1. Tha •
<…> is <…> but does not nourih any other Part. And o they exclude the S •… H •… . <…> alo t •• Fa • , which omtimes nourihes the Parts, and theWhat is the proper acceptation of the wor • Part. Marrow of the Bone
<…> .
2. That which is olid.
3. Which hath a proper Circumcription of its own. The contrary whereof is in fat, which is terminated by the figure of the Parts adjacent.
4. Which is continued with the whole, Mathematically and Phyically, both in repect of the Matter and Form joyntly conidered.
5. Which is fitted for ome Function or Ue. And o Warts and Swellings, with other things which grow upon the living Body praeternaturally, are excluded.

div.p:
And that we may undertand what is ment by Function and Ue, I hall briefly open the ame. An Action or Function may be either private or publick. The private Action is that whereby the Parts provide for themelves; the publick is that whereby they provide for theWhat is ment by the Action of a Part. whole live Creature. A publick Action as it is oppoed to ue, is the Action of the principal Part of an Organ which performes the whole Action. For every Action in the Body of a livewight, hath according to Galen, a peculiar Particle, by which it is performed. For Examples ake; The Skin hath of it elf a private Action, uch as the Attraction and Retention of Nourihment &c. it hath alo a publick action for the behoof of the whole Animal, viz. the dicerning of the tangible Qualities, uch as are perceived by the Sene of Feeling. So the action of the Liver •
•… od-making, of the Stones, Seed-making; of the Dugs Milk-making.

But the ••• e, is that help which the les principal Parts afford the more principal, in the performanceWhat by the ••• .
•• their Actions, which according to Galen is in all Parts, yea even in thoe which have no action at all. It prings chiefly from three Fountaines, and they are,

list.item:
1. The proper Temper of the Part, that is to ay the Symmetry or even proportion of the fir • t Qualities. For Examples ake, The Skin is in repect of the firt Qualities temperate; and if
you ask wherefore, I anwer, that it may be able to dicern and judg of all tangible Qualities.
2. Such things as follows the Temper, and they are the econd Qualities: Hardnes, Softnes, Thicknes Thinnes, Compactnes, Rarity, &c.

3. Neceary Adjuncts, as Magnitude, Number, Paages or Cavities, Figure, Conformation, Connexion, Situation, Surfae. But I, in thee Intitutions, for the conveniency of Learners, hall, with other Anatomits, eldom oberve this accurate difference between Action and Ue epecially, that I may avoid the tedious repetition of undry things.

div.p: But before I proceed to the Diviion and Differences of Parts, I hal briefly reolve this quetion,Which Part of the Body is firt generated. Which Part of the Body is firt generated. We mut therefore know, that according to Hippocrates, all the Parts are formed and differenced at one and the ame time, as in a Circle, there is neither beginning nor end, but altogether are both beginning and end. But all the Parts are not perfected and adorned at one and the ame time; but in the firt place the Navil-vein. 2. The Liver. 3. Afterwards the Heart (which Aritotle would have to be firt made, as Galen would have the Liver to be) and latly the brain. The Navil-vein therefore, is firt finihed and perfected, in regard of the enlargement thereof by the blood, but not in repect of its firt Contitution of the Seed. But others aid that the Groundwork or underwarpe of the Parts is Seed, and the Woof or Supertructure blood, uppoing that there are two material Principles of the body: Seed and blood. Which Opinion I have refuted and ufficiently explained in my Anatomical Controveries, Quaet. 11. touching the Parts and their Faculties and Functions.

And therefore the Veels are aid in repect of Perfection to be generated before the bowels,Why the Veels were to be made before the Bowels. and that jutly. For otherwie the bowels could not be nourihed without a proportionable Intrument to that end, namely a Vein, by which the blood is conveighed for their Nutriment. For as out of a Kernel or Seed put into the Earth, firt a long Root decends into the Earth, after that other Roots pread themelves round about the Surface of the Earth, out of which afterwards, the Trunk and branches pring up; o out of the Seed committed to the Womb, there aries firt the Navil-vein, receiving blood out of the Womb-cake; out of which Navilvein aries the Vena Portae, with its Roots.
Let us now come to the Diviion or Differences of the Parts, which may be divers.

Taking the word in a large Sene, ome divide them into parts of Neceity, as the Heart, Liver,Diviion of the Parts. Lungs, Stomach; and Parts of Commodity, and that either great as the Eyes and Stones, or les as the Nails; and parts of Ornament, as the Hairs of the Head and Beard.
But I hall divide the Parts, chiefly in repect of their End, or in repect of their Matter. In repect of their End. The principal Parts.

In repect of the worthines of the End, ome are Principal, others les principal and
<…> .

The Principal are the Liver, Heart, Brain, which are the Principles of other Parts. As, out of the brain arie the Nerves, according to the common Opinion, out of the Heart, the Arteries, out of the Liver, the Veins. Others add the Teticles, but without any need, becaue they make nothing to the Conervation of the Individual, • and Generation is caued without them, as I hall hew by Examples in the 7. Book Chap. 22.

Now we do not mean the beginning of Radication or Original; for o, the Seed is the beginningThe Beginning or principle of Radication. The Original of Dipenation. Parts ubervient or minitring. of all the Parts, but of Dipenation and Ditribution; that is uch a beginning as ends out of it elf ome Intrument, Force or common Matter. So from the Heart, as the beginning or Original of Dipenation, the Arteries arie, becaue they receive their Virtue from the heart. and eem there to have their Original. The ame may be aid of the Veins and Nerves in repect of their Originals. So the Gritles have their Original from the bones, and alo the Ligaments.
The Subervient Parts are neceary or not neceary.

The Neceary are thoe without which the Animal cann ••
<…> cannot live well. So the Lungs erve the Heart, the Guts the Stomach; the Stoma •…
• aver and Spleen; the Gallbladder, Choler-paage and Pis-bladder, erve the Liver; and all the Intruments of the Senes erve the brain.

The Not-neceary, as imple fleh, &c. in repect of other Parts: for in conumptive perons • is wated away, and in flehie perons tis a burthen, and in ects according to Aritotle have no Fleh.In repect of their Matter. A imilar part what it is, and how manifold.
In repect of their immediate Matter, ome are imple, Homogeneal or Similary; others Compound Heterogeneal, or diimilary.
A Similar Part, is that which is divided into Parts like it elf, o that all the Particles are of the ame Subtance with the whole, as every part of fleh is fleh, &c.
Of uch imilar Parts, ome reckons more, others fewer.

Aritotle in undry places, thus reckons them: Blood, Flegm, Choler, Sanies or blood-water, Milk, Seed, Gall, Fat, Marrow, Fleh, Veins, Arteries, Nerves, Fibres, Membranes, Skin, Bones, Gritles, Hairs, Nails, Horns, Feathers.
Averroes omits ome of thee, and adds Melancholy, Spirits, Mucles, Cords, Ligaments, Suet.

Galen in undry places, thus reckons them: A Bone, a Gritle, a Vein, an Artery, a Nerve, a Membrane, a Fibre, a Tendon, a Ligament, a Nail, Skin, Fat, Marrow, the Glaie and Chrytalline Humors, the fleh of the Mucles and bowels, with the proper ubtance of the brain, Stomach, Guts and Womb.

Archangelus retaines all the aforeaid, and adds three orts of Spirits, four Alimentary humors, and the Excrementitious humors, as Urin in the Bladder, Choler in the Gall-bladder, Excrementitious Flegm, and all the Excrements of all digetions, the Scarf-skin, and the internal Skin of ••
<…> Cavities. Moreover • e adds to thee, eventeen imilar parts, not commonly
reckoned, viz. the proper ubtance (etting aide the other imilar parts, Veins, Arteries, &c.) of the Brain, Tongue, Lungs, Heart, Liver, Gall-bladder, Spleen, Stomach, Guts, Kidneys, Ureters, Pis-bladder, Womb, Yard, Stones, Mucles, Kernels. But it is in Vain for him to reckon thee parts as new: for all in a manner are comprehended under Fleh. For according to Hippocrates and Galen, there is a fleh of the Mucles, and a fleh of the Bowels, and a fleh of the Glandules or Kernels. But in another place Galen propounds a threefold fleh. 1. In a Mucle, which the Ancients did only cal Fleh. 2. The Parenchyma, or proper ubtance of the Liver, Heart, Kidneys, &c. 3. In the Stomach, Bladder, Veins. 4. In the Bones, though improperly.

Whence we may gather four orts of Fleh. 1. Muculous fleh, which Galen frequentlyHow many orts of Fleh there are? terms Fibrous fleh, and it is oft and red and properly termed fleh. And in Hippocrates his Language, by fleh many times is ment the Mucles. 2. Vicerous fleh or the fleh of the Bowels. Eraitratus cals it Parenchyma or an Affuion of blood; Galen cals it Similar and imple fleh, which upports the Veels of the bowels, fills up the empty paces, and performs the Action. 3. Membranous fleh, or the flehy ubtance of every Membranous part, as in the Gullet, Stomach, Guts, Womb, bladder. 4. Glandulous fleh, or the fleh of Kernels, which erves. 1. For to upport the diviions of Veels. 2. To drink up uperfluous humors, epecially wheyih humors, becaue the Kernels are of an hollow Spungy ubtance; and therefore they are vulgarly termed Emunctories or Cleners. Thoe in the Neck being counted Cleners of the Head; thoe in the Arm-pits, of the Heart; thoe in the Groyns of the Liver. 3. To moiten the parts for their more eaie motion, or otherwie to prohibit drynes. Such are thoe which are ituate by the Tongue, Larynx, Eye-corners, &c.
But the imilar parts are reckoned to be ten: A bone, a Gritle, a Ligament, a Membrane, aThe Number of the Similar Parts. Fibre, a Nerve, an Artery, a Vein, Fleh and Skin.

Of thee ome are imilar only in the judgment of Sene, as Veins, Arteries (ome add Mucles) others are imply and abolutely imilar. That Veins, Arteries, Nerves, Mucles are not truly imple and imilar, hath been rightly taught by Aritotle: for a Mucle conits of Fleh, Fibres, and a Tendon: Nerves are made up of the Dura and pia Mater, with Marrow: Arteries, of two different coats; the Veins of a coat (and of Fibres as ome will have it) and Valves. Simply and truly imilar parts are Bones, Gritles, Ligaments, Membranes, Fibres, Fleh and Skin. To thee ome add the Ureters, the Air implanted in the Ear, &c. but in vain. For, 1. They are not parts common •• the whole body, but proper to ome parts. 2. The implanted Air of the Ears, is nothing but an implanted pirit, which cannot be reckoned among olid parts.
Here we are to oberve that all thee parts are commonly divided, into Spermatical, Sanguine, or mixt.

The Spermatical are made of eed, and uch are the eight firt reckoned; which if they are cutWhat a Spermatical Part is? aunder, they breed not again, nor can they be truly united, but they are joyned together by a Callus in the middle, by reaon of defect of matter and formative faculty, which acts not after the Conformation of the Parts.
The Sanguine or flehy Parts, contrarywie are bred again, becaue they are uppoed to beWhat a Sanguine Part. made of Blood, as the Fleh.
A mixt Part is the Skin, of which we hall treat hereafter, in Book 1. Chap. 2.

For feed and blood are commonly accounted the two general Principles of which we are made: o that in the Seed there is very little of the material principle, but much of the active, but in the blood much of the material principle, and but a little and weak portion of the active or effective principle. The firt Rudiments and underwrap as it were of the parts, are aid to be made of Seed; and the woofe or upertructure of blood flowing in. But what the Truth is in Contradiction to this vulgar opinion, we have taught in our Anatomical Controveries. For we are rather to hold, that the parts are at firt made only of Seed, as of their matter; and that the Mothers blood doth nourih, and encreae and amplifie the Parts. The Skin in comparion to other Parts, hath an indifferent proportion of Seed, not o much as the Spermatical, nor o little as the Sanguinary parts.

The Compound or diimilar Parts are, thoe which may be divided into divers unlike parts,What a diimilar part is? as an Hand cannot be cut into other Hands, but into Bones, Mucles, Veins, &c. The diimilar parts are by the Phyloopher called Members: but they are vulgarly termed Organical or intrumental parts.

Now in every Organ, there are for the mot part, four kinds of parts. For example ake,Organical parts. in the Eye there is, 1. That part by which the action, viz. Seeing is performed, namely the Chrytalline Humor. 2. That without which it cannot be performed, as the Optick Nerve. 3. That by which it is the better performed, as the Coats and Mucles of the Eyes. 4. That by which the action is preerved, as the Eye-lids, &c.
And becaue the Diimilar parts are more or les Compounded, they are divided into four degrees or ranks.

The 1. Is uch as are imilar to the ene, as a Mucle, Vein, Artery. The 2. Is made of the ormer and the ret of the imilars, as a Finger. The 3. is compounded of the econd, as an Hand, Foot, &c. The 4. Is compounded of the third, as an Arm or Leg.

Finally the Body is divided into its greatet Members, as by ome into the Head, Chet, Bellycon
•… a viion ••
and Bladder; by others as Aritotle, Ruffus a <…>
Oribaius into the Head, Neck, Chet (under they comprehend the lower Belly) and therefore Hippocrates placed the Liver in the Chet] the
Arms and the Legs. But others have better divided them into the Bellies and Limbs.

The Bellies are certain remarkeable Cavities of the Body, wherein ome noble bowel is placed: and as there are three principal Members, o are there three Bellies: the lowet belly, commonly called Abdomen or the Paunch, contains the Liver and Natural parts. The Middle or Chet, containes the Heart and vital parts. The uppermot or Head contains the brain and Animal parts. The Limbs which were given us for more conveniency of living, are the Arms and the Legs.

And therefore we hall make four books: 1. Of the Lower belly. 2. Of the Middle belly.This whole Work divided into four Books and four Petty Books or Manuals. 3, Of the upream belly or Cavity, the Head. 4. Of the Limbs. And to thee hall anwer four Petty Books: The firt of the Veins which arie from the Liver in the lower Cavity. The econd of the Arteries which arie from the Heart, in the middle Cavity. The third of the Nerves, which are commonly thought to pring from the brain. The fourth of the bones, which are mot what in the Limbs: and as the bones joyned together make a compleat frame and bodies as it were; o alo do the Veins, Arteries, and Nerves.

We may find another diviion of the body in Fernelius, which nevertheles is of no ue aveThe diviion of the Body according to the Regions. in Phyick. He divides the body into pulplike Regions and Private.

Private Regions he calls the brain, Lungs, Kidneys, Womb, &c. Publick or common he makes three extended through the whol body. 1. Hath the Vena porta, and all the parts whereinto its branches are pred. 2. Begins at the Roots of Vena Cava, and is terminated in the mal Veins, before they become Capillary. 3. Hath the Mucles, Bones, and Bulk of the body and ends in the Skin.
We purge the firt Region cheifly by the Guts; The econd by the Urinary paages; The third by the Pores of the Skin.

div.head: THE FIRST BOOK; OF THE Lower Belly.
div.p: ACcording to the MethodThe Reaon of the Order. Why Diection is begun in the lower Belly. of Anatomy, this belly or cavity comes in the firt place, and is firt of all diected that the Guts and Excrements may be the ooner removed, and the Body preerved from putrifaction.

It is all that, which is ditinguihed, within, from the Chet by the Midrif; itWhat the lower Belly is. is circumcribed by the word-like Gritle, the Share bones, Hip-bones, Os Sacrum, the Vertebra's of the Loynes, and the batard Ribs on either ide.

The former part thereof is called Epigatrium, The Parts of the lower Belly, and their Names. which compaes the tomach and guts next unto it. The Arabians call it Mirath, which generally is ued for the Belly, but in a particular ence it is taken for thoe wrinkles of the belly, which remain after child-bearing, and for the skin gathered together upon the belly, as Giggejus informs us.
And the upper part hereof is termed Hypochondrium, neighbouring upon the lower gritles of the Ribs, and it is right or left: ome term them Phrenes and Praecordia.
The middle Region is termed Regio umbilicalis, whoe lateral parts Aritotle calls Lagonas by reaon of their Laxity, and Galen, Cenen • nas from their emptynes.

The lower part which reaches from the Navil to the Share, is termed Hypogatrium, by Hypocrates, Galen, Ruffus, Pollux; the Latins term it Imus venter and Aqualiculus. The lateral parts thereof, are termed Ilia, and in the bending of the thigh by the Share Inguina the Groyns; and that part next over the Privities, which is covered with Down or Hair, is called P • bes the Share.
The hinder part of the lower Belly, is either the upper, which makes the Loynes; or the lower, which makes the Buttocks.
Moreover this Belly conits of parts covering and covered, that is to ay External and Internal.

The covering or Containing parts (which they properly call Abdomen) are either common, as the Scarfskin, the Skin, the Fat with its Membrane, the flehy Pannicle, and the Coat proper to every Mucle; or proper, and they are the Mucles of the Abdomen,
<…> the Peritonaeum.
The inner or contained parts, do erveAll the Parts which a • e to be examined in this Book. either for Nutrition or Procreation.

For Nutrition or making of Chyle, are ubervient more or les, the Stomach, the Caul, the Sweet-bread, the Guts with the Meentery: to the making of Blood, are ubervient more or les, the Meeraick Veins, the Venae portae with their Roots, the Cava with its Roots, the Liver, the Gall-bladder, the Gall-paage, the Spleen with the Vas breve, and the Haemorrhoides, the Arteria Caeliaca the Kidneys, the Capulae Atrabiliariae or black choler boxes, the Ureters and the Pis bladder.

Thoe which erve for Generation, are either Maculine or Female: the Maculine are, the Spermatick Veels, the Corpora Varicoa or Paratatae, the Stones, the carrying Veels, the Protratae, the Seminary bladders, the Yard, &c. The Female are, the Spermatick Veels, the Corpus Varicoum, the Teticles, the Ejaculatory Veels, the Womb with its parts, &c.
But when a Man is in the Womb, there are yet other things coniderable, as the Navil-veels, the coats which infold the Child, &c. of which in their place.

div.head: CHAP. I. Of the Scarf-Skin.
div.p: THe Cuticula or Scarf-skin, in GreekThe Scarfskin. Epidormis, is by ome called the highet or lat skin, alo the cream of the skin, the cover of the skin, &c. It is aWhat it is. thin skin void of life and ene, cloecompacted, bloodles; bred of Oyly, leek and clammy vapors thickned by the external cold, that it might be a cover to the skin.

The Matter of which the Scarf-skinWhether the Scarf-skin be made of eed? is made, is not eed. For 1. It is no part of the Body. 2. It is not nourihed. 3 A Spermatical part taken away breeds not again; but the carf-skin is eaily lot by rubbing and wearing, or being raied into bliters, by burning with Fire or calding Water, &c.

Nor is the matter thereof Blood, ForOr of Blood? 1. All Veins do end at or within the skin. 2. It hath no permatical Fibres, whi ••
• ais of all anguine parts. 3. In long • a • tin
and Conumptions, it many times grows thick. 4. Being cut or torne, it ends forth no Blood. 5. It is not of a red color, &c.

Nor are the Excrements of any Digetion, the matter thereof. Not theOr of the Excrement of concoction. Excrements of the firt or econd digetion; for how hould it be made of Dung, Urin or Gall? Nor the Excrements of the third, For the third Digetion or Concoction hath a threefold Excrement. 1. Vaporous and thin which Expires. 2. Thin, but more olid then the former, of a waterih ubtance, uch as are Ichors and Wheyih humors, which by their harpnes and Acrimony, would ooner hinder the Generation of the Scarf-skin, or corrode the ame after it is generated. 3. Thick, Clammy, and ticking fat, which Archangelus and Laurentius, doLaurentius and Archangelus confuted. uppoe to be dried and turned into the Scarf-skin, and they demontrate the ame from the filth which is, in bathing, craped from the foles of the Feet. And if their opinion were true, the Scarf-skin would come off in Baths.

And therefore the matter thereof is another Excrement, viz. an Oyly,The true matter of the Scarfskin. Thick, Clammy, and moit vapor (for of dry Exhalations the Hair is made) proceeding from the Skin and Members under the ame. So we ee in a Skillet of Water-gruel, a Skin grows over the top of the Gruel, being mad, of the vapors thereout acending, condened by cold.

Now the Scarf-skin is bred, partly in the womb with the Skin, and partly without the Womb. Within, For 1. So there are the rudiments and beginnings of Hair, Teeth, Nails in the Child in the Womb, 2. Without the Scarf-skin, the skin would be moit, and the Humor would weat out with pain, as in gallings and where Phoenigmi are applied. 3. Experience hews, that the Scarf-skin is omewhat apparent in an Abortion, and may be eparated by ome fretting Humidity. But whiles the Child is in the Womb, it is exceeding tender, oft, and but as yet begun to be made: becaue there is not in the Womb o much cold, only a mall degree pringing from the erous humor which urrounds the Child. But it receives its Complement and perfection without the Womb, from the coldnes of the Air, which doth more condene and dry, which is the Caue that the skin of all New-born Infants looks red.

Wherefore the remote and internal Efficient thereof is in the inward heat of theThe Efficient Caue thereof. Body, thruting forth a vapor into the urface thereof, as Exhalations are made by the uns heat. The next and external, is the coldnes of omebody, as the Air, &c. compacting, and thickning. So Gruel, Hot milk, and other hot dihes of meat, have a skin growing over them: ometimes alo the drynes of the Ambient Air, conuming the external humor, and compacting the remainders of the matter. Now by how much the aid vapor is more Earthy and Clammy, by o much more olid is that which is bred thereof.

The Ve thereof is to defend the Skin. And therefore 'tis omwhat hard, howbeit exceeding thin Ve. and yet tranparent, like the tranparent skins of Onions; leat if it were thicker, the skin hould not feel <…> it is omtimes bard and brauny, in the Hands <…> by reaon <…> of Labor and Travel.

<…>
•• d more compact than <…> And therefore it is that watery putules pas through the Skin but not the Scarf-skin. Yet not over cloe and compact, leat it hould hinder the bodies tranpiration And it is cloe wrought, not only to defend the parts under it but that alo too great an efflux of Vapor, Blood, Spirit and heat might not happen. For it is the cover of the Mouths and extremities of the Veels. And therefore thoe cannot live in good health that are born without a Scarf-skin; as was een in Lewes the King of Bohemia and Hungaria, who became gray hair'd while he was but a Boy.

It is of a white color, and therefore of aThe color of the Scarfskin. cold and dry temper and quite void of Blood, For being torn or cut, it ends forth no Blood. Nor is it nourihed by Blood, as Lauremberg and Sperlinger would have it; for it is not intrinfically nourihed by attraction of its proper Aliment; but by addition of parts the vapor growing into the like nature of the Scarf-skin, as Caerus rightly diputes, The Scarf-skin is black in Blackmores, but not the skin beneath it.

As for number: there is but one Scarfskin;Its number. only there was once two found by Aquapendent: the one being trongly fatned in the pores of the skin, and ineperable: the other eperable without offence to the skin. Which happens in ome only, not in all parts of the Body. Alo Laurembergius, in applying Veicatories, found the Scarf-skin double; but that is a rare cae, for that Veicatories do peitce unto the skin is apparent from the humor dropping out, and the pain. In brawny Calloities, indeed there are many little skins, as it were the skins of Onyons; but they are beides nature, whoe Generation and cure is delivered by Fallopius.

In point of Connexion, it ticks oIts Connexion. cloe to the Skin of a man, while he is alive, as if it were one continued body therewith. Yet many times it is cat off as nakes and erpents cat their skins, which Felix Platerus tells us did happen to himelf; and which happens in burning Feavers and the mall Pox. Salmuth oberved as much in ome Gouty perons, in an Ague, and ome other caes. In dead perons 'tis eparated by a Candle, or calding Water: in living Bodies with Phoenigmi. In the Nut of the Yard, it ticks not to the skin, but to the fleh.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Skin.
div.p: CVtis, the skin, is in Greek cal'd Derma, What the Skin is? as it were Dema a band; it is the common covering of the Body; or a Temperate Membrane bred of the eed by a proper faculty, to be the Intrument of feeling, and to defend the parts beneath it.

It is called a Membrane, which mut not be undertood imply, but o as to be a Membrane of a peculiar nature and proper temperament. And therefore Piccolhomineus was mitakenPiccolhomine • s refuted. when he would have the skin to be imply a Membrane; for the skin is thicker, hath a ubtance proper to it elf, and is temperate.

But the opinion of others is, that the matter hereof is Seed and Blood well mixed together, o that the skin hath a middle nature between Fleh <…> Nerves. And therefore Galen Galens Opinion touching the matter of the skin.
<…> that it is as it <…> a Nerve
endued with blood: he ayes not imply, but as it were. For he alo likens it to a Membrane, becaue in ome parts it may be extended, feels exquiitely, and is white.

Aritotle would have the skin to conit of fleh dried and grown old as it were. ButAritotles Opinion. the skin is eaily flaid from the parts under it, and between the fleh and skin there is fat, a Membrane, &c. to which Opinion Fernelius inclined, when he aid that the skin of the Face was a certain more dry portion of the fleh beneath it. Wherein he alo is to be blamed, Becaue 1. It may be eparated from the fleh. 2. It will admit of Scars as the skin in other places.

p.U: ay it is made of the Extremities of the Veels widened, becaue itThe Opinion of others. every where lives and feels, and the extremities of the Veels end thereinto: but this may be aid of all the parts of the Body.

div.p: Others, of the ofter Nerves pread out in the urface of the Body, an addition of blood concurring: but this Opinion is of no more force then the formet.

The skin therefore is made of Seed taken in a moderate quantity: and forThe true matter of the skin. its enlargement, it had a moderate quantity of blood; but eed eems to hold the greater proportion. For the skin is naturally whi • ih; though it varies according to the plenty of humors and Bodies beneath it. For uch as the Humor is, uch will be the color of the skin. So Sanguine perons have it ruddy; thoe that are Jaundized, have it yellow or black. Examples whereof ee in Marcellus Donatus and others. If fleh lie beneath it, the redder it is, if fat the whiter.

It is in repect to the eed, that Authors ay, the skin grows not togetherAScar, what it is? again after it is wounded. In repect of the blood, there is omewhat like the skin produced, viz. a Scar: Which conits as it were of burnt and dried fleh. Howbeit in Children, by reaon of the moiture of their skin, as alo the aboundance of glutinous humors, a wound hath been oberved to be cloed up with true skin; Witnes Spigelius.
Wherefore the skin being made as it were of a Membranous, cold and dry, and of a flehy, hot and moit ubtance; becomes temperate in all the firt and econd qualities, that it may rightly judg of all.

The Efficient Caue of the skin, is the Skin-generating faculty; as in a boneThe efficient caue of the skin. the Bone-generating faculty, in a Nerve the Nerve-forming power or faculty, &c. which faculty frames a part differing from all other imilar parts. But how doth the faculty make of the ame Seminal matter Nerves, Bones, &c. by an hidden and divine power as it were.

The publick Action of the skin, and which is neceary for the whole Living-CreatureThe Action of the skin. is, to be the primary Intrument of the ene of feeling, for every Membrane is the Adaequate Organ, as may be een in the Bones, Nerves, Stomach, &c. For though all the Organs of the enes are diimilar parts, yet one imilar part is the primary caue of the action, which is to be performed by the whole Organ. For examples ake, the hand is indeed the Organ of feeling, and epecially that part of the skin, which covers the hollow of the Hands and Feet, as being of all other mot temperate. And becaue the skin is temperate in the firt qualities; it is therefore alo temperate in the econd, as <…> hardnes, thicknes, thinnes, & <…> .

The firt ue of the Skin is, to be a CoveringIts Ve. for the Body, and therefore it hath received a Figure o round, long, &c. as the ubject parts required; and therefore alo it is eared without the Body, and becaue it was to be as it were the Emunctory of the Body. The profeors of Phyiognomy commend unto us another ue of the skin, as it is treaked with lines; who are wont to tell mens Fortunes from the Lines and Hillocks in their Hands, and from the Planetary and Adventitious Lines in their Foreheads. A third ue is Medicinal, being good for Anodin • Emplaters. Being dried, it helps women in Labor; Epileptick Convulions, according to the experience of Hildanus and Beckerus; Wounds of the Scul, according to Poppius. The fourth is more illutrious, that it might give way to Excrements, and exclude inenible ooty Fumes by way of inenible Tranpiration, by which we are more disburthened then by all our enible Evacuations put together. By this, Sanctorius through the tatick Art, in the experience of thirty years, did learn that many perons in the pace of one natural day, do void more by tranpiration, then in fifteen dayes together by tool. The fift is to attract. 1. Air in tranpiration, in Apople • tick and Hyterical fits, and in uch as dive deep and bide long under the Water. 2. Juyce, in long fating, from platers applied, if we credit the Obervations of Zacutus Lufitanus; and the force of purgative and other external Medicaments. And for this caue.

'Tis bored through in divers places, for the ingres and egres of things neceary. Now its holes are ome of them viible, as the Mouth, the Ears, the Notrils, &c. others inviible and inenible, as the pores. Thoe pores of the Body, being otherwie not Conpicuous, are een in the winter, when the Body is uddenly bared; for then the Scarf-skin looks like a Gooes skin when the feathers are pul'd of. By reaon (it eems) of thee pores it was, that a certain Perian King made ue of the skins of Men for windowes, if we may credit Orabai • s.

The Skin is thick, ix fold thicker then the Scarfskin, but thinner then it is in other Animals, nor mut any one judg of the thicknes of the Skin after it is made into Leather, for by Tanning it is much contracted and thickned, And it eems to be made lighter, for a Mans skin Tanned according to the Obervation of Loelius, weighs four pounds and an half.

It is oft and exquiitely enible, but ofter and thinner in the Face, Yard, and Cods; harder in the Neck, Thighs, oles of the Feet, Back; of a midling contitution between hardnes and oftnes, in the tops of the Fingers. So, ome part of the skin is extream thick as in the Head, according to Aritotle, fally cited by Columbus. Some is thick, as in the Neck; ome thin as in the ides, whence proceeds tickling; ome yet thinner as in the Palms of the Hands, ome thinnet of all, as in the Lips. In Children 'tis more thin and porous then in grown perons, in women then in men; in an hot Countrey, then in a cold. Alo the Skin is more rare and open in the Summer then in the Winter; and therefore it is that the skins of Animals flaid off in the Summer do more hardly retain their hair, then uch as are flaid off in the winter. Alo it varies very much according to the diverity of the uoject; o that in ome it hath been of an admirable denity and thicknes, if we beleive Petrus Ser •…
who tels of two Negro women, that could without hurt take up carry, hold, and almot extinguih burning oles with their bare Hands. Fallopius aw the skin of <…> o <…> that he lot his feeling <…>
• eao •… of the Nerves

As to its Connexion: ome skin is eaily eparated from the parts underIts Connexion. it; as in the lower and middle Belly, in the Arms and Thighs. From others with more difficulty by reaon of the thick Membrane to which it is fatned by the Fibres, and by means of the Veels. In the oles of the Feet and Palms of the Hands, it is hardly eparated, to which parts it grows that they might lay the fater hold. Alo hardly from the fleh of the Forehead and of the whole Face, epecially of the Ears and Lips, by reaon of tendons and Mucles mixed therewith, epecially the Mucle Latus o called, mingled therewith. So, in the Forehead it is moveable, and in the hinder part of the Head of ome People by reaon of peculiar Mucles; but it is not o in the ret of the Body.

The skin hath received common Veels, for Nourihment, Life and Sene. ItIts Veels. hath received two cutany Veins, through the Head and Neck, from the Jugulars; two through the Arms, Breat and Back, from the Axillaries; two through the lower Belly, Loyns and Legs, from the Groyns, which are Conpicuous in women after hard Labor, and in uch as have the Varices in many branches. It hath few Art
•• ng. And thoe very mall, in the temples and Forehead, Fingers, Cod and Yard. It hath no Nerves creeping in it, but it hath many ending in it, as Galen conceived: though Iohannes Velingus the prime Anatomit of Padua ayes there are very mall branches of Nerves running through the skin; and that rightly, for their preence was neceary to caue the ene of Feeling.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of FAT.
div.p: FAt is a imilary Body void of Life,What fat is? growing together out of Oyly blood, by reaon of the coldnes of the Membranes, for the afegard of the whole Body. That it is void of Life, appears in that it is cut without pain, and Conumptions thereof hew as much. Therefore Pliny writes that living owes are gnawn by Mice; and Aelian reports that the Tyrant Dionyius was o Fat, that when he was a leep, the pricking of Needles could not awake him. Alo in Greenland they cut fat out of living Whales which they never feel nor perceive.

Pinguedo fat, which the Greeks term Pimele, is by Gaza ill tranlated Adeps:
The difference between Pinguedo and Adeps. for Pinguedo is an Aiery hot and moit ubtance of the moiter orts of Animals, and is more eaily melted with heat, and will carce ever become hard again, nor can it be broken, and it is oft, laxe and rare: but undertand the contrary in Suet, which eaily grows hard and tiff, but is hardly diolved, &c.
Now fat to peak properly, is not a part, but rather an humor, unlesFat is not a part of the Body. haply it be conidered together with the Membrane, as many times it is by Galen.
The <…> of our order is this; becaue fat in a man is between the skin and the flehy Membrane, in •… s under the Membrane which moves the

Thoe parts are void of fat, whichwhat parts have Fat, and what not. could receive no profit thereby but hindrance by reiting convenient Complication and Ditenion, as the Brain, Eyelids, Yard, Cod, and Membranes of the Teticles. Now it is chiefly in thoe parts which are more trongly moved then the ret, hard like Suet, and interwoven between the Fibres and little Veins, as in the Palm of the Hand, the inner ides of the Fingers (for there are many tendons, Nerves and Veels, which ought to be moitened) in the ole of the Foot, epecially the Heel. It is ofter in undry parts, of which in their place.

Caecilius Folius hath larely writtenIt is not made of Chyle. that the matter whereof fat is made, is the milky juyce, or fatter portion of the Chylus, and that therewith the Bones are nourihed. To which opinion I oppoe. 1. That uch as eat fat meats, do not preently grow fat. 2. That the Chylus is too crude to nourih the parts. 3. That Children hould preently become fat as we ee it happen in Children new born, who have been nourihed only with their Mothers Blood. 4. That the Chylus is necearily changed before it come unto the Parts. 5. There is no paage from the Meentery to the extream parts of the body; for it is neither uckt through the Membranes, as ome learned men uppoe, nor is it carried through the Glandules. Not the former. 1. Becaue they are thicker, then to uck and draw as threads. 2. They would appear woln, and would in Anatomy dicover ome Oyly moiture in them. Nor the latter, 1. Becaue the Kernels are not continued with the fat parts. 2. Nor do they receive any profitable humor, but Excrements, yea they abound with a white, flegmatick, but not a fat humor. 3. We oberve that many creatures grow fat which have no Kernels. Now the fatter part of the Chyle is the material caue of fatnes, but it is only the remote caue, and therefore in deed and truth,

The Matter thereof is UnanimoulyBut of Blood. concluded to be Blood, whence Aritotle ayes, that uch Creatures as have no Blood, have neither Fat nor Suet: but it mut be blood Purified and Abolutely concocted, nor yet all uch blood, but that which is thin, Aiery and Oyly. It reembles the buttery ubtance of Milk, andThat blood is Aiery and oyly the Oyly ubtance of Seed; and therefore Aritotle did well deny Fat to be moit; with a watery moiture, his meaning was, not with an Aiery. Againt whom Fernelius and Columbus have written. And when fat is made of Oyly Blood, much of the heat is lot. Whence Aritotle ayes; Such things as are condened by cold, out of them much heat is forced and queezed. And in another place: Natural matters are uch, as the place is wherein they are.

Therefore the nature of Fat is colderFat is colder then Blood, yet moderately hot. then that of blood, yet is it moderately hot; For 1. Outwardly applyed, it Digets, Reolves, Dicues. 2. It is the thinner and more Oyly part of the blood. 3. It eaily takes fire. 4. It encreaes the heat within, as the Caul aits the Stomachs Concoction, &c.

Some will have it to be cold, becaue Aritotle ayes, whatever things grow together by cold, and are melted by Heat, are cold. But Fat is congealed by cold. I anwer: Fat is cold in repect of the Heat which before it had, while it was blood. But we mut learn <…> the ame Aritotle, that uch things as having been <…> cold, are melted with an eaie Heat, have

div.p: The Efficient, or Generating Caue of Fatnes, is moit and temperate Heat,The efficient caue of Fat. the Author of all Digetion. The caue Efficient of its growing together, is the coldnes of the Membranes (from whence it gains its white color) not imple but repective; yet ufficient to coagulate the oylie part of the blood weating forth, even as melted Lead grows congealed, when it is poured out into aHow Fat is bred? place hot enough, yet colder then the fire. And Fat grows togetherTis proved that Fat is generated by cold. by cold, in a certain degree as it were (for every thing is not made of every thing) and therefore Fat is not bred in any part. Now that Fatnes proceeds from Coldnes Galen and other Learned men have determined, o that the Fat, light, and thin Part of the Blood, while in hotter Bodies it turns to Nutriment, in colder it is reerved (and therefore hot and dry Animals are hardly eyer fat) and when the Veins end it out of themelves, it lights upon the Membranes, and grows together.
For 1. Even the Blood, when it is out of the Veels, does after this manner grow together, by meeting with the cold Air, though its internal Coldnes do alo, help forward the mutation.
2. Aritotle aies, among uch things as melt, thoe that are melted by heat, are congealed by cold, as Oyl.
3. The colder Creatures are the fatter, as Gueldings, Foemales; alo uch as lie long hid in the Earth without Exercie: So in the Winter, all Creatures are fatter.

4. Fat is only bred in cold places, asHow Fat is bred in th •… Call? in the Membranes: So we ee the Call is fat, by reaon of its membranous Subtance, alo in repect of its place, being far from the hot Bowels, for it <…> upon the Guts, under the Peritonaeum, and beca •… tored with abundance of Veins and Arteries, i •… uch
Fat; o about the Heart Fat is collected, for there is the Pericardium,And about the Heart? a cold and thick Membrane; alo the wheyih Humor contained therein: below it there is the Midriff as a Fan, on either fide the Lungs like Bellows, the Mediatinum &c. So about the the KidneysAnd the Kidneys? Fat is gathered, becaue they abound with a wheyih Excrement, lie near the Backbone, and are covered by the Guts.

5. A Cover hanging over boyling Water, coagulates the Vapors which arie unto it, and turns them into water by its Coldnes. For make the Air round about exceeding hot, and then the Vapors triking againt the cover, will not be condened.

Another Opinion is, that Fat is made by an hot Caue, becaue the matter thereofAn Opinion that Fat is caued by Heat. is hot, and becaue Fat eaily flames; alo becaue all things are made in the body, by Coction, and Heat. But the anwer is clear from what hath been aid before. And we do not mean meer Coldnes, the Caue of Crudity, but a weak Heat.

p.U: ay that Fat attains its conitency from the compactnes of theAn Opinion that it is made by compactnes. Refuted. Membranes, for that which is itelf compact makes other things o. I anwer. That cold things condene, and Condenation proceeds from Cold, nor can that which is condened condene, unles it were a firt Quality, or hould take the aitance of Cold, for otherwie the thinnes of the Membrane would make the fat thin. And why does not the denity or compactnes of the Veels make the matter contained to be condened and compact?

div.p: 2. In like manner they object: By a thick cover though very hot, the Vapor ariing from boyling Water, when it meets therewith, is turned into Water, or in a Ditillation by an Alembick, the Exhalations ariing from the ubject matter, meeting with the thick glas are topped, and by reflection turned into a thickned Subtance. But the Anwer, is clear from what hath been aid; moreover, the Vapors which are raied up by boyling, if they are by the Veel o hut in, that there is no place to breath out, new Vapors continually ariing, that there may not be a Penetration of Bodies, it is neceary, that they reaume their former conitency: But if they find egres, they turn to Water, by reaon of the cold Air urrounding the glaie Cover. And therefore it is that, to make the Liquor iue more aboundantly, Ditillers ever and anon cool the ame with cold Water. So when the Air abroad is cold, hot Vapors within do turn to Water upon the glas Windows; which does not happen when the Air is hot abroad.

3. They ay, that there are many cold Parts, as the Brain and its coats, &c. which have no Fat about them. I anwer, thoe Parts alo are dene. Nor would Nature have Fat in thoe Parts, for it would be both unprofitable and hurtful: And a moderate Heat is there provided for, by the thicknes of the Skin, the Hair and the Skull.

Fabius Pacius makes the caue toAn Opinion that it is caued by Drynes. be alo Drynes, by reaon of the Fibers of Fat. To which is repugnant 1 That Fat is not dry, but moit. 2 •… le Fibers, as the Blood hath. Touch

Other late Writers are pleaed with aBy a peculiar Form. new conceit, that Fat is made, by a peculiar fat-making form, as a bone is made by a bone-making form. Who doubtles are mitakens becaue 1 Fat doth not live. 2 It hath no certain Dimenion. And 3 The blood turns into the marrow of the bones, without the help of uch a form.

The Form of Fat as long as it is in the Veels, is not congealed, but liquid andThe form of Fat. melted, by reaon of the Heat which as yet remains in the Veels. It hath been voided liquid by Urin, as Helmo • t hath oberved, and in an healthy Woman by tool, in the Obervation of Hildanus. Folius conceives it is liquid in the Veels, by reaon of likenes of Nature, but that it is congealed without, becaue of the different Nature of the Fibres. But no man can eaily oberve the diimilitude of the fibres, either within the body, or without.

The Fat of the Belly hath three Veins, the external Mammillary decending fromIts Veels. above the Vena Epigatrica, ariing from beneath out of the crural Vein, through the Groins, and very many Veins coming out of the Loins, accompanied with Arteries. And through thee, and the Veels of the Skin, Cupping-glaes and Scarifications draw Humors out of the inner Parts, as far as I can conceive.

It hath a very great aboundance of Kernels, Its Kernels. which receive Excrements out of the Body into themelves. In ickly perons, and uch as abound with excrementitious Moiture, they are more plentiful.

The Ue of Fat is 1 To keep warm likeIts Ues. a Garment, to cherih Natural Heat, by its Clammynes, hindring the going forth thereof, and by its thicknes, topping the Paages, leat Cold hould enter; and in Summer, they keep out the Heat.

2. In a pecial manner to help the Concoction of the Stomach. And therefore the cutting out of the Call breeds Winds and Belchings, and to caue good Digetion, it is neceary to provide ome other covering for the Stomach.
3. To daub and moiten hot and dry parts, uch as is the Heart.

4. To facilitate Motion, provided it be moderate, for abundance of Fat hinders Motion and all other Actions, and to keep the Parts from being over dried, ditended, or broken. Hence it defends the ends of Gritles, the Joyntings of the greater Bones; and it is placed on the outide of certain Ligaments, alo about the Veels carried to the Skin. For this very caue, there is tore of Fat in the Socket of the Eye, leat by reaon of continual Motion, it hould become dry and withered as it were. And the Vena Coronalis of the Heart, is fenced with much Fat, to accommodate the great Motion and Heat of the Heart.
5. It erves as a Pillow and Bulwark againt Blows, Bruies, and Compreions. And therefore it is that Nature hath furniht the Buttocks, and the Hollow of the Hands and Feet with plenty of Fat.

6. In times of Famine, it is turnedWhether it may turn to nourihment? into nourihment, for we are nourihed with that which is weet and fat, as being familiar to us and our Nature, if we will beleive Galen and other Authors. Whoe Intention Rondeletius interprets to be, that the Fat doth only releive famihed perons, and hold the parts •• the Body in play, till they attain their proper Nou
• hment.

7. It fills up the empty paces between the Mucles,
Veels, and Skin, and conequently renders the Body mooth, white, oft, fair, and beautiful. And therefore perons in a Conumption and decrepit old Women are deformed, for want of Fat.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of Membranes in General, of the flehy Membrane, and the Membrane which is proper to the Mucles.
div.p: UNder the fat in a Man, the Membrana The flehy Membrane, its ituation. carnoa, or flehy Membrane lies, which in Apes, Dogs, and Sheep lies next the Skin. Before we treat thereof, ome things are to be known concerning the Nature of a Membrane in general.

The Ancients called the Membranes Hymenas, and ometimes Chitona's Coats, alo Meningas; and otherwhiles Operimenta, and Tegumenta Coverings; and with Galen and other Anatomits, peaking in a large Sene, a Coat and a Membrane, are one and the ame thing. But when they peak in a trickt and proper Sene.

That is a Membrane which compaes ome bulkie Part, as the Peritonaeum,The difference between a membrane and a Coat, and Meninx. the Pleura, the Periotium, the Pericardium, and the peculiar Membranes of the Mucles.

But the term Tunica or Coat in a trickt ene, is attributed properly to the Veels, as Veins, Arteries, Ureters, the Womb, the Gall-bladder, and the Pis-bladder, the Gullet, the Stomach, the Guts, the Stones.
The term Meninx is properly given and peculiarly to the Membranes of the Brain.

Now a Membrane is a imilar part broad, plane, white,What a Membrane is? and which may be tretched, made by a proper Membrane-making faculty, of clammy and watery Seed, to the end that it might by cloathing defend the Parts.
The Form thereof is the equality of its Surface, Thinnes, and Lightnes (leat it hould burden) compactnes and trength that it might be widened and tretched.

Its Ue is 1. To cloath and defend the Parts by reaon of its hardnes and compactnes;Its Ue. and to be the Intrument of feeling: For the Parts feel by help of the Membranes. And o great is the neceity of Membranes, that Nature hath covered every Part with a Membrane. 2. To trengthen the parts. 3. To defend the parts from the injury of the Cold, and to keep the Natural Heat from exhaling. 4. To joyn parts with parts. So the Meentery knits the Guts to the Back. 5. To hut the mouths of the Veels, leat the Humors hould flow out, or flow back: As in the Bladder, where the Ureters are implanted, in the Ventricles of the Heart, by the Valves.
Now a Membrane is thicker or thinner. The Difference of Membranes.

The thin Membrane differs in thinnes. For the Periotium of the Ribs is thinner then the Pleura, the Periotium of the Head, is thinner then the Pericraneum; the pia mater is thinner then the dura mater.
The thick Membrane is the Membrana carnoa, which is not every where alike thick; for it is thicker in the Neck then other places. And now let us peak of the Membrana carnoa, or flehy Membrane.

The Panniculus carnous or Membrana The flehy Membrane what for a thing it is? carnoa is by ome termed a membranous Mucle, by others a Nervie Coat, a fattie Coat, &c. It is termed flehy, becaue in ome places, as about the Forehead, the compas of the Neck, and the Ears, it turns to a muculous fleh, and in uch Creatures as by the help hereof can move their whole Skin, it eems to be a Mucle: It is endued with uch flehy Fibers, epecially in their Necks, by the motion whereof they drive away flies. But in Man, ave in his Forehead, it is immoveable; only Vealius and Valverda report that there were ome men who could move the Skin on their Chet and Back, and in other parts, jut as oxen do. In whom doubtles this Membrane was made of the ame contitution, which it hath in Brutes. Moreover in new-born Children, it reembles fleh, by reaon of plenty of blood; in grown perons it is like a Membrane, by reaon of continually being dried. In a Mans Body, if exact Separation be made, it will appear to conit of four ditinct Membranes. Spigelius and others do take thoe membranous Fibers, which are every where interwoven among the Fat, to be Panniculus carnous, or Membrana carnoa.
Its Ue is 1. To defend the neighboringIts Ue. Parts, yea, and to cover and defend the whole Body, and therefore it is ituate all over the body.
2. To keep in the Fat, that it flow not out, or melt by reaon of the continual motion of the Mucles.

3. To upport thoe Veels which are carried into the Skin (which go betweenConnexion. the Skin and this Membrane) for it is knit unto the Skin by very many Veins, ome fewer Arteries, branches of Nerves, and membranous Fibers; and to the Membranes under the Mucles, by the maller Fibers. It is therefore fale, that when the Fat is conumed by fating, the Skin ticks to the Mucles no otherwie, then a Ball to a peice of cloth wherewith it is covered. It ticks motOriginal. firmly to the Back, in fahion of a Membrane, and therefore it is aid to arie from thence. In the former part of a Mans Neck and his Forehead, it can hardly be eparated from the Skin and the Muculus latus; it ticks o cloe, and is thought to contitute the Muculus latus.

The Surface thereof is lippery, there where it touches the Mucles, by reaon of that clammy Humor, which is wont to be daubed upon the Membranes, leat the motion of the Mucles hould be hindred. It is of exquiite ene; and therefore if it be twitched by a harp Humor, it caues hivering and haking, as by Choler in Agues.

The proper Membrane of the Mucles, The Membrane of the Mucles what? which ome will have to pring from the Pericranium or Periotium, others from the nervous Fibers of the Mucles, is thin, and is knit unto the Mucle, by mot thin filaments.

Its Ue is 1. To cloath the Mucle
<…> Ue. and eparate them one from anothe • 2. To impart unto them the Sene of <…>

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Mucles in General.
div.p: A Mucle is termed in Greek Mus a Moue, becaue it reembles a flaid Moue; and the Latins cal it Lacertus a Lizard, from its imilitude with that Creature: Howbeit we cannot allot one certain figure to the Mucles, by reaon of their variety.

A Mucle is an Organical Part, the Intrument of voluntary motion. ForWhat a Mucle is? only this part can receive the Iuflux of the motive faculty. Helmont allowes the mucles a life peculiar to themelves, which continues for a while, even after death, as the convulive motion in the Falling-icknes which continues involuntarily. Which nevertheles does more truly arie, from the retraction and drines of the Nerves, and defect of Spirits. Alo the ame man is in an error in conceiving that new fibres do arie in the mucles, and caue the Palie. No man ever aw them, nor can they be bred anew, becaue they are Spermatick parts. The Palie ought rather to be referred to a defect of ome fibres.

A mucle is an Organical part, becaue it conits 1. Of fleh. 2. OfA Mucle is an Organical part. a tendinous part (and thee are the two parts of a mucle, which perform the Action) 3. Of Veins to carry back the Nutriment. 4. Of Arteries preerving the inbred Heat, and bringing the Nourihment to the part. 5. Of Nerves, which contribute ene and epecially motion. For the Brain ends the motive faculty through the Nerves into the Mucles. 6. Of Membranes which encompas and keep the mucles together. 7. Of Fat which moitens them, and hinders them from being dried by over much motion.

The Mucles of the whole Body are mot traitly conjoyned one withThe Connexion of the Mucles of the whole Body. another: Yet ometimes they gape, and are at ome ditance, when Wind, wheyih Humor, or ome other matter gets between them; as in the batard Pleuriie, and concerning a Soldier whipt by the Turks. Velingus told me that his mucles were o widened and eparated, that if he bent his body but a little, every mucle would bear it elf out from its Natural ituation, bunching out as it were, and welling.
We divide the Mucles into two parts, a flehy part, and a tendinous part.The Parts of a Mucle only two. The tendinous Part how many fold.
Again, we make the tendinous part to be either united, or digregated, and evered.
United, where the whole tendinous part appears, white and hard, either in the beginning, end, or middle; or in all thee parts.

Contrariwie it is digregated or evered, where it is divided into many mall fibres, carce dicernable to the ight, being compaed about with fleh which tendinous fibers may notwithtanding be dicerned among the flehy ones, in boyled Hogs-fleh, and in the fleh of a Turkey-cock, &c. So in ome Mucles, epecially <…> of the Thighs of a Turkey-cock, the tendinous <…> appear whole and united from the beginning to <…> . So in a man, omtimes the Tendon decends <…> after its Original, mixe • with fleh. Somtimes the tendinous part appears, united in the end, and evered in the beginning, as in the mucle Deltoides; omtimes it is tendinous in the middle, and omtimes not at all.

With Aquapendent we define aWhat the Tendon of a Mucle is? Tendon to be a Body continued from the beginning to the end of a Mucle, and that it is a body of a peculiar Nature, cold and dry, madeIts Beginning. of Seed, as the principle of its Generation: But the beginning of its dipenation is a bone, for it prings from a bone, and is inerted or implanted into a bone. Yet ome Mucles arie from Gritles, and ome from Tendons, and are implanted into them. AndWhy called Tendo? it is rightly termed Tendo, from tretching, becaue it is bent and tretched like the tring of a bow.
A Mucle is otherwie divided into the Head, middle, and End.

The Reginning and Head of a Mucle, The Beginning and Head of a Mucle. when it is tendinous, is by Galen and other Anatomits, called Ligamentum, which they ay is void of Sene, and that it is les then a Tendon, or the end of a Mucle.

Now the beginning in a great part of Mucles, is tendinous, eldomBoth the beginning and end of a Mucle may be called a Tendon. flehy. And to peak the very truth, the beginning may as well be termed a Tendon, as the end; eeing for the mot part, uch as is the Beginning, uch is the End, in Subtance, in Thinnes, Lightomnes, Whitenes, &c.

Now every Mucle is aid to move towards its beginning,Two things obervable touching the beginning of a Mucle. and every Mucle hath a Nerve, which is inerted either into the Head, or about the middle (and in ome through the Surface of the mucle, in others through the Subtance) o that where the Nerve is implanted, there is the Head of the Mucle: Which Galen laies down asGalens Rule. a ure Rule, and aith; that if the Nerve be implanted into the Tayl, there is the Head of the mucle. ButDiliked by Walaeus; and why? Johannes Walaeus an excellent learned Phyitian, likes not this Rule, and conceives that it is all one, whether the Nerve be inerted into the beginning, the middle, or the end. 1. Becaue that Rule renders the motions of many mucles obcure. 2. Becaue it holds not true in the Pectoral mucle, nor omtimes in other mucles of the Chet and Belly. 3. Becaue that Rule is not founded upon any reaon, for whether the Nerve be inerted into the beginning of the mucle, or into any other part thereof, the Spirits flowing in by the Nerve, may equally move the mucle: As we ee in Wind-Intruments, the Air is let in omtimes above, omtimes beneath, one way as conveniently as another. 4. And whereas that Rule is oftentimes found true, it happens by accident, becaue motmucles are moved upward, & becaue the Nerves decend from above, and therefore could not be more afely implanted any where, then in the upper part of the mucles. And that which Riolanus objects againtThe Objection of Riolanus anwered. Walaeus, touching the Contorion or Wreathing of the recurrent Nerve, is nothing. For the Nerves run back, to avoid confuion, otherwie, if Nature chiefly intended the Inertion into the Heads of Mucles, he might
have carried them right out into the Larynx, as he doth other Nerves of the ixt Pair. Some Mucles receive two branches of Nerves, as the Midrif; ome five, as the temporal Mucle.

The Middle of the Mucle, which they call the belly or body, doth for theThe middle of a Mucle. mot part well, and is flehy; ome few have a tendon in the middle, as the Muculus Digatricus which opens the nether Jaw, and the econd Pair belonging to the Os Hyoïdes.

The end or taile of a Mucle, is by ome called Tendo by others Chorda, and Aponeurois. The end of a Mucle how known by Galen and other Anatomits? And the end is omtimes round, omtimes broad, omtimes long, other whiles hort; omtimes one, otherwhiles more then one. Now this end, or tendon, is commonly conceived to be made up of a Concoure of Fibres, Ligaments, and very mal Nerves, which by little and little grow into one Body. For they will have a Nerve, when it comes to the place of a Mucle to be divided into divers lips, which are met by a Ligament, cleft after the ame manner. Conequently they Determine.

1. That the Tendon hath the ene of Feeling, but not theWhether the Head of a Mucle be void of ene? Head, which they account void of ene and Motion. But this is fale; becaue the tendinous head of a Mucle, when it is prickt, breeds Convulions and cruel Symptomes, jut as if the Head of the Mucle were prickt. Moreover, the beginning of a Mucle hath motion, and therefore ene. It hath motion, becaue a Mucle, even in itsIf it have Motion? Head, is contracted and expanded, epecially when it is flehy.
2. They ay alo that the End is thicker then the Head: which notwithtandingWhether the end be thicker then the Head. is omtimes true and omtimes fale, as in the Muculous Biceps, and others.

3. They will have the Tendon to be ofter then the Ligament (as they call it) or the beginning of the Mucle, namely o much ofter, as it is harder then a Nerve, But the contrary is true, viz. that the Tendon is harder then the beginning, becaue it many times changes into a boney and gritley ubtance, as in the feet of feathered fowle; but the beginning doth not o. Moreover, I deny that Nerves enter into the Tendon. For Aquapendent Whether the Nerves go into the Tendon. and Riolanus have oberved, by frequent diections, that when they are entred into the fleh of the Mucle, they are pread out into many little branches, which go into a certain Membranous flexure, and o vanih or end, before they come to the tendon. Moreover, a Nerve is oft, how therefore can it be mingled with an hard body? Neither is the end les detitute of ene, then the Head, eeing there come no more Nerves to it then the other: for the Nerve being implanted, tends downwards, and not upwards.
The Action of a Mucle is voluntary Motion.The action of a Mucle is Motion.

The Motion of a Mucle, is threefold, 1. A Mucle is contracted within it elf, towards the Head; and when this is done the oppoite Mucle is relaxed and looned. 2. Being contracted, it continues o. And thee two motions are primary, per e and not accidental. 3. After contraction it is relaxed which motion is accidental, and proceeds from another. And therefore Mucles are alwaies et one againt another, as Antagonits.

Now the work of this Motion or Action, which is een in the parts whereinto the Mucles are planted, doth vary according to the Variety of Parts. For in the throat it is wallowing; in the Arme bending and tretching forth, &c. Yea and omtimes one follows upon another. For the Mucles of the Chet, when they act, do diverly widen or contract the ame, they draw in Air, or expel Fuliginous ooty vapors, and caue Repiration.

This Motion of the Mucles, is omtimesAnd that Voluntary. called Voluntary, omtimes Animal, to ditinguih it from the natural, in Brutes Spontaneous. For we can haten, or lacken, or top this motion as we pleae. And in this motion, the will of a Man or the Appetite of Brutes, is like an Horeman guiding and putting his Hore forward; the Nerves reemble the Reins of the Bridle, and the Mucles are like the Hore. There are ome ingular Mucles, as of the inide of the Eare, the Midrif, the Mucles of the Chet, and Eye-lids, whoe motion is partly voluntary and partly natural, becaue they many times perform their actions, when we have no thought nor will thereto.

The ue of all the Parts of the Mucle, isThe ue. after the ame manner, as in every perfect Organ. For 1. There is that by which the action is primarily and of it elf performed, and it is the Fibrous fleh; [but epecially according to the Fibres, for the fleh being wounded according to the length of the Fibres, the motion remains unhurt, but it is not o when the fibres are wounded] for the mot part the belly of the Mucle which is mot of all contracted. Hence it is that if you cut a Mucle of in the beginning end or middle, in a living peron, or in one that is dead it pures it elf round and draws it elf into it elf like a ball: as alo it doth, being cat into the water. Riolanus counts the principal part to be the tendon, upon which the Action depends, becaue it hath a peculiar ubtance of its own, uch as is no where to be een out of a Mucle. But this is rather true of fibrous fleh, which is in all Mucles, where as in ome there is no tendon. 2. That without which it cannot be performed as the Nerve: For if the Nerves be hurt the Mucle looes its motion. 3. That by which it is more trongly and better performed, as the tendons and tendinous fibres. Wherefore thoe Mucles only, which perform continualWhich Mucles do move more trongly? and trong motions, have received united and Conpicuous tendons. For the Mucles do either move themelves only, as thoe of the Fundament and Bladder; or they move alo the skin, as in the Lips, forehead and face: and in thee there is no tendon to be een or they move a bone, and thee for the mot part evidently end in tendons, becaue the trong motion of an heavy member did require as much: or they move ome other light thing, as the Mucles of the tongue and Larynx (ome of which have tendons and ome not) of the Eyes, Stones and Yard. 4. Such parts as conerve and guard the action, as the Veins and Arteries, the Membranes and fat.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the Mucles of the Belly, or Abdomen.
div.p: THoe which are called Muculi Abdominis, the Belly-mucles, do cover the lower Belly, and Galen reckons as many, as there are poitions of fibres; right, tranvere, oblique, and thee either upwards or downwards. So that according to Galen there are eight, four on each ide; two oblique decendents, or external oblique ones, two oblique acendents or internal ones, two right and two tranvere: But Maa found out two others, and after him Fallopius, which they term Pyramidal Mucles, others Fallopian Mucles, and Sylvius calls them Succenturiatos. And o hither Anatomits have made thee mucles ten in number. Caerius accounts the right Mucles to be many, and that rightly; eeing there are for the mot part four of them on each ide; and o for the mot part.

div.p: there are ixteen Mucles of the Belly for the mot part, at leat and eldomer fourteen, when there are only three right Mucles on either ide; omtimes eighteen, when there are five right ones found, on each ide. Fontanus found them all, folded and wrapped up in an Embryo or imperfect birth.

The firt Pair obliquely decendent, [or the external] o called by reaon of the Fibres, which decend obliquely from the upper to the lower part; covers all the Abdomen, on its own ide, eeing it is very great and broad.

Its original is in the breat, from the lower part of the ixt, eventh and eightThe Original of the oblique decending Mucle. Ribs, before they end in Gritles; and it aries from undry triangular beginnings, or pires, [near the great awhap'd Mucle of the Bret] which afterward grow into one. And to every triangular pire, from the paces between its Ribs, and Nerve is carryed. Moreover, it aries alo [a mal pace being interpoed] from the point of the tranvere procees of the Vertebra's of the Loyns. So largly is the beginning thereof pread out, namely from the ixt Rib to the lowet Vertebra of the Loyns.
It ends in the middle of the Abdomen, where a white line appears, and it ends intoIts End. a large Tendon, an infinite company of oblique Fibres running together in that place.

Now the white Line, which is omtimesWhat the white Line is? fringed with fat, is the meeting together of the Tendons of the Mucles of the Belly, aving thoe of the right mucles. For the Tendons of the oblique mucles are united. and do o meet form both parts, that they form as it were a coat which covers the Belly, or as if it were but one Tendon.
It is white, becaue void of fleh, proceeding from the Mucronata Cartilago or pointed Gritle which is eated at the Sharebone: and it is narrower below the Navil then above.

The two mucles obliquely decendent are bored through. 1. At the Navil. 2. At the Groyn in men, that the eed Veels may pas through; in Women, to give paage to the two round and Nervy Ligaments of the Womb, which are terminated in the Privity near the Nymphes.

Now as touching the Original The Error of Aquapendent and Laurentius, touching the Original of the oblique-decending Mucle. of the obliquely-decending mucle, Aquapendant did long ince hatch a contrary Opinion, which Laurentius did afterwards propound as new, and of his own Invention, reprehending all other Anatomits, who were the aid mierably deceived. Now this contrary Opinion will have thee mucles to be rather termed external Acendents, o that their Original hould be from the upper part of the Os pubis, Os Ilij, and from the tranvere Procees of the Loins: And the end. in the Ribs. They prove it thus:

1. Becaue a mucle ought to arie from ome quiet and immoveableTheir firt Reaon refuted. part, uch as is the Share-bone compared to the Ribs. I anwer, the Ribs are quiet and till, being compared to the white Line.

2. They ay a mucle draws towards its beginning, and becaue the obliquedecendentTheir econd Reaon erves for Repiration, it draws the Ribs towards the Share. I anwer, this mucle doth not primarilyanwered. erve for Repiration, as I hall hew hereafter.Tis proved that thee Mucles arie from above, not from beneath.

Now our Opinion, which is Galens, is proved. 1. By the Ingres of Nerves, which is about the beginning. 2. By the carriage of Fibres, which go here from the beginning to the white Line. 3. All confes that there is a Concoure of Tendons, yea of thoe which obliquely decend, into the white Line. Therefore the End is there. 4. It
