div.p: is proved by the common Action, of which beneath.

The Ue [according to Riolanus, who aith that the Os pubis or Share-bone being moveable, doth move this boney tructure forwards, the Chet reting, or being lightly moved, in the Conjugal Embracement, and in the going of uch as want Leggs and Thighs. But we daily oberve the Belly to be moved, in ingle perons that are chat, nor doth Nature frame Parts to upply unexpected defects of mucles, but for Natural and Ordinary Actions. Spigelius upects, that from the ame moveable beginning, that ame bone is drawn obliquely upward, and enclined toward the Chet, by the help of the mucles.
The econd pare is the OBLIQUELY ASCENDENT [or internal] having Fibres contrarily ituated: It is ituated next the former, and hath a triangular Figure.

Its Original is flehy, from the Rib of Os Ilij: but membranous, bothThe Original of the obliquely acendent Mucles. from the tranvere Procees of the Vertebra's of the Loins, from which it receives Nerves, and from the harp points of Os acrum.

It grows a little by a flehy End, toTheir double End. each of the batard Ribs, and to ome of the true Ribs, but the ret its End turns by little and little into a Tendon, which is double: The one part goes upon the right mucles, the other beneath, o that the right doth ret as it were in a heath, but near the white Line it is reunited, and inerted thereinto. Which Riolanus hath oberved to happen only above the Navil, and not beneath.
The third pare of the right Mucles, by reaon of the right fibres. This pare is commonly reckoned to be but one.

Galen doth rightly make the beginning to be flehy, ariing from theThe Original of the right Mucles. Breat-bone, on each ide of the Sword-fahion'd Gritle, and from the Gritles of the four batard Ribs. It ends in a Tendon at the Os Pubis. Others contrariwie, will have the beginning to be here in the Sharebone, and the End above. But I anwer. 1. That the right Mucles receive their Nerves in the upper part, viz. one branch of thoe Nerves, which were inerted into the oblique decending Mucle, and others alo from the lat of the Back, and from the firt pare of the Loins. 2. A Mucle ues not to have a tendinous beginning, and a flehy End. Other late Anatomits will have the right Mucles to have two beginnings and two ends; one beginning and one end in the Breat, and another in the Share-bones. Who are for this Conceit of theirs, beholden to that new opinion touching the moveablenes of the Share-bone, of which I hall peak hereafter.

The Muculus rectus or traight mucle, hath for the mot part three. IncriptionsThat there are divers right Mucles. in Perons of a middle tature, and omtimes four in tall people, whoe Belly is long. But according to Carpus and Caerius, we ay that uitable to the multitude of Incriptions, there are more mucles, becaue 1. To every Joynting there comes a Nerve. 2. If it were but one, being contracted into itelf, it could not equally compres all parts. 3. There hould be no uch mucle in the whole body, wherein nevertheles there are many long ones, without uch a number of Incriptions.
In the internal Surface of the right mucles, there are two Veins conjoyned, with as many Arteries.

The upper called Mammaria, arie from the Vena cava, lying beneath theThe Veins. Claves, the more remarkeable branch whereof reaches unto the Duggs, and runs out under the right Mucle, as far as to the Region of the Navil, where it is terminated.

This is met by the other termed Epigatrica, which in Women prings from the Womb, in men the Vena cava goes upwards towards the upper Vein, which before it touches, it is for the mot part obliterated. Yet thee two Veins are omtimes joyned together by manifet Anatomois, touching one another, at their ends. Hence the Conent is uppoed to arie between the Duggs and the Womb, the Belly and the Notrils. For when the Noe bleeds, we fix Cupping-glaes to the belly, and the Duggs of Women being handled, it in cites them to Venery.
The Muculi recti receive Arteries from the Epigatrica Artery, and Nerves whichThe Arteries and Nerves. proceed from the lat Vertebra's of the Chet.

The proper ue of thee Mucles according to Riolanus, is to move the Share-bone forward in Generation, which hath been already confuted. Spigelius will have them to draw the Breat to the Oa pubis or harebones, and the Share-bones to the Breat, in a traight motion, and o to bend the Chet; whence it is, that in Dogs and Apes, they reach as far as to the Jugulum, becaue their Chet did require very much bowing. But thee contrary motions, unles they be holpen, with thoe inciions of the right mucles, do involve a difficulty. Helmont upects that they are tretched in going up hill, and that from thence hortnes of breath proceeds. Flud aith, that by a general ue, they make the Belly round, and compres it centrally, or towards the middle point thereof.

The fourth pare called the Pyramidal The Pyramidal Mucles. Mucles, do ret upon the lower Tendons of the Muculi recti. Nor are they parts of the right Mucles, as Vealius and Columbus think; but ditinct mucles, as Fallopius proves with reaons, which are partly convincing, partly vain. But that they are peculiar mucles is hence apparent. 1 Becaue they are cloathed with a peculiar membrane. 2. Their Fibres are different from thoe of the Muculi recti.

They rie with a flehy beginning,Their Original. not very broad, from the external Share-bone, where alo the Nerves do enter; and the farther they go upwards, the narrower they grow, till they terminate with a harp point, into the Tendon of the tranvere Mucle. And from this place I have oberved more then once, a mall and round Tendon produced, as far as to the Navil.
Riolanus hath oberved the left Pyramidal Mucle to be leer then the right, and when there is but one, it is oftner left then right.

The Ue of the Pyramidal Mucles, isTheir Ue. to ait the right mucles, in compreing the Parts beneath. Hereupon according as the Tendons of the right mucles are more or les trong. o, ometimes the Pyramidal mucles are wanting (though rarely) omtimes they are trong, otherwhiles weak, and omtimes there is but one. Bauhine aith If they are abent, then either the fleh joyned to the Heads of the right ones [which I have often oberved] or the Fat performs their Office. And others will have them to be as it were certain Coverings of the right mucles.

Fallopius will have the Pyramidal <…> to compres and queez the Bladder, when •… e Water, that the Urin may be forced out. Con •… wie Aquapendent will have it, that they raie and lift themelves up, and together with them the Abdomen and Peritonaeum,
that the parts beneath them, may not be too much burthened. Now Columbus charges Fallopius, that he would have thee mucles erve to erect the Yard, whereas that is Maa his Opinion [whoe Opinion is followed by Flud, becaue of the ituation of thee Mucles] but they cannot erve for that intent, becaue they reach not the foreaid part, and becaue they are found likewie in Women.

The fifth pare called the Tranvere Mucles, being lowet in ituation, doThe tranvere Mucles. arie from a certain Ligament which prings out of the Os acrum, and covers the Muculus acrolumbus, alo from the lowet Rib, and the Os Ilij. They end by a membranous Tendon, into the white Line, and do tick extream fat to the Peritonaeum, every where ave about the Share. The proper Ue of thee Mucles, is to compres the Gut Colon.

The Action of all the Mucles of the Belly, is as it were twofold. <> An equableThe Action of the mucles of the Belly. Retenion and Compreion of the Parts in the Belly: For •… y all act together, the Midriff aiti •… em, and this is the reaon why the Fibres of all th •… s, do meet together in one and the ame C •… ing as they are thus decribed by Robert E •… .

2. The Second Action <…> vs upon the former, viz. the •… dance ofWhy there are divers mucles of the Belly? Excrements. And becaue the number of parts to be compreed is great, as the Guts, Womb, Bladder; one Mucle could not uffice, but there was need of divers, acting in divers places, according to divers Angels: Right, tranvere, oblique. Every part indeed hath an expulive Power;A Praeoccupation. but thoe parts which are hollow, and often, and much burthened, do need the help of thee mucles; as in the Expulion of Excrements, of Worms, of Urin, of a Child, of a Mole, &c.

Thee are their true Actions, which are apparent from their Fabrick. ButA Secondary action of the mucles of the Belly. Nature omtimes abues the mucles, to move the Chet, when there is need of a great and violent Expiration, as in Outcries, Coughs, and the like. For then they do not a little compres the Chet.

Their Ue. They are of an hot and moit Temperament. becaue fleh is prevalent in them: And therefore they cherih Heat and Concoction: They are moderately thick; and therefore they defend the Parts, and are a Safeguard to them, even when they ret: Alo they conduce to the Comlynes of the Body: And therefore extream Fat, dropied Perons, uch as are very lean, &c. are deformed.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Touching the Peritonaeum.
div.p: ALl the Mucles of the AbdomenPeritonaeum, how o called? being removed, the Peritonaeum comes in ight, being pread over the Guts, and having its Name a circumtendendo, from tretchin •… ading about, becaue it is drawn over all <…> , which are between the Midriff and the Thighs.
Now the Peritonaeum is a membrane which doth cloath the Bowels of the lowerWhat it is? Belly.

It is a membrane, and that ufficiently thin and oft, that it may not be burthenom; but trong and compact, that it may be looned and ditended. It is thicker in Women, from the Navil to the Share, that it may tretch the more, when they are with Child; in men that are great Feeders epecially, it is thicker from the Mucronata Cartilago, to the Navil, Laurentius conceives for the Stomachs ake, which notwithtanding is hardly probable: for it was fit the lower part hould be thicker, leat while we tand, it hould become lackned and looned by the weight of the Bowels.
Some will have the Peritonaeum to be made of a ligamentous and nervous Subtance; others of Nerves only; others only of Ligaments; others of the Coats of the Brain.

The Shape of the Peritonaeum is oval:The Shape of the Peritonaeum. For it is like a Bladder, or a long-fahioned Egg. For it compaes all the lo
••• Belly, and therefore it is anwerable •… unto in Longitude and Latitude.

Its Surface is inwardly mooth, andIts Surface.
<…> were daubed with moiture, by reaon of the Guts which it toucheth; without it is fibrous, and a little rough, that it may be fatned with the mu
•… .
Its Original is at the Back-bone, at theOriginal. firt and third Vertebraes of the Loins, where the Peritonaeum is thicker; o that it cannot in that place be eparated without breaking.

It is knit alo above mot cloely toConnexion. the Diaphragma (and therefore when it is inflamed, the Hypochondria are drawn upwards) beneath to the Share-bone and the Os Ilij; before, to the white Line and the Tendons of the tranvere mucles.

Now it is in al places double (and Laurentius It is double. with Cabrolius make al Membranes double, even the pia Mater it elf) which notwithtanding is mot apparent upon the Back-bone, above the Navil it ticks o cloe, that its doublenes cannot be •• eerned: But from the Navil to the Share, it is manifetly divided into two Coats, o ditant, that in their capacious doubleing the Bladder is contained, which hath been oberved by few: And that was o ordered. 1. That the membrane might be tronger there, where it is burthened. 2. That the umbelical Veels, which run out there, may be carried more afely: For they pas through the Doublings of the Peritonaeum. Therefore alo.

The Peritonaeum is boared through before in a Child which is in the Womb: Alo above it hath holes, where it grows to the Diaphragma, for the paage of the Veels. Fernelius hath thereforeThe Error of Fernelius. How many Holes there are? done ill to contradict Galen, in denying that the Peritonaeum hath Holes. They are three; The firt where Vena cava paes through; The econd where the Stomach paes; The third where the great Artery and the Sixt pare of the Nerves do pas through the Midriff. Beneath about the Fundament, the Neck of the Bladder and Womb, and the Veels which pas through the Peritonaeum to the Thighs, the Mucles of the Abdomen and the Skin.

It hath two oblong Procees or Productions,Its Productions. like Pipes and wide Channels, decending in men, into the Cod, by the Holes of the Tendo • s of the oblique and tranvere mucles, in which productions (call'd by the Ancients Didymi) the Seminary Veels decend and run back, and near the Stone Thee productions are more widened and become the Coats of the Teticles.

Whereof, if the outer Coat be widened, and the inner (which ticks motThe Caue of a Rupture. exactly, ave by the Share-bone, where it is eparated) broken, a Rupture is made, according as the Gut or Call, or both, lip down.

It receives Veels from the neighboring Diaphragmatick, Mammary, andIts Veels. Epigatrick Veels, and omtimes from the Seminary. It receives mall Nerves, from thoe which are carried to the mucles of the Abdomen. And therefore the Peritonaeum hath the Sene of Feeling, contrary to what others have thought before Vealius, againt whom Experience alo bears witnes.

The USE of the Peritonaeum, is the ame with that of membranes in general. 1. ToIts Ue. contain the parts, and to end Connexions here and there. This the Peritonaenm doth mot of all: for it coversIt is the mother of the Coats in the lower Belly. all the Bowels of the lower Belly, and makes them more firm; lengthens out, and betows a Coat upon all of them, to ome a thinner, as need requires, and to others a thicker, as to the Stomach, Guts, Bladder, and

div.p: Womb. Alo from it proceed two doubled members, the Call and the Meentery. This alo, is an Office of the Peritonaeum, that Veels which are to be carried a great way, do run along between the two Coats thereof.

2. To hut the Orifices of the Veins. Hence the Liver, if it were not covered with a membrane, the mouths of its Veins would come into veiw. Hence alo thoe parts in which there are more Arteries, have received a thicker Membrane, as the Spleen. 3. To further the actions of the Mucles of the Belly; out of Galen.

div.head: Chap. VIII. Of the Call.
div.p: UNder the Peritonaeum is the Call as itThe Etymologie of the Call. were a Covering, others name it Zirbus, Rete or Reticulum, by reaon of the tragling coure of the Veels; the Greeks term it Epiploon the Top-wimmer, becaue it floates and wims as it were upon the Guts. For in all Living-Creatures it is.

It is ituate at the Liver, Spleen, andIts Situation Bottom of the Stomach, and from thence pred upon the Guts, whoe turnings it involves and enters into. In ome it ceaes at the Navil, in others it reaches below the Navil, and omtimes to the Os Pubis where it is inferted: [Somtimes it is joyned to the Womb with a traitIts Connexion. Connexion, as the rarely learned Marcus Aurelius Severinus found at Naples in a Shee-Fool; and in another it was knit to the bottom of the Womb in Venice when I was there] and when it comes between the bottome of the Bladder and of the Womb, the mouth of the Womb is thought to be compreed, and Women thereby madeThe caue of Barrennes. barren. In men an Epiplocele is caued, when it decends into the Cod. And becaue it is extended rather unto the left then the right ide, therefore an Epiplocele of the left ide is more frequent. Epiplocele is a Rupture in which the Call falls into the God.
Many times the Guts being left naked,Its ituation in perons trangled. the Call lies lurking under the Liver, which happens not from trangulation,

p.U: eeing in trangled perons, tis found in its right place, and in perons not trangled, we find it drawn back; but if we may credit Spigelius, it comes from the Guts being puffed up with wind. In Hydropical perons I have found it quite putrified. C. Stephanus unjutly denies it to hunters.

div.p:
Infants, if we believe Riolanus In Infants. are dititute of a Call over their Guts, which as they grow is pread out downwards, and in declining <…> it is again diminihed. •… t hath two ditinct Originals from the PeritonaeumIts Origina. and is as it were a doubled Peritonaeum. 1. It aries at the tomach, viz. the bottome thereof. 2. At the Back and Gut Colon; and no beginning cleaves to another. Hence it hath twoIts Parts. Walls or two Membranes, thin and light (that they may not be troubleome with their weight)
which lie one upon another: the external or former, which is tied to the outer membrane of the tomach at the bottom, and to the bunching part of the Spleen. The inner and latter, which is tied to the Gut Colon, and aries from the Peritonaeum, under the Midriff, jut at the Back. And between thee Walls, it hath a remarkeable Cavity: in which ome very foolihly conceive the Natural pirit is contained. Riolanus will have it propagated from aRiolanus refuted. production of the Meentery, becaue if you eparate the Membranes of the Meentery, you may proceed as far as the Gut Colon; which he proves in another place, out of Hippocrates. But in vain, eeing the Meentery it elf, prings from the Peritonaeum, and he confees the fourth part only of the Call to be Meenterical.
The Figure thereof reembles that of a Falconders pouch, for the upper OrificeIts Figure. thereof is Orbicular, and the lower part of the Call is round after a ort, and omtimes unequal.

The magnitude thereof varies: for it paes in ome men to the Navil, in others itIts Magnitude. goes further, as was aid before. Naturally it hardly exceeds the weight of half a pound, Riolanus oberves. Howbeit Vealius aw a Call of five pounds weight.

The Call hath this property above ootherIts Veels. •
membranes, that through the ubtance thereof, very many Veins and Arteries are prinkled, from the Caeliacal and Meenterical branches; and mal Nerves from a double branch of the ixt Pair. And by reaon of the many Veins, there is much Fat in the Call: and between the ame innumerable Kernels are interpoed, which uck in and feed upon the dreggy humors. Which Fat I have often oberved to have been molten in uch as have been ick of Conumptive Feavers.

div.p: Tis a mot rare Cae to find the Call perfectly flehy uch as I aw cut out of a Body in the Hopital at Zeyden.

The Ue, 1. By reaon of the plenty of itsIts ue. Fat it helps and cherihes the heat of the tomach, namely of the bottom thereof; for the upper part of the tomach is cherihed by the Liver, reting upon it; alo it cherihes the heat of the Guts, as being membranous and blood-les parts. And therefore, that ame Fencer whoe Call was taken away by
Galen, was eaily hurt by cold, and therefore he alwaies covered his Belly with Wool. The Call therefore is as it were a Pillow to the Stomach, and furthers Digetion. For that is a rare cae which Foretus relates of a young man, and Riolanus of others who lived well enough, after their Calls were taken away: Peradventure their Stomachs were ome other way trengthened, or might be Naturally more trong then ordinary. Otherwie ordinarily, by defect of the Call, Catarrhs, Loonees, Lienteries, Conumptions do arie.

2. The Membranes afford this Ue, that they prop up the Branches of a Vein and an Artery, which go unto the Stomach, Duodenum, and Colon Guts o called, and to the Spleen; alo the Fat grows by benefit of the Membranes.

3. Walaeus uppoes that Branches of Arteries and Veins are attributed in greater quantity unto the Call, then is requiite to breed Fat, and nourih the Call, and that they are there placed, being Branches of Venaporta, that the greater quantity of Blood might return to the Heart.

div.head: Chap. IX. Of the Stomach.
div.p: THe Stomach called Ventriculus, The Stomach, why called Ventriculus? that is a little Belly, is an Organical part eated in the lower Belly, jut under the Midriff, being the Intrument that makes Chyle. Paraeus oberves that it hath through a Wound in the Midriff acended into the Chet, and gone downwards by reaon of the encreae of the Call. But Naturally;

It is eated in the Epigatrium, a place encompaed with no Bones, that itIts Situation. might tretch more eaily, jut under the Midriff, as it were in the middle of the Body, and it rets upon the Back-bone: Now its left ide which is the greater and rounder in the bottom, lies in the left Hypochondrium, to give way to the Liver which lies on the right ide, and that o the Body may be equally as it were poied, and ballanced or trimmed, as the Watermen peak of their boats: Towards the right hand it grows mall by little and little, that the meat may be gradually thrut thither. Whence we gather that it is better for uch as lie down to leep, to lie firt upon their left ide till the Digetion be finihed, and afterwards upon their right, otherwie then is commonly imagined. But in the left ide there is the bottom, where the meat ought to tarry, for being rowled to the right ide, it is nearer paing out. Howbeit in this cae, much mut be allowed to Cutom.

'Tis only one in Number in man, and uch live Creatures as have teeth in bothThe Number of Stomachs in feathered Fowle. their Jaws. Riolanus bath twice oberved a double Stomach in a man, continued, but ditinguihed by a narrow paage out of one into another. Sperlingerus aw the ame in a Woman of Wittemberg and Helmontius aw a bag full of tones which grew to the Stomach. Yea, and that it hath been double in one that chewed the Cud, as Salmuth relates and others, is not to be doubted. In ome Fowls there are two Stomachs, the one membranous, which the Latins term Ingluvies the Crap, which only receives the meat, that from thence being lightly digeted, they may cat it into the mouths of their young ones, whereas otherwie young Birds could not be nourihed. The other is very flehy and hotter, having within a hard Membrane, wherein hard meat is received. Petrus Catellus a rare man, adds a third, which is in like manner flehy. In Beats that chew the Cud, and have Hornes, and teeth only in one JawIn Beats that chew the Cud. there are four; The firt Venter, the Reticulum, the Omaus, and the Abomaus; of which Aritotle peaks. The Venter and the Reticulum which is a part thereof, are ordained to hold the crude meat; The Omaus receives the Food immediately from the mouth, if it be thin, if thick, it is firt chewed, and from hence after a hort tay, it lips into the Abomaus. Now chewing the Cud, is a econd chewing of the meat in the mouth, for the more perfect Digetion thereof, whence the Aliment proves excellent, and for that caue among the Jews, uch as chewed the Cud were counted clean Beats. Chewing the Cud is caued, not as ome think, becaue the meat in the firt Stomach gains uch a quality, that it provokes the Stomach to cat it up; for o in every harp biting of the Stomach, and in all Animals chewing the Cud, would happen againt their Wills: but it depends upon the voluntary Action of the Stomach, which by a ingular membrane, expels what it pleaes, and when it pleaes; as that ome Tospot of Malta, whom I have een, would as he pleaed cat up what ever he had drunk; and others will wallow down the Smoak of Tobacco, and turn it out again. In great Sea-fihes I have oberved a threefold Stomach, as in a Porpice and others; but it grew o together, that there was rather three ditinct Cavities with paages from one to another, three perfect Stomachs.
It hath two Orifices, and both of them in the upper Region of the tomach.Its Orifices. The Symptoms of the Stomachs, Mouth, and why like Heart-paions?

The left is commonly called the upper Orifice, and omtimes ingly the mouth of the Stomach, and omtimes tis termed the Stomach, becaue of its largenes; the Ancients did cal it Cor the Heart, becaue the Dieaes thereof caued fainting Fits and other Symptoms like thoe which happen to uch as are troubled with Paions of the Heart; alo becaue of its mot exquiite ene, and becaue the Heart doth ympathize therewith, both in regard of its nearnes, and they have Nerves proceeding from the ame Branch. This Orifice is greater, thicker, and larger, o that it may admit hard or half chewed meat. Tis ituate at the eleventh Vertebra of the Chet: It hath circular flehy Fibres, that it may by Natural Intinct hut up the mouth of the Stomach, after the meat is received in, leat fumes hould arie, and go into the Brain, and breed Dieaes; and that o Digetion may be more perfectly accomplihed. So we cover it as we do our Seething-pots with a potlid, to keep in the Fumes, and to hinder the meat from falling back into our mouths, when we lie in bed, and tumble this way and that way. Through this Orifice, meats and drinks are received in. And it is but in the Epigatrick Region, and it is more near the Back-bone, then the wordfahion'd Gritle or Cartilago Eniformis: And therefore when it is dieaed, we apply Epithems rather behind then before. Helmont places the eat of the Soul, and the Principle of lifeWhether the Soul be eated in the Orifice of the tomach? in the Stomach, as it were in its central point, o that it governes and rules over the Head and principal Faculties. If you aske him more particularly where it is placed, he will anwer you that it is there after an exorbitant manner, centrally in a point, and as it were in the middle of an Atome of the thicknes of one Membrane. But the Stomach cannot be
the Seat of the Soul, becaue. 1. It is alwaies full of impure meats. 2. No Faculties flow to us from thence. 3. Great Feeders and perons of large Appetite, hould have more Soul then other people. 4. The Soul is not fixed to any Centre. 5. When the Stomach is hurt, death doth not preently follow, as appears in him that wallowed the knife. And any dammage happen, it is by reaon of the Nearnes of the Heart, and Community of Nerves, and conequently by accident. For the Soul ticks not in the Nerves primarily; but there rather from whence the Nerves have their Original and it is a common Membrane. Yet in a large ene, it may be called the Principle of Life, becaue there is the Seat of Appetite, and the firt Reception and Digetion of Aliments, whoe fault in the following Concoctions, is never amended. Now it rules over the Head, by reaon of the Conent of the Membranes, and the mot undoubted ariing of Vapors.

The right Orifice, commonly called the lower, is as far from the bottom,The right Orifice, called Pylorus. well near, as the left: It is narrower, and abides hut until the Digetion of the meat be finihed, that is to ay until the meat be turned into a liquid Cream, or Poet as irwere. HowbeitIt is opened in the Ditribution of Chylus. Walaeus hath oberved, that it may and doth let out the more liquid meats, and uch as are of eaie Digetion, by peicemeal before the ret, which may eaily be done by opening it elf a little way, o that the thicker and undigeted meats cannot pas through, as Riolanus objects, eeing they cannot pas through a narrow chink: This Walaeus I ay oberved in his Diertion of Living Creatures. Helmont affirms that in Vomiting, it is hut upwards towardsIt is hut omtimes, and opened in Vomiting. the Pylorus, becaue it is inconvenient to Health, that the faculent matter of Vomits hould pas downwards. Yet he grants that it is ometimes opened between the firt and other Vomits, when omwhat acends out of the Guts. And the truth is, that it is alo open to noxious Humors, Lienteries doth witnes, and other fluxes of the Belly, Mierere mei, and other Dieaes, which pas and repas through the Pylorus. The ame Peron beleives that it remains hut after Death, which doth, I conceive no otherwie happen, then as other parts are then tiff with Cold. It is a little

div.p:
bowed back, and hath tranvere Fibres, and a thicker Circle cat about it (others call them Glandulous Putles) like an Orbicular or Sphincter Muce [ome call it by the Name of a Valve, though it be eldom o cloely hut, but that both Dung and Choler, and other things do ever and anon acend. But the Chylus by a Natural propenion, affects to go downwards, nor doth it go the other way, unles compelled] It is called the Pylorus or Porter, becaue it lets out the Chyle: It may be exceedingly dilated, evenIt is omtimes exceedingly widened. as alo the left. Hence it is that many examples tetifie,
how that very great things have been wallowed down, and voided out by Vomit, and by Stool; as Goldrings, Nut-hels, mall Knives, Pebble-tones, peices of Iron, Frogs, Lizards, Serpents, whole Eels, Pipes, Coins, &c. The Pylorus rules over all the inferior parts, accordingWhether the Pylorus have any Rube over the inferior Parts? to the Opinion of Helmont, being Moderator of Digetion: From the Indignation whereof, he fetches the caue of the Palie, and Swimming Dizzines of the Head; and aith that a Flint having topped the ame, Want of Appetite, and Death it elf followed. Salmuth aw Death caued by the Gnawing and Scirrhous Tumor thereof, which Evils depend upon viriated Concoction, or Digetion hindered.

The tomach hath three orts of Fibres: traight, oblique, & tranvere; which areThe Fibres of the Stomach and their ue. conceived to erve for Attraction, Retention, and Expulion. But ome do peradventure more rightly determine, that the Fibres conduce to firmnes and trength, as when we would have a peice of Cloath trong, we caue more threeds to be woven into it: Epecially eeing many other parts, without thee kind of Fibres do attract, retain, and expel; as the Liver, Spleen, Brain, Stones, Lungs, Duggs. And other parts, as Bones and Gritles, though they have Fibres, yet do they not attract or expel any thing.

The Number of Fibres in the Membranes is uncertain, through the varianceTheir Number. of Authors. That the firt or outmot Coat hath more right Fibres, and the econd more tranvere, is generally agreed upon by mot Anatomits. The doubt is touching the third or inner Coat. Galen, Abenina, Mundinus, Sylvus, and Aquapendens, do allow it only right or traight Fibres. Vealius aies it hath right Fibres towards the Cavity, and oblique in the outward part. Cotaeus allows it only oblique. I with Fallopius and Laurentius, being led by Experience and Reaon, do admit al kinds of Fibres in this Membrane.
The Surface is mooth without, plain and whiteih within, when the tomachThe Surface. doth pure it elf, it appears wrinkled and omwhat reddih.

It hath a triple Membrane: The firtThe Membranes. common and external, pringing from the Peritonaeum, and the thicket of all that have their Original from the Peritonaeum, though otherwie thin enough; which Petrus Catellus conceives doth chiefly concurre in Vomiting. The econd more flehy, which is the middlemot, and hath flehy Fibres to further Concoction. The third is lowet and nervous, into which the Veels are terminated, and it is continued with the Coat of the Oeophagus, Mouth, and Lipps, that nothing may be received in, which • ungrateful to the Stomach, and becaue the meat is prepared in the mouth. Hence it is, that when Choler is in the Stomach, the Tongue is bitter and yellow: And contrariwie the Dieaes of the Mouth and Tongue are communicated to the Oeophagus and Sromach. This Coat is wrinkled, that it may be the better dilated. And it hath its Wrinkles from a flehy Crutines ticking thereunto, the better to defend it from hard meats. This Crut is thought to arie from the Excrements of theThe Crutines in the tomach whence it proceeds? third Concoction of the Stomach: and it is pungy, and hath paages like hort Fibres, from the inner Surface to the outward; that the thinner Chylus may be the better detained till the End of Digetion.

The Subtance therefore of the Stomach being membranous and cold, is holpen by the Heat of the Neighboring Parts. For the Liver lies over the right ide, and middle part thereof; for it lies under the Heart-pit: At the left ide lies the Spleen; it is covered by the fat Call: Under it lies the Pancreas or Sweet-bread; alo near it lie the Midriff, Colon-gut, the Trunk of Vena cava, and of the Aorta.

The Stomach is knit in the left partIts Connexion. to the Midriff (not to the Back-bone) by its Orifice; therefore when it is over full, by hindring the motion of the Midriff, it caues hortnes of breath: On the right ide it is joyned to the Gut Duodenum, by its other Orifice or the Pylorus.

At the Stomach, in the left ide, under the Midriff, is formed a remarkeable Cavity enclood with Membranes, partly from the Stomach, partly from the Midriff, and partly from the Call. Tonching this Cavity, that place of Hippocrates is to be undertood in the 54 Aphorim of the 7. Section. Thoe who have Flegm hut up between the Septum tranverum and the Stomach, which caues pain, and can find no paage into either of the Bellies, when the Flegm paes through the Veins into the Bladder, their Dieae is cured.

The Shape of the Stomach is round andShape. oblong, like a¯ Bag-pipe, epecially if you conider it together with the Duodenum and Oeophagus. In the Fore-part is is equally gibbous or bunching forth; in the Hinder-part, while it lies encloed in the Body, it hath two bunchings, that on the right hand being the les, and that on the left hand the greater, between which lie the Vertebra's of the Back, and the decending Trunk of the Vena cava and the Artery.

Its Magnitude varies; commonly tis les in Women then in Men, thatIts Magnitude. place may be made for the Womb when it wells. For Women are for the mot part leer then men, and yet not more gluttonous then Men, as Aritotle beleives, viz. being of the ame ize and equally healthy; yea, and they are inferior to men in Heat to diget and concoct. Alo in gluttonous perons and great Drinkers, it is greater then ordinary, o that when it wells, it may be felt as it were naked. For it is exceedingly dilated, and therefore it is thinner in Drinkers, in whom it is omtimes o attenuated, that it can no more wrinkle it elf, whence follows long weaknes. Which Walaeus in Diffection hath oberved to happen chiefly to thoe old men, whoe Stomachs in time of Concoction do breed Wind; which oftentimes alo in gluttonous perons, takes up more room then their meat. Columbus will have it, when it is tretched, to reach as low as the Navil, and Archangelus will have it to reach further, when it is over tretched; but being contracted and wrinkled in uch as live oberly, it is thick, and lies hid under the Liver. Now the Largenes of the Stomach is known. 1. By the Greatnes of the Mouth, for thoe that have large Mouths, are great Eaters, but withal bold and magnanimous. 2. If from the Cartilago Eniformis to the Navil, the pace is greater, then that of the Face or Breat.

The weight of the Stomach being dryed with the Oeophagus, according to the Obervation of Loelius is two ounces and two drams; wherein notwithtanding I have found a variety, according to the diverity of ubjects.

It receives very many Veels. Veins, as from the Spleen Vas breve, which is inferted,Veels. not into the mouth but into the bottom thereof, and there ininuating it elf into the tunicles, it
creeps upwards between them, towards the Orifice: but before it reaches the ame, it is obliterated; in ome it is not viible, becaue of its malnes, in ome it is quite abent [and therefore peradventure thoe perons have no good Concoction, or Nature Recompences that defect with other Arteries] in others I have een it flourihing, with manyfold branches. And becaue it is implanted into the bottom of the tomach, and blood emptied there, cannot provoke Appetite, as many imagine. Others will have it that a Melancholick Excrement whichWhether blood cat out of the Spleen help Appetite and Concoction. could not be changed in the Spleen, is by this Veel brought into the tomach, that by its harh and acid faculty, it might further the tomachs Concoction, and make the meats abide therein, a convenient eaon. But Concoction hould rather be hindred, by the cating in of a trange Excrementitious Humor. If we hall interpret it touching an acid fermenting juyce, the Opinion will be truer, which kind of juyce, can come from no other place but the Spleen. For according to the Obervation of Walaeus, the Spleen, epecially of a Sow, being boyled and eaten, as coming nearet that of a man, doth wont to help the heavynes and dullnes of the Stomach. Hence harp things are pleaing to the Spleen, and Hippocrates gives Vinegar to Spleenetick perons, and Celus makes a Cataplam for the Spleen tempered with the harpet Vinegar. Moreover Riolanus hath found the left ide of the inner part of the Stomach blacker then the right. Others uppoe that nothing is carried into the tomach by the Vas breve, but that omwhat is carried out of the tomach into the Spleen; whether it be the thinner part of the Chyle, as Conringius, Hortius, and Regius prove, or Blood as Hogeland conceives; they being informed by Ligature in diections of live Creatures: of which hereafter.
Moreover the tomach receives Veins from Vena Portae, viz. the Pyloric, Gatric, and Gatroepiploic branches left and right.

There is one notable Vein called Gatrica, which creeps a long the bottom of the tomach, but doth not quite touch it leat the tomach being very much tretched, it hould be in danger to be broken; but it preds many branches to the tomach: which Picolhomineus and Aquapendent will have to uck out the more thin and ubtile part of the Chyle, before it paes out of the tomach to the Liver. And this Opinion eems probable. 1. Becaue otherwie no reaon can be given of o udden a paage, eeing they who have drunk much, do preently Pis it out plentifully. 2. Otherwie the tomach would be ready to burt, when it is overcharged. 3. Thence it comes, that trength is o oon repaired by fragrant Wine, broaths, and other comfortable things.

In ome Men a part of the Choler paage, is inerted into the bottom of the tomach, by which our Country-men Petrus Severinus, would have choler to be carried into the tomach. But this is an Error of Nature, and therefore uch perons are apt to vomit Choler, for they are exceeding Cholerick, uch as Galen, Vealius, Fernelius, and Caerius have oberved. Such perons are aid to be Picrocholoi ano, vomiters of Choler.

The tomach receives Arteries from me Caeliaca Arteria, which accompany the Veins, not only for lifes ake, but that blood may be upplied from the Heart, for nourihment, for that the tomach hould be nourihed with Chyle, is a fale opinion and now out of date. Seeing it is nourihed with blood, after the manner of other parts (it is only delighted with the chyle) whichis brought out of the Arteries; which blood flows back again to the Heart, according to the Doctrine of Circulation proved and aerted by the renowned Walaeus in his Epitles. By the Splenic Arteries an acid harp juyce is conveighed into the tomach from the Spleen, as the aid Waloeus and Hogeland conceive, which I grant when there is no Vas breve, or in abence of the Spleen, wherein I eaily conent with Riolanus.

Alo it hath Nerves from the ixt pair,Its Nerves. viz. a couple in its Orifice, from the tomach branches, being produced after it hath run back in the Chet and furnihed the Lungs and Pericardium; which becaue they are oft and go a great way, they are covered with trong Membranes. And they do o cros one another, that they are carried obliquely and conequently with greater afety. The right branch compaes the fore and left part of the mouth of the tomach; the left the hinder and right part thereof. And therefore becaue the Orifice is o compaed with Nerves, as if it were altogether compoed of Nerves • thence it is that this Orifice of the tomach is exceeding enible; for there was to be the eat of Appetite and hunger: even as thoe that are very hungry, do feel that part to be as it were contracted and wrinkled together. Alo branches of Nerves are ent from thee downwards to the very bottom. A branch goes from the left Nerve, a long the upper part of the tomach to the Pylorus, which it infolds with certain branches, and goes to the hollow of the Liver. Other two Nerves alo go unto the bottom of the Stomach, from the branches which run along by the Roots of the Ribs. And therefore it is no wonder, that when the Brain is mitten and hurt, the Stomach is diturbed, and falls a vomiting, epecially in the pain called Hemicranea: As alo that when the Stomach is miaffected, the Animal Faculty languihes.

In the Stomach Fermentation of the Meats goes before Concoction, whichThe Stomachs Fermentation. Hippocrates inculcates in his book de Prica Medicina. Becaue hard things ought to be broken to peices; and thick things as bones and hells, &c. in the tomachs of Beats, eem impoible to be melted by the natural heat alone, unles omwhat ele do cut them in peices. This labor Petrus Severinus attributes to Choler, which nevertheles according to the ordinary Coure of Nature is not found in the tomach, nor does it diolve any hard meat, though Painters ue to temper their colours. De la Chambre attributes it to Spirits, without which it can hardly be performed, Riolanus uppoes that it proceeds from the Reliques of the Chyle, which have attained a fermenting faculty; it concurs indeed, for a fermentative quality may be communicated to any thing: but we mut come to ome firt, thing, by which the Chylus is fermented, and from whence the ferment of the firt meat was derived, before the Reliques of the Chyle could arie. The greater part of Doctors do attribute this whol work to Melancholy, which is carried by the Vas breve into the tomach, and of which Melancholick perons, who are otherwie no good digeters, do often complain by reaon of its harp tat. Which Melancholy if it be undertood of the acid juyce, it may be allowed. For any acid or harp things taken in, as Vinegar, and Meats teeped therein, Juyce of Citrons, Oyl of Sulphure or Vitriol, Cream of Tartar, and the like, do • ae and amend the weaknes of the tomach. Alo without the Body Vinegar ferments the Earth and Milk, even as blackcholer
doth, and the acidity of Vitriol ferments Treacle, and our leven makes the bread arie, &c.

Now Johannes Walaeus requires three things to Concoction, firt omeThree things requiite to Concoction, moiture to temper the meat and make it liquid, viz. Drink and Spittle; in the next place, omwhat to cut and mince it as it were, as the thin harp humor, and latly omwhat to melt and make liquid that which is cut, uch as is heat, wherewith in ravenous beats and ome Men, the chyle is made fluid, though they do not alwaies drink, I hould not doubt, but that the Excrements of the third Concoction, ticking to the Crut, as being till impraegnated with the virtue of the parts nourihed, do give ome aitance to the Concoction, which when they are fretted of, is impared, and o in long fating men are not o able to diget: And that the pittle beides moitening and tempering the meats, doth perform ome other more noble work in Concoction, viz. prepares the meat in the mouth, whereupon it comes to change its mels; and heals Tetters, and either kills or chaes away Scorpions and Spiders.

But what becomes of that acid Juyce, when it hath performed its office of fermentation? H. Regius beleives that it remaines after the expulion of the Chylus, to prick the tomach and provoke Appetite. But hunger is raied in the enible mouth of the tomach, and not in the bottom thereof, where this acid juyce is; alo there would be hunger after the tomach is full. I hould think that it is expelled with the Chyle, and that then it is either therewith turned into blood, or that in obtructions of the Meentery, it goes downwards, and raies diturbance.

The Action of the tomach is Coction which is termed Chylification. For theConcoction is the Stomachs Act. tomach is the Organ of the firt Concoction, the beginning and preparation of which Concoction is performed in the mouth, the middle in the bottom of the Stomach, and the Concluion in the mal Guts. Now this Concoction is performed by heat, notHow it is made. of the tomach only, but alo of the Neighbouring parts; as alo by a faculty which is naturally bred in the tomach of every Animal. Now it turnes the meats into a white Chylus or Juyce, of a like ubtance, whiles both its Oriices being hut very well, it contracts it elf, and cloely embraces the food. But touching the whole manner of Concoction ee the forecited Epitles of Walaeus.

Its ue is to receive the Meat and Drink, which it doth by reaon of itsThe ue of the Stomach. notable and large Cavity. And whereas it omtimes contains and breeds little tones, as Gentilis and Zacutus have oberved, as alo a Toad, Worms, and other things by me often oberved; this is beide the Intention of Nature. And the like we may ay of an Infant conceived and formed there and voided out at the mouth, the Hitory whereof is decribed by Salmuth.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of the Guts in General.
div.p: THe Guts are oblong, round, hollowThe Guts. bodies variouly wreathed about, joyning with the Pylorus and reaching to the Fundament; erving to receive the Chylus and the Excrements of the firt Concoction.

They have their name of Intetina inwards, becaue they are in the inmot eatWhy called Intetina. of the Body [whence Tirtullian cal'd the Croes, the Intetina Trophaeorum, the inwards of the Trophies] and o the Greeks term them Entera; ome have termed them Chordaj, and thence the Barbarians had their term Chordae; for which caue alo the trings of muical Intruments becaue they are made of dried Guts are termed Chordae, Chords.

Their Magnitude in repect of the Contents of their Cavities, and theTheir greatnes thicknes of their ubtance, is different, as hall be hewn hereafter. The weight of all of them dried, is according to the obervation of Loelius, a pound. Their length, for the mot part doth exceed the length of the peron whoe they are ix times, little more or les. Picolhomineus aies they are a foot and half horter; they are reckoned to be even times as long by Laurentius, Paraeus and Riolanus, and before them by Celus, who nevertheles began to meaure from the Oeophagus. Hippocrates aith they are near upon thirteen cubits, or not les then twelve: but the ful tature of a man, hardly exceeds three Cubits and an half. Flud in a certain Body an ell and half long, found the Guts to be but nine ells in length, o that no certain Meaure can be determined. It varies according to the Multitude of the windings, and the greedines of the peron in point of eating.

They have turnings and windings allThe ue of the turnings and windings of the Guts. over ave at the beginning and end, that the Ingres and Egres might not be hindred. Now the reaon why they have thee windings and turnings is. 1. That the nutriment may not lip away, before Concoction be perfectly finihed. Alo leat if it hould preently lip away, before the Chylus be ditributed, we hould be compelled preently to eate more meat, and o hould be hindred from our buines through greedynes of eating. Hence it is that living Creatures by how much the way is treighter from their tomach to their Vent, by o much the more greedy they are of eating; and the more their Guts are coiled, the more abtinent they are: which Cabrolius oberved in a very great eater, who had one only Gut, bowed after the manner of a Greek Sigma. 3. That we might not be continually going to tool, as it is with greedy Animals, eeing the Excrements may lie long in thoe windings.

They are ituate in the lowet Belly, the greater Cavity whereof theyThe • r Situation. fill up, omtimes they are forced to the right ide, as I have een in an Hydropick Woman diected. They are knit together by the Meentery, by which, and the Call coming between, they are tyed unto the Back, and are propped up in the Cavities of the Os Ilij.

They have a membranous Subtance, like that of the Stomach; oTheir Subtance. that they may be ditended by Chyle, Dung, and Wind. But their Subtance is thicker in the thicker Guts: And the nearer they grow to an end, the thicker they are, as the End of the Colon, and the Intetinum rectum.

This Subtance of the Guts may be divided into three Coats: The firt is properTheir Coats. and internal, and is in the mal Guts wrinkled, in the Colon tretched out into little Cells, being otherwie ufficiently nervous. A certain membranous Crut as it were compaes about, bred of the Excrements of the thirdTheir Crut.

div.p: Concoction of the Guts. 1. That the Mouths of the Mearaick Veins may not be topped. 2. That neither they nor the inner Coat might be made hard and callous, by the continual thoroughfare of the Chylus. Alo the econd is proper, and the middle mot, being trong and furnihed with flehy Fibres. The third is common and external, being bred immediately of the Membranes of the Meenterium [ave that where the Duodenum and Colon cleave to the Stomach, it aries from the lower Membrane of the Call] but mediately from the Peritonaeum. Of thee two proper Membranes, the inner is often hurt in a Dyentery or bloody Flux, that other remaining unhurt.

They have Fibres. not only tranvere, as is commonly conceived, but ofTheir Fibres. all kinds: The innermot hath oblique ones. the middlemot hath tranvere ones. The right Fibres which are allotted for the afeguard of the tranvere ones, are fewer in the thin or mall Guts, more in the large, epecially the right or the lat Gut, which was to be trong, becaue it did collect hard Excrements.
The Guts are covered on the outide with Fat, on the inide with a limy notty Subtance, that the Dung may thereby pas more freely, and that the Guts may be duller in point of feeling.

For Veels they have the Venae Lacteae or milkie Veins, which are chiefly ditributedTheir Veels. between the common and proper Membranes, which carry the Chyle to the Liver; and others from the Vena Portae, which are conceived to bring Blood for Nourihment, but they rather carry back to the Liver the Blood which remains after the Guts have received their Nourihment. They have alo Arteries from the Caeliaca for life, which by their motion preerve from purrefaction, but epecially to bring Nourihment from the Spleen to the Guts, which wanted uch kind of utenance. They have Nerves from the ixt pare of Nerves. But Walaeus conceives that the Guts have uch great plenty of Arteries and Veins. 1. That Excrements might be conveighed to the common hore, which are contained in the Veels, whence the Child in the Womb, though it take
no meat in at the mouth, yet hath it Excrements in the Guts. 2. That greater plenty of Blood might be carried through the Vena portae and the Liver, and might come to be perfected by the Liver.

All the Guts are commonly divided, into the thin, or mall, and the thick, orDifference of the Guts. large Guts. For though they make one continued Channel from the Pylorus to the Fundament: Yet becaue this paage doth vary, in Magnitude, Number of Turnings, Subtance, Situation, Figure, and Office, therefore is it ditinguihed into divers Guts.

The thin or mall Guts, o called byWhether the thin Guts may be right aid to be uppermot? reaon of the thinnes of their Membranes, are ituate partly above, partly beneath the Navil; and therefore they poes both the Umbilical Region and Hypogatrium, which is not o in Dogs. Whereupon the Ancients taking Example from Dogs, called the upper Guts thin, the lower thick: which is fale in Mankind. For a Man hath more of the thick Guts above his Navil, and more of the thin Guts beneath; eeing that which is the longet, is beneath; and the Jejunum which is hort is above. And therefore all the mall Guts are in the middle Region about the Navil. 1. Becaue they are the more noble. 2. That they may be the more near to the Centre of the Meenterie, and conequently receive Veins and Arteries immediately from the Meenterie, and quickly conveigh the Blood to the Liver. Now the mall Guts are three: Duodenum, Jejunum, and Ileon. And thee perfect and ditribute the Chyle: In as much as by reaon of their narrownes, every part of the Chylus may be touched, by their Coat and Veels. This Ditribution is holpen by the inbred Peritaltick motion, whereby the Guts are contracted from the upper part downwards.

The Craa Intetina or thick Guts,The thick Guts. are o called, becaue they have thicker Coats; they contain the thick part of the Chyle: And are made to collect, and for a eaon retain the Dung. And they are three; Caecum, Colon, and Rectum. And they are ituate by the ides of the mall Guts, which they wall about as it were, that they might give way to the thin Guts, and that the thin Guts might not be oppreed by the thick.

The Ue of all the Guts is, to be likeTheir Ue. the Earth, out of which the Mearaick Veins uck Blood, and the Venae Lacteae or milkie Veins uck Chyle. And the ue of the thin Guts is, to concoct the Chylus yet more in the paage, and to ditribute the ame. Of the thick Guts to contain the Excrementitious Reliques of the Chyle. viz. the Dung; alo Winds and Choler proceeding from the Liver. A Secundary ue of the Guts being dried, is to cure pains of the Cholick, and other Dieaes of the Guts; and being preternaturally depraved, to contain everal orts of Worms, and Duggs, and Stones; alo variouly to be affected, of which Phyitians are wont to treat.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of the Guts in Particular.
div.p: THe firt thin Gut, under whichThe Gut Duodenum. the Sweet-bread lies, epecially in Dogs, is called DUODENUM. Galen terms it Ecphiis, Herophilus, Dodecadactylon, as if it were jut twelve fingers long; though in the daies and Bodies of ours, it is not found o long; nay it is hardly four fingers long, unles men are grown les of tature then they were anciently, which is not credible. Nor can we undertand the fingers breath, of which this Gut hardly attains to eight, unles peradventure the Ancients did alo comprehend the Pylorus in ther meuring.

It proceeds in the right ide, from the Pylorus towards the Back-bone, or under the Stomach, where being joyned to the Vertebra's of the Loins, by membranous Ligaments, it defends right along, without any Circumvolution, and is terminated, where the Windings and Wreathings begin.

It is thicker then the ret of the thin Guts; but hath a more narrow Cavity, leat the Chylus hould lip in too fat. I aw a large one at Padua, and Aquapendent decribes uch another being puffed with Wind, uch as that was, mentioned by Trafelman, which had in it many Stones as big as Nutmegs, of an Ah-color.

It hath two Holes beneath, towards the Gut Jejunum; the one being theThe Holes of the aid Gut. outlet of the Exoler or Gall-carrying paage, which is the reaon we find it yellow in our Diections, the other is the new paage of the Pancreas or Sweet-bread, invented by Wirungus; which I have notwithtanding ometimes een grow together, and joyned with one only Mouth.
Its peculiar Ue aigned by Helmont, is to change the acid Cream brought out of the Stomach, forthwith into a brackih Salt.
It hath a proper Vein called Vena duodena.
It hath an Artery from the right Branch of the Caeliaca.

The econd is called JEJUNUM, becaue for the mot part it is more empty thenThe Gut Jejunum. the ret, epecially in Diections. 1. By reaon of the plenty and greatnes of the Mearaicks [the milkie Veins] which in that place are as it were infinite, and do preently uck out of the greatet part of the Chyle. 2. By reaon of the moitnes of the Chyle paing through. 3. By reaon of the nearnes of the Liver. 4. By reaon of the Acrimony of Choler. For the cholerick or Gall-paage, enters in at the beginning of this Gut, or at the End of the Duodenum, bringing Choler from the Liver to provoke Expulion.
Its inner Membrane is longer then the Outer, and therefore it is wrinkled into Foles, the better to top the Chyle, lipping by.

Riolanus fally aies that Women have no Jejunum Intetinum, being deceived by thoe, who either were dull-ighted, or finding this Gut filled, thought it could not be the Jejunum. Laurentius oberves, that it appears omwhat reddih, by reaon of the Neighborhood of the Liver.
It hath Veins from the Meenterica dextra, which are common to the ret of the Guts, excepting the lat, or rectum Intetinum, the traight Gut.
It hath Arteries from the upper Meenterick Artery.
Nerves from a Branch of the ixt pare, which is pred out unto the Roots of the Ribs.

The third is called Ileon, becaue it is rouled o and twined, it is alo forThe Gut Ileon. that caue termed Volvulus, by reaon of many Circumvolutions, which make for the tarriance of the Meat, and for that caue it hath fewer pleites or foldings.
It aries preently after the Jejunum, where few mearaick

div.p: Veins are inerted.
It ends at the Caecum.
It is ituate under the Navil, at the Flanks and Hips on each ide.

It is the longet Gut, being near upon twenty one hands breadths in length; it is one finger broad. But the Jejunum is not o long, viz. about twelve or thirteen Handsbreadth long, and the little fingers in breadth, unles it be puffed up with Wind. And as the Ileon is under the Navil, o the Jejunum poees well near all the pace about the Navil, with its very many turnings and windings.

This Ileon may frequently lip into the Cod, whence proceeds the Hernia Rupture of the Guts. Intetinalis, or Rupture of the Guts. And in this Gut happens the Volvulus or Iliaca Paio, in which the Patient commonlyThe Paio Iliaca. vomits Dung.
Riolanus hath oberved omtimes three Appendices in this Gut, reembling the Intetinum caecum

The firt thick Gut is called Caecum. 1. Becaue of the obcure Ue it hath inThe thick Guts. The Gut caecum, or the blind Gut. perons grown up, howbeit in the Infant in the Womb, it is aid to receive the Excrements. Knobleth indeed aith that it hath a double Orifice, evered with a membranous Partition, that by one it may receive from the Ileon, and by the other deliver into the Colon; but we have not yet found this in any man, in whom one and the ame Orifice takes in and gives out. 2. Becaue it hath only one Hole, whence it is alo called Monocolon. For it is a little Appendix like a long Worm, which ariing from the beginning of Colon, and the End of Ilium, of a ubtance ufficiently thick, preds it elf upon the Colon like a twined worm, and is annexed to the Membrane of the Peritonaeum; but by its End, it is joyned to the right Kidneys, the Peritonaeum coming between, and is quite free and looe from the Meenterie.

It is four fingers long, and as broad as ones thumb, but the Cavity thereof is very trait. Riolanus did find it exceeding wide, and equal to the Stoma it elf, as I alo have een it. Sylvius did in many find it olid, without any Follownes, and in uch perons, the Dung
does go immediately from the Ileon into the Colon. And Maa upects that this Appendix is only bred when the Child being from its Birth troubled with a Loones, the liquid Dung paing peedily by the Caecum, and not abiding therein, being frutrated of its Office, it grows lean. Howbeit, I have een it of the ame thinnes in a Child new born.

The Ancients by the Caecum undertoodThe Intetinum caecum, or blind Gut of the Ancients. that globous and capacious part, at the beginning of the Colon, which Celus and Rufus Epheius intimate. For that it was known to the Ancients, contrary to what Laurembergius imagins, I do hence prove, becaue 1. They diected Beats. 2. Pollux and Aritotle have et it down ditinctly. 3. Galen hath ditinguihed it from the Colon, both by Ue and Situation, placing the Caecum on the right Hand, and the Colon on the left.

The Ue of the Caecum is, not to be only for a marke or ign, as Hofman imagines, But firt to receive Excrements, leat they lip down violently into the Colon, and breed pains, and force us to be contiually going to tool. And there ome imagine the Dreggs or Excrements proceeding from cherries and cherrytones, which have been voided orty daies after they were eaten, did lie lurking. The Conciliator contends, that the Dung is here eparated from all chylous Matter. Helmont places the Fermentum tercoreum or turdie Leaven, which turns the Excrements of the Chyle into plain Turds, in this place. 2. It may help omewhat towards the Elaboration of the Chyle, either by ucking out of the white Mearaick Veins ome neglected parcels of Chyle, as Galen aid, or by digeting the inobedient Chylus, which could not be tamed, in the Stomach and mall Guts, by reaon of the multitude of Food taken in, as Zerbus uppoes. 3. It may be intead of a Ligament to utain the Peritonaeum, leat it fall down. But Riolanus oberved this very Gut Caecum in a certain Apothecary rouled to the Groin, and in little Boys into their Cod, in whom it reted upon the Os acrum. Severinus upects that the Reaon why Dogs void their Dung with more then ordinary training, is, becaue the caecum is in Dogs very narrow at the beginning, and a little oblique.

The econd thick Gut is called Colon, from the torment which is omtimesThe Gut Colon. therein caued, by colick pains. Some think tis o called from its Hollownes, and becaue it hapes the Belly. Others derive it from a word ignifying to delay, becaue it gives a top to the Excrements that are in paage. The Author of a Treatie fally acribed to Galen, derives it a colando, from training, becaue it is narrow like a trainner, and involved, that there may be a Gradation of the Excrement, and that it may not decend all at once.

Its Situation is various, for its beginning which is capacious and round, is inIts Situation and Progres. the right Flank, ariing from the caecum at the right Kidney to which it ticks; then it is turned back upwards under the Liver; where it is omtimes knit to the Gall-bladder, and is thereby dyed with a clay-color yellowihnes: It paes further, athwart, under the bottom of the Stomach, and on the left hand is joyned to the Spleen, with thin Membranes, and then it is tyed to the left Kidney, where it hath very crooked Turnings, which are apt to detain both Dung and Wind; and from thence it ends t •… ong, upon the Rectum. Wherefore it doth a •… compas the whole Belly, and omtimes acends, and otherwhile decends (hence uch as do their buines, have commonly one Harvet after another ditinct) that the Excrements may be the longer detained, and not flow out all on a udden, and that we may not every foot be ollicited to go to tool. To which intent alo erve its Magnitude and Cells. For;
It is commonly eight or nine hands-breath in length, and the thicket and widet of all the Guts.

It hath received Cells, that any hard Matter, not before ufficiently digeted, might be perfectly concocted, and at lat through the milkie Mearaicks, which are carried to the Colon, that aid Matter being concocted, might be ent unto the Liver. And that thee Cells might not be diolved, and that being collected into themelves, they might make the Cavities at times, omtimes greater, and omtimes les.

A Ligament decribed by few, or a certain Band, as broad as an half finger, is implanted through the middle thereof, on the upper part long-wie, and ariing from the Caecum, is termined in the Rectum. Moreover by reaon of its largenes; it hath two trong Ligaments, one upwards, another downwards, that it may be tyed to the upper and lower Parts. Riolanus nevertheles accounts thee two Ligaments to be but one, oppoite to the upper Ligament.

According to the Longitude of the Colon, there are extrinecally oberved certain fat Appendices, from the Spleen to the beginning of the Rectum Intetinum, as Riolanus and Spigelius have oberved. Whoe ue is to moiten the Gut, that the Excrements may lide down the more eaily.

At the beginning of the Colon, aA Valve in the Gut Colon. Valve is placed ufficiently thick and membranous, invented by Baubinus, looking upwards, not downwards, as Laurentius writes: for the Excrements do acend and not decend, when they pas out of the Ileon into the Colon, by reaon of upper Situation of the Guts. But if the Natural etling of the Excrements be conidered, they decend making hat out of the Body: And thus Bartholinus and Sperlingerus are reconciled. The firt Invention of this Valve, eems to be long unto Salomon Alberts an Anatomit of Witteberg, as appears in an Appendix to three Orations et forth by him, about the End, and from the Obervations of Schenkius, Lib. 3. Title de Ilio. Howbeit, beides Bauhinus Varolus did alo attribute the Invention thereof unto himelf, who was a well known Anatomit in the Univerity of Padua, in the year 1572. And therefore Riolanus conceives the firt Invention thereof, ought to be attributed rather to him then Bauhinus; But truly, it is in vain that he eeks to bereave him of this commendation, eeing divers Perons may oberve one and the ame thing, at one or undry times, without tealing the Invention one from another. For Nature lies open to all diligent Enquires.
It is found after this manner: WaterHow it is found out? poured or wind blown into the Gut Ileon, cannot pas through unles violently: But Water doth a little mar the Gut.

Touching its Figure or Shape and Number, Authors do not conent. For omitting uch as wholly deny the ame; Bauhinus determines that it is only one, having the figure of a Nail. Archangelus aith, that there are three Valves at the Caecum, as in the Heart, looking downwards. I have ought it at Padua in many Bodies, and at other places, and alwaies found it, but never more then one, and that of an orbicular or circular Shape. Pavius to Hildanus and afterwards Falcoburgius, did not find out a membranous Valve, but rather a Ring or Circle with an hanging brim. But the aid Circle is nothing but a Valve, for ome Valves are
found of a circular Figure, both in the Heart, and in other Veins. The whole contitution of this Valve is elegantly decribed by that great Practitioner Nicholas Tulpius, that it is a Circle on which hangs a Membrane, two fingers broad, and o haped that it is fit to hut the egres of Intetinum Ileum. Before which there hangs a Cortin or lack veile as it were; now the latitude of this Pendulous Membrane is very unequal; for where it looks towards the Ileum, it diffues it elf looely, to the quantity of near two fingers breadth, but the farther from the place it is, the cloelyer it is trait'ned, o that about the middle of the Gut (for o far it runs) it is either quite obliterated, and ends in to that Membranous compas, which inwardly evers the Intetinum Colon a Caeco. From which unequal latitude, there follows necearily that ame circular form, which the value exprees being artificially extended: as the maller picture faithfully exprees. Now this Membrane is fatned above to that ame fibrous circle which ends the Colon, but it is fatned below or rather trongly held, by two very little Membranes, proceeding on both ides from the ide of that Orifice, through which the thinner Guts disburthen themelves into the wider: the ue of which bones, is to hinder that the value do not eaily totter, for they bind it to the Ileum: But the lower part of the value doth wave up and down looely.

The ue thereof is, that nothing may pas back out of the thick Guts into the thin, be it Wind or Excrement, epecially in a trong excretion or training at tool, or in cotivenes of the Belly. Hence it is, that the matter of Clyters cannot naturally reach unto the mal Guts.
The Colon hath Veins and Arteries under the Stomach from the Epiplois potica. But in the left ide it hath the Haemorrhoidal Vein, and from the lower Meenterick, the Haemorrhoidal Artery.

The lat thick Gut is termed RECTUM, becaue it goes traight out,The Intetinum rectum, or the traight Gut. without any turning, and ends at the Fundament; for it goes treight downwards, from the top of the Os Sacrum to the extremity of the Crupper-bone, to which it is Knit firmly, by the Peritonaeum, leat it fal of: alo it grows in men to the Pipipe in the Yard; to the Neck of the Womb in Women, by mediation of a Muculous ubtance. Whence prings the conent of thee parts in Men and Women, epecially of the Womb and this Gut in Women, for the Gut being exulcerated, oft-times the Excrement is cat out the female Privity.
It is long, as it were an Hand-breath and an half, and three fingers broad; and Corpulent and thick, having Fat Appurtenances, growing thereto on the outide.
It hath Veins from the Hypogatrick branch of the Vena Cava, and Haemorrhoidal Veins.
Four Nerves are inerted into the end thereof, which make this Gut very enible, as is apparent in the Tenemus.
Its end is termed Podex or Anus, the Are or Fundament, having three Mucles,Touching the Fundament. of which peradventure five may be made. The,

div.p: I. Is termed Sphincter The Sphincter Mucle. or Ani Contricter, the hutter or contractor of the Fundament, o that though ome part thereof may be cut of in Fitula's or other Dieaes, yet is not therefore the whole ue thereof, quite taken away.

Galen and Fallopius and others do make two of this Mucle, becaue its upper part is thicker; the inferior part is ineparably annexed to the Skin, as is een in the Fore-head and Eye-lids, and therefore Galen called this part the skinny Mucle, or the flehy Skin.
It aries from the lower Vertebra's of Os acrum and is compaed with tranvere Fibres all a long the Fundament.

It is fatned on the forepart. 1. To the paage of the Bladder, by Fibrous couplings. 2. To the Yard, to the Mucles whereof it gives beginning. 3. To the Neck of the Womb. Behind to the Crupper-bone which lies under it. At the ides, by Ligaments produced from the Os acrum, into the Os Corae.

Its ue is, to pure up the Fundament, that we may do our buines when we pleae. And therefore being palied or otherwie hurt, it makes the dung to come from a man whether he will or no: even as the Sphincter of the Bladder being hurt, the pis flows out involuntarily.

II. and III. Two other Mucles have inertions into the upper partThe Mucles cald Ani Levatores, or Are-lifters. of the Sphincter, very much Commixed therewith. They are called Ani Levatores Are-lifters. Becaue,

Their ue is to draw the Fundament upwards into its own place again, after the Excrements are voided. epecially when we have been forced to train hard at tool. And therefore when they have been weakned or lacked, omtimes the Fundament is drawn up with difficulty, and omtimes it continues hanging forth.

Thee Mucles are under the Bladder broad and thin, ariing from the Ligaments of the Share, the Os acrum and Hip: from whence they are carried downwards, to the right and left ides of the Fundament, which they compas about. But they have a certain peculiar and ditinct portion, growing to the Root and Neck of the Yard, which may be counted a third and ditinct Mucle. The ue of thee Mucles ceaes in thoe who have their Fundament hut up. Such a Cae Fernelius aw, And I aw the like at Padua in one named Anna, whoe Fundament was o hut up, that he voided his Excements by his mouth when concoction was finihed, having an Horn to put into his mouth for that end.

div.head: Chap. XII. Of the Meentery.
div.p: THe Meenterium is o called, becaueMeentery why o called. it is in the middle of the Guts, not becaue it is the middle Gut as Cicero will have it [and Macrobius who follows him; for it doth not partake of the nature of a Gut, ave in that it is Membranous, nor is there any defence for Laurembergius, becaue we are rightly aid to dwell in the middle of the world, uppoing the Earth to be a part of the World.
