div.p: the word Iutetinum in Cicero, for ome midling bowel] but becaue like a Circle it embraces the Guts round, and gathers them together into the form of a Globe, and cloaths them. Tis called alo Mearaeon: Gaza in Aritotle tranlates it Lactes [in a large ene] thereby undertanding that which involves and wraps up the Lactes that is the Guts, and what ever is contained in them.

It is one; but others divide it into the Mearaeon or Meenterium, and theIts Diviion. Meo-Colon. The former being in the middle of the belly and knitting together the mal Guts: the latter which knits up the Colon, in the right and left ide and in the lower part thereof, cleaves to the right Gut.

It Figure is very near Circular, and after it hath been narrow in its rie, in itsIts Figure. progres, at the Circumference it degenerates into very many foldings, that it might gather in the length of the Guts: for one hands breadth of the Meentry, doth embrace more then fourteen handsbreadths of the Guts in a narrow pace. In the ides it becomes oblong, epecially on the left ide, where it decends to the Intetinum rectum. Whereupon Galen made a threefold Meentery: a right, left and middle.
Its Magnitude from the Centre to the Circumference is a pan: but itsIts Magnitude. Longitude and Circumference is three ells.

It Aries at the firt and third Vertebra ofIts Rie. of the Loyns, [which is thought to be the Caue of that great conent which is between the Loyns and the Guts] where Membranous Fibres are produced from the Peritonaeum, which turn into trong Membranes,

Through which the Mearaick VeinsIts Veels. [both the Blood and the Chyle-bearers] being exceeding mal and numerous, and by little and little running together into fewer and greater, are dieminated. [But of thee more largely in the firt Manual Chap. 3.] And after the ame manner the Arteries: [from the Caliaca, that they may carry arterial blood with heat to the Meentery and Guts for the Nutrition and Fermentation of each of them and in no wie to draw chyle in a ound tate of Body, or other things as Varolius and Spigelius conceit. And that the blood is Circulated even in the Meentery, by means of thee Arteries, I hall demontrate hereafter againt Riolanus.] It receives alo Nerves from thoe which are carried from the ixth pair, to the roots of the Ribs, as alo from the Nerves proceeding from the Vertebra's of the Loyns, that they may give the ene of Feeling to the Meentery, as is manifet in the batard colick and other pains; and an obcure motion in ditribution of the chyle.

It hath Kernels interpoed to fil up theIts Kernels. paces, and to cherih the heat: but one greater then the ret it hath at its original which Aellius following Fallopius, terms Pancreas: different from the other Pancreas ituate under the Stomach and Duodenum. Out of this he fetches the Original of the milky Veins, with probability enough, becaue there they grow all into one, and from hence are carryed both downwards and upwards to the Liver Add hereunto, that it is in color like thoe Veins; and the
Veins themelves have in this place omwhat proper, viz. that they are interwoven in the whole Body of this Pancreas, with wonderful turnings, twitings, and twinings.

It is urrounded with Fat as in the Call, which proceeds from fat blood lipt out of the Veels, and retained by the denity of the Membranes, and o congeled; that it may cherih the Heat of thoe Parts, and further the preparation of Chyle.

The Ue of thee Kernels is, 1. To prop up and upport undry DitributionsThe Ue of the Kernels. of the Branches of Vena porta and Arteria magna. Hence it is, that about the Centre of the Meenterie are the greatet Kernels, becaue there is the Ditribution of the greater and more collected Veels. Moreover, thee Glandules or Kernels, when they are at any time troubled with a cirrhous hard Tumor; there follows a Leannes of the whol Body, becaue they bear hard, and lie upon the branches of the Vena portae, and of the milkie Vein, o that the Nourihment cannot be freely carried through the aid Veins. 2. To moiten the Guts, with the Humors which they uck out of the Parts, and promote Digetion by way of boyling as it were. Which Ue Spigelius denies, becaue there are Animals that have not thee Glandules, and nevertheles are fat; and others though they have thee, are lean. Which may happen without any prejudice to my aertion, becaue thee former Animals have uch good Juyce, as needs no purification; the latter have o little nutritive Juyce, that it cannot ufficiently be depurated by thee Glandules. And therefore, 3. They erve to uck uperfluous Humors out of the Guts, which was Hippocrates his Opinion. I add 4. A peculiar Ue, viz. to receive that plenty of milkie Veins which paes that way, and to keep ome portion of the Chyle, becaue 1. It is of like ue with that greater middle Kernel, and its ubtance is the ame with that which exceeds this only in magnitude, becaue greater milkie Veins pas that way. 2. I oberved that in Fihes, epecially in a Lump-fih male and female, beides the great white one, the others did alo end forth a white Juyce. 3. This being granted, both Atrophia and other Dieaes are better undertood, to which Opinion alo Aellius eems to have enclined. And whereas Riolanus makes the Seat and Root of al Kings-evil wellings to be in thee Kernels, and aith they never hew themelves on the outide of the Body, except the Meenterie be firt dieaed with the ame kind of Swellings, is not likely, for 1. Though they may be remote and accidental caues. 2. There is no communion between thee kind of Swellings in the Head, and the Kernels of the Meenterie. 3. Many have the Kings-evil wellings, in whom thee Kernels are perfectly ound. 4. All would be ubject to uch Swellings, becaue all have thee Kernels. 5. Thoe people dwelling under the Alpes, that are o ubject to thee Swellings, hould have their Meenterie differing from thoe that are not o troubled. 6. The aid Swellings are filled by any kind of Humor proceeding from any Region of the Body.
The Ue of the Meenterie is to be the common Band of the Guts, wherebyThe Ue of the Meenterie. they are knit to the Vertebra's of the Loins.
And the Ue of its two Membranes, isAnd of its Membranes. that through them the Veels may pas afer unto the Guts.

div.head: Chap. XIII. Of the Pancreas, or Sweet-bread.
div.p: THe Word Pancreas ignifies Allfleh, The Subtance of the Pancreas. whereas this part hould rather be call'd All-kernel, its Subtance being wholly glandulous, looe it is and hapeles, three or four fingers long, omtimes ix or even, and more, cloathed with a thin Membrane from the Peritonaeum and in fat Bodies, it eems all made of Fat, which others term dirty fat and moiture; ome Calicreas the Sweet-bread or White-bread, and Lactes; becaue of its milkie whitenes and oftnes.
Its Situation is under the lower part of the Stomach, and the bottom thereof,Its Situation the Duodenum and Vena portae, as far as the Regions of the Liver and Spleen.
Now its Original is at the firt VertebraOriginal. of the Loins. In the middle its Parenchyma is white.

And it hath for Veins the SplenickIts Veels. Branch; for Arteries the left Branch of Arteria Coeliaca; for Nerves thoe of the ixt-pares branches, which go to the Stomach and Duodenum, and it hath alo little Kernels.

Beides all which, it hath alo another Paage which is membranous, and of a peculiar Nature by it elf, pread out all along the Pancreas, omtimes in a trait Line, omtimes in a crooked Line, which hath been as yet decribed by no Anatomit, being firt dicovered at Padua, when I was there, in the year 1642. by John George Verungus, a very diligent Anatomit, but killed by cruel Fate; it is remarkeable for its Cavity, and the trength of the Walls thereof. I beleive Fallopius did not know it. He mentions indeed mall Paages, ending into the Pancreas and Kernels next it; but becaue this paage is only one, he rather aw through a mit the milkie Veins, dipered into the Pancreas of the Meenterie and other Kernels. It is for the mot part ingle, though the ame Party had found it double running one by another in parallel Lines: A hort one in the ordinary place, and beneath it a larger. The Orifice whereof opens widely into the Gut Duodenum, near the Entrance of the Gal-paage, with which it is omtimes joyned by one and the ame Mouth, but more frequently (as I found with the Author) by a different but neighboring Circle. The little Valve ituate before the egres thereof, looking outwards, keeps the Probe from entring this new paage, being thrut in by the Duodenum. And therefore in a Living creature, being bound towards the Gut, it wells more and more, but beyond it is preently emptyed, if we beleive Jacobus Baccius, which is an Experiment hard to make for before that this paage which lies intangled and encombred can be freed, or bound, the Creature dies. From thence this paage creeps through the whole Body of the Pancreas, preading out on both ides infinite little Branches, until by narrower but orderly dipoed twigs, it goes by little and little traight forward, and is ilently terminated towards the Spleen. But it goes not into the Spleen, although Folius hath aured me, that he hath oberved it to go thereinto. Peradventure that was againt Nature, nor eems it feaible, becaue the Branches are firt obliterated by an orderly defect, ere they touch the Spleen, and there is no cavity there about, though an eminent one towards
In this TABLE both the Body of the Pancreas together with the new Wirungian Paage, as alo the Veels drawn there through to the Spleen, are expreed.

page 31 the Guts. In which Cavity (truly) there is no conpicuous Humor, ave that a Probe being thrut in, is for the mot part died with a yellow cholerick colour, the Walls thereof being coloured with the like tincture, o that Choler eems to be therein contained, by the ordinary Law of Nature, which Johannes van Horn likewie a Friend of mine aw at Venice, in a cholerick loones, the aid Veel being evidently full of Gall or Choler. And therefore this new found paages

Ue, is not to carry Chylus ut of the Duodenum into the Spleen, bo ue 1.Its Ue. It doth not reach to the Spleen. 2. A Valve hinders the Ingres. Nor doth it erve to carry Melancholy out of the Spleen, to which ue erve the Capulae atrabilariae, the black Choler boxes. Nor to carry fermentative Juyce unto the Stomach, as Hortius Junior ingeniouly feignes, Becaue 1. Such Juyce is not bred in the Pancreas, which is a glandulous Body. 2. The way is more ready to that purpoe, from the Spleen; this being a more troubleom and encombred paage, for it would be troubled by meeting the Chylus in the Duodenum, and would be infected by the nearnes of the Gall-paage. 3. Never any uch Juyce een in this paage. 4. Who will be bound that it hall be able to pas beyond the Pylorus? Nor is it to prepare Chylus, which Baccius affirmes to be found in living Creatures. Nor to nourih the Pancreas, eeing that Humor is therefore unfit, and the coeliack Arteries do that work, but for the common good. But how, or which way hall it return to the Liver? For he rightly denies it to the Spleen. Shall it return to the Duodenum, and from thence to the Meentery? There would be an infinite Circulation. He hall not eaily find it in living Anatomies; alo he confounds the Pancreas with the large Kernel of the Meentery. Nor finally does it end the Excrements of the Chyle to the Duodenum, as Licetus, Riolanus, and Vetingus conceive; for in this Paage no Chyle is een, but yellow Walls. Moreover the refue of the Chyle is already voided by tool, nor does the Chyle part with any new Excrement, till it undergo a new change in the Veins of the Liver. Now ure it is, that out of the
Pancreas it elf, whoe proper paage it is, and in which it begins, and is ended, omwhat is thereby voided into the Guts, and it doth as I conjecture.

1. Purge forth Choler, whether bred in the Digetion of the Pancreas, or in the Spleen, for each of thee are taken to be Auxiliary-Livers. And it is as it were the Bladder-gall of the Spleen, which is conveniently joyned by its mouth, to the other paage of the Livers-Gall-bladder, by the Duodenum, o that look what ue the one affords to the Liver, the ame the other may be uppoed to afford to the Spleen. And to prevent our doubting, the Humor of Choler daubs the inide of this Paage. To which Opinion of mine, very many Learned men have aerted, though in ome things they dient.
2. To receive into it elf the Excrements of Arterial Blood from the Heart and Spleen, though the neighboring Branches of Arteria Coeliaca.

3. Riolanus counts it a profitable Ue, that by this Paage, in vomiting, divers Humors are purged out, and the Redundancies of the firt Region; and conequently the fomenting Humors which maintain longlating and malignant Feavers and chronical Dieaes, and which lurks in the Pancreas, is this way voided forth. And I may well ad omwhat to this mot learned Invention. That not only by Vomit, but alo by tool, through the aitance of Choler-purgers, hot cholerick Ditempers may be by this Paage dicharged, which burn the Meentery, Spleen, Arteries, and Heart it elf. And hence proceed cholerick tools in burning Feavers, and blood in a Dyentery or Bloody-flux, by reaon of the large Inundation of Choler, continually flowing from hence into the Guts; which is o much the more hard to cure, by how much the Pancreas doth lie out of the reach of Medicaments, being deeply whelmed among the Bowels.

The Ue of the Pancreas it elf is, 1. To prop and upport Veels paingThe Ue of the Pancreas. through the ame, as the Branches of Vena porta, of the Coeliack Artery, and of the Nerves: Epecially the Ramus Splenicus. 2. To ait the Concoction of the Stomach, which is performed in Heat and Moiture. 3. To erve as a cuhion under the Stomach. And therefore that old Woman of Rome in whom it was become toney, fell firt into a continual Vomiting, afterwards into an Atrophy or conuming of fleh, and at lat died thereof, as Panarolus hath it in his Obervations. 4. To uck out the wheyih Blood which lides along that way, and through help of the Kernels to purge it. 5. In ickly and melancholick Bodies, to perform the Office of the Spleen, which Riolanus hews from the Example of the mot renowned Thuanus: Whoe Pancreas or Sweetbread, did equal the Liver in amplitude and weight, yet was it wholly cirrhous; but his Liver hard and round as a ball, and full of Flegm like Potters-clay, and his Spleen was found o mall, that it hardly weighed an ounce.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Touching the Liver.
div.p: ANd o much may uffice to have aid touching the Organs detined to primary Digetion or Chylification, we come now to thoe which are any waies aiting the econd Concoction or Sanguification. And the Principal of thee is the Liver.
The Liver is an Organick Part eated in the Lower Belly, jut under the Diaphragma or Midriff, on the right ide, being the Organ of Blood-making, and the beginning of the Veins.

It hath its Name in Greek, from a Word that ignifies want or Indigency,Why the Liver is the Original of the Veins? becaue it upplies the want of the Parts of the Body, the Latins cal it Jecur, as if you would ay juxta Cor, near the Heart. 'Tis called the Principle or Beginning of the Veins, becaue therein the Roots of two of the greatet Veins appear dipered, viz. of the Cava and Portae, as Roots implanted in the Earth. The milkie Veins are uppoed to arie from the Pancreas: Yet Trunks and Branches of them are alo to be een in the Liver. Now the Roots of Trees dipered in the Earth, do grow together into a Trunk without the Earth. The Vena arterioa of the Heart, is in truth an Artery: And the Arteria venoa, is a Vein, and may owe its Original to the Liver, becaue in a Child in the Womb, it is joyned with the cava, and opens it elf thereinto by an Anatomois: And beides, it carries Blood to the Heart, but brings none from it, if there be any force in this Argument.
The Liver is commonly but one in Number, eldom two: And more eldomIts Number. is the Liver quite wanting, as in Matthias Ortelius.

It is ituate in the lowet Belly, underIts Situation. the Septum tranverum (which alo Hippocrates and Aritotie acknowledged) by the Ribs, and for the greater part in the right Hypochondrium, a fingers breadth ditant there from, that the motion thereof might not be hindered: Therefore a Swelling in the Liver caues hortnes of breath. In Birds it lies equally on both ides: As alo for the mot part in Dogs which have a thin and long Spleen. In Man it eldom changes its place, o as the Liver hould be in the left, the Spleen in the right ide, which Gemma and Spererius have oberved. It rets lightly upon the former and upper part of the Stomach, epecially on the right ide, for otherwie ome part thereof reaches to the left ide alo, and omtimes the greatet part, the Spleen being very mall. But ome conceive that Aritotle was ignorant of the Situation of the Liver, becaue the aid Huper de to Diazoma, &c. which they interpret, above the Septum is the Liver eated. But the Philooper is thus to be tranlated: It is placed on the other ide, or beyond the Septum tranverum; for Huper with an Accuative ignifies beyond, but with a Genetive, it ignifies above.

And by reaon of the Midriff, to whichIts Figure. it was to give way, it hath its upper and outward Figure ufficiently round, convex or gibbous, even and mooth, where alo there is an oblong Cavity, behind at the Paage of Vena cava. And becaue of the Stomach it hath received a Figure which is hollow on the inner and lower ide, which is termed its imous or addle ide, and it is more uneven then the other having in it two hollownees: One on the right hand for the Gall-bladder; another on the left, for the Stomach to pas by. So that the Liver is on the right ide of an ample roundnes, but on the left it is narrow and harp.

The Liver is divided by ome, into theIts Diviion. right and left part: between which there is a mal cleft or chink, where the UmbilicalA Mans Liver is not divided into Laps or Scollops. Vein enters. Otherwie for the mot part, it is entire in a Man and undivided, ave that Spigelius oberved here

NN. Certain Eminencies of the Liver, anciently termed Portae the Gates.

HHHH. The extremities of the aid Veins, called Capiliary Veins, becaue of their malnes.

page 33
a certain little lobe, of ofter Fleh then the ret of the Liver, compaed with a thin and ubtile Membrane, which is carried out into the Call, and omtimes empties the Liver when it is full of Blood. In this little and oft lobe, I have manifetl •
<…> certain • il • Veins inerted in the cutting up of Fihes; o that according to the diverity of the parts of the Liver, we have now the Inerting of t •••
• eels which hath hitherto been unoberv ••
But in B •••• s (excepting an Ox and ome others) it is divided into di •…
which they call Lobes of Scollops, wherewith they ay the Stomach is covered and contained, as with o many fingers. Galen therefore and Plempius have done ill to ay that Mans Liver is divided Naturally into Lobes, Laps, and Scollops, for preternaturally and rarely it is indeed o divided, as Fernelius, Sylvius, and Gemma have oberved. Galen is to be excued, becaue he took the Extuberances of the Liver made of the Trunks of the Veels for Lobes. And Hortius junior doth learnedly refute Plempius, for giving out the Clefts, Cavities, and Extuberances of the Liver, for Lobes perfectly ditinct.

The Greatnes and thicknes thereof, is remarkable and exceeding great inIts Magnitude. a man (as is his Brain) not only for Nutrition as in brutes, but for the breeding of Animal Spirits, which are often diipated (and they are bred of the Vital Spirit, as it is bred of Blood. Yet it is greater then ordinary in bodies that are of a cold Complexion, and in fearful Perons and great Eaters, to augment the Heat of the Heart. In perons dead of a Comumption, I have omtimes een an exceeding great Liver, four or five times bigger then ordinary, and omtimes again very exceeding little. And others have found a very mall Liver, and omtimes no Liver, or the Liver conumed away; and a great and trong Spleen performing its Office. Rhais and Abenina gather the greatnes of the Liver from the length of a bodies ingers.

It is compaed with a thin Membrane, pringing from one of theIts Membrane. Membranes of the Veins, which hath its Original from the Peritonaeum. In this there arie little bladders of water, from whence the Dropie come, Witnes Platerus. I have een of thee bladders in a he Goat, many in number, whiteih, which being cut open, were found to contain within a ingle coat or skin, wheyih Humor, with notty Flegm, and another yellow ubtance, whether through a fault in Nature, or becaue the Goat was camed. I have more then once found intertwited ropes of Worms, in other Membranes of the Liver.

It is fatned by three trong Ligaments. 1. To the Belly, by the umbelicalis Its Connexion. Vena, or Navil-vein, which after the Birth, is in grown Perons dried up, and turns to a Ligament, leat the Midriff hould dangle too much, and hould hang too low down. 2. Above to the Midriff, on the right ide, by a broad membranous and thin Ligament, but yet a trong one ariing from the Peritonaeum, which the Midriff undercircles; and this is called the Ligamentum upenorium or hanging Ligament. 3. Alo above to the Diaphragma, but on the left hand, by another Ligament prung from the Peritonaeum, round, and exceeding trong: Alo in its after-part where the Vena cava paes, i • cleavs by its bunchy ide to the Peritonaeum. Riolanus reckons thee three Ligaments for one, becaue he contends that the umbelical Vein is dried up, which being carried through a duplicature or folding of the Peritonaeum, hath for its Companion the Membrane it elf, which being rouled back over the Liver, runs out upwards & downwards to the Diaphragma it elf, which it invets and fatens. But it is al one cae. For Ligaments are termed undry, becaue they faten and upend divers parts of the Liver, although the two latter arie from the Peritonaeum. Now therefore according to his reckoning, there will be two Ligaments, ••• one only; the former from the Umbelical, and the other from the Peritonaeum. The fourth Ligament annexed to the mucronata Cartilago, at the Cleft of the Liver, is no pecular one, but mut be reckoned as part of our econd Ligament.

It hath a Subtance red and oft [oIts Subtance. that with a little tick it may be beaten off, and eparated from the Veels interwoven, either when it is boyled or being raw] pred about the Veels, like congealed blood, for which caue it is termed Parenchyma, that is to ay an Effuion or hedding forth of blood, becaue it is poured about the Veels, and fills the paces between them [in ome kind of fihes it eems to be a congealed Fat, out of which an Oyl is boyled to burn in Lamps. Yet is it hardly corrupted; for Riolanus hath oberved that a Liver having been accidentally kept a year together, hath remained uncorrupt. In ubtance it is mot like an Oxes Liver, and being boyled; differs not there-from, neither in conitence, color, nor tat, and therefore our fleh is more like that of Oxen then of Swine.

The Color of a ound Liver is ruddie [butIts Color. if it be quite void of blood, or boyled, we may rightly ay with Gordonius, that it is whiteih, as in an Embryo, before affuion of blood be made. But we hall find it very large and red, in Children new born, of a good Contitution. I have demontrated it to be yellow, in the fih called a Lump. In a Lamprey it is green (which makes Bronzerus dipute touching the Principallity of the Liver) though the blood be red, whether it have contracted its color here, or in the Heart, or from it elf] In ome ick perons, as thoe which have the Dropie, it is very pale, as alo the Spleen and Kidneys.

Now thoe Veels in the Liver, are theIts Veels. Roots of Vena portae and cava, (with a few [to a mans firt thinking, but upon erious Examination according to the Obervation of Walaeus, an innumerable company of] mall Arteries interpoed, of a whiter color, dipered from the Coeliaca, through the addle part thereof) [partly that they might nourih the Liver, and warm it throughly with the heat of the heart the branches of Vena portae aiting likewie to the ame intent; partly that by the motion of the Pule, and the neceity of running back, it may ait and provoke the paage of the blood out of the Liver according to the conjecture of Slegelius. For whereas Galen tells us that the Liver is cooled by the Arteries, that is not cononant to truth: For they are hot, and by their motion further the blood, and draw it to thoe parts wherein they are implanted;] which appear ditinct, the fleh or Parenchyma of the Live being taken away, how they are carried this way and that way, without order, among which alo mall branches are dieminated, which afterwards unite into one common Paage, and o carry Choler into the Gall-bladder. Now it is conjoyned with the Roots of Porta, that there the Blood may be eparated from the Choler. But more Roots of the Porta are pred up and down here and there through the lower part of the Liver, very few through the upper part: Contrariwie, more of the Roots of the Cava are carried through the upper and tuberous, or boie part thereof, and fewer through the hollow or addle part. To thee mut be added the Roots of the Milkie Veins. Aellius did omtimes oberve their trunk to be in the Liver. But he did not preciely add the place, which I have determined to be in the third Lobe.

The Anatomoes or Conjunctions ofTheir Anatomoes. the Roots of Vena Porta and Vena Cava, are peculiarly to be oberved. For rejecting thoe who altogether deny the Union of thee
Veins, or who conceive that they are obcurely and hardly known: [among whom Harvey and Riolanus are lately come upon the tage, the former of whom could no where find any Anatomois, either in the Liver, Spleen, or any other Bowel, though they had been boyled, till the whole Parenchyma would crumble in peices, and was eparated like dut from all the trings of the Veels, with a needle. Only he oberved this one thing, in a freh Liver, viz. that all the branches of Vena Cava creeping along the boie part of the Liver, have Coats like elves full of infinite little holes, as being made for the draught of the Body, to receive uch Blood as ettles there: but that the branches of the Vena Portae are not o but are divided into boughes, and that every where the branches of both, do run out to the highet Eminency of the boie ide of the Bowel, without Anatomoes. But the Porta hath likewie very many holes great and little, as the Cava hath, ome of which will admit the probe, others not, only they make certain Cavities covered with a thin Membrane. Whence it is apparent, that the blood is taied by thoe cloed holes and not trained out, ome of them being covered with a Coat, Riolanus inpired by the ame Spirit, doth trongly oppoe the Anatomoes of the Vena Cava and Portae leat he hould be forced to admit the Circulation of the Blood in that Place. He was afraid that the concocted liquor hould be confounded and mixt with the unconcocted. And what if they be confounded and jumbled together? The Chymus being changed into imperfect blood is confounded coming out of the milky Veins, with that which is contained in the Cava, for both of them are to be perfected in the Heart. And the other which flows out of Porta, prepares both with its acid juyce. But be it how it will be, the Authority of all Anatomits doth aert thoe Anatomoes from the times of Eraitratus and Galen to our daies, becaue it is manifet to uch as earch diligently, that thee roots are joyned together, omtimes athwart, o that one lies over the middle of another as it were, omtimes the extremities of one Vein touch the Extremities or ends of another, otherwhiles the ends of one touch the middle of the other; and omtimes they touch not one another at all; peradventure where the Branches of the Liver erve only for Nutrition. Bauhinus wihes us chiefly to oberve a remarkable Anatomois, which reembles a channel, and is as it were a common and continued paage, out of the Roots of Porta into the Roots of Cava, admitting a pretty big Probe. But becaue we cannot rely upon naked Authorities, experience mut be called by us to counel, which doth necearily perwade us that there are uch Anatomoes or Unions of the Mouths of the Veeis, by reaon of the paage of the Blood out of the milky Veins and the Venae Porrae, unto the Cava, and out of the manifet Arteries, eeing the paage only through the fleh cannot uffice, in a quick and plentiful Flux. I confes all the kinds of Anatomoes are not appearent to the Eye as to be een open, in dead bodies, though no man can therefore deny that there are uch things; but ome of them are inenible, which admit neither Probe not Wind, and ome admit Wind and nothing ele. The Renowned Walaeus oberved and found by experience, that the Veins of the Porta are in the Liver no where opened into the greater branch of Vena Cava, but that the very mallet branches of Vena Porta, do open into the mallet branches of the Vena Cava, as he oberved in a Liver blown up with wind, after the fleh was taken away, and floating upon water. I have in an Oxes Liver curiouly ought for apparent Anatomoes, becaue there they mut needs be viible becaue of the greatnes, following the example of the mot learned Slegelius. But the very truth is they are not viible to the Eye: the Veels indeed are divers waies interwoven and twited one among another; Trunk with Trunk, branches of the Trunkes, either with the Trunk of another Vein, or with little branches; and that either in the middle of thoe little branches, or in the extremities, even as we ee both the Veels cleave together in the Womb-cake: But a Probe finds no entrance, by any open hole of an Anatomois. Nevertheles, it is not to be denied, but that in living Bodies there is a paage known to Nature though unknown to us by reaon of the neceity of a through paage. Which I the rather believe, becaue that in the conjunction of the Veels, yea even of the greater, where the Anatomoes eems hut, the Coat is extraordinary thin and for the mot part ingle, as appears by its tranparency, which in Living Bodies being ratified by heat and motion, doth eaily uffer the blood to pas through.

By thee Unions therefore of the Roots of the Vena Cava and the Vena Portae, the Blood may pas through: And by them likewie the peccant matter paes, when we Evacuate the habit of the Body by Purgations. Not that it hould be carried out of the Porta to the Meentery, as hath been hitherto beleived, but o as thence to pas through the Heart, and be emptied out through the Caeliacal Arteries, and thence through the tomach or the Gall-Conduits into the Guts, forced along by virtue of the purging Medicament.
Thoe Anatomoes are likewie to be oberved, by which the mal Veins of the Gall-bladder, are joyned to the Branches of Vena Portae and Vena Cava.

The Roots of Vena Portae, do by littleThe Original of the Veins. and little towards the lower part become maller and greater, until they make one Trunk, which is called Vena Porta, the Gate-Vein: So alo the Roots of the Cava, above and in the fore-part do altogether make up one Trunk; before the going out whereof, certain Circles are placed, here and there in the greater branches, being of a Membranous ubtance and very like to Valves, omtimes thicker, other whiles thinner and like Cobwebs, which were firt dicovered by Stephanus and after by Conringius in an Oxes Liver; and I likewie found them, looking towards the larger trunk, which hinder the return of blood, not o much of that which is impure and dreggy, as of the pair being once gone out to the Heart: afterwards, as oon as it comes to the Liver, it is divided into two great branches, the acendent and decendent; and hence it is that they ay, the Cava aries from the upper or boie part of the Liver, and the Vena Portae from the lower and hollow part.

The Liver hath two Nerves from the ixt pair, one from the Stomach, another from the Cotal, dipered only through its Coat, and not through its ubtance (as Vealius will have it) that in its inmot body, it may be void of ene, in regard of o many motions of humors. And therefore the pains in this part are, dul and rather a kind of Heavynes then pain. Yet Riolanus hath oberved, that two remarkable little Nerves do accompany the Vena Portae, and go into the very ubtance of the Liver.

The Action of the Liver is Sanguification.The place of Blood-making, the Matter and Efficien. For of the Chylus • rawn by the Mearaick milky veins, •• e Liver makes Blood; and the Blood i • made
