page 36 in the branches of the milkie veins; the ubtance of the Liver, doth not only utaine the Veins, as ome would have it, but it is the efficient of Sanguification: And together with Blood, it generates natural Spirit.

Sanguification therefore or Bloodmaking, is thus performed: the moreThe Authors opinion how the blood is made. unprofitable and thicker part of the Chyle (which is made firt in the Stomach and finally perfected in the thin Guts) is thrown out into the thick Guts, and voided at the Fundament; but the more laudable and thin part is drawn in by the milky veins, pred up and down in the Guts; and •… le altered, and from them by means of a power proceeding from the Liver, it receives the firt Rudi •… of Blood, and is then called Chymus. The greatet quetion is whether the Liver draws it, or it is forced thither. It eems to be drawn by the heat of the Liver, as Chaf or Straw is drawn by heated Amber, and as Blood is drawn into the outward parts by hot Fomentations. Which is here viible by Ligatures and live diections, in which the attraction of the Liver is o great, that the milky Veins are peedily emptied. There is not the ame neceity, that it hould be forced thither, as other have thought, becaue the beginning of the Motion or moving principle hould either be without the Chylus, or within it. It cannot be in it. 1. Becaue nothing thruts or drives, but that which is alive. 2. The Chyle newly drawn out of the Veels, doth not move it elf. 3. It is void of Appetite. 4. It hould alwaies be driven downwards not up to the Liver. Nor can it be in
any thing without it. 1. Becaue the Meeraick Arteries have enough to do to drive out their own blood, and the Veins have work enough to receive it. 2. And the milky Veins are exceeding mall. 3. The proper Fibres of the Veins, do erve more for trength, then for driving. 4. The Stomach indeed, and the Guts are contracted, but they are not able to expel the chyle; for their motion is obcure, and though it were evident, yet it would not preently follow, that it mut drive into the Liver. 5. Thoe Bowels being contracted on all ides, and hut up, as much Chyle is retained, as is expelled. 6. The Abdomen doth ofttimes ret, according to our deire and pleaure, being apt to be moved by the Mucles; but the motion of the Chylus is performed continually and wiftly, viz. the due time of ditribution being come. 7. The dreggy Chyle hould be ent unto the Liver, without difference, as well as the pure. It is therefore principally drawn by the Liver, howbeit ome contruction of the Guts, is econdarily aitant thereunto. This Chymus being attracted in the Roots of the milky veins, as in the place where, is by the Parenchyma or Subtance of the Liver, as the Efficient caue, with the aitance of the internal heat of the Chyle, changed into a new ubtance of blood. Now it gains a Rednes like the ubtance of the Liver, not o much from the fleh of the Liver alone, which it elf ows its color to blood hed about it, which it layes away when it is wahed or boyled, and in ome other Creatures we find it of a green color, as from its own proper and adventitious Heat (as Grapes are red) which vanihing away, the rednes ceaes, as it happens in blood-letting. Nor is that a ufficient caue, eeing in healthy bodies it continues afterwards red, and therefore we mut take in light as another Caue, of which there is a great quantity in red colors, ubiting even without Heat, unles the ubject happening to be diolved, it come to be extinguihed and exhale. Hence it is, that boyled blood becomes black, and putrid blood is duskie. Hence alo, by how much the more Natural inbred light any man hath, the more he hines with bright blood; contrariwie, in Melancholick perons, the ame being darkned, the blood grows black and dark. That light and fire are the caue hereof appears in Oyl of Sulphur, by the mixture whereof Liquors become red.

Now this Heat and Light, is partly planted in the liver, and the Chyle it elf, pringing thereout, by reaon of its previous preparation, and partly kindled therein, either by reaon of the nearnes of the Heart, and bordering parts, or by reaon of the Arterial blood, derived from the Heart and Spleen.

The more crude Blood being thus made, is not ditributed to nourih the Liver or the Body, which Office is performed by the Hepatick Arteries, but by inenible Anatomoes of the fleh and Veels, it is expelled into the Roots of Vena cava, where by longer tarriance, it is more elaborated, and oon after with the returning blood of the Vena porta and the Arteries, it is poured out into the Trunk of cava, going all traight along, through the upper part of the Trunk to the heart, that it may there attain its lat accomplihment whereby it becomes fit to nourih all the Parts. Not any thing returns this way to the Liver, the Valves hindering, which in the Liver look outwards, in the Heart inwards, as the whole Fabrick and Ligatures do tetifie. By thee it is, that the Cava alwayes wells towards the Liver, and is empty towards the Heart.

Afterwards the Nourihment of all the Parts of the Body being accomplihed by the Capillary Arteries, becaue all the blood is not conumed, which by continual Pulations is ent forth, nor can that which is uperfluous return the ame way, by reaon of the Valves of the Heart eated by the Aorta, which lets any thing pas from the Heart, but admits nothing back again; and becaue any Artery being tied, is full, and wels towards the Heart, but is empty, and lank towards the Veins: Therefore it mut needs return as it were by a circular motion, out of the mallet Veels back again into the greatet Veins, and the Trunk it elf of the Cava, and thence into the Heart. As it paes through the Liver, other blood there newly bred, is joyned with that of the Vena porta, and that which is redundant from the Arteries, for the retoring of that which is pent, and o the Circulation is again repeated. Mean while, as hath been aid, Choler is drawn out of the blood, by branches of veels, terminating into the Galbladder and Choler-paage. But the wheyih part, is becaue of its thinnes retained a while, that the blood may more eaily pas every where, and afterwards it is ent away, partly to the Kidneys (with the wheyih blood, which according to Galen is not concocted in the Kidneys, but becaue the Serum is an Excrement of the Liver, the Kidneys do only eparate the blood from the whey) and from thence by the Ureters into the Bladder; whence the Urin does afterward partly go into the Skin, and paes out by weat and inenible Tranpiration.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Of the Receptacles of Choler, viz. the Gall-bladder, and Choler-paage.
div.p: ON the right hand and hollow part See Fig. III. Table 17. of the Liver, for the Reception of two orts of Choler, thick and thin, two Conduits or Paages are engraven: The Veica biliaria or Choler-bladder, and the Canalis biliarius or Cholerchannel. Galen himelf knew as much, when he aid that from the Liver a twofold cholerick Excrement was purged; the one unmixt and imple, the other mixed and thick, which I collect contrary to what Hofman aerts, out of the fourth Book of the Ue of the Parts, 12. and 13. and from the fifth Book Chap. the 6. For the Channel poures out thick and dreggy choler, but the Bladder uch as is more thin and yellow. For the larter bordering upon the Vena porta, ucks more plentifully out of the Spirituous and Arterial Blood; the former being placed at the Roots of the Cava, draws a les quantity of Choler, and uch as is more thick, becaue that blood is thicker.

The Veica biliaria or Gall-bladder calledThe Shape of the Gal-bladder. alo folliculus Fellis, is a Veel long and round, fahioned like a Pear, hollow, furnihed with a double Membrane, the one, whereby it is fatned to the Liver, from the Peritonaeum [which is alo the ame, wherewith the Liver is covered] without Fibres, and wherewith that part only is covered, which hangs without the Liver: The other proper and more thick, but trong, having all manner of Fibres; which a certain Crut encompaes, bred of the Excrements of its third Digetion, to keep off the harpnes of the Gall.

This Gall-bladder is mall, compared Its Greatnes to the Spleen and Kidneys. Being two
fingers breadths in deepnes: but the more cholerick any peron is, the greater is this Gall-bladder oberved to be.
'Tis divided into the Bottom and theDiviion. Neck.

The Bottom is round, and eated lowermot,Bottom. viz. when the Liver is in its Natural Situation, it is died with a yellow color, and ometimes black, viz. when the Choler being over long kept, is burned.

The Neck, being harder then the bottom, looks upward, grows long and narrow, untilNeck. it end into a very mall and narrow paage. At the Neck is oberved, firt a certain peculiar hollownes, and alo certain little Valves or Membranes, omtimes two, otherwhiles three, which hinder the Regres of Choler. Regius proves, that they are ometimes opened by Spirits, through a Nerve inerted into the liver, and o let Choler return into the Liver; which appears by anger, and the udden boyling of the blood in angry perons, by admixtion of burnt Choler. Howbeit by preing, or queezin • , and blowing, we cannot force any Choler back. And if the force of the Spirits were o great, they might as eaily open and hut the valves of the Heart, when they are in the Arteries more plentiful then ordinary. They pierce indeed by their finenes the valves, when they are hut, but they carry not the blood with them. Choler, truly, may by ome other means be inflamed, which is every where among hot blood. Finally, the valve would be broken by the violence of Spirits, and greater danger might follow thereby, then if the Gall-bladder were broken, an Example whereof Salmuth relates.

The Gall-bladder hath received very many mall Paages, furnihed with undry little twigs, owed up and down in the Liver, between the Roots of Cava and Porta; which afterwards being joyned into one paage, do carry pure Choler into the Gall-bladder: and the Gall-bladder having digorged it elf into the Gut, is daily filled again, and o it continues that coure. Contrary to the Opinion of Arnioeus; that the Bladder is filled with Choler, which being hindred by the Chylus, from decending by the Porus biliarius, into the Guts, does drive back again into the Bladder, For I have often een Waloeus demontrate, how that the Bladder being never o little queezed with a mans hand, even when the Guts are full of Chyle, Choler is eaily quirted into the Guts.

It hath two very mall Veins to nourih it. Alo it hath very mall Arteries fromIts Veins and Arteries. the Coeliaca, to nourih and preerve Heat. It is not therefote nourihed with Choler, as Joubertus conceives. It hath a little diminutive Nerve, carce viible, from a little Branch of the ixt pare, which crawls up and down the Coat of the Liver.
Its ue is to receive yellow excrementitious Choler, pure and thin (not the ExcrementIts Ue. mingled with the Blood, as the Kidneys do) and to retain it ome while, and then to expel it.

Now touching the ue of this Choler, Learned men are of undry minds. Some with Aritotle will allow it no ue, only it was a thing could not be avoided, and is drawn away, that the Blood may not be defiled; which Opinion Conringius maintains. Others attribute more to Choler, and make it ueful to the whole Body. 1. In that it <…>
• iver, according to Italy-Abbas and
•… ina, and by that means comforts •… e econd Digetion, and helps the Natural Heat of the Liver, like fire under a kettle. Yea, it heats the whole Body, if we will credit Nemeius, epecially the Stomach, to further its Digetion. If that be true, we mut undertand it of a moderate quantity thereof; otherwie an over great Heat of Choler would burn the Stomach.

2. Ofkin to thee, is the Opinion of Helmont; that it is the balom of the Liver, and the whole Blood, brought from the Liver to the Meentery, and that therefore the Gall precedes in the work of Sanguification, and the Liver follows; alo he ayes it hath the contitution of a neceary Bowel. But how hould it come into the Liver, ince Anatomy doth teach, that this humor is brought out of the Liver, but not carried back thither. For, the way is too long, through the Meentery, where by reaon of its acrimony, it makes hat out, or the edge thereof is blunted. And of what • hall it be bred, if it go before the Concoction of Blood? There are few Veins and Arteries dipered there abouts, but tore of Choler is collected. That the Action of the Liver goes before that of the Gall, Children in the Womb do hew, in whom the Liver is full of blood, before the Bladder well with Gall, or be o much as lightly colored therewith.

3. Their Opinion is not much unlike, who conceive that Choler preerves the neighbouring Parts, and the Liver it elf from corruption, which Zerbus would therefore prove, becaue when the Gall-bladder is removed from the Liver, the ubtance thereof where the Gallbladder lay, does preently diolve and melt.

4. A greater number of Authors will have it to erve to expel the Excrements of the Belly, by trengthening the Guts with its Heat, or provoking them to Expulion by its Acrimony. For although the Choler-paage, be implanted into the beginning of the Gut Jejunum, or into the Duodenum; yet it hath an eaie paage to the Colon and Ileum. That it paes through the Jejunum, is manifet from its yellow color, and the quick paage of the Chyle there through. Howbeit, it ought to be moderate in quantity, otherwie the Belly is dried and made cotive, or too much looned.
5. I add that it makes the Dung liquid, and apt to pas, to which intent Painters ue it to temper their colors.

The other Receptacle of Choler, isPorus biliarius. the Canalis or Porus biliarius, the Choler-paage, which is found even in thoe Animals which have no Gall-bladder, as the Hart, the Deer, the Camel, the Roe, the Dolphin, the Sea-calf, &c. It is a veel round and long, and the paage thereof is twice as large as the Neck of the Gall-bladder, and it goes right out from the Liver [being ometimes forked, yet o that its two branches do oon become one, according to the Obervation of Riolanus] through the common paage into the Gut (not into the Gall-bladder, as Fallopius conceived) receiving a thick cholerick excrement, which may plainly be perceived, if the aid paage be opened and blown up, for then the Gut wells, and not the Gall-bladder. And Riolanus oberved that ome have died of a Dyentery proceeding from Choler, in whom the Neck of the Gall-bladder was obtructed, but the Porus biliarius or Choler-paage, very much enlarged. Which alo was known to Galen, who will have Choler to be forced right forwards, even from the Liver into the Gut Duodenum: And next to Galen we are beholden to Fallopius for the true Decription of this Choler-paage.

The Ductus communis or commonDuctus communis, naturalis, the common paage natural, Paage, which goes into the beginning o • the Gut Jejunum, or
about the end of Duodenum, is made up of the Necks of the Choler-paage, and of the Gall-bladder, and is obliquely inerted between the two Coats of the Gut, the length of a finger, and omtimes it is parted into two, having looe Membranes, from the inmot and middle Coat of the Guts, before its Orifice. Where there is plenty of Choler, as in cholerick Natures, it often flows back into the Stomach, o that uch perons fating, are often griped in their Bellies.

Sometimes though eldom, this Paage goes into the bottom of the Stomach,Pre • ernatural. and there empties Choler. Whence proceeds Vomiting of Choler, and uch perons are termed Picrocholoi ano, Choler-vomitets. Which is eldom found in ravenous Beats, according to the Obervation of Argenterius; as alo in Dogs by the Obervation of Walaeus, contrary to the Opinion of Akakia. But in cae this paage be inerted into the end of the Gut Jejunum, uch perons are ever troubled with cholerick Loonees, and are termed Picrocholoi • ato, Choler-purgers by tool. Such as he mut needs have been, in whom the Choler-paage was inerted into the Gut Colon, as Severinus oberved, when he diected the aid party at Naples.

div.head: Chap. XVI. Of the Spleen.
div.p: LIen or Splen the Spleen, is eated underScituation of the Spleen, the hort Ribs on the left ide, jut over againt the Liver, as if it were a econd Liver, under the Midriff, between the Ribs and the Stomach, being in ome higher or lower then in others. Yet in all it is nearer to the hinder or back-part, eeing it retsSee Table XV. upon the Vertebraes and the batard Ribs, o that a man cannot feel it with his hand, unles it well, and o become nearer to the Belly-rim; and this cituation of the Spleen is eldom o changed, as to find the Liver in the left ide, and the Spleen on the right.

It is for the mot part only one, eldom two (as Aritotle oberves in the 4. de Generatione Its Number. Animalium, Chap. 4. And Posthius at Montpelier and Panarolus at Rome) and more rarely three one upon another, though not all of like bignes (as Fallopius oberved) but a mot rare cae it is for the Spleen to be wanting (as Aritotle hath oberved in the place forecited, and alo Laurentius and Schenkius concerning one Matthias Ortelius, and Hollerius in a certain Girle) nor can it naturally be wanting, becaue Nature abounds not in things uperfluous, nor is wanting in things neceary. That vulgar Opinion is therefore fabulous, whichWhether the Spleen may be taken out of the Body. holds that it may be taken out of the Body without danger of death, and that in uch as ued to run Races, it was uually taken out, which never any man yet aw or recorded, excepting Pliny, Flud, Fiorovanta, Rouetus, who if they peak truth, doubtles thoe perons made a very bad hift to live, or died oon after, for want of that mot noble Bowel, or only the outward part of their Spleen was cut off. For deep Wounds in the Spleen are to be accounted mortal, becaue of the plenty of Arteries, and the conent it hath with the principal Parts of the Body. This Conceit prung Quetionles from that old Opinion of Eraitratus, who conceived that Nature had made the Spleen in vain, which Opinion Plautus alo follows in his Comedy called the Merchant. And others follow them, who are o far to be born with, if they hall ay it is not neceary in reference to all kinds of Live wights, but only in repect of ome orts. For uch live Creatures as have no bladder do want a Spleen without detriment, as the Chamaeleon, and many others. Inects have no Spleen, and therefore that Proverbial Speech is fale: Habet & muca plenem, even a Flie hath a Spleen.

It is not o great as the Liver, yet in Mankind the Spleen is ufficiently thickWhy a man hath a large Spleen. and big, not o much becaue of the tubborn humor which it is to mater, and is hard to overcome, as becaue of the Arterial, fermentative, or leavening, and yeaty Blood, which it was to contain. For it is ix fingers long very near, three fingers broad, one finger thick, of which greatnes it is not found in any other living Creature. Yet is its bignes various, according to the variety of Subjects, and the everal Contitutions of Men. 'Tis thought to be larger in uch perons, as have Naturally a greater quantity of Melancholy or acid Juyce then others have, which flowing thereunto, it is oon augmented by reaon of its looe and pungie ubtance. Thoe perons whoe Spleen is over grown, are lean, and bad colored. Whence it was that the Emperor Trajan termed the Exchequer a Spleen, becaue as the Princes Excheque is inriched, the People are impoverihed; o as the Spleen increaes, the Body pines. They who conceive it elaborates the Chylus, do bring this for a reaon, viz. that it draws too much Ch • le by the Ramus plenicus, and defrauds the Liver. But becaue that Action of the Spleen is quetioned, another reaon mut be ought after. The mot renowned Conringius allows the Premies for true in a praeternatural greatnes of the Spleen, otherwie, if it be Natural and legitimate, the Body flourihes when the pleen does flourih.

Be the tate of the Spleen what it will, I conceive the Body is diminihed, when the Spleen is augmented, becaue it bereaves the ret of the Body of the fermentative acid Juyce, and either conumes it to nourih it elf, if it be naturally great; or is unable to prepare and expel it, when its greatnes is praeternatural and ickly.

Its Shape is for the mot part like on Oxes tongue, whence ome have called itIts Shape. linguoum Vious, the Tongue-bowel. On the outide towards the Ribs and the Midriff, it is a little bunching and boie; omtimes it hath marks made in it by the Ribs, being hollow on that ide, which is towards the right hand, by reaon of the tomach which lies cloe by it: Where all along the middle part, there is a certain white Line, with prominencies in it, which admits Veins and Arteries with the Caul. Howbeit, praeternaturally it receives undry Figures, viz. exactly round, triangular, harp-pointed, made rough with eminencies, divided into two parts; as Archangelus hath rightly oberved.

Its Color in a Child in the Womb is red,Its Color. like that of the Liver, becaue it is nourihed with pure Mothers Blood: But in perons come to age, it is blackih, becaue of the thick blood wherewith it is nourihed, and in uch as are yet older, it becomes black and blew. I have oberved it red in grown perons, and Vealius before me, as alo Spigelius who therefore beleives, that uch as have it blackih are unhealthy. Conringius thinks that black color is caued by Intemperance in eating, and in drinking epecially. I do attribute much to the temper of particular perons in this cae, and to the variety of Heat. Now the Spleen does praeternaturally put on many colors, according
to the Humor praedominant, as black and blew, ah-color, &c. In Beats of hot Contitution, it is blacker then in Mankind, and in Swine it is whiter.

It is knit by thin Membranes ariing from the Peritonaeum, to the PeritonaeumConnexion. it elf, the Call, and the left Kidney, omtimes alo to the Septum, which Fernelius denies, nor can he be excued, unles we hall ay he intended the Centre of the Midriff, for thereto it is not fatned. But in its hollow part, it is knit to the upper Membrane of the Caul, from which alo (according to others from the Peritonaeum, or as ome will have it, proper to it elf) it receives,

A Coat thin and ingle, yet thicker then the Membrane of the Liver, which in agedIts Coat. perons is oftentimes hardned, o as to become bony and gritly. It ought to be thicker, that it might be tronger to endure the force of the Arterial Blood.
Its Subtance or Parenchyma, is like thick, black, and congealed blood.Subtance.
It hath Veels of all kinds.

It hath from the Vena Porta a remarkableIts Veins. Trunk, which is called Ramus plenicus, cituate far beneath the Liver, and ent ath wart unto the Spleen. The numerous branches of this bough, being for the mot part mall as Fibres, are pent in the Spleen, aving two which ometimes pas out of the Spleen: The one is called Vas breve entring into the tomach, ometimes by one, otherwhiles by more branches [which more frequently, as Walaeus informs us, is a little branch of Vena plenica, which when it is come to the middle pace betwixt the tomach and the Spleen, it is divided forkwie into two twigs, one of which goes to the Spleen, the other to the tomach] which veel ome will have to belch out acid blood to provoke appetite, or to trengthen the tomach, which is afterwards voided by the Guts. Another branch goes unto the Fundament, and makes the internal Haemorrhoid Veins.

It hath many and great Arteries from aIts Arteries. branch of the Coeliaca, which the Liver hath not. 1. To cherih life and inbred heat. 2. That the Blood might be more trongly altered. 3. That for its own Nourihment, it might receive blood, and withal prepare acid Juyce brought thereunto, with Arterial blood, for to ferment the Chyle and all the Blood.

Now we are to take pecial notice of the frequent Anatomoes of the ArteriesIts Anatomoes. of the Spleen, with the Veins thereof, epecially one remarkable one, before the Entrance of the Veels into the Spleen: the ret are in the Spleen.
Alo we mut oberve its little Nerves, ariing from the left Cotal branch of the ixt pare, dipered rather through the Coat, then the Subtance thereof.

The Action of the Spleen is by uch Doctors as follow the old Opinion aid to be chiely threefold. 1. To draw melancholick, excrementitious, and limy Humors out of the Liver. 2. To eparate the melancholick Excrement there from, that it may be nourihed by the good blood. 3. To void it being eparated, into the Stomach and Guts. Alo they ay that the nutriment of the Spleen is elaborated and broken by the Arteries, becaue pongy and looe fleh ought to be nourihed with vaporous and ubtile blood. The Paages by which the melancholy Juyce is aid to be belched forth, are firt the Vas breve, and then the Haemorrhoidal Vein. They will have the Spleen therefore to be the Receptacle of the melancholick Excrement, or of thick dreggie Blood eparated in the Liver (even as the Gall-bladder receives the yellow Choler) and that therefore the Spleen is et jut over againt the Liver.
Howbeit I deny that the Spleen is ordained Whether the Spleen receive Melancholy from the Liver? only to receive an Exerement; For

list.item: 1. In the Spleen there is no large cavity receiving, as in the Gall-bladder, and in the membranous hollownes of the Kidneys, and in the Bladder.
2. If it were a Receptacle for Excrements, why was it not eated in an inferior place, that it might more conveniently receive the weighty Exerement as other Receptacles?

3. Rondeletius denving that the pleenThe argument of Rondeletius invalid. is the Receptacle of Melancholy, gives this reaon: becaue that humor while it is naturally dipoed, is all conumed upon the bony, and other hard and dry parts; and eeing it is in us the leat in quantity of all humors therefore there is no part ordained to receive it, no more then there is for bloody Excrements, which pas away by Sweat and inenible Tranpiration. Yet I conceive this Argument is not very trong.
4. Why are there no Branches of this Receptacle pred through the ubtance of the Liver, or at leat of the Ramus plenicus, even as the Gall-bladder receives Branches pred up and down the Liver?
5. Why are there not ome Paages, which carry this Juyce from the Liver.
6. No part is nourihed with an Excrement, notwithtanding the Saying of Columbus, that no part is nourihed with an Excrement aving the Spleen.
7. It is aburd that an Excrement hould flow back into the Vena porta, and afterwards into the Ramus plenicus.
8. It hould receive in, and purge forth Excrements, by the ame Paages.
9. The tronget reaon, that the Spleen is no Receptacle of Melancholy is, In as much as it is another Organ of Sanguification, as hall be proved by and by.

div.p: Later Anatomits have conceived, that the Spleen doth elaborate Blood, as theWhether the Spleen make Blood? Liver doth, but they are not agreed, touching the way, nor the Nature of the Chyle. Caparus Bartholinus my Father was of Opinion, that the Spleen did make a thick, but good ort of Blood, of the thicker part of the Chymus, which by an inbred Faculty it hath, it draws to it elf, through the Ramus plenicus. This he proved,

list.item: 1. By the likenes of the tructure of the Spleen, with that of the Liver. For as the Liver is a flehy Bowel, covered with a Coat, furnihed with very many Veels, the fleh whereof reembles blood, hed round about: Even o, the Spleen is a Bowel, furnihed with a Coat, and with very many Veels variouly interwoven, whoe proper fleh is as it were congealed blood, hed round about the Veels.

2. In the Spleen, there are very many textures of the Veels and infinite Anatomoes. Now there are no where uch textures, and plications, or foldings of the Veels, ave for a new elaboration, as may be een in the Brain, Liver, Stones, Duggs, &c.

3. It appears from the Scituation of the Ramus plenicus, which is far beneath the Liver, out of the Trunk of Vena porta, where part of the Chymus is attracted, or of the Chyle, which hath ome dipoition towards blood If therefore it receives matter there, of which blood is made, why therefore hall not the Spleen make blood?

4. Nature is wont either to double the Parts of the Body, and et one on each ide, as appears in the Kidneys, Stones, Lungs, Duggs, Organs of the Senes, &c. or if he makes only one, he is wont to place it in the middle. as the Heart, Stomach, Womb, Bladder, Noe, Tongue, Mouth, &c. Therefore the Spleen mut needs be another Liver.
5. Dieaes of the Spleen, as well as of the Liver, do hurt Blood-making or Sanguification.
6. Somtimes the Situation of the Liver is changed, o that it is in the left ide, and the Spleen on the right.

7. The Liver failing and growing les, the Spleen is augmented, and aits the Liver, as is known by many Examples, whence the Spleen hath been often een in Diections, to be greater and redder then the liver.

8. Tis unlikely that o many Arteries enter into the Spleen, for the ake of Excrements, but rather to diget & concoct thick Blood, that o by contrary thinnes, the tubborn thinnes of the aid Blood may be overcome.
9. In a Child in the Womb, the Spleen is red as is the Liver, by reaon of the caue aforeaid.
10. Such as the Dieaes of the Liver are, uch in a manner are thoe of the Spleen.
11. And the Dieaes of the Spleen and Liver, are cured well near with the elf ame Remedies.

12. If Authorities are of force, enter Aritotle in the 3. Book of the Parts of living Creatures, Chap. 7. where he aith, that the Liver and Spleen are of a like Nature; alo, that the Spleen is as it were an adulterate Liver, and where the Spleen is very little, there the Liver is Bipartite, or of two parts, and that all parts in the Body almot are double. Plato calls the Spleen an expres image of the Liver. Others call it the Livers Vicar, the left Liver, &c. The Author of the Book touching the ue of Repiration, hath confirmed this, as alo Apbrodiaeus, Araeteus, and others. Archangelus makes another ue of the Spleen to be, to make more plenty of Blood.

div.p: If any hall demand, To what • nd erves the Blood which the Spleen makes? For what Parts the Spleen makes Blood?
Some conceive it erves to the ame end, with that of the liver, viz. to nourih the whole body, and to ait the liver.
But he was of Opinion, that this was not done ave when neceity requires, in ome defect or Dieae of the Liver.

But he conceives that ordinarily the Spleen is an Organ to make blood, to nourih the Bowels of the lower Belly, as the Stomach, Guts, Call, Meentery, Sweetbread, &c. and that the Spleen it elf is nourihed with ome portion of the aid Blood, and ends the ret to the parts of the body. And he conceives that the liver makes blood for the ret of the parts, epecially the muculous parts. And he proves it,

list.item:
1. Becaue the bowels of the lower Belly receive their nourihment from the Vena plenica, or from the branches yueing therefrom, namely from the branches of Vena port •
only, and not from the Vena cava.
2. Becaue thoe bowels are thick, more earthy and bae: And uch as the like parts are not found in the body beides, and therefore thee parts tood in need to receive uch blood from the Spleen.

3. And therefore the liver is greater, becaue it makes blood for the whole body beides: The Spleen les, becaue it makes blood only for the lower Belly, ave when in caes of neceity it is forced to help the Liver.
4. In Dogs the Spleen is long and thin, becaue the Parts or Bowels of the lower Belly are maller in a Dog, and les wreathed and folded, then in a Man.

5. There is an evident difference between the Fat bred in the muculous Parts, or thoe which are nourihed by the Vena cava, and that dirty, and oon pu • rifiing Fat, which is bred in the lower Belly, as in the Cal, Guts, Meentery, &c. Hence arie o many Putrefactions in the meenterick Parts. And by how much an Humor is thicker (as is the muddie Fat we peak of) o much the ooner it putrifies: As the dreggie fat doth ooner, then the Fat in muculous parts. So the Blood of the Spleen is more dipoed to Putrefaction, then that of the liver, and this then the blood of the right Ventricle of the Heart. Moreover, the blood of the Arteries is les ubject to Putrefaction, then any of the former; and the Spirit leat of all.

6 He believes this to be a mot trong Argument, that where a part is found having the ubtance of the Bowels, there alo there are Veins from the Vena portae, or the branches of the Spleen: but where a part is coniting of muculous fleh, there are Veins which have their Original from Vena cava, as appears in the Intetinum rectum, in which by reaon of its twofold ubtance, Nature hath placed two orts of Veins. In the muculous Part, there are the external Haemorrhoid Veins, which arie from the Cava: In the • owellie or guttie ubtance, there are veins from the Vena portae.

div.p: Thee, and uch like Reaons prevailed with my Father of pious Memory, to prove that the Spleen drew Chymus, by the Ramus penicus. Which Opinion was at that time embraced by mot Anatomits, as Varolus, Pothius, Jeenus, Platerus, Baubinus, Sennertus, and Riolanus in his firt Anthropographia. But that Age deerves excue, as being ignorant of what Poterity hath ince found out. For the milkie veins dicovered by Aellius, do hew, that no Chyle thick or thin, is drawn by the Mearaick Veins, or carried any whether, but by the milkie Veins only to the Liver, and not to the Spleen. Moreover, a Ligature in live Diections declares, that nothing is carried through the Mearaicks to the Spleen, but contrariwie from the Spleen to the Mearaicks. Yet I allow thus much to the foreaid reaons, that there is a certain Generation of Blood made in the Spleen, by the manner hereafter to be explained, not of Chyle, which hath here no Paages, but of Arterial Blood, ent from the Heart.

Hofmaannus and Spigelius bring theWhether any portion of Chyle be carried to the Spleen, and what way? dreggie part of the Chyle, through the mearaick Veins unto the Spleen, that it may be there concocted into Blood. Who are in the ame fault. For the Arteries are ordained to carry blood to the Meentery, which is very manifet by Ligatures, and it is contrary to the coure of Nature, for the blood to be carried, and the Chyle brought back the ame way, leat they hould be mingled together. Moreover, in live Anatomits, there was never any Chyle oberved there. And the dreggie Portion of the Chyle, which no part tands in need of to nourih it elf, is more fitly purged out by the Guts.

Sperlingerus a learned Man, conceives that this work is performed by the milkie Veins, as to the Liver. Which were a ready way, if the milkie Veins do go to the Spleen, which no man as yet hath been able to oberve. Thoe that thought otherwie were deceived by nervie Fiberkies.

Others who very well aw, that the Meentery ent nothing to the Spleen, would have the Chyle to come right out from the Stomach to the Spleen, by waies manifet or hidden. They account the manifet waies to be the Vas breve, and its branches, by which the pleen ucks the more wa • ry part of the Chyle. But the Vas breve, carries acid Juyce from the Spleen, but nothing
to the Spleen, no more then the other Veins. Moreover, omtimes it is not inerted into the Spleen, but there is a Branch of the Splenica without it. I omit, that the Vas breve is never full of the white liquor. Daniel Flortius indeed hath in this cae ubtituted the Vena plenica, but contrary to Experience, and the Office of the Veins. The plenick Vein receives all its blood from the Spleen and its Arteries, and returns nothing, and therefore being bound in living Anatomies, it is filled, and wells towards the Spleen, according to the Obervation of Walaeus, but towards the Liver it is emptied. Howbeit Regius appeals to the Ligature, that the Vas breve wells betwixt the Ligature and the Stomach, and that it is lank between the Ligature and the Spleen. Bachius is nothing moved herewith, though he cannot untie the knot, and Hogeland is various in this Obervation; o that I much doubt, whether the Vas breve is alone o filled, before I hall ee it atteted by the Eyes of ome others.

Beides the Vas breve, Carolus Pio proves that the wheyih and potulent matter, is drawn out of the Stomach, by the Gatrick and Epiploick Veins; who was ignorant of the motion of humors in thee veins. Both the veels disburthen themelves into the Ramus plenicus, and then the blood is ent by a traight Paage unto the Liver, and returns unto the Spleen, without any hindrance of the Valves.

Thoe who are for hidden Paages, would force upon us, either the Pores of the Stomach, or a ditinct veel, to us as yet inviible and unknown. Among the former is Velingus, among the latter Conringius, who nevertheles differ, touching the Concoction of the Humor. Velingus will have the Spleen to make blood of the mor •
• arry Portion of the Chyle, with the earthy and limy parts mixed therewith, drawn by the inviible Pores, like the milkie veins, reting upon the tomach it elf, and the Pancreas. Conringius will have only the potulent liquor to pas by a veel to us inviible, by reaon of the cloe ticking of the Spleen to the tomach, and the Serum therein contained, which is not o white: Which Veel will at one time or other be dicovered. But all would be well, if thoe men that have eyes in their heads, would hew us either thoe Paages, or that peculiar Veel. The Pores are too narrow for the dreggie parts of the Chyle to pas through, and who can hinder them weating out ome other way, rather then into the Spleen? Many times when the Spleen tuck not o cloe to the tomach, I could ee no veel, nor could I ee any uch thing in a Youth, who having largely drunk, was here lately choaked with a bit of a Neates-tongue.

Howbeit, Reuner, Pio, and Conringius lately praied, do uppoe, that only potulent matter, is by the Spleen preently uckt out, and that therefore it makes only watry Blood ordinarily. But there is no trong and ufficient reaon for this Opinion, eeing there are no manifet Paages. Nor mut it only draw that which is thin, which both the Blood and Chylus tand in need of, as a vehicle or carrier, though it flow not alone, but is variouly mixed with groer matter, according to the Contitution of the blood; till having plaid its part, it is either eparated by the Kidneys, or weats through the whole Habit of the Body. If the wheyih moiture be praeternaturally eparated in the tomach, from the thicker Chyle, either it is voided by Vomit, and the groer Chyle wanting the help thereof to carry it, will make the Colick in the Guts, as I aw in our famous Wormius; or it is voided through the Pylorus, which is alwaies open for liquid meats, and uch as are eaily digeted, according to the Obervation of our mot deired Walaeus; much more after much drinking, which is omtimes in great Drinkers, quickly voided by urin, not paing through the Spleen, but through the Guts, if there be a conveniency of quality, thinnes of Humors, loones of the Veels, and trength of the attractive Faculty. All which conpiring, Aellius rightly avouches there is no way o long, which is not oon paed over. In uch as are otherwie contituted, Drink does not o oon lip away by Urin. For ome will drink all day, and never ue a Chamber-pot. In ome alo their Belly becomes looe, and the Drink goes away, quetionles, by the Guts. The blood, indeed, of Splenetick perons, is thin and warry, not that it comes uch immediately from the tomach, but the fault is in the whole blood, communicated by the Arteries to the Spleen. I pas over, how that thee are the igns of a diordered Spleen, from the praeternatural tate whereof, no good Argument can be drawn to prove any thing, touching its Natural condition; by which Anwer, all other Arguments brought by mot learned men, for this potulent Chylus are anwered.

It is a doubtful quetion, why onlyWhat Creatures have no Spleen uch Creatures have Spleens, which have Kidneys and Bladders, according to Aritotle, which Panarolus found true in a Chamaeleon. Is it becaue of the Attraction of wheyih Humors? I cannot beleive it. But they have no Spleen, becaue they make little blood, and therefore the wheyih Humor did not want peculiar Receptacles, but the Superfluities of the blood is pent upon Feathers, Skin, Scales, &c. They are therefore without a Spleen, becaue Fermentation was not neceary, in the imperfect Concoction of thoe kind of Creatures, who have a perpetual and Natural Lientery.

Riolanus hath lately in his Enchiridion out of all thee Opinions, hammer'd a mixt action of the Spleen, to attract limy Blood for its own Nourihment, and after that to pour out a certain particular fermentative Whey, through the plenetick Arteries into the tomach, and becaue its fleh is of a drinking Nature, to draw and uck uperfluous Liquor through the Veins out of the tomach. To which I have already anwered, part by part. The Action verily of the Spleen is more noble, then to receive uperfluous Humors out of the tomach. And through what Paages hould it do that? For the Office of the Veins is, to carry back the blood in the parts, out of the Arteries to the Trunk, according to the Doctrine of the Circulation, which Riolanus does here vainly oppoe. And Ligatures in living Anatomies do hew the ame.

Francicus Ulmus, Carolus Pio, and Aemilius Parianus, will needs have it that the Spleen makes Arterial blood, for the left Ventricle of the Heart, as the Liver doth for the right Ventricle. Which Opinion is coufuted, becaue, 1. There is no way by which the blood here made, can go into the left Ventricle of the Heart; for it cannot go by the Aorta, becaue of the Valves there placed at the mouth thereof. 2. There would •• a mixture of perfect and imperfect Juyce, if by the ame way, and at the ame time the Heart hould receive and return blood. 3. Many Creatures live without a Spleen, which generate Vital Spirits nevertheles.

Mr. De la Chambre in his Treatie of Digetion, uppoes that the Spleen makes Spirits for the ue of the Belly. But there is Spirit enough to nourih and vivifie the inferior Parts, upplied from the Aorta. But if he undertand ome qualification of the pirituous blood accommodated to the ue of the belly, he deerves to be excued.

Helmont a late Writer, hath detinedWhether the Spleen be an Organ of the enitive Soul? the Spleen for more noble Actions. He gives it out to be the eat of his Archeus, which being the immediate Organ of the enitive Soul, determines the Actions of the • i •• l Soul reiding in the tomach. He calls it the Seat. 1. Of the Undertanding, wherein the Conceptions thereof are formed, becaue it is of all the Bowels the fullet of Blood, and enriched with very many Arteries; and the Brain does only keep the Conceptions ent to it from the Spleen. 2. Of Sleep and Dreaming. 3. Of Venery, becaue Pollutions are in the dig •• ; and there about the tomach, the firt motions of lut are perceived: For they are aid to proceed out of the Loins, in which the Spleen is the principal Vital Member. Finally, perons troubled with the Quartan Ague, are not ubject to lut, becaue their Spleen is dieaed. 4. Of undry Dieaes, which are accounted to be Dieaes of the Brain and Chet, as the Tiick, Pleuriie, Apoplexy, Falling-icknes, Night-mare, Swimming of the Head, &c. But 1. All thee Conceits bottom upon a fale Foundation. 2. No ound Anatomit will grant that the tomach and not the brain is the eat of the Soul. 3. The Spleen is full of blood for other ues, that it may prepare acid blood for the fermentation of the whole blood and the Chylus. 4. There are Living-Creatures, that both leep, and are addicted to Venery without any Spleen, or though they have a Spleen, when the ame is dieaed. 5. Nocturnal Pollutions pring from an hot Contirution of the Spermatick Veels, and wheyih harp Blood, as the Diection of the aid Parts does declare. 6. That is rather to be affirmed touching the Kidneys in the Loins, as hall hereafter appear. 7. Other Parts in the Belly are dieaed beides the Spleen; in uch as have Quartan Agues. Yet it cannot be denied, but that the Spleen does ait in ome meaure, by adminitring acid blood 8. The Spleen is but the remote eat of the foreaid Dieaes, by reaon of Vapors raied from thence; but proper Dieaes which pring not from Sympathy, do primarily depend upon the Brain.

The lat and truet Opinion, is that of Walaeus, my quondam mot worthy The Opinion of Walaeus touching the ue of the Spleen. Mater, founded upon ocular Inpection, and mot certain reaon. He finding in live Anatomies no motion of Humors through the Ramus plenicus of Vena portoe to the Spleen, did certainly conclude, that it was unlikely, that either Melancholy or Chyle is carried out of the Liver into the Spleen, by the Ramus plenicus; and that therefore the Spleen receives no melancholick Excrement from the Liver, not that any blood is made in the Spleen of Melancholy or Chylus. But contrariwie he oberved alwaies, that all the blood was carried, both wiftly and trongly enough perpetually out of the Spleen into the Liver, as alo the blood which comes out of the Haemorrhoidal Vein, the Vas breve, and other Veins which are joyned to the Ramus plenicus. And that there is no motion of Humors to the Spleen, unles by the Ramus plenicus of the Arteria Coeliaca: And therefore the Spleen does not receive any matter to change and alter from any place, ave the Arteria Coeliaca. And he conceives that it is mot likely, that the blood being further to be perfected, is diolved by the Heat of the Heart, and that when it is forced from the Heart, through the Coeliacal d •• eries into the Spleen, the whole mas of blood is not retained by the Spleen, but as the Gall-bladder contains only Choler, o the Spleen holds only the acid or harp part of the Blood, which you may call Melancholy, jut as we ee the acid Spirit eparated from things that are ditilled: And that the aid acid Humor is perfected by the Spleen, by means of which the Spleen appears black and acid. And that this harp humor is afterwards mingled with Blood in the Veins, and with Chyle in the Stomach, and makes them thin: And that therefore the Spleen being obtructed, gros Humors are multiplied in the Body, not becaue thick Humors are not drawn by the Spleen, which naturally are never found there; but becaue the Spleen cannot communicate that attenuating acid Humor to the Blood or Chyle. And that as much of this acid Humor, as is unfit for Digetion, is voided with the Serum by Urin, for uch acid Liquors, as Vinegar, Spirit of Sulphur, &c. are eaily mingled with Water; and the aid acid Humor by Ditillation may again be eparated from the Urin.

In as much therefore as the SpleenHow the Spleen may be aid to be the eat of Laughter. draws the harp part of the blood out of the Heart, and •••• ds it prepared to the Meentery, that the ret thereof being to be wrought by the Liver, may become more pure and clear; the Opinion of the Ancients may be allowed, which held the Spleen to be the eat of Laughter. For the cheerfuller, and livelier Animals, or live Wights, have great pleens; the more lacivious have great livers; the gentler have little galbladders; the fearfuller have great hearts, and the loudet, have large lungs, &c. Whence that Vere had its Original.

q.l: Cor ardet, pulmo loquitur, fel commovet iras,
Splen ridere facit, coget amare ecur.
Heart fears, Lungs peak, the Gall moves' anger fel,

Spleen makes us laugh, Tis called Lover in the North of England, & poibly that is the Etymology of the Word.
Liver doth Love compel.

div.p: The Spleen therefore perpares blood to accommodate the Bowels of the lower Belly, and of the whole Body after the manner aforeaid. And the excrementitious part of the blood, which cannot be eparated by the Spleen, if it be thin and watery, it is purged out. 1. By the Arteries, not only to the Guts, but alo to the Kidneys by the emulgent Veins. Hence in Dieaes of the Spleen, Urins are many times black, for which caue in uch caes we adminiter Diureticks. And plenerick and melancholick perons o called, abound with wheyih Humors, as is well known from Hippocrates and Galen, for erum ought to be the vehicle or carrier of the groet Humor. Hence is it, that perons troubled with the Quartan Ague, do mot plentifully weat and pis: Alo when it is very plentiful, by the Haemorrhoid Veins. 2. By the tomach, whence in the S • urvey, the Patients pit exceedingly, as alo in the Quartan Ague, o that Galen places pitting and pawling among the igns of that Dieae. Hence alo melancholick perons are wont to be extream pitters. Now it comes from the Spleen to the tomach, not only by the Vas breve, but alo by other near Veels.

If the Excrement of the Spleen beHow its thick. thick and earthy, it is voided directly by the Fundament, and comes not at the tomach, for 1. From Melancholy as Galen cells us, comes the blacknes of the Excrements. 2. By reaon of its weight and heavines, it etles downwards. 3. The evacuation of Melancholy by the internal Haemorrhoid
Veins, does free men from melancholick Dieaes preent, and preerves from future, as the divine Hippocrates teaches in many places.

div.head: Chap. XVII. Of the Kidneys.
div.p: A Threefold Excrement is purgedThe threefold excrement of the Blood. from the Blood; thin Choler into the Gall-bladder, thick Choler into the Canalis bilarius, and Whey into the Kidneys. And becaue we have already poken of the Receptacles of the two former Excrements, we hall now alo peak of the third.

The Kidneys are termed RENES, fromThe true Expoition of the Kidneys. flowing, becaue the Matter of Urin does flow through them. In Greek they are termed Nephroi, as if you would ay Piers: From which Etymology that taken out of Varro, differs not much. viz. that they are called R • n • s, as if you would ay Rivuli Rivole • s or little Springs.

The Kidneys are two in number,Their Number becaue among all Excrements, the wheyih is mot plentiful, and exceeds the two excrementitious Cholers, by reaon of the Blood, whoe vehiculum it was to be, until it come into the large Veins of the Cava; and that one being dieaed, the other
might draw the wheyih Humor;Whether when one Kidney is dieaed the other ceaes to perform its office? but I am not of the Opinion of Beverovi • ius and of Loelius after him, that one Kidney being dieaed, the other draws the wheyih Humor. For the contrary is een in uch as have one Kidney only topped with a great tone, or conumed by an Ulcer; and the contrary to what he imagines, is een in other parts, for one Eye being hurt, the other ees; and all the collups of the Lungs being conumed on one ide, that on the other ide does further Repiration, unles haply both parts be affected by ome common Caue, for otherwie they mut be forced to ay, that that happens only omtimes. There is eldom found only one, and then it is a great one placed in the middle, for otherwie the body hould not be well ballanced, nor could the Veels be conveniently carried. Tis montruous, when both the Kidneys are joyned into one beneath, and cleave together, as I have een at Padua. Tis more rare to find three or four placed one upon another, or one beneath another.

They are ituate under the Liver and Spleen, where they ret upon theTheir Situation. Mucles of the Loins, between the two Coats of the Peritonaeum, at the ides of the Vena cava and Arteria magna, under which very great Nerves lie hid, both of the Mucle Poas, and others, which evidently pas this way unto the Thighs. Whence it is that a tone being in the Kidney, a numnes is felt in the Thigh of the ame ide. It is a rare cae which Cabrolius hath oberved, for the Kidneys to ret upon the Back-bone of the Loins. Nor are the Kidneys eated jut one againt another,Which Kidney is the highet? leat there hould be ome impediment to attraction, and leat ome part of the wheyih humor hould lip aide. But the rightide Kidney is lowet in Men, to give way to the Liver, under which it rets immediately, reaching by its end, the third Vertebra of the Loins. It is eldom higher then the left, and eldom are the two Kidneys eated one jut againt another. The left Kidney for the mot part, lies partly under the pleen, but is eldom higher then the pleen. Contrariwie in Brutes, the pleen goes more downwards, and the right Kidney lies higher, and therefore there is a Cavity in the Liver by means of the Kidney, which does not Naturally happen in men. Here ome oberve that the right Kidney is nearer to the Cava, and the left more remote, by reaon of the left Emulgent Vein, which is much longer then the right.

They are not alwaies both jut of one bignes, but for the mot part they are.Their Bignes. They are commonly of the length of four Vertebra's; their latitude for the mot part, three fingers, their thicknes that of a thumb, yet the right Kidney is very many times larger then the left, becaue by reaon of the heat of the right part, it draws the wheyih blood more vehemently, unles it be fretted by ome Dieae, for then it grows lean and thin. Alo uch as are given to flehy deires, have larger Kidneys then ordinary. But their Proportion is not alwaies alike convenient for the body.

The Surface of the Kidneys, as in the liver is lippery and mooth: It is eldomSurface. in Mankind uneven, as if it were compoed of many Kidneys or kernels, which any man may frequently find in a Child yet in the Womb. But the Kidney is alwaies o made, in an Ox and Bear, in a Calf, and mot curiouly of all in a Sturgeon, in which the Kidneys are made up like bunches of Grapes, of triangular and quadrangular dies or tiles as it were after an Artificial manner, as I have demontrated in the Anatomy of that Creature.
The Colour of the Kidneys is a darkTheir Colour. red, but eldom intenely red. In dieaed perons the Kidneys are variouly coloured, even as the Liver and Spleen are.

The Kidney is haped like a kidney-bean oShape. called, alo like an Aarum leaf, if you repect the plane urface. Externally in the Back or about the Flanks, it is of a round, bunching hape beneath towards the upper and lower part it is boie, but in the middle concave and hollow. Helmont hath een the left Kidney triangular, and in the ame peron the right Kidney not o big as an Hazel-nut. Hippocrates compares the kidneys to Apples: Without doubt to the broader ort of red Apples; unles by the word meloiin he intended the likenes of the kidneys in man to other Creatures.

They are knit by an external Membrane,Connexion. which is from the Peritonaeum, to the Loins and Midriff, and by the emulgent Veels to the Cava and Aorta Veels, by the Ureters to the Bladder. And the right kidney, to the blind Gut, omtimes alo to the Liver, the left to the Spleen and Colon. Hence pains of the kidneys are exaperated by plenty of Winds and Excrements.

They have a double Membrane: TheMembranes. firt internal one near and proper, being very thin without Fat and Veins, from the external and common Coat of the ingredient Veels dilated (for a Vein only goes in with but one Coat) which growing very cloe, makes the fleh more compact, and being turned back inwards, it accompanies the Veels, enters into, and invets their Bellies. Another external from the Peritonaeum, which adhaeres but looely, whence they term it the Swath-band of the kidneys. For it is as it were a coverlid or blanket of the kidneys; and becaue it is encompaed with much Fat, for the ake thereof, it hath received the Vena adipoa o called, that is to ay the Fat-vein, o that in fat perons, the kidneys lie quite hidden. Whence he that knows or earches into hidden things, is aid toWhat it is to earch the Reins? earch the Reins. For the Scripture ues two words Pela • oth and Ta • oth, the former of which Mercerus will have to be derived from a word ignifying to perfect and finih, becaue there is in the Kidneys a power of conulting, and finihing things conulted upon: The latter they derive from Tiach a blot, and from the Radical word tivvach to daub, or plater, and crut over, becaue the Kidneys are cruted, and hidden as it were with Fat. Some indeed explain the Phrae of earching the Reins to be meant of Concupicence carnal and venereal Delectation, from the word Calah to deire, Witnes Rabbi David, and Pagnine, or from Celi a Veel, becaue in and from the Kidneys is the deire of Venereal pleaures. Howbeit this alo is a ecret Quet, toln pleaures Venereal eeking the night and dark places and ecret carriages, which I have largely demontrated in my Vindicae anatomicae againt Hofman. Fat is betowed upon them to preerve the Heat of the Kidneys in regard of plenty of Serum which would overcool them, and to defend the Veels. There is les about the right Kidney if we beleive Aritotle, more about the left, becaue the Heat of the right Kidney, either uffers it not to congeale, or melts it when it is congealed.

They have a ubtance or fleh hard compactSubtance. and dene. <…> like that of the

page 46 Heart, but not o fibrous, becaue the Fibres of the veels are there. But on both ides of the internal Cavity, the Fat being removed, there appears a looe ubtance, uneven and hollow. This fleh omtimes is conumed and putrefies, whence comes worms in the kidneys. In a Dog I have een a worm o great in the right kidney which lay hid like a nail, that beide the external Coat of the kidney, there was none of the fleh left.

The kidneys have two Bellies as it were,Their Bellies. the outermot in the hollow part which Fallopius calls Porta; through which the emulgent veels are carried, and firt they enter bipartite or divided into two, and oon after they are commonly divided into four, and o pread abroad into the whole ubtance of the kidneys, till at lat they are conumed and pent into very mall and fine threads. The inner Belly is nothing but the large Cavity of the Ureter, that is to
ay a membranous Cavity, made of the Ureters, pred out and widened in the Cavity of the kidneys. But the Ureters in their progres are not attenuated within, as other Veels are, but they have the ends of their branches (eight or ten for the mot part) broad and open like Pipes, embracing certain Caruncles, or little flehy Eminences.

Thee Caruncles are like kernels, les coloured and harder then the ret ofThe Caruncles. the fleh. Carpus was the Finder out of them, though Rondeletius aies that he did firt oberve them, and calls them Mammilary productions. Others call them Papillary Caruncles, becaue they are very like the Nipples upon Womens Duggs: They are as big as Peae, omwhat broad above, convex beneath, and they have very little holes bored through them, o that they will hardly permit an hair to enter, which furrows and little channels may be oberved, if the kidneys be cut long-wie. I have intead of thee found tones in an Ox. The holes were to be exceeding mall, leat the blood which is requiite to nourih the kidneys, hould with the Serum and Choler flow into the Ureters, which indeed happens when the kidneys are dieaed or the Paages too open.

They have Veels of all kinds. Veins from the Cava. 1. The emulgent or milking Veins o called from their Office, which are greatThe emulgent Veins and Arteries. and remarkeable by reaon of aboundance of wheyih humor in the Body: In which Baubinus aith there are Valves to be een, which hinder the returnA Valve in the Vein. of erum into the Vena cava. But Experience teaches otherwie, for with their broad end they look towards the Cava, and with their harp and lunary part they repect the kidneys, by which they are opened, according to the Opinon of Dr. Harvey, which I have found true, and demontrated by viible Inpection, o that any matter may eaily repas, from the kidneys by the Emulgents to the Vena cava, in the olemn Circulation of the Blood. By a hort and crooked paage they are carried downwards to the hollow part of the kidneys, as alo the emulgent Arteries, which are remarkable and large, derived from the Trunk of the Aorta, unto the kidneys, not o much to furnih vital Heat, to reit coldnes, as to nourih the kidneys, and to purge away the wheyih humor, which is mot plentifully contained in the Arterial blood. For thee emulgent Veels are eldom one like another, or one in number, omtimes with ix, five, four, three, and for the mot part two branches, they go ditinctly to the kidneys, and that either on the one or both ides, eldom on one alone. And when they have entred the hollow part of the kidney, each branch is uddenly ubdivided into four or five little ones, which being again divided into other leer ones, they are at lat pent into Veins and Arteries as mal as hairs, which end at the the Heads of the Caruncles, into which they hed their wheyih humor, that it may ditil into the little Pipes of the Ureters: Yet are the Emulgents never opened at the Pipes of the Ureters. For wind or water being forced in, it flows indeed through the Emulgents, but it goes not out by the Pipes. Into the left Emulgent in ome bodies there is implanted a branch of the Vena azugos o called, which is thought to be the caue of that Conent which is between the Chet and the Kidneys, which the Arteries do not a little further.

2. The Venae adipoae. The right being drawn from the Emulgent, eldomVenae adipoae. from the Trunk, the left from the Cava to the outward Coat, which contain blood to nourih the Fat. Moreover, the kidneys need no other Veels to nourih them beides the Arteries, as the Veica bilaria or Choler-bladder, and the Pis-bladder; for they do not draw a pure Excrement as thoe do.

The Kidney hath one very mall Nerve on each ide, from the StomachbranchTheir Nerves. of the ixt pare, ditributed into its proper Membrane, whence ariesWhy uch as have a tone in their kidney are ubject to vomit? the Sympathy between the kidneys and the tomach, as when perons dieaed in their kidneys, are troubled with tomach-icknes and vomiting. But there are a few branches of Nerves, which proceed from about the beginnings of the Arteries of the Meentery, part of which enters into the hollow of the kidneys with the Emulgents, and is dieminated through their ubtance. Hence perons having the tone in their kidneys, have more vehement gravative and tretching pains: But their pain becomes more harp, when the tone enters into the narrow and very enible Ureters.

Now this is the tructure of the KidneysThe tructure of a Dogs kidney. in Mankind. For in a Dog it is otherwie, in whoe kidneys there are other Cavities; but in the kidneys of a Man there are none, ave what are formed by the Emulgents and Ureters variouly divided.

Alo there is a feigned Dream of omeThe Cribrum benedictum of the Ancients. of the Ancients, touching the Cribrum benedictum by them o called. For they feigned that there were in the kidneys, two Cavities eated according to their length: The one uppermot, into which the wheyih blood hould be poured out of the Emulgents, the other lowermot, which a certain tranvere Membrane was thought to ever like a eive bored through with very mall holes, which made them call it the Colander, and the bleed eive, through which they would have the Serum trained into the Ureters, and the good blood to tay behind to nourih the kidneys. Thee Dreams of the Ancients Vealius did rightly reject;The Error of Vealius. but he is mean while deceived, while he would have uch Cavities in the kidneys of men, as there are in Dogs kidneys, and wil not have the kidneys of a man or heep to be cut up, becaue of the Fat. Riolanus defends this Opinion of the Colander or Seive, but he explaines it only of the Caruncles (as I do) which are pierced through with very mall holes.

Their Ue. Eraitratus and the followers Aritoles Error touching the ue of the Kidneys. of Aclepiades did conceive that Nature had made the kidneys in vain. And Aritotle omtimes aies, that there is no need of them. But

Their Ue is to draw the wheyihHow the Urin is made? blood, by the emulgent Arteries, that o the mas of blood may be purged. The blood therefore going out through thee Veels, is alwaies carried through the branches of the Emulgents, which are pred abroad through the whole fleh of the kidneys, and go at lat into very mall paages, o that at lat the wheyih Humor is poured right out into the fleh of the kidneys: But the anguine and laudable portion, does partly remain to nourih the kidneys, and partly returns by little emulgent Veins which are open into the Cava, and o to the Heart. The wheyih and watry part is trained through the Papillary Caruncles, which have holes into the branches of the Ureters, which grow together into one large Cavity or Expanion of the Ureter, into which the wheyih
humor is emptied, and through the Ureters into the Bladder, where it becomes urin. And becaue urin is yellow, a portion of yellow Choler not drawn out by the Gall-bladder, is thought to pas along with the Serum or wheyih humor that the Ureters might be clened by Choler, as the Guts are.

Olhafius, Sennertus, Olaus Wormius, whom a great many others have followed,Whether the Kidneys prepare Seed? as Hofman, Meybome, Hortius, Loeleus, Eichtadius, Sperlinger, and others have attributed to the Kidneys the preparation of Seed, becaue hot Kidneys caue a propenity to flehy lut, and cold Kidneys indipoe to Venery, and becaue in Creatures that ue Venery, the kidneys have a rank mell and tat of Seed, which in guelded Animals they have not. Becaue in a Gonorrhaea proceeding from aboundance of Sperm, Remedies are uccesfully applied to the kidneys: becaue men are aid to proceed from the Loins of their Progenitors, and they have been famed for the eat of Lut: Becaue the Loins being whipped, do raie an Appetite to Venery: And finally becaue in perons given up to lut, the kidneys are conumed. Which Arguments are indeed of ome weight, unles peradventure that mell and rat happen to the kidneys, becaue they are nourihed with uch a nutriment as is the matter of Seed, which is carried for the Generation thereof in bordering Veels. And when the kidneys are hot or cold, the neighbouring places are alo hot or cold, through which the matter of Seed is carried, and in which it is altered, and therefore Seed may have affinity to the Contitution of the kidneys. For Johannes Walaeus conceivesThis Opinion reconciled with the Doctrine of Circulation. that the Circulation of the blood cannot admit this ue of the kidneys, for blood is not carried from the kidneys to the tones, by the Emulgents and Veins: but it falls down only out of the Aorta by the Spermatick Arteries. But this action of the kidneys defended by uch Learned men, may be reconciled with the circular motion of the blood, if we hall ay. 1. That the more wheyih part of the Arterial blood is drawn by the kidneys through the emulgent Arteries, whereby the ret which decends right along through the Spermatick Arteries, becomes more pure and fitter to make Seed. Of which this is a ign, that when the attraction of the kidneys is weak, and the blood comes to the tones more wheyih then it ought to be, the eed which is voided, is unfit for Generation, though plentiful in quantity. 2. That the neighbouring Spermatick Veels are irradiated and virtuated by the kidneys, even as the Brain irradiates the lower Parts, by an inbred property reembling light. 3. If any thing hould be carried from the kidneys to the tones, we might very well ay, it is a wheyih ubtance, which tirs up a harp titillation and trong provocation and deire to Venery. For I am not perwaded by the Arguments of Helmont, that the alt of the Urin takes away the fruitfulnes of the Seed, if it be moderate, eeing it helps the Seed both by its acrimony and fluidity or thinnes of ubtance. Little Birds, indeed, though very lacivious, have neither kidneys nor bladder; yet they have omwhat that upplies the Office of the kidneys, viz. certain Caruncles or little parcels of fleh, which reemble the kidneys, which are continued with the Vena cava and Aorta, Witnes Aritotle and others.

Beverovicius artributes a kind of Sanguification or Blood-making toWhether the Kidneys make Blood? the kidneys. 1. Becaue they have a Parenchy •• and very many Veels. But they might have their Parenchyma becaue of their Veels, that they might not be intangled one with another. And it was requiite they hould have very many Veels, to the end they might plentifully purge away the Serum or wheyih part of the Blood, o that through very many and very mall outlets, the Whey might be iued out into the Caruncles, without any coniderable quantity of Blood therewith. 2. Becaue the Kidneys which in healthy perons are red, clear, olid; according to the kind of the Dieae, become omtimes obcure and blackih, omtimes whiteih; otherwhiles looe, brittle, and as it were rotten; and omtimes again, hard and dried. But that might happen, becaue as ome other parts, o the kidneys might be ick, or through icknes of the Body, Concoction being omwhere hurt, they could not be nourihed with good blood. 3. Becaue the Urins of perons troubled with the tone are crude: But of that another caue is commonly rendred. Viz. in that the kidneys being topped, the thinner part only of the Urin can make its way forth. 4. Becaue perons troubled with the tone are wont to well and look pale, like thoe that are termed Leucophlegmatici. But this may eaily happen, becaue the kidneys either through weaknes cannot ufficiently draw the wheyih humor out of the blood, or being topped it cannot be duely expelled. But if he or any other hall affirm, that allowing the Circulation of the blood in thee parts, the blood is there omwhat more changed, then it was in its imple Veel, I hall not diagree with them therein. For themelves it is that they change the blood, but it is for the ret of the body only, that they purge out the wheyih Excrement.

div.head: Chap. XVIII. Of the Capulae Atrabilariae, or Blackcholer Caes.
div.p: THee Veels are by mot Anatomits neglected and not oberved, though they are evermore found in all Bodies, what ever Archangelus aies to the contrary. Nor mut we ay that thee Capulae are made of a uperfluous Matter, as a ixt finger ues to be.

We are beholden to Bartholomew Eutachius Their firt finder out. for the firt dicovery of thee mall Bodies, who mentions them by the name of Kernels, and after him Archangelus and Bauhinus. Caerius cals them Renes uccenturiatos Deputy-kidneys or Auxiliary kidneys. I hall call them, in regard of the ue I allot them, Capulas atrabilarias, Black-choler Caes.
Now thee Caes are o cated, that they ret upon the upper part of the kidneys on the outide, where they look towards the Vena cava, being covered with Fat and Membranes.

Their number is the ame with thatTheir Number. of the kidneys. For upon each kidney there rets a Cae. I have once een four of them, of which the two greater being four quare were eated above, and the two maller being round, uneven, and rough, were placed beneath the emulgent Veins.

Their Magnitude is not alwaies alike; commonly that on the right ideTheir Magnitude. is bigger then that on the left, yet omtimes the latter is bigger then the for
•…
In a Child new born, they are near as big as the
kidneys, peradventure becaue they are moiter then ordinary, and contain a more thin melancholy Juyce, which becaue they do not trongly enough expel, but treaure it up rather, therefore thee Caes are widened. But in grown perons they are traitned, and become les, though they abound more with Melancholy, partly becaue the Melancholy being gathered by degrees, is through the trength of nature by degrees expelled; partly, becaue the Serum in hotter perons is dried up, wherewith the new born Infant abounded; and partly becaue as the Reins grow bigger, they are compreed. Yet I have once oberved them in a grown peron, by reaon of aboundance of black Choler, twice as big as ordinary, whereas commonly they are no bigger then a large vomiting Nut.

They have an apparent internal Cavity, both in perons grown and newbornTheir Cavity. babes, compaing the inner circumference of the whole Cae as it were, in which they are found to contain a dreggie and black humor, o that even the inner ides are coloured with the aid blacknes. In Infants I have een to my thinking wheyih blood in them. I admire that Riolanus could not, or would not ee this Cavity, for though he cries that it is o mall, that it will hardly admit a little Pea, yet is it omtimes wider, and alwaies o large, as to contain many peaen compreed, and we can thrut a Probe into it, this way and that way, without violence. It contains therefore a large Cavity, repecting the malnes of its Body. Nor hath Nature ever labour'd in vain, no not in the mallet paces of the Capillary Veins. It is a mall matter which they can hold, yet it may be counted much, becaue it is ucceively received in, and cat out again. This Humor might have been indeed allayed and weetned by the admixture of blood, as Choler alo might, yet Veels and Receptacles are ordained for both thee Excrements, that the blood might not be polluted.

In Shape and Subtance they many times reemble the kidneys, ave thatTheir Shape and Subtance. their ubtance is a little looer; o that they eem little kidneys reting upon the great ones. Which perhaps was the Reaon that Caerius did call them Auxiliary kidneys: But more frequently their ubtance is flat like a Cake (howbeit hollow within) and their hape is round-long and omwhat quare. Somtimes they are three corner'd, eldom round; for they are eldom een in one and the ame hape.

They are knit where they ret unto the external Membrane of the kidneysTheir Connexion. o fat, that negligent Diecters, when they take out the kidneys, leave them ticking to the Membrane of the Diaphragma or Midriff. And this is the Reaon that many oberve them not.

They have Veels: Veins, and Arteries, derived to them from the middle of theTheir Veels. Emulgents. Somtimes alo a Vein is ent thither from the kidney, and omtimes alo a branch near the Liver from the Cava is brought thereto, omtimes alo from the Vena adipoa, and omtimes from all thoe places, omtimes with a ingle, otherwhiles with a double branch. Somtimes they have a ingle Artery from the Emulgents, omtimes a double one; and otherwhiles they have from the Trunk of the Aorta, one while a ingle branch, otherwhiles three together.

Thee Caes have Nerves alo. For about the beginnings of the Arteries of the Meentery, ome branches of Nerves mixed together are produced, one part of which goes unto the kidneys, and thee Caes which ret upon them.

Their ue hath been hitherto unknown.The ue according to the Authors Opinion. If it may be allowed to conjecture, as doubtles it is, due conideration being had to the Structure and Paages; we may ay, that a thick and excrementitious black-cholerick humor, is detained in thee Caes, which had not been purged from the Blood made in the Liver, or Spleen, or both, but epecially that blood which we formerly proved to be made in the Spleen; which is here kept and digeted, becaue it could not pas through the narrow waies of the kidneys. Nor let the acending of an heavy ubtance trouble us, which ever and anon happens in the Body, by means of the expulive and attractive Faculty of ome Part; yea and vehement attraction is advantaged by the highnes of Situation in motions Spiritual. Hence alo peradventure it is that Urins are omtimes black, when at any time this Humor is collected in the Caes, in too great a quantity. Where alo may be often doubtles, the eat of ome morbifick caue, epecially of Melancholy. And the reaon why melancholick perons are thereby little pained, is becaue the mallnes of the Nerves, and the thicknes of the Humor, do render the Sene dull. The renownedAccording to Velingus.
Velingus agrees with me in this ue, but he hews not whence, nor how the humor comes. For he conceives they help to draw the wheyih humor, and that they treaure up a parcel of black Choler, which furthers the eparation of Whey from the Blood, like Runner. Olhafius will have them to receive theAccording to Olhafius. thick and terretrial Excrements of the kidneys, which remain after their Digetion. And therefore becaue a greater Bowel hath more Excrements then a leer, the Conceptacle for the right kidney was to be larger, and that for the left leer, and therefore the right ide Cae is greater then the left ide, becaue the right kidney is greater then the left. But no man hath thought of the waies by which the black blood hould be dicharged into thee Capulae or Caes. The Arteries do eaily occur to uch as hold the Circulation of the blood. For according to the old Opinion, a way is readily found to thee Capulae from the Emulgent, or from the Trunk of the Aota it elf, which bringing Nutriment uch as it is, do withal unlade the Excrement of the Arterial blood, which was not evacuated formerly. But how it returns out of the Capulae, howHow the Humor comes out of the Caes into the Kidneys. it comes to the kidneys to colour the urins black, is not o eaie to hew, for the Veins end in the Emulgents, or in the Cava it elf, eldom in the kidneys, and o either they hould perpetually keep that excrementitious Juyce, which is unlikely, or end it back again to the Cava and the Heart, or they ought, verily, to enter the kidneys directly by the Emulgent Veins, without any hindrance by the contrary motion of the blood going out of the kidneys. This contrary motion a thicker and tronger humor can eaily overcome, manifold branches alo oppoing the ame, as in Rivers we now and then ee waters run contrary to the tream, by the banks and in the middle, by reaon of ome fountains opened. But oftentimes the Vein of the right ide Cae, is immediately inerted out of the Trunk • f the Cava. And in uch a chance, truly, either Capula or Cae is not ufficiently purged, whence aries ome hidden Dieae; or the circular motion •… e there neglected, which in the
