mallet Veels doth frequently vary; or if it mut be Religiouly oberved, we mut here conceive a Reverberation of the Kidneys; for the Blood flowing back out of the Kidneys through the Emulgent Veins up to the Cava, becaue it dicharged only Whey and no thicker Juyce in the kidneys, it ininuates it elf by the Vein next the Capula, and coming back out of the Capula by the little Arteries, with the Emulgent Arteries it goes again to the kidneys, and from thence is purged by urin. He that can give the bet Conjecture, let him be counted the bet Prophet. Spigelius whom Laurenbergius of Rotoch, does Their ue according to Spigelius & Laurenbergius. faithfully imitate, has aigned other ues to thee Capulae. 1 To fill the empty pace between the Kidneys and the Midriff. 2. To prop up the Stomach, in that place which is above the emulgent Veins and Arteries. But I anwer, 1. Nature makes, nor does nothing in vain or inconiderately, much les doth he appoint a noble animated Part, only to fill a pace, which he might have filled by making the kidney a little bigger. 2. Thee props would have been too weak by reaon of their malnes. Nor hould this ue belong to the Stomach alone, but to other neighbouring Parts. Riolanus writes that they have no ue in grown perons,Whether they have any ue in grown perons. but that after the Child is born they become ueles, and therefore we mut eek for their ue in the Child in the Womb, when it is great, whoe kidneys being void of Fat, the Juyce ordained to breed kidney-fat, is received into thee Caes. But, 1. Their Cavity, Veins, Arteries, Humors, &c. will not allow us to ay they are withered up in grown perons. 2. The ue of the Navil-veels ceaes, becaue the Child is no longer to be tied to its Mother, nor to draw its nutriment from her. And that thee Ca •… r Capulae are erviceable to grown perons, was •… ed before, for • therwie their Veins, Arteries, •… uld be • o •… end. 3. That the kidneys of Children in the Womb hould be alwaies void of Far, I have found to be fale. 4. The kidney-fat is never made of that wheyih black Juyce, and hardly any man ever aw an oylie Juyce in thee Capulae.

div.head: Chap. XIX. Of the reters, or rin-channels.
div.p: THe Ureters or Urin-carryers, areThe Ureters. round-long Veels or Channels, ariing out of the Kidneys, planted into the Bladder, into which they carry the Urin from the Kidneys.

The Ureters are commonly two in Number, on each ide one, omtimesTheir Number. two, & omtimes more, yet al growing into one before their Inertion, as alo Carolus Stephanus oberved in a certain Body. But the far renowned Riolanus, in a body infected with the venereal Pox, aw two Ureters on either ide, inerted into the bladder at •… s places, the one towards the neck, the other in
the bottom thereof. Salomon Albertus oberved three on the right ide, and but one on the left. I have frequently oberved the like difference, as among other things I hew in my Rare Anatomical Hitories.

Their Situation. They run through many parts in their beginning, middle,Their Situation. and end. Their beginning is in the kidneys themelves, what ever Hofman, Riolanus, Laurenberg, and Plempius ay to the contrary; in which they rie like Roots out of the Earth, and as a Vein out of the Liver. Nor does their imilitude with the Bladder move me; becaue, 1. The Nature of the Ureters is peculiar and ditinct from them both. 2. They are not much unlike the belly of the kidneys. 3. All Parts do carry with them the nature and colour of their Original, as we ee in the Aorta and the Cava. Nor does their cleaving fat to the Bladder infer any thing, eeing the connexion is not greater there then in the kidneys, being conveniently eparable, between the Membrane of the Bladder and the Mucle. And therefore this Original The Original of the Ureters. is in the kidneys, out of nine or ten little Pipes or Channels, to each of which the Caruncles aforeaid are applied, though the Caruncles may be alo applied to their middle part being bored through. Now thoe Pipes go into fewer and greater branches, commonly into three, ditributed into the upper, middle, and lower Region of the kidney. Thee grow afterwards into one large Cavity which goes out of the flat ide of the kidney. The middle part, is the wholeTheir Middle. long-round Pipe or Channel, reting upon the Mucles of the Loins, between two Membranes of the Peritonaeum, with which

The Ureters are fatned; above to the kidneys, below to the Bladder,Their Connexion. with the inner ubtance whereof they make one continued Body, o that they cannot be pluckt away without breaking. Their End is, where they are implanted, beingTheir End. carried obliquely a fingers breadth, between the proper Membrane of the Bladder, and its circumvolved Mucle, not far from the Neck of the Bladder, in its hinder part. And beides the oblique Inertion of the UretersWhy the Urin cannot go out into the Emulgents. (which cannot at al, or very highly hinder the regres of the wheyih Humor into the Ureters, becaue it is broad) two little Membranes are placed in the Implantation, like the Valves in bellows, hutting up the paage of the Ureters, o that the Urin cannot go back. Hence it is, that the Bladder being blown up, will not admit o much as any wind. Laurentius, Riolanus, and Plempius deny thee Valves, contrary to all other Anatomits. But though the paage be crooked, yet is it open enough. The Gut Colon is not a little wreathed, and the Ileon more then that, and yet they have a Valve affixed. Yea they are themelves forced to confes, that the two Membranes clapt together, do exactly hut up the paage of the Ureters, and what hinders but that they may be termed Valves.

As for their Magnitude. They are long-round Veels, thick andTheir Magnitude. hollow, as big as traws. But in Diections of perons troubled with the Stone, we have often een their Cavity o wide as to admit two fingers, yea and as big as the Guts.
As to there Figure, they are round Veels like Water-pipes, a little crooked like the letter,Figure. S.

They have a double Membrane: TheMembranes. one common from the Peritonaeum for trength ake, the other proper, like the inner ubtance of the Bladder, and continued therewith, white (whence ome and Celus among the ret call them the white Veins) bloodles, nervous, thick, trong furnihed with traight and crooked Fibres, that they may be tretched.
They receive mall Veins and Arteries fromVeels. the neighbouring Parts.

They have Nerves from the ixt pare, and the Marrow of the Loins. Whence they have an exquiite ene, and are pained when tones pas through them, which ene of pain is encreaed, by the ditention of thee membranous Bodies, caued by great tones.

Their Ue is, that through them as Conduitpipes,Ue. the Urin eparated from the Blood by the kidneys, may be carried into the Bladder; and omtimes Gravel and Stones, Worms, Pins, Ha •• , Quittor, Blood, &c. Now the Urin is carried by a manifet Paage formerly explained into the bladder, which Paage, becaue Aclepiades was ignorant of, he would have the UrinThe Error of Aclepiades and Paracelus. carried into the bladder, after a blind manner, as if it were firt reolved into a vapor, and did o weat through, and afterward became an humor as before: Which tranudation Paracelus likewie held.

div.head: Chap. XX. Of the Pis-bladder
div.p:
THis Bladder is eated in the lowetThe Situation of the Pis-bladder. part of the Belly, between two Coats of the Peritonaeum, in a Cavity fahioned by the Os acrum, the Hip and Share-bones (as it were in a little belly of its own, eparate from the Paunch) in men above the
<…> rectum or Are-gut; in women between the <…> the Womb, and the Os pubis, and the Shar •… .

Its Magnitude varies, for the greater the Lungs are, the greater is the bladder, oIts Magnitude. that thoe Live-wights which have no Lungs, have no bladder; and according as it is variouly ditended. For omtimes being full, it does o trout in the belly, that it may be felt by the hand, and omtimes being empty, it is in Diections hardly dicerned at firt, by reaon of its mallnes, being no bigger then a large Pear.

Its Figure is long-round and globous,Its Figure. that it may hold the more: And it hath within one Cavity, eldom two, ditinguihed by a Membrane as a partition wall. Such were found in a Maid of thirty five years old, by Voltherus Coiter, and Caparus Bauhinus, and Raphael Thorius, and Brovardus, have decribed unto us the like which they found in the body of the great Caaubon, the one of which being the left and praeternatural, had a paage into the right by a round hole, which would admit the tops of four fingers, being full of the urin, which at et times, and its uual endeavor, it voided by the right Cavity, which was ix times as great as it, being continued thereunto, with as many Membranes thick, and common to the ret of the greater bladder. This double Cavity in thee and the like, is not formed of the dilatation of the Ureter, within the foldings of the bladder, which may nevertheles often happen, but in Caaubon each Ureter did end in the bladder •• Spannd that it was originally o, the aid perons demo •… e. It being the pleaure of nature,

page 52 that as his mind was above that of other Mortals, o the unuual tructure of his body, hould afford like admiration to Poterity. From the bottom, it is by little and little traitned into a narrow neck, whence arie two parts of the Bladder, The Bottom and the Neck.

The Bottom is fatned to the Peritonaeum, alo to the Navil, by an intermediateIts Connexion. Ligament, called Urachus, and the two Navil-arteries dried up, leat when a man walks upright, the bottom hould ret upon the Neck. Hence is the Sympathy between the neck of the bladder and the Navil. The neck of the bladder is fatned in Women to the Neck of the Womb, and the neighboring Hip-bones; in Men to <…>
Rectum Intetinum.

Its Subtan •
•… tly membranous for trengths <…> becaue of exten
•…
Its Subtance. and w •… ether, •…
ly flehy, becaue of motion. For it hath two Membranes, and one Mucle infolding the whole bladder, which all other Anatomits except Aquapendent, do make to be a third Membrane, and not a Mucle.
The firt Membrane is outmot and common, from the Peritonaeum, trongMembranes. and thick.

The other is inmot, and proper, thin, of exquiite ene, interwoven with all kind of Fibres, that it may admit of much ditention and contraction [wherein there are very many wrinkles, in perons troubled with the tone, and little cavities are engraven which hold tones, being caued through long want of ditention] And it is covered with aThe Crut of the Bladder. flehy Crut, or wrinkled Coat as it were, made of the Excrements of the •… igetion, leat the innemot Coar hould be
by the harpnes of the Urine.
That which is in the middle, betwixt this proper and the outmot Coat, is by others called the econd proper Membrane, which nevertheles they grant to be thick, and furnihed with flehy Fibres.

But it is rather a Mucle encompaing the whole Bladder: becaue it hath FibresThe expulive Mucle of the Bladder. viibly flehy, inerted into the beginning of the bladder: So that, as the circular Mucle called Sphincter, does cloze the bladder, that our water may not pas from us againt our wills, o this Mucle does help the voidance of our water, whilet by contracting it elf, it queezes the bladder. And this is, indeed, the Opinion of my Mater Aquapendent; the truth whereof Walaeus was wont thus to prove in the Diection of live Dogs: having cut off all the Mucles of the Abdomen, he makes a mall piercing wound into the bladder, out of which wound or hole, the urin pins out as far, as naturally it does from the Yard: yet I hal not refue to grant thus much to other Authors: Viz. that the Mucles of the Abdomen or Belly, do alo help forward the Expulion of Urin. It ma es nothing againt us, that the tomach, and Guts, and Womb, have the like flehy membrane; for they alo did need uch an one, that they might more eaily be widened and contracted. Hence, though the Membrane of the Bladder be more flehy, yet in a large ene, the Membrane of thee other parts may likewie be termed muculous. But the condition of Spirituous blood, forcibly iuing forth, and of a dull and lazie urin are different. Moreover, in the Veins, the precedent blood is forced on by that which follows, according to the Laws of Circulation, and the inbred Faculty.
The Bladder hath three Holes: Two a little before the Neck, where the UretersIts Holes. are inerted, of which before, the third is in the Neck, to let out the Urin.

Now the Neck of the Bladder, is its narrowerIts Neck. part, through which the Urin is voided. In Men this Neck is more long-round, narrow, and a little writhen, becaue being placed under the bodies which compoe the Yard, it is carried upwards, under the Share-bones, from the Fundament to the Original of the Yard: To which in the hinder part two Kernels are adjoyned, called the Protatae. In Women the Neck of the Bladder is hort and broad, tretched forthright downwards, and implanted above into the Neck of their Womb. In both Sexes the Neck is flehy (which therefore heals, being wounded, whereas wounds in other parts of the bladder are deadly) interwoven with very many Fibres, epecially uch as run athwart, which pure up the Neck of the bladder, that our water may not pas from us againt our wills, and this orbicular Mucle isThe Sphincter Mucle. therefore called the Sphincter. Which if it be over cooled, or troubled with the Palie, or any other Dieae, the Patient cannot hold his water.

The Bladder hath Veins, termed Venae Hypogatricae, implanted into the ides of itsIts Veels. Neck, which being variouly ditributed through the bladder, are mutually conjoyned one with another, and with the Arteries, and are penetrable by mutual holes from one to another, o that the blood may eaily pas out of one branch into another, according to the Obervation of Sylvius, that the nutritive blood brought in by the Arteries, may return by the Veins. Now the reaon why the Bladder hath Veins, is, becaue it draws a meer Excrement, viz. the Urin, with which it cannot be nourihed.
It hath Arteries from the Hypogatrica in Men, in Women from the Veels which go into the Neck of the Womb.
It hath coniderable Nerves from the ixt pare, and from the Medulla of Osacrum.

Its Ue is, to contain Urin, and to be theIts Ue. Bodies Chamber-pot; alo Stones it contains and Gravel, and omtimes other things, as Hairs, Witnes Galen, Donatus, Hollerius, Shenkius, Tulpius; Worms, by report of Hollerius, Mundanella, Dodonaeus, of which there was a late Intance at Hafnia, Pinns, and which is mot trange, Pot-herbs, according to the late Obervation of John van Horn. And its next ue is to expel the aid Urin contained.

div.head: Chap. XXI. Of the Seedpraeparatory Veels in Men.
div.p: HItherto we have handled the Organs of Nutrition; thoe of Procrea ion or Generation come next to be poken of, which are different in Men from thoe in Women. In Men thoe which firt preent themelves, are
The twofold Spermatick Veels, viz.The Spermatick Veels and their Original. the two Spermatick Veins, and the two Spermatick Arteries.

The right hand Vein, aries from the Trunk of Vena cava, a little below the Rie of the Emulgent: The left prings from the Emulgent, for otherwie it hould go over the Aorta, and there would be danger of breaking, or • ather leat by the Pule of the Artery, the motion of the blood in the Vein, hould be in ome ort topped and hindered. Therefore it hath its Rie eldom from the Cava, and omtimes from both places.
Both the Seminal Arteries do arie from the Arteria magna, or great Artery: Almot two fingers breadths ditance from the Emulgents.

Thee Veels are in Men greaterTheir Magnitude. then in Women; and the Arteries are larger then the Veins, becaue very much Heat, and Vital Spirit, and Arterial blood are requiite, for to make the Seed. Somtimes one Artery is wanting, and omtimes both, peradventure in uch as cannot ingender.

Thee Veels are omwhat ditantTheir Paage. one from the other; they are obliquely carried above the Ureters to the Groyns, but in their progres, thee Veins and Arteries are joyned by infinite Anatomoes (o that the Arteries are o coupled within the Coat of the Veins, as if they were but one Veel) and they are knit together by a Membrane ariing from the Peritonaeum, and are afterwards carried to the beginning of the Stone, like the tendrils of a Vine, being o interwoven, that a curious eye cannot ditinguih a Vein from an Artery.

And this Intertexture of Veins and ArteriesThe Corpus varicoum. thus made, is by ome called Corpus varicoum, pampiniform, Pyramidal, &c. which others do thus ditinguih: Where the praeparatory Veels do from a narrow beginning, firt widen themelves into a broader Bais, they are termed Pyramidalia. And when afterward before their entrance into the Stones, they become here and there criped like the Tendre •… Vine, they are called Pampiniformia. Howb •… e Veels do not pas through the Peritonae • m •… but are carried between

Thee Praeparatory Veels of Generation, when they come unto the Stone, are not changed into the carrying Veels, as if one continued body with them as many imagine. But they pierce through the proper Coat of the Stone, and are pred through the ubtance thereof, and o obliterated.

The ue of the Spermatick Arteries, is to carry Blood and Spirit to the Stones, andTheir Ue. in thoe various interweavings to prepare the ame, by a vertue which they fetch from the tones, by reaon of its long tay and accurate Concoction, and ifting in thoe crooked Mazes, that it may becom Seed, and may nourih the Stones, for which nourihments ake, in thoe that are not yet of ripe age, thee Arteries carry blood, before they can labor and make Seed. Now the ue of the Spermatick Veins, cloely interwoven with the Arteries about the Stones, and joyned to them by mutual Anatomoes, is, to carry back that blood which remains uperfluous, after the Stones are nourihed, and the Seed made, unto the left Emulgent, or to the Vena
•… ediately, on the right ide, where the S •… in is commonly propagated from t •… there an • need to fear, leat this return of the blood through the Veins hould withdraw matter from the Seed, or that the generating Spirit, hould return upwards from the tones. For by reaon of the intricate mixture and intertexture of the Veels, no part goes back, ave what the tones dimis, as not neceary for themelves, nor the whole Body. And therefore we do for the mot part find the Arteries which bring the blood greater, and the Veins which carry it back leer, becaue the Stones do not return o much as they receive. And that the Spirit is retained, the ilent coure of the blood through the Veins, is a token. Which blood, verily, is retained in the tones from flowing back, by the ame power whereby it is retained in other Parts of the Body.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. Concerning the Stones.
div.p:
THe Stones or Teticles o called, as witneingThe Stones. the courage and trength of a
man, without which a man was no ufficient witnes in the Roman Court, are alo called Did ••• i or Gemelli Twins, becaue commonly

They are in Number two. Seldom one great one and no more, as in Sylla Their Number. and Cotta, Witnes A • rianus; eldomer three, as in Agathocles the Tyrant of Sicilie, and ome Families of Italy of the Colci, epecially at Bergoma, and others at Paris, according to the Obervation of Fernelius, which is alo proper to a renowned Family in Germany,; and four, which Aritotle partly oberved, and Riolanus the Father, o mall that they proved barren, becaue either they do not ufficiently diget the matter of Seed, or they do not eaily receive the ame, becaue of the traitnes of their paages.

They are eated externally in Men,Why placed without in Men? without the Abdomen, under the Belly, at the Root of the Yard, in their Cod or Covering. 1. For Chatities ake, if we believe Aritotle. For uch live-wights as have their Stones hid within their Body, are very lecherous, do often couple, and get many young ones. 2. That by reaon of the longer paage, the greater tay of the Seminal matter, may caue the better preparation. 3. Laurembergius would have them nearer that external place wherein they were to generate, viz. the Womb. But that nearnes, doubtles, helps nothing to Generation, though the nearnes of the Yard does: Nor do we find this oberved in many Animals which generate out of themelves.

That the Stones have lain hid in the Cavity of the Abdomen, until Puberty or Ripenes of Age fit for Generation, Martinus Rulandus proves in two Hitories, Pareus in one, and Riolanus in a tory not unlike. In which kind of perons, if the Yard hould alo lie hid, we hould ever and anon have an appearing change of Sexes.

The Epididymides ret athwart upon the Stones, and compas them as it were, being a kind of little Stones, oblong, round, white, and wreathed, but at both ends, omwhat harp, of which ee the following Chapter.
Their Magnitude in men does commonly anwer that of a mallTheir Greatnes. Hens Eg. And in men the Stones are greater then in women.

The Figure of the Stones is Oval.Their Figure. Which Figure varies omtimes, by reaon of the neighboring Veels more or les turgent: And therefore ome ay the right Teticle is more full vein'd, and it is thought to be more hot, and have eed better digeted. Whence Hippocrates calls it the Boygetter, becaue it receives more pure and hot blood and Spirits out of the great Veel, viz. the great Artery. The left Stone isWhether the left Stone be colder then the right. thought to contain colder Seed, more wheyih and and weak, becaue for the mot part, the matter is beleived to be brought from the Emulgent, and therefore Hippocrates cals this Stone the Girl-getter. Whence that common Saying, Wenches are begot by the left Stone in the left ide of the Womb; Boys by the right Stone in the right ide. And Hippocrates aies, there is in a man as wel as in a woman both male and foemale Seed, that is to ay, hotter and colder. But I am not of Opinion, that wenches are alwaies begotten by the left Stone, and that it receives a colder ort of Seed, for, 1. There are ever and anon Virago's or manly Women, which exceed Men in trength and courage. 2. Blood is communicated from the great Artery, as well to the left Stone as to the right. 3. The Arteria Spermatica is oftner wanting on the right ide then on the left. But the Generation of the fra • ler Sex, depends not o much upon the coldnes of the left Teticle, as upon the cold Contitution of both the Stones, or rather of the whole body, which adminiters Matter for the Seed. Howbeit the left parts of the body are generally aid to be colder then the right.

Moreover the right Stone is fuller of Seed, doth wel more, and hath a greater Vein and Artery, o that Nature eems to deign the Generation of Foemales more then of Males. It was therefore ill aid of Aritotle, that Nature of her elf did alwaiesThe Error of Aritotle. intend the Generation of Males, as being mot perfect, and that a Foemale is ingendred, when Nature being hindered, could not ingender a Male, o that a Woman is in his account a kind of Monter in Nature. Howbeit Nature eems more ollicitous for theWhether Nature alwaies intends to beget Boys. Generation of Women then of Men, for the Caues aforeaid, nor does Nature alwaies regard that which is bet or mot perfect, but that which is mot neceary, as a woman is: For many of them are but enough for one man. For women when they are big with Child, are ueles to a man; alo they are hort lived, nor can they bear o long, as a man can beget. But of this, I have dicoured more fully, in my 12. Anatomical Controverie de patribus.
The Teticles have Coats and Coverings,Their Coats. ome proper, others common.
They have two Coats common to themCommon. and other parts, to defend them from external injuries.

The firt is formed of a thinner skinThe Cod. and carf-skin, then is to be found in other parts of the Body, and is called Scrotum or Scortum, hanging out like a pure or bag, and ubject to the touch. Tis oft and wrinkled, void of Fat, that it might be more eaily extended andWhy void of Fat. wrinkled together: becaue the oylie matter which hould make Fat, goes into the Stones to make Seed. In the lower part it hath a line running out according to the length thereof, which divides it into a right and left part, and is called a uture or eam,

The econd Coat conits of a flehy Pannicle, which is alo thinner then is found in other places, full of Veins and Arteries, and called dartos. Which Covering is by others comprehended under the term Scrotum.
The proper Coat or Coverings, which onPorper. either ide do cloath each Stone are three.

The firt proper Coat is called Vaginalis the cabberd Coat, and by ome Helico • ides, by reaon of its hape, which is thin, but yet trong, full of Veins, ariing from the procees of the Peritonaeum. It cleavs to the Dartos, by many membranous Fibres, which others have reckoned for a peculiar Coat. Whence it is externally rough, internally mooth.

The econd is termed Eruthroeides the red Coat, being furnihed with ome flehy Fibres, bred out of the Cremater, and inwardly pred over the former. Rufus names this in the firt place, and Riolanus and Velingus following him, account it the firt Coat, becaue it compaes the former, and is propagated from the Cremater.

The third lat and lowet, immediately encompaing the ubtance of the Stone, and is as it were binding the ame, is termed Albuginea, and by ome Nervea,

The Subtance of the Stones is glandulous, white, oft, looe and pongy, byThe Subtance of the Stones. reaon of very many Veels there dipered and looe, though without Cavity, as the Liver alo and the Spleen have no Cavities. They have Veels of allVeels. kinds. Veins and Arteries from the Seminary Veels: An indifferent large Nerve from the ixt pare; omtimes alo they have two Nerves from the one and twentieth pare of the Spinal Marrow, conjoyned to the Seminal Veels, carried with them through the production of the Peritonaeum, and dieminated into the Tunicles.

They have on each ide one Mucle, ariing from a trong Ligament, which is in theMucles. Share-bone, where the tranvere Mucles of the Belly end, of which they eem to the Parts. They go along through the production of the Peritonaeum, which they compas about well-near, and grow to the beginnings of the Stones. They are •••• ed Cremateres or Supenores, hangers or utainers, for they hold up the Stones, that they may not too much draw down the Seminal Veels. Alo in the Carnal conjunction, they draw back the Stones, that the Seed-channel being hortned, the Sperm may be ooner and eaier conveigh'd into the Womb. In ome perons thee Mucles are capable of voluntary motion, who can draw up, and let down their Stones as they lit: where thee Mucles are doubtles tronger then ordinary, that they may not only hold the Stones upended, but move them from place to place.

The Ue of the Stones is, by theirThe Efficiens caue of the Seed. Heat and inbred Faculty, to make eed. For the Efficient caue of Seed is the proper fleh or ubtance of the Stones, both in regard of their hot and moit temper of their pecifick Property; ince no fleh in the Body is found like that of the Stones. Now they turn the blood being prepared into Seed, which is requiite to preerve the Species of Mankind: And that which remains over and above, either goes back by the Spermatick Veins into the Heart, or turns to nourihment for the
Stones. Nor can Seed be ordinarilyWithout the Stones there is no Generation. bred without the Stones, nor perfect Animals without them, for from them the Seed receives both its form and colour. That ome have ingendred without Stones, though not according to the ordinary Coure of Nature, Smetius in his Micellanies, Fontanus in his Phyica, Cabrolius, Hofmannus de Generatione, and others, do tetifie. Now the place wherein the Seed is bred, is not any large Cavity in the Stone, but certain very mall Veels therein formed, covered with a very delicate thin Coat, as Vealius rightly teaches. Now thee following Authors after Aritotle, have taken away the faculty of Seed-making from the Stones, viz. Fallopius, Cabrolius, Pothius, Caparus Hofmannus, Caear Cremoninus, Adrianus Spigelius, Regius, and others, becaue the Matter of Seed does not go into the Stones, nor is there ever any Seed found in them. But they wil have them principally to be Receptacles for the wheyih Humor which flows in with the Blood; which they collect from their glandulous ubtance, and the largenes of the left Stone. But they are confuted by Eunuchs and gelt perons, whoe Stones being cut out or bruied, they become unable to engender. Alo Seed hath been frequently oberved in the Stones. Witnes Dodonaeus in his 39. Obervation touching a Spanih Soldier, Hofman de Generatione Chap. 18. Carpus and Riolanus. It is indeed not to be found in ome Bodies, becaue it was not bred, by reaon of ome icknes, or Imprionment, or upon Death the Spirits being diipated, a watry Liquor appears intead thereof. Nor can the Seed come to the Vaa deferentia otherwie then by the Teticles, which begin at the Stones, as the praeparatory Veels end in them, by the Obervation of very many Anatomits, and why the left Stone is greater then the right, another reaon is alleadged by learned men.

Alo the Stones eems to give trength and courage to Mens bodies, as mayThe Sympathy of the Stones with the whole Body, be een in gelded perons, who are changed well-near into Women, in their Habit of Body, Temperament, Manners, &c. And doubtles the tones do exceedingly ympathize with the upper Parts of the Body, epecially with the Heart. For we ee that cordial and cooling Epithems in fainting Fits and bleeding at the Noe, being applied to the Stones, do help as if they were applied to the very Heart and Part affected. The Caue hereof is hard to tell; Jaccbinus, Laurentius, Hofmannus, conceive that it comes to pas by reaon of Paions of the Mind, which are joyned with flehly Lut. But Eunuchs alo are lutful, for they are great Lovers of Women: And Eunuchs are often tranported with anger and other Paions of the Mind, but they receive not never the more the Habit of Men. Galen eems to have been of Opinion, that a Spirit was bred in the Stones and diffued thence al the Body over. But glandulous Bodies of the number of which the Stones are, are unfit to engender an hot Spirit; nor are there any Paages about the Stones, for the ditribution of that new Spirit, according to the Opinion of Galen. Nor is therefore the Opinion of Mercatus allowable, viz. that thoe Spirits are not indeed bred there; but that the Vital Spirits are collected in the Stones in great quantity, that from them they may return back into the whole Body; for thoe which are there collected, are collected to engender Seed. But the Opinion of Thomas a Vega does better pleae me, til I hall find a more probable, viz. that a Seminal Air is raied up in the Generation of Seed, which thus changes the whole Body. The fleh truly of ungelt Creatures, hath a rammih tat of the Seed, which the fleh of uch as are gelt hath not. This Vapor or Air of the Seed is carried to the Heart, either by the inner Pores of the Body, or by the Veins which reconveigh to the Heart the uperfluities of the generated Seed. Helmont imagines the Stones do act by a ruling power, at a ditance, as the tomach does upon the Womb, the Womb upon the upper Parts, and that without any right waies or marks; which nevertheles an Anatomit eeks to find, if it be poible. Vetingus ingeniouly makes the reaon of the change of voice, temperament, trength, &c. in perons guelded, to be the oppreion of their inbred Heat by plenty of Matter, which ought to turn to Seed. Now their Sympathy with the Heart, depends partly upon the Nerves, partly (for we hold the Circulation in the Stones) from the foreaid Veins, returning back to the Heart, by which both the vertues of Cordials acend, and of cooling Medicaments, even as we apply Cordials and Coolers to the Hands, with like ucces.

div.head: Chap. XXIII. Of the Vaa deferentia, the Ejaculatoria, the Paratatae, Seminal Bladders, and the Protatae.
div.p: WEE have propounded the Spermatick praeparatory Veels above, which end into the Stones, to which they carry Matter to make Seed.

Now there are other Veels, which begin at the Stones, and end at the Root of the Yard, whither they carry and there quirt out the Seed, which hath been made in the Stones. And thee are termed Vaa deferentia, or Veels that carry away the Seed; and they are two in number, on each ide one.
Now we divide thee Veels into the Beginning, Middle, and End.

The Beginning are termed Paratatae, The Paratatae. as if you would ay idle attenders upon the tones, ceremonious waiters, alo Corpora varicoa or variciformia, becaue they are twited and wreathed, like thoe crooked black Veins called Varices. Galen in his Interpretation of hard words ued by Hippocrates calls them Epididymides, Names. becaue they ret upon the tones, which nevertheles others ditinguih by a peculiar ue, as that they prepare the eed; and the Paratatae do add more perfection thereto: Others invert the Matter, and perwade themelves that the Paratatae prepare the eed, and the Epididymides finih it, which Opinion of theirs they have received, I know not how well, from the ancient Phyitians. And they are oblong Veels, placed upon the tones, white, thick, and round, a little depreed, and olid, growing narrow by little and little.

As for their Subtance, tis of a middle nature betwixt that of the tonesTheir Subtance. and that of the Vaa deferentia. For their ubtance is ofter then the latter, and harder then the former, becaue they are glandulous within, and fungous; and externally membranous.

As to their Original, the Opinion ofTheir Rie. Spigelius and other late Anatomits, does againt all former Authority thus determine: viz. that
they arie by continuation from the Seminary Veels, o that both the Praeparatory Veels, and the Paratatae, and the Out-carrying Veels, are but one continued Body, receiving divers Names according to its different Parts, and their repective Offices and Situations.

But Walaeus conceives, that it is more uitable to what appears in Diection, to ay, that thee Veels do not arie from the praeparatory Veels, but are rather mixed with them, fatned to, and opened into them: and that as he uppoes, to the end that the blood forced in by the Praeparatory Veels, may depoite that Matter which it contains fit to breed eed, into the little branches of the Vaa deferentia. But the ret of the blood, which is unfit for Nutrition and Generation of Seed, is by other Anatomoes hed into the Veins, and by Circulation returns to the Heart.

Now they have their Original from the tones. by means of innumerable mall Pipes or white Fibres. And there is no communion at all between the Veel that carries away the Seed, and the Veins, and Arteries of the tones, which Vealius conceives to be apparent in Diections. Yet are they fatned to the inmot Coat of the tones, though they have a proper Coat of their own.

The Ue of the Paratatae, is to perfect and finih the eed, by a power which theyTheir Ue. receive from the tones. Moreover, while the eed abides in them, it comes to pas that vehement and frequent Lut is not provoked.

The Ejaculatory or quirting Veels, are imply termed the Middle, becaue they carry eed from the tones and the Corpora varicoa, to the eminal bladders: for they are een to carry a whiteih Humor, yea and the Paratatae are frequently found full of eed.
They have a Subtance white and nervous; and their Figure is round and long: They have an obcure Cavity, becaue the eed by means of the pirits whereof it is full, does eaily pas.

Their Situation is partly in the Cod, partly in the Cavity of the Belly, above the Os pubis or Share-bone. For they are carried upwards, and are knit to the Praeparatory Veels, by a thin Membrane, and o pas along to the Flanks and the Share-bone, which for that caue have a light Cavity. And afterwards being turned back downwards, they are carried above the Ureters, and under the hinder part of the Bladder, above the rectum Intetinum, they are on each ide widened at the Neck of the Bladder, where
Their End is, and thee Veels o widened do contitute

The eminary Bladders, which are many in number like little Cells, and eemSee Fig. III. Tab. XXI. to make on each ide one remarkable, great, and winding one, becaue one goes into another, which you cannot compare to anything better then to a bunch of Grapes. The Cavities do neatly repreent the Cells of a Pomegranate in order and figure. Rondeletius did firt of al decribe thee Bladders, and after him Fallopius. Thee nervous Bladders are eated between the Ligaments of the Pisbladder and the Are-gut, by the ides of the deferent Veels, a little before the aid Veels grow thick, and unite.

Their Ue is, to contain the eed being wrought, and to reerve the ame til time of Copulation, o that there may be eed ufficient to beget many Children. And therefore that •… ouder which Aritotle relates of a Bull that engendredWhether a Bull may ingender after he is guel after his to •• s were cut off: though others attribute this effect to the Protatae, as Archangelus and Columbus. Now the eed may be contained in thee Cells many months together, and in regard of the multitude of thee little Bladders, eed may be voided in many Acts of Copulation; and all not pent at one Eay.

And that eed is contained in theeWhether eed is contained in the Bladderkies. little Bladderkies, beides the Authority of Fallopius, Platerus, Laurentius, Aquapendent, and Caerius, it is manifet by this Experiment: If you queez them, preently feed is forced into the Pipe of the Yard, jut like Milk out of the Dug, or pis out of the Pis-bladder, &c. But if you pres the Protatae with your finger, yet nothing comesWhether in the Protatae? away, unles you pres the Bladders alo. And that the eed does not continually ditil and drop out of them, into Urinary paage, a little Caruncle hinders, which tops their hole The perpetual eat of a virulent Gonorrhaea, hath been by the Obervation of late Anatomits found to be in thee Bladders, for upon Diection there hath been found an evident Impothumation in thee parts. From the ituation of thee Bladders and of the tones, without the Cavity of the Abdomen, Riolanus would give a reaon why men are not o cruelly infeted with the filthy vapors of corrupt eed, as women are. But the Peritonaeum does not hinder the evaporations of the eed, becaue the Veins do inwardly open upwards. Alo Viragoes or mannih women, are not troubled with the aid vapors. The reaon mut therefore be ought in the quality of the eed, which being in men and manly women more benigne, does neither go to, nor infect the Heart.
After the Contitution of the eminary Bladders thee deferent Veels are united into one mal paage which goes into the Protatae.

Now the Protatae, as if youSee Tab. XXII. Let. QQ. would ay the Waiters, are two Kernels, manifety differing from the eed bladders, in ue, form, ituation, and magnitude, though Hofman think otherwie; their

Situation is at the Root of the Yard, above the Sphincter or Mucle of the Bladder, on each ide, at the neck thereof. Columbus calls them Protatae, Vealius glanduloum corpus, Fallopius glanduloion aitens, others call them the little tones, to difference them from the true tones. Before and behind they are flat, on the ides round.
They are commonly as big as a Walnut.

Their Subtance is pongy, and yet harder and whiter then that of other Kernels, and they are covered with a thicker Membrane; all which is to hinder the ovlie ubtance, of it elf apt to run, from paing out. And becaue they are of exquiite ene, therefore they caue pleaure in Copulation. Thee Kernels are open by certain Pores into the Urethra or Pis-pipe, which is evidently apparent in uch as have died of the Gonorrhaea, of which Gonorrhaea thee Pores being dilated are many times the eat.

Their Ue is to contain an oylie, lippery, and at Humor, which is preed forth when need requires, to daub the Urinary paage, to defend it from the acrimony of the eed or urin, and that it may not fall in through drines, but may remain lippery; becaue through it in Copulation, the aid Humor does uddenly flow out of the eed.

This is that which Galen ment, when he aid that they contained a certain Humor like eed, but much thinner, the ue of which Humor, is to excite Lut,
and to caue Delight in Carnal Copulation.

Mean while, Spigelius, Riolanus, and others do conceive that they containWhether the Protatae do make eed. eed, which is there collected, and thence voided, having attained ome further perfection, as Velingus conceives. Others as Laurentius, conceive they do both; for he will have the Protatae both to thicken the eed, and to breed a thin humor, and excite titillation. But that they do not contain eed, their compreion hews, which voides none, unles the Veicles or eed-bladders be withal compreed. And eeing the eat of the Gonorrhaea is here,The eat of the Gonorrhaea. which we frequently oberve to continue many years, without any remarkable Detriment to Health, it is unlikely that the eed flows from the Protatae. I aw a man at Padua, who was troubled thirty years with the Gonorrhaea, and hath it till, being otherwie in Health. The eed therfore is not contained in them, nor does it tay there, though it may pas through.

Others do conceive, that they help to make the eed, yea that they and theThe Protatae do not help to make eed. bladders are the only eed-makers, as Regius endeavors to prove. Which if it were true, guelded perons might engender. Guelded perons do indeed end forth a moit matter reembling eed, and they are provoked to Venery, but they can get no Children. And if they have been oberved at any time to engender, according to what is related of guelded Hores and Bulls; there was doubtles remaining in the eed-bladders, o much eed made by the tones, as might erve for one bout of Generation. But if they engendred more then once, doubtles one tone was left behind, when they were guelded.

div.head: Chap. XXIV. Of the Yard.
div.p: THe Genital Member of a Man is commonlyIts Names. called in Latin Penis a pendendo, becaue it hangs, alo Virga the Rod or Yard, Colis, &c. Many other Names are wont to be put upon it, which are better pat over then mentioned. In Englih tis mot uually termed the Yard or Prick. Plato in his Timaeus compares it to a certain living Creature, becaue it hath an Appetite to Generation. Howbeit, it is indeed the Part and Intrument of a Live-wight, and the Faculty of Appetite is eated in the Brain.

Tis eated at the Roots of Os pubis, that carnal Copulation might more convenientlySituation. be accomplihed, and that it might be no impediment to other parts it is placed in the middle, becaue only one in number. Yet there was once a man diected at Bononia who had two Yards. Which alo Obequens relates of a Boy, among his Prodigies. Another named Anna, being lately a vagrant in Italy, had no Yard, but intead thereof a certain piece of pongy fleh under his Navil, which Nature had provided him to pis withal.
Its Figure is round and long; but not exactly, becaue it is broader on the upper • ide,Figure. which they call the Back of the Yard.

Its Magnitude coniting in thicknes andMagnitude. length, does vary, both in the everal orts of Animals, and in the Individual Creatures of the ame ort. Particularly, tis in Man o great as was neceary to propagate his pecies or kind: But proportionally horter then in many Brutes, becaue Mankind couples after another manner then thoe beats do. In particular Men, there is exceeding great variety. For it is for the mot part greater then ordinary, 1. In little Men. 2. In uch as abtain from carnal Embracements, if we beleive Galen. 3. If the Naviltrings be not tied cloe to the Navil in Infants; for otherwie, by reaon of the Urachus or Pis-pipe, the Bladder and neighboring Parts, are drawn more upwards. Yet Spigelius is herein of a quite contrary mind. 4. In uch as have large Noes. For the proportion of the Yard anwers that of the Noe very much, if we will beleive Phyiognomits. 5. In Block-heads and dull-pated Aes. Some Nations have this Member larger then ordinary, as the Aethiopians or Blackmores.
It conits of the Scarf-skin, Skin, flehy Membrane, and a proper ubtance of its own.

It is void of Fat, even in the fattetWhy the Yard is void of Fat, the firt Opinion. Laurentius his Error. men. And it is a great quetion why there is no Fat found either in it or about it. Some, as Laurentius, think it is becaue fat through its oftnes would hinder its erection: But the Yard will tand, as long as the Bodies thereof are blown up. Others make the Caue to be leat the weight thereof hould do hurt, and that the Yard might not grow too great. But if there were a little Fat, it would add nothing to the weight, nor would it enlarge the Yard over much. The truer Caue therefore is this, that there is therefore no Fat, that its ene might not be dulled, and the pleaure of Copulation abated, when the Fat hould melt by rubbing the Yard.

Its proper Subtance is not boney as it is in a Dog, a Wolf, a Fox, a Whale,Its Subtance. &c. but peculiar and proper to it elf, uch as is no where to be found in anyThe four Parts of the Yard. other Part of the Body. Now there are four proper Parts of the Yard, the Urethra or Pis-pipe, the Nut, and the two nervous Bodies.

The URETHRA or Pis-pipe, is a nervousUrethra. Pipe or Channel, alwaies of the ame ize, from the neck of the bladder (to which it is joyned, but does not arie therefrom, nor communicate therewith) like a long neck, to the End of the Yard; ave where the Nut is joyned with the nervous Bodies. For there indeed it hath a uperficial Cavern or Hollownes, in which an Ulcer and intollerable pain does omtimes happen when ome corro • i • e humor is th ••• collected, by means of a Gonorrhaea, or ome other occaion. It is exceedingly widened in perons troubled with the tone. Alpinus aw it o wide in Aegypt, that it would receive a large Hazel-nut. And therefore it is eaily blown up, to draw out the tone.

In the beginning thereof are thoe Pores, through which we aid before the eed tills forth. There is alo a little Membrane or Caruncle like a Valve tretched before it, to keep the eed and urin from returning into the permatick Veels. It is eroded or fretted by harp Humors, or by ue of the Catheter, whence follows a perpetual Gonorrhaea. Riolanus obervs that it is found in Boys, till the twentieth year of their Age, but I ee no caue why it hould not remain in their after Age, when the encreae of eed, makes it more neceary then formerly.
The Bodies of the Yard do embrace and touch this Urethra, and it is •… d back with them, and o reaches to the N •… the figure of an S.

One Membrane is internal and thin, of exquiite ene, as thoe can witnes who are troubled with the tone. With which alo the Nut is covered; and it is bred out of the thin Membrane, which cloaths the Nerves of the Yard. The other is external, more flehy and furnihed with tranvere Nerves. The middle part of its proper ubtance, is looe, pongy, and black, that it may be ditended together with the nervous Bodies.
The Ue of the Urethra •… mon paage for the Urin, Seed, and o •…

The Nut or Head of the Yard, is theThe Nut of the Yard. •
outmot welling part thereof, roundih or pointed, even and compaed with a Circle like a Crown.
It hath Fleh more enible and olid then the ret of the Yard, covered with an exceeding thin Membrane.
It is oft and of exquiite ene, for Titillations ake. In ome Men it is more harp, in others more blunt.

It hath a Coat or Covering called the Fore-skin, or Praeputium a putando, from cutting off, for the Jews and Turks cut it off, and therefore they are nick-nam'd Apellae
and Recutiti, skinles or skin-cut. In which Nations tis wonderful what Vetingus told me himelf aw, viz. that in young Boys it grows out o long and pointed, that it reembles a tayl. Hildanus oberved it in a certain peron very great and flehy. At the lower end it is tied to the Nut by a Membrane or Band termed Fraenum the Bridle, which is terminated in the hole of the Nut. Some will have it to be made up of the extremities of the Nerves. Carolus Stephanus thinks it is compoed of a Combination of the Tendons of the Mucles of the Yard, and a Nerve.
The two nervous Bodies, on each ideThe nervous Bodies. one, do make up the remaining and greatet part of the Yard: the whole ubtance whereof is like a mot thick pungy Artery, tuffed with fleh.

For the ubtance thereof is twofold, the firt external, compact, hard, and nervous; the other internal, pungy, thin, and hollow, and of a dark-red colour enclining to black; and therefore Vealius aies tis filled with a great deal of black Blood, like a Pudding.

Now this ubtance is rare and pory,Whence the hardnes and Erection of the Yard proceeds. that it may be filled with Spirit, and Venal and Arterial Blood; by which means the nervous ubtance thereof is the more tretched, and the Spirits are not oon diipated, whence proceeds the hardnes and tiffnes of the Yard, not o much for Copulations ake, as that the man might quirt his eed right out as far as might be, even to the Orifice of the Womb, after the Yard hath been moved in the female Privity.

Thee two Bodies have their Original from the lower parts of the Hip-bones, as from a firm and table Foundation, to which they are trongly tied with two Ligaments; where in their Rie they keep ome ditance, that place may be allowed to the Urethra; and then they are carried upwards, and grow into one about the middle of the Share-bone (like the two horns of the letter y) but o as they do not both remain perfect, but they looe near a third part of their nervous ubtance. Howbeit they remain ditinct, by the coming between of ome membranous partition (which conits not of a double Membrane, as at the Rie of the Bodies, but of one ingle one) very thin and tranparent, trengthned with nervous and trong tranvere fibres; which fibres are ranked and ordered like a Weavers Comb.

All kind of Veels enter into the Yard, Nerves, Veins, and Arteries. 1. External ones running in the Skin, very frequent, from the Pudenda, and alo internal ones pred through its Body. They are therefore mitaken, that think the Yard is detitute of Veins. Its internal Arteries are two remarkable ones, ariing from the Hypogatrica, which are inerted at the beginning of the growing together of the Bodies, and are pred up and down, according to the length of the Yard, But in the middle, where the Septum or partition is thinnet, they end branches up and down, through the paces of the Fibres, the right Artery into the left Body, and the left Artery into the right Body, carrying Spirit and Blood, to blow up, erect, and nourih the Yard. The Nerves alo are dieminated from the Marrow of Os acrum, through the Yard, as well the external and Skin-nerves, as the internal, and thoe remarkable ones, which acend through the middle of the forked diviion, and are thence dieminated into the Mucles, the whole Body, and the Nut; that there might be an exquiite ene and delectation.
Alo the Yard hath two pare of Mucles. The Mucles of the Yard.

The firt pare hort and thick, are the Yard Erectors; this pare aries nervous, under the beginning of the Yard, from an Appendix of the Hip, and growing flehy, it is carried to the bodies of the Yard, into which it is inerted, not far from their Original.
Their Ue is to raie and keep the Yard up in Copulation.

The econd Pare which widens the Urethra is longer, but thinner or leaner. Thee two flehy Mucles arie from the Sphincter of the Fundament, following the length of the Yard: then they are carried beneath and inerted into the ides of the Urethra, about the middle thereof.

Its Ue is to widen the lower part of the Pis-pipe, both in piing, and epecially in Copulation, when the bodies of the Yard are full, that the Egres of the Seed may not be hindred. And in thee Mucles is the place where Surgeons do commonly take out tones. The Line of the Cod being drawn to one ide, according to their length, and not according to their breadth as Marianus anctus notes againt the Ancients, an hollow Catheter being thrut into the Ureter, upon which, the Inciion is to be made, which manner of cutting Aquapendent decribes and approves of.

The Ue of the Yard is for Copulation:Copulation. which a man cannot rightly perform without the Erection of his Yard, and the quirting out of the Seed which follows thereupon. For the man quirts his Seed right out into the Mouth of the Womb, where being afterward joyned with the womans Seed, an drawn in, and retained by the Womb, Conception is aidConception. to be made.

A econdary Ue thereof is to void urin, yet was it not therefore made, eeing women do make water without it. By reaon of this twofold ue of the yard, the Arabians make two paages, as Vealius tells us, who oberved uch a like Conformation in a certain peron.

In ome the Nut of their Yard is not bored through in the ore part where it ought to be, but in the lower part, as Hofman hath noted out of Aritotle and Paulus, who cannot make water if their Yard do not tand, or when they it. Others, and that more frequently, have it imperforated in the upper part. They are both unapt for Generation. Somtimes the Yard hath no paage at all as Julius Obequens hath oberved.

div.head: Chap. XXV. Of the Parts erving for Generation in Women, and firt of the Spermatick Praeparatory Veels.
div.p: THe Parts erving for Generation inThe Genitals in Women quite different from thoe in men. Women, do ome of them agree after a ort with thoe in Men, as the permatick Veels, the Stones, and the Vaa deferentia, or Veels that carry away the Seed. Others are wholly different, as the Womb with its Bottom, Orifice, and Neck, the Hymen, the M •• tle-hap'd Caruncles, the Vulva with its Wings, t •… itoris, and the little Hillocks.

div.p: For we mut not think with Galen, Archangelus, Fallopius, and others, that thee Female Genital Members, differ from thoe of Men only in Situation. Which Opinion was hatched by thoe who accounted a Woman to be only an imperfect Man; and that her Genital Members could not be thrut out by reaon of the coldnes of her temper; as in Men they are thrut out by vertue of their greater Heat.

Howbeit, the generative Parts in Women differ from thoe in Men, not only in Situation, but in their univeral Fabrick, in repect of Numbe •
Surface, Magnitude, Cavity, Figure, Office, and <> ufficiently manifet to a skilful <> to any <> that will compare what follows to what went before.

And the fality of their Opinion isThe imilitude of the Yard and of the Womb ridiculous. ufficiently apparent, by means of the undry Conjectures which they bring. For ome liken the Womb to the Cod of a Man, and ome to the Nut of the Yard. Some will have the Neck of the Womb to anwer the Mans Yard, and others will have the Clitoris. Which Conceits falling to the ground by their own weaknes, I hall proceed to explain the Parts.

The Spermatick praeparatory Veels The praeparatory Veels in women. in Women agree with thoe of Men,
in their Number, Original, and Office, &c. I mut now therefore only tell you wherein they differ.

They differ firt in Magnitude. Thee Veels in women are horter, becaueHow they differ from thoe in Men. of the hort way they are to go, but therefore they have many turnings and windings which make up the Corpus varicoum: to the end the eed may tay long enough to receive due preparation. In the next place they differ in their Implantation. For in women they are not totally carried to the tones, but they are divided in the middle way: and the greater part goes to the tone, and makes the Corpus varicoum, and the leer part ends into the womb, into whoe ides it is dieminated, epecially to the upper part of the bottom, for to nourih the Womb and the Child therein; and that by thoe Veels ome part of the mentrual blood may be purged forth in uch as are not with Child. For the leer branch being tripartite, is below the tone divided into three branches, one of which, as was aid, runs out into the womb, the other is ditributed to the deferent Veel or Trumper of the Womb, and to the round Ligament; the third branch creeping along the ide of the Womb through the common Membrane, ends near the trueneck of the womb, ininuating it elf alo among the Hypogatrick Veins, with which and the Arteries, they are joyned by Anatomoes. Of which ee Zerbus, Fallopius, Platerus, and others, who have hewn Riolanus and my elf the way. That is a rare cae, which is figured out by Belerus, viz. for the permatick Arteries to be joyned by way of Anatomois with the Emulgent Artery. For this caue in women thee Veels go not out of the Peritonaeum, nor reach to the Sharebone: becaue the Stones and Womb are eated within.

Thee eminal Veins and Arteries are intertwined with many wonderful Anatomoes, for the preparation of eed. Yea and the Veins do receive into themelves the Hypogatrick Arteries of the Womb, according to the Obervation of Arantius and Riolanus. Yet I remember the Arteries were wanting in a woman that had bore male Children, and Francicus Zanchez relates how they were turned into tone in a woman of Toloue.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI. Of Womens Stones.
div.p: NOw the Stones of Women, thoughHow the Stones of Women differ from thoe of Men. as to their ue, they partly agree with thoe in Men; yet in many things repecting their tructure, they differ from them. And

list.item: 1. in repect of their Situation; which they have within in the Cavity of the Belly, two fingers breadth above the bottom, in uch as are not with Child, and are knit by means of certain Ligaments above the ame: viz. to the end they might be hotter, andWhy Womens tones are placed within their Bodies. conequently more fruitful; ince they were to work a matter of which alone Mankind was to be generated, the eed of the man being added not as a material, but an efficient Caue.

2. In Magnitude, which is not o great in women as in men, unles very eldom. For by reaon of the encreae of Heat, they are contracted after a woman is pat fourteen, whereas they are before that time ditended more largely being full of a white Juyce.
3. In their external Surface which is more uneven, then that of a mans tones.
4. In Figure, which is not o round, but broad and flat on the fore and hinder-parts. Alo the tones are within more hollow, and more full of permatick moiture.

5. In Subtance which ome conceive to be harder then that of mens tones, but others conceive, and that more truly, that it is ofter, and if you take off the Membrane, you hall find them conglomerated or knobbed together of divers little Kernels and Bladders, but eldom like thoe of men. In ome great eafih, there is no difference of the tones of the Males and Females, in ubtance, but only in the ize.
6. In Temperament, which is commonly accounted more cold, and that the eed contained in them, is more moit, thin, and waterih.

7. In Coats. For they are covered with one only Coat, becaue they are otherwie in a cloe place. And that Coat ticks exceeding trongly to them, and is by Galen termed Dartos. Howbeit, where the tones receive the eminal Veels, they are covered half over with the Peritonaeum.

8. In Connexion; for they are knit unto the womb by two manifet paages, or rather the one of them is an obcure one, out of which during carnal Copulation, there is hed, not a wheyih ubtance, but the womans eed.

div.p:
Their Ue is to make eed which helps to generate after its way and manner: which Aritotle againt all Reaon and Experience, was bold to deny to women, in ome places of his Writings, contrary to the expres Doctrine of Hippocrates de Genitura, where he tells us that women alo end forth eed out of their Bodies, omtimes into their womb, whereby it is moitned, and omtimes without, if the Orifice thereof do gape over much. Now that in the Womb it helps to the Generation, he thereby demontrates, in that if after Copulation. The woman hal not conceive, the eed which they have both of them voided, does flow out of the womb. But ome other Anatomits deny that thee tones do make eed. But they will have them to be meet Kernels, to receive that moiture which needs abound in the womb, which is the Opinion of Cremoninus; or that they are only made for a mark and ign, which was the Conceits of Rhodiginus, and of Hofman ince him, who account them rather Carcaes of tones then true tones, becaue they are mall, void of Juyce, and uncompact. But as for what concerns Humidity we deny that Argument, and ay 1. That there was no need of o much preparation to water the womb. One Veel gently carrying a wheyih Humor, might have erved that turn, yea the Pores alone might have ufficed, as it is well known to happen in a clammy humor ditilling into the Knee. 2. They may anwer both Intents, viz. Generation and Irrigation. 3. Experience tells us that eed and no other humor hath iued out of the tones of women being diected. Guinterius was hindred in his Diection, by the plentiful eruption thereof. The nocturnal pollutions of women tetifie the ame, and women became barren, when in ancient times they were guelded or payed, Witnes Athenaeus. Galen experimented the ame in Sows. Varro writes that Cows being guelt, do conceive if they go to Bull preently after. 4. The aid eed is found in the Diections of women, if they are luty and free from D •• aes In them and in Women with Child, Belerus ha •… und the tones welling with eed, which
he hath expreed by a neat Picture. 5. That it is true eed, we may gather from a real and enible effect thereof, like that of the eed of men, as Moles, and imperfect Eggs, by reaon of the difference of Sex, to which the Male adds Life and Perfection. 6. Women have ufficient heat to make eed, and ufficient intruments to that end; yea, and ome of them are better provided then men. Their tones are indeed mal and little, but not void of Juyce. Their number does recompence their malnes, even as we omtimes ee more Juyce pret out of a Bunch of Grapes, then a olid and whole Apple.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII. Of the Veels that carry away the Seed, epecially the Trumpet of the Womb.
div.p: COncerning the Veels which carry away the Female-eed, the Doctrine of Anatomits hath been hitherto omwhat intricate, partly through varity of opinions, and partly the obcurity of the matter it elf, which nevertheles I hall endeavor to reduce, and as much as may be to illutrate the ame.

The deferent Veels are taken either in a large or a trict ignification. Strictly for thoe ame obcure Paages and Veels only, which carry part of the eed bred in the tones, into the womb. Largely and generally, 1. For the preparatory Veels alo, 2. For them and the Womb-trumpet, which others refer to the ervatory and jaculatory Veel. I hall peak of both briefly and ditinctly.

The deferent Veels are properly thoe mall paages derived from the tones, either to the bottom of the womb, with a very hort paage, or dieminated at the trumpets of the womb, with undry, and thoe exceeding mall Twigs, reembling the Venae lacteae, ariing from the permatick preparatory Veels, and continued with them, however here they change their name and ue, becaue they immediately pas over, and lick the tones.

Galen conceives that the former is only inerted into the ides of the womb, which are termed Cornua, or the wombs horns, and other Anatomits are of the ame opinion, who profes they could find no other Inertion. But Zerbus, Fernelius, Laurentius, found another Branch herefrom, which goes not into the bottom as the former, but into the Neck, o that one part of this deferent Veel which is the horter but larger, is inerted into the middle of the Horn of the ame ide, and there poures out uch eed as it hath, into the Cavity of the womb: but the other part being the narrower and longer, is carried along the ides of the womb, below the Mouth, to the beginning of the Neck. Varolius hath alo made mention of this Part, and aies it is o mall in uch as have never conceived, that it cannot be found, ave by a skilful Anatomit, but in Women with Child it is very large. Spigelius, becaue he could not omtimes find it, did count it a port of Nature. Vetingus does eem to allow of it, eeing he brings eminal Matter from the tones, to the bottom and heath of the womb, this way. I hould willingly aent to the Opinion of Spigelius, becaue it is eldom een. Little Branches indeed are alwaies dieminated unto the neck of the womb, but the •
<…> directly from the preparatory Veels, and bring blood rather then eed, of which ee other Anatomits, epecially Platerus, Riolanus, and my Father Bartholinus beneath.

The Ue of thee Veels is, partly to carry the eminal Matter to the Trumpets, that it may be there further accomplihed, and better wrought, and reerved for further ue, and partly to the bottom of the womb. Where another Branch ends into the Neck, the eminal Humidity is voided this way alo, cauing greater delight by reaon of the length of the way.

The other deferent Veel, which ought to keep the Seed before it be quirted out, is the Trumpet of the Womb, by Fallopius o called, from the likenes it hath to a Trumpet of War, which he thus decribes. There aries a eminal Paage, mall and very trait, nervous, and white, from the Horn of the womb it elf, and when it hath gone a little therefrom, it grows broader by little and little, and crips it elf like the tendrel of a Vine, till it comes towards the end. Then dimiing its wrinkled Cripations, and becoming very broad, it ends into a certain Extremity, which eems membranous and flehy, by reaon of its red Colour, and at lat becomes very torn and ragged, like the jagged edges of worn clouts, and hath a large hole, which lies alwaies hut, thoe jagged ends alwaies falling in upon it, which nevertheles if they be diligently opened and widened, they repreent the broad end of a brazen Trumpet.

I hall handle the Particulars more ditinctly. The Trumpets arie from the bottom of the womb by one end, nor do they reach with their other end to the Stones, or any other remarkable Part. And therefore they are not manifetly paable in this other Part, but hut up and blind, o that they are like the Intetinum caecum, and are as it were an Appendix of the Womb. But this hutting up may be made according to the Opinion of Fallopius, which Riolanus who was ince him, challenges for his own, by the fringes and jagged ends of the Trumpets, falling together, like Raggs of Cloath.
They are two in Number, on each ide one.

They are eated o as to compas half the Stones, but they are ditant from the Stones, on every ide, near half a fingers breadth, unles the womb be dieaed, by which they are drawn up nearer to the Stones. They are ordinarily fatned only by very thin Membranes, not unlike the wings of Bats or Flitter-mice, through which many Veins and Arteries are dieminated, carried from the Stones into thee Paages, and carrying Seed out of the Stones.
Their Subtance is nervous, white, thick and hard.

Their Figure is round and hollow. Somtimes their Cavity o praeternaturally widened, as to contain a Mole, which Marquardus relates in his Empirica Praxi; omtimes a Child, Examples whereof are recited by Riolanus. Nor could he ee any other waies for the mans eed to enter, ave the turning and winding Paages of thoe Veels. But in a living woman, the mans eed full of pirits, might eaily be drawn thither, by the widened waies of the womb miaffected, which Paages being afterwards (Conception being made, and the Trumpets ditended) hut up, were not een by Diectors. Or whether hath there not been a hapeles Mole, or a Child without life been haped, without the eed of a Man, of the Mothers eed only contained in the Trumpets; which having received no life from any Father, and the paages being hut up, it grew great, and kil'd the Mother?

In the Natural Figure let us conider the Beginning, Middle, and End. The Inertion o •
Beginning is at
the bottom of the womb large, where it attains a nervous Pipe, tretched out to the middle well-near of the Trumpet, hollow, that it may tranmit the Seed to the bottom of the womb. The Middle being capacious, hews certain little Cells, containing white eed. The End is narrower, though it carry ome widenes with it. Howbeit before the End, it is wreathed and criped like the tendrel of a Vine, as is viible in Men and Beats.

The Paage therefore of the Trumpets, is not in all parts traight, but winding, becaue the way is hort from the tones to the womb. But the pleaure ought not to be hort, when the eed is poured plentifully out of the tones into the horns of the womb in Copulation. And look what the Seed-bladders are in Men, as to preerve the eed, thee blind paages may be the ame in Women, when they couple oftentimes, and til void eed. For they may be o termed, becaue they are annexed to the tones by little Membranes, that by Veels brought to them from the tones, as by the milkie and mearaick Veins, they may eaily draw the eed by them concocted, and lay it up within themelves for future occaion, and end it forth when need requires.

Their Ue is, 1. According to Fallopius to erve as Chimneys, by which the ooty vapors of the womb may exhale. Which I for my part cannot believe. For the ooty Vapors are condened, and being reolved into water, are reerved till the time of Childbirth, or acend by inenible Pores, or breath out at the mouth of the womb, both in Women with Child, becaue the mouth of the womb is never o cloe hut as to hinder, as the Examples of Superfoetation tetifie, as in uch as are not with Child. Nor can I wel tel how the ooty vapors hould find way through thee crooked Paages. 2. According to the aid Fallopius in his Obervations, they make eed, becaue he alwaies found eed in them, but never aw any in the tones; to which I anwered before. 3. Their true Ue is, to draw eed out of the tones, by blind paages of the Veels dipered through the Membrane, and when it is drawn to perfect the ame by ome tarriance in the Tendrels and Cells, by the irradiation of the vertue of the tones; that it may be more fit for a Child to be made of; finally to carry it to the womb, epecially in the Act of Copulation, by thoe little Pipes implanted in the Horns of the womb, that it may meet the mans eed in the Cavity of the womb or its Neck, to caue Conception.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII. Of the Womb in General.
div.p: THe Womb is by the Latins termed Uterus, from Uter a Bottle by reaon of its hollownes, in which Sene Tacitus does ue Uterum Navis for the Keel of a Ship. Iidorus aies tis o called, becaue tis on each ide one: in a more large ignification tis termed Venter in the Digets and Intitutes. Alo tis called Matrix, Utriculus, and Loci muliebres, where conit the beginnings of Generation, according to Varro. In other Animals, according to Pliny, tis termed Vulva, epecially in Sows, which the ancient Romans did account a delicate Dih: Of which ee Plutrach, and Langius in his Epitles, alo Martial, Horace, Apitius, Athenaeus, and among late Writers Catellanus. Hofman conceives that Vulva is corrupted from Bulga, and Bulga a Word ued by Lucilius and Varro, is originally French, if we believe Fetus, who renders it a Bag. Nonius interprets it to be a Satchel or Knapack hanging about a Mans Arm. See hereof Voius. But the term Vulva is approved by Celus, and the Authors formerly commended.

It is ituate in the Hypogatrium, orWhy the womb is placed in the Hypogatrium. the lower Part of the lower Belly, which is framed in the Cavity termed Pelvis, by the Osacrum and the Flankbones. And therefore that Pelvis or Bain, is larger in Women: and therefore they have Buttocks greater and wider. Now it was requiite that it hould be o placed, that the Womb might be ditended according to the greatnes of the Child, and that the Child might be conveniently excluded.

Moreover the Womb is placed in the middle inclining to no ide, ave omtimes when a Woman is of Child with a Boy or a Girl: for then the Child lies more to the right or left ide, though that be no certain Rule.

Now it lies between the Intetinum rectum or Aregut, which is beneath it, and the Bladder which lies upon it, as between two Pillows. Why therefore hould we be proud who are bred between Dung and Urin?
Its Magnitude is conidered in lengthIts Magnitude. depth, and thicknes, and all thee vary in repect of Bodies, Age, and Venery.
Its Length in thoe of a middle tature, who ue Venery, from the external Privity to the bottoms end, is commonly eleven fingers; the bottom is three fingers.
The Breadth of the bottom, is two or three fingers, becaue in Women not with Child the latitude of the bottom and neck is one and the ame. And hence the amplitude may eaily be conjectured.

But in Virgins, which have not attained to ripenes of Age, it is little and les then the Bladder: in uch as are full of Age it is greater: yet if they abtain from Venery it is mall enough, though thick, as it is alo in very old Women. But it is greater in uch as have oft conceived, and bore Children: that a man may well near grap it in his hand, unles when the Women are great with Child: for then it is more and more enlarged, and whereas before Gravidation, the bottom of the Womb did not pas beyond the beginning of Osacrum, it reaches afterward to the Navil and beyond, o that it rets upon the thin Guts.

The thicknes of the Womb does varyWhether the womb becomes thinner in women with Child. after the ame manner. For in Virgins the ubtance thereof is thin, in grown perons thick; and by how much a Woman hath been oftner with Child, by o much is the ubtance of her womb the thicker. When the Coures flow, the womb grows thick; and when the voidance of the Coures is at hand, the ubtance of the womb appears welling and thick. In Women with Child, Galen, Vealius, and other AnatomitsAn Error of Galen and Vealius. conceive, that the womb the more it is tretched, the more it is attenuated, & that its thicknes is pent in its length, as Galen peaks. But ocular Experience makes againt this, and the Authorities of Sylvius, Mundellus a Surgeon of Paris, Aranthus, Varolus, Platerus, Bauhinus, Heurnius, Rouettus, and Laurentius. For from the firt Conception until the Birth, it is encreaed according to all Dimenions, and becom • as larger • o a little thicker and ofter, o that in the lat • onths •• e wombs ubtance is two

The Womb does then o far depart from a membranous Subtance, and becomes red, and of a fungous and pungie Subtance, and full of holes like a Pumice-tone, diviible as it were into many Barks and Shells: which happens becaue of the plentiful Afflux of Blood and Spirits for the Child. Touching both Opinion Falcobergius thus judges; that the Subtance of the Womb does indeed become more thin, as he oberved in Diections of Women with Child; but that it eemed thicker, becaue the Womb-liver does grow exceeding cloe therto, and that this might deceive many. But Nicolas Fontanus aies, that in the womb of a Woman with Child, he hath eparated the Womb-liver from the Membrane, and that he hath found the Membrane to be exceeding thick. Which may very well be, for the Membrane being pungie, drinks in the affluent moiture of the womb, and puts on a thicker condition of Subtance. If at any time it happen to be praeternaturally thin, either through defect of Humor, or through much Ditenion, it is eaily broken. And Salmuth hath oberved as much in a Childbed woman, by reaon of trong Forcers. Now the Subtance of the womb is thicket of all about the internal O •…
