The Figure of the Womb is by omeThe true Figure of the Womb. counted round, by others Pear-fahion'd. But though the Womb encline to roundnes that it may be of the greater capacity; yet we conceive with Soranus and Fallopius, that its bottom may bet of all be reembled to a Gourd; becaue it is by little and little traitned downwards. But the Neck of the Womb reembles an oblong and round Pipe or Channel.
The Connexion is either of the Neck of the Womb or of the Bottom.
The Neck is tied by its own ubtance, and by membranes; but the Bottom by peculiar Ligaments.

On the foreide the Neck grows to the Pis-bladder and the Share-bones, by Membranes ariing from the Peritonaeum. In the hinder part to the Osacrum, and the rectum Intetinum, with ome Fatnes. But about the Privity it grows together with the Fundament. On the ides, it is looely knit by certain Membranes to the Peritonaeum.

The Bottom is not fatned by itsThe Ligaments of the Womb. Subtance, but is free, becaue it ought to be moved, as hall be aid in its Action (w •• refore a Venetian woman died of pains in
her womb, the bottom thereof being tied by the Call) but in the ides it is knit by two pare of Ligaments, whoe ue is to hold the womb upended or dangling.

One upper pare is broad and membranous, and is held to arie from the MuclesThe upper Ligaments of the Womb. of the Loins; and it ends into the bottom of the womb, near the horns. It is looe and oft, that it may be ditended and contracted. Aretaeus likens it to the wings of Bats or Flitter-mice. And by help of this pare, the bottom is fatned to the Bones of the Flank. But becaue it is interwoven with flehy Fibres, therefore Vealius and Archangelus have, perhaps not unjutly, reckon'd them to be Mucles. Now they carry along the praeparatory and deferent Veels, even as they contain the Stones. Now this pare of Ligaments or Mucles, is omtimes loonedThe falling down of the Womb. by violence, difficult Labor in Childbed, weight of the Child in the Womb, &c. o that the Bottom of the Womb fals into the Privity, omtimes with the Neck inverted; alo omtimes it hangs out, and is cut off; in which cae alo it is neceary that there be a Solution of the Connexion of the Neck.

The other pare is lower, being round like Earth-worms, reddih like MuclesThe Lower. (whereupon ome have conceived them to be Mucles, that perform the Office of the Crematers in Men, o that the Womb is by them moved up and down, or at leat is etablihed and trengthned, in carrying Burthens, expelling the Child, Outcries, and Labors, in Deflux of Humors into this Part, which Opinion Pinaeus embraces. Alo it is hollow, epecially in the end. It aries from the ides of the Bottom of the Womb, and at its beginning touching the deferent Veels, it acends to the Groins, and as the permatick Veels in men, o thee Ligaments in Women, pas along through the productions of the Peritonaeum, and the Tendons of the obliquely decendent Mucles of the Belly, and there they are obliterated into Fat, or Membranes of the Bones near the Clitoris, to which they are fatned, and degenerated into a broad and nervous thinnes. Where two other Mucles begin, without the Belly, being thin and broad, cloathing the whole inner face of the Lips; by help of which, ome women move the Lips. The remaining part of the foreaid Ligament, runs to the Knee, and afterward into a Membrane of the inner part of the Thigh. Hence it is, as Riolanus acquaints us, that women with Child do in their firt months complain of a pain in the inide of their Thighs.

The Ue of this Part is, 1. As hath been aid, to draw the Bottom of the Womb upwards, leat it hould fall down in relaxations, in bearing of weights, and in taking off pains; which nevertheles be more rightly aid of the pare. 2. To hinder the acent of the womb towards the upper parts, which of it elf cannot happen, unles wi • hal the Privities which are continued therewith, and the heath be drawn upwards, but in the womb relaxed, and ditended, it often happens. 3. Riolanus upects that the excrementitious Humors of the womb are omtimes carried into the Kernels of the Groins, by thee Ligaments, where alo he hath found venereous B • bo's raied. Otherwie, Hippocrates draws the Bubo's in the Groins of Women from their Coures, which Aurelius Severinus refers to critical Abcees, and Arantius eeks out their Paages in the Veins, by which the turgent Humer is carried from the womb to the Groins. I put the Arteries in place of Veins, whereby Excrements are both here and in other parts, carried to the extremities or outmot places in the Body. 4. Spigelius in a Woman kil'd with over much carnal Copulation, oberved thee Ligaments near the Womb, full of Seed. Which makes me upect that thee Ligaments, having received a Seminal Moiture, do moiten the neighbouring Parts in Women with Child, that all Parts may more eaily be looned and tretched in Virgins and barren Women, they are meer Ligaments, and by their Moiture defend the womb from the violence of burning Heat.

The Subtance of the womb is membranous,Its Subtance. that it may be dilated and contracted, as need hall require, furnihed with many pleits and folds, which in Women with Child are tretched our, to widen the womb, but they are contracted when the Child is excluded, and in aged women. Beides thee pleits, it hath in women with child Pipes and large Cavities, or Cells exceeding manifet. Now the Subtance of the womb is made up of a common and proper Membrane.

The common is doubled, and growsIts Membranes. to the ides on each hand, ariing from the Peritonaeum, being exceeding thick, and mot firm for trength, mooth every where, ave where the Spermatick Veels enter, or the Ligaments go out.

The proper and internal is alo double; though it is hard to dicern o much, by reaon of its cloe adhaeion, ave in Exulcerations. And be • ween both there were flehy Fibres, uch as are found in the Stomach: which ome call the proper Subtance and Parenchyma of the womb (whereinto a pungie Body is here and there trewed) and the ue thereof is to heat the womb. But thee Membranes are not of the ame thicknes alwaies: as was aid before, when I pake of the Magnitude.
The Veels of the womb are Veins, Arteries,Its Veels. and Nerves.

The Veins and Arteries accompanying one another, are carried between the Coats of the womb, and pour forth their Blood into thoe membranous Pipes of the womb, but are not carried into the inmot Cavity of the womb. And they are twofold: ome arie from above, others from beneath. For, from the upper and lower parts, that is to ay, from the whole Body, the Blood ought to come, both that in the monthly terms, the whol Body may be purged, and alo that in the time of a womans going with child, her Fruit might be nourihed. Thoe which come from above, do creep all the womb over, but epecially in the bottom thereof, and they are Branches derived from the Seminal Veels, before the praeparatory Veels are contituted, and alo from the Haemorrhoidal Branch, whence there is o great a Conent between the Womb and the Spleen. The left ends of the Veins and Arteries are joyned with the right ends: thatWhy the left Veins of the Womb are joyned to the right the right part may alo be augmented with plenty of Blood. The Mentrual blood is hed forth by the Arteries in Women not with Child: and therefore according to the Obervation of Walaeus, if about the time of the Mentrual Flux, the Pule of the Heart and Arteries may be made greater, then the blood is more vehemently forced into the womb by the Arteries, and o the Mentrual Flux furthered. We ee alo when we have given Cordials appropriate to the womb, and tirring the Spirituous part of the Blood, that then the Coures encline to flow. Finally, the colour of the Mentrual blood in healthy women, declares that it is Arterial blood. Now it r • ns back again to the Heart, by the Veins
•… d to the Arteries for all that Blood
neither can, nor mut be voided out of the Body, when they are obtructed, becaue the blood cannot freely pas upward out of the leer Veins of the womb into the greater, the Mentrual blood is collected in great quantity, and makes great commotions of the womb. Thoe Veins and Arteries which come from beneath and acend, do arie from the Hypogatrick Branches of the Cava and the Aorta, and creep through the neck of the womb, and the lower part of the bottom, where they are every where joyned with the uperior ones. For very broad Veels are united through the bottom, both without, andAnatomoes in the womb. in the ubtance of the womb, which Anatomoes do more appear in mentrual women, and in uch as are with Child. And they may be eaily oberved, if in dead Bodies ome of them be blown up. For they all well by that blat into one. The Mouths of thee Veels or Pipes rather, do enter into the Cavity of the bottom, and are called Acetabula or Cotylidones Cups or Saucers: which gape and are opened, when the Mentrua are purged. And in Women with Child, when the womb-liver is joyned to them (in Beats the Verticilli or Tufts) drawing blood for the Child. And becaue Branches are carried into the neck of the womb from thee Veels, by them women with Child that are Plethorick, may void Mentrual blood in their firt months, when there is more blood then needs to nourih the Child. For it is not probable, that that blood comes out of the womb: for the Child would be uffocated, and through too great opening of the internal mouth of the womb, Abortion might follow.

Now it is obervable, that the VeelsThe Largenes of the Uterine Veels. of the womb, do in the time of a a womans going with Child o well with blood, epecially about the time of Childbirth, that they are as big as the Emulgent Veins, or half as big as the Vena cava or Aorta.

Nerves very many in number, are carried from the pares of the Nerves of Os acrum, and from the ixt Conjugation of the Brain, to the Neck of the Womb, and the parts about the Privities for pleaures ake: as alo to the lower part of the Bottom. Whence there is a great Sympathy betwixt the Womb and the Brain. To the upper part of the Bottom few Nerves are carried, and they are intertwited like a Net.

The Action and Ue of the womb, is to attract and retain the womansThe Action and ue of the womb. eed expelled by her Stones, and the mans eed, cat in by his Yard. Both thee Seeds are drawn into the bottom, retained, conerved, and cherihed, whence proceeds Conception. For the Womb is like a Garden or Field, which receives, preerves, and nourihes the Seed: and therefore Aritotle cals it the Field of Nature. For even the womb is alo a Field of Generation, the place or matter wherein, affording alo Nutriment of Arterial blood, yea and the Matter of which viz. the womans Seed; for the Spirituous ubtance of the Mans Seed, is the Architect which performs the work, and gives life to the womans Seed. Now the Seed of both of them, ought to be fruitful with the formative virtue which falls from the whole Body, and well and duely contituted; the womans being fit to receive the animated form, and the mans to give the ame. To the internal Heat of which two Seeds joyned together, the external Heat of the womb joynes it elf, and by a ingular virtue, tirs up that ame inbred •… ative faculty, to perform its work, by a way to <…> together unknown. Hogelandius adds the Fer •…
Action it elf impreed upon the Seed, and the due Situation of a certain Mas in the Seed, becaue we ee that of an Eg never o little haken, no Chicken is ever hatched, and alwaies in the middet of the Seed of Animals, a little after Conception, we find a certain chrytalline tranparent Mas. Certain it is, that all the Particles of the Seed, have a peculiar Determination, referring to that Part of the Body of the Parents, from whence they came, and which they are to form in the Child. But the change of this, or that determinate clotter of the Seed, does only vary the Situation of the Child formed in the Womb, which is the caue that we find the Child variouly ituate in the Womb. Eggs that have been haken, eem to be les fruitful, by reaon of the confuion and rupture as it were, of the ingular determinate parts, and the los of the Heat. Fabricius, Pacius, and Harvey do attribute the formative or haping Faculty to the Womb, and deny the ame to be in the Seed; wherein they are mitaken. For, 1. Chickens are hatched out of the Eggs, only by the itting of the Hen or ome other Bird, alo in a bed, in the artificial Furnaces of Aegypt, Tucany, Denmark, and Seeds of corn do prout upon Chamber-floures, without the aitance of any womb. 2. The external Members would ooner be haped then the internal. 3. The Father hould contribute nothing to the ormation of the Child. 4. No caue could be given of the likenes of the Child, omtimes to the Father, otherwhiles to the Mother. Now the Followers of Des Crates and amongt the ret Regius do aver, that the Particles of the Seed are agitated only by the Heat of the womb and of the Seed, and they being agitated, in regard of their figures, do necearily fall into the Branch of a Livewight, jut as when the oblong Particles of Salt, agitated in water by the force of Heat, and joyned one with another, do firt make a plate, and by the frequent multiplication thereof a four quare grain or corn, and as of ix little balls agitated upon ome plane and united together a Roe is made; and as of the Particles of Vapors ariing out of Cellars in cold weather and variouly miteing upon their doors, with a whirling motion, undry pictures of the patts of Plants are formed. And out of the aid Branch or Stalk, by little and little the whole haping of the Child is perfected without any undertanding of the Soul, or any corporeal Faculty, directing the ame, as in the Workhoues of Glasmakers after a Bubble of Glas is rudely cut, Gloves, Boots, and other things are blown by ignorant perons that come to ee the works; and in ome Fountains, by reaon of the figures of the Pores in the Pipes, we ee Images formed by force of the water breaking forth. A neat way, truly, of Conception and Formation in the womb, if it were true. No man is able in this Matter to trace the Workmanhip of Nature. But I cannot as yet perwade my elf, that all things are done rudely and mechanically in the Body, who have alwaies had an higher Opinion of Nature then o. By this means a Man were an accidental Being, and his firt haping would be accidental and fortuitous, o • by chance medley. The figures of the foreaid things happen by accident and contingently, and vary in the Particulars, whereas the Divine Shape of the mot noble Creature Man, is alwaies one and the ame, and happens of it elf after the ame manner. How could that Branch be formed without the Mind, which is not in our Hands? I profes I know not. For a Glas is formed by the widening and working of an inanimate Matter, and as in the formation thereof, there is required the blat and the hand of the Artificer, with the aitance of •• e fire; o in an animated Child, the internal

page 69 formative Faculty of the Animated Seed. does jovn it elf to the Heat of the womb and of the Seed. Nor is the Formation of the Child only apparent, as the artificial Images of water are, but true, contant, and permanent. Abenina, Paracelus, and Am •• tus Luitanus, have contrariwie been perwaded that a Child may be generated our of the Mothers womb: but nob •• will be forward to believe them, unles
they could new us ome example, which their Followers will never be able to do. For that a little child hould be made in a Glas of a Mans Seed and Mentrual Blood, placed in Hore-dung, it hath never been my hap to ee as yet, and it ought to be doubted, becaue the Experiment cannot be made. For the Heat and Virtue of the Seed and Blood would expire, before they could be mingled in the Glas, and it would be a very hard matter, to get the Seed of a woman to mingle among the ret.

That Conception hath been made, and a Child formed out of the womb, ome Examples tetifie. Touching the Trumpet of the womb, I pake before, from the Relation of Riolanus. A Child conceived in a womans Stomach. That a Child was conceived in the Stomach of a young woman the Wife of an abominable Taylor, and voided by her mouth the length of a mans finger, but well haped in all Parts external and internal. Salmuth informs us, decribing the Story from the Letters of Komelerius to Gothofredus Hofmannus, nor does he doubt of the truth of the Story. That the ame may be performed in the neck of the womb, thoe Superfoetations, eem to demontrate, which are voided in the firt place to make more room for the larger Conception in the womb. But thee are to be accounted very rare and praeternatural caes, if true. But Superfoetation, whether in the womb or without, depends from the virtue of the womb, reaching all over the whole Body thereof.

The womb is therefore neceary to preerve the Species or kind. Howbeit it contributes alo to the health of the Individual, as the emunctory or clener of the whole Body. Howbeit very many women have lived very long, and happily without it, witnes Abenzoar, Aegineta, Wierus, Zacutus. When it hath fallen out putrified, it hath been all in a manner cut off without danger, according to the Obervations of Rhaes, Carpus, Mercurialis, Langius, a Vega, Paraeus, Baubinus, and others. Fernelius tells us he aw a childing woman, who voided with her Child her whole womb, pluckt away by the roots, without danger of life. Saxonius relates other Stories of like Nature. Saronus aies that Sows are made more corpulent in Galatia, by cutting out their wombs. Pliny tells us that Sows were hung up by their ore Legs, and had their tones and wombs cut out, that o looeing the ue of Venery, they might become more fat and delectable to the Palate. Nor is it without reaon, becaue the womb is the Mother of many Dieaes, by reaon of the Obtruction of the narrow Veels, and the ready falling down of Humors, which when the womb is away, are more readily purged out by a larger paage.

Moreover another action of the womb is aid to be a certain Natural motion:The wombs motion. whence Plate would have the womb to be a certain Animal or Live-wight, and Aretius aies it is an Animal in an Animal, becaue of its motion. For in carnal Copulation, and when it is poffeed with a deire to conceive, it is moved now up and then down, and gapes to receive the Yard, as a Beat gapes for its Food. And omtimes it is moved downwards, to expel the Child and Secondine, with o much violence, that it falls out.

Moreover it is moved with, rejoyces in, and is delighted with weet melling things: but it huns tinking and trong melling things, as Catoreum, Aafoetida, &c. Hence Aritotle aies, that women with child will micarry at the mell of a Candle- •• uff.

But the womb is enible of C •… not under the formality of Odours, but is only affected by the delicate and ubtile vaporous matter conjoyned. Even as we ee al the Spirits recreated, by weet melling things, not in repect of the mell preciely, but of the vapor conjoyned therewith, which is familiar and acceptable to the Spirit. And therefore the Genital parts of women are the ooner affected, becaue they have an exceeding quick Sene. And becaue weet melling things have good and pleaing Vapors joyned with them; and tinking things have filthy and ugly Vapors; therefore by the latter, the Spirits are made more impure, and becaue the womb is full of Spirits, therefore he is delighted with weet and fragrant things, and abominates uch as are tinking.

And nevertheles, ome women areWhy weet melling things do hurt ome women. found whoe wombs are badly contituted, who are put into Fits of the Mother by weet melling things, and cured by uch as tink: becaue Nature being provoked to Expulion by the latter, does with the tinking Vapors expel the morbifick Matter. But with the former filthy Vapors are tirred up in the womb, which before lay hid, o that they acend to the Midriff, Heart, Brain, &c. whence proceed trangling Fits of the Mother. Now thee Vapors acend partly by the enible Pores, and partly by the Veins running back, and carrying the aid Vapors with the uterine Blood: for I cannot allow of the power Helmont aigns to his ruling Parts, without manifet and known Paages. Now the womb it elf does not acend, nor is it moved out of its place, unles being ditended, it takes up more room then ordinary, nor does it roule up and down like a Bowl or Globe in the Cavity of the Belly, as Hippocrates and Fernelius have imagined. Nor do the horns of the womb being welled, move any more then the womb it elf, as Riolanus upects, for they are fatned by their Membranes, and they cannot hed their Seed into the Belly, the waies being topped, but Vapors have an • aie motion, which being diipated, the Swelling of the Belly preently falls.

Beides its Sene of Smelling, Tating, Feeling, it is furnihed according to Helment, with a kind of brutih Undertanding, which makes it rage, if all things go not according to its deire. But thee things favor of the Opinion of Plato, who improperly did compare the womb to a living Creature. Whence that fury proceeds, I have already declared. As for what that ame Novellit Helmont aies, that it lives many times, and keeps a coile after a woman is dead, no man will eaily believe it. For its life depends upon the life of the whole Body; and if it tir after death, either that motion proceeds from winds, or from a Child eeking its way out, after the Mother is dead, as undry Examples demontrate. Sphinx Theologico-Philoophica, tells us that the Mother being dead, a Child uddenly iued out of her womb, and cried lutily. After which manner Laurentius decribes the Birth of Scipio and Manilius. Eberus hath two Examples of a Child born after the Mothers death, as alo Johannes Matthaeus, and the like caes are freh in the memory of many here at Hafnia. But in oppoition to Winchlerus, Sperlingerus, and others that deny it, we mut oberve, 1. That the Child mut necearily be trong. 2. That the Orifice of the Mothers womb mut be large. 3. That the Mother being dead, the mouth of the womb mut be widened, and her Thighs pred, or ele the Child will be trangled before it can come forth.

div.head: Chap. XXIX. Of the Bottom of the Womb, and its Mouth.
div.p: WEE have treated hitherto ofSee Tab. XXVII. the Womb in General, and its imilar Parts. The diimilar Parts follow, into which we have divided the ame: viz. the Bottom, the Neck, and the Privity, with the Parts annexed.

The Fundus or Bottom of the womb, is that part which reaches from the internal Orifice to the End upwards. We divide it into the lower and narrower part and the larger upper part; to which we ad a third part viz. the Mouth.

The lower and narrow part, is that between the Mouth of the womb, andThe hort Neck of the womb. the beginning, largenes thereof, and it may be called the hort Neck, to difference it from the true and long Neck. For before the widenes of the womb begins, between it and the inner Mouth, there interceeds another Neck as it were, or narrower Channel, then the largenes of the Bottom, and this is oberved both in Man and Beat. And Fallopius is of Opinion, that this part was called the Neck of the womb by the Ancients, as Galen, Soranus, &c. Pinaeus reckons this part to be as long as a mans thumb, I have oberved it to be five fingers breadth, long in a Doe.

The Cavity hereof is not large, but uch as will admit a Probe or large Quil.Some Caue of Barrennes. It is rough, leat the Seed which hath been drawn in, hould flow out again, as happens in ome barren women, which have this part lippery, by reaon of bad Humors. This roughnes aries from wrinkles, which according to the Obervation of Pinaeus, have their Roots ituate beneath, and their Edg tending inwards or upwards, that they may eaily admit, hardly let go any thing.

The large and upper Part is chiefly termed Fundus or the Bottom, and this PartThe Bottom. is properly called the Womb or Matrix, and it is the principal Part for whoe ake the ret were made, being wider and larger then the ret.
It is eated above the Os pubis or Share-bone, that it may be there dilated and widened.

The womb hath in a woman only one Cavity, not ditinguihed into anyNo Cavities or Cells in the womb of a woman. Cells, as ome fally attribute therunto even Cells. In Brutes it is commonly divided into two parts, and therefore thoe parts are called the two Horns of the womb: though theWhy Horns are aid to be in the wombs of women. form of Horns is not conpicuous in all Brutes, but in Cows, Does, Sheep, Goats, &c. Howbeit in imitation thereof, Authors have attributed horns to the wombs of women, becaue on the ides of the bottom thereof, there is on each ide ome protuberancy, where the deferent Veels are inerted. But the womb of a woman is very eldom divided into two parts, as it is in Beats, as it hath been oberved in ome by the Brother of Baubinus, Sylvius, Riolanus, and Obequens before them. And I doubt whether their wombs be o divided, who bear two or more Children at a Birth. The lat year many women at Hafnia bore Twins contrary to their cutom, yea and ome three Children at a Birth, which they never did before nor ince. We mut not therefore account that to be proper to Families, or attribute the ame to the wombs being double, which properly belongs to the Seed. Alo that they are not conceived in a double womb, the womb-cake tetifies, which alone is ufficient for many Children, only it hath o many trings fatned to it in everal places, as there are Children, as Beterus hath lately decribed it in a like Hitory.

Yet is it divided into the right and left part. In the former Boys are for the mot part ingendred: in the latter Girls. And it eldom happens otherwie, if we believe Hippocrates and Galen. Hunters have this ign whereby they known whether the Beat they hunt have a male or female in her belly, for if when he is truck dead, he fall on her right ide, they conclude he is big of a Male, becaue the burthen he goes with is mot weighty on the right ide; if on the left he fall, they judg it is a Female. Tis reported that women with child of a Boy, do lift their right foot higher then their left, as they walk, as Salmuth gives us to undertand, all which igns are nevertheles fallacious. Hippocrates and his followers do reckon other igns, which are not proper for this place.

The right and left ide are differenced by a Line or Seam which ticks up obcurely, which Aritotle termes the Median Line. The like Line is een in the lower Belly under the Navil, dividing that Region into two parts, which they conceive to be then more viible, when women bear twins. But in ome women with child I have een this Line manifet, who bore afterwards only one Child.

The outward Surface is mooth and even, and covered as it were with a watry Humor. The inner part hath many Poroities, which are Mouths, through which in the time of a womans going with child, blood eaily paes out of the Veins of the womb to nourih the Infant.
Its Ue is to receive the Seed, contain the Child, nourih it, &c.

The Orifice or inner Mouth of the womb The inner Orifice of the womb. is oblong, and tranvere, but very narrow (but when it gapes, it is round and orbicular, which is perhaps the caue why the German Midwives call it the Roe, and the French Midwives, the Crown of the Mother) like the Hole of the Nut of the Yard, that no hurtful thing may enter in, nor the Seed drawn thither, eaily pas out. If at any time it fall out of the Privity, or be turned inide out, it reembles exactly the Mouth of a Tench.

If the Situation thereof be changed, o that it be not jut in the middle, looking towardst he bottom, tis conceived a Man cannot quirt his Seed thereinto, and that the Seed will ooner flow back, then the woman conceive. If it be quite abent, which eldom falls out, an uncurable BarrennesSome Caues of Barrennes. is thereby caued. As alo Barrennes is caued, if it be otherwie affected, viz. with Cancers, cirrhous Tumors, Obtructions, Calloity, over much Fatnes: epecially through over much Humectation and Relaxation, either through over much Copulation as in Whores, or through too great a Flux of Humors.
In women with child a glewih clammy Matter grows to the Orifice, and fills the hort Neck wellnear; that thee Parts being moitned, may more eaily be opened in the time of Travel.

Within the Channel of this Mouth to the lower part thereof, grows its little bunch, which does more exactly hut •… ole, according to the Obervation of Riolanus
He alo informs us that about this little bunch, there are to be een Pores or little Holes, which eem to be the ends of the deferent Veels, ending at the Neck. Columbus found thoe Veels implanted like the teeth of a comb, full of Blood.

By this Orifice, the womb draws the Seed into it, which being conceived, it isThe Ue of the Orifice of the womb aid to be hut o cloe, that the point of a needle cannot enter. And therefore Phyitians do vainly quirt Liquors thereinto with a Syringe, and Whores endeavor inWhen the Mouth of the womb is opened. vain to draw out the Conception. But it is opened in Superfoetation, in the Ejection of a bad Conception without hurt to the Child, which omtimes happens in the Emiion of Seed, but it is epecially opened after a wonderful manner at the time of Child-birth, when it ought to be widened according to the greatnes of the Child, o that the widenes is in a manner equal from the bottom of the womb to the Privity, whereout the Child paes. And this aies Galen we may wonder at, but we cannot undertand. And he admonihes us upon this occaion, that it is our duty to acknowledg the Wiedom and Power of him that made us. But this Orifice as well as the womb, does chiefly conit of wrinkled Membranes, which being moothed out, will admit of unimaginable Dilatation.

div.head: Chap. XXX. Of the greater Neck of the Womb.
div.p: IN the Bottom of the Womb we haveSee Tab. XXVII. oberved three things; the Bottom it elf, the leer Neck, and the Orifice. In the greater Neck alo, three things are to be noted. The Neck it elf, the Hymen, and the Mouth of the Bladder. Of the Hymen we hall treat in the following Chapter.

The Neck or Channel of the womb, is by Aritotle alo omtimes called Matrix, and the Door of the Womb, Fallopius calls it Sinus pudoris, the Privity. It is a long Channel, being hollow even when the Child is in the womb, admitting both a Probe and a mans finger, as may be een in uch as are new born.
It is ituate between the external and the internal Mouth, receiving the Yard like a heath.

Its Figure. The Neck is omwhat writhen and crooked, alo it is horter and traiter, when it is looe, and fals together; that the internal parts may not be refrigerated. But it is traight and widened 1. In carnal Copulation. 2. In the monthly Flux. 3. In the time of Child-birth, when it is exceedingly tretched according to the Shape of the Child; whence alo proceeds the exceeding great pains of women in travel: and then as alo during their Coures, women are very much cooled.

Its Magnitude. The length thereof is eight fingers breadth commonly, or even; o as to be as long as a Mans longet finger. It is as wide as the Intetinum rectum or Are-gut. But the longitude and latitude of this part are o various, that it is hard to decribe them. For in carnal Copulation, it accommodates it elf to the length of the Yard, and this Neck becomes longer or horter, broader, or narrower, and wells undry waies according to the lut of the woman. And when that happens, the Caruncles well with Spirits which fill them, as appears in Cows and Bitche •… deire Copulation; but the Channel is made narrower and les, as alo in the Act of Generation, that it may more cloe embrace the Yard: and therefore its

Subtance is of an hard and nervous fleh, and omwhat pungy, like the Yard; that it may be widened and contracted within, the upper part is wrinkled, when it is not ditended, butWrinkles in the Neck of the womb. being widened, it is more lippery and mooth. Howbeit in the Neck of the womb alo when it is ditended, there are many orbicular wrinkles in the beginning of the channel near the Privity, mot of all in the fore part next the Bladder, les towards the Intetinum rectum on which it rets; and they erve for the greater Titillation caued by the rubbing of the Nut of the Yard againt the aid wrinkles. And in young Maids thee wrinkles are traiter, and the Neck narrower, through which the Mentrual blood is voided; alo in grown perons that are yet Virgins. But the wrinkles are worn out, and the ides become callous, by reaon of frequent rubbing, 1. In old women. 2. In uch as have ued much Copulation, or have frequently bore Children. 3. In thoe that have been troubled with a long Flux of the Coures, or of the Whites. And in all thee the ubtance does alo become harder, o that it becomes at lat gritley, as it were old women, and uch as have born many Children. But in young Maidens, it is more oft and delicate.
The Ue of the Neck is to receive the Yard being raied, and to draw out the Seed.

Finally, beyond the middle towardsThe Orifice of the Bladder. the end of the Neck, in the fore and upper part, not far from the Privity, comes the Inertion of the Bladder into ight, that the Urin may there be voided by the common Paage. It is as long as a knucle of ones finger, without flehy, or rather covered with a flehy Sphincter. Pinaeus oberves that it is black within, of the ame ubtance with the Pis-pipe in Men, as any man may ee, now Riolanus that told us o.

Wierus hath noted in his Obervations, that the outer extremity of the Neck of the Bladder, does not in all women appear in the ame place, in many tis een above the outer traits of the neck of the womb, under the Nymph; in ome few it lies hid inwardly, in the upper part of the Privity. But the entrance into the Bladder, is ound on the back-ide, when the Membrane called Hymen is there: of which we are now to peak.

div.head: Chap. XXXI. Of the Membrane called Hymen.
div.p: THe Hymen or Membrane calledSee Fig. IV. and V. of Ta • . XXVIII. Eugion, is by others called the cloure of Virginity, and the Flower of Virginity, becaue where it is, there is a ign of Virginity.

Now whether or no there is any ign of That there is ome true ign of Virginity. Virginity, ought not to be doubted. For all Men find that marry Virgins, that there is omwhat that hinders their Yard from going in, unles it be thrut forward with great force and trength. Whence Terence aies the firt Copulation of a Virgin is exceeding painful. And at that time for the mot part, blood iue with great pain, more or les; which Blood is alo called
•… er of Viro.

For by reaon of the widening of theWhy Virgins are pained in their firt carnal Copulation. trait Neck of the Womb, and the tearring of the Hymen, all Virgins have pain and a Flux of blood in their firt Copulation. Younger Virgins have more pain and les Flux of blood, becaue of the drines of the Hymen and the mallnes of their Veels; but thoe that are older, and have had their Coures, have les pain and greater flux of blood, for the contrary caues.

But if her Coures flow, or have flowed a little before: the Yard is eailyAn Exception. admitted, by reaon of the Relaxation of thoe Parts, whence there is little or no pain, and little or no flux of blood. And therefore Maids ought not to be married at that eaon, leat the Bridegroom come to upect the Virginity of his Bride.
Now what it is that hinders the Yard from entring, that is to ay, inWhat is the token of Virginity. what part the token of Virginity conits, there are undry Opinions and Differences.

I. The Arabians ay the Hymen isThe I. Opinion of the Arabians. a piece formed of five Veins at the middle of the Neck of the womb, inerted on either ide, o that the Mouths of the rightide Veins are joyned with thoe on the left.
Thee are Fancies.

II. Others (among whom are Fernelius and Ulmus) do ay that theThe II. Opinion. ides of the Neck grow together, and when they are eparated and widened, the Veins are broken which run in thoe Parts. But this is contrary to Experience, which witnees, that in little Girls the Neck hath its Cavity, nor do the ides thereof tick together.
III. Others ay it is a tranvere Membrane.The III. Opinion.

And herein they are right. But they are deceived, who have feigned it to have Holes in it like a Seive, and placed it in the lowet end of the Neck: through which they would have the Urin to be voided.

IV. The newet Opinion of all, is that of Severinus Pinaeus, a motThe IV. Opinion. expert Surgeon of Paris, who hath wrote an whole Book of the Notes of Virginity, not unprofitable to be read. Now he accounts the four Myrtle-hap'd Caruncles to be the Hymen, tied together by a mall Membrane, placed in the outer part of the neck of the womb; of which hereafter. And ome learned men are at this day of his Opinion, as Bauhinus for one. I could find no other in a young Girl, lately diected in this place.

V. The more common Opinion is, that the Hymen is a tranvere MembraneThe V. Opinion trengthned by many Authors. going athwart the neck of the womb, a little above the Neck of the Bladder, which reits the firt Entrance of the Yard. And many Experiments and Authorities tand up for this Opinion. And in the firt place of four mot renowned Anatomits, of Padua, Vealius, Fallopius, Aquapendent, and Caerius. And all Antiquity had ome knowledg hereof. Hence the Author of that old Friers vere, or riming vere.
div.q: Et magnum crimen perrumpere virginis hymen.
Tis a huge in to break the skin of a Virgins Gim.
div.p:
Archangelus, Alexander Benedictus, and Wierus aent hereunto. Carpus alo knew as m •…
ger eem to have been ignorant hereof in the 1. Sect. of his 175. Exercitation, where he peaks of a Root that extreamly excites Lut. For he aies; If any hall pis thereon, they ay he will preently be full of flehy deires: Virgins that look to Cattle in the fields, if they it thereon or make water, tis aid the skin in their Privity will break, as if they had been defloured by a Man. Columbus and Sebizius did three times find it, Baubinus twice, as he averrs in his Book of the imilar Parts, and Wolfius eems in his Intitutions to aent thereunto, who witnees that he found it at Padua. Adrianus Spigelius affirms that he found it in all the Virgins that ever he did cut up, and I my elf and Velingus at the ame time aw it at Padua. Nor is it neceary to bring all the Authorities which might be had in this ubject to this place.

And whereas Columbus and Paraeus The Confutation of uch as deny it to be alwaies found in Virgins. deny that it is alwaies found, and Laurentius aies he could never find it: the reaon was that they wanted Bodies to diect, or were negligent in their work: or they might diect uppoed Virgins who had been defloured. Or if they diected young Virgins, they through wantonnes do omtimes with their fingers break the aid Skin or Membrane. But if they hall ay they did cut up abortive Births, Girls of two or three years old &c. I anwer tis incredible that the Hymen hould be wanting in uch, eeing the Authorities and Experiences of skilful Anatomits forecited, are againt it. Again, if in ome by them diected, it was wanting; by the ame right that they ay this Membrane is praeternaturally preent, we hall ay it was praeternaturally abent. For it is eldom abent, and for the mot part preent. And others that are for Laurentius againt us, uch as Capivaccius and Augenius, are to be rejected as perons not skilled in Atronomie.

VI. There is a midling OpinionThe VI. Opinion. of Melchior Sebizius, viz. that all the igns of Virginity mut be joyned together, when they are preent. And when the Hymen or Skin o called is abent, we mut ret in the traitnes of the Neck and other marks, which being widened in the firt Copulation, pain and effuion of blood follows by reaon of the Solution of Continuity.
Thee things thus promied, let us come to the Structure of this Hymen or thin Skin which goes cros the neck of the womb.

Tis ituate in the neck of the womb, near the end thereof, jut behind the Inertion of the Neck of the Bladder, or a little more inward. For the Situation does now and then vary, though the difference is but little. And there this Membrane goes cros the Cavity, like the Diaphragma or Midriff.
Its Figure. In the middle it hath an hole like a ring, o that in grown Maids, it will admit the top of ones little finger, through which hole the Coures flow.
But Aquapendent hath many times found this hole in a threefold difference.The hole in the middle of the Hymen, is of everal fahions.
I. As being Naturally contituted, and jut oppoite to the external Privity.
II. Higher, and not jut againt the Privity.
III. That in the middle was no round hole, but a chink omwhat long. Sebezius likens it to the horned Moon a little full. For Nature ports her elf in the variety of Shape.
But eldom is the Hymen without any holes <…> then the Coures cannot come away, whence f •… lat Di •… Death, unles it be ope •…
Its Magnitude. On its ides, where it grows to the neck of the womb, tis thicker then in the middle.
Its Connexion. It is continued to the Subtance of the Neck, as if it grew out of the ame.

Its Subtance is partly membranous, partly flehy, nor yet very thick. And in ome it is thinner and weaker then in others. As in the Prayan Virgins of Campania, who are there all devirginated after twelve years of age, partly by the Heat of the Sun, partly of their own Bodies breaking the Membrane, as I was told by Relation of Friends there. In ome it is more oild and thick, and omtimes o trong, that it mut be cut open, epecially when the Bridegroom is lazie and impotent: for if he be a luty Carle, he is wont after ome months labor, to make his way through.

This Membrane is furnihed with many little Veins, which being broken in the firt Copulation, pain and blood-hed aries. Finally, it wears away at lat, either through Copulation, or wanton rubbing; even as in men the Fraenum or bridle of the Yard is omtimes torn.

But there is a great and erious Quetion, whether or no in the firt carnal Act, all A Quetion touching the hedding of blood in the firt Copulation. Virgins mut needs void Blood, as a certain ign of their Virginity?

I anwer, that it happens o for the mot part, and ought alwaies o to happen. And therefore in 22. of Deuteronomie, at Marriages the bloody cloath was hewed to the Elders, as a witnes of the Virginity of the Bride. Leo Africanus aies the ame cutom was ued in Mauritania, and I was told by a Syrian, that it is oberved at this very day in Syria. Augenius indeed out of Rabbi Salomon and Lyranus, do undertand this Text Metaphorically, as if the preading of the Garment did ignifie, the words of witnees, by which the Chatity of the Bride was diligently enquired into and declared. But the bet Interpreters retain the Litteral Sene of the Words. Sebizius proves that it was to them a perpetual ign, becaue 1. Their Virgins were married very young. 2. Every one was careful of himeif becaue of the Law of Jehova • . Others contrarywie conceive that it was a ign for the mot part. Marius excepts when the Bridegroom is impotent, and a Surgeon may eaily judg in uch a cae. Sennertus aies in that Law the affirmative Inference is good, but not the negative; and that nothing ele can be concluded, but that where it is, it is a ign of Virginity. Therefore it may be hindred, and not appear.

list.item: 1. If Virgins break it through wantonnes with their fingers, or ome other Intrument. Hence it is that ome Nations, ow up the Privities of Girls new born, leaving a little way for the Urin to come forth; nor do they open it till the time of Marriage: and then the Bridegroom caues it to be opened, that he may be ure he hath a Virgin.
2. If it be the time of her Coures, or he have had them a little before.
3. If the Chink in the Hymen be very long, for then there happens only a Dilatation and no breaking.
4. If the Neck of the Womb be very wide, and the Yard not ufficiently thick.
5. If the Man thrut in his Yard cleverly.
6. If the Virgin have had the falling down of the womb, whereby the Hymen was broke.
7. If the Virgin be in years before he is married.

8. If by continual Deflux of harp Humors, the • n be either moitued or fretted, which frequen
•… pens in ickly men, through fault of their Con
•… badnes of the Climate <…> healthly Hebrew Virgins, being in a good Climate, and of a trong Contitution, did eaily by care avoid thee Inconveniences.

div.p: The Ue of the Hymen is, to defend the internal Parts from external Injury. 2. To tetifie a Maids Virginity.

Now a Maid may conceive withoutWhether Conception may be made without hurting the Hymen. hurting the token of her Virginity, which Americus Veputius relates to have been common in the Indies, and Speronus and Peramatus prove the ame. Tis reported that at Paris a certain woman in this preent Age wherein we live, was got with Child, without any Detriment to her Virginal Parts, and a like Hitory is related by Clementina. Which we may conceive to be done five manner of waies, reckoned up by Plempius and Sinibaldus, which for Honors ake, I hall here omit. Nor does this any waies prejudice the Conception of our Savior, which was performed without any of thee waies, without the Embracement of any Man, and only by the overhadowing of the Holy Spirit, of which it belongs to Divines to treat. If we believe Suidas, the Membrance was by the Midwives found in the Virgin Mary, when it was quetion'd, whether he had lot her Virginity or no; which I conceive to have been inconitent with the Modety of that bleed Virgin. The living Simon Magus, that he might be reputed for a God, boated that he was born of his Mother Rachel, he being a Virgin. St. Augutine conceits that in the State of Innocence, the Seed of the Man might be conveighed into the Womb of the Woman, her Virginity remaining uncorrupted, even as now Mentrual blood comes out of the womb of a Virgin, without any Detriment to her Virginity. Which Opinion Vives does explain and approve.

But that Women can become fruitful without the Seed of a Man, is incredible. For Caranza judges that Story of Pomponius Mela, of certain hairy women in an Iland, which are fruitful without any Copulation of Men, to be a Fable. Touching Incuboe, the Quetion is different, which I have handled in another place. It was lately reported in France, that Magdalena •• A • vermont the Wife of Hieronymus Augutus de Montelione a French Knight, did conceive a Son called Emmanuel, only by imagination, which de Lord a Profeer at Monpelier, made to be upected, and P. Sanchius in the ame place did wih me not to believe it. Old Authors relate that Mares in Portugal, do conceive by the wind, Ludovicus Carrius does jutifie their report. But Jutinus the Epitomizer, does more rightly explain their meaning to have been only to note the fruitfulnes of thoe Mares, and the peedines of their Conception

div.head: CHAP. XXXII. Of the Womans external Privity in General.
div.p:
WHere the Neck of the Womb ends, there begins the lat and outmot part of the womb, viz. The Womans Privity, or the outward Orifice, or Mouth of the Neck of the womb; others call it Vulva quai valva, as if you would ay a folding Door, alo Cunnus a cuneo from a wedg, or from an Impreion [whence in a Manucript of Englih Receipts, I have found it called the Print] Plautus calls it Saltus, a Wood or Grove, or
traight. Alo by another Metaphor he calls it Concha the Shell-fih, and Na •••
the Ship; others commonly call it Natura muliebris, the Womans Nature. Varre tells us the Romans called it Porca the Furrow or Parley-bed, the Sow. And what Experience of biting made, Suidas and Eutathius call it cuneiron or cuona, the Dog, let thoe judg that can peak by Experience.
It is only one in Number. Obequens tells of a Woman that had two Privities, and Licetus hath oberved many uch as Monters.

Its Situation is external, in the former Region of the Share-bones, where veryParts of the Privitie. many parts are to be een without Diection, and ome without drawing open the Lips; as the Hairs of the Share, the Lips, and the Hillocks themelves; the great external Chink, the Wings, the Tentigo; but ome parts cannot be een without drawing the Lips aide, as the foa navicularis, the two maller Chinks by the Nymphs, the bodies of the Clitoris, the Hole of the Neck of the Bladder, with with a flehy Valve, the wrinkled Chink or immediate Mouth of the Neck, with four Caruncles, and as many Membranes: where afterwards the Channel begins of which we have poken.

The Hairs of the Share in uch as are ripe, break out about the Lips, the better to cloe the Chink. And they are in Women more curled then in Maids; of undry colors, being produced by Nature, partly the helter, and partly to cover thee parts, which he judges ought in decency to be covered. But the Italian and Eatern Women out of a deire of cleanlines and neatnes, do by Art remove thee Hairs as unprofitable.

The Lips being drawn open, there appears 1. MAGNA FOSSA the largeSee Fig. II. and III. of the XXVIII. Tab. Trench or Ditch, with the outer GREAT CHINK, and we may call the foreaid Ditch Foa navicularis the Boat trench, becaue of its likenes to a little Boat or Ship. For it is backwards more deep and broad, that the lower and after-end might degenerate as it were the Ditch or Trench. In this Ditch the Lips being opened, two Holes appear, but hardly viible, ave in live bodies, out of which a good quantity of wheyih Humor Iues, which moitens the Mans Share in the time of Copulation. The Orifice or Beginning of the Neck of the Womb, is in the middle of this Ditch.
Now this Ditch with the external Chink were to be large, that the Child might in the external part come out more eaily, eeing the Skin cannot be o tretched, as the membranous Subtance within may be.
Then we meet with two COLLATERAL CHINKS, which are les: the right and the left, and they are between the Lips and the Wings.
Now in this large Ditch, there are firt of all to be een certain Caruncles or little Parcels of fleh, of which we are now to dicoure.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII. Of the Myrtle-haped Caruncles.
div.p: IN the Middle of the Ditch orSee. Fig. IV. of Tab. XXVIII. Trench aforeaid, appear four CARUNCLES or little Particles of fleh, preently after the Wings.
They are o ituate that each poees a corner, and oppoe one another in manner of a quadrangle.

One of them is before in the circumference of the hole of the urinary Paage, to hut the ame (it being greater then the ret, and forked) leat after the water is voided, any external thing as Air, &c. hould enter into the Bladder.
The econ oppoite to the former, is ituate behind, the two remaining ones are Collateral.
Their Shape reembles the Berries of Myrtle.

Their Size varies, for ome have their horter, longer, thicker, and thinner then others. Howbeit they abide til extream old Age, and wear not away o much as in thoe that have ued frequent Copulation and frequent Child-bearing.
They have ome Membranes joyned to them, which Pinaeus together with the Caruncles terms Valves: o that their ubtance is partly flehy and partly membranous.
The Hole in the middle between thee Caruncles, is of various ize, according to the age of the Party. Howbeit Riolanus hath oberved, that in Virgins it equals a third part of the great Chink.

Alo He conceives, thee Caruncles are made by the wrinkling of the flehy heath of the Privity, that the external part being narrower then the heath, may in time of travel be widened as much as it. And therefore in a Child-bed Woman, after he was brought to bed, he oberved them for even daies quite obliterated, by reaon of the great ditention of the Privity, nor is there any appearance of them till the Privity be again traitned and reduced to its Natural form.
Their Ue is, I. to defend the internal parts, while they immediately hut the Orifice of the Neck, that no Air, Dut, &c. may enter. To which end alo the Nymphs and Lips of the Privity do erve.
II. Fortitillation and pleaure, while they are wolen, and trongly train, and milk the Yard as it were, epecially in young Laes.

But Pinaeus will have their ue to be far different. For he aies thee Caruncles, whoe Extremities are flehy Membranes, are o bound together, as to leave only a little hole, and o to make the Hymen or true Mark of Virginity. Nor will he have it eated acros or athwart, but long-waies, o that the figure of the whole Hymen hould make an obtue cone, or a cone with the harp end cut off.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIV. Of the CLITORIS.
div.p: FAllopius arrogates unto himelf the Invention or firt Obervation of this Part. And Columbus gloriouly, as in other things he is wont, attributes it to himelf. Whereas nevertheles Avicenna, Albucais, Ruffus, Pollux and others, have made mention hereof in their Writings.

Some cal it the Nymph, as Actius andThe Names of this Part. Aegineta. Columbus terms it Dulcedo amoris the Sweernes of Love, and the Sting of Venus; becaue this part is the chief Seat of Delight in carnal Copulation: which if it be gently touched in uch as have long abtained from carnal Embracements, and are deirous thereof, Seed eaily comes away. The Greeks call it Cleitoris, Cleitoris. others name it Tentigo, others the womans Yard or Prick: both becaue it reemblesIts likenes to a Mans Yard. a Mans Yard, in Situation, Subtance, Compoit Repletion, with Spirits and

page 76 Erection. And alo becaue it hath omwhat like the Nut and Fore-skin of a Mans Yard, and in ome Women it grows as big as the Yard of a man: o that ome women abue the ame, and make ue thereof in place of a mans Yard, exerciing carnal Copulation one with another, and they are termed Confricatrices Rubters. •… ich lacivious Practice is aid to have been inven
•…
Pbilaenis and Sappho the <…>
• oetres, is reported to have practied the ame. And of thee I conceive the Apotle Paul peaks in the I. of Romans 26. And therefore this part is called Contemptus virorum the Contempt of Mankind.
Now the CLITORIS is a mall Production.See Tab. XXVIII.
It is eated in the middle of the Share, in the upper and former end of the great Chink, where

Its Size is commonly mall; it lies hid for the mot part under the Nymphs in its beginning, and afterward it ticks out a little. For in Laes that begin to be amorous, the Clitoris does firt dicover it elf. It is in everal perons greater or leer: in ome it hangs out like a mans Yard, namely when young Wenches do frequently and continually handle and rub the ame, as Examples retifie. But that it hould grow as big as a Gooes neck, as Platerus relates of one, is altogether praeternatural and montrous. Tulpius hath a like Story of one that had it as long as half a mans finger, and as thick as a Boys Prick, which made her willing to have to do with Women in a Carnal way. But the more this part encreaes, the more does it hinder a man in his buines. For in the time of Copulation it wells like a mans Yard, and being erected, provokes to Lut.

Its Subtance is not boney (though it was o in a Venetian Courtezan, whoIts Subtance. had it cut off, and the hardnes whereof did inflame the Yards of the Lovers) but as that of a mans Yard, it conits of two nervous Bodies hard and thick, within porous and pungy (that this part might rie and fall) ariing ditinctly from the Hip-bones, about the brims of the aid Bones. But they are joyned together about the Share-bone, and make up the Body of the Yard. Its Mucles are, according to Pinaeus three, according to Riolanus Its Mucles. and Velingus four, like as in a mans Yard, and erving to the ame Intent. The two uppermot round ones, ret upon longer Ligaments, and proceed from one and the ame place; the two others being lower, broad, and flehy, proceed from the Sphincter of the Fundament.
The outmot End or Head, ticking out like the nut of a mans Yard (the ret lying hid) is called TENTIGO, having an hole as a mansTentigo. Yard, but no thoroughfar.
It eems to be covered with a Fore-skin as it were, which is made of a mall Skin ariing from the Conjunction of the Wings.
Alo it hath Veels of all orts brought unto it.Its Veels.
Veins and Arteries common to it and the Privity, a Nerve from the ixt Conjugation, all more large then the Nature of its Body might eem to require, to caue an exact Feeling and Erection.
Its Ue is to be the Seat of Delectation and Love. And it is like the Froenulum or BridleIts Ue. on the Nut of a mans Yard. For by the rubbing thereof, the Seed is brought away.
Howbeit Aquapendent conceives that the Ue of the Clitoris, is to utain the Neck of the Womb in the time of Copulation.

Bellonius and Iovius do conceive that this is the part wherein the Aethiopians were wont to circumcie women. Aetius and Aegineta do hew us how to cut it off, confounding it with the Nymph. And even at this day, the Eatern Nations, in regard of its bignes extraordinary, do ear it, that it may grow no more. And they hire ancient women to perform this Piece of Surgery, which they improperly term Circumciion. And it is to thoe people as neceary, in regard of the deformed greatnes of the Clitoris, as it is comely; for at Alcair in Aegypt, Wenches go naked after this Circumciion, and when they are married, they wear a Smock only. Of which things is alo this kind of Circumciion, I have dicoured at large in my Puerperial Antiquities.

div.head: CHAP. XXXV. Of the Wings and Lips.
div.p: TWo red Productions offer themelves to our view between the Lips, which they term pterugia and ALAS, that is the Wings.

Galen calls them NYMPHS, eitherSee FIG. III. and IV. of the Tab. XXVIII. becaue they do firt admit the bridegroom, or becaue they have charge of the Waters and Humors iuing forth. For between them as it were two walls, the urin is cat out to a good ditance with an hiing noie, without wetting the Lips of the Privity. Others call them the Curicular Caruncles.
They are eated between the two Lips.

Their Magnitude is not alwaies alike: for omtimes one Wing, otherwhiles both, eldomer in Virgins then in women, do grow o big, epecially being frequently drawn by the fingers, or otherwie by an Afflux of Humors that by reaon of the impediments thereby happening, tis neceary to cut them. And Galen tells us that this Dieae is frequent among the Aegyptians; o that they are faln to cut them in Virgins that are to marry, and in other women alo; and Aeetius and Aegineta do peak to the ame purpoe, which others will have to be undertood of the Clitoris. And they are in the right as I conceive, becaue the Clitoris being over long, may hinder the amorous Embracement, and may be raied like the Yard; but the Nymphs cannot be this way troubleom, which are ofter, and in ome do hang down very long, yea in Whores that trade with thee Parts.
They are in Number two; the right and the left, now they are in the beginning commonly joyned together, where they make a flehy Production, like a Fore-skin cloathing the Clitoris.
Their Figure is triangular, but one angle is blunter then the ret, viz. that which comes without the Lips. It is like a Cocks-comb: and for that caue haply by Juvenal termed Crita.

Its Coloi •
is red like a Cocks-comb under his throat.
Tis covered with a thin Coat rather then Skin, as the Lips and other parts of the Mouth.
Its Subtance is partly membranous, oft, and pungy (bred peradventure of the doubling in of the Skin, at the ides of the great Chink) and partly flehy.

Their Ue is the ame with that of the Myrtle-hap'd Caruncles. And moreover that the Urin might be conveighed between them, as between two wals. Some conceive they erve as a Ligament, to upend and traiten as it were, in Virgins, the lower part of the external Chink, which eems unlikely. The Lips perform that Office, and the Nymphs hould rather traiten uch as are defloured, in whom they are longer.

The two LIPS, between which the external Chink conits, have certainThe Lips and Venus Hillocks. riings adorned with hair, which are termed Monticuli Veneris, the Hillocks of Venus. In women they are flatter then in maidens. This Part is that which is properly termed the Privity. Thee Hillocks are longih, oft Bodies, of uch a Subtance, the like whereof is not to be found in the whole Body again for it conits partly of Skin, and partly of pungy Fleh, under which is placed a parcel of hard Fat.

<…>
Juncture of the Lips, is in Virgins right,
trait, as it were a ligamentih Subtance for firmnes; but in uch as have lot their Maiden-head, it is looe, and in uch as have had a Child, yet looer; as Riolanus hath found by Experience, and any body ele may find that covers the Glory of uch Experiments.
The Ue hath been hinted before.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVI. Of the Membranes which infold the Child in the Womb.
div.p: ALL the Parts erving for Generation, both in Men and Women are explained. But becaue my deign is to dicoure of what ever comes under knife of an Anatomit, I mut alo propound ome things which are contained in the Womb of a woman with child, uch as are

I. The Infant, whoe Structure differsWher •• n the Child in the Womb differs from a grown peron only in ome things, from that of a grown peron. Which I hall briefly recount, as I did publickly, not long ince demontrate the ame, at the Diffection of a Child. Now the parts of a large Child differ from thoe of a render Embryo, and the parts of both thee from thoe of a grown Man. 1. In Magnitude, either proportionate to the whole Body, or les proportionate. 2. In Colour, ome parts are more red, ome more pale then in a grown peron. 3. In Shape, as may be een in the Kidneys and Head. 4. In Cavity, as in the Veels of the Navil and Heart. 5. In Number, either abounding, as in the Bones of the Head, Breat, and Sutures of the Skull; or deficient, as in the Call, ome Bones, of the Back, Writ, &c. 6. In Hardnes, as in the aid Bones. 7. In Situation, as the Teeth. 8. In Ue, as the Navil-veels, and thoe of the Heart, the Gut Caecum, &c. 9. In Motion, as the Lungs, &c. 10. In Excrements. 11. In Strength and Perfection of the Whole.
