div.p: Thee things will be more evident, if we hall run over all the particles which are in a Child different from the parts of our Bodies,

list.item: 1. The Umbilical or Navil-Veels, vulgarly called the Navil trings, are three, and hollow throughout to pas and repas the Mothers blood, which in grown perons turn to Ligaments.

2. There is little or no appearance of the Call, becaue there is as yet no publick digetion of the Stomach or Guts, and they are ufficiently cherihed by the Members of the Child folded together and the hear of the Womb.
3. The tomach is mal, no bigger then a Wall-nut, and for the mot part empty, there being no publick Concoction, or it is moitened with a clammy Humor.
4. The Caecum intetinum is large, omtimes thick, other whiles long, for the mot part ful of Excrements, of which I pake before.
5. The thin Guts appear contracted, colored with yellow Excrements decending through the Gallbladder.

6. The thick Guts epecially the Rectum, do contain thick black Excrements, from the private digetion, of the Stomach, Guts, Liver and Spleen or of the Spleen only, voided hither by the Caeliaca, or of the Liver alone, purged out by the Choler-paage. They are black, through their long tay.
7. The true Kidneys, are compacted of very many Kernels. The deputy Kidneys are large and more hollow.

8. The Liver with its <> fills both the Hypochondria. The Spleen is mal, becaue there is yet no fermentation in the Stomach and Veins. The color of both, is more bright and red, then in a grown peron.
9. In the Dugs there are no kernels, only a little ign of a Nipple.
10. The Thymus growing to the Veels, is viible beyond the Heart with a threefold large kernel.
11. The Ears of the Heart are large, epecially the right Ear, and pale.
12. The Unions of the Veels in the Heart, by Anatomois and a little Channel, are ingular, of which we hall peak in the following Book.

13. The Lungs hine with a yellow rednes, which is afterwards allayed by their motion. Becaue they are at preent immoveable, becaue tranpiration alone and the Ventilation of the Mothers Blood do uffice the Child in the Womb, unles it happen to cry in the Womb.

14. In the Head all things are large. The Eyes tick out, the skull is exceeding big, but divided into many parts, the brain is oft and commonly overflows with moiture; the Pericranium continued with the Dura mater, paes through the Sutures.

15. In the Skeleton, the Bones of the whole Body are oft in the firt months, afterwards ome are hard, according as they are of ue, as the Ribs; ome are gritly, as the Bret-bone, the Writ-bone, and the Tarus or beginning of the Foot (all without any hard Apophyes or Epiphyes) which nevertheles in tract of time do grow to a bony hardnes, the middle parts growing hard firt: and after their hardning ome remaine one continued bone, others are divided into many Particles.

16. The Crown of the Head remains very long open, covered only with a Membrane, which by little and little with age grows cloe up. The Sagittal future reaches to the Noe. The greater Conjunctions of the bones are moveable, placed one upon another, that in the coming out of the Womb, the skul being preed, may give way to the traitnes of the paage. The Os Cuneiforme is divided into four parts. The Bones of the Noe and both the Jawes are divided, a Gritle coming between. The Teeth lie hid in their ockets, covered with the Gums. The Vertebrae of the Back, have no harp productions, that they may not hurt the Womb. The Breat-bone being oft, hath in the middle according to the length thereof, four little round bones, Plane and Pory. Alo the Planke, Hip and Share-bones are ditinguihed by Gritles. The Carpus and Tarus are Gritly, and afterward as the Child grows bigger, they are pread out into divers bones, when there is a neceity of uing the Hands and Feet, to handle and go.
17. In the outward parts, as the Skin, Hairs, Nails, &c. there is ome difference, known to all.

div.p: II. The Membranes which invet the Child, cloath and cover it: of which in this Chapter.
III. The Navil-veels, of which in the Chapter following.

The MEMBRANES which infold the Child; are the firt thing bred in the Womb after Conception, to fence the nobler part of the Seed as may be een with the Eyes, even in the mallet Conceptions, and as the Authority of all Authors well-near does tetifie.

Their Efficient caue, is the formative faculty, and not onlyWhether the heat of the Womb only • e the Efficient caue of the Membranes. the Heat of the Womb; as the Heat is wont to caue a crut upon Bread or Gruel. For then,

list.item: I. The Crut would tick hard to the Child and could not be eparated.

II. The Heat of the Womb is not o great, as to be able to bake the ubtance of the Seed in o hort a time; whereas thee Membranes are bred well near immediately after the Conception. And if there were o great Heat in the Womb, no Conception could be made, according to Hippocrates in the 62. Aphorim of his fifth Book.

div.p: We conceive their matter to beSundry opinions concerning the matter of the aid Membranes. the thicker part of the womans eed. Others, as Arantius, will have them to be productions of the inner Tunicles, the Chorion of the Peritonaeum, and the Amnion of the Membrana <> . Others that the Mothers eed alone makes thee Memibranes: others, that they are made as well of the mans as the Womans eed.
Thee Membranes in Man-kindTheir Number. What the Secondine is, and why o called? are two, in brute Beats three: which being joyned and growing together, do make the SECUNDINE o called.

list.item: 1. Becaue it is the econd tabernacle of the Child, next the Womb.
2. Becaue it comes away by a econd birth, after the Child. [Hence in Englih we call it the Afterbirth.]

div.p:
The firt Membrane is termed AMNIOS becaue of of its oftnes and thinnes, alo Agnina, Charta Virginea, Induium, &c. And it is the thinnet of them all, white, oft, tranparent, furnihed with a few very mal Veins and Arteries, dipered within the foldings thereof. It compaes the Child immediately and cleaves every where almot to the Chorion, epecially at the ends, about the Womb-Cake, united in the middle thereof, where the Umbilical Veels come forth. Yet we can eaily eparate it from the Chorion. There is in it
plenty of Moiture and Humors wherein the child wims which proceeds in Brutes from Sweat, in Mankind from Sweat and Urin. But Aquapendent having oberved that in BrutesWhence the Liquor proceeds that is in the Amnios. the Sweat and Urin were contained in everal little Membranes, the latter more low and externally in the Chorion, the former higher, and more inwardly in the Amnion; he thought it was o in Mankind much more. But Experience and Reaon are againt it, becaue there are no Paages to the Chorion. And becaue we do not find the Urachus open in Mankind, therefore the Urin cannot be thence collected in the Amnios, but is voided by the Yard if it be troubleom, and the remainder is kept till the time of the Birth, in the Bladder, which in Children new born is for the mot part ditended and full, but in Brutes empty. Nor does the harpnes of the Urin offend the Child in the Womb, becaue 1. It is but little in a Child in the Womb, becaue of the benignity and purity of its Nourihment. 2. The Skin is daubed with a clammy Humor, and Brutes are defended by their hairines. Therefore the Ue is
I. That the Child floating therein as in a Bath, may be higher and les burthenom to the Mother.
II. That the Child may not trike againt any neighboring hard Parts.
III. That in the Birth, the Membrane being broke, this Humor running out, may make the way through the Neck of the Womb, mooth, eaie, and lippery.

Part of the Amnios does ever and anon hang about the Head of the Child when it comes forth, and then the Child is aid to be Galeatus or Helmeted. This Helmet the Midwives diligently oberve for divers repects, and they prognoticate good fortune to the Child, and others that ue it, if it be red; but if it be black, the praeage bad fortune.

Paraeus, Lemnius and others, conceive that the happy and trong Labor of the Mother, is the caue that the foreaid Helmet comes out with the child, but in a troubleom Labor it is left behind. Spigelius contrariwife, thinks that when the Mother and child are weak, it comes away. Beterus makes the Reaon to be the roughnes of the Amnios, which the child is not able to break through, or the weaknes of the child, for which caue it eldom lives to ripenes of Age. I have een both thoe that have come into the world with this Helmet, and thoe without it, mierable; and by chance it comes to cleave both to the Heads of trong and weak children.
The econd Membrane is termed Chorion, becaue it compaes the child like a Circle.

This immediately compaes the former, and lies beneath it in a round hape like a Pancake, whoe inner or hollow part it covers and invelops, preading it elf out according to the meaure thereof. It is hardly eparated therefrom, and it trongly unites the Veels to the Womb-liver, and bears them up. Towards the child it is more mooth and lippery, but where it is pread under the Womb-cake, and fatned thereto, it is more rough: alo it is ufficiently thick and double. In Brutes the Cotyledons What the Cotyledons are. cleave hereunto, which conit of a flehy and pungy ubtance. But in Mankind, this Membrane cleavs immediately to the womb, by a certain round and reddih lump of fleh, fatned to one part only of the womb (commonly the upper and former part) nor does it compas the whole child; being framed of an innumerable company of Branches, of Veins, and Arteries, among which bl •• d out of the Veels eems to be hed and interlarded.
That ame round Mas is called PLACENTA UTERI the Womb-pancake, by reaon of its Shape; alo the WOMB LIVER: which I will now exactly decribe according as it hath been my hap to ee it.

Its Figure is circular, but the Circumference unequal, in which I have oberved five Prominences ranked in due order, and the Membrane Chorion in the intermediate paces, thicker then ordinary. Where it looks towards the Womb, it is rough and waved, like baked bread that hath chinks in it; and being cut in this part, it dicovers an infinite number of fibres, which if you follow, they will bring you to the Trunks of the Veins.
It is one in Number, even in thoe who bear two or more children at a burthen. For into one Wombcake, o many Cords are inerted in divers places, as there are children.
Its Magnitude varies according to the condition of the Bodies and the children • Yet it is about a foot in the Diameter.

The Subtance thereof eems to be a Body wove together of infinite little fibres, blood as it were congealed being interpoed, which is eaily eparated. Seeing therefore it hath a Parenchyma, it is no wonder, if like a kind of, Liver it make or prepare blood to nourih the child.

The Nature and Appearance of the Subtance, is not every where alike. For here and there it is glandulous, epecially in the tops of the Hillocks, as being the Emunctories of the childs Work-houe, placed in the outmot Verges. It is thicker in the middle of the hillocks; and thin about the brims, variouly interwoven with the Capillary Veins: For,

It hath Veels, viz. Veins and Arteries running through the ame, from the Umbelical Veels, which by little and little are all extenuated about the brims of the Womb-cake, making wonderful contextures, cloely ticking to the Subtance thereof, o that no part of the Branches is void. They are joyned together by various Anatomoes, which hall be hereafter decribed, through which the blood in the child runs back, out of the Arteries into the Veins. For I have oberved in the Veins of the Womb-cake, how that the blood contained, may eaily by ones finger or an intrument, be forced towards the Trunk or Cord, but not towards the Womb-cake. The contrary where to happens in the Arteries, which by impule of the finger, do eaily end the blood to the Womb-liver, but hardly to the Trunk.
Its Ue is 1. To upport the Navil-veels, under which it is pred as a Pillow.

2. Becaue it hath a ingular kind of Parenchyma, to prepare blood to nourih the Child, as the true Liver does in grown perons. For it mediately ucks the Mothers blood through its Veins, out of the Veins of the womb, and prepares and tempers it for ue, and oon after ends it through the greater Navil-vein, into the Liver of the child, that it may be carried right forth unto the Heart, by the Anatomois and little Channel; out of which by the Arteries it is ditributed into the whole body of the child to nourih the ame. But part of the blood returns through the Iliack Arteries, to the Womb-cake, as an appurtenance to the child; partly to preerve the ame by its heat, and to nourimit with Arterial blood, partly that it may be there further perfected; which Labor being finihed, it returns back again into the concomitant Veins, that together with other blood, newly upplied by the Pipes of the womb, it may pas back again by the Umbelical Veins, and repeat the foreaid Circle.
The XXX. TABLE.
This TABLE preents a Child in the Womb naked, al the Coats both proper and common being divided.
The FIGURE Explained.
AA. Portions of the Chorion diected and removed from their place.
B. A portion of the Amnios.
CC. The Membrane of the Womb diected.
DD. The Womb-cake or wombliver, being a Lump of Fleh furnihed with divers Veels, through which the Child receives its nourihment.
E. The Branching of the Veels, which in this place make one Ligament to cover the Umbilical Veels.
FF. The Band or Ligament, through which the Umbelical Veels are carried from the Womb-cake to the Navil.
GG. The Situaton of a perfect Child in the Womb, ready to be born.
H. The Implantation of the Umbilical or Navil-veels into the Navil.
The third called ALLANTOIDES the Pudding-membrane, does not cloath the whol conception, but compaes it round like a Girdle, or a Pudding.

Its Ue is, to receive Urin from the Urachus in Brutes. For in Mankind there is no uch Membrane: for the child in a woman, its Urin is received by the Amnios mingled with Sweat: or is kept in the Bladder till the Birth-time. And therefore Spigelius cannot be excued, for admitting this Membrane in Mankind; whoe Decription (becaue it belongs not to this Anatomy) he that deires to ee, let him look in Aquapendent.

div.head: Chap. XXXVII. Of the mbelical or Navil-veels.
div.p: THe Membranes being diffected and removed, the UMBELICAL Veels come in view, o called, becaue in the Region of the Navil, the child being excluded, and the blood a little forced up to nourih the • me, they are cut off, and being tied in a knot, do make

The NAVIL which is in the <…>
What the Navil is, and of what parts it conits. of the Belly, yea and of the whole Body, if you meaure it with a circle, the Arms being tretched out.
Now there are four Navil-veels: ONE VEIN, TWO ARTERIES, and the URACHUS. Which are covered and veiled as it were with a certain common
Coat or Crut, which ome call Intetinulus, Funiculus, Laqueus, &c. which does not only wrap up all the Veels, but alo ditinguihes them one from another.
And the Ue of this Coat, is to keep the Veels from being intangled one within another, broken, or any other way hurt.

The VENA UMBILICALIS, muchThe Vena umbilicalis. greater then the Artery, being carried through the two Coats of the Peritonaeum, is bred in the firt place before all other Veins, in repect of Perfection, becaue it ought to afford nourihment to the ret.

It is een inerted into the Liver by aIts Inertion. Cleft, and goes through the Navil, omtimes imple, otherwhiles double, and divided into two Branches, the length of about an F • ll and half, as far as
to the Womb-cake. And it is variouly coiled or rouled about, that its length-might prove no hinderance. From the Navil it goes over the Breat, and from thence it is obliquely carried over the right and left ide of the Throat and Neck, turning it elf back at the hinder-part of the Head, and o over the middle of the Fore-head unto the Womb-cake; omtimes alo by this imple flexure on the left hand, it compaes the Neck like a chain. All which is to be undertood of the whole Cord, and the ret of the Veels contained therein. And this Journey being finihed, it preads infinite Branches through the Secondine, till it looe it elf into exceeding delicate fine hairy thrids.

Its Ue is to draw Blood to nourih the Child, and to carry it into its Liver, NowIts Ue. the way is doubtful. Mot men perwade themelves, that the Veins and Arteries of the Womb, are joyned with the little Veins and Arteries of the Womb-cake, and that from them joyntly blood is derived into the Navil-veels to the Child. But the Arteries are to be excluded from this Office, becaue they are not joyned to the womb, nor ought they to carry any thing to the child, but to carry back from the child to the womb-cake. The Veins do only bring thither, and that by a twofold way, either immediately from the womb, or mediately. Immediately, when they are joyned to the Veels of the womb; mediately, when by the interceeding or going between of any flehy Subtance whatoever, both in Mankind and Beats (which is alwaies for the mot part glewed to the womb, and violently broke off in the Birth) it is ucked through Pipes, firt out of the womb into the outer parts of the womb-cake, and thence into the Capillary Veins thereof, out of the leat into the greater, till at lat it is carried to the Umbilical Trunk, and to the Liver. Nor does it lip through the Veins of the womb into the Pipes, becaue the Blood of the Veins does not nourih, but it is brought in by the Arteries in a woman with child, and goes up back again by the Veins, in a woman not with child.

This Vein eems full of certain Knots: which are nothing but a more thick andThe Knots. flehy Contitution of the Membrana carnoa in thoe Parts; and a wider opening, wherewith as a poon, the Blood is drawn in, in its long Journey, and is by little and little topped, leat it flow too violently; that the Blood may be there the longer labored, as we ee in the Spermatick Veels: and that the Veels may be tronger.

By the Number of thee Knots, the Midwives do gues the number of Children that a woman hal bear: and if the Knot which firt follows, be white and narrow, they foretel that the next child will be a Girl, if red, round, and welling, that it will be a Boy. The firt Divination is vain; for there are as many Knots in the Navil of the lat child, as of the firt. But the latter may be excued by the defect or abundance of Natural heat, whence the Diverity of Sexes aries. From the ditance of the Knots one from another, they foretel that the Conceptions will be ooner or longer one after another, and that there will be Twins, if one Knot ret upon, or be near to another. Which we have often found to be fale, though chance, do now and then confirm the hope of credulous women.

Two ARTERIES are inerted into the Iliack Arteries, and are carried with the VeinArteries. after the foreaid manner to the womb-cake, where it is pred about in divers Branches, whoe Ue is not, as hath hitherto been believed, to bring to the child vital Spirit with Arterial blood, becaue thee Arteries are not joyned to the Arteries of the Womb, according to the mot certain Obervation of Arantius; but to carry back part of the Arterial blood, which is uperfluous to the Nourihment of the Child, by the two Iliack Branches into the Placenta or Womb-cake, partly to nourih the ame, and fill it with vital Spirit. Partly that the Blood may there be made more perfect, being weakned by a long Journey, and nourihing the Membranes; which afterwards runs back again to the Child, by the hairy twigs of the veins joyned thereto, with that new blood coming out of the womb.

This Motion is confirmed by Experience. I have often preed the welling veins with my finger, and have oberved that the blood is eaily forced out of the vein towards the Child, not to the Womb-cake, where the knots like valves do top the ame; contrariwie, it is eaily forced out of the Arteries into the Wombcake. The ame is manifet by Ligatures. For the Umbilical Arteries of a live Child being bound, as yet cleaving to the Mother being alive, Walaeus hath oberved and others after him, that they pule between the Ligature and the Child, but have no Pule between the Ligature and the Mothers womb.

For this Motions ake the venal andAnatomoes of the umbilical Veels. Arterial branches are joyned together by Anatomoes, within the Womb-cake, that the Paage might be ready for the blood to run back out of the little Arteries, into the little Veins.

I have here, following my own ight, oberved everal waies of Anatomoes. For omtimes the twigs of the Veins and Arteries, do go one over another croswie, both internally and externally. Somtimes they are joyned by Inertion, omtimes they couple ide to ide, and omtimes they are wreathed. The mallet Twigs of the Branches are inoculated into the greater, united in like manner, but with more blunt Anatomoes, till the Arteries are reduced to four Branches, the Vein to two, which at lat grow into the trunks of their own kind, pringing out of the Womb-cake. The Arteries go about the veins, and do partly accompany them, and partly creep alone by themelves. I upect that there are Anatomoes only in thoe places, wherein they are neceary for the paing Blood out of the Arteries into the veins, and that the olitary veins do uck freh Blood out of the Womb.

Without the Navil and Wombcake,Their Twiting. thee veels being united, as they pas along like a Rope, they are well twited one with another, yet for the mot part by an orderly Circumvolution, even as a larger Rope is made of maller cords twited together, repreenting the wreathings of our Unicorns Horn, which we could eaily perceive by holding it to the light. Which is o contrived 1. Leat by the winding paage of the Navil-veels, the motion of the Blood hould be hindred, eeing every veel that is twited, keeps it coure. 2. That the Child in the womb might receive its pittance of Nourihment by little and little, without danger of choaking. 3. That by this wreathed and crooked Journey, the future A ••
ment of the Child, might be by little and little purged and clarified.

Moreover, it is to be noted in the twiting of the cord 1. That knots and pots are tranparent in the vein and not in the Arteries, by reaon of the Blood appearing through a thinner Coat. 2. That a pans ditance from the Conjunction there appears, a wonderful contexture, and a rougher and more confued twiting then in other Parts. 3. In the outer Coat of the Intetinulum, infinite cuts and lines are een imprinted as it
were, according to the length thereof, colored on the outide with blood, uch as are to be een in the Cerebellum.

Its Length was before noted, viz. an ell and an half, in a grown child, or threeThe length of the Rope. pans, that the child may tir more eaily, the blood may be better prepared, and the econdine drawn out. If this cord be omtime either overtwited, or by motion wrapped about the Neck of the child, there is danger that the child will be trangled, and the Mother have an hard labor, becaue the child is drawn back by reaon of the hortnes of the cord, nor can it bear the violence of an indicreet Midwife. I have een it twited divers times about the Neck of a child, whereby the birth was retarded for divers hours, and when the child came forth it could hardly breath: if in uch a cae the childs Face be red tis a good ign, but a deadly token if the Face be black and blew.
'Tis as thick as a mans Finger, becaueIts thicknes. trength and a jut capacity is requiite to utain the Veels. When it is dry it becomes maller, and it is kept to procure other births,

figure.head: The XXXI. TABLE.
It hews the Child taken out of the Womb, but fatned till to the Womb-Cake, the Umbilical Veels being eparated about their Rie.
The Explication of the FIGURE.

B. The Liver of the Child.
C. The Pis-bladder.
DD. The Guts.
E. The Umbilical Vein.

div.p: The Child beingThe binding of the Navil. born, the rope mut be tied near the Belly, the ditance of two or three Fingers breadths, with a trong thred wound often about, and about three Fingers from the binding, it mut be cut off, and the Navil mut be lookt to, till it dry and fall off, of its own accord. Now the times of its falling of are uncertain, in repect of the Contitution of the child, and the plenty of Blood which flows thereto, from whence the Midwives Prognoticate how long the child hall live. If it fall of the fift day from the hour it was tied, they foretell the children will be long-lived; if on the third day, they ay they hall be hort-lived.

The Navil being thus haped and confirmed, is covered with a trong Skin, which may be preternaturally tretched to an immene degree, to receive the Guts in a Rupture of the Navil, uch as Severinus hath decribed in a Picture, and as my elf have een at Hafnia in an ancient Woman.

In ome there is a paage through the Navil into the Belly. Alpinus reports that the Aegyptians cure a bloody Flux, by thruting their Fingers into the Patients Navil, and turning it divers times about. Dung came out of the Navil of a Student, and Worms like Earth-worms with quittor came out of the Navil of a Boy, according to the Obervation of Salmuth. Tulpius aw quittor which Nature ent from the Chet, come out at the Navil, and Folius found Stones bred here. I. D. Hortius oberved blood flow from the Navil in a certain Gentleman, monthly. And he
tels us of a Boy who had a wheyih liquor like Urin dropping from his Navil, and omtimes freh blood. For the inner Veels are many times opened, by the Acrimony of the blood and wheyih humors. Alo the Navil doth inenibly open it elf when purgatives, Medicines for the Mother and to kill the Worms, &c. are applied thereto.

Now thee Veels, after the Child is born, do within the Belly degenerate into Ligaments: the Vein to a Ligament of the Liver, the Arteries into lateral Ligaments of the Bladder. Becaue their ue is now lot, and there is no longer any paage of the Mothers blood, unles they be omtimes preternaturally opened as in the examples alleadged. Yet are they not of o great moment, thatThe Dignity of the Navil is not much. their breaking or cutting off, hould caue death, as ome and among them Laurentius imagine, being quetionles abued by ome Fabulous tory. For they report that the Aegyptians punih Robbers by flaying them alive, and that they leave the Navil untoucht, that they may be tormented the longer: for they think when the Navil is cut off a man mut needs die, the four Veels being detroyed. But Riolanus a man of great experience aw contrary examples, and any man may judg by a Rupture of the Navil. If death follow, it is by accident, the inner parts being alo hurt, and a wide dore opened for all hurtful things to enter. Sperlinger conceives that they are choaked, becaue the Navil being cut off, the Liver falls down and draws the Midriff, the Organ of breathing. But 1. This hortnes of breath doth not caue udden death. 2. The Liver is held up by another trong Ligament from the Peritonaeum.

The fourth Veel, the Urachus or Pispipe, which is half as little again as theUrachus. Artery, conits of two parts, according to the Obervation of Riolanus; the inner, which is Nervous, ariing from the inner coat of the Bladder the outer which is more Membranous, from the bottom of the bladder. It is not after the ame manner in Beats as in Mankind.

In Beats tis carryed without the Navil between two Arteries, and is at lat pred out and widened into the Coat which is termed Allantoides, where Urin is collected and reerved, till the young one is brought forth. And therefore this Veel is termed Urachus, that is to ay the Pis-pipe.
In Mankind, 1. It doth not go without the Navil, and therefore it doth not make the Coat Allantoides, for which caue the Child hath only two Coats.

2. The Urachus is not hollow throughout according to the experimentsThe Urachus is not hollow in Mankind. of Carpus, Arantius, Corteius, Riolanus and others, whom I have found to be in the right, in uch Bodies as I have diected both old and young, though Aquapendens and Spigelius would perwade us otherwie. But it is a little Cord or Ligament, wherewith the bladder is fatned to the Peritonaeum and utained, leat when it is ditended with Urin, its Neck hould be queezed: Though I deny not but that the ame thing is done by the Arteries.

But a Child in the Womb voids Urin by its Yard into the Membarne Amnios (which makes it o ful of Liquor) and a great part is retained alo in the bladder, which is the caue that new born Children, for the firt daies are in a manner continually piing. Aqua-pendens denies this becaue, 1. The motive faculty doth not exercie it elf in a Child in the Womb. 2. No Mucle Acts. 3. Neither doth Nature ue o different a manner of voiding Urin in Men and Beats. But I anwer, 1. That the various moving of a Child in the Womb, which Big-bellied Women feel, doth witnes that the Child hath a moving faculty though imperfect. 2. The bladder is provoked to excretion, by the over great quantity and harpnes of the Serum, or wheyih humor. 3. The Coat called Allantoides which is not in Man-kind, doth hew the difference between Man and beat.
Uarolus will have all the Urin to be contained in the bladder, till the birth time. But then it would be broken with over tretching; and whence comes all the liquor which is in the Coat Amnios.

Aqua-pendens, Spigelius and almot all others will have it go out by the Urachus, and be collected between the Amnios and Allantoides, as in beats. But eeing it is not perforated, but olid in Man-kind, it cannot admit the Urin. For it cannot be trained through, without a manifet paage, becaue it is thick, and the ame way might hold in grown Perons. Velingius propounds both thee opinions and determins nothing. Now it is no more Porous in a young child then a grown peron. And Laurentius eagerly defends this opinion out of Galen, bringing the examples of ome, who when their Urin was topt, did void it at their Navil.

But I anwer: This is done praeternaturally,The Error of Laurentius. as it is alo a known opinion of many, that the Umbilical Vein hath been preternaturally opened in Hydropical perons, and voided the Water. And Laurentius himelf confees, that all the four Umbilical Veels do turn to Ligaments; wherein he is right, for they are dried. How therefore can they be opened unles preternaturally? So it was I conceive preternaturally opened in the ame Italian called Anna, who hath no Yard, in tead whereof a pungy bit of fleh hung out under his Navil, whence the Urin dropt. Fernelius and others have other examples of the Urachus opened.

Before the Production of all the Umbilical Veels in the Womb, the eed being curdled in the top of the hinder part, two certain Roots are inerted, on each ide one from the horns of the Womb, firt oberved by Varolius and called Radices Dorales, the back Roots which are obliterated, when the rudiments of the Child are framed, touching which Riolanus explains Abenina.

div.head: THE SECOND BOOK; OF THE Middle Venter or Cavity.
div.p: THe middle Venter or Belly termed Thorax the Chet, and byThe middle Venter what it is. ome abolutely Venter, is all that which is circumcribed above, by Clavicles or Channel-bones; beneath the Midriff; on the foreide by the Breatbone; on the hinder part by the Bones of the Back, and on the ides by the Ribs.
The fore-part is called Sternon and Pectus, &c. the Hinder-part, the Back; the Lateral Parts are termed the Sides.

Howbeit the Ancients as Hypocrates and Aritotle, &c. did comprehend allHypocrates and Aritotle. from the Channel-bones as far as to the Privities, that is to ay, the middle and lower Belly under the Name of Chet. And therefore in this Sene Hypocrates did well write, that the Liver is eated in the Chet: which other unskilful perons not undertanding, did imagine that Hypocrates was ill vered in Anatomy.

Its Figure is after a ort Oval, though not exactly, and Hypocrates compares itIts Figure. to a Tortoie or the Belly of a Lute. In Mankind, it is more bunching in the fore-part, but in the middle of the Bret-bone it is flatter, about the ides round, becaue of the bowing of the Ribs, in the Back more flat.

Its Magnitude in General, varies according to the different degree of Heat:Magnitude. for by the widenes of the Chet we meaure the Heat of the Heart. But in particular perons it is larger towards the lower Belly, where the vital bowels are concealed, and grows narrower by little and little at the beginning of the Neck.
Its outer Subtance is partly bony, partly flehy.Subtance.
This middle Belly is not wholly flehy as the lower is, 1. Becaue it was not to contain any Parts, that were very much to be tretched. 2. That over-much Fat might be bred there, and hinder Repiration.
Yet is it partly flehy, becaue it contains Parts whichought to be moved, as the Heart and Lungs, and for the ame Caue,

It could not be altogether bony, like the Skull; for that is a very rare cae which Cardan mentions in his 11. Book of Subtilties, Page 458. in my Edition, of a Man that intead of Ribs, had one continued Bone • rom the Throat to the Flanks.
Yet is it in part bony, for to afeguard the noble Parts. For,
Its Ue is, to contain the vital Parts as theIts Ue. lower and firt Belly contains the Natural.
Now the Parts likewie of this Belly areIts Parts. either containing or contained: and the former either common or proper.
The Common are the ame which are inCommon. the lower Belly. Howbeit thee things following are here to be oberved.

The Skin of the middle Belly is hairyThe Ue of the hair under the armpits. under the Arm-pits. Thee Hairs are called Subalares Pili, being ueful to keep thoe Parts from wearing and fretting, in the Motion of the Arms, eeing they exceedingly and quickly weat, becaue they are termed the Emunctories of the Heart, receiving the Excrements thereof (in ome alo that are hotter of contitution and trong-hearted the breat is hairy) as the Groins are called the Emunctories of the Liver.

Moreover, there is little Fat found in the Chet, if you except the Dugs, thatWhy there is little Fat in the Chet. Repiration may not be hurt by the weight thereof. For by reaon of its bony part, o great plenty of the matter of Fat could not flow into it, as in the lower Belly, which is wholly flehy, and therefore alwayes the fattet part of the body; the middle belly or Cavity is indifferently tored with Fat; the Head is leat fat of all. But the fat it elf being otherwie white, is wont in the chet to appear a little more yellow then ordinary, by reaon of the heat of the vital Parts which lye under the ame
The proper Parts beides the Mucles, Bones, &c. are the Dugs of both Sexes,The proper Parts. the Midriff, the Membrane of the Sides termed Pleura, and the Mediatinum or Partition-wall.

The Parts contained are the Bowels and Veels. The Bowels, are the Heart with its Heart-bag or Pericardium, the Lungs and part of the Weand or Wind-pipe, o •
apera Arteria. The Veels are the Branches of the Venae cava and Arteria magna, underpropped with the Thymus or Kernel in the Throat. and undry Nerves.

div.head: Chap. I. Of the Dugs.
div.p: ACcording to our Anatomical Method,See Tab. XXV. Lib. I. the firt Parts in the Chet which we diect, as oon as we have done with the lower Belly, are the Dugs. Now we hall treat of the Dugs of Women, cating in between while, wherein thoe of Men differ therefrom.

The Scituation of the Dugs, is in the middle of the Bret, above the PectoralWhy the Dugs in Mankind are eated in the Breat. Mucle, which draws to the Shoulder. 1. Becaue of the nearnes of the Heart, from whence they receive heat. 2. For Comelines ake. 3. For the more convenient giving of uck: becaue the Infant cannot preently walk after the manner of Brutes, but being embraced in his Mothers Arms, it is applied to the Dugs. No other Creatures have Dugs in their Breats aving the Apes, who hold their young ones in their Arms likewie. Laurentius tells us the Elephant does the like, and Riolanus ayes as much of the Bat or Flitter-moue. Some great Sea-fihes of the Whale-kind have Dugs on their Brets, full of Milk, as we lately oberved in a Whale that came out of Norwey.

They are two in Number: not becaue of Twins; but that one being hurt, theNumber of the Dugs other might upply its Office. Howbeit Varro reports, that Sows will have o many Pigs as they have teats. Walaeus in a certain woman oberved three Dugs, two on the left ide of her Bret, and one on the right. And Cabrolius oberved in a certain woman four Dugs, on each ide two.

As to their Magnitude. In Girls new born, there is only a Print or Mark viibleMagnitude. on the bret, and afterwards by little and little it wells, and in little wenches hardly any thing appears beide the teats, untill by degrees they grow to the bignes and hape of Apples; and when they are raied two fingers high, their Coures begin to flow. In old women they wither away, o that nothing appears but the Nipples, the Fat and Kernels being conumed.
In women they wel more, and in women with child the lat moneths, they are more and more encreaed.

In men they do not rie o high as in women, becaue ordinarily they wereThe difference of the Dugs in men and women. not to breed milk [yet becaue of the equality of the kind, it was convenient that men hould have them as well as women.] And therefore in men, the Dugs are commonly without Kernels: yet in burly people, the Fat which is under them raied the breats. In the Kingdom of Sengea, the Dugs of women hang as low as their Bellies; and in the Ile of Arnabo, 'tis aid they turn them over their houlders to their backs, and there uckle their children.
Their Shape is roundih. They repreent as it were an half Globe. And inTheir Shape. ome becaue of their over-great weight they hang down.
The Dug is divided into the NippleTheir Parts. and the Dug it elf. For in the middle of the Dug there is to be een a peculiar Subtance, which,

Is called Papilla, the Teat or Nipple, being pungy, like the Nut of aHow the Nipples come to have o exquiite Sene. Mans Yard, and therefore it will fall and rie when it is uckt or handled. For it hath an excellent and exquiite Sene of feeling, becaue it is as it were the Centre, into which the ends of the Nerves Veins, and Arteries do meet. Which is apparent from the Delicacy of its Sene, and the rednes of its color, a ure token of Blood brought in by the Arteries, by reaon of the Concoure whereof, Chyrurgeons do judg Cancers and other Tumors about the Nipple pernicious.

Riolanus believes that the Skin is doubled, and as it were compreed: but the doubling would make it thicker. But the Skin is exceeding tender, eaily rubbed off, and apt to be pained when the Child ucks very freely. Only in old women it grows thick. Not is the Nipple any other where made of the Skin traitned or folded.

If the Nipples turn upwards, a Male child is in the Mothers womb, if downwards a Girl according to the Tradition of Hypocrates, which hath not been as yet ratified by the confeion of women with child.
As to Number, there is one Nipple on each Dug. Hollerius aw two Nipples upon one Dug, which both yielded Milk.

Their Colour in Virgins is red, in uch as give uck it enclines to black and blew, and in them alo they are more ticking out, by reaon of the Infants ucking; in uch as are pat Child-bearing, the Nipples are of a black color.
They have a Circle round about them which is called Areola the little Parley-bed, in Virgins pale and knotty, in uch as are with child and give uck, brown, in old women black.
'Tis bored through the middle, with very mall holes for the Milk to pas through: For

The Ue of the Nipple is to be intead of a Pipe or Funnel, to put into the Mouth of the Infant, whereout it may uck the Milk: Secondly, to erve for a pleaing Titillation, whereby Mothers and Nures are enticed the more willingly, and with a certain Sene of pleaure to give their children uck.

The Dugs do inwardly conit of a Membrane,The Dug. Veels, Kernels, or rather kernellih Bodies, and Fat: though the two lat do chiefly make up the Dugs; the Kernels and Fat lye concealed between the Membrane and the Skin.
Now the flehy Membrane does faten the kernellih Subtance which it compaes, unto the Mucles which lye thereunder.

The Kernels are many: In Virgins more hard, in old women conumed, in uch as are with child and give uck, more welling and pappie. Yet there is one great one, jut under the Nipple, which the other leer ones do compas about, and infinite textures of Veels lye between them. Riolanus hath oberved a womans Dug to conit of one continued Kernel, and not of many, the contrary whereto we ee in cirrhous and cancerous Tumors.

The Ue thereof is, to turn Blood into Milk. And the ue of the fat of the Dug is to encreae heat, and to make the Dug of an even round hape. And therefore uch as have the Fat conumed by ome Dieae or old Age, they hang ill favoredly like empty Bladders, and are unfit to make Milk.

The Veels. The Dugs receive their Skin and external Veins from the Axillary, which are called the Thoracicae Superiores, the upper Chet-veins, which in women with child and uch as give uck, are often black and blew viible. They receive other internal Veins, brought thither a long way, that the Blood might be the longer therein wrought, which are termed Mammariae
Venae or Dug-veins, which decendThe Venae Mammariae. on each ide one, from the Trunk of the Axillary Vein, under the Bret-bone, to the Glandules or Kernels of the Dugs. Thee are met by other acendent Veins, by the right Mucles, of which before: and therefore the Infant being born, the Blood is carried no longerWhy Milk is bred after the child is born. to the womb, but to the Dugs, and is turned into Milk. And hence it is that women which give uck, have eldom their Coures. Hence alo, when the Children uck over-much, Blood comes out at the nipples. Yea, it hath been oberved that a womans coures have come away through her Dugs, and Milk by her womb; howbeit, this is a rare chance.

But the Matter of Milk, be it what it will, cannot according to the Principles of the Bloods Circulation, be carried by the Veins to the Dugs. The Venae mammariae or Dug-veins, do only carry back what remains uperfluous, after the Child is nourihed, and Milk made. Moreover, they are eldome joyned with the Epigatrick Veins, and they are too few and mall, alone to carry o much blood from the womb, as may uffice a Child that is a liberal Sucker.

Their Arteries proceed from the upper Trunk of the great Artery: andTheir Arteries. from the Subclavian branches, which are joyned after the ame manner with the Epigatrick Arteries, as was aid of the Veins. The Th racicae Arteriae or Chet arteries, o plentifully and evidently, that in cancerous Tumors of the Dugs, a woman hath bled to death by them, of which cae I remember ome Examples. Hence it eems more likely, blood is carried to the Dugs to make Milk, which blood being conumed in fat and elderly women they are therefore none of the bet Nures. Hence it is that women which give uck, receive great damage by looing their blood; contrariwie they are advantaged, by whatever may draw and provoke their blood to their Dugs, as by rubbing them, &c.

Now Proper Martianus and Petrus Catellus do maintain out of Hypocrates, thatThe matter of Milk is not Blood as Martianus holds. the matter of Milk is twofold, viz. Blood and Chyle: and that the greatet part of the matter thereof, is preed out of Meats and Drinks, not yet digeted in the Stomach, into the Dugs, by the Child welling in the womb, and after the Child is born, by the paages made wide by ucking: and that another mall part is made of blood acending from the womb, which is rather to be reckoned as an Efficient caue, by reaon of its Heat, then of a Material caue.
That Blood alone is not the matter of Milk, beides the Authority of Hypocrates, they prove, becaue

list.item: 1. Otherwie it were impoible that a woman hould live, voiding two pounds of blood every day, in the form of Milk.
2. When a woman gives uck, her Coures flow, which in the firt moneths of her going with child, are uppreed.
3. When a woman left breeding Milk, he would fall into a dangerous Pl • thory, or fulnes of Blood.
4. There would be no Child-bed Purgations at all, the Milk being o violently carried into the Dugs, the econd day after Child-birth, that it caues a Feaver.
5. Nature would then have framed greater Veels from the womb unto the Dugs.
6. The Milk would not retain the mell, and vertue or operation of the Meats eaten, becaue thee things are changed in the blood.
7 The Blood collected into the Dugs, does breed Madnes. Aphor. 40. Sect. 5.

div.p: But that it depends upon the Stomach But aries from the Stomach & the Chyle. and the Chyle, thee following Reaons evince.

list.item: 1. The force and efficacy of Purgatives, is after ome hours violently carried into the Dugs, as divers Experiments do teach. Yea and our Country-women, when children that have the cough, uck at their breats, they drink pectoral Decoctions, and believe that the ucking child does preently draw them.
2. If a Nure do wallow an hair in her meat and drink; it comes into her Dugs according to Aritotle, and ticking in the Nipples, it caues the Dieae Trichiais or Hair in the Nipple.

3. A branch of Cichory according to the Obervation of Martianus, hath come out of a womans Dug, which he had eaten the night before at Supper: and bran hath been een in the Excrements of a child that only lived with ucking.

4. Nures perceive as oon as ever they have eaten and drunken, the going down of the Milk, and the welling fulnes of their Dugs. Yea, and our Nures are extraordinary careful not to eat, while they give their children uck, for otherwie the children hould uck undigeted Milk.
5. Catellus pleads their Scituation over the Stomach, not near the Liver or Womb, excepting in beats.
6. The Milk is colder then the Blood, and leaves more Excrement in her that gives uck, then blood does in the Embryo or child in the womb.

div.p: Howbeit we find many difficulties in this new Opinion, and thoe of no mall moment.

list.item: 1. There are no manifet paages fromThe aid Opinion refuced. the Stomach to the Dugs, which if any man can find, I hall willingly acknowledg my elf convinced. Martianus, indeed, Catellus, Vetingus, and Hortius do talk of inviible paages, like the milkie Veins, which cannot be dicerned in a dead body; or at leat they conceive the Pores of the fleh may uffice to admit a paage for milkie Vapors. But the Pores eem too narrow for thick Chyle to pas through, which in the Meentery did require large milkie Veins, which any body may dicern. A ubtile Spirit and thin Vapors with moakie teams, do pas through the Pores, and not the Chylus, nor blood, according to Nature; for if o, then there were no ue of Veels. Nor is the Infant atisfied only with Vapors. I willingly acknowledg, that Nature endeavors the tranlation of Humors from one part to another by unknown wayes, but he does it compelled, and beides her cutomary Coure, whereas the breeding of Milk is a contant and ordinary thing.
2. The Dugs being heated by any other caue whatoever, do not breed Milk, but the action is hindred by the aid Heat.

3. Nures confes, that after they have drunk, the Milk does manifetly decend out of their backs, and from about their Channel-bones, and puts them to ome little pain. For there the Chet-arteries are eated, and not the Stomach.
4. A tender Infant hould be ill nourihed with undigeted meat, having been ved to be nourihed with blood before.
5. Out of the Nipples of Children newly come out of the Womb, before the ue of meat, a wheyih matter drops like Milk, before they have eaten any meat.

6. What hall we ay to that Aphorim of Hypocrates?
If a Woman want her Coures, neither any hivering o Feaver following thereupon, and he loath her Meat: Make account that he is with Child.

7. Cows, when they eat gras after hay, or hay after gras, before the fifteenth day, there is no perfect change either in the Contitution or colour of their Milk or Butter, according to the Obervation of Walaeus; yet they perfectly change their Chyle the firt day, but their Blood more lowly. Alo our Nures oberve, that after they have lept, and their Meat is digeted, their Dugs make Milk, which does not o happen, if they want leep.
8. Hogeland proves by Famines and Seiges, that when all the Nutriment of the Nure is turned into perfect blood, yet nevertheles Milk is bred in the Dugs.

div.p: Wherefore until ome diligent hand hall have found evident wayes and paages,And the Argument of Martianus and others are anwered for the Anwering of the contrary Arguments: You are to Note. 1. That we admit of the Chyle as the remote matter of Milk, but not as the immediate matter thereof. 2. That the Blood being plentifully evacuated by the Milk, is bred again by plentiful meat and drink; and therefore the plenty of Milk ceaes when there is little drink taken in, as all Nures do tetifie. Morcover, uch as are of a Sanguin complexion afford mot Milk, whereas thoe that are of a tender contitution grow lean by giving Suck. 3. That all the blood which is poured out of the Arteries into the Dugs, is not turned into Milk, but only the more wheyih part, a great deal running back by the Veins into the Heart. 4. That Women which give uck have their Coures, becaue the Veels of the Womb are then more enlarged, then in the firt moneths of their going with Child: and ever and anon they flow paringly from Nures, and leave off by fits. Alo Women that give uck eldom conceive, unles they be of a Plethorick habit of body, that is to ay full of good blood. Our Women when they would wean a Boy, if their Dugs well, they do by certain Medicines keep back the Milk, by traitning the Veels, that the matter thereof may not enter nor be drawn that way. 6. That the Breat and Dug-Arteries are large, and are more and more widened by continual ucking. 7. That the Milk doth drink in the faculty of Meats and Purgatives, even by mediation of the Blood, which conerves the color and faculty of the meats, though undry digetions have preceded; though vapors alone be raied, and the ubtance acend not. 8. That many things are performed in the body, according to the ingular contitution of particular perons, yea and many things which rarely happen, which is to be undertood of the Milk, which was in the Dugs of that Man at Cous, and of other things thence voided.
Nerves are carried from the Nerves of the Chet, epecially the fift, for to caueTheir Nerves. ene, and they end in the Nipple.

Beides thee Veels, the Dugs have alo white Pipes, according to the obervationTheir Pipes. of later Anatomits, pringing from the whole Circumference of the lower part which growing narrower, do alwayes meet together, wherein Milk being made, is preerved for ue. Whether or no they are nothing but widened Arteries, becoming white, becaue of the change of the milk and the bordering kernels (which I am willing to believe) I leave to acuter Eyes and Wits to determine. They treaure up the Milk, when there is occaion of omitting to give the Infant uck: and when that ue is over, they grow as mall as the mot Capillary Veins.

Their Ue is, 1. General in Women and Men, to be afeguards to theThe ue of the Dugs. Heart: hence Nature hath given Men of cold Complexions larger Dugs then ordinary; and Women that looe their Dugs become rough-voiced, according to Hypocrates. Nor doth the pectoral Mucle hinder, which performs the ame Office, which is Riolanus his Objection; for the more noble parts require great fencing, even by the mallet thing, as the Eyes from the Eye-brows, the Heart from the water in the Heart-bag or Pericardium, &c.

II. In women their ue is to breed Milk, to nourih the young Infant. For the Child was nouriht by blood in the Womb, and milk is the ame blood only whitened, o that Nature eems to have put a trick upon living Creatures by obtruding upon them the gentler appearance of white milk, in place of red blood, as Plato hath it. Which is the Caue that the People of Savoy and Daulphine did anciently prohibit their Preits, the ue of milk, as well as of Blood.

Now the Efficient Caue of milk,The Efficient caue of Milk. is not the Womb, where milk was never oberved, nor do the Dugs breed milk, by that vertue thereof which it elf wants; nor of the Veins or Arteries, unles it be the nearet, can the vertue be communicated from the Dugs. For as for what Baronius relates of St. Paul, how when he was beheaded, not blood but milk ran from his Neck, either it was a miracle, if true; or a erous humor flowed out, which ometimes flows from the Arm, when a Vein is opened, and I have een it very like to milk, or finally the Liquor of Kernels being cut, did reemble milk. But the true efficient caue of the milk, is that ame kernelly fleh of the Dugs, unto which there is none like, in the whole body. Now it works this moderate Concoction by the propriety of its ubtance, and by reaon of its proper temperament. Aulus Gellius conceives the milk becomes white, by Reaon of plenty of heat and pirit Book 12. Chap. 1. But I am more enclined to believe, that milk is white, becaue it is aimilated to the Dugs that are of the ame color.

Somtimes therefore (though itMilk may breed in Virgins, Men, Women not with Child, &c. happen eldom) milk may be bred in Virgins, and in Women not with Child, according to the Obervation of Bodinus in his Theatre of Nature, of Joachinus Camerarius in Schenkius, of Petrus Catell • s touching one Angela of Meina, of A. Benedictus and Chritopher a Vega concerning a Girle of Bridges, and of others. In Scania in our Country, a maid was lately accued to have plaid the Whore, becaue he had milk in her Dugs, which nevertheles he proved to be a propriety of her Family, by producing her young brother who likewie had milk in his Breats. Infants new born hed a wheyih milky liquor out of their Nipples. Thee examples are confirmed by the Authority o •
Hypocrates in the 39. Aphorim of his fifth Section, where Women have milk though neither with Child, nor lately delivered. And this happens, when the Dugs are filled with abundance of pirituous blood, and uppreion of Coures be joyned thereto: for then the Glandulous ubtance digets more then is neceary to nourih the Woman. Yea, in men that are flehy, large-dug'd, and cold, of contitution, a milky humor, and as it were milk is frequently een; epecially if their Nipples be frequently uck'r, and their Dugs rubbed, as
the examples of many do tetfie. Aritotle writes of a certain Hee-goat in the I tand Le •… s, who yeilded o much milk, that C • rds were made thereof. Matthiolus, tels us that in undry places of Bohemia, three Goat-Bucks were found, that gave milk, by which perons that had the Falling-icknes were Cured. Others have een Men, out of whoe Dugs tore of milk came. Aben-ina aw o much milk milked from a Man, that a Cheee was made thereof. C. Schenkius relates that Laurentius Wolfius had tore of milk in his Breats, from his youth, till he was fifty years old. Jo. Rhodius had uch an Hot in England, and Santorellus knew a Calabrian, who his Wife being dead, and he unable to give wages to a Nure, did nourih his own Child with his own milk. Walaeus aw a Flemming of like Nature, who being even forty years of Age, could milk abundance of milk out of huge Dugs which he had. A. Benedictus relates the tory of a Father that gave his Son uck. And Nicolaus Gemma, Vealius, M. Donatus, Aqua-pendens, H. Eugubius, Baricellus, do witnes the ame thing, and I have allready told you as much of a Boy of Scania in our Countrey of Denmarke, and Cardan aw a man thirty four years old, out of whoe Dugs o much milk did run, as would have uffied to uckle a Child. They relate how that in the new world, all men well-near abound with milk. Now that this was true milk which we have related did run from men, is hence apparent becaue, it was as fit to nourih children, as that of Women.
III. The ue of the Dugs in Women is to adorne them, and render them the more delectable to Men.

IV. They erve to receive Excrementious moiture. Whereupon their Dugs being cut off, Women incur undry Dieaes; becaue the blood which acends finding no Veels to receive it, runs hatily into the principal parts, the Heart, Lungs, &c, Which danger I conceive the Amazones did tudy to avoid, by their o vehement exerciing themelves in warfare. Some cut the Dug off when it is cancered, but the operation is dangerous, by reaon of the bleeding which follows.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Intercotal, or Ribbetween Mucles.
div.p: SUndry Mucles which we meetSee the Figure of the following Chapter. within the Chet hall be firt of all explained in the fourth Book, by reaon of the Method of Section. But the Intercotal or Rib-between Mucles, o called; becaue they are interwoven between the Ribs, mut be explained in this place.

Now they are totally flehy, forty four in number, on each ide two andTheir Number. twenty; eleven external; and as many internal. For evermore between two Ribs, two Mucles ret one upon another: and there are eleven Intervals or Spaces between the Ribs. Others have done ill to make their NumberThe Error of others. ixty eight. For in the Intervals of the true Ribs, they have made divers Mucles lying hid between the boney parts of thoe Ribs, differing from thoe which are found between the Gritley parts.
The External ones arie from the lower parts of the upper Ribs, and decending obliquely towards the back-parts, they are inerted into the upper parts of the lower Ribs. The Internal contrary wi • e.
The External end at the Cartilages: The Internal fil the paces, both of the Ribs and Gritles.

They have oblique Fibres and mutually cros one the other like this Le ••• X, becaue the Mucles are otherwie hort, becaue of the malnes of the Intervals. Hence in the opening uch as have a uppuration in their Chet, Section is to be made traight according to the Coure of the Fibres, nor overthwart,
They have received undry Veels. Veins from the Azygos and upper Intercotal, Arteries from both the Intercotals. Nerves from the ixt pare; joyned to them which proceed from the Marrow of the Back.

Their ue, is to Dilate and ContractTheir ue. the Chet; the external imitate the drawing of the Subclavius: By raiing the Ribs, and traitning the Chet, and help towards Expiration. The internal draw away the Ribs, and by enlarging the Chet help the Drawing in of the breath. Galen, contrarywie, makes the external erve for drawing in, and the internal for blowing out of the Air, whoe opinion is favored by Vetingius,

Others with Vealius, will have the external Mucles to thrut the lower Ribs upwards, and the internal ones to draw the upper Mucles downwards, that they might o mutually ait one another in traitning of the Chet. But we hould rather think, that when the Internal ones are quiet, the External do act by themelves.

Fallopius, Arantius, Riolanus, do account them only to be flehy Ligaments of the Ribs, whereby they are knit one to another, becaue the Ribs cannot be moved of themelves, ave by the Mucles of the Chet. But the Thorachick or Chet Mucles being unmoved, the Ribs are often moved by help of thee Mucles, receiving ome impule alo from the Diaphragma or Midriff. The Ligaments of a Mucle are never bare. The Ribs may be fatned one to another, and likewie moved by thee, which is common to all other Mucles. Howbeit the motion of the Ribs is obcure, becaue they are inarticulated in one part only, and the parts between the Ribs are narrow; But their Number upplies their malnes.

div.head: Chap. III. Of the Diaphragma or Midriff.
div.p:
The DIAPHRAGMA or Midriff, isThe Diaphragma or Midriff, why o called. o termed from ditinguihing or eparating, ome term it Praecordia becaue it is ordinarily tretched ou • before the Heart, and Phrenes, becaue it being affected, the Mind and Sene are diturbed by reaon of the Conent it hath with the brain, o that when the Midriff is inflamed a Paraphrenitis or petty Phrenzy is caued. The Caue of this conent is very doubtful. Hippocrates aies, the Heart becomes foolih through blood flowing back unto the Heart and Midriff, from the multitude thereof, which foolihnes makes it dull and nummed as it were, and that nummednes makes it Phrentick. But the more firm experience of latter Phyitians, hath proved that the brain and not the Heart, is the eat of Madnes. Aritotle attributes
The I TABLE
The Explication of the FIGURE.
This Figure preents the External proper Parts of the Breat, alo Delineates the Situation of the Midriff in the Body.
A. The Pectoral Mucle in its proper place.
B. The ame out of its Situation.
C. The Mucle Serratus major Anticus, or Greaterfore-ide-Saw-mucle in its own place, being partly viible.
D. The ame out of its place.
E. The Serratus anticus minor, leer foreide-Sawmucle.
FF. The Claviculae or Chanel bones.
G. The Subclavian Mucle.
HHH. The Intercotal, or Ribbetween Mucles.
III. The Diaphragma or Midriff.
K. Part of the great decendent Artery.
L. An Hole for the Vena Cava decendent.
M. An Hole for the Gullet paing through the Diaphragma.
nn. The Venae Phrenicae or Phrenick Veins o called.
oo. The Phrenick Arteries.
PP. The two Appendices or Appurtenances of the Diaphragma.
QQ. The Mucles termed Poas.
RR. The Muculi Quadrati or quare Mucles of the Loynes.
SS. The internal Cavity of Os Ilium, or the Flanck-bone.
