prudence to the midriff, and when it draws out of the neighboring Liver and Heart Excrementitious Humors, the mind is thereby hurt, and the external Senes. Yet, Neither doth he olve the doubt, for many other parts draw like Humors, without cauing madnes; nor doth he unfold, how the Midriff imprints thee ravings upon the Brain. The conent of Vicinity makes nothing to the purpoe, becaue it is nearer other parts, nor ociety in the ame Office, becaue the Lungs being dieaed in a Peripneumonia, do not caue a Delirium; nor finally, the communion of Nerves and Veels, becaue in the Inflammations of other Nervous parts no uch thing happens; Catrenis doth therefore necearily flie to an occult conent, peculiar to this part alone. Others term it Septum tranverum the Cros-partition, becaue it goes cros, and divides the Body, and eparates the middle belly from the lowermot. Some call it Cinetus, Dieptum, Dicretorium, and the Greeks alo call it Z • ne, Di • zoma, Perizoma, &c. Now it is a ingularWhat it is? and peculiar kind of Mucle, having an action and figure differing from all others.
Its Situation is overthwart, or acrosIts Situation. the body, and becaue it enclines a little downwards, oblique.
Its Figure is circularly round, avingIts Figure. the long Appurtenances.
This Mucle is in Number only one, becaueIts Number. of the unity of its Action common to both ides, but it is a great one. Meyonerius aw a double Midriff at Lyons.

Its Magnitude anwers the DiametralMagnitude. widenes of the lower Belly, which is
comprehended between the lower Vertebra's of the back and the Ribs. Hence great and whaley fleh, becaue they have longer and more Ribs then we have, have a larger midriff, creeping mean-while as far as to the extremities of the Ribs. For,

For it eems to arie from the Vertebra's of the Loyns, by two omwhatAn Head and Tail in the Midriff. long flehy parts (which cleave to the mucles of the Loyns, at the ides of the great Artery, and growing by little and little wider, about the lowet Vertebra's of the Chet they grow together, where this Mucle begins to grow Circular) and is fatned to the Chet round about, beingknit where it is flehy to the extremities of the Ribs: though we hould do peradventure more rightly, to make the beginning thereof, in its whole Circumference, as well from the Loyns as the Ribs, which Galen doth alo omwhere ininuate: For eeing it could not be knit to the eleventh Vertebra, becaue of the great Artery, and the beginning of the Lumbal mucle, it is trongly inerted, by its two mal appurtenances to the Vertebra's of the Loyns.

p.U: omwhere (whom Sylvius, Vealius, Aquapendens, Spigelius and many more follow) will have the middle of the Diaphragma to be the Head thereof, becaue the Nerves are there inerted, and the Centre in a Circle, upon which one point of the compas doth ret, while the other is carryed about, may be well taken for the Head of the aid Circle. But as it is a peculiar mucle, in Situation, Action, Figure, Nobility, &c. o hath it omwhat peculiar in this point. But the beginning or Head cannot be in this Centre, becaue it is moveable, and the Ribs and Vertebrae of the Loyns, in repect thereof immoveable. Moreover, the Nervous or Tendinous part, is the End of the mucles, and not their Head.

div.p: Its Subtance is flehy, in the middleIts ubtance. Nervous and Membranous, where a Membranous Centre hews it elf and a Nervous circle in tead of a Tendon, to which flehy Fibres do run, from the Circumference of the Chet, as to their Centre. Whence necearily the middle part of the motive mucle is Nervous, for otherwie it could not be moved. Secondarily, it helps to trength, in a perpetual motion, and in the upenion of the bowels which adhere thereunto; moreover it erves to ecure the Veels which pas through. To utain the beating of the Heart, it was not to be trong, as Riolanus upects, becaue 1. A oft part doth eaily give way and yeild to a blow. 2. The point of the Heart doth not trike againt the Midriff in its pulation, for the Heart mites the breat when it is erected in the Sytole, and is contracted at the ides; in the Diatole when it decends to the Diaphragma, it becomes oft and flaggy, and gives no pulation.

Note that Wounds in the Nervous Centre of the Diaphragma, are by all accounted deadly, whether becaue a Nervous part being offended, doth induce a Convulion, or becaue it cleaves to the Pericardium or Heart-bag and to the Liver, or becaue repiration perihes, and the Heart placed over the ame is likewie hurt; for the Pericardium and Liver being hurt, do admit cure. A wound is more afely made in the flehy Circumference thereof.

It is cloathed with a double membrane, for trength. The upper isIts Membrane. from the Pleura, to which the Pericardium or Heart-bag is firmly fatned, and omtimes alo the Lobes or Laps of the Lungs by little mal Fiberkies; the lower is from the Peritonaeum. Alo it hath its proper ubtance, formerly decribed.

It hath Holes: ome being very exceedingIts Holes. little, and others great. Thoe very little ones are the Pores, through which vapors arie from the inferior parts. They are widned by the perpetual motion of the Diaphragma, not by Odours and Fumes, as Helmont believes. Otherwie, becaue the Membrane is thick, it hinders the drinking in of thick vapors, and will not let them acend without the Veels. Among the greater, there is one on the right hand, in the middle of the Nervous part, to give a paage to the Vena Cava: Another on the left hand greater and omwhat backwarder, for the letting through of the Gullet or Oeophagus with tw •… Nerves which go unto the Stomach. And where it aries about the Vertebra's of the Loins, there appears a diviion, for the through-fare of the great Artery, and the Vena ine Pari, or Vein without fellow. Thee wide holes do admit from the inferior parts, the paage of thick Vapors with the blood, which cannot be prohibited by the Diaphragma. Hence in the 29. Aphorime of the fift Section 'tis aid, in a Fruitful Women, her lower parts being perfumed, the cent goes up to her Notrils.
As to its Veels. It has Veins and ArteriesVeels. from the Neighbouring Veels vena cava and Arteria magna, called Venae phrenicae: and ometimes from the Vena adipoa

Nerves are pred through its whole Subtance, being brought from the pinal marrow of the Neck, between the fourth and fift Vertebra: which is proper to this part, and common to no other internal part under the Channel bones, becaue according to the Conjecture of the renowned Hofman, it was not to lie open to external wounds or Blowes, leat we hould be maters of our own Life or Death. But intruments of death are every where obvious, which the Love of Life and Fear of God hinders us from makeing ue of. Now they are carried through the Cavity of the Chet, and are propped up by the mediatinum. Other Anatomits have oberved other Nervs paing that way from beneath, proceeding from the cotal and tomachick Branches. And becaue the Nervs of the Diaphragma or Midriff areSardonian Laughter in their paage mingled with certain little twigs, which are pread abroad into the mucles of the Jaws and Lips; hence when the Diaphragma is mitten there aries a kind of Laughter, which is no real Laughter, but a counterfeit one uch as they call Rius Sardonius the Sardonian Laughter, becaue the mucles of the Face uffering a Convulion at the ame time, and the Jaws and Lips being moved this way and that way, the partie eems to laugh. Such was the laughter of Thycenis in Hippocrates and of Agnerus in our Countryman Sarco his relations, who was cut aunder in the middle with a harp word: alo of that man in Aritotle whoe Midriff being in the fight pierced with a Dart, made him die laughing. Pliny relates as much of other Fencers, and Homer tells us that Juno laught with her Lips when her Forehead cowled.

Galen makes the Caue of the Sardonian Laughter to be in the Muculus latus quadratus, the broad quare Mucle. But it reaches not to the Lips, Laurentinus Politianus, makes the pirits to be the caue of this Convulion, which becaue of the ene they have of ome troubleome thing, run back to the upper parts. Mancinius will have the Heart to be widened, and the face drawn into the poture of laughing, by the hear which
is raied by tickling and wounds, becaue he will have the Heart to be the eat of Laughter, in defence of Aritotle whom Phyitians have confuted. Riolanus has ometimes oberved laughter to arie in the guelding of a man, which was the forerunner of a deadly Convulion; for which caue he condemns our reaon drawn from the Nerves, not giving us in the mean time any better reaon viz. why laughter hould arie upon the wounding or hurting the nerves of the Midriff and Privities, and not when any other nerves are wounded.

Its Ue is 1 To help free Repiration; for violent repiration is aited by the muclesUe. of the Chet; the former Repiration Galen
• erms gentle or mall, which depends only upon the Midriff, the other trong, the intercotal mucles aiting thereto, a third ublime, where the Diaphragma, intercotal or rib between mucles, and mucles of the Chet do act all together. Birds indeed, though they breathe have no Midriff, but their breathing which is light and care perceptible, becaue of the lightnes of their bodies, is performed by their Lungs and Chet. Contrariwie Fihes which breathe not have a Midriff, but membranous, to eperate one Belly from another. In the greater ort of Sea fihes of the whaley kind, I have oberved a flehy Midriff like that of Creatures which live on the Land.

Now the motion thereof is thus: when the Breath is drawn in, theHow the motion of the Diaphragma is performed. Midriff is tretched, when it is blowne out, it is remitted or lackned, contrary to the Opinion of Arantius and Laurentius. Of whom the latter will have the Midriff contrary to all other mucles to draw towards its end, and he will have the fibres which run out from the Circumference of the Chet, to be equally contracted, and the ribs to be drawn to the nervous Circle, and o to caue repiration. But how can the membranous Centre of the Septum, draw the ribs to its elf and contract the whole Chet unles haply becaue it is fatned to the Mediatinum. But I have oberved more then once in diections of living Bodies, that the Midriff is tretched out, when the Creature draws in its Breath. For the Guts are driven downwards by the Midriff when the Breath is blown out, and they acend again when the Breath is drawn in, which alo any man without Anatomical Section, may perceive in himelf, by laying his Hand upon his Belly. In Wounds of the Diaphragma, the Guts and Stomach, when the Breath is drawn in acend into the Chet, which Paraeus twice oberved, which differs only according to more or les, from the naturall coure of breathing. Now the motion of the Midriff ought to be uch, becaue the Chet when the Breath is drawn in, mut be widened to receive and contain the Air and woln Lungs; and contrarywie, when the Air is breathed out, the Chet ought to be traitned, becaue then the ooty vapours are expelled, and the Lungs flag and become mall again, and therefore in the former cae the Midriff is lifted up, and in the latter depreed.

Jo. Walaeus beides that motion, whereby the flehy part gives way inwardly, has oberved another motion in the Diaphragma during the drawing in of the breath, whereby the flehy part thereof being contracted into it elf, comes to have folds in it, o that one portion of the flehy part is placed upon another: and he oberved that this folding is chiefly about the Appendices or Appurtenances, and when the breath is trongly drawn in: and he conceivs that by this means the Midriff is the more hortened, and the Chet by the lifting up of the Ribs, more widened.

II. To ait the mucles of the belly, in their compreion, when they would force out the Excrements and the Child in the womb: for from above it thruts the Guts downwards. Hence, according to the Obervation of Platerus, when the belly is cotive, Sneezing and Coughing do help, becaue thereby the Midriff and Dung conteined in the Guts, are driven downwards, becaue of the Strugling of the aid Midriff and its bearing down, the Excrements of the belly and Urine come away of themelves in live Anatomies and in uch as are put to death by hanging.

III. To ditinguih the lower belly with the natural parts, from the middle belly with its vital parts, leat from the Ignoble parts frequent vapours hould acend, to the parts more noble, as the Heart &c.
IV. According to Hippocrates, it is the Fan of the lower belly, which fannes and cooles the Hypocondria or parts under the nort ribs.

V. Others uppoe it caues natural repiration, becaue it depends not upon our will and pleaure, and moves when we are aleep, and never o much as think of it, and by help thereof, Men in Apoplexies do for a eaon breathe. But Piccolhomineus does more rightly aign a voluntary motion thereunto, howbeit only when ome neceity contrains, as in eaing of the belly, piing, and fetching of breath, becaue it is a Mucle of a nature by it elf; but not a motion abolutely or imply voluntary, which is dicerned in progreion & apprehenion, that is to ay in going and handleing.
Its motion ceaes in a trong Apoplexy, only tranpiration does then remain: but in a light Apoplexy, we ee the Diaphragma alo moved with the Chet mucles.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Pleura, Mediatinum, and Thymus.
div.p:
THe PLEURA or Rib-coate, which the Greeks call Chitòn What the Pleura is, and its Original. hupezocòs, or abolutely bumèn, is a membrane which on the inide cloathes the cavity of the Chet, hard and white, but in ome pleuretick perons according to Hippocrates, black and blew, whence it is that Practitioners conceive that this is affected in the Pleuriie, which notwithtanding is demontrated to happen econdarily, by Manelphus, Cletus, Platerus, Zacchius, Vitaglianus, Benedictus. It is omewhat thicker and tronger then the Peritoneum.Its Thicknes. Arieing from the Coats, which cover the intercotal nerves which proceed out of the Backbone, by means of which it is continued with the Coats of the Brain. And therefore it is thicker in the Back, to whoe vertebra's it cleavs as it were ineperably. Hofmannus will have it arie from the Breat-bone rather than the vertebra's of the Back, wherein he is out, as I have proved in my Animadverions upon Hofman, and in my Anatomical Colledge. In dieaes of the Chet, it becomes many times ten-fold thicker: though others ay it is o attenuated in pleuritick perons, that it can hardly be decerned. Fallopius aw it of a thick callous ubtance, in a Dropie
of the Lungs, and Platerus aw it in like manner woln by a Scirrhous Tumor.

It is every where double, that the Veels may be carryed within the folding thereof. The outer part which looks towards the Chet, is harder and thicker, the inner part beingThe place of the matter which caues a Pleuriie. fatned to the Ribs is thinner. Between thee the matter of the Pleuriie is often collected, and not only between the Pleura and Mucles. Galen makes it to be ingle, and will allow it to be double, only about the Mediatinum. Riolanus explains that ame Duplicature to mean its thicknes, which cannot be hewed without tearing. The contrary whereto is manifet in the woln ides of uch as have the Pleuriie.
It hath its inner urface mooth, leat it hould by its roughnes hurt the Lungs; its outer more rough that it might be the tronglyer fatned.
Somtimes it is found furnihed with a little fat (as there is alo now and then in the Peritonaeum) near the Vertebra's of the back, where the Veels are greater then ordinary.
The Ribs alo have their Perioteum or Membrane o called, which ome call the third coat of the Pleura, and others Membrana Circumoalis the bone-about Membrane.

It hath very many Holes, the lowermoreIts Holes. of which I have reckoned up in the Hitory of the Diaphragma, the upper are there where it affords paage to the Vena Cava, the Arteria aorta, the Wezand or Apera arteria, the Gullet and the Nerves of the ixt Pare.

As for its VESSELS. It hath Veins from the olitary Vein or Vena fine Pari, and the upper Intercotal or Rib-between Vein; Arteries from the Intercotal or Rib-between Artery, and from the great Artery; Nerves, twelve in number, proceeding from the foreide of the Vertebra's of the Chet. And therefore wounds in this part are attended with mot grievous pains.

Its USE is. 1. According to Galen to plater over the whole Cavity of the Chet and to render it mooth and even, that the Lungs migt not be hurt in their motion. 2. To cloath the Chet and its parts on the inide (even as the Peritonaeum affords coats to the parts of the lower Belly) and to contitute the Partition Membrane. Or,

MEDIASTINUM, Which is an of-pring of the Pleura, being a doubl • Membrane; eparating the Cavity of the Chet and the Lungs into two parts. For after that the Pleura having taken its Original about the Back hath acended by the ides to the Bretbone, taking its coure again towards the Back-bone, it is carried right out from the middle of the Bret to the Back. Being fatned on each hand to the ides of the Bret-bone, this Membrane is not obcurely double, as is the Pleura, but viibly, being contituted of the Pleura doubled; and there eems at firt ight to be as great a pace between both, under the Bretbone, as the breadth of the Breat-bone comes to. But this is only in appearance and not really o; for that ame Cavity under the Breat-bone, is then only caued, when the Breat-bone is in diection, pluckt from the Mediatinum, for before the Membranes of the Mediatinum are mot cloely united one to another. Which it is trange that no Anatomit did oberve before Ad Falcoburgius. After him, I have often made the Experiment, in grown perons and Children new born, in Land-beats and large Sea-fihes; nor could I hew any Cavity betwixt the Mediatinum and Breat-bone, no not to the mot expert Spectators, but I found the Membranes of the former ticking cloe by certain Fibres to the latter, which we forcibly eparated with a Penknife. Which that it might be more apparent, the inwards of the Belly and the Midriff being taken away, I made it viible to the Eyes of all that were preent. Thee things are to be undertood of the leer Cavity (to atisfie Riolanus who is my Adverary in this point) between the Membranes of the Mediatinum and the ternum: For the greater, wherein the evermoveing Heart is eated, no man in his right wits will ever deny. In this greater Cavity, or in this Duplicature • if a wound inflicted on the foreide hall penetrate, lightly, o that the Heart ettling beneath remain unhurt, it is ufficiently void of Peril and afe enough; which one unskillfull in Anatomy would pronounce deadly, But towards the Vertebrae, the Cavity grows narrow by little and little, and the Membranes meet together. But in the middle the Cavity is wider, and in the fore part of the aid Cavity, the Heart and Vena Cava are placed; in the latter part the Gullet, with the Stomach Nerves. If in this Cavity humors praeternaturally aemble and putrifie, they may afely be let out by boreing an hole in the Breat-bone, if we believe Columbus and Hofmannus, which Nicolaus Fontanus doth notwithtanding deny.
It is of a thinner and ofter ubtance then the Pleura; and about the VeelsIts ubtance. tis frequently full of fat like the Call.

For Veels, it hath Veins and Arteries from the Dug-veels and the olitary Vein or Vena Veels. ine Pari, applied inwardly to the breatbone, which being taken away they become viible: Alo it hath its own proper Vein called Mediatana, which is omtimes one and large, other whiles double and mal.
Alo the Phrenick and Stomachick Nerves are carryed through this Duplicature, and afford branches to the Mediatinum.
The ue of the Mediatinum is, I. ToThe ue of the Mediatinum divide the Chet into two parts, that one Diviion of the Lungs being hurt by a wound or otherwie, the other might perform its office.
II. To hang the Heart and Heart-bag dangling in o free a poture, as to trike againt no part of the Chet.
III. To utaine the Veels running through the ame, as alo the Midriff in Mankind, leat it hould by the weight of the Bowels be drawn too much downwards.

The Thymus grows thereto in the Jugulum or Throat-pit the highet partThe Thymus what it is? of the Chet, whereunto in ordinary Anatomical Figures it is fatned, and hath its name from the leafe of time which it reembles, not from Thumos the Mind, as if in diturbances thereof by paion, the blood and Spirit hould work or grow hot within this Kernel, in the Vena Cava, as Riolanus interprets the meaning of the word; for the blood grows hot in the Heart, here it hath only a paage and tarries not, eeing few branches are dicernable in the body of the Thymus, unles omwhat be left by the Arteries for Nutrition ake. In children and the Embryo in the Womb, les ubject to paions, the Thymus is greater and more Numerous, in perons of ripe years who are oon angry, we find it dried and co •… . Now it is a kernellih, oft, pungy, <…> (ome term it the Sweet-bread, becaue

page 94 in a Calfe 'tis counted a dainty bit) In a Child new born tis ditinguihed into a threefold Kernel ufficiently big. In grown perons, tis extenuated, its moiture being conumed by heat. Howbeit I have een it large in great Sea-fih, from which many other Kernels were diffued on either hand, about the Mediatinum and ides of the Lungs.
Blood-conveighing Veels do pas through this Thymus or Sweet-bread; howbeit in the ubtance thereof, being diected, we cannot manifetly dicerne any.

The ue therefore of the Thymus is 1. To underprop thoe great Veels which acend that way, as the Vena Cava, Arteria magna, and their branches paing along to the Arms and Shoulder-blades. 2. Alo for afeguard, as is uual, and that the Veels may not be hurt by touching upon the bones. 3. That it may be as it were a cover and fence for the Heart, for I have een it as a Bulwork to the Heart, which the Heart of a Child in the Womb tands in need of, becaue as yet it tirs not. And therefore it hath a large Thymus, as a Sturgeon alo hath and other Creatures which live in the Water, by reaon of the external cold.

div.head: Chap. V. Of the Heart-bag and the Humor contained therein.
div.p: THe Pericardium which ome termThe Pericardium. See Tab. 3. of Book 2. the Coat, Cae, Box, Chamber, Cover of the Heart, or Heart-bag, &c. is a Membrane compaing the whole Heart, whoe Figure it therefore Emulates, as alo its Magnitude: But it is o far ditant from the Heart, as is neceary for the Hearts motion, and the reception of the Liquor contained in this Bag. Columbus aures us, that a Scholar of his had no Pericardium.

It aries at the Bais from the Coates which compas the Veels of theIts Original. Heart, which proceed from the Pleura (for this Coat is not between the Bais of the Heart and the Pericardium) where for their akes.
It hath five Holes; viz. for the ingate and outgate of the Vena Cava, and for theIts Holes. letting out of the other three Veels.
Its Situation is more to the left ide then the right; and more to the fore then theSituation. hinder part of the Body.

It is knit circularly to the Mediatinum, with very many Fibres, and toIts Connexion. the neighbouring parts, but epecially the Nervous circle of the Midriff, it cleaves exceeding cloe, which is a thing peculiar to Mankind: For herein a Man differs from Dogs and Apes, and in all other Creatures likewie, the difference holes.
Its External Surface is Fibrous, the Internal lippery, and both void of fat.Its Surface.
Its Subtance is thick and hard, and o much harder then the Lungs, as it isIts Subtance. ofter then a bone.
Its Veels. It hath mal Veins. belowIts Veels. from the Phrenick Veels, above from the Axillary.
It hath no Arteries that can well be een; peradventure, becaue it is o near the Heart. Yet doubtles it hath ome although hard to be dicerned.
It hath very mal Nerves, from the left Recurrent, and the little twigs of the Septum.
Its Ue is I. To be a firme tabernacle for the Heart, that in its motion it might notIts Ue. trike againt the hard parts of the Body.

II. To contain a wheyih or Watry Humor, like Urin to ee to, though neither harpe nor Salt, tranparently clear, in ome like water, wherein fleh hath been waht; Guil. Toletus in Burgenis calls it a flegmatick Humor of an unpleaing tat. And becaue of this Liquor Galen reembles the Heart to a Bladder.

This Humor is found in all Animals naturally contituted, bothWhether all Live-Wights have this wherih Liquor in their Heart-bags. living and dead, yea and in the Child in the Womb, as appears by the diection of bodies both living and dead: But in ome more in others les; in perons that are in a Conumption, it is very little and inclining to yellownes. In perons Pleuritick it is now and then of a quittorih nature, according to the Obervation of Salmuth.

In dead bodies tis more plentyful: Becaue then very many Spirits areWhy more plentiful in dead Bodies. in the cooled parts of the body condened into water. In Women Children, and aged perons, tis more plentyful, by reaon of the debility of their heat.

If it happen to be in two great a quantity, Palpitation of Heart, and a uffocating death follows therefrom: if it be quite conumed, a Conumption of the body happens. But that it may be bread a freh when it is pent, we ee clearly in thoe whoe Heartbag being wounded, the aid Liquor hath run out; for in Johannes Saviolus, his Heart-bag being wounded with a Dagger, water iued at every Pule of his Heart, out of the wound, yet was he happily cured by the Renowned Velingus.
Whence this water hould haveWhence the liquor in the Heart-bag proceeds? The firt Opinion. its original, the opinions of learned men are different.

I. The firt Opinion is of thoe, who will have it to be ent out of the Veels of the Heart, eeing Blood-letting cures the Panting of the Heart proceeding from the Super abundance of this Liquor: And they conceive that this waterih Liquor is forced out by the fervent heat of the Heart, as in a tick of wood when it burns the ap runs out. Of kin to this is the Opinion of Nicolas Maa, which will have it to proceed from the trainings of the blood, which come from the Liver to the Ear of the Heart. And Hofman is much of his mind, who maintaines that it is part of that wheyih moiture which acends to the Heart with the blood; but becaue the motion thereof is perpetual, there would no mal danger arie, from o large an Afflux of Humors. I let pas, how that the tronger perons, whoe blood is moved mot wiftly, have les quantity of this Water then thoe that are weaker.
II. Others, and among them Hippocrates eems to make one, will have it to proceed from our drink, ome portion whereof they conceive peirces like Dew out of the Aperia Arteria, into the Arteria Venoa.
III. Some conceive it proceeds from a Watry matter in the Seed, as the inbred Air of the Ears, is thought to proceed from a windy matter in the aid eed.

IV. Of kin hereunto is the opinion of Jaolinus, who will have it to be a elect, mot perfect and Elaborate portion of the erons Humor, ent thither by Nature it elf, haply in the firt formation of the Child, through the Veins and Arteries, beides another part of the drink, of which Hippocrates peaks, and he has experiments touching the ame.
V. Some ay it proceeds from the watry Excrements of the third digetion.
VI. Others from the pittle, lipping out of the Kernels of the Tongue into the Wezand, and from thence into the Arteries and Heart.
VII. Others, from the fat of the Heart, by agitation turned into water.
VIII. Others from the thicker part of the Air which we draw in, being changed into water.

IX. And latly, ome think (which I conceive to be mot likely) that it proceeds from moit Vapors and Exhalations, forced out of the Humors of the Heart by the motion and Heat theerof, and thrut forth into the Heart-bag and there congealed into water, in regard of the compactnes of the aid Heartbag.

Its Ue is, I. To moiten and cool theIts Ue. Heart, and to facilitate the motion thereof. And therefore thoe in whom it is conumed, have their Hearts roated: As it happened to Caimire the
Marques of Brandenburg: And to that young man of Rome, mentioned by Panarolus. Hofmannus being of a contrary mind, will needs have it to be as a Spur and Incitement of Heat; as Smiths are wont to dip their wips of Straw in Water that they may burn the longer: And as Wood is prinkled with Water to make it burn more lutily. But thoe bundles of Straw are preerved by the water, becaue their ubtance being made more moit and Tenacious, is not o oon conumed. But the heat of the Heart is preerved by its radical moiture, and by the blood continually flowing in, nor doth it need any Incitement from the Water, for if o, then the Heart would be more hot and luty in old perons, who have mot water in their Heart-bags, II. It erves to make fat by congelation. III. That the Heart by wimming therein, may be les ponderous, and may not trike againt any part.

An HUMOR likewie is commonly found in the Cavity of the Chet, reembling blood and water mingled together, wherewith the parts of the Chet are meared, that they may not be overheated nor overdryed. Hence the ide of our Saviour being opened, blood and water flowed out, which by the uddan flux, and mixture of blood and the Authorities of the Ancients, I have at large proved, in my Dipute of the ide of Chrit, againt Laurentius, Arias Montanus, Bertinus, Nancelius, Poza, Tremellius, Beza, Tirinus, Grotius and others, who would have it to proceed from his Pericardium or Heart-bag, alo againt Collius, Tarnovius, Brentius, Laurenbergius among the late writers, and Cyprianus, Prudentius, Brigitta, Vida, Sannazarius, Vigerius, &c. who would fetch it from the Veels of the Heart being wounded. Now the Objection of P. Laurenbergius is not worth a button, who aies there was not enough of the aid Liquor in the Cavity of the Chet; becaue 1. The natural quantity might uffice, eeing the Evangelits do not record that it come away in a great quantity. 2. It might be augmented in that lat conflict for life, notwithtanding the great perfection of his Body, which being for our Redemption made liable to temporary paions, underwent death it elf. 3. I have at Padua omtimes oberved o great a quantity of Water in this part, that it hung down like a great pure, the Midriff being depreed by its weight. Jaolinus in wound of the Chet (the inner parts being unhurt) did omtimes collect every day five meaures of water called Heminae, for thirty daies together, which the Membranes being inflamed, was dried up and diminihed, but when the Inflammation was cured, it returned in its former Quantity.
In a Boy at Paris, who died of the mall pox, I being preent, tore of water was found in this part, but of a green colour, of which ele-where.

div.head: Chap. VI. Of the Heart in General.
div.p: THe Heart is called in Latine COR à currendo from running, becaue of its motion; ome peradventure will derive it from the Greek name Kêr which they derive from céo which ignifies to burn: the Greeks term it cardia, we the Heart, quai bieròn a acred thing. It is the principall part of a living Creature, which none is found to want according to Aritotle, and by the hurting whereof the Creaure does for the mot part immediately die, becaue it is the fountain of Life, and labors the vital Spirits, which having made, it ditributes, by the Arteries ariing from it elf, into the whol body, Yet may you find examples in Schenkius of thoe that have had no Hearts. See alo Gellius book the 16. Chap. 15. Galen relates that beats acrificed have lowed at the Altar, after their Hearts were taken out; and the Lord Verulam tells of a man who pake three or four words of a prayer, when his Heart was pluckt out of his Body, and in the hand of the Executioner. Plinie tells us the entrails were twice found without any Heart, when Caear acrificed, and Julius Obequens aies the ame. The Lives of uch perons were maintained by the remainders of arterial Blood. And Spigelius upects that among the Bowells, the Heart was rather hid, and unfound then wanting, who aw o much fat in an Otrich, that a man might eaily have bin deceived, o as to think the Fowl had no Heart. Peradventure thoe Hearts of the acrifices were tole away by the Devil.

A Live-wight dies not with every hurt of the Heart. For the Heart undergoes all kind of dieaes. 1. Putrefaction, witnes Galen, in a petilential and a putrid Fever. 2. The Conumption according to Plinie, to be dried like a roated warden, according to Jordanus. to be wholly conumed by immoderate Heat, as Tileeus averr's. 3. Inflammation, in which Cae it cannot live a natural day, as Saxonius found by experience in a certain Reader. 4. Filthy hollow Ulcers have bin found therein by Fernelius, Trincavellius, Riverius. 5. Divers kinds of Tumors, Columbus aw an hard Tumor in the left ventricle of a Cardinal, as big as an Egg. Benevenius aw a welling of black fleh. Maa, Hollerius, Bauhinus, and Joubertus, have other like Stories. I lately found in the Parenchyma of an Oxes Heart on the left ide a welling as big as a Pigeons Egg, in a double Coat, full of Whey and Flegm.
On the out ide Gener aw an Excrecence of Fleh, in the Bais the quantity of an ounce and ix drams Bavius makes mention of the Membrane eaten and fretted away round about.

Alo Hitories hew that it will bear wounds for a eaon. Paraeus tells of one wounded in the Heart who ran two hundred paces. Jacotius tells of an Hart that carried an old arrow fixed in its Heart, which is confirmed by Thomas à Vega and Alexandrius. Galen aw an Hare wounded in the Heart, run a darts cat after the wound received. Of a Student at Ingoltade, Sennertus and Iohntonus tells us, who had both the ventricles of his Heart peirced through with a weapon, and Nicholas Mullerus of a Souldier who lived fifteen daies after he had received a wound in his Heart, of which he hung up a Table at Groeningen. He recounts many like examples een by himelf, and Tulpius tells us of one that lived two daies, being wounded in the right ventricle. Glandorpius tells us after Sanctorius, that the Heart of a Rabbit was pierced with a harp Intrument, and yet it lived many months after.
Wee mut therefore note

list.item: 1. That the Heart can endure Dieaes, but becaue it lies far from the way of medicines, it cannot hold out o well as other parts.

2. That, as Galen tells us, if the wounds do pierce into the belly thereof, the party or Creature wounded dies, of neceity, but if they be in the Subtance thereof, it may live a day and a night, but then Inflammation ariing death follows.
3 That the right Ventricle does more eaily bear an hurt, becaue upon the left depends the life of the whol Body.
4. Both Ventricles may endure a mall time after they are hurt, if the Veels that continue the motion of the blood, be undamnified.

div.p: The Heart is one in Number, Theophratus writes, that in Paphlagonia Partridges have two Hearts, an example whereof Galen relates in a man, in his anatomical adminitrations.

It is ituate in the middle of the body, not conidering the leggs, as it isWhy the Heart •• in the middet of the Body. in brutes; in which the Heart is in the middle, for moveablenes and Securities ake, and in the middle of the Chet likewie, where it is on all ides compaed with the Lungs. Now the Heart in repect of its bais, is exactly in the middle, that nourhing blood and pirit might more commodiouly be ditributed into the whole body.
Howbeit the Motion thereof is more dicernable in the left ide.

1 Becaue in its left Ventricle the vital pirit is contained, and fromA vulgar Error that the Heart is in the left ide. thence aries the Arteria magna, hence the common people imagin that a Mans Heart reides in his left Side, but Practitioners applie Cordials to the left ide.

2 Becaue the point of the Heart enclines towards the left ide, underWhy the point of the Heart enclines to the left ide. the left nipple, that it may give way to the Diaphragma: now to the right hand it could not decline, by reaon of the Vena cava, which acends there through the middet of the Chet. Sometimes the upper part of the Heart enclines to the left ide, and uch perons are left handed if we beleive Maa, thoe whoe Heart is exactly in the middle, ue both hands alike.

As to its Magnitude. In a man proportionably the Heart is greater thenWho have the greatet Hearts. in other Creatures, as alo the brain and Liver. According to the common Coure of Nature, it equalls ix fingers breadths in length, and four in breadth. Otherwie, the greatnes of the Heart differs according to the Difference of the Age and Temperament. For perons cold of Contitution, and fearfull have great Hearts, but uch as are more hot and confident, have little Hearts: Of which ee Donatus. Hence Aritotle aies of fearfull Creatures, as the Hare, Deer, Moue, Hyena, As, Weazel, &c. that they have a great Heart, conidering the proportion of their bodies. The Philoiphers of AEgypt, in ancient times, as appears by Herodotus in his Euterpe, have dreamed thee things of the greatnes of the Heart. That the Heart of uch Perons, as are not wated by any violent dieae, does every yeer grow two drams heavier, till they become fifty yeers old, o that a man of fifty yeers Age, his Heart weighs an hundred drams: but from the fiftyeth year to the hundredth, by a retrograde or back motion, it looes every yeer two drams, till it vanih away, and the party die.

Its Figure is conick, becaue it ends in a point. Its upper part by reaon of the full veels therein, is broad and round, although not exactly, and is called the Root and Head, and Bais of the Heart: the lower part being harper is called conus, mucro, vertex, cupis and apex Cordis; the cone, point, top of the Heart. Hippocrates calls it the end and taile. On the foreide the Heart is more boie, on the hinder ide more flat. In the contractions the whole Heart is longer as ome hold, but broader and more drawn together according to others; in its Dilatations or Widenings it is greatet, and of a globous figure, of which I hall peak more exactly hereafter.

Its Connexion is to the Mediatinum and the Midriff by the Pericardium; but toConnexion. other parts by its Veels, they are joyned to the Bais. the point being free, and hanging dangling like a bell in the Steeple, that it may the more eaily be drawn back to its Bais, or moved to the Sides.
Its Subtance is firt membranous, like a Bladder, in the Child in the Womb, afterward from the mothers blood there grows fleh or a olid, thick and compacted parenchyma.

list.item: 1. That it might endure the perpetuityWhy the Subtance of the Heart is o thick. of the Motion: for a fence, and that it might more forcibly drive the blood to places far ditant in the whole Body.
2 Leat the ubtile and lightfull Spirits contained even in the moveable blood hould exhale together with the inbred heat.

div.p: In the right ide the wall is les thick, becaue it ends blood only to the Lungs, which have their venal blood not o ubtile. The trength of the left ide is greater, by reaon of tronger motion to drive on the blood, to upply the neceity of the whole body. In the point, the fleh is thicker and harder not o much becaue it ought not to be moved, as Riolanus conceives, as becaue it is free, contracting the whole Heart in a brief manner, and detiture of Veels and Ears. In its Bais, it is not o much ofter as thinner. whoe Veels and Ears do recompence what it wants of firmnes. Now this fleh hath all kinds of Fibres, o mingled one with another, and o compact, that they cannot be eaily dicerned; partly for trength, partly for motion. For all thee Fibres being tretched in the Sytole of the Heart they draw together the Ventricles and the inner ides, to help the Protryion or thruting forward of the blood.
This ubtance is cloathed with a Coat Its Coat. hardly eparable, for the greater firmnes, to which it grows in repect of the matter, not of the efficient Caue.

There is Fat about the Pais of the Heart but hardly about the Cone or harpe End thereof, becaue it is moitned by the liquor of the Heart-bag, 1. To anoint the Veins about the Heart. 2. And to moiten the Heart, that it may not be dryed by motion. 3. To heat the water in the Heart-bag, as the fat of the Kidneys doth, according to the conjecture of John Daniel Hortius. Somtimes it is quite hid with the aid fat, which Spegelius, Riolanus, Jeenius oberved in a prince of Lunaeburg, o that the by-tanders are apt to be deluded and think there is no Heart.

It was nevertheles rightly aid byWhether Fat is found about the Heart? Aritotle, Galen and Avicenna, that fat called Pimele could not grow about any hot part, as the Heart, the Liver, the Arteries, the Veins, &c. For this kind of Fat is eaily melted by heat; but in the mean while, to tea •
Adeps or Tallow, which differs much from Pimele or Greaie fat, in ubtance, conitency and place, as I have demontrated in my Vindiciae Anatomicae from Pollux, Suidas, Erotianus and others, may grow about uch parts, becaue it is not eaily melted. Which makes a puttering when it is put to the flame of a Candle, becaue of a watry ubtance mingled therewith, according to the Obervation of Jaolinus, which hinders it from uddain congealing: o that it is no wonder that it is not melted by the heat of the Heart. Now this ame Tallow is bred about the Heart, either
becaue the Heart being of a very hard ubtance is nourihed with thick blood, of which uet is bred; or becaue Excrementitious dregs are bred of the Nutriment of the Heart; or becaue the blood is much tirred, as by the great Agitation of Milk, better is extracted, which is the opinion of Achillinus.

As for Veels. The Heart hath a Vein which is termed Coronaria theThe Coronary Vein of the Heart. Crown-vein, becaue it incircles the Heart, and is omtimes double. It aries from the Cava, without the right Ventricle, about whoe Bais it Expatiates in a large tract from the right Eare, and with a wide Channel it compaes about externally to the left Ear, which it doth not enter, but turns aide into the Parenchyma of the Heart. Hence it preads its branches downwards through the urface of the Heart, but the greatet tore through the left ide thereof, becaue the fleh is there thicker. A mal valve is fatned in its original, which grants entrance to the blood into the right Ventricle, but will not uffer it to go out.

figure.head: The III. TABLE.
The FIGURE Explained.
This TABLE hews the Situation of the Heart in the Body and the going out of certain Veels therefrom.

list.item: A. The Heart in its natural Situation encloed in the Heart-bag.
BB. The Lungs.
CC. The Nervous part of the Midriff.
DDD. The fleby portion thereof.
E. A portion of the Vena Cava above the Heart, going upwards.
F. Part of the aid Vein peircing the Midriff.
G. The great Artery ariing out of the Heart.
HH. Its branches to med Carotides, the Drowie-Arteries.
I. The point of the Heart enclining to the left ide of the Body.
KK. The Nerves of the ixt Conjugation, from which the recurrent Nerves do pring, which ditribute five branches to the Heart-bag & the Heart.
L. The left Ear of the Heart.
M. The right Ear.
N. The Veels of the Heartbag.
O. The Cartilago Scutiformis, Sheild-fahioned Gritle.
P. The firt pare of the Mucles of the Larynx in their proper place,
Q. The Situation of Os Hyoides.
R. The Apera Arteria or Wezand.
S. The Axillary Artery, about the Original whereof, the Right-hand Recurrent Nerve begins.

figure.p: page 98

div.p:
As for its Ue. Some have perwaded themelves, that it erves to nourih the external part, becaue it is leer then ordinary, creeps about the external urface only, and the Heart is nourihed with Arterial blood. Others will have it to nourih the whole Heart. Licetus aignes its Office to train the blood to the left Ventricle of the Heart, which I wonder at, Becaue 1. It is exceeding mal. 2. It creeps about the External parts. 3. It aries externally from the Vena Cava. and not from the right Ventricle of the Heart. Botallus eems to have acknowledged the ame way, whoe opinion examined by Walaeus. Others, as Riolanus, make it erve not o much for Nutrition, as to repaire the fat; but, firt it reaches farther then the fat. 2. No branches thereof are to be een in the fat. 3. The fat may be generated from
Vapors of the Heart, without any Veins. The true Ue of the Coronary Vein is, to bring back the blood of the other Veins, when it returnes from nourihing the heart, into the right Ventricle again, which the Situation of the Valves doth hint unto us, and the unfitnes of this blood to nourih the olid ubtance or Parenclyma of the heart.

It hath two Coronary Arteries from the great one, at the ame place, in its original, before it paes out of the Pericardium, furnihed with a Valve which prohibits the regres of the Blood. Through thee, becaue they are moved and Pule, blood is carryed to nourih the heart and Ears, and here is made a peculiar kind of Circulation, as Harvy teaches, out of the left Ventricle into the Arteries, out of them into the Coronary Veins, out of which it lides into the right Ventricle, being to be forced again through the Lungs into the left Ventricle.

Now ome men perwade themelves, and epecially Hogelandius, that the Blood which remains after Nutrition, doth not all pas back through the Veins, but that ome particles thereof weat through the Parenchyma into the Ventricles, and caue Fermentation in the Generation of Arterial blood. But 1. The Fermentation, if there be any, may be made by the reliques contained in the Cavities. 2. The coronary Veels, do not reach unto the Ventricles. 3. Tis hard when the body is in health, for the blood to weat through o hard and compact a fleh, unles the blood be very wheyih, and the body of a thin Texture. 4. Why doth not the blood weat through the Skin, which in ome parts is very thin? 5. No particle remains in the fleh, ave what is ordained for the nourihment thereof.

Nerves it hath likewie, obcure ones, from the ixt conjugation, inerted into three places: One being terminated into the heart it elf: Another into its Ears; A third among its greater Veels, to caue ene and not motion according to Piccolhomineus, becaue the Nerve being cut aunder the heart moves nevertheles. The heart hath not many Nerves, but a great Contexture of Fibres like to the Nerves, which Aritotle perhaps reckoning for Nerves, aid the heart was the Original of the Nerves. But that may be Materially true, not formally. Yet I have een in the heart of a Sow, the branches of the Nerves with intangled twigs towards the Cone or Point, carryed from the Septum to the Wall of the Belly.

Yet that is fale which Fallopius tells us, that a great Squadron of Nerves is An Error of Fallopius. pread up and down the Bais of the heart, reembling a Net: For the motion of the heart, is no Animal motion, but a natural motion, becaue the heart is no Mucle: For the heart is moved without our will, and it beats in the Child in the Womb, before the Child hath received the Animal faculty. And Galen did rightly deny that the heart was a Mucle.Whether the Heart be a Mucle? 1. Becaue it hath all kind of Fibres. 2. Becaue a Mucle is the Intrument of voluntary motion. But if any one hall ay the heart is a Mucle ubervient to natural motion, I hall oppoe uch an improper manner of peaking: And o that of Hippocrates may be true, that the heart is a mucle. For he defines a Mucle to be fleh made up into an Orbicular hape. Others conceive that being long boyled it reembles a Mucle, and that then it is not one, but divers Mucles, by reaon of divers motions contracted into themelves. Others grant it to be a Mucle of a nature by it elf, as the Midrifl, which is perpetually moved. Walaeus mot rightly of all others calls it not a Mucle, but aies it is contracted in its motion like a Mucle, by Fibres interwoven in the fleh, and epecially in the Ventricles, like the temporal Mucle in uch as chew their meat.

The Temperament of the heart in repectThe Error of Averroes. of active Qualities is hot, yea the hottet of al the parts of the Body. How beit with a gentle and light-ful heat, not corching and burning, if it be rightly dipoed. And therefore tis no wonder, that in live diections, omtimes we feel o little heat in the heart with our Finger, epecially when our Skin is thick, we hold it but a little while, and the external Air is not rightly prepared before hand. It communicates the ame heat to other parts, and renders ths Arterial blood fit to nourih, which heat being awaged in the Veins by reaon of the long jorney, it mut of neceity run back again to the heart, that it may be refurnihed and retored with the ame heat. But vain is the opinion of Averroes, that the heart is cold, becaue of the cold parts which it contains, viz. its Veels and Valves: Unles haply he ment the heart void of Spirit, as many will have it.
Thoe whoe heart is hotter then ordinaryAn Hairy Breat what it ignifies? have their Breat rough with hair, and the parts near their Hypochondria; and thoe men are angryly inclind, and daring.

Seldom is the heat of the heart oAn Hairy Heart what it ignifie • ? great, as that it elf hould thereby become rough with hair, uch as Pliny and Valerius Maximus tell us was found in Aritomenes a Micenian; and in Hermogene •
a •… cian, Coelius Rodiginus relates: and Benevenius, Z •… Luitanus and Murelus avouch that they aw uch •••• ry heart in certain Famous Theives. Now uch <…> are audacious in the highet degree, extream <…> craty, and for the mot part wicked. Riola •••
••
us, that the matter of thee haires, is the thi ••
• or things of that wheyih humor which is in the Heartbag. But I am more apt to beleive, that it is the plenty of Fuliginous Excrements pringing from an hot heart.

As to the paive Quallities, the Heart is moit, viz. more moit then the Skin, but drier then the Mucles, becaue harder: for the parts of the bodie, look how much ofter they are then the Skin, by o much are they moiter then it. It is a mot rare Cae for a mans Heart to be o olid, dene and compact, as that it will not burn, uch as was the Heart of Germanicus the on of Druus; or cartilaginous, uch as Riolanus oberved in a wicked fellow.
The primary Ue of the Heart.

1. According to Harvey, Baccius, and other of his followers, is no other then to be the Intrument of the Soul, to force and urge the venal blood received from the Ears into the Arteries, by whoe aitance it dipenes Nutriment to the whole body, and is rather joyned as an Aitant to the Ears, that being of greater force, it may upply the defect of the Ears.

But this is a econdary ue of the Heart. For 1. Nutriment was to be prepar'd & filled with vital heat, which it has not ele where ave from the heart. 2. Nature might have provided for this paage of the blood, by ome other member not o laboriouly framed, 3. The neceity of the Heart would not be o great as it is. 4. It is a igne that ome farther thing is performed i •
the Heart, in that venal blood does not nourih, before it enters the Heart.
Now the primary action of the Heart is to be.

II. The Fountain of Heat, whence it is pred into the whole body, whereby the parts are animated and utained. Swowneing teaches o much and other defects of the Heart, in which the heat of the Heart being intercepted, the Members of the Body begin to flag and being detitute of heat, become tupid. And therefore cordials do good in uch caes, which tir up the languihing and nummed heat of the Heart. Alo the Diection of living Creatures does hew, that the Heart is hot, yea that the heart of a Creature being taken out and newly dead, a warm finger, or ome other warm thing being laid upon it, is een to come to its elf again and to tir, which the Lord Bacon Contantine, Harvey, and others have oberved in a Dove, an Eele, a Salmon, and a Man.

It is therefore the Fountain of Heat, both in repect of its Subtance and of the Blood contained in it. I joyn both together. For the Heat prings not from the blood alone, as Harvey would have it, for the Heart in an Egg, and a Child in the Womb, before it is perfect and hollowed with ventricles, is hot and moves, and the ame heat remains in Hearts taken out of the Body and cut up. The blood which flows thither from the Coronary Veels, flowes thither for Nutritions ake and to preerve the Heat. Nor are the ret of the anguine parts, therefore judged to be hotter then other parts becaue they more abound with any heat, but becaue they have Arteries full of arterial blood, and depend upon the influence of the heart, wherewith the blood is heated. So that unles all the blood did pas through the heart, the parts would never grow hot, and the further the blood goes from the heart, by o much the loer in its motion, and the colder it growes. That the coldnes of the heart makes the parts of the Bodie cold, though full of blood, the lownes of the Pule is a ign.

Nor do the Blood and Heart grow hot only from the motion of the Heart, as the followers of Des Cartes wil have it, for 1. they grant that the fiery atomes or indiviible particles of fire, are excited and put into action by motion, though they are only brought into play, but not produced by the aid motion. 2. Many things are moved without waxeing hot, as water, unles they have an inbred principle of heat. 3. Before motion there was heat proceeding from the eminary original, which is afterwards preerved by continual motion.
III. Not o much to make as to perfect the Blood.

It makes Arterial Blood and perfects the venal, or that whichWhether the Heart doe perfect the Blood. is contained in the Veins. For they are out who attribute too much to the heart, as if the heart alone did make blood of the Chylus, they alo are mitaken, who maintaine that the heart contributes nothing to blood-makeing. I goe in a middle way. The Liver challenges the firt makeing of the blood of the Chylus, as I have formerly demontrated, which becaue it is not there perfected, being to thick and unfit to nourih, it is neceary that it hould receive its perfection from other parts. No part is fit for this work ave the heart, which is one of the firt parts generated in the Womb, and through which in a grown peron all the blood in the body has its paage. That the Lungs and heart-ears hould perform their Office, no man will beleive.

The heart perfects two orts of Blood, that of the Liver and that of the Veins. That of the Liver is twofold, the ••• of the Vena portae, the other a cruder ort newly •… f Chyle. The Vein blood i • likewie twofold one of the decendent trunk of vena cava, and the other of the acendent trunk of the aid vein. It receivs the Liver blood through the Cava, to which another joyns it elf out of the lower and upper Truuk, which remaining over and above after the parts are nourihed, by its long journey is become pauled and luggih, and has lot its heat, which is neceary for pulation and nutrition.

This perfection which the Blood receivs from the heart, is hereby confirmed, in that the blood when it comes out of the left Ventricle, has not altogether the ame Conitence nor Colour, which it had when it entred the right Ventricle. The diverity conits in Heat and plenty of Spirits, wherewith it is furnihed when it goes out of the heart, and which it wants when it enters thereinto; and in Effect or Operation, for that which goes out is fit to nourih, but that which enters in is mot unfit, Vital Spirits are added by the inbred faculty of the heart, and the ooty vapors are taken away by that mot hort Concoction, being evacuated by the Lungs and Pericardium or heart-bag.
For what parts does the heart perfect and renew the blood.

The ancients did beleive that the Heart made blood only to nourih the Lungs. But the Veels of the lungs are greater then is requiite only for their Nutrition, and there is continually more blood forced thither by the pulation of the right Ventricle, then could any waies be ueful for the Lungs, unles they were to be nourihed with as much blood as is ufficient for the whole Bodie. And that all is not conumed upon the ubtance of the Lungs, the blood which returnes is a witnes, which runs in great plenty at every pulation, to the left Ventricle, through the Arteria venoa, which in live anatomies being tied, is een to well betwixt the ligature and the Lungs. For there is no way for it to return into the right Ventricle, the paage being topped by the cloe hutting of the mitre-fahionned Valves.

The right Ventricle therefore is buied about blood which is to be ent to nourih the Lungs; the left doth perfect the blood which flows back from the Lungs, being there impraegnated with air, for the Nutrition of the whole Bodie. For the arterial blood alone is that which nourihes, becaue it is only fit for nutrition, and it alone is forced through the Arteries into the utmot parts of the Bodie.

To perfect this blood many thingsWhat things are requiite to perfect the Blood? concur. 1. Heat, which is very dull and laie, as well in the crude blood of the Liver, as in the returning blood of the whole Body. 2. Vital Spirit which by the confeion of all men, ought to be joyned therewith, 3. Light the companion of the Spirits, by which the blood receives a more Illutrious color, is moved and made fit for Nutrition. 4. A certain light and momentary Concoction, weetning the crude: parts, attenuating the whole ubtance, and drawing forth the latent flame. 5. The whole Fabrick of the heart, internal and external, and the Veels both receiving and expelling. 6. The eparation of Excrements, though the receptacles of the aid Excrements are not very manifet. The ooty Vapors of the right Ventricle do evaporate through the Vena Arterioa. The Watry Vapors of both the Ventricles, are congealed into the water of the Heart-bag, and are pent into the ubtance of the Hairs under the Arms. The remaining Excrements continue mixed with the Blood, and are carryed into the Arteries, and the wheyih parts are purged by the emulgent Arteries into the
Kidneys, and by weats into the habit of the Body, the thicker parts by the Hemorrhoidal Arteries and the Ramus Meentericus. Some parts return with the blood through the Veins into the Heart, that by everal repeated coures, there, they may be at lat matered and overcome.

p.hi: Whether or no is the Blood equally perfected in the right and left Ventricle?
p.note: In which Ventricle the Blood is perfected.

div.p: Although the heat of both the Ventricles doth eem to be equal, becaue in Mankind they are both made of piritful eed, and as much is afforded to the right Ventricle by the Liver-blood, and the returning blood of the Veins, as to the left by the Lungs; moreover in Live Anatomies we can hardly perceive that the one is hotter then the other.
Yet that in the left the blood receives greater perfection, thee igns and tokens do perwade me; becaue

list.item: 1. It receives the Blood in ome meaure prepared from the Lungs.
2. It ought to perfect it for the whole Body, whereas the right perfects it only for the Lungs.
3. It hath thicker Walls, more compacted flehy Pillars, wherewith the heat is both more eaily preerved and reverberated, and the blood more trongly driven.
4. The blood is therein more frequently clottered by heat, and Cartilaginous and boney ubtances appear being dryed by heat.
5. When the left Ventricle is hurt, there is greater danger of death, then when the right is hurt.
6. Many Live-wights want the right Ventricle.
7. In dying perons it is ooner dead and void of motion then the right.
8. The Cavity thereof is more narrow, and therefore it doth more eaily preerve and perfect that which is contained therein.

div.p: We cannot exactly define the place. It is the whole Cavity, endued with the virtue of the Parenchyma, becaue the blood fils the whole in the Diatole, and the inbred pirit, is every where diffued. Nor is there any token, of any tay which the whole blood makes in one place more then another, nor of any peculiar virtue of any particle.
The Time. It is perfected in a Moment, becaue

list.item: 1. It is forthwith received and expelled, and makes no tarriance.
2. From its abidance there, the blood would not be perfected but become adut.
3. The flame on the Candle nuf, lights another Candle in the twinckling of an Eye.
4. The Arterial Blood doth continually run to the extremities of the Body, and therefore it ought to be continually and uddenly perfected in the Heart.

div.p: IV. A fourth ue of the Heart is perpetually to move. 1. That it might preerve the Blood and all parts of the Body from putrefaction. 2. That it may help the heat and Elaboration of the Blood. 3. That it might kindle and tir up the vital Light. 4. That it might end fitting nourihment to all parts.
This motion of the Heart is termed PULSUS the PULSE, which is continualWhat the Pule is. without ceaing, raied by the influent Blood, and the Pulifick or Pulative faculty, there reident.

It conits of a Sytole, Diatole •…
ytole. Its Parts. Which mut be diligently •… ned by all their caues, according as Oc •… Inpection of living Bodies and reaon hall Dictate.

Sytole, being the proper and natural motion of the heart, is a contraction and drawing of the heart into a narrow compas, that the blood may by that means be forced out of the right Ventricle through the Vena Arterialis, into the Lungs, and out of the left Ventricle through the Aorta into the whole Body.
Diatole, being an accidental motion, is the widning of the heart, that Blood may be drawn in through the Vena Cava into the right Ventricle, and through the Arteria venoa into the left,

Peri-ytole is a certain ret and top going between both motions, when the Blood is about to enter into or go out of the Ventricles, o mal in healthy perons that it cannot be dicerned, being very manifet in uch as are at the point of death, It is only one between the Sytole and Diatole, or between the Diatole and Sytole. This is the natural tate of the heart.
Beides thee motions two others are Oberved.

1. A certain Undation or waving towards one ide according to the carriage of the right Ventricle, as if it did gently wreath it elf, as we ee in an hore when he is drinking; of which Harvey peaks. 2. A trembling motion of the Heart, when it is cut in under. The former depends upon the Situation of the right Ventricle: The latter is preternatural to the heart, not ariing from other particles or mal Bodies, ent in by the Coronaria, which is then cut in under, but from the remainders of the vital Spirits.

We are taught by the tetimony ofThe Heart takes in Blood in the Diatole. our Eyes, that in every Diatole blood is plentifully received in, and in every Sytole plentyfully expelled, both into the Vena Arterioa and the Aorta. This appears I ay to our Eye-ight.

1. By Ligatures or bindings in live Anatomies. If the Cava and the Aorta with the Veels of the Lungs hall be bound or preed down with the Finger or any other Intrument on either ide; we hall manifetly perceive that the part of the Cava which is inerted into the Heart is made empty; that in the Diatole of the Ear, it is filled, and thereby the Heart; and that the other part of the Acendent and Decendent Vein, on this ide the Ligature, doth wel. In like manner, the Arteria Venoa being tied near the heart, by the Diatole of the left Ear, it is made void and empty on this ide the Ligature where it looks towards the heart, but towards the Lungs it aries and wels. The Arterial Veels of the heart, do hew themelves in a contrary fahion: For the Vena Arterioa being tied, it wels towards the heart, becaue it is filled by the Sytole of the right Ventricle; the Arteria Magna being bound, wels between the heart and the Ligature, being filled by the Sytole of the left Ventricle.

2. Beides the Ligatures, we may gather as much from the veels being opened or wounded. The Vena Arterioa and the Aorta Arteria being opned by a Lancet, at every Sytole or Elevation and Contraction of the heart, it pours forth plenty of blood, as long as the heart continues trong, for when it languihes, it intermits ome Pules, before it voids any Blood. Now we oberve no uch thing, when the Cava or Arteria Venoa, are opened between the heart and the Ligature.

3. The point of a living Heart being cut off, or the <…> being cut aunder through the middle, in e
