4. The welling of the Heart and the Flagging thereof, being Palpable and viible to the external ene, do ufficiently demontrate, when it is made trait in the Sytole, that of neceity omwhat mut be queezed out as it were forcibly, and that when it is widened in the Diatole, it mut needs be filled with humors.
5. The Ventricles in the Diatole appear greater, and in the Sytole leer.

6. From the largnes of the Veels of the Heart: the Vena Cava and Arteria Venoa, do open into the heart with wider mouths, then to uffer only a mal quantity of blood to enter. Alo the Arterial vein and the Aorta are larger, then to end forth nothing, or only Spirits.

The Quantity of Blood which fillsThe Quantity of blood in the Heart. the Heart in the Diatole, and which goes out by the Sytole at every pula
•… not be exactly meaured be
•… ies according to the different tate of the
heart, and the temper of Animals, their Age, Sex, coure of Diet and Life, &c. It is apparent to our Eyes in live Anatomies, that much is received and expelled. But it moves not in and out in o great quantities in perons that are well in health, when the Heart is more quiet and hath the command of it elf. The Antients uppoed that a drop or two was enough at a time, and that the blood did freely pas and repas the ame way. But one drop of blood unaltered, is not able to fill the heart, nor doth provoke it to pulation, not to peak how the foreaid experiments do hew the plenty that paes to and fro. Now the Valves do hinder the free paage and repaage of the blood by the ame waies, of which the three pointed ones or Tricupides o called, do hinder the blood which enters the heart from paing back the ame way, and the Mitre-hap'd Valves do hinder the blood which goes out of the heart from returning the ame way.

Later Phyitians, are divided in their opinions. Some uppoe that a drop or two is either o rarified as to fill the heart, amongt whom is Des Cartes; or is turned into pirit, as Riolanu's Primroe, Leichner and others uppoe, who meaure it by grains, whom we hall anwer when we come to the Caues: Others being Patrons and favourers of the circular motion of the blood, as Harvey, Walaeus, Conringius, Slegelius, &c. do calculate the quantity, by ounces, drams and cruples.

To clear up this Quetion, three things are to be conidered, 1. How much blood is contained in the Diatole of the heart. 2. How much is expelled or driven out of the heart, in its Sytole; whether all that enters the Heart in its Diatole, is quirted out in the next Sytole. 3. How many pulations the heart makes in one hour; or how often the heart receives omwhat by its Diatole, and expels omwhat by its Sytole, in the pace of an hour.

1. In the heart being in its Diatole, Harvey hath found above two ounces of blood. Alo Plempius found near upon two ounces of blood, in the left Ventricle of the heart of a man that was hanged. Riolanus will hardly allow half an ounce in the left Ventricle of one that was hanged, and aies there was more blood in the right Ventricle. Hogeland alo wil have half an ounce or a dram at leat, to enter, at every opening of the Ear.
Now the quantity of all the blood contained in the body, doth eldom exceed twenty four pounds, or come hort of fifteen.
2. In the Sytole there is expelled either a fourth part, or a fit, or a ixt, or at leat an eight, or all together that is contained in the heart.

p.U: uppoes half an ounce in a man, or three drams, or one dram, in a Sheep and a Dog he aies a cruple. And he proves the ame by that uddain effuion of all the blood, if the very leat Artery be cut, and becaue in the pace of one half hour, all the blood may be paed through the heart, he certainly concludes, that in every Sytole of the heart, much blood is expelled. Conringius approves of his Computation. Walaeus admits of half an ounce, but he uppoes only one cruple, as doth Slegelius. Regius has many times oberved half an ounce, omtimes two or three drams, in the heart of a Dog diected. Hogeland contents himelf with a dram. I being more paring uppoe half a cruple, in the mallet proportion to the quantity which iues in uch as •… ded. For there goes not out o much i •… free heart, • s in one that is bound and forced; <…> there o much expelled in the following Sytole, as was drawn in by the Diatole, ome part ticks in the hollow pits of the heart, much tates in the Cavity formed by the production of the three pointed Valves and Ditinct as it were from the Ventricle; finally, the heart cannot be o traitly contracted in the Sytole, as to queeze out every jot of the Blood therein contained. Therefore Conringius doth rightly upect that abides there the pace of one or two Pules, till by little and little it raie it elf, which I undertand of the reliques and part of the Blood, not of the whole received by the foregoing Diatole.

div.p: 3. Primroe numbred in one hour 700 pulations of the Heart. Riolanus 2000. Walaeus and Regius 3000, Harvey, 2000. in ome 4000, 6000, 8000. Cardan 4000. Plempius 4450. Slegelius 4876. I have told upon mine own writ about 4400, But the number varies according to the Age, Temperament, Diet &c. of every peron. So many Sytoles therefore and o many Diatoles there will be in one hour, as long as the Heart is vigorous, for a languihing heart has more Diatoles then Sytoles.
From thee three Praemies I have calculated, how much blood may in an hour be quirted out of the Heart, by its undry pulations.

Now uppoeing all the blood contained in a mans body to be fifteen pounds, if that be taken away which goeth into the Nutriment of the parts, the defect whereof is uplied by new blood bred in the Liver, it will follow,

list.item: 1 That more blood paes through the Heart every hour, then can be afforded by the Concoction of the Liver and the Stomach.

2 That all the Blood in the Body paeth through the Heart, in the pace of a quarter of an hour, or half an hour, or an hour, or an hour and an half, or two houres at the mot. For I cannot agree to Riolanus his conceit, that the blood is circulated only once or twice in a day, becaue he builds upon a fale uppoition of drops, and that only half the blood is circulated.
3 That the parts to be nourihed do not need o much blood for their nourihment.

4 Becaue neither the Veels are broken, nor the Arterial blood can run back again becaue of the valves nor is elewhere diipated, of neceity it runs back through the Veins into the Heart, and the Circulation is performed, of which I hall peak more in my book of Veins and Arteries.

div.p: What the form of the Heart is in its Sytole and Diatole, is known byThe form of the Heart in the Sytole. three tokens. 1 By the Anatomy of living Creatures 2 By the Comodity and Convenience of motion and Ret. 3. By the carriage of the fibres and the ituation of the parts.
In the Sytole

list.item:
1 The Point of the Heart draws up to the bais or broad end, and it becomes broader becaue it is buied in expelling the blood, the length <…> being changed, into breadth, becaue the bais ••• broad • nd is immoveable in repect of the point,
which is tied to no Veels. But according to the obervation of Walaeus in thoe living Creatures, whoe Aorta Arteria does not proceed from the Bais, the broad end or bais of the Hea • t withdraws it elf from the Point. Riolanus will have the Pais of the Heart alwaies to draw towards the Cone or Point thereof, becaue the aid Cone is harder then to be drawn or bended backwards. But ele where, he denies that the Bais being trongly fatened to the veels, can be drawn towards the Point. And therefore other, whom he and Slegelius do follow, conceive that it is extended long-waies, that its walls being contracted, it may expel the Blood. But then the Orifices of the Veels being drawn downwards in the lengthening of the Heart, would be hut, and a contrary motion would happen; beides that living Anatomies do hew, that the heart becomes horter in its Sytole. Nor can it appear longer but horter, if either the point draws to the Bais or the Bais to the point. Both forms erve for expulion of the blood, for whether you pres a bladder ful of water longwaies or broadwaies, you will queeze out the water as oon one way as another.

2. The inner walls are on each ide, drawn up to themelves towards the Ribs, becaue they are contracted and traitned, as we find by putting our Finger in: But the outer parts being welled, eem to be made broader, by reaon of the contraction of all the parts, blown up in the ditenion. It differs therefore from Galens Sytole, which Leichnerus will have to be drawn likewie into it elf, the Longitude of the Heart being changed into Latitude. For indeed and in truth the Diatole is, when the heart is made wider, either long-waies or broad-waies, to the intent that it may be filled, unles the inner parts be traitned.

3. The foreide of the heart is lift up towards the Breat-bone, epecially obout the Bais. For the Broad end or Bais of the heart, mites the Breat where the Pule is felt, becaue that part is raied, and nearet the Breat-bone; in the Sytole the Heart is, vigorated and mettleome, not in the Diatole, and then the Arteries are dilated and filled, whereas the heart is emptied in the Sytole, and at the ame time the Pule is felt, in the Writ and the Breat, at one and the ame time. But the Pule is mot of all dicerned, in the left ide of the Breat, becaue there is the Oriice of the Arteria Aorta.
4. The whole heart becomes every where tight and hard.
5. It is more contracted and traiter then within, and les in bulke, which we judg by our ight and feeling.
6. It appears white, epecially in the more imperfect ort of Animals, by reaon of the voidance of blood in its Sytole.

div.p: In the Periytole, when the heart is looe and oft, before the Diatole follows, and the heart is in its propertate.

list.item: 1. The point withdraws it elf from the Bais, and the Bais from the point in ome perons.
2. The lateral parts internal and external do extend themelves towards the Ribs.
3. The foreide falls in, the hinder part is depreed, epecially above at the Orifice of the Aorta, according to the accurate Obervation of Walaeus.

div.p: The other Periytole which goes before the Sytole, is hardly by any notes dicernable from the Diatole
In the Diatole, which Backius tells usThe hape of the Heart in the Diatole. begins in the middle way to Dilatation, and ends in the middle way to contraction,

list.item: 1. The upper ide is lifted up and wolne by blood flowing in on either hand by the Venal Veels, the welling proceeding by little & little to the point. But it doth not then mite the Breat, as Laurentius and Roellus would have it, becaue the Arteries undergo the Sytole, and the heart ceaes from expulion, for which caue it is not Vigorated.
2. It is more flagging and ofter, becaue it uffers in its reception of blood.
3. The fides remain more lank and extended, and the Cavities remain wider, and therefore when a man puts his Finger into a living heart, he feels no contriction.
4. It is red, becaue of the thinnes of the walls, and the Blood received in, which is Tranparent.

5. The Cone departing from the Bais in the Periytole, renders the heart more long. that it may be more capacious to receive the blood. That it is drawn back towards the Cone, as many write, our Eye-ight will not allow us to believe, nor can it or ought it o to be. It cannot becaue the Fibres are relaxed and not bent; nor ought it, becaue it mut be enlarged to receive, which you may in vain expect, the Ventricles being traitned and revelled. Nor do I aent to Des Cartes and Regius men of mot ubtile wits, that in the Diatole the point draws near to the Bais, in the Sytole it departs therefrom; for they confound the Periytole or quiet poture of the heart, in which the heart is oft, looe and void of blood, before the Diatole is performed, after the Sytole is ended. Moreover, Walaeus believes, that thoe men were deceived, who in a wounded living heart, pretend to have een blood expelled in the Diatole; becaue they took that to be the Dilatation, which was indeed and in truth the contraction. The blood which goes out of the wound, goes out in the Diatole, not driven by the Pule, but becaue the way lies open downwards, it gently lides out, drop by drop.

div.p: The Efficient Caue of the motionThe next Efficient Caue of the motion of the Heart. of the heart, is either immediate or remote. The Immediate is twofold, the Blood and the Pulifick faculty. Pulifick or Pulative faculty.
The Blood either remains in the ame quantity as it flowed in, or it is changed in quantity by boiling, working and rarifying.

1. Pure blood and incere, flowing in through the Vena Cava and Arteria Venoa, and remaining uch, only becoming more perfect and vital, raies the heart into a Tumor like water in a Bladder or Skinbottle, which being for the greatet part ditended, becaue the plenty of blood is burthenome, it raies its elf to expel the ame, by gathering together its Fibres; and this motion happens to the heart in this cae, as the motions of other Members, viz, the tomach, Guts, Bladder, Womb, which are extended by the reception of Chylus, Whey, Wine, Blood, &c. which being expelled they fall again; and like the Mucles, which are tretched being woln with Animal Spirits. By this Blood the Heart is continually moved, as a Mill-wheele is by the perpetual falling down of the Water, which ceaing the Wheel tands till. There is plenty of blood enough to ditend it, no • o much furnihed from the Liver, as from the <> and decendent branches of the Cava, running
back from the remotet Veinulets or mallet branches of the Veins, and it is continually forced along, with Celerity and Vehemency, according to the Demontrations and Doctrine of Harvey and Walaeus. I hall jutifie what I now ay with only one experiment: If the Veels which bring into the heart be tied and o topt, the Hearts motion ceaes, and there remains nothing but a Wavering and a Palpitation; but the Ligature being looned, it recovers its motion.

Aritotle makes the Caue to be Blood which is not pure, nor in o great quantity as to be able of it elf to ditend the Heart, but boyling and working, which boyling of the blood many have followed, though explained after a different manner. Caear Cremoninus makes the caue to be the reitency of the Heart, and the welling thereof by reaon of the Ebullition, which afterward falls, by reaon of the inbred heavynes of the heart, as parts puft up with wind, do of their own accord ettle when the wind is out, and the heaving of the Earth caued by repletion and blowing up of wind, ettles again, by the peculiar heavynes of the Earth. Capar Hofman flies to the inaequality of the boyling blood, which is like boyling water, part whereof acends and part decends.

Others do interpret the matter with greater ubtilty aying that the blood is changed into an Airie pirit. Primeroe aies, that blood jut as Milk, Honey, and very many things beides, doth exceeding wel and rie, o as to become nothing but a kind of Spirit or light Air. Leichnerus aith that of one grain of good blood a great quantity of Cordial Balam is made: even as by one grain of Odoriferous Gum cat upon a Cole, an whole Chamber is filled with a delitious mel.
But many difficulties tand in the way of this Opinion.

list.item: 1. No boyling is of it elf equal, but the Pule is omtimes equal.

2. The Pule hould be greater according as the Boyling is greater. But the boyling of the blood is greatet in burning Fevers, by reaon of the extremity of bubbling heat and the various nature of the Blood, yet is the Pule in uch caes very mal, and in Putrid Fevers it is evermore little in the beginning according to Galen.

3. In live Anatomies, if you wound the heart or the Arteries near the heart, pure blood leaps out abundantly, not frothy, nor boyling, nor heaving, and it continues as it came forth. Nor can it in a moment of time, either boyl in the Heart or Leave boyling, if it did boyl. Yea and if in two Veels you hall receive the veiny blood out of the Cava near the heart and the Arterial blood out of the Aorta near its orignal, you hall find no difference: neither at the firt, nor afterwards. This Harvey, Walaeus, and as many as have made trial can witnes with me.

4. It cannot all be turned into pure pirit by the heart, nor ought it o to be. Not the former, becaue there is not o much heat in a ound heart, nor can the blood taken out of the Arteries et over a great fire be all extenuated, as Conringius hath oberved. Not the latter, becaue the parts for whoe nourihment it is ordained, are not meerly piritual.

5. Plunging into cold water would awage the boyling. But the Arm being hard bound till it wel and grow red again, and then thrut into mot cold Water or Snow, when you unbind the ame you hall perceive how much the Blood returning to the Heart doth cool the ame, as Harvey hath taught us.

div.p: The mot ubtile Renatus des Crates and Cornelius Hogelandius, and Henricus Regius who tread in his footteps, with equal commendation, do after another manner demontrate the motion of the Heart to proceed from a Drop or two of blood rarified: when the Ventricles of the Heart are not ditended with blood, of neceity two large drops do fall thereinto, one out of the Cava into the right Ventricle, another out of the venoa Arteria into the left, becaue thoe two Veels are alwaies full, and their Mouths towards the Heart are open, which drops becaue of their aptnes to be dilated, and the heat of the Heart, and the remainders of blood therein burning, preently they are et on fire and dilated by rarefaction, by which the Valves through which the drops entred are hut and the Heart is ditended. But becaue of the traitnes of the Ventricles, the blood rarifying more and more cannot there abide, therefore at the ame moment of time, it opens in the right Ventricle the three Valves of the Vena Arterioa which look from without inwards, and being agitated by heat, it breaks out through the aid Vena Arterioa, and by ditending the ame and al its branches and driving on the blood, makes them beat the Pule: but in the left ventricle it opens the three valves of Arteria magna looking from without inwards, and through them breaks into the great Artery, which it widens, and drives the next blood warmed and ex •… led by the former pulations, into the ret of the Arteries of the whole body, that they might be thereby ditended. And o they conceive the Diatole is caued. And they ay the reaon of the Sytole is, becaue the blood being expelled out of the ventricles of the Heart, the Heart is in part evacuated, and the blood it elf in the Arteries cooled, wherefore of neceity the heart and Arteries mut flag and ink, whereupon way is again made for two drops more to enter, that o the Diatole may be repeated.

I dare not deny a light Rarefaction from a gentle heat, uch as we oberve in the opening of a Vein, and I grant that it may be omtimes praeternaturally augmented; but that a few drops hould be rarified into o great a bulk, as to caue the motion of the Heart, and that they hould be cooled in the Arteries, many Arguments, beides thoe before thoe oppoed to the Ebullition of the blood, do diwade.

list.item: 1. Living Diections, in which neither when the Heart, nor when the Arteries are wounded, does the blood come out drop by drop or rarified, but pure, uch as the Ear had forced out.
2. The Heart being cut in pieces or pricked, is een to pule, without any rarefaction of blood, which is but imaginary.

3. In trong Dogs the point of the Heart being cut off, Walaeus oberved, that when by reaon of the Efflux of Blood, it was not half full, it was nevertheles erected, but not filled by rarefaction: but when it was contracted, that portion of blood which remained in the Heart, was cat out to the ditance of more then four Feet. It is in vain to call in the outward Coldnes of the Air as an aitant caue: for the blood in the Heart doth not grow cold in a moment, the heat thereof being yet Vigorous, as a boyling pot taken from the fire and uncovered doth not immediately ceae to boyl but after ome time.

4. Jacobus Back doth elegantly devince the ame from the tructure of the heart and its Veels. For the Muculous fleh of the heart being firme and
trong, is unapt to rie and fall by the bare Rarefaction of the blood. A more vehement action is requiite to move this vat bulk. Alo the Arteries of the heart hould have had a greater Orifice, and the rarefied blood being to go forth would require a larger pace, then then was neceary for its entrance.

5. A Confuion would arie in the motions of the Heart and valves, as he oberves. The Diatole of both of them would be performed in the ame time, and o the valves hould be ueles, both which is repugnant to experience. Moreover the valves mut, be both hut and open, in the Sytole of the Arterie.

6. That it hould be cooled in the Arteries, neither reaon or occular inpection will permit. It is drawn hot out of the Arteries, differing little or nothing from that which is contained either in the Heart, or near it. In the mall Arteries there is indeed no Pule felt, but that is to be imputed to the malnes of the veels and their ditance from the Heart which forces the blood. Nor ought it becaue it enters into the Capillary Veels, that it may nourih the parts with hot Blood, not with uch as is cooled and thickned, before it is changed into the econdary humors. And what ue is there of rarefaction, if it preently ettle again.

div.p: The Experiments and Reaons which learned men bring to the contrary, from an Eele and an hunting dog, from the contraction of the members by Cold from palpitations, from pirit of wine reembling the Pule, from vehement protruion &c. are eaily anwered if you conider

list.item: 1 That a certain motion is retored even in Hearts that are dead, by exciteing their heat as in Mucles.
2 The Fault is in the Veels contracted by Colds not in the Blood. when they fall in and flag.
3 Palpitations arie from plenty of blood, as examples tetifie, uppreion of the Coures, and the cure by blood-letting.
4 In the Heart there is an even motion, different from that which raied by pirit of wine or any thing ele.
5. The protruion by pure blood is more vehement, if the faculty concur, and the Fibres of the Heart be united.
6. The Heart is in its Periytole or very near it, when in the point cut off, no dilatation is oberved, if it continue till in the Sytole, the dilatation is not felt, till the Diatole follow.

div.p: The pulifick Faculty implanted in the Heart, mut needs be joyned withWhether there be a pulifick Faculty. the blood as the caue of its motion, either that it may guide the influx and egres of blood, and ait the ame, which would otherwie proceed diorderly, as I explain the matter; or that it might of it elf produce the motion, according to the Opinion of the Ancients, which cannot be conerved, if the perpetual flux of the blood hould be topped. That the Heart tands in need of uch a faculty I prove

list.item: 1. Becaue the Pule would be alwaies unequal, the influx being unequal, unles directed by ome Faculty.

2. When the Heart in Feavers is more vehemently moved then ordinary, through the urgency of heat, and in dying perons Nature being at the lat pinch, and uing all her might, yet is the motion of the heart weak, as appears by the Pule, becaue the inbred Faculty is either lot or weakned. Contrariwie, though the aid Faculty be trong, and the influx of the blood ceae or be hindred, after large bleedings, or by reaon of Obtruction of the Veels, either in the whole Habit of the Body, or the paages thereof, or near the Heart, the Motion of the Heart fails. And therefore both are to be joyned together as primary Caues.
3. Any Particles of the Heart being cut off, do pule by reaon of the reliques of this Faculty or Spirit remaining.
4. The Heart being taken out of the Body, or cut in pieces, lightly pricked with a pin, does preently pule, as Walaeus hath oberved.
5. It were contrary to the Majety of the principal Part, to be moved by another whether it will or no, without any aitance from itelf, and o to receive a violent Impreion.

div.p: Regius hath ubtituted the influx of Animal Spirits into the fibres of the Heart intead of Animal Spirits, and Hogeland the little petite Atomes of the blood moved in the Parenchyma. But we mut know in the firt place 1. That the motion of the Heart is Natural which lats perpetually, yea againt our wills, and when we are aleep, and not Animal. 2. That we exclude not the Spirits, which are the Souls Servants and Intruments. 3. The mall Boddikies or indiviible Particles of the Blood, have all dropped out in di • ected Hearts, becaue the Vena coronaria was cut aunder. And that if any reliques of the aid Bodikies did remain, they could not be excited to motion, either by pricking alone, or by raiing heat, unles a Spirit or Faculty be allowed, which being extinguihed, though the pieces of the Heart be laid in never o hot a place, they will never pant.
Among the Remote Caues there is

1 The vital Spirit, as well thatRemote Caues of the motion of the Heart. which is implanted in the Heart, as that which comes thither from without, with beat ufficiently manifet in live diections, and which warms the whole Bodie. And that either not hineing with light, as mot will have it, or hineing. That a lightfull heat of the Heart is requiite in this cae, many things argue. 1 The motion of the Elements is imple, never circular, and light moves it elf and the humors with a circular motion. 2 The Heart and the Blood are more quickly moved by light then otherwie they could be, which in the twinkleing of an eye, dazeles all things, illuminates all things. 3. There is in all particular parts beides the obcure principles of the Elements, alo a lightfull part propagated from the eed, which ought to be preerved by a like flame, kindled from the Heart 4 In Hippocrates to dream of pure and brightly hining tarrs, ignifies Health of Bodie. 5 No Homor although hot, does pant and move it elf, unles a burning flame, as we ee in pirit of wine, a Candle, and other things. 6 In Glow-wormes their hinderpart only pants and hines, where their Heart is, of whoe light I have dicoured in my Second Book of the light of Animals Chap 11 and 12. That the vital pirit is really endued with light, and that there is an inbred light in the Blood and Heart, which helps forward the circular motion of the blood, I have demontrated in my aid Treatie Lib. 7. Cap. 5. 23. H ••
mont conents that the animated pirit, in the left Ventricle of the Heart, inlightned by the former light, is the Mover of the Heart. After Caimus and other ancient Authors, Ent aerts the ame thing touching the flame, raied out of the Seed in the firt bladder of the Heart raied by the heat of the Hen which hatcheth, and firt of all hineing forth, when the Lungs perform their office. yet he errs, that in the external widening he begs, in the Contruction more inwardly he tends to the beginning: for in the Sytole all that illuminats
is expelled, and then it is vigorated in a narrow heart, which is evident in optick tubes and hollow glaes. I ad that in the Diatole of the left Ventricle, it ets on fire and kindles by the Sytole from the Lungs, the vital flame.

2. The Shape and Conformation of the Heart and Veels being exceeding well fitted to receive and expell the blood. Epecially the fibres of the Heart, and the flehy columns. Thee make not o much for the Strength of the Heart alone, as for the motion. For all the fibres being contracted greater and leer, in the walls and eptum, which according to Harvey are circular, as in an artificial Net, or Pure queezed, the contents are expelled. They are tretched in the Sytole, and remitted in the Diatole. By help of the maller fibres, wherewith the fleh is interwoven, a languihing contriction is made, but to a tronger, thoe greater flehy ones concur contained in the Ventricles, which Walaeus often oberved in live Bodies diected.

3 The Pule of the Heart, the Blood and the extream parts, the pule is from the Heart, which ceaing, the motion alo ceaes. Now it begins from the vena cava, and is continued from the Auricula dextra, by and by from the right ventricle into the Vena arterioa, or if the point be cut off, externally from the Arteria venoa into the left Earelet, thence into the left Venricle, out of which the Pule is felt by a manifet contriction to goe into the Aorta, in the Anatomy of living Creatures.

They drive, becaue 1 The Blood is offenive by its Quantity. 2 They are moved being irritated by any external force. 3 Blood is continually uppeditated. For Blood thruts and drives on Blood, o that even after the Heart has bin taken out of Bodies, Walaeus has een a quick motion of the blood in the veins. Which nevertheles did not happen by any proper power, which the Blood has to move it elf, but partly by the driveing of the external parts, which remitt or end back that which remains after nutrition as bur •… enome and uperfluous, partly by a pontaneous contraction of the Veels filled with Blood, whoe Arteries in living Bodies being bound towards the Heart, do well; towards the extream parts they are empty: But the Veins too near the mallet branches and the parts from which they bring back the Blood are puffed up, but are flat where they look towards the Heart, to which they drive the Blood; in a word, partly by the contraction of the mucles and their driving, in the flehy and outward parts, as Harvey oberves.

4 The Attraction of the Heart and Parts, leat they be detitute of aliment profitable and ufficient for them, which we oberve according to Nature in thoe parts that are nourihed; but beides nature in wounds, Ulcers, Tumors, &c. And this may eaily be done, becaue the blood dipered in all places, is immediately fatened to the Heart and Parts which draw it, the Pule of the cava and Arteries aiting the ame.

div.head: Chap. VII. Of the parts of the Heart in pecial, viz. the Earlets, Cavities, Septum, Veels, and Valves.
div.p: THe parts of the Heart which are pecially to be conidered are either externally een as the Earlets; or within only, as the Ventricles or two Cavities, the Septum or partition, and the Veels with the Valves.

The Earlets or little Ears, were o termed, not from hearing, but becaueThe Earlets of the Heart why o called? of ome reemblance in their hape. For from a long Bais they end in a blunt point (howbeit the left is more accumulated) of an obtue triangle; and they have a Cavity, that the Ventricles might be produced before the Heart. For that ame puling Bladder in an Eg, is the Earlets,What pules firt in an Eg. becaue they were neceary in the Child in the Womb, though the Heart were not o oon neceary, which afterwards grows upon the Bladder. Others give another reaon, becaue the Earlets oberve the ame proportion in their puling as the Bladder had. But this is very hard to ditinguih in the firt Generation. Others take the Bladder for the Heart, whoe Expanions or Earlets appear red, becaue they are tranparent, but the Heart is not een by reaon of the plenty of Seed, and Pule intermitted. I upect that both may lie hid under the Veicula or bladderkie, but that the Earlets are preently drawn and moved, becaue of their ue. Otherwie it would eem inconvenient that the Appendix hould be greater then the whole Body. Nor is the Heart a bare Parenchyma or affuion of blood. It hath Cavities produced doubtles out of the foreaid Bladderkie.

Now the EARLETS are Procees or Appendixes; and according to Hofman, nothing but the Subtance of the Heart attenuated and widened. Which I know not how true it is. I hould rather ay they eem to be the ubtance of the neighboring Veels dilated, although they are made firt of Seed out of the bladder, and are the firt motion, and the lat in dying.
They are ituate at the Bais of the Heart, before the Orifices of the veelsTheir Situation. venal to which they cleave, and whereby they are mediately joyned to the heart. They are on each • ide one

For two they are in Number, anwerableNumber. to the number of the Hearts Ventricles, the right Earlet being greater, and the left maller. And both are large in an Embryo or Child in the Womb: the former is joyned to the Vena cava, with which it eems to be one common body; the latter to the Vena arterioa.

The Subtance of the Earlets is peculiar,Subtance. uch as there is none in any other part; by reaon of their ingular ue. Howbeit they are thin and oft, for their more eaie contraction and nervous for trengths ake. But the left is more hard, a little more flehy and thicker: yet the Heart is not o. Howbeit they anwer in a certain proportion to the Ventricles of the Heart.

Their external Surface, when theyTheir Surface. are extended and full, is even and boie or bunching (but their circumference unequal) when they are contracted, it is wrinkled; and in the left it is more wrinkled then in the right, becaue the inner fabrick is more turning and winding, and hath more pits in it, for

The Earlets being inwardly diected and pread open, do dicover unto us 1. a certain fleh-membranous plain, tretched out to the extremities of the treble pointed Valves, to which the fibres of the Valves are fatned. 2. About the whole circumference flehie Columnes grow out, firt the great crooked ones,
out of which Spring many leer ones, with a wonderful and neat contexture, omtimes ingle, omtimes wreathed, and infolded either with the great ones, or with one another.See Tab. IV. of Book II. 3. Between thee Columnes deep Pits are een, more in the left, fewer in the right. In the middle partition of each Earlet. Folius hath found out many little Holes, which I have alo een, through which he conceives the blood is carried into the left Ventricle, when there is need of les matter. But eeing they are rarely to be een, nor do they penetrate into the Ventricles, yea they are les, I am more apt to think they are Pores common to many, erving for motion, or the nutrition of the Part.

Botallus hath found a Paage ufficiently viible near the right Earlet, which goes preently right out, into the left Ventricle. This Walaeus explains to be ment of the oval hole, or that paage by him oberved, which goes obliquely out of one Earlet into the other. Such an one I have often een in Oxen and Goats, but it is the coronal Vein, nor does it pierce into the left Earlet, but decends into the Parenchyma of the heart.

As to their Colour: In an Infant in the Womb ome months old, they areTheir Colour. red, by reaon of the abundance of purple blood, according to the Obervation of Harvey. I have oberved the ame in the Conceptions of beats, the Heart being white and bloodles, and the Earlets

page 108 full of blood and ruddy. In grown perons they are commonly more obcure then the Heart it elf, when they move not, but in their motion they ucceively change their colour, as the Heart does; for being moved they are pale, becaue they expel the blood in their contractions, which does mot of all appear in their extremities; they grow red again in their Diatole, when they have received blood.

Their Motion is manifet to the ene in live Anatomies, by reaon of theTheir Motion. blood ruhing in, and filling them, wherewith they well in living bodies, and by their contracting themelves, by means of their flehy fibres contracted into themelves, endeavoring to force the blood out into the Ventricles.

There are three parts of their motion; Sytole, Diatole, and the ret or paue which comes between them, which cannot be dicerned, ave in perons ready to die, for they are performed o wiftly in ound perons, that they eem to be confounded, and to be performed all at once, as in the dicharge of a Gun, all eems to be performed in the twinkling of the eye, and in wallowing, as Harvey informs us.

The Diatole is caued by the blood received from the Vena Cava and Arteria Venoa. The Sytole is performed, when the Earlets being filled, do by contracting themelves, expel the Blood into the Ventricles.

The Diatole and Sytole of both the Earlets, do happen at one and the ame time. When the right Earlet undergoes its Diatole, at the ame time the left Ear undergoes the ame; when the latter is contracted in the Sytole, the former alo expels. But the Diatole of the Heart and Earlets, happens at different times, as alo both their Sytoles. The Sytole of the Earlets happens at the ame time with the Diatole of the Ventricles, and contrarily, and the contriction of the Earlets doth alwaies forego the Diatole of the Ventricles, both in healthy perons and in uch as are at the point of death. But the motion of the former is more lating then the motion of the latter, When the left ventricle ceaes, the left Earlet till continues puling, which being extinct, the remaining motion is in the right ventricle, and that ceaing, the right Earlet proceeds panting, being the lat that dies, ave that when it ceaes, a certain trembling motion doth as yet continue in the blood which flows in, by reaon of the driving of the extream parts.
Their ue, is

list.item: I. To be Store-houes to the Heart; for they firt received theTheir ue. Blood and Air, that they may not uddenly ruh into the heart, whence the heart might be hurt, and the Animal faculty uffocated. And hence it is that they are placed only at the veels which pour into the heart, and not at the Arteries which void the blood forth.
II. To afeguard the veels to which they are joyned.
III. To be intead of a cooling Fan to the Heart, according to Hippocrates.

IV. According to Walaeus, to be in place of a meaure, by which the vena Cava and Arterioa do meaure the blood into the heart, for eeing all the blood was not to go out, at every pule, but the greatet part was to tay behind to be further perfected, nature joyned the Earlets to the heart, as veels which hould give in o much blood to the Heart, as was naturally to be cat forth at every pulation. For which caue he thinks it is, that the right Earlet is greater then the left, becaue the right Ventricle is more Capacious then the left, and like-more is voided therefrom then from the left, viz. ooty Exhalations and the Nutriment of the Lungs.

div.p: The CAVITIES of the Heart or its Ventricles, Chambers, or Caves &c. The Ventricles of the Heart. Aritotles Error. are not three, as Aritotle falely acribes to greater Beats, for three are not found, no not in a Whale, but only two, as Walaeus and Sylvius have oberved in the diection of a young Whale. Nor did Galen at Rome find more in an Elephant. And by a very rare chance three were oberved by Aemilius Parianus at Venice in the Heart of a certain Coverlid-maker. And Velingius twice oberved the like. Alo Walaeus aw a third Ventricle in the Heart of an Oxe. Caealpinus oberved three in Birds and Fihes, and the right Ventricle doth eaily appear to be divided into two near the point, by a certain thin Partition, yet in truth both come into one. Licetus undertands that ame third Ventricle of Aritole, to be the Prominency of the right Ventricle, turned in beyond the left, o that the left Ventricle commonly o called is Aritotles middle Ventricle. Conringius doth otherwie excue Aritotle, viz. that the right Ventricle in his account is whence the Cava aries, the middle whence the Aorta prings and the left, whence the Arteria Venoa or left Earlet aries, which being the leat of all, is in mal Live-Creatures hardly viible. But o there hould be four Ventricles, the Vena Arterioa being added, as at firt ight may eem, not three only. There are therefore only two Cavities found in the Heart of a Live-wight, the right and the left, having their inner urface uneven and rough, epecially the left. The Heart of a certain Polander cut up by Riolanus, was perfectly olid, having no Ventricles at all.

Many Pits are formed in them by the flehy Fibres, in the right more, but narrower, in the left fewer, but deeper, that they might contain the blood received in, hence in the Contriction of a Living Heart they are leer, in the Dilatation wider. The Pits are contituted and fenced by

Thoe flehy Particles termed La • ertuli Muclekies, omtimes round, ometimesFlehy Pillars in the Ventricles of the Heart. thin, being five or more in the right, two only viible in the left, but very thick ends. Velingus oberves that the larger have Pores which pas through them. The ue of them, is according to ome, to be Ligaments of the Heart. Maa counts them little Mucles. Vealius and Riolanus call them Columnae carneae, flehy Pillars, which being contracted, do further the Diatole of the Heart. Parianus aies by help of them the Heart contracts it elf, Walaeus alo hath oberved in live Diections, that they ait the Contraction or Sytole of the Heart, epecially when it is trong and vehement, at what time their welling begins at their Bais, and goes on by little and little unto the point. Harvey aies they draw the Cone or Point of the Heart to the Bais or broad end thereof, by their obliqu • fibres. And he is apt to think that heat is carried through all of them. A. Benedictus and Ent, that they hinder the blood from going into Clotters, while it is haken and agitated by them. Ba ••• us, that they are intead of Ropes and Bands, to hinder leat in the Contractions of the Heart, the Valves being forced beyond their pitch and overhot, hould be unable to retain the Blood. Slegelius will have it that they are contracted, that they may hut the Orifices of the Veels of the Cava and Vena Arterioa by their Fibrekies. All thee Opinions are true and mut be joyned together, as will manifetly appear to him that hall accurately conider the times of the motions of the Heart.

Many things are preternaturallyThings preternatural found in the Heart. found in the ventricles of the Heart. Bauhin hath ound bits of far, and our mot expert Countryman Wormius hath took out of both the ventricles certain Caruncles or mal particles of Fleh, whiteih within, but of a hining red color without; which I alo have long ince found, at Padua and at Hania in my Diections, both of Men and Beats, Eratus hath found a Flegmatick concretion, like yellow marrow, which is found, in the boyled bones of Oxen. Vealius two pounds of Glandulous and blackih fleh, Benivenius a Gobbit of fleh like a Medlar.

Salvius hath oberved Worms, as alo I. D. Hortius at Confluentia; May a twibladed Snake like a Whip at London, and M, A. Severinus much uch another at Naples. Hollerius found tones (with an Impotume) in a woman troubled with the tone; and Wierus tones as big as Peae.

Bones are more rarely found in the Hearts of Men. Yet Gemma did onceA Bone in the Heart. find ome, and Riolanus twice, in the dead body of preident Nicolas being eighty years of Age, at the beginning of the Aorta, and in the Queen Mother of Lewis the thirteen King of France, being after her deceae opened to be Imbalmed. Johannes Trullus ound one in the Heart of Pope Urban the eighth of a triangular Figure repreenting the letter T. Simon Pauli my Renowned Praedeceor in the Anatomical Theatre, took a bone as hard as a tone of a Figure of the Pythagoraean letter Y, out of the Heart of a Man of Hania forty years of Age, the bignes of a Wallnut, and the hape not unlike the Heart. I conceive they are all bred through the drynes and low motion of the Humors in aged and ick Perons. Yet nature makes ue of this defect to provoke and quicken the motion of the blood, when it paes lowly, as waters flow more eaily when a peice of wood is cat in, or that all the blood may not clotter, as our Women and Butchers tir their blood about with a tick, when they intend thereof to make Puddings, that it may not go into Clotters.

The right Ventricle receives blood out of the Vena cava, which Vein it receives intoThe right Ventricle. it elf: And therefore it hath not o thick a fleh or wal, as the left hath, that their might be an even poie, eeing it contains more matter, and bears a greater weight then the left. Nor is there o perfect a Concoction made in this Ventricle, as in the left in which there is more heat.

It is not exactly round but emicircular, reembling the Moon encreaing, nor does it reach to the End of the Point, but it eems to be as it were an Appendix to the left Ventricle, which when the left is taken away, eems till as it were to repreent an whole Heart.
Yet is it deeper and larger then the left, by reaon of the tore of blood, which it was to contain, both to nourih the Lungs, and to make vital Spirits in the left Ventricle. For
Its Ue is

list.item: 1. To receive blood out of the vena cava, to nourih the Lungs, the aid blood being poured into the Lungs through the Vena arterioa. Therefore Fihes which have no Lungs, and draw no Air in at their Mouths, are without this Ventricle, having no more then one. This right Ventricle therefore, does concoct and attenuate the Blood, for the Nourihment of the Lungs.

II. To end the thinner part of the Blood through the Septum or partition, into the left Ventricle, to make vital Spirits; and the thicker part through the Lungs, both to nourih them, and that it may return to the left ventricle, for the Nutriment of the whole Body.
III. Further to perfect and prepare the blood which runs back as uperfluous after the extream parts are nourihed, and the crude blood which is bred in the Liver.

div.p: The left Ventricle is narrower, but more noble; having a round Cavity,The left Ventricle. and which reaches unto the point of the Heart. Its fleh or wall is three times as thick as that of the right ventricle. Alo it is harder, that the vital Spirits may not exhale, and that the motion of the blood might be tronger, being to be forced into the farthet parts of the body.

Its Ue is to make vital Spirit and Arterial blood, of a twofold matter, I. Of blood prepared in the right ventricle, and paed through the Septum and the Lungs. II. Of Air drawn in by the Mouth and Notrils, prepared in the Lungs, and tranmitted through the Arteria venoa with the blood into the left ventricle of the Heart, to kindle and ventilate the vital flame, yea and to nourih the ame. The latter fihes tand in need of and Leucophlegmatick perons, the former uch as are eated in a narrow or infected place, or are under extream heat, for fear of uffocation and extinction of the flame in the Heart.

The Ue therefore of both ventricles is in a manner the ame, viz. to generate Arterial blood, and to perfect the venal, and to receive the ame running back from all parts of the body through the veins, and to expel the perfect blood through the Arteries into the farthet parts of the body, that they may be thereby nourihed. This is proved by the Conformations of the ventricles, which in part are like one to the other, in the right two veels, a Vein and an Artery carrying out, and bringing back and as many in the left. In the former are two orts of Valves the trebble pointed, and Mitre-hap'd, and the like in the latter. The left expels and receives as much as the right, ave that it is conumed in nourihing the Lungs and the Heart. Yet their different Contitution and Magnitude, argues ome difference. Whence 1. There is a different Coction in the one and other, as hath been demontrated above. 2. The right works for the Lungs the left for the whole Body. 3. The right ends ooty Exhalations and blood to the Lungs; the left receives from the Lungs Blood Impraegnated with Aire.

There is a Septum or Partition between the two Ventricles, which is thick like the other Wall of the left ventricle (which Columbus once oberved to be Gritley) hollow on the left ide, on the right bunching, full of hollownees and holes. which ome uppoe to be the third ventricle of Aritotle; which hollownees or Caves are more large towards the right ide, but their utmot ends towards the left ide are hardly dicernable. Helmont decribes them to be triangular, whoe Cone ending in the left ventricle, is eaily topped, but the Bais of the aid triangle in the right ventricle, is never topped ave in Death. But I have een them Circular o that they could eaily admit a Peae, but obtue towards the left Hand.

That they are open is the opinionManifet Pores in the Septum of the Heart. of the Ancients and of many Anatomits which follow them. Gaendus aw Payanus at Ajax hew the Septum of the Heart to have through-fares, by reaon of undry windings and crooked Con • -holes as it were, and that by lightly putting in his Probe, without any violence, which he wreathed gently and turned it upwards and downwards and to the ides. And although by a Probe breaking the tender fleh of the Septum, we may eaily make a way, yet we may not doubt of the Eyewitnes of Gaendus nor of the Dexterity of Payanus; eeing I alo of late found the partion of a Sows Heart, in many places obliquely perforated with manifet great Pores, which were open of themelves without the ue of a Probe, o as to admit a large Peae; but when I put in my Probe, it brought me to the left ventricle, where a thin Membrane as it were an Anatomois was placed, hindering any regres. Riolanus alo hath een it bored through towards the point, where it is mot thin. Walaeus in the Partition of an Oxes Heart, did omtimes find a Cavity in the upper part according to the length of the Heart, open into the left ventricle about the point
of the Heart, the length and breadth of a Mans Forefinger, which he conceives to be the third Ventricle mention'd by Aritotle.

Yet are they not alwaies open in dead bodies, becaue in living bodies they are kept open, by the continual agitation of the Heart, which ceaing, they are not o viible to the Eye-ight, even as we ee no manifet paages, when the weat breaks out plentifully through the Skin, nor when the eed breakes out of the Kernels and Spermatick veels, into the Urinary paage: nor the Pores by which the Empyema or out of the blood out of the vena Arterioa peirces into the Arteria venoa, through the ubtance of the Lungs, or the blood in the Liver, out of the branches of Porta into the Cava. Caelus is in the right, where he aies, that nothing is more foolih, then to think that look what and how it is in a living Man, o it mut needs be in one that is dying, Yea that is dead. Whence many (as Columbus, Spigelius, Hofman, Harvey, &c.) have denyed that any thing paes through this Septum or Partition. But it is no wonder that they make a doubt of it: For,

I. They are o crooked and winding, that a Probe cannot eaily pas through them. Howbeit thee Pores become more conpicuous, in the Heart of an Ox long boyled, as Bauhinus, Riolanus, my elf with others can witnes. And you are to oberve, in oppoition to Hofman and Plempius that deny it. that in the boyling a moderation mut be ued, and that the Fibres in living Bodies do never tick o cloe together, but that they leave Pores, as the Nerves do hew, finally, that the quicket-ighted Anatomits can ee no Membrane in the boyled Hearts of Oxen. II. In dead Bodies all paages fall in and hrink together. III. That an extream traitnes was requiite in the End; becaue the thinnet part of the Blood, is trained as it were in that part: And in the mean time, becaue thee holes are not in vain, therfore,

The Ue of the Septum or Partition of the Heart, is, that the thinnerWhether the Blood pas through the partition of the Heart? blood may pas there-through into the lef ventricle, for the Generation of vital blood and pirit, which is afterwards ditributed through the Arteries into the whole Body, for to preerve and tir up the life and natural heat. But the thicker and greater part of the blood, by a natural and ordinary way, and not a violent only, is communicated to the Arteria venoa, through the vena Arterioa, by mediation of the Lungs, that in the left ventricle it may be mingled with that which weats through the Septum. The thicker part is ordained to nourih the Lungs, and that it may return back to the left ventricle tis tempered with Air. The thinner part paing through the Septum, nourihes the ame in its paage, becaue the external Coronary veels do only creep through, and in that long and dangerous journey through the Lungs, it would vanih away and come to nothing. By this way only uch as dive deep into the Sea, and thoe that are hanged for a mal while, do live a while and come to themelves, after the motion of their Lungs is ceaed.

The Motion of the Septum or Partition doth help forward this paage, which that it is moved according to the motion of the Ventricles, I have thee igns and tokens; Becaue 1. It is furnihed with Circular Fibres, as well as the Walls, in a boyled Heart, uch in a manner as are in the Sphincter Mucle, as Harvey tetifies, which eeing them move the Ventricles, they mut as well move the Septum. 2. A certain Palpitation is felt, if you put in your Finger into a living Heart, according to the obervation of Walaeus. 3. In Creatures ready to die, when the motion of the left ventricle ceaes, the Septum follows the motion of the right Ventricle, as the ame Harvey oberves: and if the right Ventricle be wounded, Riolanus tells us, that the motion remains in the Septum in his Obervations. Yet the ame Riolanus in another place being wier, denies that it is moveable, unles towards the Bais where it is oft gives way a little, and that o it ought to be that the paage may be maintained, becaue when the Ventricles are dilated above the through-far'd Septum, and traitned again like Bellows, the little holes would be hut up. But there is no fear. For in the Sytole, when the point is drawn back to the Bais, the Pores are opened in the Septum moved upwards, that the blood may at once pas both the Septum and the Lungs. Contrarywie in the Diatole, becaue the Heart is ditended long waies, the pores are drawn back with the Septum, and are hut up, until the Heart be filled.

As to the Heart-veels there are foundVeels of the Heart. four remarkeable ones going out of the Heart which Hippocrates calls the Fountanes of Humane Nature. Into the right Ventricle are inerted two Veins; the Vena Cava and Vena Arterioa; into the left, as many Arteries; Arteria Venoa and Arteria Magna. Before all which are placed within eleven Valves or little dores, made of the Tunicles of their Veels widened and tretched out. The Veins which bring in to the Heart, viz. the Cava and Arteria venoa, have trebble-pointed valves, looking from without inwards; the Arteries which carry away, viz. the Aorta and the Vena Arterioa, have Sigmahap'd or Mitre-fahion'd valves open inwards, hut outwards. The former admit blood into the Heart; being open they uffer the blood to flow out, being hut they hinder it from returning the ame way. The trebble-pointed valves do not only wink, but they are cloe hut by the blood ditending the Heart, and by the contriction of the Heart which traitens the veels. The Sigmoides or Sigma-hap'd are hut by the Relaxation and falling in of the Heart in the Diatole, whereby the Fibres being tretched out long-waies, they are drawn downwards with the Walls and o hut, like the Chains in Draw-bridges.

The Trebble-pointed or Tricupides, are opened by the impule of new blood through the Cava, and Arteria venoa, and the Diatole of the Heart, whereby the Fibres being drawn downwards, they are opened; But the Mitre-hap'd valves, are open'd in the Sytole by the Contriction of the Heart, and the blood urgeing its way out. Alo they may be praeternaturally hut, by the blood expelled and tanding eated in the full veells, to which, endeavouring to run back, they make reitance by reaon of their conformation, which Artifice of Nature, we ee every where imitated by the Flood-gates and Locks made upon Rivers. But that according to nature they are not hut by the returning of the expuled blood, as ome conceive Walaeus proves, Becaue 1. Our enes oberve that the blood is carried from the Heart, not to the Heart by the Arteries. 2. In a rare and languihing Pule, the Artery doth not rie or wel lat in the upper part towards the Heart, but it wels there firt. 3. If an Artery be tied two fingers from the Heart, and it be o opened betwixt the Ligature and the valves, that the blood may freely pas forth, yet the valves will divers times traitly be hut, and the Heart is orderly moved.

div.p: And therefore many of the Ancients and later writers are deceived, who imagined that the blood did freely pas out of the Heart, and back again thereto. And that the valves do not naturally cloe and open, appears by a Tumor in the Arteries between the Ligature and the Heart, and the emptying of the veins near the Heart.

The firt veel is the VENA CAVA inerted into the right Ventricle, with a very large andVena Cava. gaping Orifice, three times greater then the Orifice of the Aorta, and therefore it eems rather to arie from the heart, then from the Liver, epecially eeing it ticks o firmly to the right Ventricle, that it cannot be eparated therefrom.

Whether it hath any motion is hard to determine. Aritotle and Galen eem to have been of that opinion; but the Interpreters expound thoe places to mean an obcure motion. But Walaeus hath dicovered a manifet motion therein, from the Jugulum as far as to the Liver, but mot evident near the heart: and that therefore even in that place the Vena Cava is furnihed with flehy Fibres, whereof it is detitute in other places. Alo Ent hath oberved that the vena Cava of a dead Beat, being with a mans Finger lightly touched in the Belly near the Thighs of the Beat, did expres a trembling motion.
Its Ue is, to bring in Blood from the Liver, and the whole body, by its acending and decending Trunks.
A Membranous Circle grows to the Orifice thereof, to trengthen the heart: Which is preently plit into three trong Membranous.
VALVES, termed Janitrices, Gatewarders, looking from without inwards, that the blood may indeed enter; but not return back into the Cava.

They are termed TRICUSPIDES, trebble-pointed, by the Greeks Trichlochines, Its treble pointed Valves. becaue they are like the Triangular heads of Darts, when they are hut, and fall cloe one to another.

They grow, as alo the ret of the valves do, to many hreds (in the Cava commonly each one to five remarkeable Threds, intertwited with many little ones) whereby they are joyned to that flehy particle, before explained; which ome call the Ligaments of the heart, others as Aritotle perhaps, the Nerves of the heart.

The VENA ARTERIALIS or vas Arterioum, the Arterial veins or Arterial veel.The Vena Arterioa, why called a Vein? Others call it Arteria Pulmonaris, the Lungs Artery, becaue it is in truth an Artery, both in Subtance and Ue.
Twas called a Vein firt by Herophilus and afterwards by mot other Anatomits, before the Circulation of the blood was found out, from its Office, becaue it ends blood to nourih the Lungs.

Tis termed an Artery, I. By reaon of its Subtance, which conits not of aWhy call'd an Artery? ingle Coat, as a vein doth, but of a double one. II. Becaue in a Child in the Womb it performs the Office of an Artery, and Pules as hall be aid in the next Chapter, As alo in a grown peron, becaue it carries Nutritive blood to the Lungs, which is partly wrought in the right ventricle.

This veel paes out of the heart with a maller Orifice, and yet greaterIts Original and Progres. then the Lungs tand in need of: For Columbus and Arantius oberve, that two Fingers have been thrut thereinto; and it ought to be the greater, becaue it receives blood from the continual pulation of the right ide of the heart. Moreover, reting upon the Arteria Magna and inclining to the left ide, it goes to the right and left parts of the Lungs with a double branch, a right and a left: Which afterward pend themelves into undry branches in the Lungs.

It Ue is, to receive blood out of theIts Ue. right Ventricle, and to carry it to the Lungs for their nourihment, and according to the obervations of latter Authors, to pas over the ret of the blood through the Arteria venoa into the left Ventricle of the Heart, and to hinder the blood from liding back again into the heart.

Three VALVES are placed therein,The Sigma-fahioned Valves. ariing from the Coat of the vein it elf, looking from without inwards, and reembling an half Circle, or the letter Sigma, as it was anciently figured, and did reemble the Latine letter C.
The ARTERIA VENOSA, which othersThe Arteria venoa, why an Arterie? call Vena Pulmonaria, is the third Veel of the heart, which is een in the left Ventricle.

It is termed an Artery becaue of its Office: For I. It Pules in a grown peron, becaue it is united to the left Ventricle, but it moves not by a proper motion of its own, becaue it is neither an Artery, nor doth it carry pure Arterial blood. II. It is implanted into the left Ventricle.

Tis called a VEIN, 1. Becaue of itsWhy a vein. Subtance. 2. Becaue in a Child in the Womb, it performs the office of a vein. And it is produced as it were from the Cava, to which it is joyned, by way of Anatomois. Yea and in a grown peron, it carries blood alo to the heart, as doth the Cava.

It Aries with a round and great Orifice (greater then that of the Arteria Magna) divided into two parts preently after its egres, jut in a manner as if it aroe with a twofold mouth; and it is dieminated into the right and left part of the Lungs.
The Ue.

I. In its Dilatation to draw Air toWhether Air enters into the Heart? the heart, not bare and imple Air, but mixed with the blood which returns from the Lungs, for the Generation of vital pirits and Arterial blood, and to nourih and kindle up the vital flame. For the Arteria venoa being opened in living Anatomies, doth pour blood and not pure air into the heart, which for the mot part we oberve thicker then ordinary in the Carcaes of Men and Beats, becaue the motion of the left ventricle ceaing, the blood received in this vein, cannot be driven or drawn to the heart. And when the Arteria venoa is cut or opened, there appears no air, becaue the air is not pure and imple, being mixed throughout with blood. And when the Lungs of a living or dead Creature are by Art blown up, not a jot of air is perceived to come thence to the heart, becaue the Carriage of blood is wanting, and the natural Drawer and Driver is alo wanting. But that the air uch as it is, doth come into the heart, their Examples do tetifie, who have been tifled with the ums of Quick-ilver. Coles, Lime, &c. And otherwie the Lungs and Lung-pipes were made in vain.

II. In the Contraction of the Heart to thrut out a portion of vital blood, into the Lungs, together with
ooty exhalations; which is an old opinion. But that in the Sytole of the heart, blood or ooty teams hould be carried this way. 1. The Valves hinder, which will not uffer any thing to return. 2. The Arteria venoa being tied, doth wel towards the Lungs, and is lank and emptied near the heart. 3. Being opened it pours forth blood on this ide the band, but beyond it being opened it voids neither blood nor ooty exhalations. 4. The ooty teams of the right Ventricle, do evaporate through the vena Arterioa, turn into water in the Pericardium or Heart-bag, breed the hairs in the Arm-pits, and exale into the whole habit of the Body, through the Aorta. 5. The air which goes into the heart, and the ooty teams which go out with the blood, hould be carried the ame way, in contrary motions, which is a thing unual in the natural coure oberved in the body. For though ever and anon Excrements are driven from and Nutriment is drawn to the ame part, yet the way is different, epecially where the afflux is continual, as in the Arteria venoa from the Lungs; or at leat they are performed at different times. Therefore.
III. In the contraction of the heart, it drives blood which is uperfluous after the nourihment of the Lungs, or that which runs back, out of the vena Arterioa, into the left Ventricle of the heart.

Two VALVES only are placed at the Orifice of this veel, which look fromThe Mitrehap'd Valves. without inwards (bred out of the Nervous circle which grows out of the ubtance of the heart) which being joyned together do reemble a Bihops Mitre, They are greater then the Valves of the Cava, have longer threds (and each hath even large ones, beides little ones annexed to them, which from a broad Bais do commonly end into a harp point) and for trengths ake very many flehy Explantations. Therefore two were ufficient to hut the Orifice cloe, becaue they are greater then others, the Fibres longer and larger, the Columnes or Pillars tronger, and the Orifice it elf is more Ovall-hap'd, then that of the ret.
The ARTERIA MAGNA or great Artery o called, becaue it is the root of all others,The Arteria Magna. is another veel of the left Ventricle, from whence it proceeds and aries.

At the Orifice hereof, is placed intead of a Prop, not in Men, but in certain Beats, as Harts, Oxen, Hores, &c. a certain hard ubtance, which is omtimes Gritly, omtimes Boney, according to the greatnes and Age of the Beats. In man the mot noble and tronget, Harvey aw a portion of this Artery turned into a round bone, near the Heart, whence he concludes that the Diatole of the Arteries, is caued by the blood alone, not by any Pulifick faculty, derived through the Membranes. Alo Johannes Schroderus writes that the meeting together of the Arteries in the Bais of the Heart, was in an heart degenerated into a bone.

The Ue thereof is, to communicate the Vital pirit, with the Nutritive ArterialIts Ue. blood, received from the heart, unto all parts of the Body, for Nutrition and life; which that it may not pas back again into the heart, Three Valves are placed (like thoe in the vena Arterioa exactly hut) looking fromIts Valves. without inwards, which are termed Sigmiodes or Sigma-hap'd Valves.

div.head: Chap. VIII. How the Veels are united in the Heart of a Child in the Womb.
div.p: THe Veels in the heart are otherwieIn the Child in the Womb. dipoed when the Child is in the Womb, then they are after it is born; which though Galen knew and made mention thereof; yet the greatet part of Anatomits have either neglected the ame, or have delivered falities thereabout, by aying that the Unions of the veels were ome of them only made by a Chanel, others only by way of Anatomois.
But the Conjunctions or UNIONSThe Union of the Veels of the Heart. of the VESSELS of the Heart in a Child in the Womb, are twofold:
One is made by an Anatomois, another by a Chanel.

By Anatomois an Union is made of the Vena Cava and the Arteria Venoa, under the right Earlet, near the Coronaria, before the Cava doth abolutely open it elf into the right Ventricle. The hole is large and of an Oval Figure.
Now Nature contrived this Union by way of Anatomois, 1. By reaon of Vicinity. 2. Becaue of the likenes of ubtances.
Before this hole in the Cavity of Arteria venoa is placed a Pendulous, thin, hard, little Membrane, larger then the hole.

Its Ue is, I. According to the DoctrinIts various Ues. of Galen and his Clients, that the blood may be carried through this hole, out of the Cava into the Arteria venoa (not into the right ventricle, for vital pirit is not yet bred, nor do the Lungs need blood o attenuated) to nourih the Lungs; becaue they could not otherwie be nourihed in a Child in the Womb, becaue in it the heart hath no motion whereby the blood might be forced out of the right ventricle into the vena Arterioa: And therefore this Arteria venoa, is a vein in the Child in the Womb. But that it erves the turn of the Heart, and not only to nourih the Lungs, divers things Evince oberved by the favorers of the Circular Motion. For 1. The Heart is moved even in an imperfect Child, after the third moneth, as Egs and Embryo's do tetifie. But before the third moneth only a little Bladder of the Earlet pants, as in Inects before the Heart is perfectly hollowed. But this motion were in vain, if the Heart hould not receive or expel any thing. 2. The blood by the Anatomois is immediately poured into the left Ear, and is necearily thence conveighed by the Sytole of the Heart, into the left ventricle. 3. All the blood is carried through thee Unions, doubtles not for the ake of the Lungs alone, which might be nourihed after the ame manner as in grown perons, although void of motion, the veins in part gaping. 4. The Child in the Womb is nourihed with Arterial blood, which can come from no place but the Heart, as hall be demontrated hereafter. Therefore,

II. The true ue is, that it might conveigh part of the blood in a Child in the Womb, out of the Cava of the Liver, into the left ventricle of the Heart, which cannot go thither the ordinary way, the Lungs neither dilating themelves nor Repireing. In which paage the right ventricle alo draws omwhat to it elf
And that the blood may not lide back into the Cava, a little MembraneThe ue of the little Membrane. there placed hinders, when it fals in and ettles.

A little while after the Birth this'Tis hut after the Birth. Hole grows together and is dried up, o that a man would think the place had never been perforated, and that by reaon of the plenty of blood in a grown peron, forced out of the Lungs now opened and inlarged directly to the left Earlet, which uffers not a mal quantity of blood to flow out of the Anatomois, whereupon being hut it grows together. Howbeit in grown perons, it remains for a eaon open. Pinaeus oberved it thrice, Riolanus once, and my elf more then once. Botallus mot frequently in Calves, Sows. Dogs of a large ize, and therefore he would have it to be alwaies and naturally open, that blood might pas this way out of the right to the left Ventricle. Caecilius Folius treading in his Foot-teps, thinks it is open in all Men, to the ame end, as in a Child in the Womb, but contrary to experience. For it is then only open, when Nature hath hut up other paages, as I aw at Padua in that old Man, whoe Arteria venoa was topped with Flegm. In Water-fowl and other Animals that live in the Water, as Ducks, Cators, Swans, Bitturns, &c. it is alwaies open, becaue they live now and then in the Water, without the Ue of their Lungs. And I have omtimes oberved in dead bodies the little Membrane winking, and receiving the Probe without any violence, but I cannot allow that it is o alwaies. And that light opening would be unprofitable. For the paage of o much blood.
Another Union is by a longih Channel,By a Chanel or Pipe. viz. that of the vena Arterialis, and the Arteria Magna, becaue they are ditant one from another.

This Union is without the Heart (the other within the ame) two Fingers from the Bais, in grown perons four, for the Channel doth not begin from the tock of the Arteria Magna. It goes obliquely to the Arterioa (therefore no valve is annexed to it becaue the crookednes was able to hinder the Egres) [or rather becaue the blood is forced thither, from the right ventricle of the Heart through the vena Arterioa but it is not in like manner driven back out of the left,
