by the Arteria venoa] where it is divided into two, as if it had three parts; the leat whereof notwithtanding is the Channel.

In Infants of three or four years old, it is til to be een, but without any throughpaage:Which is dried up. in grown perons tis by little and little attenuated and dried, being dititute of all Nutriment, becaue no Humors pas any longer through the ame, until through abence of Life and Nourihment, it Putrifies and Conumes quite away.

The ue thereof is, I. According to the Mind of Galen, that the vital Spirit being receivedIts ue. from the Navil-Arteries into the Arteria Magna, may from hence be carried, through that Channel into the vena Arterioa and o traight into the Lungs, to maintain Life. But, 1. It erves not the Lungs alone. 2. The Navil-Arteries do bring out of the Arteria Magna, but carry nothing thereinto. 3. The Pipe is greater then to erve only to carry Spirits. 4. The Lungs of a Child in the Womb being red, are not nourihed only with Spirits.
II. According to Petrejus and Hofmannus, to bring Arterial blood to nourih the Lungs. Who had aid well, if they had not omitted the good of the whole body.

III. According to late Writers, that the blood which lides out of the upper Trunk of Cava into the right ventricle may pas through this Pipe, the greatet part thereof indeed to the Aorta, that o with the ret it may nourih and enliven the whole body of the Embryo; but the leat portion of all goes up to the Lungs by the ordinary way.

Both the ventricles in the Child perform one and the ame thing, and part the blood which is to be carried, becaue the more perfect blood is upplied by the Mother, and therefore the Walls are a like thick. And the two ventricles in the Child which doth not repire, perform the ame, which in imperfect Animals void of Lungs, is accomplihed by one ventricle.

This Pipe therefore aits the Anatomois in tranporting the blood of the Heart, becaue either of the waies would otherwie be two narrow. For I have oberved in a Girle new Borne, by me publickly diected, that the Pipe was wanting, becaue the Anatomois was larger then ordinary: and there is reaon for it. The Lungs mut be nourihed and the whole body mut be nourihed. Which can never be effected, unles the Arterial Blood be ditributed out of the Aorta. It comes not from the Mother through the Iliack Arteries, becaue they are not joyned to the Arteries of the Womb, beides their motion is contrary, as the binding of the Navil Arteries doth hew. For the Navil-Arteries derived from the Child, do wel towards the Heart thereof, and towards the Placenta or Womb-cake they are empty; for the Arterial blood in the Child after it is nourihed, runs back through the Iliack veins to the Placenta, as a part of the Child which mut be nourihed, out of which it paes again into the Navil-veins, and is mixed with that other blood which comes out of the veins of the Womb, and runs joyntly back again to the Liver and Heart of the Child, that the Circulation may be repeated. Now it flows conveniently out of this vena Arterioa through the Pipe or Channel into the Aorta, by reaon of its Situation downwards, and its crooked inertion into the Aorta. Therefore eeing the Arterial blood, is not carried fr •• the Mother, upwards to the Heart, neither can the Lungs be nourihed thereby.

div.head: Chap. IX. Touching the Lungs.
div.p: THe Lungs called i • Latin Pulmones The Reaon of their Name. in Greek Pneumoe • 's or Pleumones, have their name from Repiration or drawing in and blowing out the Air: becaue they are given to Animals living in their Air and breathing, but not to fihes which have neither Neck nor Voice.
They are eated in the Cavity of theTheir Situation. Breat or Chet, which they fil, when they are ditended.

They are divided into the right andDiviion. left part by means of the Mediatinum: that one part being hurt, the other mayInto Lobes. yet perform the Office. Each of thee parts is divided into two Lobes, Laps or Scollups, about the fourth Vertebra of the Chet, of which the upper is horter then the lower; eldom is one part divided into three Lobes, as in Brutes; becaue a man goes bolt upright, Brutes looking downwards nor by reaon of the hortnes of the Chet, could any thing lie between the Heart and the Liver, except the Midrif. Yet oftentimes Piccolhomineus, Riolanus and my elf, have after Hippocrates and Ruus Epheius oberved three. Now the Lungs embrace the Heart with their Scollups as with certain Fingers.
Their hape reembles that of anTheir Figure. Ox-hoofe. On the outide towards the Cavity of the Chet, the Lungs are Boie or bunching out, on the inide they are hollow, where they embrace the Heart.

Their Colour in the Child is red likeTheir Colour. that of the Liver: by reaon of the nourihment is receives from its Mother; in grown perons tis yellowih Pale; omtime Ah-color'd: in uch as have died of a long icknes blackih. In ome perons healthy enough. I have een them Party colored, like Marble. In that part where it is knit unto the Chet by Fibres, tis red, as in a Child in the Womb.

Tis Knit in the Fore-part to the BretboneConnexion. by the Mediatinum, behind to the Vertebra's; omtimes the Lungs at the ides grow to the Pleura by certain Fibrous bands, whence aries a lating hortnes of Breath. Now this Connexion doth frequently deceive Phyitians, nor knowing or dicerning Penetrating wounds of the Chet. Nicolas Maa conceives this Connexion profitable to the Heart, leat it hould be oppreed with the bulk of the Lungs, or the facility or breathing hould be hindred, and Riolanus aies he evermore found this a •• eion. I have cheifly oberved it about the lower Ribs. near the Diaphragma, leat they hould pres and bear upon it. Others ay the Lungs are bound to Fibres, that in the wounds of the Chet, they might follow the motion of the Chet, though with a weaker motion. Hippocrates in his econd Book de Morbis calls it the Lungs liptA certain Caue of long lating Short-windednes. down to the ide; and this comes to pas either from ones Birth, or after a Pleuriie, or by reaon of Tenacious and clammy flegm interpoing it elf; o • from ome external caue, as negligent
Curing of a wounded or uppurated Chet. Alo the Lungs cleave to the Heart, by the Vena arterioa and the Arteria venoa.

The Subtance in a Child in the Womb is compact and thick; o thatThe Subtance. being cat into Water it inks, which the Lungs of grown perons will not do. But after the Birth, becaue it begins to be moved with the Heart, by heat and motion the Heart becomes light and oft, lax, rare and pungy; o that the Lungs will be eaily raied and fall again, and eaily receive the Air: Which may be een by the ue of a Pare of bellows in dead bodies. Helmont hath een the Lungs hard and toney, in an Athmatical peron, and Salmuth oberves that little tones have been there generated in hortnes of Breath. Alo touching tones we have the Tetimony of Galen, Trallianus, Aegineta.

The Lungs are compaed with a thin light Membrane, furniht with manyMembrane. Pores which Pores are ufficiently viible, when the Lungs are blown up with a pair of bellows, and Job. Walaeus hath oberved the aid Pores in live Anatomies, as big as a large Peae. This way the Sanies or Corrupt matter of the Chet may Penetrate and come away by Coughing. This Membrane is produced from the encompaing Pleura. For when the Veels enter into the Lungs, they devet themelves of their Coat, which grows out of the Pleura, which doth afterwards invet the Lungs.

The Veels. The Subtance of the Lungs is interwoven with three orts ofThe Veels. Veels, which make not a little alo for trength. Two proceed from the Heart, of which before: The Vena Arterialis and Arteria Venalis.
The third is proper, viz. The Trachea or Apera arteria o called, of which in the following Chapter.

If thee Veels be fretted aunder as in perons Phciical, or having the Conumption of the Lungs, many times plenty of blood is cat forth, or ome Cartilaginous ubtance; yea and the Veels themelves of the Lungs intire, which I have een, and Tulpius hath two examples. And oftentimes perons in a Conumption die uddenly, becaue the greater Veels being fretted aunder, the Heart is trangled with blood iuing there from.

Thee Veels of the Lungs are great, not o much becaue they wantedWhy the Lungs • at • o great Veels? much blood, for their ubtance is very mal, etting aide the Veels, nor needed they o much blood as is ufficient to nourih the whole body; but they are great, becaue the greatet portion of the blood is carryed this way out of the right Ventricle of the Heart into the left by thoe wide paages, for the more ubtile blood can find its way through the obcure Pores of the Septum. This paage is proved.

list.item: 1. By the greatnes of the veels. For the vena arterioa and the arteria venoa are mot large. And becaue the former is a veel which carries out of the Heart, it is furnihed with the Mitre-fahion'd valves, which hinder the blood from paing out of the Lungs the ame way; and the latter bringing blood out of the Lungs into the Heart, has the treble-pointed valves, hindring the blood from returning.

2. Great Quantity of Blood is continually ent by the Pule of the Heart, through the vena arterioa and thence through the arteria venoa unto the left ventricle, which is further confirmed by Ocular Inpection.

3. By Ligatures in living Anatomies. For the Vena arterioa wels towards theSee Tab. 4. of Book 2. Heart; but near the Lungs it is empty; the Arteria venoa contrarywie, wels towards the Lungs, but is empty towards the Heart.

4. The left Ventricle of the Heart being wounded, or the Arteria aorta, great plenty of blood will iue, as long as life remains, till all the blood in the body be run out. And from what other place can it come, eeing o much is not contained in the Heart, but out of the Lungs through the Arteria venoa, which had drawn the Blood out of the Vena arterioa by the Anatomoes.
5. In the Arteria venoa as well of a living as a dead Body, o much Blood is found, that it hath often hindred me in my publick Diections.

6. By the imilitude of the Veels one with another. The Vena arterioa carrying out of the Heart into the Lungs, is jut like the Aorta in ubtance, largenes, neighbourhood, and Valves. The Arteria venoa doth in like manner reemble the Vena cava by traitnes of Connexion, ubtance of a Vein, Earlets and treble-pointed Valves.

div.p: This Circulation through the LungsHow Circulation is caued in the Lungs. is furthered, 1. By the widening of the Lungs when Air i • drawn in, which being every where filled, the veels are ditended, as when they ceae, the motion of the Blood is either retarded, or quite ceaes. 2. By the Situation of the veels of the Lungs. The Vena arterioa is Dieminated in the hinder or Convex part of the Lungs, becaue it is trongly moved by the Pule of the Heart, the Arteria venoa doth cheifly poes the foremore and hollow part, that the Blood might more readily lide into the Heart. In the Middet of which the Branches of the Wind-pipe are eated, that in the blowing out of the Air, they might receive ooty Exhalations from the Vena arterioa, and in drawing the Air in, they might communicate the ame to the Arteria venoa. 3. The anatomoes, by which the veels are joyned together, both the branches which joyn mouth to mouth (though in dead bodies they cannot be dicerned by the Eye-ight) and the Pores of the Parenchyma which is light and Porous.
It is to be noted for the anweringContrary objections anwered. the objections made againt this Circulation.
1. That the Lungs are not oppreed or burthened o long as they being ound, the Blood perpetually glides through by Peice-meal.

2. That the blood doth not drop out through the Pipes of the Weand, becaue partly they draw in only Air or ooty Exhalations, and in no wie Blood of a thicker nature then they, unles they be preternaturally fretted in perons that have the Conumption, partly becaue nature never ceaes to drive found humors through the paages ordained for them, and retains what is neceary, which would otherwie go out at the paages of the Body being opened.

3. Although the Lungs of Dead bodies are whitih, yet the veels do manifetly tranpire through the external Coat. The Parenchyma it elf is frequently ful, in perons trangled with blood, in others it is found emptied, becaue in the Pangs of Death it is forcibly excluded.

4. In burning Feavers, both the Lungs are hot, and thereupon the voice is Hoare and dry, and they are oppreed, as appeared in the Epidemical Feaver
which raged up and down this year, by which many were trangled.
5. It is no good judging of the healthy tate of the Body, from the preternatural tate thereof.

Very mal Nervulets from the ixth Pare are pred only through the MembraneWhy Ulcers of the Lungs are without pain. thereof (which if it be inflamed, a pain will be felt, and communicated to the ide it elf and to the Back) not through the ubtance of the Lungs, leat by Reaon of their continual motion they hould be pained. Hence the Ulcers of the Lungs are without pain. Howbeit Riolanus allots very many Nerves to the ubtance of the Lungs alo, drawn from the Implication and Contexture of the Stomach Nerves. I alo have een many pred abroad within the Lungs, proceeding from the ixt Pare, and alwaies in a manner accompanying the Bronchia or Lung-pipes, derived from the hinder part, and only a little twig conveig'd to the Membrane from the forepart.

What the Action of the Lungs is, Authors Quetion. That they never move at all is Helmonts Paradox, but erve only as a eive, that the Air may pas pure into the Chet, and that the Mucles of the Belly alone do uffice for Repiration. But that they are indeed and in truthWhence the motion of the Lungs proceeds. moved, the cutting up of live bodies hews, and Wounds of the Chet, that they move long and trongly. Moreover that they may be moved, any one may try with a pair of Bellows. Finally, They ought to be moved, for otherwie both the Heart would • e uffocated, and the motion of the blood in the Lungs, would be hindred. The Mucles of the Belly do indeed concur, but econdarily, becaue they are not joyned to the Heart, and when they are moved Repiration may be topped, Yea, and when they are cut off in a living Anatomy, the Lungs are moved nevertheles. But whether they are moved by their own proper force, or by ome other thing, is a further Quetion. Averrhoes who is followed among the late writers by John Daniel Hortius, conceives the Lungs are moved by their own proper force, not following the motion of the Chet, for otherwie aies he we mut grant that a violent motion may be perpetual.

But we are to hold, that though the Lungs are the Veel of Repiration, yet they are o not by doing, but by uffering. For they have no motive force of their own, as Averrhoes will have it (becaue at our pleaure we can top our breathing, or quicken or retard the ame) nor do they receive the principle of their motion from the Heart, or from the blood raiing them, as Aritole conceives, and his followers, For 1. The efflux of the bloodAritotles Error. out of the Heart, is made by the orninary motion, but the Repiration is voluntary. 2. The Caue of the Pule and Repiration would be one and the ame, and they would be performed at one and the ame time. But thirty Pules anwer one Repiration. 3. While we draw in our Breath trongly, and hold the air drawn in for a eaon, the welling of the Lungs hould compel us to let our breath go, becaue it lifts up the Chet, according to their opinion. 4. The Blood of the Heart doth not abide in the Lungs by an unequal retention, o as to ditend them, but it is forthwith expelled according to nature. 5. When it tarries longet in dieaed Lungs, it makes hortnes of Breath or difficulty in breathing, but no Tumor. 6. In a trong Apoplexy, the motion of the Lungs ceaes, the Pule being afe and the Heart unhurt.

Nor are the Lungs raied up, by theThe Opinion of Falcoburgius. air forced in, which when the Chet is lifted up, becaue it hath no other pace whither it can go to, it is carried through the Apera arteria or Weand into the Lungs, as Falcoburgius and Des Cartes conceive, and Hogelandius, Regius, and Prataeus who follow him: For 1. The air may eaily be condened, as may be proved by a thouand experiments, as by Cupping-glaes, Weather-glaes, Whips, Trumpets, Winds and infinite things beide; and therefore it may be mot traitly compacted about the Chet, and compreed within it elf, as well by the internal ubtile nature of the air and dipered by Atomes, eaily recollected one within another, as by the external impule of the Chet, whereby it may more eaily be condened, then driven into another place. 2, By the motion of the Chet or uch a like body, we do not ee the lightet thing that is, Agitated. By an hole in a Wall all Chinks and Dores being cloely topped, our Notrils being topped, we may with our Mouthes draw air out of the next Chamber, to which it is not credible that the air moved by the Chet, can reach with a trong motion; and though air may penetrate into the Chamber, through ome chinks and Rifts, yet is it not in o great quantity, as to tretch the Chet o much as it ought to be tretched, in free Repiration. The ame experiment may be made in a Glas or Silver veel applied cloe to ones Mouth. 4. While I have held my Breath, I have oberved my Belly to be moved above twenty times the while. But whether is the Air then driven? Mut it not needs be, becaue all places are ful of bodies, that the air next the Belly is compreed and condened? See more of this ubject in my Vindiciae Anatomicae, and in a peculiar Dicoure.
Therefore the Lungs do only follow the motion of the Chet to avoid Vacuum: And therefore only they receive the air drawn in, becaue the Chet by widening it elf, fils the Lungs with air.

Now that the Motion of the LungsThe motion of the Lungs is proved to arie from the Chet. aries from the Chet experience hews. For 1. If air enter into the Chet, being peirced through with a Wound, the Lungs remain immoveable, becaue they cannot follow the widening of the Chet, the air ininuating it elf through the wound, into the empty pace. But the Chet being ound, the Lungs follow the widening thereof, to avoid Vacuum; as in Pipes, Water is drawn upwards, and Quittor, Bullets, Darts and other hard things are drawn out of body through the avoidance of Vacuum. 2. If the Midriff of a live Creature be peirced through with a light wound, Repiration is topped, the Chet falling in.

But omwhat there is which hindersAn Obervation in live Anatomies. many worthy men from aenting to this caue of the Lungs motion, becaue after the Chet is perfectly opened, the Lungs are oftentimes moved along time, with a vehement motion. But according to the Obervation of Johannes Walaeus, Francicus Sylvius, and Francicus Vander Shagen, that is not the motion of Contriction and Dilatation, which is the natural motion of the Lungs; but it is the motion of an whole Lobe upwards and downwards, which motion happens, becaue the Lungs are faten'd to the Mediatinum, the Mediatinum to the Midriff, and the Lungs are alo
eated near the Midriff: whence it happens, while the Creature continues yet trong, that either the Lungs with the Mediatinum are drawn, or by the Midriff driven, the Diaphragma or Midriff, not yet falling down nor looing its motion, which I oberve in contradiction to the mot learned Son of Hortius. Now that this motion proceeds not from the inbred force of the Lungs, doth hence appear, in that alwaies when the Chet is depreed, the Lungs are lifted up, being forced by the Midriff, which at that time ries a good height into the Chet; and contrarywie the Chet being lifted up, the Lungs are depreed. And becaue the Lungs are the Intrument of Repiration, Hence it hath thee following,

list.item: I. According to Plato, Galen, and Abeninae, to be a oft Pillow and CuhionIts Ue. under the Heart.

II. According to others who follow Columbus to prepare and wellnigh generate the vital Spirits (which are afterwards to receive their perfection in the heart) whiles in them the blood is as it were Circulated, firt boyling with the heat of the Heart, and afterwards ettled by the coldnes of the air.
III. It hath more proper ues when it is Dilated, and when it is contracted.

div.p: When the Lungs are Dilated, they receive in the Air like a pair of Bellows through the Branches of the Wind-pipe.

I. To prepare Aire for the Heart, for the convenient nourihment of theAll kind of Air is not a friend to mans Spirit. lightful Spirit. For every quality of the Aire is not a friend to our Spirit, as is een in uch, as are kild with the moak of Charcole, and the team of newly whited Walls.

Helmont conceives that the Air is united to the pirit of the Heart, and that it receives a fermentation in the Heart, which accompanying the ame they do both dipoe the Blood to a total tranpiration of it elf, which is the reaon why in the extremity of cold weather and at Sea, we eat more heartily, becaue the thinnes of the Air dipoes the blood to inenible tranpiration. Backius is omwhat of the ame mind, who conceives that by the moit and thin body of the Air, the blood is made apt to run, o as that it may be diffued into the mallet paages of the Body. Others acribe both thee effects to the abundance of Seroity in the Blood. Therefore Hippocrates aies that water is hungry; and we ee that uch as are given to drink, are enclined to weat much, as alo Scorbutick perons.

II. To fan and cool the heat. For we ee that the heat of our Bodies tands inOur heat doth want a Cooler. need of omwhat that is cold, without which it is extinguihed, as is apparent in uch as tay long in very hot Baths, as the flame of a Candle in a cloe place, wanting Air goes out. AndWhy Fihes need no Lungs. therefore the Lungs are called the Fan and cooler of the Heart, and the Fihes in the Water and other Animals that have but on Ventricle in their Hearts, are without Lungs, becaue they do not want uch a cooling. As alo Infants in theThe Lungs of Children in the Womb move not. Womb, being fanned by their Mother, and the wide Anatomoes, have their Lungs without motion. Hence it is that having een only the Lungs, you may judg how hot any Creature is; for Nature makes the Lungs the larger, by how much the Heart is hotter. Therefore the Lungs are not abolutely neceary to Life, but erve to accommodate the Heart. For intead of Lungs a boy of Amterdam four years old, had a little Bladder ful of a Membranous wind, as Nicolas Fontanus a Phyitian of that Citty doth tetifie, which being guarded with very mal Veins, had its original from the Apera Arteria or Weand it elf, whoe office it is to cool the Heart. Who nevertheles died of a Conumption, becaue haply, his Heart was not furnihed with a ufficient quantity of Air.

When the Lungs are contracted in Expiration, they do again afford us a twofold ue. I. Sooty Excrements do pas away through the ame, being carried out of the Heart with the blood, through the Vena Arterioa. II. To make an articulate voice in Men, and an inarticulate ound in Beats, by affording Air to frame the voice. And therefore Creatures that have no Lungs, are mute, according to Aritotle.

div.head: Chap. X. Of the Lung-Pipe or Weand.
div.p: THe Pipe or Channel of the Lungs,The Weand. is by the Ancients called Arteria, becaue it contains Air: Galen and others Why call'd Trachea or Apera Arteria? call it Trachea arteria or the rough Artery, becaue of its unevennes, and to difference it from the mooth Arteries. Lactantius terms it Spiritualis Fitula, the Spirit or Air-Pipe, becaue the Air is breathed in and out thereby, Now it is a Pipe or Channel entring into the lower part of the Lungs, with many branches, which are by Hippocrates termed Syringae and Aortae, whoe head is termed Larynx, of which in the following Chapter; the ret of its Body is termed Bronchus, becaue it is moitened with drink. For that ome part of the drink doth pas even into the Wind-pipe andWhether any part of our drink doth pas into the Weand and Lungs. Lungs, Hippocrates doth rightly prove by an Hog new kild, in whoe Lungs matter is found jut o colored as the the drink was, which he drunk immediately before he was killed. And that ome drink may be carried through the Wind-pipe, may be proved out of Julius Jaolinus an Anatomit of Naples, who eeking in the body of a Noble peron, the Caue of his death, found his Pericardium or Heart-bag, o ditended with Humor, that it being queezed, ome of the aid Humor came out at his mouth.

As to its Situation: in Man-kind itIts Situation in Man-kind. rets upon the Gullet, for it goes down from the mouth traight along to the Lungs: and at the fourth Vertebra of the Chet, it is divided into two branches, each of which goes into the Lungs of its repective ide: they are again ubdivided into two other branches, and thee again into others till at lat they end into very mal twigs in the urface of the Lungs. But the branches thereof which are greater then the ret of the Veels of the Lungs, entring into the Lungs, do go through the middle thereof, between the Vena Arterioa which is hindermore, and the Arteria venoa which is before it: with which it is joyned by obcure Anatomoes, or conjunctions of Mouths, hardly dicernable by our Eyeight.

In Bruits tis Situate much after the ameIn a Swan.
manner. Yet we mut note that it is different in a Swan, and after a manner altogether ingular. For being longer, it ininuates it elf by a crooked winding into a cae of the Breat-bone, and oon after from the bottom of the cae, it returns upwards, and having mounted the Channel-bones, it bends it elf towards the Chet. But before it reaches the Lungs, tis propped by a certain boney Pipe, broad above, narrow beneath, which in a Duck is round, then it is divided into two branches, which wel in the middle, but grow maller where they tend to the Lungs, till they enter into them.
'Tis cloathed with a double Membrane: one External, another Internal. Its Membranes.
The External is a thin one ariing from the Pleura, and ticks cloe to the intermediate Lingaments of the Gritles, and Uhers along the recurrent Nerves.

The Internal being furnihed with traight Fibres is thicker and more olid (mot of all in the Larynx, leat of all in the branches of the Lungs, indifferently in the middle Pipe) to the end it may not eaily be hurt by Acrimonious drinks, or other Liquors voided by Coughing, or falling down from the Head.
It aries from the Coat which compaes the Palate, and therefore is continued with the Mouth.

It is meared with a fat Humor to hinder its being dried up by motions, loud cryings, drawing in of hot Air, going out of harp ooty Exhalations, &c. And by the SuperaboundanceThe Voice hurt. or Deficiency hereof the Voice is hurt. For in the former contracted by Ditillations, it becomes Hoare; in the latter through burning Feavers, &c. It becomes quea • ing. If it overabound, we are quite Dumb and unable to peak, and the moiture being conumed our Speech returns again: which might happen in that ame dumb Son of Craeus mentioned by Herodotus, and in Aegle a Samian wratler, mentioned by Valerius Maximus, and Zacharias Orphanus a Fool, of whom Nicolas Fontanus tels a tory in his Obervations.
This Coat is of exquiite ene, that it may raie it elf to expel what ever is trouble-ome thereunto.
Between thee two Membranes is the proper ubtance of the Trachea arteria, which is partly of the nature of a Gritle, and partly of a Ligament.

list.item: I. For the Voices ake: becaue that which makes a ound mut be olid.Why the Wefand is in part Gritly?
II. Otherwie by reaon of its oftnes it would alwaies fall together, and would not eaily be opened in Repiration.

div.p: It was to be partly Ligamental, and not wholly of a Gritly ubtance: for if itWhy in part Ligamental. hould conit of one only Gritle, or many circular ones,

list.item: I. It would be evermore open, and not omtimes widen and then fall together.

II. It would bear hard upon the Gullet, to which nevertheles, it ought to give way, epecially in the wallowing down of olid meats, that the Throat or Gullet might be ufficiently widned. And o the Gritles help to frame the Voice; and the Membranous Ligaments for Repiration.

div.p: The Gritles are many, round like Rings, but not exactly. For on their backide, where they touch the Gullet, a fourth part of a circle is wanting, in place whereof there is a Membranous ubtance.

From their hape they are termed Sigma-hap'd reembling the old Greek letter C, til they are fixed in the Lungs, for then changing their Fignre, they change their name. For the Wind-Pipes do there conit of perfect Gritles, Round, four quare, or Triangular, but where they are joyned to the ret of the Veels of the Lungs they become Membranous.

Thee Gritles are joyned together by Ligaments going between, which in Men are more flehy, in brute Beats more Membranous; and in men the hew like little Mucles. And the Gritles do every where keep an equal di •… n from another, and the higher, the •… ey • hey are.

It hath Veels
•• mmon wi •• others. Veins from the the external Jugulars; Arteries from the Carotides; Nerves, from the Recurrent Nerves of the ixth pair.

Its Ue is, I. In drawing in the Air, that by it as a Pipe, the Air may be receivedThe Ue of the Weand. from the Lungs, as from a pair of Bellows. Hence comes that ame Wheezing in uch as have the Tiick, the Pipes of the Weand being topped, o that the Air coming and going and not finding a free paage makes that Hiing noie.

II. In blowing the Air out, I. That through it Fuliginous Excrements may be voided at the Mouth and Notrils. For which intent the mouths of the Vena arterioa do o artificially joyn with the Mouths of the Apera arteria, that there is paage only for ooty teams but not for blood, unles it come away by force and violent Coughing. In the next place, that it may help to form the voice, which it doth by expiration likewie, though ome Juglers frame their Voice by inpiration only or drawing in of their Breath. And therefore Hippocrates calls it the breathing and vocal Organ. A wonder therefore it is that ome Men can live long in the Water like Fihes, by Nature and not by Art, if Cardan is to be believed in the econd Book de Subtilitate, when he makes relation of one Calanus a Diver in Sicily, who would lie three or four hours under the Water. And how in the Wet-indies everywhere, uch as dive for Pearloyters, will lie an hour together under the Water. If they did this by ome art, it were not o wonderful. So the Aegyptians are mot perfect divers, and exercie Robberies that way. For as appears by the Decription of Nicolus Chritophori Radzivilij his journey to Hierualem, they lie lurking under the Waters, and not being content to teal on land, what ever they can catch they draw into the water, and carry it away: and frequently they catch a man as he lies upon a Ships deck draw him under the water and kill and trip him of his cloathes: So that uch as ail are aid many times to watch all night armed, And in the ame parts, aboundance of fiher men will dive under the water and catch fih with their hands, and they will come up with a fih in cach Hand and a third in their mouths. Thee perons doubtles, do either live only by Tranpiration, as uch do that have fits of the Apoplexy and the Mother; or they have Anatomoes open in their Hearts, by means of which as in the Womb, the blood is freely moved without any motion of the Lungs.

div.head: Chap. XI. Of the Larynx.
div.p: THe Head or beginning of thisThe Larynx. Lung-Pipe, is termed LARYNX, which is the voices Organ.
Tis Situate in the Neck, and that inIts Situation. the middle thereof, for it is
In Number one, that there may be onlyNumber. one voice.

Its Figure is round and almot circular;Shape. becaue it was to be hollow for the voices ake; but on the foreide it is more Extuberant, on the hinder ide depreed, that it may give way to the Gullet, epecially in the time of wallowing, in which while the Oeophagus is depreed, the Larynx runs back upwards, and o aits the wallowing, both by giving way and bearing down that which is to be wallowed.

Its Magnitude varies according toMagnitude. the Ages of perons. For in younger perons the Larynx is trait whichHow the voice becomes hril, or big? makes their voice hril: in grown perons tis wider, and therefore their voice is bigger. To which alo the length or hortnes of the Larynx doth contribute: and if plenty of Air or Spirit be drawn and expelled, the Voice becomes big; if little, it becomes mal.

And therefore according to Galen there are two caues of a great Voice:What the Caues are of a great Voice? the Largenes of the Apera arteria, and the trong blowing out of the air, and Hippocrates aies both thee are caued by great hear. And thereforeHow the Voice comes to change. in his Book of the Seed, he teaches us that the tones do contribute to the formation of the Voice, Hence Males when they grow of ripe years change their voice. A Guelded Hore looes his neighing. A Capon leaves his crowing or crows after a weaker fahion, different from his former crowing.
The Parts of the Larynx or about the Larynx: are Gritles, Mucles, Membranes, Veels and Kernels.

Its Mucles do firt of all offer themelves, which move the Gritles, whichIts Mucles. the Larynx is poet of, that it may be moved with a voluntary motion, eeing we utter our Speech, as we pleae our elves.
Now the Mucles of a Mans Larynx, are but thirteen, four common and nine proper: though ome make twenty, other eighteen, others fourteen.

div.p: The Common are thoe which are implanted into the Larynx, and yetThe Common. do not arie therefrom.
The Proper have both their originalThe Proper. and termination in the Larynx.

The firt pair of the common, called by the Ancient Sternothyroides, being lower more, aries within from the Breat-bone, its original being broad and flehy, and going a long by the Wezand, it is inerted beneath into the ides of the Sheild-fahion'd Gritle.
Its Ue is to traiten the Chink of the Larynx, by drawing down the Scutiformis.

The econd Pair called Hyothyroides, being the uppermore, aries from the lower ide of the Os hyoides, being broad and flehy, and touches the Scutiformis, being implanted into the Bais of the aid Scutiformis.
Its Ue is to widen the Chink, by lifting up the Scutiformis,
Spigelius and Vetingius aign contrary offices to thee: for they will have the firt pair to widen and the econd to traiten the Chink of the Larynx.
Others do here add a third pair, which Columbus nevertheles and Caerius do account but one Mucle.
But this is rather Muculus Deglutitorius, or a Swallowing mucle, becaue ariing from the Scutiformis tis wrapped about the Gullet.
It is judged, by contracting the ides of the Scutiformis, to traiten the Chink: but it is no Servant to the Larynx unles by accident.

The firt proper Pair, aries on the foreide, from the lowet part of theThe Proper. Scutiformis, as the Inertion of the Nerves doth hew, and ends at the Annularis. And therefore this pair may be termed Thyrocricoides; but not, as mot Anatomits will have it, Cricothyroides. Some will have it to arie from the fore-ide of the Cricoides, and to end into the lowet ide of the Scutiformis. If it be broad and pred out ide-waies, it may be divided into two pair, the foremore and the ide pair, and o Riolanus divides it. But it is for the mot part ingle and mal enough.

Its Ue is to draw the Cartilago Annularis to the Scutiformis. (lightly, becaue it is almot immoveable) o that they may be joyned together, and kept in that poture. Others who differ about its original, will have it to widen the Chink or the Scutiformis.

The econd Pair ries from the back ide of the Annularis, with a flehy orignal, and is implanted into the lower part of the Glottalis or Arytaenoides, with a Nervous end, opening the Larynx, by drawing aunder the two Gritles called Arytaenoides. And therefore they are called Par Cricoarythenoides poticum. Caerius cals them Par Cucullare.

The third pair, Cricoarythenoides laterale, aries above from the ides of the Annularis, and is inerted at the ides of the Glottalis, into the joynt, there where it is not touched by the former, and opens the Larynx, with the ame oblique carriage of the Gritles.

The fourth pair, called Thyroarytenoides, being inward and very broad, proceeds from the Scutiformis, viz. from its inner and fore part, and from the Cricoides likewie, as Riolanus upects, and ends into the ides of the Glottalis, or the Arytaenoides, which while it contracts and draws to the Thyroides, it huts the Larynx, by a traight paage. When this pair is inflamed in a Sq •… ie, it makes the Dieae deadly, becaue it exactly hurs the Chink.

The ninth Mucle, which others term Quintum par Arytenoides, aries from the hinder line of the Guttalis, and being carried along with tranvere Fibres, it is inerted into the ides thereof, hutting the Larynx, while it traitens the Cartilago Arytaenoides.

For it is to be noted, that all the proper Mucles of the Larynx, are ordained either to contract or widen the Chink, which that it may be the more conveniently accomplihed, ome of them widen and traiten the Thyroides, others the Arytaenoides, which Gritles do compas the Chink, which being drawn in, or widenet, the Chink is withal made narrower or wider. Whence it appears, that I have not unskillfully propounded the Mucles of the Larynx, as Riolanus upbraides me.
The Epiglottis in Mankind has no Mucle; for it is not voluntarily moved in Men, as ome vainly perwade themelves; but is only depreed by the weight of uch things as are wallowed.

But in brute Beats, the Epiglottis hath Mucles, becaue they are continually eating, and chewing the Cud, and they have a very great Epiglottis. And in them ome Mucles arie from the Hyoides, and are implanted into the Bais of the Epiglottis, which they lift up; (and this pair Vealius reckons to be the fift common pair) and others are eated between the Coat of the Epiglottis and the Cartilage, hutting the ame.
The Gritles of the Larynx are five: Its Gritles. which in elderly perons do omtimes attain a boney hardnes; by means whereof, ome have caped the danger of uffocation, when they hung upon the Gallows.

The firt Gritle is termed Cartilago Thuroides, or Scutiformis, Scutalis, Clypealis, Peltalis, &c. from its hape; becaue it reembles a heild, being in a manner four-quare, hollow within, Boie and bunching without, but more in Men then in Women: becaue their Necks are made even, for beauties ake, by thoe Kernels placed by the Larynx. That ame bunch which is een on the foreide Adams Apple is more bunching out in Men then in Women. of the Nec •… s called Adams Apple, becaue <…> common people have a beleife, that by the judgment of God, a part of that fatal Apple, abode ticking in Adams Thro •• , and is o communicated to his poterit • . It is ditinguihed in the middle with a line, and therefore ome have made it double, whereas in truth it is very rarely found otherwie then ingle.

In its Corners it hath procees, above two long ones, wherewith by help of a Li •… ment, it is joyned to the lower ides of Os hyoides; and beneath two likewie, by which tis j •… d to the following Gritle.

The econd is the Cricoeides or Annularis, becaue it is round like a Ring, and compaes the whole Larynx. Now it reembles the Turkes Ring, wherewith they Arm their Thumbs when they hoot, for the hinder part is broad and very thick. The fore part is traiter and drawn in like one of our Rings. Tis vulgarly termed Innominata, or the nameles Gritle, becaue the ancients gave it no name. Tis the Bais of the ret of the Gritles, by help whereof they are joyned to the Apera Artera, and therefore it is immoveable.

The third and fourth, which others count for one, when the Membrane is taken of appears to be double. Tis called Arutainoeides, Guttalis, by reaon of its reembling the pout of an Ewer, whereout the Water is poured, if the two procees of the upper part are conidered, which being joyned together do make up that little Chink which modulates the voice, which others term
•… gula, Parva Lingua, or Glottis, the <…> Tongue, for the voiceThe Glottis. cannot be <…> through a narrow paage. This rets upon the upper and hinder ide of the Cricoides, in the Cavity of the Thyroides.

In this place is to be oberved a certain Hollownes, which is formed between the Guttalis and the Scutalis, by the Membranes which gather up the Cartilages; into which if peradventure while one is peaking or laughing, and the Epiglottis is open, a cru •• of bread or a drop of drink do happen to fall, it caues Coughing, becaue it goes againt the Coure of the wind. But if any thing lide leaurely down the Chink, by the Walls of the Larynx, it hinders not the wind, and o caues no Coughing.

The fift is termed Epiglottis, which covers and huts the Chink, leat an coniderableEpiglottis. quantity of meat or drink hould fall into the Weand, but that the Epiglottis being hur, they might pas down the Gullet. But it is not exactly hut, o that ome mal quantity of drink may lip down the ides. For when we ay that drink paes
not into the Weand and the Lungs, it is to be undertood of the greatet part; for that ome is carried thither, I have hewed you before. And therefore in Dieaes of the Chet, we precribe Electuaries and Lozenges, which are to be held in the patients mouth, his Head leaning backwards, till they melt away, that ome portion of them may lip in by the Walls of the Weand. Tis opened when we Laugh, and therefore Men mut be careful that the • do not Laugh when they are upping of broath <…> the like. Alo let uch as are greedy eaters take •… eah, any meat get between the Epiglottis and the <…> whence immediately uffocation follows, as I have e •• in a yong man of Hafnia, who was uddainly choaked by a peice of Neats-tongue weighing an ounce and an halt, greedily eaten.

Now the Subtance of the Epiglottis is oft, and its Shape reembles a Tongue, or an I vie leaf, according to Hippocrates. And on either ide a Membrane is fatend to the common mouth; uch an one as that which being daubed with a clammy Humor, doth compas the inner Cavity of the Larynx, and the outide thereof is likewie covered thereby.
As for Veels. Veels
The Larynx hath Veins from the internal Jugular.
It hath Arteries from the larger branch of the Carotides.
It hath Nerves which Galen terms Vocales, for the motion of the Mucles, from the recurrent branch of the ixt pair.
Two parcels of Kernels attend the ame.Kernels.

One Parcel at the upper part of the Larynx, viz. at the ides of the Uvula
<…> Gargareon which are called Tonilla or Amyg •… alo Parithima and Antiades the Almonds of the Ears: which being Spongy (on each ide one) • o <…> the moiture of the Brain, t ••• it into Spittle and therewith m •• ten the Throat, Larynx,Spittle Tongue and Oeophagus; though it helps alo our Tating, which cannot be performed without moiture. Thee Kernels are about the Root of the Tongue, and are covered with the common Coat of the Mouth, and receive Veins from the Jugulars.

They have placed by them two little white Bladderkeys, which receive • ero • ity out of the Kernels, and void forth into the Mouth. Riolanus doth acknowledg no uch in a Man, but Sutitutes in their tead Ligamental Membranes, tretched out from the Uvula to the Almonds.

p.U: tand by the loweride of the Larynx, on each ide one, at the ides of Cricoides and of the firt ring of the Weand, being great and pongy, through which Veins are pred, from the Jugularis externa. In Women it is more Perpicuous; in a Man and in an Ox, more flehy and red.

div.p: The Ue is, to bedew the Larynx, with a clammy and fat, but not fluid moiture, that the Gritles may be more fit for motion, and the voice may be made weeter: which is imitated by thoe who anoint their pipes with Oyl.
The Ue of the Larynx is to be the Organ of the Voice.
For the Organs of the Voice are either Remote or Immediate.

The Remote are the Chet and the Lungs, without the Aitance of the Heart; for if the four Veels of the Heart hould be tied, and the Heart cut off, yet a Dog can both run and bark, as beides later Authors, Galen did often experiment: and the illutrious Sr. Francis Bacon, in his Hitory of Life and Death, Article 15. tels of an unbowelled Man, who after his Heart was taken out, uttered three or four words of his Prayers.

The Immediate are either preparatory, as the Trachea; or aitant as the Mucles and Nerves; or conervatory, as the Mouth and Throat. But the mot principal part is the Larynx: and that part thereof termed Glottis is the next and adequate Organ of the Voice.

Now the Voice is made after thisHow the Voice is made? ma •• er: the Air is uddenly and trongly blown out by the Lungs, and the Chink is moderately traitned, where by the miting of the Air the Voice is made, as we perceive the wind to whitle through the Chink of a Dore. And therefore Aritotle cals the Voice a miting of the Air; undertanding, in a caual way of expreion, the Acton for the quality pringing therefrom. And if the breath go out, the Organ being wide open, it caues a Sig • . Sig • ing.

And therefore, that noie which Animals make cannot properly be termed a voice, they wanting this Organ; as the noie which ome ihes make, the croaking of Frogs, and the • re • king of Gras-hoppers. Aritotle tels us that the croaking of a Frog is made, when the Lip of the lower Jaw being equally let down, and a little water being in their Throats' the upper Jaw which remains immoveable, is o forcibly bent, that their Eyes eem to parkle. But, it is evident, that a Frog hath Lungs, and a Chink in tead of a Larynx. And therefore the Voice is an Animal ound, made by the Glottis throughWhat is properly a Voice? miting the Air as it is breathed in and out, being produced to ignifie the Conceptions of the Mind. And therefore Voice is only in living Creatures, nor is every ound in them a Voice, but that which is made in the Glottis; not Coughing, nor hawking, If any Fihes make a noie, it is by their Gills or ome uch thing, but not by their Mouths. Creatures without Blood and Inects, as Bees Wapes, Locuts and the like, utter no Voice, but as Aritotle rightly oberves in his fourth Book de Hitoria Animalium, they make a noie which proceeds from their Back, as for example ake, a Grashopper makes a noie, by rubbing its wings one againt another; For in thee inects there is contained a certain Spirit and Air, in a Membrane beneath the Septum Tranverum. Others will have it that inects make uch noies by beating the Air after undry manners with their wings.

The Differences of Voices are infinite,The differences of Voices, or Speeches. which are made, 1. By the Figuration of the Mouth. 2. By the different Percuion and Modulation of the Air, as we ee in Pipes. 3. From the largenes and other qualities of the Intruments, viz. the Larynx, Weand, Lungs and Chet. 4. According as the Voice comes to the Ear, intire or mangled. And beides thee differences, every particular Beat hath a voice of its own, which the Brutes themelves can accurately ditinguih, having herein a better hearing then Men. For a Lamb newly brought forth, knows its Mothers bleating among a thouand Sheep, and the Ew likewie knows the bleating of her own Lamb from all others. Which is alo true of Henns and Chickens. For the ame voice never happens, becaue the Intruments do never agree in all things: even as
Bells made of the ame matter, the ame weight, the ame form, and by the ame workman, do nevertheles alwayes differ in ound.

The Parts of the Voice or Speech, areParts of Voice or Speech. Vowels and Cononants. We repreent the Vowels only by five Letters, becaue the root of the Tongue is only moved by o many motions. But when a Vowel is further cut and modified, in the fore part of the Tongue, by the Lips and Teeth, it becomes a cononant, which therefore cannot be uttered without a Vowel, becaue that is its matter, eeing it aries only from a Vowel modified and cut: jut as from the confued ound of a Pipe, an Articulate and Harmonious ound is made, when after a certain Method, the ounding Air is again topped and cut by the Fingers.

div.head: Chap. XII. Of the OESOPHAGUS or Gullet.
div.p: THe OESOPHAGUS which ome term Gula, others tomachus, and Coelius Aurelianus Via tomachi and Ventris the way of the Stomach and Belly, in Englih the Gullet, is the Pipe or Funnel of the Stomach, as the Weand is the Pipe of the Lungs.

'Tis o Scituate, as that it begins in the Throat, where it is termed Pharynx, Its Scituation. and from thence goes down right forward, under the Weand, into the Stomach. And when it is come as far as to the fift Vertebra of the Chet, giving way to the Aorta, which paes through the middle thereof, it bends to the right Hand; afterwards it ries again to the left great Artery, and at the eleventh Vertebra, through the Diaphragma or Midriff it enters the left mouth of the Stomach, accompanied by two Nerves ariing from the ixt pair.
It hath a few Veins from the Cava, the Azygos, Intercotal and JugularIts Veels. Veins.
It hath Arteries from the Intercotal Arteries, and the internal Carotides.
And Nerves from the ixth pair.

Its Connexion is, at the beginning with the Jawes and Larynx, by the Coat ofConnexion. the Mouth, which is common to it and the Stomach. To the Vertebrae, the Trachea and neighbouring parts 'tis joyned by Membranes ariing out of the Ligaments of the Back. And becaue it lies upon the SpinaWhen the Gullet is dieaed, Medicaments are applied to the Back. or Back-bone, therefore when it is Dieaed, we apply external remedies to the Back-bone.

A Glandulous Body grows to the hinder part of it, which affordsIts Kernels. moiture, to wet the Cavity thereof, the better to ait the wallowing of things. And omtimes it wels o much, as to hinder the wallowing of all liquid meats and drink.
Its Subtance conits of a triple Coat, that it might more eaily be tretchedSubtance. long-wayes and broad-wayes.

The firt is common with the Stomach. This ome will have to arie from the Ligaments of the Vertebra's, others from the Pleura, who are therein both mitaken. For it hath its rie, there where the Membrane of the Stomach aries, viz. from the Peritonaeum, for it is one continued Body with the Membrane of the Stomach, it is exceeding thin and in a manner detitute of all Fibres.

The econd is the firt Proper one, the external being more flehy, thicker and ofter, then the other; being as it were a Mucle bored through, being commonly reputed to be interwoven with round and tranvere Fibres. Alo Hofman doth thereby prove it to be a Mucle, becaue it uffers Convulions and Palies.

The third is the econd Proper one, internal, more Nervous, omwhat ubtile and harder, being commonly aid to be interwoven with treight and long Fibres. It is contained with that Membrane which covers the Palate, Throat and Lips, and therefore when a Man is ready to vomit, his lower Lip trembles.
Howbeit, contrary to the vulgar opinion aforeaid, our Eyes can witnes, that the inner Coat is furnihed with tranvere and circular Fibres, the external with traight and longih ones.
The Mucles of the Gullet which otherMucles. have paed over in ilence, are four.

The firt, is the ame I poke of before, treating de Larynge. It is only one like a Sphincter Mucle compaing the Gullet. And therefore Riolanus, Spigelius, and Ve • ingus term it Muculus Oeophagus, being the Authors of that name.

The econd, is the Sphaenopharyngaeus by them o called, ariing from the internal acute proces of the Sphaenoides, and being obliquely implanted into the ides of the Oeophagus, that it being drawn upwards and widened, it may be the more wide to receive in meat.
The third is Stylopharyngaeus, which ariing from the Bodkin-hap'd acute proces, is tretched out to the ides of Oeophagus; which both Dilates and Amplifies.

The fourth, is Cephalo-pharyngaeus, commonly aid to arie from the Chin, but according to late Authors, from the lowet part of the Heads-top where it is nearet the Neck; and is inerted with a various contexture of Fibres into the beginning of the Oeophagus, where it is larger: and therefore becaue of its Latitude and Fabrick, it eems to be two.

The Action therefore of the OeophagusWhether Swallowing be a Natural or Animal Action? is Animal; eeing it is performed by Mucles and not natural, as the vulgar opinion is of all Authors, and wallowing doth doubtles depend upon our free will and liberty.

Now wallowing is performed after this manner: when any thing is to be wallowed, that ame firt Mucle which Galen terms Sphincter doth every way contract it elf, whereupon its oblique Fibres, which reach from the Oeophagus to the Larynx, are made tranvere, which being done, the Larynx is lifted up, and the Gullet is depreed; and the Cavity of the Gullet o depreed, is made more narrow. Hereunto the fourth Mucle is aitant. For as the firt being contracted, embraces the meat which by chewing is brought into a round Mas, and o bears it down: o this fourth Mucle alo contracting it elf, comes out as it were to help, and that the meats received in at the Mouth may not go back, it traitens and repels them on every ide, and tranmits them into the Gullet, o that by both thee Mucles contracted, and the Semicircular joyned therewith a perfect circle as it were and Sphincter is made, viz. by the fourth in the upper part of the Pharynx, and by the firt in the lower.

The Ue of the Gullet is, that by it as by a Funnel, meat and drink may be paed into the Stomach. And liquid things are indeed more eaily wallowed then olid; contrarywie inWhy omtimes olid meats are more eaily wallowed then liquid. ome ick perons olid meats are more readily wallowed then liquid, becaue the faculty is more provoked by a tronger object, being otherwie lulled a leep as it were; epecially in the Palie.

div.head: Chap. XIII. Of the Neck.
div.p: AN Appendix or Appurtenance to theThe Neck. middle Belly. is the NECK, as a medium between the Head and the Chet.
'Tis termed Collum a Colendo, becaue it is wont to be adorned: or a Colle Why call'd Collum. from an Hillock, for it aries out of the Body, as an Hill out of the ret of the Earth.

'Tis oblong for the modulation of theIts Magnitude. Voice; and therefore Animals which utter no true Voice, as Fihes and Frogs, have no Necks: and thoe which make the greatet Voice, have the longet Necks, as Cranes and Geee, &c. By the ue of Venery the thicknes of the Neck is altered, becaue heat ditends the Apera Arteria, the Carotides, and the Jugular Veins. Whence it was an ordinary Practice among the Romans to meaure the Brides Neck the day after the Wedding, by which they knew whether he were a Virgin or Corrupted, as we learn out of Catullus and Mercurialis.

The hinder part of the Neck is properly termed Cervix. Now the parts of theIts Parts. Neck are either external, as the Skin, Mucles, &c. or internal; as the Veels which run through the Trachea and Oeophagus: of the latter I have poken, of the ret I hall peak in their proper places.

The Ue of the Neck is, 1. For the Oeophagus, Weand, and Lungs. Hence CreaturesIts Ue. that have no Lungs, as Fihes, have no Necks. 2. To be intead of an Hand to ome Creatures, to take their meat with, according to Galen. 3. That it may afford Nerves to the fore-parts, the Shoulder, Cubit, Hand, Midriff; for thoe creatures only have thee parts who have Necks.

div.head: THE THIRD BOOK OF THE Uppermot Cavity, VIZ. THE HEAD.
div.p: THe third or upper Venter or Cavity is the Head, the chief manion-houeWhy the Head is placed o high. of the enitive Soul which is placed in the top of the Body, for the Eyes ake, which are there placed as in a Watch-tower; and requiite it was that the Brain hould be near the Eyes, becaue they have oft Nerves, which cannot be caried far.
The Head is round like a Globe, but a little flatned withal, and longih.Its Figure.
'Tis greater in Man then other Creatures, becaue of the Largenes of hisGreatnes. Brain.
And for more afeguard, the Head isSubtance. altogether bony.
The Head is divided into the Hairy Diviion. part, and that which is without Hair.
The former is termed Calva, the latter Facies.
The external parts of the Calva are thee following.Calva.
Sinciput, which is the forepart reaching from the Forehead to the coronal Suture.
Occiput, which is the hinder part, reaching from the Lambda-fahion'd Suture, to the firt Vertebra of the Neck.
Vertex, which is the part cituate between the two former, bunching out.
Tempora, the Temples, which are the Side-parts, between the Eyes and the Ears.

Now the parts which contitute the Calva, are ome of them external and cloathing, others internal and contained. The former are either common, as the Scarfskin, the Hairy-skin, the Fat, the flehy Membrane: or proper as the Pericardium, Periotium, the Mucles, the Bones, the Menings. The contained are the Brain, the Petty-brain, and the Marrow, which is partly in the Skull, partly in the Back-bone.

The mooth part of the Head, called the Face beides the parts containing, hathThe Face. parts proper to it elf, viz. the upper part which is called the Forehead, and the lower in which are the Organs of the Senes; as the Eyes, Notrils, Ears, and Mouth, wherein the Tongue and other parts are concealed.

div.head: Chap. I. Of the Hairs.
div.p: IN the Head there is the greatet plenty of Hair, therefore the Nature of the Hair may conueniently be delivered in this place: though conidered as an Excrement, it does not belong to this place.

Hairs are found well-near in all CreaturesWhat creatures have Hair. that engender their young ones within their bodies, as Aritotle aures us: intead whereof Fihes have cales, Birds feathers, and ome Beats as the Hedg-hog, have long harp prickles.
Now the Hairs are indeed Bodies, but not parts of the body, unles in a very large ignification, as when we ay ome parts erve only to adorn the body.
The immediate material Caue of which the hairs are made, is certain fuliginous and excrementitious Vapors, thick and earthy, yet omwhat glewih and clammy.

Its therefore fale, which ome affirm,Whether Hair & Nails grow of good nutriment. that the Hairs and Nails are nourihed and generated of good and laudable nutriment. For they grow even in perons conumed and pined away, and being cut, they grow again in all ages of a mans life; and the oftner they are cut, the ooner they grow again. Yea in dead men, as on thieves upon the Gibbet, &c. they grow. See Paraeus at the end of his Book, who had an embalmed body in his houe twenty four years together, the Hairs and Nails whereof grew again as often as they cut them. They are therefore bred of ooty Steams and Vapors, of the third Concoction, or of the flehy ubtance it elf, by whatoever heat reolved into vapors.

The remote Matter, is nothingThe remote matter of Hair. eminal out of which the hair prouts as a flower, nor any fat ubtance enclining
to the Nature of the Seed or Blood, but a uperfluous moiture; epecially that which is contained in the Kernels. And therefore where there are Kernels, in thoe places thereWhere Hair b • eede. are commonly Hairs, as at the Ears, in the Arm-pits, in the Groins, &c. And if omtimes there are Kernels without Hairs, this want of hair prings from a too great quantity of humors.
For the Matter in which, or the Place where hairs are bred, ought not to be too moit, nor too dry; as we ee nothing grow in a wet fuliginous Soyle, nor in ground over dry and parched.

And therefore the Skin, becaue it is a temperate part, as the place of GenerationWhy cruted Animals have no hairs. of hairs; but if it be too moit, or too dry, as in ome perons it is, the hair does not hoot forth: and therefore cruted Animals, as Crabs, Lobters, Oyters, &c. have no hairs.

The Skin therefore on which hairs mut be bred, ought to be moderately dry, leat the hair hould fall from its root; but it mut not be immoderately, but laxe and rare, leat otherwie the hair hould not make its way through. And therefore hairs may grow all over the skin, becaue it is every where porous, and every Pore hath the root of an hair fatned therein, excepting the palmes of the hands and the oles of the feet, which parts becaue of their continual motion and wearing, have no hairs, and becaue they were to be of an exquiite ene. And for this caue there grows no hair upon a Scar, becaue it hath no Pores.

Hairs alo do omtimes grow on the inner Membranes of the Body, in the Heart as was aid before, in the Womb, in the Urinary paages, Witnes Hypocrates, Galen, Schenkius. Hair was found in the tomach by
•• eer, and lately in Norway bairs were voided by vomit from the Stomach, whether bred there, or taken in. At the Danih Hellepont red hairs were lately taken out of the muculous fleh of an Ox leg.
The Efficient Caue of hair, is not the Soul, nor any vegetative hair-making faculty, but moderate heat, drying up thoe fuliginous vapors, and thruting them forth into the pores of the Skin.
Thee three things already explained, are the chief Requiites for the GenerationRequiites to the Generation of hair. of Hair, viz. The Matter, the Place convenient, and Heat.
From whence by the Rule of Contraries, the Caue of Baldnes may beCaue of baldnes. gathered, viz.

list.item: 1. When Matter is wanting.

2. When the Skin is Originally too dry, and afterwards grows drier, and is not moitened by any neighbouring part. Now the fore-part of the Head is here to be undertood, which is commonly the only bald place; for no man, according to Aritotle, becomes bald on the hinder-part of his Head. For either Fat or other moiture in the hinder-part and the Temples keep them from baldnes; fat in the fore-part, the Skin becomes dry and hard like a hell, and therefore is bald.

3. By reaon of too much or too little heat. For weak heat does not ufficiently dry the matter, as in cold and moit perons, and uch as are in years. And therefore the humor growing over hot by carnal Copulation, is the caue of baldnes, and for this caue Boys and Eunuchs do not become bald.

4. Alo four Husbandmen near Bruxells became bald by poyon, as Francicus de Paz the King of Spains Phyitian oberved, and wrote thereof • o Nicholas Fontanus; And Hamelmannus in his Annals tells of an Hore of the Count of Oldenburg, which by poyon was made bald hither, becaue this poyon had ome pecifical contrariety to the Hairs, or becaue the Spirits being extinguihed, and the vigor of the Body quelled, the roots of the hairs could not be retained in the Skin. Such a poyon is the fat of a certain Whale in the Iland of Feroe, newly taken out, by which Copper-veels are alo broken.

div.p: The Hairs are commonly divided into uch as are bred in the womb, and uch as grow afterwards.
Thoe bred in the Womb are threefold, thoe of the Head, of the Eye-lids,Hairs bred in the womb. and the Eye-brows.

The Hairs which grow afterwards, are uch as pring up when a man comes to a jut age; that is, in a boy when he begins to breed Sperm, and in a Maid when her Coures break forth, for then the Skin grows open.

Alo thee are threefold: for 1. Hairs breed on the Share, eldom in the Womb and the Heart. 2. In the Arm-pits, alo in the Notrils and Ears. 3. On the Chins of men but not of women; for in women their Coures pend the matter of hair which hould make a beard, and therefore omtimes, when their Coures are poxt, women have hairs growing on their Chins. It was a rare cae for a young woman of thirty years of age, one of the Arch-dutches of Autria's Women, to have ever ince he was a Girl, before her coures brake forth, a long beard with mutachios like a man. And I aw uch a like Girl not long ince in the Low-countries, who was alo hairy all her Body over. Lately Helena Marwin in Fionia, had a Girl with a long beard of a reddih yellow colour.
The End or Ue of Hairs,Ue of Hair.

list.item: I. Is to cover the Parts.

II. To adorn them. And this is chiefly een in the Hairs of the Head and Face. For
1. The Hairs of the Head do hieldWhy a man hath plenty of hair? the Brain from external injuries of cold and heat, &c. So in Aethiopia by a peculiar thrumming of their hairs, they are defended from the heat. And as a man hath the greatet Brain of all Creatures, o hath he thereon mot plenty of hairs.
2. They moderately heat, as otherwie in the Head there is no Fat to keep it warm: but rather a bony ubtance, and that far ditant from the Heart. Now the hairs according to the advice of the Phyitian, are to be let grow, or to be cut off in this or that peron, but they mut not be haven off, becaue thereby Defluxions are caued. So alo the beard does cherih and moderately warm the Chin. In perons that are recovering out of icknes, the hair mut not be cut off, for fear of a relape, touching which Quetion ee Sitonus.
3. They adorn: for bald perons andThe Beard adorns. thin-hair'd are deformed. So the Beard alo adorns a man, and makes him venetable, epecially if the hairs be pred all about. But in women there was no need of o venerable an appearance.

III. To purge the Humors and Spirits, and the whole Body of uperfluous ooty teams. And therefore frequent cutting the hair, quickens the • ight, and Celus in a long Defluxion of Rheum, bids us cut the hair to the skin. C. Aurelianus ayes that in the Phrenzie, when the hair is cut off, the parts tranpire, being freed from a great burthen. Hence a reaon may be drawn why Helmont.
• ating an Aes milk, could tell
whether he had been curried and combed that morning or not.
IV. To afford igns whereby to know the Temperament, Manners and hidden Dieaes of every peron.

div.p: The Form of Hairs is not the Soul, as many would have it, becaue in peronsTheir Form. that conume, and uch as are dead, the hairs grow; and thoe who conceive with Plempius, that there is a Soul in perons dead twenty four years, I leave the Readers to make an etimate of their Widom. Nor do they retain a vegetative life in dead perons, for o the whole man hould not die, nor is there any thing in a dead Carkas, that hould rather preerve this life, then the enitive or rational, not to ay that thee ignoble Parts by the long-lating of their lives, hould excel all other parts. Plants indeed pring living from the lifeles Earth, but out of a living Seed, which I deny to be in the Hairs, and therefore they tick not in the Body like Plants, nor are bred thereout. Nor mut we ay with Plotinus, that certain reliques of life remain after death, as warmed rooms remain hot, when the fire is out; for uch Reliques of life could not remain o many years. The form therfore of the hairs may be decribed by their accidents, which are thee following.

I. Magnitude: Now the Head-hairs are longet, becaue the Brain is greaterMagnitude. then the ret of the Kernels: alo they are thicket, becaue the Skin of the Head is mot thick, howbeit it is laxe and open, and contains ufficient moiture.

According therefore as the Skin is thick or thin, rare or compact, and the humor plentiful or canty, and the heat weak or trong, the hairs become thick or thin, hard or oft, plentiful or canty, &c. He had tore of hair on his Head, who could uffer himelf to be hot in the head with a bullet, and had no hurt, whom Busbequius aw in his Voyage to Contantinople. Yet they grow not infinitely, becaue the Exhalations are not o plentiful, nor does the expulive Faculty work infinitely.

2. Their Figure: The hairs are traight and flat, in uch as abound with moiture, but curledFigure. in uch as are dry. Therefore curled hair is harder then that which lies flat. Hence all Blackmores are curle-pated, becaue of their dry Temperament. But the Scythians and Thracians have long flat hair, becaue they are moit, according to Aritotle. Again the hairs are traight becaue of the traightnes of the paages through which they break forth; and crip becaue of the crookednes of the aid paages. The augmenting Glas informs us that the hairs are quadrangular; though others will have them to be round becaue of the roundnes of the Pores.
Alo they are porous or hollow within, as the Dieae Plica in Poland does hew, and the hairs of an Elk. Again becaue they may be plit, they have Pores, according to Aritotles maxime.

III. Their Colour: which in Brutes follows the colour of the Skin; and inThe caue of the colour of the hair. men is exceeding variable, according to the Country, ambient Air predominant Humor, Age, &c.

For thoe that dwell in hot and dry Countries, have their hair not only dry, crip and brittle, but alo black, as the Aegypians, Arabians, Indians; alo the Spaniards, Italians, and part of the French have their hair for the mot part black. They who dwell in cold and moit Countries, have their hairs not only oft and • t • aight, but for the mot part yellow or white, as the Inhabitants of Denmark, England, Norway, Swedland, Scythia, &c.
Again the predominant Humor makes the Colour of the hairs: as in flegmatick perons, the hairs are for the mot part white, and o of the ret.

Alo the Variety of Heat makes variety of Colours: for immoderate heat makes black hairs: for a vaporous Excrement is raied by the heat, and is changed into an exact ooty tream. But temperate heat makes the hairs yellow; more temperate makes them red; a weak heat makes them white. But both thee caues of Colours do eaily concur in the hair, as when flegm abounds, weaknes of heat is joyned therewith, and when Blood abounds, heat is moderate, &c.

Alo a change in the Colour is made in repect of Age, as alo of other accidents. For grown perons have their hair not only thicker, harder, tronger and more plentiful, but at length alo grey and whiteih.

But no Hairs on the Body of Man are Naturally green, or blew, though there are both green and leek-colour'd Choler in Mans Body; the caue whereof is not the thicknes of the hair, uncapable of light, as Cardan imagined, becaue the hair is capable of being yellow, its thicknes nothing hindring; but, as Scaliger rightly philoophizes, eeinge, • ry colour is not agreeable to every Plant, no more is it to the hairs. Yet I have een green hair'd men at Hafnia, and thoe as work Metals have their hair commonly green. Marcellus Donatus relates of Antonius Maria Catabenus, grey hair'd through Age, how that much Choler mixt with blood abounding in his Body, not only his Skin became of a Verdigreee or yellow-green colour, but his grey hairs were alo died of the ame hue.
The Ancients conceived that grey hairsThe caue of grey hairs. did proceed from drines, as the Leaves of Trees when they are dried, look white.

But Aritotle confutes them. For thoe who go with their heads covered, do ooner grow grey, and yet are not o dried, as thoe that expoe their heads bare to the air. Again ome are grey as oon as they are born or quickly after, which cannot proceed from Drynes.

Now they grow oonet grey that goWhy they are oonet grey-hair'd that go with their Heads cover'd? alwaies with their Heads covered, becaue the heat cannot be fanned, but is overwhelmed and trangled, which being extinguihed, an external heat is introduced; o that putrefaction is the caue of grey hairs, which prung from carity of innate heat, which cannot o diget the humors as in youth. And the outmot and mallet end of the hair is whitet, where there is leat heat.

Now why a white Humor hould arie from putrefaction, the Caue is,Why Men are oonet grey about their temples? according to Aritotle, becaue a great part is turned into Air, which being well mixed with an earthy and warry Subtance makes whitenes. Hence alo it is apparent, why men are oonet grey about their Temples, becaue there great and flehy Mucles are placed under the Skin, which through moiture do eaily putrifie. Add hereunto, that the Bones of the Temples are very thin, and therefore extraneous heat can eaily pas through them.

div.head: Chap. II Of the Membranes without and within the Skull.
div.p: THe EXTERNAL MEMBRANES which compas the Skull, are two: The PERICRANIUM and the PERIOSTIUM which compas the Brain; alo there are two Meninges or Matres o called, viz. DURA MATER and PIA MATER, that is to ay a thick Membrane and a thin one, which perform the ame Office in their Cavity, which the Pleura performs in the middle Cavity and the Peritonaeum in the lowet.
The PERICRANEUM is a Membrane thin and oft, compaing the Skull, andThe Pericraneum. pringing from the dura Mater coming out at the Sutures of the Skull.

That it prings from the dura Mater, the extraordinary Conent between the Brain with its Meninges and the Pericraneum, does ufficiently prove, which cannot be by any other way more conveniently made forth. Moreover, this production of the Pericranium from the dura Mater, is manifetly viible in Infants, in whom the Moles of their Heads are not yet ufficiently cloed. Thoe Fibres wherewith Hortius, Spigelius, and Laurenbergius do conceive that the Pericraneum is only fatned to the dura Mater, do not go unto the Throat: for the Bones being by little and little hardned and compreed, that ame Continuity of the Pericraneum and dura Mater, was broken off with Age, from whence aroe that appearance of Fibres which hath deceived ome.
The PERIOSTIUM is a mot thin and nervous Membrane, and therefore exceedingPeriotium. enible, by help whereof, all the bones aving the teeth being compaed therewith, become enible.
I ditinguih thee two Membranes with Vealius and Bauhinus againt Fallopius, Laurentius and others, who confound them, eeing they may be accurately eparated by a skilful Anatomit.
Now the various Mucles about the Head hall be explained in their proper place.

The CRASSA MENINX or harder Membrane called alo DURA MATER,Craa Meninx. becaue of its thicknes and hardnes, and becaue many conceive all the Membranes of the Body do arie out of this and the tenuis Membrana or pia Mater, does cover the Skull all over on the inide, and all its Cavities and hollownes; and ticks trongly to its Bais, o that ome have thought it took its Original from thence.

Now it compaes the Brain alo looely, on the upper ide, and covers the inide of the Skull. (For wheras Hildanus and Varolius have oberved that it is traitly fatned to the Skull, that was beides the ordinary Coure of Nature) that there may be ome ditance between, as there is between the Heart and the Heartbag, both in living and dead bodies, though in the latter it is greater, by reaon of the defect of Spirits and the falling in of the Brain, which I grant Olbafius and Hofmannus; and this is o contrived that the welling Veels of the Brain, may not be compreed, and that there may be no hindrance of the

Motion of the Brain, which is made up of Sytole and Diatole, and is continual,The Brain moves. as may be een in Wounds of the Head, newborn Children, and mot vehement pains of the head, as Fabricius Hildanus hath oberved: And I my elf have frequently een this motion in wounded perons. Strange therefore it is that ome learned men will needs deny this motion. But it is a very hard task to aign the true Caue of this motion: Some make it to be the Meninges; others the Arteries; others the Subtance of the Brain. But it is ill acribed to the Meninges: for a great portion of the brain being taken away, and the Meninges themelves, the brain was oberved to move in a living Sheep, by the renowned Riolanus. They judg better who acribe the ame to the Arteries, for the motions of the Brain and Arteries do happen both at one and the ame time, as may eaily be oberved in Fractures of the Skul, and in the Heads of Infants. Yea and Walaeus oberves that in thoe who being wounded in the Head to the Brain, have extream anguih, only certain conpicuous Arteries do move, and not the Subtance of the Brain; and when the parties wounded gather trength, the motion of their Brain evidently returns. Alo Coiter hath oberved in living Lambs, Kids and Dogs, that the brain it elf hath no motion but only the Arteries. To him Olbafius gives conent, becaue the motion is mot obervable about the Cavities of the dura mater, where are mot Arteries. And therefore I conceive we mut not have recoure to the ubtance of the brain: which is alo oft and flaggie, and ufficiently indipoed for motion. But the chiefet motion is oberved at the full of the Moon, by reaon of the working of the humors at that eaon. But that alo prings from the Arteries, which are more ditended with blood: for the motion of the Heart becomes quicker or lower, according to the various Influence of the Stars. That the motion of the brain hould anwer the motion of the Lungs, I have no ufficient ign to prove.
Now it is fatned to the pia mater and the brain, by Veels; to the Skul by thin membranous fibres pringing out of it elf, paing out through the futures, and contituting the Pericranium.
This Meninx or Coat is double, as the ret of the Membranes are. The external part repecting the Cranium, is hard, rough, and of a mall ene, becaue of the hardnes of the Skull which it was to touch.
The inner part is mooth, lippery, brightly hineing and white, being more drenched with a waterih moiture.
It is fourfold where it ditinguihes the Brain from the petty-brain, in which place Dogs have a bone underpropping their brain, that it may not bear hard upon the Cerebellum, Branilet, or petty-brain.

But on the Crown of the Head it is doubled,The Sickle. where it divides the brain into the right and left part: and becaue the Reduplication is in the hinder-part broad, and grows afterwards narrow by degrees, yet not to a point, o as to repreent a Reapers Sickle, thereforeSee Tab. 11. they term this Body Falx the Sickle. And while it is thus multiplied, it contitutes.

Cavities hollownees, being receptacles of abounding blood and Spirits, and theyThe upper Cavities. are four in number; which Galen omtimes calls the Ventricles of dura Mater; and others call them Sanguiductus, Citernes of Blood.

The firt two begin at the Bais of the Hind-part of the Head, by the ides ofThe firt two. the Lambda-hap'd Suture, where the Veins and Arteries disburthen themelves. The Veins truly, of the jugular branch are manifetly inerted, and receive blood out of the Cavities; but the Arteries, whether mediately by certain branches of the
