Cavities, as Walaeus upects, or knit immediately to the Cavities themelves, do disburthen themelves, into the Cavities, And thee two being afterward united, do make up.

The third which is longet of all: For it goes all along the Head to the tops ofThe third. the Notrils. Galen omtimes calls it a Vein, becaue it contains tore of Blood. And when thee Cavities are opened, an immeaurable quantity of Blood comes out by the Noe, which is upplied from the Arteries.
The fourth Cavity, not reaching to the Skul as the former, is hort, and goes inwardly between the Brain and the Brainelet, unto the Glandula pinealis.

It aries, where the three former meet together, and this beginning ome from Herophilus call Torcular the Wine-pret; and Nymmannus conceives that this part is cheifly obtructed in the Apoplexy. But 1. We do omtimes allow thereof, as a remore Caue for all that accident is to be referred to the noble Ventricle. 2. Vital blood may be brought to the Brain by the rete Mirabile, whence Veels go for Nutriments ake, to the ubtance of the Brain

The third, or the uppermot of the ickle; and the fourth Cavities, do eem to me to end into the two former, or greater lateral ones; in which I follow Fr. Sylvius exceedingly vert in the Anatomy of the Brain: and that not by a treight paage, but inclining to the ides; o that there is no common concoure of thee four Ventricles; though thee greater lateral ones are joyned by an intermediate paage or Channel. Yet here alo I have found ome diverity according to the varietySee Tab. II. of ubjects, o that they have omtimes met, and omtimes been eparated. Riolanus makes the Torcular with Galen to be in the third longitudinal Cavity, beca • e it ditributes blood into all parts of
the Brain and Brainlet or Cerebellum, which Reaon holds truer in reference to the Arteries.

Beides thoe four Cavities or Ventricles already decribed, three others, by the InformationThe lower Cavities. of Sylvius have in diection preented themelves to me; which nevertheles, I have not alwaies, and I tell you o much, leat any man not finding them preently in one or two Bodies, hould accue me of falhood. Riolanus accounts them to be Coherences of the Duglicated Brain, pred under the greater once by the intercedency of the pia Mater. Which is nothing, for they have Cavities as the others have, nor are they naked Coherences.

The one of thee, which was alo oberved by Vealius, is carried through theSee Tab. II. lowet part of the Sickle, and therefore I have termed it, the lower Ventricle of the Sickle; and for ditinctions ake, I have termed that which is commonly call'd the third, the upper Ventricle of the Sickle. This lower Ventricle of the Sickle, ends into the fourth Ventricle.

The other two maller lateral ones, on each ide one, are ditant about a thumbs breadth from the greater, ituate in the dura Mater which ditinguiheth the Brain from the Brainlet, not being o long as they. The one of them goes into the great lateral Cavity; I have alo een them ending into the fourth.
From the Cavities arie the branches or creeping jugular Veins, and into them the Arteriae Carotides, being ditributed upwards and round about, and opening into them by mutual Anatomoes.

Now the blood is contained in thee Cavities in very great plenty, becaue the bulk of the Brains ubtance is very great, and they perform the office not only of Veins but of Arteries alo, eeing they Pule as

the Arteries do. Which Walaeus could never perceive in the diected brains of live Creatures, nor in fractures of the Skull. Though it be evedent even to thoe that open the Skull with a Trepan, as Riolanus confees.

The Ue therefore of the Ventricles, is not o much to contain the two orts ofThe Ue. Blood, received from the Veins and Arteries; as only to receive the Arterial blood, by means whereof they Pule. For the Arterial blood communicated to the Brain by the Arteria Cervicalis, which remains over and above after the Nutriment of the Brain and Brainlet, and the Generation of Animal pirits, is voided into thee Caveties, either immediately or mediately, by the little twigs of the Cavities, as Walaeus upects; and from thence through the jugular Veins which are joyned to the Ventricles, together with a thin Skin cleaving to their Walls, it runs back downwards to the Heart, that it may be wrought over again. For that the blood is circularly moved in the Brain alo, appears likewie by the Ligatures of live Creatures; eeing the jugular being bound, wels towards the Head, but is empty and lank towards the Cava and Heart.
P. Laurenberg conceives ••• Animal Spirits are generated in the Cavities, without any firm judgment or probable Reaon.

A. Kyperus a mot learned Man, conceives that a pecial ue of thee Cavities is, to ventilate and cool the blood, for the better ervice of the Brain and the Generation of Animal Spirits; eeing the extremities of the Arteries do end in them, and the Ventricles themelves are cloed in by a ingle, cold Membrane. But in my Judgment the Arterial blood does not come into the Cavities, before it be cooled, when it returns from the Generation of Spirits. And then it needs no cooling, being to return immediately through the Veins into the Heart.
The Ue of the dura Mater is, I. To cover the brain with the Marrow and Nerves thence ariing.
II. To ditinguih the Brain from the Brainlet, and the Brain it elf into two parts.
III. To contitute the Pericranium, while it ends Ligaments therefore, through the Sutures.

Th •
pia Mater call'd o becaue of its thinnes, doth immediately encloe thePia Mater. Brain, and its Parts and Ventricles, leat they hould run about; therefore it was to be thin and oft; and it is of mot exquiite ene. It is thicker in the third Ventricle, then the ret, if we will believe Olhofius. The ene of this Membrane was more dul in him that had three bones growing thereto without hurt, which were een at Paris by my Coin-German Henricus Fuiren: & in that Venetian, who had a pretty large tooched Bone, growing in Falce or the Duplicature of the Meninx, which Folius did hew me.
Its Ue is; To cloath the Brain, the Brainlet, the Marrow and the Nerves.

div.head: Chap. III. Of the Brain and its Marrow in General.
div.p: WIthin the Skul a threefold oft and white ubtance is to be conidered: the BRAIN or foremore Part, the BRAINLET or Cerebellum the hindmot part, and the inmot partwhich lies deep under the Brain being a white MARROW; which becaue others do ignorantly confound with the Brain it elf; I do thus truly et down the truth of the matter.
The Brain commonly o called hath two parts, the one Internal the other External.

The External part is properly andWhat is properly the Brain. tricktly called the BRAIN and is all that which appears outwardly oft, of an Ah color or yellowih white; which color ome conceive to arie from an innumerable company of Veins there dieminated; and this External ubtance is as it were the bark.

The Internal is the remaining ubtanceThe Marrow what? which lies hidden beneath the the former, being more hard compact and white, which we may call the MARROW, in which are eated the Ventricles commonly o called, but not in the Brain it elf; o that

The Brain and Marrow it elf Differ, How they differ? 1. In Situation. 2. In Color. 3. In Conitency. 4. By the going between of Lines. 5. In Magnitude. 6. In Figure. 7. In Cavities, which are in the Marrow, not in the Brain. 8. In Nobility.

The white part therefore of the Brain eems to be buryed in the Ah-color'd part, as the Chrytalline Humor is in the Glaie. And though thee two ubtances, the White and the Ah-color'd, do in dead Carcaes putrified eem very cloely united and continued one to another; yet in the freh bodies of healthy perons uddenly killed, they are eparated with undry lines, o that they may be very well actually evered, if great Dexterity be ued, and Diection be begun preently after the parties death, otherwie they are overflowed with much moiture and fall in.
This middlemot white ubtance orParts of the Marrow. Marrow, I divide into the round and long Parts.

The Globous or round part, which IThe Head of the Marrow, what? hall call the Head of the Marrow, reembles the Figure of the Skul, and is of great bulk, having in it three Cavities or Ventricles commonly o called.

The long part, which I will call the Tail of the Marrow, aries immediately out of the former like a certain Tail, wherein is ingraven the Calamus Scriptorius or fourthA new opinion concerning the place where the Animal pirits are made. Ventricle o called by ome; wherein I hold the true Generation of Animal Spirits to be affected.
And this long Portion of the Marrow, is the beginning and original of all Nerves whatoever that are in that place; contrary to what is commonly thought.

Alo this lengthened Marrow may be conidered in a twofold manner: either as it remains till within the Skul, and then the Nerves arie therefrom, which are vulgarly; attributed to the Brain: or as it is without the Skull, and lides into the Back-bone, gaining the title of the Spinal Marrow.
But that young Learners may not be confounded, I hall now propound the tructure of the whole Brain commonly o called.

The greatnes of a Mans Brain isThe Magnitude of the Brain. remarkable in proportion to the ret of his body, as Aritotle oberves. And for the mot part a man hath twice as much
Brain as an Ox, viz. the quantity of four or five pound weight, becaue he is a more noble Creature, and perpaps becaue he goes bolt upright: for when when we would have any thing that is moveable to tand upright we put a great weight on the top, to prevent its falling. Yet the cull of a montrous beat lately found in Scania, might preternaturally contain twice that quantity of Brain. The Skull it elf is kept in the tudy of Wormius. And among Man-kind, Men haveWho have mot Brains. more Brains then women. For to them the greatet brain is given, that have mot need of brains, and greatet ue of them, for the exercie of undry excellent Animal faculties. Yet Spigelius or Bucretius will not allow of this difference of the brains of the two Sexes, moved doubtles by Ocular Inpection, and the great Minds and Endowments of ome Women, which the foregoing Age and this of ours have brought forth. But Women are therefore aid to have les brains then men, becaue for the mot part they have les bodies.

It is of a roundih hape anwerableKnobs of the Brain. to the Skul; yet inwardly the brain hath certain knobs, which by ome are cal-Proceus mammillares

The outward urface of the brain is ful of turnings and windings likeWhy the Brain hath windings. thoe of the Guts: which we mut not ay were made for undertanding with Eraitratus, eeing Aes alo have them; nor for lightnes ake as Aritotle would have it; nor that they are without End or Ue, as others conceit; but that the Veels of the brain might be more afely conveighed through thoe turnings and windings, leat they might by continual motion be in danger of breaking, epecially at the ful of the Moon, when the brain doth mot of all wel within the Skul.

The windings of the brain (which I firt learnt of Fr. Sylvius a great Anatomit)The winding Clift of the Brain if you diligently examin the matter, you hall find to decend a good depth, & that the brain doth gape on each ide, over & above that ame middle diviion made by the Sickle, with a winding clift, which begins in the forepart, about the roots of the Eyes,See Tab. 3. whence according to the bones of the Temples, it goes back above the Root of the pinal Marrow, and divides the upper part of the brain from the lower part. Yet now and then, that ame great Chink cannot be found or very hardly. Intead thereof I have found a certain mal lateral clift on each ide eaily eparable, even in the common ection, near the Ventricles, ful of the Carotick Arteries.
The inner Surface hath undry Extuberances and Cavities, as hall be aid in the following dicoure

The Colour is white, becaue the brain, as all other parts hath its original fromThe Colour. the Seed, but o, that it hath les of Amplification then of Contitution: and therefore in extream fatings the brain uffers no diminution.

Its Temperament is cold and moit, which appears from its whitenes andIts temperament. moitnes. And therefore Hippocrates aies the brain is the eat of cold and clammy humors. For the overgreat heat of the brain is an hinderance both to Reaon and Sleep, as appears in Phrenetick perons. Yet is it by reaon of the pirits hotter then any Air, as Galen rightly aies; yet is it not o exceeding hot as the Heart

Its ubtance is proper to it elf, uch as is not in the whole body beides.Why the ubtance of the brain is moderately oft? Hippocrates doth liken it to a Kernel, by reaon of the Colour and plenty of moiture. It is oft and moit for the more eaie impreion of Images and Conceptions, for it is the eat of Imagination: Yet is it not o oft as to run about, but hath a conitent oftnes, o that what is imprinted therein, may continue for a eaon: for the brain is alo the eat of Memory.

The followers of Des-cartes doth weave the brain together of oft and pliable Fiberkies, mutually touching one another, with intermediate paces of the pores, by which Fiberkies the Images of Objects are imprinted upon the brain. They do indeed excellently explain the reaon of Sene, if this Hypotheis of theirs were true. But uch Fiberkies are not found in the oft ubtance of the brain, unles we hall mean the beginning of the Spinal Marrow, out of which the little Ropes of Nerves do arie.

It is a rare cae for the ubtance of the brain to be quite wanting, but Hortius aw it omtimes much diminihed by over great ue of carnal Embracements, as his Epitles hew. Howbeit Schenckius, Valleriola, Carpus, &c. aw a Boy without any brain; as alo Nicolas Fontanus at Amterdam in the year 1629, who intead of a brain and pinal marrow, found a very clear water encloed in a Membrane.

Sundry Veels are Dieminated through the brain. For if youThere are Veins in the Brain. queeze the ubtance thereof, many little Dripplekies of blood do weat out: and therefore I conclude with Galen that very many capillary Veins and Arteries are there dieminated: which I have alo divers times beheld with mine Eyes. Which will then principally happen, as Fr. Silvius oberves, when the brain is Flaccid and Friable, becaue he oberved that then it would come of it elf from the Veels, in diection; and epecially if the Veels by means of Age, or any other waies, are become more olid then ordinary.
Now there are no Nerves Dieminated through the Brain and therefore it is Void of all Sene.

The Veins which are carryed through the ubtance of the brain are, 1. The five branches of the jugular Veins, ome of which go into the Cavity of the dura mater, others are pred up and down through the Coats and ubtance of the brain. But they, according to the Obervation of Walaeus, are no other then, 2. very mal twigs, which on either ide go into the ubtance of the brain, out of the Cavities of dura mater.

There are four Arteries from the Carotides and Cervicales, whereof the former are dieminated into the brain upwards and downwards, the latter into the Brainlet or Cerebellum. In the Chinks the ame Carotick Arteries are carried in very great number, both in the urface and the bottom, which Fr. Sylvius conceives to be the caue of that ame troubleome puling about the Temples in ome kinds of Head-ach: though in the judgment of A. Kyperus the pulation of the external Arteries adds omwhat hereunto, as the Cure of the pain doth hew, by opening the aid Arteries.

The Ue of the Brain according to Aritotle, The Ue of the Brain. is to cool the Heart, which Galen jutly refutes, becaue the brain is far from the Heart. But there are ome Peripatericks who deny that Aritotle dients from the Phyitians, while he aith the brain is made to temper the heat of the Heart, and they will have it made to produce Animal pirits: In as much as the Animal pirits cannot be generated, unles the vital Spirits be firt cooled But,

The Ue thereof is, 1. To be the Manion of the enitive Soul, for the performance of Animal Functions. Now the brain is no particular Organ of Sene, as the Eyes, Ears, &c. but an univeral one: for judgment is made in the brain of the Objects of all the Senes.

Alo it paes judgment touchingOf the brains Motion. Animal Motion, whereas it elf hath no Animal Motion: But it hath a Natural Motion, communicated from the Arteries, and that a perpetual one of widening and contracting it elf, as appears in Wounds of the Head and new-born Children, in the forepart of whoe Head, the brain is een to pant, becaue their bones are as yet exceeding oft and plyable.
In its Dilatation the brain draws vital Spirit with arterial blood out of the Carotick Arteries, and Air by the Notrils.

In its contraction it forces the Animal pirits into the Nerves, which like Conduit pipes carry the aid Spirit into the whole body, and therewith the faculties of Sene and Motion. And by the ame Contraction, the blood is forced out of the Ventricles through the Veins unto the Heart.

The Matter therefore of the AnimalThe Matter of the Animal Spirits. Spirits is two fold; viz. Arterial blood ful of vital Spirit, and Air. Touching the place of its Generation we hall peak hereafter. For I am not of their opinion who confirme that this Spirit is Generated in the ubtance of the Brain, or in thoe Ventricles in the forepart thereof.

2. That the Animal pirit may be contained and kept in the brain as in a Store-houe, after it is generated. And the ubtance, truly, of the Brain is a convenient Houe and Receptacle for the Animal pirit, eeing it is the ame with the internal Marrowy ubtance of the Nerves, which alo contains the aid Animal Spirit.

Now I am of Opinion that in theA new opinion of the Author, touching the ue of the Brain and the Marrow. Brain, properly o called, or the Rinde, is contained Animal Spirit for Sene; and that in the whole Marrow Head and Tail, Spirits is kept for Motion, which hall be made manifet in the following Chapter.

div.head: Chap. IV. Of the Parts of the Brain in Particular, and I. of the lengthened and Spinal Marrow, and its noble Ventricle.
div.p: SOme with Galen, Vealius, Fallopius, The right Diection of the Head mut begin at the lower Part. intending to contemplate what is contained in the Brain, begin their Diection in the upper part and proceed to the lower, and therefore they do unfitly propoundSee the Figure of the Section in the Manual of Nerves. and explain many parts. I, treading in the teps of Contantinus Varolus, hall take a quite contrary Coure, yet uch as is true and accurate, beginning at the lower part of the brain and o paing to the uppermot: and I hall afterward propound the order of parts from top to bottome, for their akes that will needs follow the vulgar and common way of Diection; where alo a third way of Diection hall be propounded.

Beginning therefore at the lowet part of the Brain, we meetThe beginning of the Spinal Marrow. firt with the beginning of the lengthened Marrow; the progres whereof becaue it is contained in the Vertebra's of the Spina or Back-bone, therefore it is termed Spinalis and Doralis, Medulla, the Spinal or Back-marrow.

And if any one hall think weAn Objection. ought therefore to begin with the brain, becaue the Spinal Marrow is aid to take its beginning therefrom;The Anwer. we anwer, that we make the Marrow both as it is within the Skull and inA new Opinion of the Author, that the Marrow is the Original of the brain. the Back-bone, to be the beginning rather of the brain; and that the brain being divided into two parts, is as it were a certain double proces or production of the Marrow it elf.

Which is yet more manifet to thoe thatA proof hereof. behold the Anatomy of Fihes; for there the Head and Tail of the Marrow, is very great, but the proces of the Marrow, or the brain is very little: the Caue whereof is, that Fihes ue motion more then ene, intimating that the brain or barke contributes more to ene and the Marrow it elf to Motion. Hence Fih are dull of Sene, but very nimble in motion. And according to this opinion of ours that aying will be verified, than an hard body is fittet for motion, and ofter for ence.

div.p: The lengthened Marrow aries as ome conceive from the brain alone, according to others from the Brainlet or Cerebellum. But it hath both (to peak now at a vulgar rate) for its beginning.

For it aries from four Roots or Foundations; two of which are greater from the fore-part of the brain commonly o called, two are leer from the inner part of the Brainlet or petty Brain. From thee united, the pinal Marrow eems to be contituted. But it is peradventure a more true opinion to think, that thoe originals are procees of the Marrow it elf, as was aid before.
The Subtance of the Medulla oblongata or lengthened Marrow, is a little harder then that of the brain.

One part thereof is within the Skull, four Fingers breadths above the great Hole ofThe pinal Marrow divided. the Hind-part of the Head. Another and the longet part thereof is without the Skull in the Vertebra's, from the firt of the Neck to the lat of Os acrum.
Its Figure is longih and round, The Scripture calls it the Silver Cord. In its beginning it is thicker and larger then elewhere.

It is further divided into the right and left part, even as the brain is, by the pia Mater Another diviion. which immediately invets the ame, which may be een in the Marrow of an Oxe indifferently boyled. Hence there may be a Palie of only one ide of the body.

Now it is divided into many little Cords as it were, about the ixt and eventh VertebraAnother diviion. of the Chet: and if the pinal Marrow of a body newly dead be preently plunged in cold water, and a eparation of thee cords made, you may ee the hape of an Hores tail, (epecially towards the end) divided into many long Hairs: o that according to Laurentius, the Nerves alo of the Back and Loyns, do pring from the Marrow of the Neck.
It is covered with a tripple Membrane, the firt which immediatelyThe Coats of the Marrow. covers it, is from the pia Mater.

The econd is from the dura Mater and cleaves to the former, Which two, according to the Obervation of Spigelius, are not eparated any ditance one from another, as they were within the Skul, but touch one the other.

The third being external prings according to Galen from a trong Ligament, which binds together the foreparts of the Vertebra's, and in the hinder part ends into a trong Coat, leat in bending or extending the Back-bone, the Marrow hould be hurt.
A thick and clammy humor is poured round about this Coat, to moiten the ame.

Afterwards the Marrow is hut up in the Vertebrae, leat it hould be hurt (as the brain is hut up in the Skul) eeing it is a noble part, and the original of the Nerves. Therefore the Ancients called the Cavity of the Spina or Back-bone Hieran Surigga, the holy Pipe.
In the beginning of this Marrow, while it is yet in the Skul, there appears ingraven.

An Hollow Cavity, which Galen calls the Ventricle of the Brainlet; othersA noble Ventricle in the Marrow. call it the fourth Ventricle of the brain, though it is not in the brain. But I hall term it the noble Ventricle of the Marrow. This is mot olid, mot pure, mot ubtile, but leat of all, for it containes a matter of geater force and faculty then the ret, as Galen aies.
And becaue, after a traight even progres, it is widened on each ide, and harpened afterwards into a point, becaue of this hape tis called Calamus Scriptorius, the Writing Pen or Quil.

Now from the Cerebellum orThe cover of the noble Ventricle is from the Brainlet. Brainlet, which is joyned to this Marrow, another and middle half of this Ventricle is contituted, as it were a cover; o that all this Cavity is between the brainlet and Medulla oblongata, or production of the Marrow, but the cheif Cavity is the lowermot, which is in the Marrow.

The Ue of this Ventricle I hold toThe true place where Animal Spirits are generated according to our Author. be this, viz. that it hould be the place where Animal pirits are Generated and Elaborated. For this Ventricle is 1. The mot pure and ubtile. 2. It hath a Cavity ufficient for that purpoe. 3. It is eated in uch a place, that it can poure forth Animal pirits, into all the Nerves round about it. And therefore Herophilus did rightly judg, that this was the mot principal Ventricle.

Nor can I devie how it came to pasA Proof. that certain learned Men could not ee thee weighty Arguments, who have written without caue, that I aigned the Generation of Animal Spirits to the Calamus Scriptorius, without any reaons moving me thereto.

Now mut we think with Spigelius, that this Ventricle did only reult by conequence, out of the round particles of the Brain, touching one another without any deign of Nature: for Nature doth nothing to no end, no not when he eems mot of all to do o.
Others conceive that the Animal Spirit is bred in the fore Ventricles of the Brain.
But they are full of Excrements, whoe receptacles they rather are, as appears by the Glandula Pituitaria unto them, and in that they are often found filled with Flegm, and abundance of water.
Others in the Rete Mirabile, othersThe preparation of the Animal Spirits where it is? in the Plexus Choroides.

But in thee we hold the Animal Spirit is prepared, but not Generated, For nature is wont to provide intertwinings of Veels for the preparation of any matter: and eeing thee Veels are o mal, how can it be generated in them, epecially eeing o many Excrements of the brain flow through the Ventricles.

Others will have them to be wrought in the ubtance of the brain. Others in the lengthened body of the pinal Marrow. But the Generation of o ubtile a Spirit, did require ome Cavity, which is alo allowed to the Generation of the vital Spirits.
For which caue ome have been induced to allot the making of the natural pirit to be in the right Vencle of the Heart, becaue there is no Cavity in the Liver.

I am therefore of opinion that the Animal Spirit is prepared in the Rete Mirable, and yet more in the Plexus Choroides, and that is generated and wrought up in this Cavity of the Medulla Elongata, or in the noble Ventricle; and afterward, as much of it as not derived into the pinal Marrow and the Nerves of the brain, is preerved and retained in the whole brain, as in a Store-houe.

The Ue of the lengthened and pinal Marrow, is to be the original of all theThis Marrow the beginning of all Nerves. Nerves. For from that part thereof within the Skull, thoe Nerves arie which are commonly attributed to the Brain, being uually reckoned to be even pair. But from the longet part thereof which is in the Backbone, Anatomits do reckon thirty pair of Nerves to arie, viz. as many as there are holes in the Vertebrae.

Mean while we mut not o undertand the matter, as though only o many branches or Cords did thence arie. For every Nerve arie with many little trings or Fibres, which going out at the hole of any Vertebra, are there joyned together by the Membranes, as if the Nerve came out of one branch.

div.head: Chap. V. Of the Cerebellum Brainlet, Or Petty-Brain.
div.p: THe Brainlet being as it were a littleThe Brainlet what it is? and private kind of Brain, is a certain maller portion, placed under the Brain in the lower and after-part of the Occiput or Minder-Head: In Brutes it takes up commonly the whole Region of the Occiput.
It hath the ame Subtance, Conitency, Colour, Motion, &c. with the Brain.

In the Turnings and Windings it differs from the Brain. The brainIts Structure. hath undry Circumvolutions with out any Method or Order; the Brainlet hath circular and ordinate ones, tretched one over another like Plates. They are differenced partly by interpoed Veels, partly by the pia mater, which being eparated, the everal Circles may be taken out after another.
The inner Subtance is various, whiteih and Ahcoloured, which ditributed certain Veels as it were.

The Veels interpoed betwixt the everal plates, are carried through the pia mater like nets, which according to the accurate Obervation of Francis Sylvins, ariing from the Branches of the Arteria cervicalis, do at lat end into the fourth Ventricle.
It is contituted chiefly of two lateral parts, on each ide making a Globe as it were.

It hath two Procees or Excrecences, termed Vermiformis or Worm-like, becaue they are variouly orbiculated, and conit of many tranvere portions, coupled with a thin Membrane. Their Extremity being thin and convex, is as big as a mall • a • e.
And they are ituate at the eat of the noble Cavity, one before, the other behind.

About the hinder-part of the Trunk of the Spinal Marrow, in the Circumference of the noble Ventricle, out of the ame brainlet there proceed two other globous procees, omtimes two of each ide, omtimes three. Thoe are greatet which are eated by the Vermiformis, the ret areSee Tab. 4. Fig. 1. maller. Varolius calls it the bridg of the brainlet.

The Ue of all the Procees is to hinder the noble Ventricle from being obtructed, by preure of the brainlet. Laurentius aies they help the motion of the Ventricles like a Valve, becaue the Vermiformis being hortned opens the way, which goes from the third to the fourth Ventricle; when it is extended it huts the Chink, leat the Spirits hould go back into the upper Cavities. Riolanus dients but little from him, for he will have it to open and hut the entrance of the fourth Ventricle. But it is not moved of it elf, becaue, as the brain, o is it void of any proper motion, unles you aign it to the Veels or pia Mater, which are very mall, or at leat to the neighbouring Animal Spirits.

Now I believe the ue of the bridg is, to combine and keep in compas the Circles of the brain, and as a bulwark to defend the noble Ventricle. And therfore it would more properly be called a Sconce or Fence, then a bridg.
The Ue of the brainlet is the ame withThe Ue. that of the brain. But Galen would have it to be the Original of the hard Nerves; which is fale. For no Nerves have their Original from it.

div.head: Chap. VI. Of the ret of the Parts oberved in the Brain; viz. the Rete mirabile, Glandula pituitaria, Infundibulum, Ventricles of the Brain, Corpus calloum, Fornix, Plexus, Choroides, Glandula pinealis.
div.p: THe precedent parts being conidered, we mut come now to thoe things, which are preently viible, about the Conjunction of the Optick Nerves, uch as are; the Rete mirable, Glandula pituitaria, and the Infundibulum.

The Rete mirable or wonderful Net, Rete mirabile which ome call Plexus retiformis, is o called by reaon of its artificial and wonderful tructure, for it hews like many Nets heaped together. Now it hath another tructure in Calves and Oxen, in which Creatures it is alo more manifetly dicernable then in mankind, though we mut not ay that it is not in Men as Vealius doth, Vealius his Error. though hard to dicern. I remember nevertheles that it hath been wanting.
This Net lies under the Bais of the Brain, encompaes the Glandula, at the ides of the Cavity of Os Sphaenoides.

It conits (not of the Nerves of the third Conjugation as Volcherus would have it, but) of the Carotick and Cervical Arteries, carried up from the Heart, to the Bais of the Brain, which convey blood and Spirit in to this Net.
Riolanus places the Rete mirabile at the ame Bais of the Brain, viz. The off-pring of the Plexus Choroides, which creeps through the former Ventricles.

The Ue of this Net is, that therein the blood and vital Spirit may be a very long time detained, that the firt preparation towards the Generation of Annimal Spirits may there be made. Alo Waloeus hath oberved that this Net doth conit of mal twigs of the jugular Veins; that they may doubtles carry back uch blood as is uperfluous after the preparation of the Animal Spirits.

The Glandula pituitaria or Rheumkernel, Glandula pituitaria. is o called from its ue, becaue it
receives the Excrements of the brain out of the Ventricles through the Funnel. AndIts Seat. therefore it is placed at the end of the Funnel in the addle of the Sphaenoides. Galen calls it barely Glandula.
On the upper-ide it is hollow, beneath boie or bunching.Its Figure.
Its Subtance is harder and more compact then that of other Kernels.Its Subtance.
It is cloathed with the Pia Mater.

Its Ue is the ame, with that of otherIts Ue. Kernels, viz. by its drinking pungy fleh to receive groer Excrements (for the thin Vapor out at the Sutures) collected in the Ventricles of the brain, many times in great quantities. For the brain being ofThe Brain ful of Excrements. great bulk, did need much Aliment, and therefore it breeds many Excrements, epecially when it is in any meaure diordered. Thee Excrements the Kernel doth omtimes cat into the Palate of the Mouth, and omtimes uffers them to drain away by the holes in the bais of the Skull.
Others uppoe the ue of this Kernel to be, to hut the Funnel, leat the Animal Spirits hould go forth. For jut over the Glandula Pituitaria or Rheum-Kernel, is

Infundibulum or Funnel, o calledInfundibulum. from its hape, for above the Head thereof is large, the lower part is a long and trait pipe. Others call it Pelvis the Bain, which words doth more properly belong to the Head, or beginning of the Funnel then to the whole body thereof.

The Funnel therefore is an Orbicular Cavity (omtimes triangular with harp or blunt Angels) made of the pia Mater, where it ingirts the bais of the brain. Its beginning is large, at the hole of the third Ventricle, as they call it; through which the Excrements are packt away out of the Ventricles into this Funnel.
Riolanus informs us that it hath four little pipes, which ditil Rheum or Phlegmatick erum through the four holes reting upon the Sellae Sphenoideae.
Its of a dark Colour, and if you open it you hall find it full of thick Flegm.

The FIGURE Explained.
The Fornix being removed the Glandula Pinealis is here to be een as alo the third Ventricle of the Brain, which is in the middle between the two foremore Ventricles.

div.p:
Two little whiteih Kernels or Portuberancies of the brain are placed before this paage, which are to be een, the brain being turned upide down, there where the Funnel receives wheyih E • c •• men ••
••• of the Ventricles.
Thee things being thus handled, the Original of the Nerves follows in coure the Section to be oberved, which every where arie from the Marrow; of which I hall peak in our Manual of the Nerves.
The Ventricles or Cavities of the Brain do follow.

Thee according to the common manner of Section, beginning from above, are thought to be three: two foremore and uppermore as they call them, and one in the middle, to which ome add a fourth, of which we poke before.
But if diection be made after the new manner, beginning from beneath; there appear only two, o that the third is common, being a portion of the other two.

I conceive that there is but one Ventricle of the brain, which is in theThe Authors opinion that there is but one Ventricle of the Brain. middle, but the beginning thereof is divided into two; or there are two procees, which receiving the Excrements, carry them into the middle it elf, which they call the third. For there is one continued Cavity of the brain, and the two Ventricles o called, do end into a common Cavity.
Mean while, becaue this and that part of the Cavity eem diverly formed, ome ditinction may be allowed for Doctrins ake.

Thoe two Ventricles which are ill termed the foremore and uppermore (becaueThe foremore Ventricle decribed. they conit alo in the hinder and lower part of the Brain, perhaps they might better be called the lateral Ventricles, and with Vealius the right and left) are the larget of all, crooked, full of windings, Semicircular, and cloathed with the pia Mater.

They are commonly and not unfitly liken'd to the Moon when he is in the Wane; although they are hardly ever demontrated to be uch in diection. But eeing they are both oblong, and very large in their hinder part, they may alo be likened to Hore-hoes. This round form of the Ventricles was firt dicovered by the mot accurate Fr. Sylvius, and after him I have often demontrated the ame. But if you would find the true Figure, you mut cut the brain deep towards the Skul, or the Temples, on each ide, becaue it is deeply unk into the Corpus Calloum. For that part of the Ventricles towards the Septum lucidum is higher, and that which is towards the lateral part of the Skull is lower. The foremore and deeper parts, are near to the Mammillary procees, and if we believe Piccolhomineus, Bauhinus, Riolanus, they are in ome manner tranpaable, epecially in elderly perons.
Moreover they run out in their hinder part by a traight Coure, where they form a Cavity which is omwhat round, not unlike the Finger of a Glove; this I remember hath been omtimes wanting.

Moreover it is to be noted, that thee Ventricles do environ the lateral and hind parts of the Roots of the Spinal Marrow, which alo, under the Plexus Choroides, a part of the brain being wreathed and attenuated inwards, and upwards making the Concameration of the Ventricles, doth embrace with a elvidge as it were and a Fringe or lace, which the praie worthy Sylvius wont o to call for likenes ake, it being knit to the was foreaid roots by exceeding thin threds. If gently lifting up the Plexus, you hall remove this lace from the Root, you hall find little Arteries creeping through the lower urface of the Ventricle, continued to the Ne • -like Coronet of little Arteries inveting the root; by help of which, this Lace eems to tick more cloe to the Root.
But here you hall oberve, that there is an eaie outgate for the Humors contained in the aid Ventricles, which may decend down along the pinal Marrow.

They are therefore formed, not inCorpus Calloum. the Brain, but in the marrow, where they call it Corpus Calloum, becaue the ubtance is there harder like a Callus, where the Ventricles eem to ret upon the two foremore Extuberancies.

The Conformation of the VentriclesThe Conformation of the Ventricles of the Brain. of the brain, which all cannot eaily dicerne, I have by Anatomical Inpection and the Guidance of Sylvius, learnt to be thus.

Two Roots of the Spinal Morrow do penetrate a good depth into the ubtance of the brain; to the upper and former whereof, epecially where it looks inward, the brain being continued (now I mean the whiteih and Ah-coloured part by the term Brain) it preads it elf every way, epecially outwards and backwards and by little and little wreathes and contracts its lower extremities inward and upwards, till at lat being attenuated, it doth on all ides embrace the Root of the pinal Marrow with a lace, a little below the place where it prings therefrom, as was aid before; and o forms the lateral Ventricles.

But in the foremore and inner part, and whiteih ubtance acending from each Root, and making one body cal'd Corpus Calloum, it is carried back; and covering the middle ditance between the Roots, which is the third Ventricle, and the wide mouths of the lateral Ventricles opened thereinto framed by it elf, it makes the Fornix, Arch or Vault; and is continued to the hinder and inner part of the Limbus or edge of each Ventricle.

Regius adds many pores in the Ventricles; looking into the Fiberkies of the ubtance of the brain, in which the Animal pirit is bred. But thoe pores and Fiberkies are inviible to the Eyes of Anatomits.

They are ditinguihed by a looe andSeptum lucidum. wrinkeld Partition-Skin: which if it be tretched out and held againt the light, it hines becaue of its tranparency, and is therefore cal'd Septum lucidum: which ome will have to pring from a mot thin portion of the brain it elf, others from the pia Mater doubled. But the former opinion is truer, which you may perceive, if after the manner of Sylvius having removed the brain and ickle of the other ide, you hall earch the Ventricle of the oppoite part, and hall lift up that part of the brain which is continued with the Corpus Calloum, at the Orifice of the third ventricle; for then it may eaily be een, and dicerned to be a mal portion of the brain.
The lower, whiteih part, where the ventriclesFornix. are joyned, is termed

FORNIX the Arch, or Tetudo the Belly of a Li • e, being of a Triangular Figure, coniting of three hanks, one before and two behind. In the common Method of Diection, this body is uppoed to be pred out over the third ventricle, and to lie beneath the Corpus Calloum.

Under the Fornix according to the obervation of Sylvius the Cheroides plexus of both ides, is immediately carryed, tending towards the Glandula pinealis; under which Plexus, in its upper part, the two Roots of the pinal Marrow grow together; o that here the Tetudo, is not eated immediately under the third ventricle.

div.p: The third Ventricle commonly o called,The third Ventricle. or the long Chink, is the meeting together of the Ventricles aforeaid, which is formed in the Centre, as it were of the Marrow of the Brain, by reaon of the Conjuction of two round Trunks proceeding out of the Brain. It hath in it two paages, the firt foremore, going downwards to the Glandula pituitaria, that it may there void its Excrements: the other is hindermore, cloathed with a Membrane; which hole ome call Anus, the Fundament; it goes beneath the Buttocks to the noble Ventricle, that the prepared matter of the Animal pirits, may pas into the place and Womb as it were of their Generation.
This hole is nothing ele but a pace ariing upon the mutuall contact of theThe Anus, what it is? four Trunks of the pinal Marrow,

Now the Nates or Buttocks, and the Tetes or Stones are four Orbicular prominences,The Nates and Tetes. which they ay are in the Brain, which is falf. They call the two portions of the Roots of the Medulla oblongata, which arie from the Brainlet, Nates; and thoe two little ones of the Roots from the Brain, they call Tetes. And thee parts are lower, the other upper.
Thee differences, as Fr. Sylvius notes, between the Tetes and the Nates, have place in Brutes rather then in Men; for the Men they are commonly equal, and many times the Tetes are the bigger.
But it is a trifling peice of buines to impoe uch Names as thee; as alo when theyPenis. Vulva. call the Glandula pinealis, Penis, and a certain long ditch between the Eminences they term Vulva.

Between the fore-more Ventricles o called, and the Seat of the Tetudo, thereThe Plexus Choroidis, what? is, the Plexus Choroidis or Reticularis o called, being a contexture of very mal Veins and Arteries, ent partly from the Arteries, partly from the Veels of the dura Mater in the fourth Ventricle. There is a glandulous ubtance interwoven within this Plexus, and a portion of the pia Mater. The Plexus Choroides being truly glandulous, does receive a little branch of the Carotick artery, which pierces into the lower part of the brain, which ends about the Glandula pinealis, where it branches up and down through the lower Surface of the Ventricle.
The Ue hereof is the ame with that of the Rete mirabile.

At the beginning of that hole, which paes from the middle Ventricle into the nobleGlandula pinealis. Ventricle, there is placed a certain Glandule or Kernel, termed Pinealia the Pine-kernel Glandule, becaue it is fahioned like the Kernel of a Pine-apple. The Greeks call it conarion or om • cono • ides, ome term it the Yard of the brain
It is of an hard ubtance, of a yellowih and omtimes dark colour, and is covered with a thin Membrane. In Creatures newly kil'd tis large, in old karcaes, being melted it is carce apparent, or is very mall, as alo in men, whoe brains cannot be opened whil't they are warm. And therefore they ay it pends like Camphire expoed to the air, being alo partly melted, as Salt is in a moit place.
According to the Obervation of Sylvius a nervous little tring does faten this Kernel as it tands betwixt the Tetes.
Who alo oberved more then once certain granes of and in this Kernel, and omtimes alo a little tone as big as the fourth part of a peae, and omwhat round.

The Ue of this Pine-kernel is like that of other kernels, and epecially to help the ditribution of Veels through the brain. Some will have it placed like a Valve before the hole which paes into the fourth Ventricle.

Des Cartes and his Followers Meyonerius, Regius, Hogelandius, do conceive that this Kernel being placed in the middle of the Ventricles, which when a man is awake are ditended with Spirits perpetually, does 1. Receive the motions of all Objects. 2. That the Soul in this part done by thee motions, does apprehend all external enible Objects, and all the Ideas proceeding from the five Senes, as in a Centre, and dicern the ame, and does afterward by help thereof end Spirits into all parts; as in a mal Sphaerical glas, all things are received in the ame order in which they are either in a Field or Chamber.

For this caue Meyonerius will have it to be of a conick Figure, becaue Individuals require more pace then orts or kinds of things. And that thee Idea's are diverly moved by the motion of the animal pirit, but are alwaies found joyned by the Verb EST, and according to their equality or inequality, truth or falhood is compounded, being compared together like two Lines.

And that for this caue Infants do not preently peak nor reaon, becaue the lappines of their brain gives not paage to the Idea's. And that the overgreat and confued motion of thee Idea's in the Pine-hap'd kernel, makes ravenings, as in perons drunk, phrentick, &c.
But many things there are which will not uffer me to embrace this new and witty Opinion. For

list.item: 1. It is too mall and obcure a body, to be able to repreent clearly the Species of all things.
2. The Species of all Senes do not come hither, becaue the Nerves do not touch the Kernel.
3. It is placed in the Quarter of Excrements, whether they are purged out, by the third, and two foremore Ventricles, where the Species or Repreentations of things would be defiled.

4. The Species of things are perceived rather there whereto they are carried. But every enory Nerve each in its place carries the Species to the beginning of the pinal Marrow, and therefore each in their place are judged and received by the Soul, in the beginning of the pinal Marrow. Moreover this Marrow is big enough, globous, hard, and of a brighter colour.

5. Several Idea's would be confounded in this little body. The Eye indeed being likewie very mall, receives the Species or Repreentations of things without Conuion, but they are only the viible Species; whereas in this Kernel the divers Species of different Senes are to be received.
6. There is hence no open or known paage to the Nerves, as from the beginning of the Marrow, nor any communion with ome Nerves of the external enes.

div.p: The Ue of the Cavities or Ventricles That the Ventricles of the Brain erve to receive Excrements. of the brain is, to be the Receptacles of Excrements, which is apparent.

list.item: 1. From their Structure: for an hole goes from the Cavities to the Glandula pituitaria.
2. The Surface of the Ventricles is continually moitned with a watry Humor.
3. They are often found topful of flegm and watry moiture.

div.p: Howbeit in this new Section afterThe order of the parts to be hewn in the new way of Diection. the neck of the funnel is hewed with the Glandula: the Marrow being lifted up, firt of all the Nates and the Tetes are een, and then the hole into the noble Ventricle; afterwards divers Nerves, the, Ventricles of the brain with the hole into the funnel the Corpus calloum, the Fornix, the Plexus Choroides, and the Glandula pinealis.

But in the old and common way ofThe order of the parts in the old Diection. Diection, thee parts of the brain are hewed in order: The Corpus calloum, the Septum tenue, the two Extuberances, upon which the Ventricles ret; the two Ventricles, commonly called the foremore; the Fornix, the Plexus Choroidis, the third Ventricle, its two holes, the Glandula pinealis; and the brainlet being a little removed, the Nates and Tetes the brainlet, the worm-fahion'd Procees, the noble Ventricle, the Pelvis, Glandula pituitaria, and Rete mirabile.

But if you will ue the middle way of Diection, familiar to Fr. Sylvius, thusThe order in the middle way of Diection. you hall proceed. Take off the Skull as deep as conveniently you can. Then uffering the left ide of the brain to remain untoucht, with its Membrane; begin your Diection on the right ide, firt of all cutting aunder and removing the dura Mater; then take away ome particles of the brain with the pia Mater, til you come to the Cavity of the Ventricle, and then follow both its upper and lower paage with your Diection, as you eeThe Diection of the right ide. it done in the econd Table. Separate the Limbus if you pleae, with a blunt probe, from the root of the Spinal Marrow, and hew it; though that may be more conveniently done in the oppoite ide of the Brain. The greatet part of the right ide of the Brain being thus taken away, the upper and lower Cavities of the Sickle are to be hewn, as alo the greater right ide lateral Cavity, and the oblique decend of the upper Cavity thereinto, all which you have expreed in the foreaid Table.

Thee things being thus done, go to the left ide, and therein firt cut aunderThe Diection of the left ide. the dura Mater, and remove it with the Falx or Sickle; then gently remove the left ide of the Brain, into the place of the right ide newly removed; and as you are doing this oberve from Tab. 3. the Veels going into the lateral Cavity, and how they rie up about the optick nerves, and are ditributed into very many branches, creeping every where up and down the inner Subtance of the brain, and epecially the winding Surface thereof, til at lat they end into the Carotick Arteries. Then earch out that ame notable chink or clift, between the windings,
which is figured out in the Table aforeaid; and having cut the pia Mater, open the ides thereof a litlittle with a Spa •• er, that the branches of the Carotides may better appear, which are carried through the bottom of the turnings, with the Rudiments of new windings. But if, before you hall begin to hew the brain, you hall free theAn excellent Argument for the Circulation of the Blood. Carotick Arteries and the jugular Veins from the parts adjacent in the Neck, and bind them ditinctly; and then by a Wound made in an Artery hall put in a crooked hollow probe and blow; the veels dieminated through the whole brain wil wel, as being branches of the Carotick Arteries, until the air with the forced blood hall at length empty it elf into the Ventricles: if by the foreaid hollow probe, you hall in like manner blow into the Ventricles, you will perceive their continuation and communion with the jugular Veins, by the welling and ditention of the aid Veins; and will acknowledg that the Circulation of the blood, is not a little confirmed by this pleaant Spectacle.

Hence, returning to a farther earch into the fabrick of the brain, and a wary Inciion being made in the hinder part of the ide propounded, earch there for the larger Cavity of the Ventricle, and follow it with your Diection to both the Ends; then turn back every way the outer part of that which is diected, the middle part being kept upright, which rets upon the root of the Spinal Marrow, and is continued therewith, which is excellently well expreed in Table the ixt, in the Explication whereof, what you ee et down, weigh in order.

Finally, taking away the Brain, oberve again all the Cavities and that more ditinctly; and then when you have een the third Ventricle, the Funnel, the Glandula pituitaria, the pares of Nerves, after the uual manner; go back again to the Penis, Anus, Tetes, Nates, &c. and examine the brainlet and its parts.

Nor will it be unprofitable, as often as a new occaion of Diection is offered, o often to change the ection in ome part; for o it will come to pas, that you will alwaies oberve omwhat which was unoberved before, or neglected, or not ditinctly enough conidered.

div.head: Chap. VII. Touching the Forehead.
div.p: THe Hairy part of the Head beingWhy Mens Face, is void of Hair? explained, the mooth part or FACE follows, which in man is void of Hairs, otherwie then i • is in Beats, for Beauties ake; it is alo called Vultus becaue of the judgment of the wil, which is Conpicuous of the Face.

The upper part thereof, viz. the Forehead is termed Frons a ferendo from carrying,Frons why o called? as ome conceive, becaue it carries in it tokens of the mind: the ret thereof, from the Eye-brows to the Chins end, is the lower part, in which are many other parts, which are hereafter to be explained in order, external and internal, the Organs of the Senes, Mucles of the Eyes, Noe, Lips, &c.

The Skin of the Forehead, becaue it is moved, therefore it hath Mucles, whichIts Skin. Platerus terms the ignifiers of the Affections of the Mind. Now the Mucles of theMucles. Forehead do lift up the Eye-brows, and are thicket at the aid Eye-brows.

They arie from the Skull, near the coronal Suture, and are knit at the ides to the temporal Mucles, but in the middle they are ditinguihed a little above, but beneath they are o nearly aociated, that they eem to be one Mucle, and end at the Eye-brows. Yet I have oberved in a large noed peron, that an Appendix of the aid Mucles did reach to the Gritles of the Noe.

They have traight Fibres. Surgeons therefore mut not cut them athwart, leat they detroy the lifting up of the Eye-brows; but upwards, according to their length. Homan after Aquapendent tands for oblique fibres, on the right ide from the right hand to the left, on the left ide from the left hand to the right. But this they do againt Experience, ocular Inpection, and Reaon. For the skin of the Forehead is by a traight coure, either elevated or depreed by help of right fibres, which are the caue of traight motion. In the point of right fibres, we have the Conent of great Anatomits Vealius, Laurentius, Bauhinus, Platerus, Velingus, &c.
And becaue the skin of the Forehead grows cloe to thee Mucles, therefore both the Forehead and the Eye-brows are moved.

Howbeit there are omtimes alo two Mucles in the binder part of the Head, which move the skin thereof, hort, thin and broad, with traight fibres, ending above into a broad Tendon, and touching the hindermore Mucles of the Ears, in their ides. Some men that are furnihed with thee Mucles, can draw the skin of their Heads backwards.

div.head: Chap. VIII. Of the Eyes.
div.p: THe Eyes are termed Oculi ab occultando The Eyes why called Oculi? or occludendo from hutting or hiding, becaue they are hid under the Eye-lids; they are the Intruments of Sight made of Humors, Membranes, Mucles, Veels, and other Parts.
They are eated in an eminent placeTheir Situation. like Watch-men, in boney Sockets covered with the Periotium for better Safeguards ake.

They are in Number two, for theTheir Number. perfection of Sight, and that one being defective, the other may upply its place and office. Howbeit both-Eyes ee but one Object, at one and the ame time, and not a double one, whether becaue the knowing and judging Faculty is one, as Aquapendent conceives, or becaue the Axle-tree of the two viual Pyramides, do pas along upon the ame Surface of a plane as Galen expounds the matter; or becaue of the exact imilitude they have received from particular things from whence they came, the internal ene judging only one and the ame pecies, as Aquiloniu •
does philoophize. They are in Mankind very little ditant one from another, both for the Nobility and perfection of their Action, and the Reception of viible pecies.
They are round; but a little longih,Their Shape. like bulbous Roots whereupon
Two Angles or Corners are made, at the Socket of the Eyes, which are termed Canthi; the inner and greater at the Noe, the outer and leer at the Temples.

In and about the Eye, there are undry parts, ome without the Eye, for afeguardIts Parts. or commodities ake, as the Eye-lids with their Hair and the Eye-brows, alo Caruncles in the Corners of the Eyes; other parts there are which con
•… the Eye it elf, and they are Fat, Mucles, Membranes and Humors.

Palpebrae the Eye-lids are parts which cover and hut the Eye, which cleneThe Eye-lids. and putrifie the Cornea Tunica, and likewie by their overhadowing render the Picture in the Retina more illutrious, according to the opinion of Averrhoes, Varolius Plempius.
The are made up of the Skin, the Membrana carnoa, Mucles, a Coat, the Tari and Hairs: and therefore their ubtance is oft,

The Eye-lid, is either the lower which if we believe Galen, is of it elf immovable,Whether the lower Eye-lid be moved? ave in ome birds. Yet Bauhin and Aqua-pendent do aver that they are really moved, and Fallopius proves it by the example of a Sea-Calf, and any one may prove the ame in a Looking-glas, wherein he may ee his lower Eye-lid meet the upper. But either this motion is obcure or we mut ay with Vealias and Sylvius that the upper part of the circular Mucle doth lift up the upper part of the Eye-lid, and that the lower part is drawn down, by the other part of the Mucle, which notwithtanding is not true, becaue the traight Mucle lift up; or we mut ay with Piccolhomineus that they follow the motion of the Cheeks; or finally, the Orbicular Mucles only moves the upper Eyelid, and doth but embrace the lower, and knit it is a coupler. The other is the upper, which is moved and that mot wiftly. o that we compare a quick motion to the twinkling of the Eye.

Now they are moved upwards, that is to ay are opened and lifted up byThe Mucles of the Eye-lids. the right Mucle which is les then the other. It aries about the Optick Nerve, and ends with a Tendon into the Extremities of the Eye-lid. They are moved downwards, that is
The VII. TABLE.
The Explication of the FIGURES.
This TABLE repreents the Mucles of the Eye in their natural Situation, and the Mucle of the Eye-lid by it elf.
FIG. I.

BB. The inner and whiteih portion of the Brain diected.
CC. The Brainlet or Cerebellum
D. The meeting and union of the Optick Nerves.
EE. The parting of the aid Nerves going to each Eye.
F. The Caruncula Lachrymalis drawn out of its place.
GG. The firt Mucle of the Eye called Attollens.
H. In the right Eye, hews the econd Eye-mucle, or the Muculus deprimens.
II. In both Eyes hews the Muculi recti interni or Adducentes.
KK. In each Eye hews the recti externi or Abducentes.
L. The Muculus quintus, or obliquus externus, is hewed in the right Eye.
MM. The ixt Mucle or the obliquus, internus, whoe Tendon paes through the Pully, N.
O. Shews the optick Nerve in the right Eye.
P. The Cornea Tunica, in the midt whereof is the Pupilla.
FIG. II.
A. The optick Nerve.
B. The Nerves which moves the Eye.
C. The Trochlearis Muculus, whoe Tendon, E. goes through the Pulley, D.
F. G. The Muculi recti, internal and external.
H. The Mucle proper to the upper Eye-lid, contained within the Socket of the Eye.
III. The Eye-lids cut out off.
KK. The Cilia, that is the Ends of the Eye-lids adorned with Hair.
page 144
to ay are hut and covered, by a certain Orbicular or Circular Mucle, which is every way half a Fingures breadth, ariing from the Root of the Noe, which afterwards runs back with circular Fibres, under the lower Eye-lid, through the outward corner, and ends above the upper Eye-lid, at the ame place of the inner corner. Spigelius and others do divide it into the upper and lower Mucle, becaue each hath a different Nerve coming from divers places, and they oberved that in the Convulio canina o called, omtime the lower Eye-lid was tif, the upper being moveable. But no diviion of this Mucle can be dicerned by the harpet Eye-ight, the Fibres being every where continued, though the inertion of the Nerves be different as it is in ome other Mucles, of the Noe &c.

The Membrana carnoa is thin in this place, together with the Mucles, likeThe Membranes. another imple thin Membrane; and therefore Aritotle aid that the Skin of the Eye-lid was without fleh, and being cut off, like the Fore-skin, it grows not again.
They are cloathed with an inner Coat pringing from the Pericranium, exceeding thin and oft, leat they hould hurt the Eyes, which they touch.

The Extremities of the Eye-lids are hard and Gritley; but oft like mal Gritles, and Semicircular, the Greeks term them Tarous, the Latins CILIA whereon the Hairs are fatnedThe Cilia, what? (which ome term Cilia) being traight becaue ituate in an hard place, keeping all waies in a manner the ame greatnes hindering mal and light matters from falling into the Eye, and erving to direct the fight which Galen proves from uch as have them fallen or pulled off, who can hardly dicerne things afar off, epecially if they be of a dark colour, which Montaltus doth prove by the example of a youth at Lisbon.

The SUPERCILIA or Eye-brows, are Hairs growing at the bottom of theThe ue of the Eye-brow. Forehead, above the Eyes, intercepting uch things, as fall from the Head that they may not light into the Eyes.

CARUNCULA a mal portion of fleh, is placed at each great corner of the Eye, containing Humor to moiten the Eye; and it is placed over an hole bored in the Noe-bone, which isPunctum lachrmyale called Punctum lachrymale (ditinct from thee two holes in the edge of the Eyelids, which Galen call Tremata, and are mot viible in living bodies, epecially of uch as are inclined to weeping) leat we hould continually weep. But in an Oxe there is moreover a moveable Membrane, which can hut the Eye, though the Eye-lid be open, by help whereof Brutes wink and cover their Eyes, when they fear any thing hould fall into or hit them.
In the paces between the mucles and undry Veels, there is fat, whichThe ue of fat in the Eye. heats, moitens, and o helps the motion of the Eye, and makes it round and even.

The MUSCLES of Mens Eyes areThe Eye mucles. ix. Becaue they have o many ditinct motions: four traight and two circular: all are eated within the Cavity of the Skul, and accompany the optick Nerve. All their Tendons being joyned together at the tunica Cornea, under the Adnata, do make that Coat which Columbus call Tunica innominata, the Nameles coat, as if it Columbus his Error. had not been known to the ancients, whereas Galen hath made mention thereof, in his tenth Book de Uu partium Chap. 2. & 8. though it be not properly a Coat, but only divers Tendons of Mucles, nor doth it compas the whole Eye. Yet by ome it is called Tunica Tendinoa or Tendinea, the Tendinous Coat.
The firt Mucle being the upper andThe firt Mucle of the Eye. thicker is called Attollens the lefter up or Superbus, the proud Mucle.

The econd oppoite to the other, being the maller in the lower part, is termedThe econd Deprimens the depreer, and Muculus humilis the lowly Mucle, becaue it draws the Eye downwards towards the Cheek-balls.
The third placed in the greater Angle isThe third. called Adducens, the drawer to, and Bibitorius the drinking Mucle, moving the Eye inwards towards the Noe.
The fourth is called Abducens the drawerThe fourth. from, drawing the Eye towards the ide of the Face to the mal cornerward; tis alo termed Indignatorius the Mucle of indgnation.

All thee four Mucles have the ame beginning, the ame progres and end: for the beginning of them all is acute, near the hole where the optick Nerve enters into the Socket of the Eye, from the Membrane wherof they do arie: they have all a flehy and round belly: their end is a very mal Tendon, as was aid, at the Cornea.
By thee four acting together the Eye is drawn inwards, and is kept from trring, which holding is by Phyitians called Motus tonicus.

The fift is lean, round, hort, oblique, The fift. eated between the Eyes and the Tendons of the econd and third Mucle, and acending by the outer corner of the Eye, to the upper part of the Eye, is inerted into the Cornea tunica by the Region of the Iris. It whirles about the Eye obliquely downwards to the external Angle, or corner.

The ixt being the mallet of all, andThe ixt or pulley Mucle. having the longet Tendon, wheels the Eye about unto the inner Corner. For ariing from a common beginning with the firt four, it is carried right out to the inner Corner; there it paes through the Pulley, and acends in a right Angle to that place where the fift was inerted. 'Tis called Trochlea Muculus the Pully-mucle, becaue it wheeled about as it were through a Pulley which Pulley is a Gritle in the Eye ticking out, firt oberved by Fallopius, though Riolanus do alo attribute the Invention thereof to Rondeletius who lived at the ame time with him. Tis ituate at the upper Jaw-bone, by the inner corner of the Eye, and therefore in the Cure of Fitula lachrymalis, the Surgeons ought to have a great care, leat they wrong this Pully,
Thee two lat are termed Amatorij, love Mucles, and Circumactores, rowling Mucles the upper and lower. For by the help of thee Mucles lovers cat Sheeps-Eyes one at another.
There is yet a eventh Mucle in Brutes,A eventh Mucle in Brutes. which may be divided into two, three, or four.
This is a hort Mucle, compaing the optick Nerve, fat coming between, and being flehy it is inerted into an hard Coat.
Its Ue is; to hold up the Eyes of Brutes which look down towards the Ground, and to enwrap the oft optick Nerve.
An eigth membranous Mucle may be added, wherewith Brutes do wink.

Some Animals have no Mucles. Scaliger proved it by Diection in Cats, yet Caerius pictures out the Mucle of a Cats Eye. A Chameleon indeed hath no Mucles, and yet moves his Eyes every way, and either of them backwards, and that by a wrinkled membrane furniht with Fibres, as Panarolus does aver.
Veels are ent to the Eye, a Vein from the Jugulars, an Artery from the Caroticks,Veels of the Eye. dieminated through the Mucles, Fat, and Membrane.

The Eyes have the two firt pare of Nerves, as they are commonly reckoned:The Nerves. The firt is the Optick or eeing pare being thick and porous, carrying from the Brain the Faculty of eeing with the Spirit, or carrying the viible Repreentations of things to the Brain. It is inerted behind, into the Centre of the Tunica cornea, to which from the hard Tunicle or external Membrane it communicates a Coat, and paes more inward to the Centre of the Retina, into which its marrowy ubtance is pred abroad; and omtimes a portion of the vitrea tunica, ticks to the inner part of the Marrow. In Brutes it is inerted obliquely, and not into the Centre of the cornea tunica, but into the ide. The econd is the Moving pare, which goes into the Membranes, and ends a little Branch into every mucle. • ut touching thee Nerves I hal dicoure more largely in my Manual of the Nerves.

The Membranes beides the external and the conjunctive (which isThe Membranes of the Eyes but three. common) are but three and the Humors three. And as in a Nerve, there is a threefold ubtance which enters the Eye: o thee three ubtances do make the three Coats of the Eye. For the firt Coat aries from the dura Mater; the econd from the pia Mater; the third from the marrowy ubtance in the Brain.

The Tunica adnata alba or conjunctiva is mooth and thin, ariing fromAdnata Tunica. the Pericraneum. Some will have it arie from the Perioteum, and end at the Circle of the Iris, after it hath communicated a Coat to the Eyelid. It is the outmot Coat of all, next the bone. Hippocrates calls it the White of the Eye.
It fatens the Eye to the Socket and inner Bones like a Ligament.Its Ue.
It is of exquiite Sene.

It is prinkled about with very many little Veins and Arteries, not appearingThe Seat of the Ophthalmia or Blearey'dnes. ave when there is an Afflux of Humors, for then they well and are very red as in the Opththalmia or Blearey'd orenes, which Dieae is eated in the Part.

This Adnata being removed, the firt that offers it elf, is the Sclirotica or dura 1. Tunicle of the Eye. o called, which aries from the dura Mater, and it is thick, tretched, equal, and dark on the back part. The forepart of this they call tunica Cornea, becaueCornea. it is polihed and tranparent like an horn: for it may be caled into four plates, over which the Epidermis is placed, and involves the whol forepart of the Eye. It is next the clirotica or dura, firmly cleaving in the hinder part of the Choroides, yet joyned with the Chrytalline in the middle, that it may eparate the watry and glaie Humors.

The econd is called Choroides, becaue it is like the Chorion, and Veels are2. Tunicle of the Eye. prinkled up and down. It aries from pia Mater, being from the firt Original blackih, epecially within, that the Idea's received in a dark place, might be the more illutrious. In Brutes it is of everal Colours, omtimes watchet, &c. Under the tranparent Cornea it is in men omtimes skiecolour'd, omtimes blew, or grey, which Colours are een through the Cornea. This in its forepart is termed Uvea, by reaon it is of the colour of a Grape, in which part it is thick and doubled: it is moveable and according to the diverity of the Object or Light, it is contracted and dilated, as we may very well dicern in Cats. This forepart is alo perforated in the middle, to let in the Species or Repreentations of viible Objects, where

The Pupilla or ight of the Eye is formed,The Pupilla. which in Mankind is round: in ome Brutes of an oblong hape, or long and round. Riolanus hath oberved the compas of this hole or the Crown thereof, being drawn with the point of a Penknife, to have been cut off orbicularly, which may better be een in an Ox eye boyled, which makes him think this Circumference to be a ditinct Membrane from the Uvea, ince it hath peculiar fibres. But this is confuted by Plempius, and becaue the Verge of the uvea tunica hath divers colours, hence aries

The Iris or Circle, which Galen, Caerius, Riolanus Iris. reckon to be ixfold, and Plempius but threefold: a double narrow one at the White of the Eye, a third at the Sight true and larger, illutrated with a contant colour. This Circle is een variouly coloured, and where it makes the Iris, it is omtimes skie-coloured, otherwhiles fierie, grey, black, &c.

From the Circumference of the Uvea, where its duplicated MembraneLigamentum ciliare. bends it elf back to the Chrytalline, there aries a Ligament or Intertitium ciliare o called, which are certain then filaments produced out of the Uvea repreenting the black Lines of the Eye-lids, like Hairs, and they compas the Chrytalline humor, which by help of thee is knit to the neighboring parts: it is moved with the Uvea being moveable. Carteius will have its ue to be to move the Chrytalline, that the Situation thereof may be changed, according to the various neceity of ight.

The third is the Retina or Amphibletroides as the Greeks call it, that is the Netfahion'dThe third Coat. Coat, made of the inner ubtance of the Brain or of ome Nerve pred out as it were, the pia Mater withal accompanying in the ame, if we believe Galen and Caerius. Therefore this oft, and as it were notty matter may be gathered together, compaing the vitreous Humor and its vitreous Coat like a Net. It is an exceeding thin coat, but more dark then lightom, mixt with an obcure Rednes, becaue the Species received, are here topped and repreented; yet is it a little notty, with which Snot is omtimes white, for the illutration of the Species received. In my Judgment, it is the limines of the marrowy Subtance.
Its Figure is emicircular, like a Mitre, and its ides are near the Chrytalline, for the ditinct Repreentation of the Species.

p.U: aies it hath no Veels; contrary to Galen, Caerius, Sylvius and others, and Experience it elf: for the hinder part of the Choroides and the clirotica tunica, have Veels manifetly apparent in this Coat, and there they ought to be, that it may be nourihed with its contents. This compaing yet farther becomes the Aranea or Chrytalloides,Aranea. the proper Tunicle of the Chrytalline Humor, cloathing the fore and hinder part thereof, white, mot thin and tranparent, o that it is cal'd the Looking-glas.
