div.p: I add the tunica Vitrea, which covers the vitreousVitrea. or glaie Humor on all ides, that it run not about, and eparates it from the Chrytalline Humor. It is of exceeding moothnes and thinnes, hed about the Humor like a thin Skin, not only in the convex part of the aid Humor, but alo in its concave part, where it receives the Chrytalline, where indeed it cleaves cloe to the Chrytalline Coat, but is different from it. It is furnihed with many, but very little Veins, and the inner portion of the marrowy Subtance of the Optick Nerve, cleaves to the Centre thereof. The form is uch as that of the glaie Humor, large and convex behind, and concave before.
The Humors of the Eyes are three, the watry, the glaie, and the Chrytalline: ofHumors of the Eyes. which the lat is the mot noble, and by ome termed the Soul and Centre of the eyes.

The watry becaue thin and fluxive likeThe watry Humor. water, occupies the whole pace between the Tunica cornea, and the fore part of the Chrytalline. Riolanus alo proves that it is poured round about the vitreous Humor, and that all of it is contained within the whole uvea tunica; becaue the Eye being cut in the hinder part, water flows out as much as if it were cut before. But if the vitrea tunica be alo cut with a large Wound, no wonder if water flow from thence, which Plempius alo notes; not to ay how eaily the inner parts are broken, when they are rudely fingred. In the Humor Suffuions are made.

This Humor is no animated part,The watry Humor is no animated part, the other Humors are. but eems only to be an Excrement remaining after the Nutrition of the Chrytalline Humor: for it is both conumed in Dieaes, and lot in Wounds of the Eyes; the other two humors are animated parts, eeing they have their proper circumcription, are nourihed with blood brought Veinlets, when perihed they are not retored, and are bred in the Womb: and the Chrytalline of the mot pure lightful part of the Seed.

The Ue of the watry Humor is to defend the bordering parts from drines: others add, that as a medium it erves to break the brightnes continually flowing in, and to greaten the Repreentations of the Objects, being traitned in the Pupilla or Sight.

The Vitreous or glaie Humor is een behind, like molten Glas, ofter thenThe vitreous of glaie bumor. the Chrytalline, then which it is nevertheles five times bigger, and twice as big as the watry Humor. It is round in its hinder part, plane before, but being concave in the middle, it makes an hollownes wherein the Chrytalline Humor is placed as in a Pillow. Its Ue is not barely to nourih the Chrytalline, as Galen conceived, but to prepare and communicate Nourihment thereto. According to Aquapendent from whom Riolanus had the notion, that the light carried beyond the chrytalline may not return defiled by dark and other coloured tinctures, and o diturb the Sight. Platerus more rightly, that the plendid vitreous Humor might fill up a neceary pace between the Chrytalline and the Retina, which others explain more clearly, that the glaie. Humor may give a paage to the Species to the Retina, and may refract them from Perpendiculars.

The Chrytalline (which ome call the icie becaue of its firmnes) is o calledThe Chrytalline. from its exceeding bright and hineing colour, which it hath, being free from all other colours, that it may receive all colours, it is hineing, indifferently •• rd round behind, with ome longnes, flat on the foreide: howbeit according to the undry affections of the Eye, this form is variouly changed.

Its Ue is, to be the chief Medium of ight, as a glas held before the hole, receives the external pecies into a dark Cloet, even o the Chrytalline Humor, both receives and collects the Species or Repreentations of things. And becaue the humor is tranparent, the Species are no • topped therein, nor colours perceived, which mot Anatomits have beleived after Galen; for otherwie there were no reaon why they hould not be as well perceived in the Cornea, and vitreous Humor, both tranparent and animated. Therefore the ight is not primarily made in this Humor, but the Species are dicerned in the retina tunica, becaue there they are topped by a dark Body, as we een on the Wall of a Chamber, when the Windows are hut.

Scheinerus conceives, that the Species which did repreent all things the bottom upwards, are corrected and refracted in the Chrytalline Humor, o as to repreent all things in their due poture. But according to the Obervation of Job. Walaeus, Fr. Sylvius, and Fr. Vander Schagen, the Choroides, the Sclirotica, and Retina tunica, being taken away from behind, all things are een by the Eye, and repreented with the bottom upwards; very mall in an Oxes Eye, omwhat greater in a Mans. Plempius proves the ame by an Experiment of a glas Intrument filled with the three Humors, placed before the hole of the Window, where all things appear on the Wall with the wrong ide upwards. And doubtles the Species mut needs be repreented with the bottom upwards in the Retina, otherwie we hould ee all things the wrong end upwards, and not right, which Keplerus hereby demontrates, becaue in paion the Patients mut be jut oppoite againt the Agents.

Others will have it, that our Judgment corrects the depraved Figure, which dicerns the jut Magnitude of things by very mall Species received. Others alledg the common Sene, which eeing the inverted pecies, behind and above the Cavity of the Retina, apprehends them in their true poture. Finally others ay that a true Judgment is therefore made, becaue it is made by a right Line.

div.head: Chap. IX. Concerning the Ears.
div.p: THe Organ of Hearing, viz. the EARS are either external or internal.
The external which are by ome termed Auriculae the Earlets, are in Mankind of a emicircular Figure, convex without, concave within.
The outer Ear is divided into the upper and lower part.
The upper is broader, and by omeNames of the parts of the outer Ear. called Pinna, by others Ala. The lower is oft and hanging down, termed Fibra, Auricula infima, Lobus.

The outer Circumference of the Ear is called Helix, alo Capreolus, becaue of its wreathed formed. The inner part oppoite to the former, is termed Scapha or Anthelix. In the middle hereof is a large Cavity, the principal part of the external Ear, called Concha. But the Cavity near the Meatus auditorius or Hearing-paage, where Ear-wax is collected, is cal'd Alvearium. Towards the Temples there grows a certain eminency like a covering, which either receives or hinders
things that would go into the Eare, and is termed Hircus the Goat, becaue Hairs grow thereon.
The Parts whereof the external Ear is compoed, are either common, as the Skarf-Skin, the Skin, a Nervous Membrane, Fleh, and a little Fat in the Lobe: Or Proper, as Mucles, Veels, and a Gritle.

The Skin is exceeding thin, cleaving to a little Fleh with a firm Gritle; and as inIts Skin. the Palms of the Hands a Nervous Membrane is firmly faten'd thereto; by the ene whereof it happens that cold water prinkled on the Lap or Lobe of the Ear doth cool the whole Body. In the Lobe it is o mingled with Fleh, that it becomes thereby fattih, flehy and pungy: Hence the Lobe is oft and flexible, o that it may be bored with no great trouble, and therefore ome hang Jewels and Ear-rings thereon.
As to Veels: it hath Veins from the Jugulars.It Veels.
Arteries from the Carotides.
Little Nerves, two from behind, and two from the ides, ariing from the econd pair termed Cervicale.

Mucles rightly conpicuous in uch as move their Ears, are common orThe Mucles. proper. which it was my luck once to ee, and uch Jutinian mut have had, whoe Ears could move as Procopius decribes him. But in mot people the Ears are unmoveable, both becaue of the malnes of the Mucles, andWhy few move their Ears? becaue there was little need of their motion, becaue a Man can do that with his Hands which Beats do with their Ears, wherewith they drive away flies.

The firt Mucle is common to the EarThe ue of the firt and each Lip; and it is a part of the firt Mucle which moves the Cheeks, and the Skin of the Face, and it is termed Quadratus, the quare Mucle, ufficiently thin and broad. It is implanted into the Root of the Ear under the Lobe, that it may draw the Ear to one ide downwards.

The econd is proper and eated more foreward, leaning upon the temporalThe ue of the econd Mucle. Mucle, from the end of the Mucle of the Forehead (from which it differs by the carriage of the Fibres) ariing omtimes with a round, otherwhiles with a corner'd beginning, and being Tendinous, it is implanted into the upper part of the Ear, where it is narrower, that it may move the Ear upwards and forewards.

The third and hinder more aries above the Proceus mammillaris, fromThe ue of the third Mucle. the hind-part of the Head and its Mucle, with a narrow beginning; afterward growing broader and divided as it were into three parts, it goes hindlongs to the Ear, that it may draw it, omwhat backwards and upwards.

The fourth ariing from the Proceus mammillaris, being broad, grows narrowerThe ue of the fourth, by little and little, till at lat it ends in a Tendon. This Mucle is rather threefold, becaue it hath three Inertions, yet all pring confued from one place. Some of thee are omtimes wanting, otherwhiles they are all found; omtimes there are more, nature variouly porting her elf in the Mucles of the Ear.
The Ears Gritle, is a ubtance tied to the Os petroum, by a trongThe Ear Gritle. Ligament pringing from the Pericranium.
Certain Kernels there are outwardlyThe Kernels cal • d Parotides. about the Ears, thick and large, which are termed Parotides, though this word do alo ignifie the wellings of the aid Kernels.
They are not only behind theTheir Situation. Ears, as is commonly imagined, but on both ides and under the Ear, but not above.
Thee Kernels by the Ears are called the Emunctories of the Brain, becaue they receive the Excrements thereof.

There are alo many other Kernels inThe • at of Kings-Evil wellings. the whole pace which is under the lower Jaw, in which many Dieaes are bred, and wellings called Scophulae in ome Creatures, as wild Swine. The common people count thee Kernels a dainty dih and cal them Sweetbreads.
Their Ue is, to moiten the parts, and to ait in the diviions of the Veels.
The Ue of the External Ear is,
I. For Ornament, and therefore the Englih, Dutch and other Nations punih Male-factors by cutting of their Ears.
II. To aveguard the Brain, that it may not be hurt by the Air uddenly ruhing in.

III. To be the Organ of Hearing,The External Organ of Hearing. not principal, but aitant. The true Organ lies within, as doth that of the welling. And as the Noe being cut off a Man can mel though imperfectly; o if the Ears be quite cut off cloe to a Mans Head, he can Hear, but dully, confuedly, with a m •• mering noie, o that Articulate words will eem as the noie of Watertreams, or the creekings of Gras-hoppers, as they know who have lot their Ears. Yea, and the Hearing of that Ear which is not cut off, is dammaged, unles the cut Ear be topped.

The Ue therefore of the External Ear, is more readily and rightly to receive ounds; and to gather them when they are cattered in the Air into the Cavity of the Ear, that they may come unto the Drum without violence, being firt moderated and allayed in the hollow and winding paages. Hence, leat ounds which are diven towards the Ears, hould lip beide, Beats turn their Ears this way and that way to ounds. Hence alo the Emperor Hadrianus; that he might heat more ditinctly, would hold the hollow of his Hand before his Ears, which alo deaf perons frequently practie. Hence ome Scythians, whoe earlets ar mortified and rottted of with cold, doth apply a Fih-hell to their Ears, that the Air being detained in the Cavity thereof, may be more eaily received, that o they may hear the better. Hence, they hear mot exactly, whoe Ears tick furthet out from their Heads, and if our Ears were not too much preed down, what by long lying upon them. what by the binding of Nures, we hould hear better then we do.
The Internal Ear hath alo undry partsThe Internal Ear. contained in the Os petroum, and beides the parts and little cavernes of the Bones, there are: The Drum, two Mucles, the Veels and inbred Air.

In the auditory paage cloathed with Skin, through which ounds are carryed, is found a Cholerick clammy humor, which the Ancients cal'd Cerumen. Earwax, being purged from the Brain but Intrinically it is obliquely placed before this hole or paage of Hearing.

There is a certain Partition, or little Orbicular Menbrane, compaed with a boney circle, which ome call Myrinx, others Sextum Membraneum and Mediatinum, others Tympanum, but ome rightly mympani Membranula. For it isTympanum. tretched before the internal Cavity containing the congenit Air, as the Parchment or Velam on a Drum Head. Caerius conceives that it aries from the Pericranium, but Velingius believe that it is an expanion of the Perioteum, who hath alo oberved it to be double, and alo frequently cruted over by thickned Excrements.
It is exceeding dry, that it may ound the better, for dry bodies are fittet for ound.

It is Tranparent thin and ubtile, that the ounds may more eaily pas throughA caue of Deafnes. to the implanted Air: For thoe that have it thick from their birth, have an incurable Deafnes, as thoe alo who have a thick Coat growing over the ame without, the Cure whereof is nevertheles taught by Paulus; and if this happen from the birth, uch perons continue for the mot part Dumb, becaue they can neither conceive in their mind nor utter with their Tongue uch words as they have never hard. But if a Snotty matter cleave thereto within, or a thick HumorA Caue of thicknes of Hearing. flow thereto, a thicknes of Hearing or a Deafnes incurbale is thereby caued. If a thin Humor flow thereto, there arie tinklings and noies in the Ears.

Finally it is Nervous, of o exquiite a Sene that, it can neither bear the putting in of a Probe, nor harp Humors; yet is it trong o as to endure againt external Injuries; for being hurt or corroded it caues thicknes of Hearing or Deafnes, as they find by experience, who have it hurt by the noie of great Guns or Bells, or in whom it is broken by wimming. For the afeguard therefore hereof, there are three little Bones added within (of which, the Hammer ticks fat to the Drum, and is een through the ame) and two Mucles.
The Ue thereof is, to hut the paage of hearing, and to eparate the innate Air from that which is external, and to keep it within. Alo to ave it from Dut, Water, creeping things, &c.

Within the Membrane of the Tympanum, thereis an Internal Cavity in theThe Cavity of the Drum. Bone, containing a certain Air, which ome term the inbred, Congenit and complanted Air, becaue it is placed in the Ears at the firt formation, being pure, ubtile and immoveable: which ome count the internal Medium of Hearing, others the Organ it elf of that Sene.
There are two Mucles of the inner Ear according to Anatomits.Mucles of the inner Ear.
They call the firt the Internal, eated in the Os petreum, with a double Tendon: The one being fixed to the higher proces of the Hammer, the other to its Neck.
Its Ue is to draw the Head of the Hammer obliquely inwards, and to carry it inwards from the Anvil, and the proces of the Hammer being bowed back, to drive the little Membrane inwards.

The econd is external, found out by Caerius, though Aquapendent doth likewie attribute to himelf the Invention thereof; it is exceeding mal, flehy, and coniting in the upper Region of the Auditory paage, with its Tendon implanted into the Centre of the Membrane, there where the Hammer is inwardly joyned to the aid Membrane. So that Parianus labours in Vain by denying this Membrane in contradiction to Caerius.
Its Ue is to draw the Membrane with the Hammer outwards.

A certain mal Gritly paage is to be oberved, which goes from the Concha of the Ear near the ides of the Pterygoidean proces, to the Palate. Fallopius aies it is a conveighance of Water, furnihed with a mal Valve, Riolanus in the mean while, an old Mater of Anatomy, denying that there is any uch Valve to be found.

The Ue hereof is, 1. To purge theWhy Maticatories help in Dieaes of the Ears? inbred Air, for this way Excrements pas from the Ear into the mouth, but, not back again, becaue there is a Valve to hinder. And this is the Reaon that Maticatories are very helpful in Dieaes of the Ears.
II. To let in ound in Deaf and topped Ears.

Varro writes and Pliny with Archelaus, that Goats draw in Breath at their Ears, which Aritotle reports of Alcmeon. And uch as are omwhat thick of hearing, do perceive words more ditinctly when they Gape, and when our Ears are topped, we can hear our own Speech though weakly. Such as have the Venereal Dieae, are hurt not only with cold Air, but with any other uneven noie, paing through their Mouth into their Ears, as Tulpius oberves, who alo hath oberved that two perons troubled with the Orthopnaea, were aved from choaking, by voiding their Breath out at their Ears, by means of this paage. Thoe do abue this paage, who render the moak of Tobacco which they take, through their Ears.

Finally, we meet with the Nervous Auditories or Hearing Nerve, which proceeds from the fift pair of the Brain, entring the Ear through the hole of Os Petroum. It touches the Cochlea and the Labyrinth with a double branch that it may in both places perfect the Hearing. To which a Branch is added to move the Mucles, proceeding from the fourth pair, and cleft in two.

div.head: Chap. X. Of the Noe.
div.p: ANother Organ of Sene follows, viz. The Noe the Intrument of melling, given to Men and fourfooted Beat that bring fourth living Creatures.
Now it is divided, as the Ear, into the External and Internal Noe.
The Internal hath Bones and Nerves,The Names of the parts of the Noe. with the Mammillary procees, of which in their place.
The External is Extrinecally divided into the upper and lower part.

The upper part which is boney and immoveable, is termed the Back of the Noe, and its Acuminated part, Spina. The lower part is Gritley and moveable, the utmot end wherof is termed Globulus and Orbiculus, by the only feeling whereof Michael Scotus pretends to tel whether a Maiden have lot her Virginity. The lateral or ide parts are termed Pterugia alae, Pinnae; that is Wings or Pinnacles, that flehy part which ticks out in the middle near the Lips, is called Columna the Pillar.

The Noe is divided within, by a partition Wall, into two Holes or Cavities which they call Nares the
Notrils: that one hole being topped, we may draw in and pas out the Air by the other. And when both are topped, the Mouth upplies the Office of the Notrils. Now each hole is again divided about the middle of the Noe into two parts: the one acends upwards, to the Os Spongioum; the other goes above the Palate into the Throat and upper part of the Mouth. Hence drink omtimes comes out at the Notrils: and things put into the Notrils, the Noe being hut, are wont to lip into the Mouth. Hence alo the thicker Excrements alo of the Brain, while they are carryed downward to the Notrils, may lide into the Mouth, or be brought thither by Hawking, and o purged out at the Mouth.
It is ituate in an high place, viz. between the Eyes. 1. For comelynes Sake. 2. Becaue all mels mount upwards.
The Magnitude varies, as alo the Figure, for ome have great Noes, others little Noes, ome Hawkenoes and Roman-noes, and others addle-noes &c. Touching which Phyiognomits Dicoure.
Its Subtance conits of the Scarf • -Skin, The parts of the Noe. Skin, Mucles, Bones, Gritles, Veels, and Tunicles.
Its Skin is thin, and void of fat, thatThe Skin. it may not grow too much; under the partion in the Colomme it is thick and Spungy; o that it is like a Gritle and is compat with Hairs termed Vibriae.

There are eight Mucles of the Noe,Mucles of the Noe. epecially in large Noed people, but they are mal becaue the motion of the Noe is little. Four erve to widen the Noe, while the Alae or Wings being drawn upwards, they open the holes of the Notrils. And there are four more which traiten the Noe.

The two firt widners being flehy, do arie from the Cheek-bone, near the Mucle of the Lips, which they make a third. They are inerted partly into a part of the upper Lip, partly into the lower Wing. Caerius found them reembling the leaves of Myrtle.

div.p: The other two which are commonly triangular, and like the Greek letter on each ide one, with a harp and flehy beginning, do grow from the Suture of the Forehead by the Foramen lachrymale or Tear-hole, and are implanted into the Spina or the Pinnae of the Noe. I have omtimes oberved an Appendix thereof to have decended to the upper Lip, viz, in uch as cannot lift up their Noe without their Lips. Caerius againt the mind of all Anatomits, draws its original from the Pinnae of the Noe; but they are moveable.

The two firt Str • itners, which are little do arie
flehy, about the Root of the Pinnae, are carried along tranverly, and inerted into the corners of the Alae. Caerius did firt of all oberve a portion thereof and decribe it, which is not alwaies found; for more often the circular Sphincter involves the Pinnae of the Noe orbicularly. The Ue thereof is a little to hut the Notrils, depreing the Pinnae.

The remaining two are exceeding firm and membranous, lying hid under the Coat of the Notrils, in the inner part. They arie from the Extremity of the Noe-bone, and are implanted into the Pinnae or Wings.

Beides thee Mucles of the Noe aforeaid, I have found on the Noe-back of a certain peron, a flehy Mucle, thin, tretched right out from the frontal mucle, with a broad Bais, and ending oon after, narrower about the outmot Gritle of the Noe.
Gritles do make up the Subtance of the lower part of the Noe, and are fiveThe Gritles of the Noe. in number.
The two uppermot being broad ones, do tick unto the Bones of the Noe, and the more they decend, the ofter they grow, o that the end of the Noe hath a ubtance, partly gritly and partly ligamental.
The third being in the middle of the other two, make sthe partition-wall between the two Notrils.
By thee are placed the other two, of which the Pinnae of the Noe are contituted, and they are tied together by membranous Ligaments.
As to Veels. It hath Veins from the Jugulars.Its Veels.
Arteries from the Carotides.
Nerves from the third pare, on each ide one, which goes through the holes common to the Noe and eyes, at the greater corner into the Coat of the Noe, and the Mucles, and the Palate.

The Coat which cloaths the Notrils is from the dura Mater, and common toThe Coat of the Notrils. the Mouth, Palate, Tongue, Larynx, Gullet and Stomach; but in the Notrils it is thinner and of exquiite ene; for being vexed it caues Sneezing: it isThe caue of Sneezing. bred with many little holes which go into the Os cribroum.

Riolanus informs us that within the Cavities of the Notrils, there are pungy parcels of fleh to be een, of a reddih colour, wherewith the pungy bones of the Noe are filled, of which being welled, the Dieae in the Notrils, called Polypus, is bred, touching the pulling out and cure whereof, read Tulpius.

list.item: The Ue of the outer Noe is
1. That through it air may enter intoThe ue of the Noe. the Brain for the needs of the Animal Spirits.
2. That by it air may enter into the Lungs, for the cooling of the Heart, and to breed vital Spirits.
3. That by the Notrils Odours may be carried to the Mammillary procees, which lie concealed above the Os cribroum. And therefore they whoe Noe is cut off at the Roots, cannot mell at all, or badly.

4. That the Excrements of the Brain may flow down there through, as by a Channel. Which is but a econdary ue of the Noe, becaue Jo. Walaeus, Jo. Dom. Sala my Maters and my elf, have known ome perons that never voided any Excrements at their Noe
5. It is alo omtimes aitant to the Voice.

6. It adds an Ornament to the Face. It is toried in the Chronicles of England, how a company of honet Maidens of that Country, in the time of the Daneih War, did cut off their own Noes, that they might preerve their Maidenheads from the violence of the Daneih Soldiers, by this deformity. This was the punihment of Adulterers in Aegypt, which alo Jebovah threatens to the Inhabitants of Hierualem, by the Prophet Ezekiel. In our Hitoriographer Saxo, we read how Hialto deformed a Curtezan by cutting off her Noe, when he asked him who hould be her next Lover. And therefore becaue it makes much for the Ornament of the Face, the Chirurgia Curtorum was invented, teaching how to upply a Noe in the room of that which is cut off, of which ee Tagliacotius.

div.head: Chap. XI. Of the Mouth, Cheeks and Lips.
div.p: THe lat Organ of Sene remains, viz. the Tongue the Organ of Tating, which before I explain, I mut propound the external parts about the Mouth, and the internal parts in the Mouth.

The external parts about the mouth are undry. The upper part under theThe Names of the outward parts about the Mouth. Eyes, between the Noe and the Ears, by reaon of its uual Rednes, and the unuual by reaon of bluhing, is called Pudoris edes the Seat of hamefatnes, Maium or Pomum the Apple, alo Circulus Faciei, the Circle of the Face.

The lower and looer part which may be blown up, as we ee in Trumpeters, is termed Bucca the Cheek, the upper part of the Lip is called Mytax. The Cavity imprinted therein and dividing the ame, is called Philtrum, from its lovelines. Now the Lips are two, the upper and the lower, and the chink between both, is termed Os the Mouth. The outer parts of the Lips which hang over, are called Prolabia. The lower part under the lower Lip is called Mentum the Chin; the flehy part under the Chin is termed Buccula.
Now the Mouth conits of parts, partly boney, as the upper and lower Jaw with the teeth; partly flehy, as the Lips, Lip-mucles, Cheek-mucles, and lower Jaw-mucles.
The whole inner capacity of the Mouth is cloarhed with a thick Coat, which goes alo about the Gums and Lips, and is thought to be doubled when it contitutes the Uvula.

list.item: The Ues of the Mouth are:The ue of the Mouth.
1. To receive in Meat and Drink, and to prepare the ame, or begin Chylification the beginning, of which is performed in the Mouth.
2. To receive in and let out the Air.
3. To peak and frame the Voice.
4. To give paage to the Excrements of the lungs, the Head and Stomach, by hawking, pitting, and vomiting.

div.p: Two pare of Mucles there are, commonTwo pare of Mucles common to the Cheeks and Lips. to the Cheeks and Lips, on each ide two Mucles.
The firt is that ame broad and quare mucle lying under the skin of the neck, which the Ancients did not ditinguih from the Skin.

It aries about the Channel-bones, and the hinderpart of the Neck; and with oblique Fibres (which a Surgeon mut diligently oberve, leat he cut them freely and athwart, and o make the Cheeks to be pulled
away to one ide) it is implanted into the Chin, the Lips and Root of the Noe, and ometimes of the Ears: which parts alo it moves to the part, and this is firt cramped inSpamus Cynicus. the Spamus Cynicus.
The econd lies under this, which makes the Cheeks with its Bulk, and therefore is termed Buccinator the trumpetting Mucle, which is mot conpicuous in Trumpetters.
Tis round like a Circle, thin and membranous; interwoven with undry Fibres,The Figure of the Mucle Buccinator. ineparably clothed with the coat of the Mouth.

In the Centre hereof Caerius hath oberved a certain trong band, breeding from without, and creeping to the Cheek-bone, where it is terminated into a certain mall and lean Mucle, directly oppoite to the Bucca.
This Mucle aries from the upper Cheek-bone, is inerted into the lower, at the Roo • s of the Gums.
Its Ue is to move the Cheeks and Lips: and it is to the teeth intead of an hand, while it thruts the meat this way and that way to the teeth, that it may be more exactly chewed.

The Lips conit of undigeted pungy fleh (Fallopius reckons it for the ninth pareThe Lips. of Mucles which move the Lips) whoe Skin is o mingled with Mucles, that it eems to be a muculous Skin, or a skinny Mucle.
They are covered with a Coat common to the Mouth and Stomath:Trembling of the Lip in uch as are ready to cat, how caued? and thence it is that in uch as are ready to vomit, the lower Lip trembles.
The parts of the Lips which touch one another are red, becaue of the afflux of blood.
Their Ue is,

list.item: 1. To hut in the Mouth and Teeth, and to defend the inner parts from cold and external Injuries.
2. For the conveniency of Eating and Drinking.
3. For the Voice and Speech.
4. To cat out the Spittle, and therefore that Servants might not pit nor peak, they were bound with Skins, as Ammianus Marcellinus informs us.
5. For Ornament.

div.p: There are ome proper Mucles of the Lips beides the common ones aforeaid, which nevertheles may vary in repect of number. Some reckon fewer, and others more: for ome are by ome Authors counted imple, which others reckon to be manifold.
The proper Mucles which move the upper Lip, are on each ide two. Three there are which move both Lips. The lower Lip is moved only by one proper pare.

The firt pare proper to the upper lip, is a remarkable pare decribed by Fallopius, Four pare of mucles moving the upper Lip. which lipping down from the corner betwixt the Eyes and Noe, is traight way unk into the Subtance of the upper Lip.

The other pare, ariing from the upper Jaw-bone, jut in the Cavity of the Cheeks under the Socket of the Eye, thin but broad, flehy, unk into tore of Fat, is carried down wards right on, to the upper Lip, which moves it directly upwards with the firt pare. Sometimes alo it is obliquely inerted into the confines of both the Lips, wherefore ome do make two pare therof.

The firt pare common to both Lips, is long, flehy, broad at theMucles common to both Lips. beginning; aries outwardly from the Jugal proces, and decending obliquely through the Cheeks, it is terminated in the pace between the two Lips. Sometimes I have een it from the beginning drawn out as a Rope to the firt proper pare. Its Ue is; to draw both the Lips obliquely upwards towards the Temples.

The econd common pare of the Lips, from the lower Jaw-bone to the ides of the chin, flehy, aries with a broad beginning, and ometimes tretched out to the middle of the chin, grows by little and little narrower' till it is obliquely inerted into the ame confine of each Lip, but lower, which draws away the Lips obliquely downwards and outwards, in uch as grin and gern for anger.

The third Mucle common to the two Lips is circular like a Sphincter encompaing and contituting the whole Mouth, pungy, and firmly ticking to the ruddy Skin, it draws the Mouth together, when people imper as Virgins are wont to do.

The proper pare of the lower Lip is calledMucles of the lower Lip. Par Mentale, the Chin-pare; ariing from the middle of the Chin with a broad beginning, and aeends directly to the middle of the lower Lip, which it moves downwards.
Now all the Mucles of the Lips, are o mixed with the Skin, that the Fibres do cros one another mutually, and therefore the motions of the Lips are very divers.

To caue that exquiite Sene which is in the Lips, Branches of Nerves are ent thither, and Veins and Arteries from the neighbouring places: from whence that ame ruddy plendor of the Lips proceeds, a note of Beauty and of Health.

The Mucles of the lower Jaw (for it isMucles of the lower Jaw. moved) the upper being immoveable) ome reckon eight, others ten, called Maticatorij, Manorij, Molares, Chewers, Eaters, Grinders, becaue they erve for the chewing or grinding of the meat. One only pare deprees the Jaw, becaue it is apt to go downwards of it elf: the other pares etch it up, which are exceeding trong ones. Hence it is that ome can take heavy weights from the ground with their teeth, and o carry them. Hence phrantick and otherwie ditracted perons do hut their mouths with o much tubbornnes and trength, that they can hardly be opened with great force and iron Intruments. Contrariwie, the tubbornet peron in the World may be compelled without much ado, to hut his or her mouth.
The firt Mucle is termed Crotaphites, Temporalis. the temporal Mucle from its Scituation, becaue it poees the Cavity of the Temples.
This is the greatet of them all, firm and trong, yet firmer and tronger in ome Beats, as Lyons, Wolves, Dogs, Swine, &c. which were naturally to bite hard

Forth End of the temporal Mucle, is in the begining of the lower Jaw, whichThe ue of the temporal • mucle. it moves and draws upwards, and o huts the mouth; and it is terminated in a harp proces, with a tendinous Nerve hort and trong.
Now it aries from the Temples wich a beginning broad, flehy, and emicircular, and by little and little grows narrower as it decends.

Three Nerves are on each ide inertedWhy tis dangerous to hurt the temporal mucle. thereinto, two from the third pare, another from the fift pare. And therefore this Mucle being wounded or bruied, there is great danger of Convulion and
of Death in concluion; epecially if the lower part be hurt which is mot Nervous. And becaue of the ditention hereof, Hypocrates did pronounce the Luxation of the lower Jaw-bone to be deadly; unles it were put preently in joynt again.

For afeguard ake, Nature hath given it, 1. A Membrane thick and hard, and black and blew in color, wherewith it is covered, and hines with a neat color; the Pericraneum, o that the inner part of the Mucle being all flehy, doth there tick to the bone without the Pericranium. 2. The Os jugale over the lower part Tendinous and Nervous. 3. She hath fenced the Tendon with fleh above and beneath.
The econd Mucle is the Manorius primus, firt chewer, called Maeter, Molitor, Manorius primus. and Mandibularis, or Lateralis, eated in the Cheeks.

It aries from a double Head: the one flehy, the other Nervous, from the Os jugale, and the firt bone of the upper Jaw. It is implanted into the lower part of the Jaw-bone (by a Connexion ufficiently broad and trong) which it turns this way and that way, in uch as are eating. For the Fibres of the Head do o interfere and cros one another, that they move the Jaw both forwards and backwards and idewayes.

The third pair is the Pterygoides or Alare externum, the outward Wing-mucle, theAlaris. finding whereof we owe to Fallopius; but Vealius accounts it a part of the temporal Mucle. 'Tis eated under the temporal.

It aries from the Os Sphaenoideum and the external proceus Alaris, with a beginning partly Nervous and partly flehy. 'Tis implanted into the Neck of the lower Jaw-bone, and the inner eat of the Head thereof.
Its Ue is to move forwards and thrut out.
The fourth is termed Manorius alter, the other Chewer, or Alaris internus, beingManorius alter. thick and hort.
It aries Nervous from the Productions of Os Sphaenoideum called Alatae internae; and is inerted into the inner and hinder part of the Jaw, with a broad and trong Tendon.
Its Ue is to draw the Jaw upward and backward, to ait the temporal Mucle.
The fift is termed Graphyoides, becaueGraphyoides.

It aries from the Appendix Styloides, Membranou,s and broad, and oon becoming round and flehy, tis inerted into the Chin. Hence it is een to have a double belly, and therefore 'tis alo termed Digatricus, twi-belly. 'Tis fatned to a Ligament leat it hould go too far back. For,
Its Ue is to draw the Jaw downwards and o to open the Mouth.

Others do reckon for another pair, part of the Muculus quadratus, fixed in the middle of the Chin. Which broadet Mucle, ariing from the upper part of the Bret-bone, the Channel bone and the Shoulder tip, and covering the Neck and the whole Face, after Galen, Sylvius, and Theophilus, Riolanus decribes in this place. I poke thereof, in the beginning of the Chapter.

div.head: Chap. 12. Of the Parts contained in the Mouth, viz. the Gums, Palate, Uvula, Fauces, and Throat-bone.
div.p: PArts contained in the Mouth beides the Teeth: are the Gums, Palate, Uvula, Fauces, Tonguebone, Tongue, Almonds or Tonillae, Larrnx, and beginning of the Gullet. Of the three later I poke in my econd Book, becaue of the Connexion of Parts. Of the five former, we will treat in this Chapter and of the Tongue in the Chapter following.

GINGIVA the Gum, is an hard fleh compaing the Teeth like a Rampart, and inGingiva. uch as have lot their Teeth, erving in ome meaure to chew their meat: which being either eaten away, or too much relaxed, or overdryed, the Teeth become looe, or fall out.

PALATUM the Palate, is the upper part of the Mouth moderately hollow, like thePalatum. Roof of an Houe, whence it is called the Heaven of the Mouth, and is the Bais or Foundation on which the Brain rets, being made of the Os Sphaenoideum.

'Tis inveted with a thick Coat ariing from the dura Mater, which covers the Cheeks and whole mouth on their Inides, and is common to the Gullet and Stomach, and therefore there is alo a conent between thee parts. Nor can we purge the Head with Maticatories, unles we purge alo the Stomach by the Palate.
'Tis furnihed with mall Nerves for Sene.

The UVULA hangs from the Palate further into the Mouth near the paagesThe Uvula how eated. of the Notrils, over the Chink of the Larynx among the Almonds or Kernels o called. Some call it Gargareon, from the noie it makes when we Gargle any Liquor; 'tis alo called Gurgulio and Columna.

It is a Proces made of a Glandulous, Spungy and red Subtance, which Columbus doth uppoe to be made of the Coat of the Palate Reduplicated in that place. Riolanus rather believes that it is fleh, ariing from the extremity of the Mucles, which are carried to the Body.

It is roundel' long, thicker above, and ends in an acute Figure obtuely. It isIts Mucles. upended and held up by two little Mucles, an Internal and an External pair, either to tir the Uvula Forward and Backward in the time of wallowing, or when it is relaxed with Humors and falls down, to draw it up again.

Riolanus, from Aretaeus, the Author of Anatomia Vivorum, Abenina and Carpus, decribes two broad Ligaments fatening the Uvula on both ides, like to wings pred abroad, which the Arabians term Galamach of which he is worthy to be conulted.

Sometimes by reaon of Humors too much flowing in, it hangs two muchThe falling o • the Uvula. down, which is called Caus Uvulae the falling down of the Palate of the Mouth. Which if it cannot be retored to its place by Medicaments nor manual operation,s it is wont to be burnt and cut by Skilful Chirurgeo • u.

div.p: Its Ue is to moderate, the coldnes of the Air, that it may not uddenly ruh into the Lungs: and therefore thoe that have lot the Palate of their Mouths dye of a Conumption.

Some think it helps to modulate the Voice, and therefore they call it Plectrum vocis, theVulgar Error. triking quil of the Voice. But though it be wounded or quite cut off, yet is not the voice hurt, unles ome neighbouring parts, which ait the voice are alo damaged: for then by the roughnes of thoe parts, caued by thoe Catarrhes, which have eaten the Uvula, the Voice becomes Hoare.

A econd Ue is, to hinder drink from paing out of the Mouth into the Notrils. And therefore Salmuth tels of the Son of a Man called John, who being born without any Uvula or Almonds, voided the Milk which he uckt, out of his Noe, and did not live long.

By FAUCES ometimes we undertand the whole widenes of the Mouth: but more trictly it is meant of the hinder and lower part, which cannot be een, but when the Mouth is wide open and the Tongue held down, the Greeks term it Pharynx, howbeit that word in Hypocrates doth oftentimes ignifie the Dieaes of this part, as Inflammation, &c. Galen calls it Ithmus becaue of the narrownes of the place.

In the Fauces is that Bone which from the hape of the Greek letter v isNames of the Os hyoides. called Hyoides, Hypiloides, alo from reemblance to the letter Lambdoides, that is the Upilon or Lambda-haped Bone. 'Tis alo called Os gutturis, the Throat-bone, and Os linguae, the Tongue-bone, of which I mut treat in this place, and not in the Hitory of the Bones, becaue it is not fatned to the other parts of the Skeleton.
Now the Bone is the Bais and Foundation of the Tongue, upon which it is placed and moved: and it is et before the Larynx.
It conits of undry little bones, three at leat, ometimes of five, even,Its Contruction. nine.

The middle Bone is the greatet, bunching without, hollow within, under which ticks the
Epiglottis; it hath procees termed Cornua, borns two in Number, coniting of Bones more or fewer, greater or leer.
Four Gritles are added, two are omewhat great, long and round, in the Belly of Os hyoides, two alo beides the Horns, which in ome perons become bony.
Its procees are fatened to the Ligaments and ends of the Styloides, alo with the Cartilago guttalis.
This Bone is moved, but not except the Tongue be moved; and therefore itIts Mucles. hath four pair of Mucles common to the Tongue, nor can the Mucles of the Tongue be hewed till they are removed.
The firt pair lies concealed in the fore-part, under the Skin, reting upon the Weand and the Cartilago Scutalis.

It aries with a broad and flehy beginning, from the higher and inner Region of the Breat-bone; and therefore this pair is called Sterno-hyoides. Its End is flehy, in the Bais of Os hyoides. And in the middle according to their leng • h, thee Mucles are divided with a line.
Their Ue is to draw right down.
The econd being under the Chin and the fift pair of the lower Jaw; is large, hort and all flehy.
It aries from the inner part of the lower Jaw, with a various carriage of Fibres: it is ended in the middle eat of the Hyoides. Some call it Genio-hyoides.
Its Ue is to draw right upwards and a little forwards.

The third is lean and round, eated under the Chin, ariing from the Root of the Appendix of Styloides; it ends into the horns of the Hyoides. Somtimes they are bored through the middle, for the Mucle which opens the Jaw.
The Ue is, to move idewayes, and a little obliquely upwards. 'Tis called Stylo-cerato-hyoides.
The fourth being lean and long, lies concealed under that Mucle of the Scapula which they count the fourth, moving downwards and obliquely idewayes.

It aries from the upper ide of the Scapula, near the proceus Coracoides, and therefore 'tis called Coraco-hyoides: it is carryed upwards obliquely to the ides of the Os hyoides, under that Mucle of the Head which is counted the eventh. And this pair is long, hath two Bellies, and is extenuated in the middle like a Tendon, like that which draws down the lower Jaw.

Some add to thee a fift pair, which is indeed proper to the Tongue, Riolanus indeed the Mylo-gloum and therefore he terms it Mylo-hyoideum; but Vetingus the Genio-gloum, and therefore he calls it the Geniohyoides internum: which ariing inwardly from the Chin under the Par Genio-hyoideum, is inerted into the Bais of the Hyoides, which it draws traight upwards.
The Ue of this Os hyoides, isThe Ue of Os hyoides.

I. To be the Bais of the tongue, and yet but obcurely moveable: leat as Walaeus conceives, it hould perpetually hang in the Throat, and hinder the wallowing of Meat; but it moves forward in wallowing, and o makes the Orifice of the Guller more wide.
II. That from it many Mucles might arie of the tongue and Larynx.

div.head: Chap. 13. Of the Tongue.
div.p: THe TONGUE called Lingua a lingendo The tongue. from licking.
Is placed in Mankind, in the MouthIts Scituation. under the Palate thereof:
Is in Number one, in Sea-Calfes two, inNumber. Serpents divided into three parts, in Lizards and Snakes divided into two parts.
In Man 'tis long, broad and thick, andFigure. thicker at the Root, thinner and harper at the End.

Its ize is moderate anwerable to the mouth, which if it be too great, o thatMagnitude. it cannot move readily, it makes a man Lipe and Stutter; and if it be overoft and moit as in young Children, they cannot peak plainly. Galen, Carnerarius, Zacutus Luitanus and M. Donatus, have oberved the tongue grown to o montrous a greatnes, that it could not be contained within the mouth.

As to the Connexion, in fihes the whole tongue cleaves to their mouth;Its Connexion. in mankind, it is in its hinder part fatned to the Larynx, and the Os hyoides, alo to the Fauces and Tonillae. Beneath in the middle of its body 'tis fatned with a trong membranous Ligament for trength and tabilities ake; alo for the inertion of its proper mucles, whoe extremity is termed Fraenulum; nor can any other tring be found different from this. This in many new born Children, doth o tie the whole tongue, that it is wont to be torn by the Nail of the Midwife (which is nevertheles a Pernitious coure andA Pernitious Practice of midwives. not to be allowed) or the mall Knife of a Chirurgeon, that it may not hinder the Childs ucking or future peaking, and that it may freely turn and move it elf. Howbeit for want of skill, they cut it in all Infants indifferently, whereas not one of a thouand, when it is let alone, doth tammer.
'Tis cloathed with a Coat (hard in uchIts Coat. as ue to wallow very hot Liquors) ordinarily thin, oft, and porous, that tats may eaily peirce into the tongues flehy

Subtance, which is a peculiar kind ofSubtance. fleh, uch as is not in the Body beides (and it is the Organ of tat, not the Coat, as Galen would have it, nor the Nervus Gutatorius, as ome from Columbus) oft, looe, rare and pungy, to drink in the tats brought to it with ome humidity. In Fihes and ome other Animals 'tis bony. It is rather of a kernelly then a Muculous ubtance, epecially about the Bais thereof.

For the tongue is no Mucle, eeingWhether the tongue be a mucle. it hath no Fibres, nor moves any other part, but is moved by its Mucles. Others add this Reaon, becaue then motion would be made towards the end of a Mucle, and the tail of a Mucle hould be moveable the head immoveable. But this Reaon is fale. For the beginning of the tongue is near the Larynx, and aries as it were from the Os Hyoides.

As to Veels. Two remarkable VeinsIts Veels. are to be een under the tongue, which are wont to be opened in Quinzies and Dieaes of the Fauces, termed Raninae from their color, ariing from the external Jugulars, thee
Two pretty big Arteries do accompany, from the Carotides.

Nerves are inerted into the Tongue, both thoe of motion, and thoe of Sene: a thicker pair creeping through the inner parts, from the eventh conjugation, which being obtructed or not reaching to the Tongue, the tat is lot according to the obervation of Columbus. A thinner pair runs through the outer parts of the Tongues Coat, ariing from the fourth conjugation, or as ome ay, from the third.
The Tongue is ditinguihed in the middle of its urface, into the right andThe line of the tongue. left part, by a certain white line, which Hippocrates terms Mediana.

The mucles proper to the Tongue, endingIts mucles in its ubtance, are by ome Anatomits reckoned to be ix, by others nine, by ome ten, by others eleven, which move the Tongue, upwards and downwards; forewards and backwards; to the right hand and to the left.

The firt pair, which in Oxen is double flehy and thick, aries from the out ide of the Appendix Styloides, being Maigre in Mankind: it ends with tranvere Fibres, into both ides of the Tongue, about the middle thereof.

Its Ue is to move the Tongue inwards. But by reaon of the Fibres interwoven, they lift the Tongue upwards if they act both together; but upwards only to one ide, if only one of them act. This pair is called Stylogloum.

The econd pair is called Mylogloum, ariing from the ides of the lower jaw, at the Roots of the grinding Teeth. Tis inerted under the Bais of the tongue, into the tongues Ligament. Riolanus will have it belong to the Os hyoides, becaue it touches not the tongue. But it uffices to move the tongue, if it be affixed to the Ligament thereof.
Its Ue; when one acts, the tongue is moved obliquely upwards; when both act, it moves with its point right to the Palate and upper teeth.

div.p: The third pair aries inwardly at the middle of the Chin, whence tis called Geneo-gloum; it ends, wellnear into the middle of the tongue inwardly. Velingius will have it fatned into the Bais of the Os hyoides, and therefore he reckons it amongt the Mucles thereof. And by reaon of the diverity of its Fibres, it eems to perform contrary actions: for the greatet part of the Fibres, which is towards the Root of the tongue, being drawn towards the Original, the tongue is thrut without the Lips; but the mallet part of the Fibres acting, tis drawn inwards. This pair hath incriptions as if it were many Mucles.

The fourth pair aries flehy out of the upper and middle Region of the Os hyoides, and is terminated in the middle, after it is drawn out according to the length of the tongue. It is omtimes obcurely divided, as if it were many Mucles.
Its Ue is, to draw the tongue right in, and o to depres the ame. And it is called Baiogloum, or Hypilogloum.
The fift pair is called Cerato-gloum, becaue it aries from the upper horns of the Hyoides, and is obliquely inerted into the ides of the tongue, near the Root thereof.
Its aries omtimes from the lower horns, viz. when the higher are wanting, epecially in Women. And this pair is double in Oxen.
Its Ue is, to move the tongue directly downwards towards the inner parts, when both act; but if only one be contracted, it moves it to the right or left ide.

By others an eleventh Mucle is added, which yet is no Mucle, becaue it conits not of flehy Fibres; but it is a parcel of fleh, coniting of very many Kernels and far, ituate at the Root of the tongue, and appearing when the foreaid Mucles are taken away.
Its Ue is, that the tongue may be moitened by this plenty of Kernels.
The Ue of the Tongue is:The ue of the Tongue.

list.item: I. To be the Intrument of Tat.
II. Of Speech.
III. To further the chewing of Meat, by turning it this way and that way.
IV. To lick with.

div.p: By all which it appears, that the tongue is not neceary to the very being of life, but to the well being: for the part thereof may be cut off without danger of life or health, Zacutus, Walaeus and others after Galen, have found by experience. Abenzoar, Joubertus, Foretus, have oberved that Stones have bred under the tongue, hindring Speech, till they were cut out; and I remember that long ince uch tones were taken out at Padua.

div.head: THE FOURTH BOOK OF THE LIMBS.
div.p: BY Limbs we undertand thoe Members which grow as it wereThe Limbs what? out from the Trunk of the Body, viz. the ARMES above, the LEGS beneath. In which are chiefly conidered the Mucles, Veins, Arteries, NervesWhy the mucles alo of the Head, Neck, Back &c. are handled in this Book? and Bones. Of the four lat I hall treat, in the four following Manuals: but of the Mucles of the Limbs in this Book, as alo of the neighboring Parts, viz. the Head, Neck, Chet, Back, &c. their Mucles; not becaue they appertain to the Limbs, but becaue in the Order of Diection, an Anatomit cannot hew them before the Mucles of the Limbs.

div.head: Chap. I. Of the Arm and Hand in General with the Nails.
div.p: ARitotle calls the Arm with its Hand,The ue of the Hand. Organon Organón, the Intrument of Intruments, wherewith Man otherwie naked and unarmed is guifted, that he may not be inferior to the Brute-beats and conquered by them; but may overcome them, making for himelf Weapons, and other neceary Intruments. Man therefore hath received Reaon and Hands, which Beats have not; and the Hand is his Servant and Intrument.
Now the old Writers Hippocrates and Galen by HAND did undertand thatManus what? Part of the Body, from the top of the Shoulder to the ends of the Fingers, and this is termed umma Manus.
And it is divided into the Arm and Hand trictly o called, or the extrema manus.
And the Arm is divided again, into the Shoulder and Cubit, the Shoulder is the part of the Arm from the Shoulder-tip to the bending of the Elbow.
The Cubit is that part from the bending of the Elbow unto the Writ.

The Manus extrema or Hand properly o called, is divided into the Brachiale or Writ, which is the part between the Elbow and Palm; into the Potbrachiale or Metacarpum, after-writ, which is the part between the Writ and beginning of the Fingers, and into the Fingers. The Potbrachial part internal is called the Palm of the Hand, the external part is called the Back of the Hand.

There are many Fingers, that the actionWhy many Fingers on the Hand? of the Hand might be the better performed, which is laying hold: alo that we might be able to take up the mallet matters, which we do by two fingers, and other things of many-haped Figures: and becaue all things could not be comprehended with one hand, two were made that meeting together, the one might help the other.

The right Hand is more active commonly and more ready for motion, notWhy the right Hand is more active then the left? for thoe caues which others childihly cite, but 1. Becaue in a mans right ide is the Vena ine pari o called, which peradventure is double in uch as can ue both hands alike. 2. Becaue the bones are more heavy in the Shoulder, Shoulder-blade and whol arm, then on the other ide, as ome men know for certain; which may proceed from an impreion of more plentiful Heat in the Mothers Womb, the right part wherof is hotter then the other. Hence Aritotle teaches, that naturally the right hand excels the left; and in another place, he tells us the firt endeavor of motion is on the right ide; o that when a man is about to walk, firt moves his right Leg; a Bird about to flie, moves firt its right wing. 3. Becaue the trunk of the Subclavian Artery is greater on the right ide then the left, as they know that have diligently conidered the matter in oppoition to Riolanus, though the difference is not, neither needed to be very great. Plato conceives that all men are naturally ambidexters, viz. that they can ue both hands alike, and that it is mens unskilfulnes and ignorance that makes them right handed only or left handed. But Aritotle is of Opinion, that from our firt Formation, the right ides of our Bodies, are alwaies in a manner hotter and tronger then the left, unles any man by much cutom, and much exercie, do draw much Heat and Spirit to his left Hand that he may become Ambidexter, and able to ue it as his right.

Now the Fingers for perfection of ActionThe number of the Fingers. are made five in number, differing in length and thicknes. Tis beides nature, if either the Fingers be quite wanting, which I have een at Malta and at Florence; or if in place of true Fingers there appear only certain oft
marks as big as Peaon, which I lately oberved here at Hafnia.
The firt is cal'd Pollex a Pollendo becaue of its trength, and it alone is oppoed to the whole four, when any thing is to be taken up, and therefore it is thick.
The econd is cal'd Index and Demontrator, the hewer, or pointer: becaue therewith we point at any thing.
The third is the longet and middlemot, cal'd Impudicus the hameles, becaue Phyitians ue it in filthy and tinking places; not is it wont to be adorned with Rings.

The fourth is termed Medicus, alo Annularis, the Ring-finger, becaue it is adorned with a Gold Ring before any of the ret, by reaon of a common bu • fale opinion Repugnant to Anatomy, viz. that a Vein hould come from the Heart to this Finger above all the ret; now the Heart is comforted with Gold.
The fift cal'd Auricularis the Ear-finger, becaue fittet to pick the Ears, is mallet, and by us cal'd the little Finger.

The Caue therefore of laying hold, which is the action of the Hand, orLaying hold. as others peak les accurately, its chiefet ue, is the apt compoition of theHow the Hand is compounded? whole Hand. Yet the chief Organ of this motion is a Mucle: the trength is in the Bones, which are three in every finger, the lower of which as the utainer is alwaies greater then that which is above it and tronger, and in the Joynts they are furnihed on each fide with a Gritle, on which an Oyly moiture is poured out for Hummectations ake, and to Facilitate the motion.

A econdary ue of the Arms and Hands as Kyperus learnedly Dicoures, is the better to help our going by their weight and ballancing; Yea and to peed our going; and therefore dancers on the Ropes, whoe Foot is broader then that which they tread on, do bear themelves up with long Poles, and when they dance a pace, they ballance themelves with their Hands, which they move this way and that way.

The Nails are placed externally on the tops of the Fingers, as alo ofOf the Nails. the Toes: whoe upmot part being white, is called the Root of the Nailes, the white half Moon, and the little Skin which grows to the Root.

Their matter is not Alimentary Humors; as Aemilius, Parianus and Plempius would have it, and others, but thick Excrements, not which acend from the Heart, as Roa Anglicana conceives; or from the Arteries, but from the Bones and Gritles, as the great Hippocrates doth affirm.

The Efficient is that heat which the Soul directs to this rather then any other part of the Body. But the Nailes are not made by the Soul, as Parianus and Plempius contend, becaue in Cacochymick and Phlegmatick perons they grow more abundantly, in uch as have been twenty five years dead, according to the obervation of Pareus. Nor are we moved when they ay that there is a great variety of colours in horns and hels of Fihes, for they no more prove the action of the Soul in uch things, then in party coloured and peckled Marble.
Their End and Ue is,

list.item: I. To fence the ends of the Fingers and Toes which are exceeding oft, and to aveguard them by their hardnes, o that they may more eaily take up any thing. So in the Feet, that they may be able to reit the hardnes of the Ground and tand firm. And therefore it was ill aid by him of old, that the Gods had erred in their placeing the Nails.
II. For ornament: and therefore we cover our Fingers when the Nails are impaired.
III. To rub, crarch and defend, which is a econdary ue.
IV. To free the Body from uperfluous Humors and teams Fuliginous.

V. To afford Phyiognomits and Phyitians tokens of Life and Health, which may be een in divers authors. And Achmetes ch. 74. 75. interprets dreams concerning them, according to the Tradition of the Indians, Perians and Aegyptians.

div.p: Their form we gather from the Accidents.
Their Figure is omwhat convex, that they may apply themelves to the Fingers.
They have a ubtance indifferently hard that they may reit, but yet flexible, that they may yeild a little and not break.

They are Tranparent and thereforeColour of the Nails and igns from thence. variouly coloured: for according to the fleh beneath them, they are red, blewih, &c. And therefore Phyitians are wont to oberve the Colour of the Nails; for the Nails, for examples ake, grow pale when the heat of the Heart is deficient; in uch as are at deaths door they are livid and brown. Thoe ame white pots which in yong people omtimes appear in their Nails, pring from a vigorous heat, which drives hidden Excrements to the Nails, and eparates them from others of a different Nature.

They are knit about the Root with aWhence the ene of the nails proceeds Ligament, and Skin grows about them without; and fleh grows under them, or rather the tendons of Mucles, there dilated: there is therefore in that place an exquiite ene, and great pain when they are hurt.
And o much may uffice to have poken of the Nails, briefly, and by way of Compendium.

div.head: Chap. II. Of the Mucles of the Humerus, or of the Brachium, peculiarly o called.
div.p: THe common containing Parts being removed, viz. the Scarf-skin, the Skin, the Fat, the Membrana carnoa, &c. the MUSCLES hew themelves, by which the motion is made, of which I am to treat in this whole Book; in a convenient place, though Hofman think otherwie, epecially becaue the Doctrin of the Mucles is ueful and neceary, by reaon of Iues, Wounds, &c. And in the other parts they could not be treated off.

Now touching the action of the Mucles of the Arm in general, it is to be noted, that the inner Mucles do motly erve to bend, and the outer to extend. And in the whole Arm the internal Mucles are more and tronger then the external, becaue bending is more worthy then the extenion.

The Humerus is variouly moved,The Mucles of the Humerus how many? and therefore it hath undry Mucles, partly lying upon the Chet, and partly growing to the Scapulae or Shoulder-blades, &c. Some reckon them even, others

div.p: eight and Caerius nine. For the Arm is aid to be lift up by two Mucles, Deltoides and Supra-pinatus; and downwards by two, the Ani calptor and Rotundus major: forewards by one alone, viz. the Pectoralis; backwards by three, the Infra-pinatus and Sub-capularis, and the Tranverus brevior. But they conceive the circular motion thereof is caued by all of them acting one after another: but others will have the Arm to be wheeled about by the Infra-pinatus, Suprapinatus, and Sub-capularis. But I hall in recounting them follow the order of Diection.
The firt is termed Pectoralis, becaue it takes up the Breat or forepart of the Chet being great and flehy; which Galen conceived might be divided into three or four.

It aries from wellnigh the whole Bret-bone, and the Gritles thereto annexed; where it is a little tendinous in part of the Clavicula, and the fift, ixt and eventh true Ribs. 'Tis implanted with a hort, broad Nervous and trong tendon, into the Os Humeri, between the Deltoides and the Biceps.

Its Ue is, to move the Arm to the Bret, and as the Fibres are contracted more to the upper or lower part or right forward, o doth the Arm incline this way or that way. This is the Mucle which uffers in that torment which the Italians call Tratta de corda, the Strappado. For it is very much haled and drawn a under, when the Arms are pulled forcibly backwards.
The econd is called Deltoides, from its likenes to the Greek letter alo Triangularis Humeralis, which is flehy and o abides, and is pread upon the Head of the Shoulder.
It aries from the middle of the Clavicula, looking towards the Scapula, and from the top of the Humerus, with a flehy end indeed, but yet a trong tendon lies concealed therein.

Its Ue is to lift up the Arm. In theThe place of an Iue in the Arm. middle hereof the Ancients were wont to make Fontanels or Iues; but others in the external part of the aid Mucles: but an Iue is better made in the pace between the Deltoides and the Biceps, as I hew in my Treatie of Iues, becaue 1. There is the Cephalick or Head Vein. 2. It is between two Mucles. 3. It may be very well een and dreed by the Patient. Now the place is exactly found below the Shoulder joynt, four or five Fingers bredth, where when you bend the Arm you may feel the pace between the two Mucles, and the Arm being lift up, it is Circumcribed in fat perons with a mall Cavity, as Claudinus, Solenander and others oberve. Ferrara meaures four Fingers bredth from the Elbow upwards. See alo Glandorpius.
The third is broadet of all, and with its fellow covers almot the whole Back. 'Tis called Ani Scalptor, Clawbreech, becaue it draws the Arm backwards and downwards.

It aries with a membranous and very broad beginning, from the points of the Vertebra's of the Back bone, from the Os acrum and Ilium, as far as to the ix: Vertebra of the Chet. It is inerted between the Pectoral and the round Mucle, with a trong, hort and broad Tendon. Its hape is triangular.

Fallopius out of Galen againt Vealius, doth teach that this Mucle is furnihed with a new, but very mal beginning, while from the lower Corner of the Shoulder-blades, it receives very many flehy Fibres. This Mucle becaue it hath a large beginning, and therefore divers Fibres; according as they are variouly contracted, o the Shoulder is either drawn more upwards or depreed more downwards. And becaue it alo paes through the lower corner of the Shoulder blade therefore it lightly draws the ame alo away with the Shoulder.
The fourth is called Rotundus major, and it is obliquely eated behind, under the Axilla, being flehy, thick, and rounder then the ret.
It aries flehy from the Rib of the lower Scapula, and acending a little with its tendon, hort, broad, and trong, it is implanted with the Pectoral, into the upper and lower part of the Humerus.
Its Ue is, to draw the Arm downwards and backwards, and to work contrary to the Deltoides.

The firt is hort and round, quite flehy, which aries with a harp beginning out of the lowet corner of the Scapula; after it grows thicker and thicker to the middle of its belly, and thence growing maller by little and little, it terminates with an acute end into that Ligament, wherewith the Head of the Shoulder is involved.

It hath an oblique Scituation, and ome call it Tranverus muculus brevior, others Rotundus minor. And it is the eighth in Fallopius his account: which Mucle others uppoe to be a certain portion of the fourth.

The ixt is called Infra-pinatus, alo Supercapularis inferior, becaue it covers the whole external bunching part of the Scapula, whoe form alo it bears; but becoming more narrow, it is with a broad and hort Ligament inerted into the Shoulder.
It is thought to wheel the Arm backwards and outwards.Its Ue.

The eventh is the Suprapinatus, alo Supercapularis uperior, alo Rotundus minor; it is flehy and omewhat longih, over the Armpit; it fills the Cavity between the upper Rib of the capula, and the Spina thereof, out of which it grows.
Now it is inerted with a broad and trong tendon, into the Neck of the Humerus, at the Ligament of the joynt, being carryed above the firt joynt.
The Ue of this is thought to be the ame with that of the former. Others conceive it moves upwards with the Deltois.

The eighth is termed Subcapularis or Immerus; being very flehy, it quarters betwixt the Scapula and the Ribs, and takes up the inner part of the Scapula; but it is inerted with a broad tendon, internally, into the econd Ligament of the Humerus.
Its Ue is to bring about the Arm inwards.
The ninth Mucle was firt oberved by Arantius and Placentinus, being in the former part of the Arm and called Perforatus.

It aries from the Coracoides Proceus of the Scapula (and is therefore by Riolanus called Coracordeus, or Coracobrachiaeus) it is inerted into the inner part of the Shoulder about the middle, by the tendon of the Deltoides. It hath a beginning nervous and hort, a long round Belly ufficiently corpulent, and a trong tendon. Its Belly hath an hole bored in it, and gives paage to the Nerves, which are ditributed to the Mucles of the Cubit. This Mucle others have only termed a Muculous Portion of the Biceps.
'Tis ueful to draw the Arm to the Proces of the Scapula; or draw it forward upon the Breat.

div.head: Chap. 3. Of the Mucles of the Scapula or Shoulder-blade.
div.p: BEcaue the Scapula is moved forward and backward; upward, and downward; therefore it hath received four Mucles. To which nevertheles others add two more,The Error of other Anatomits. viz. the Serratus major and the Digatricus, but they do not well. For the later is proper to the Oshyoides, the former to the Chet.
I. The firt is called SERRATUS MINOR, and it is pred under the Muculus pectoralis.
It aries from the four upper Ribs, excepting the firt and acending obliquely upwards, with an end partly flehy, and partly tendinous, it is inerted into the Scapula by the Procelus ancoriformis.
Its Ue is to draw forward into the Breat.

II. The econd is by Galen called Trapezius, others term it Cucullaris, becaue it reembles a Friars Cowl. But that this Mucle was given our firt Parents, as the Badge of a religious life, as Riolanus conjectures, I do not believe, becaue others are religious that wear no Cowles, and many are irreligious that wear them, whether you look at their Profeion or Manners. However this Name was given this Mucle by Chritian Phyitians, becaue of its likenes to a Monks Cowl.

It aries flehy and thin from the hinder-part of the Head. From whence it decends to the eighth Vertebra of the Chet, and from thence as alo from the hinder part of the Head growing mall by little and little, it is inerted into the Back-bone, the Scapula, the top of the Shoulder and the Clavicula.
But becaue of its various Original and various Fibres,

It variouly moves the Scapula, upwards, obliquely, by reaon of Fibres obliquely decending from the hind-part of the head to the Omoplata, which Riolanus denies in vain; downwards, by reaon of the carriage of fibres, acending from the eighth Vertebra of the Back; and right out to the Back, by reaon of right fibres in the middle of the Mucle, tretched out to the Scapula.
III. The third is the Rhomboides from its figure like a Diamond, cituate under the Cucullaris, thin and broad.
It aries from the three lower Vertebra's of the Neck and the three upper Vertebra's of the Chet, and with, the ame latitude is inerted into the Bais of the Scapula.
Its Ue is to draw back a little obliquely upwards.
IV. Is the Levator, which others call the Mucle of Patience; becaue thoe whoe Affairs go cros, are wont to lift up their Shoulders: it is above the Clavicula.

It aries from the five tranvere Procees of the Vertebra's of the Neck, with undry beginnings (which
makes it eem divers Mucles) which oon grow into one: and its Inertion is in the higher and lower corner of the Scapula, with a broad and flehy tendon. Its Ue is, to draw forward and lift up the Scapula and the Humerus.
With thee Mucles the Scapula is moved directly or of it elf, and the Brachium per accidens, accidentally; as the Scapula is accidentally moved by the Mucles of the Brachium.

div.head: Chap. 4. Of the Mucles of the Chet, or which erve for Repiration.
div.p: VEry many Mucles erve for Repiration; as the Midriff, all the Intercotal Mucles, ome of the Belly (of which I have treated in the firt and econd Book) and ome
Proper to the CHEST, which are reckoned on each ide ix; to which nevertheles Fallopius adds three in the Neck; which in Vealius are parts of Mucles poeing the Breat and Back.

The proper Mucles of the Chet do grow thereto: two in the forepart, ubclavius and triangularis; Serratus major poees the Sides; the ret are in the hinderpart, viz. the two Serrati potici and the Sacrolumbus.
I. The SUBCLAVIUS, becaue 'tis eated under the Clavicula, fills the place between it and the firt Rib. Platerus reckons it amongt the Intercotals.

It aries flehy from the inner and lower part of the Clavicula: it is inerted flehy into the upper part of the firt Rib, which it draws upwards and outwards. And this is the firt mucle which dilates or ditends the Chet. To this Spigelius aigns a contrary ue, viz. to draw the Clavicula downwards which nevertheles is of it elf immoveable, and therefore he acribes thereunto a Rie and an Inertion contrary to it.
II. The SERRATUS MAJOR, is a great, broad, and every way flehy mucle, with the oblique decendent of the Abdomen, it makes a Saw-like Combination.

It aries flehy, from the internal Bais of the Scapula. Riolanus hath oberved an higher Original thereof, from the two upper Ribs, as far as to the Clavicula, which two Ribs eem immoveable. It is carried by its tendon, with five unequal ends, to the five true Ribs, and ometimes to two batard Ribs; which it lifts up. Spigelius alo and Velingus do acribe a contrary Ue hereunto, and conequently a contrary Original, and Inertion,
III. SERRATUS POSTICUS SUPERIOR minor, does quarter under the Rhomboides in the Back, between the two Shoulder-blades.
It aries membranous from the lower Spines of the Neck, and the firt of the Back: it is inerted into the three Intervals of the four upper Ribs, being tripartite: and it draws thoe Ribs upwards.

IV. SERRATUS POSTICUS INFERIOR major, is membranons and broad almot in the middle of the Back, under the Muculus latiimus or Ani calptor ariing from the Spines or harp points of the lower Vertebra's of the Back. It is inerted into the Intervals of the four lower Ribs, being parted as it were into Fingers. Its Ue to widen the lower part of the Chet.

V. Is pred under the former, and by others uppoed to be common to the Back and Chet. 'Tis called SACROLUMBUS, becaue it aries from the lower part of Os acrum, and the harp points of the Vertebra's of the Loins. It is flehy within, nervous without. It is inerted into the lower Ribs, with a double tendon, one external which is tronget, the other internal. It is not eaily eparated from the lowet mucle of the Back, o that it eems to be a parcel thereof. Its Ue according to Velingus, to contract the Chet. Spigelius conceives as I do, that becaue it grows out of one beginning with the Muculus longiimus of the Back, that therefore it extends and raies up the Chet.

VI. Is the TRIANGULARIS, mall and ubtile, in lean perons carce flehy, it lies inwardly concealed under the Breat-bone, out of the lower part whereof, it hath its Original. And therefore it may conveniently be called the Mucle of the Breat-bone. Its obliquely inerted into the lower Gritles, which it draws to, and traitens the Chet.

div.head: Chap. V. Of the Mucles of the Head.
div.p: THe HEAD is moved, either econdarily by the mucles of the Neck, according to the motion thereof; or primarily upon the firt Vertebra, to which it is immediately and cloely joyned, bein bent forward and backward. It is turned round upon the tooth-fahioned Proces of the econd Vertebra (on which the hind-part of the Head rets, and to which it is firmly fatned) as it were upon an Axle-tree; which motion is performed by nine pare of Mucles.

The firt pare is long and thick, by ome called Splenium, pred out on each ide upon the Vertebrae. It aries from a double beginning, one from the Spinae of the upper Vertebra's of the Chet, another from the five lower Spinae of the Vertebra's of the Neck, from which it is carried to the middle of the Occiput. Its Ue is, to draw the Head directly backwards. But if only one do act, the motion is thought to be made circularly to one ide.

The econd is implicated and complicated, and therefore termed Complexum. It eems to conit as it were of three Mucles. It hath divers beginnings, at the eventh Vertebra of the Neck, at the firt, third and fourth of the Chet, and it is after a different manner implanted into the Occiput.
Riolanus oberves touching the Fibres of the Splenium and the Complexus, that they are cros-wayes interected, and dipoed for the trength of both the Mucles.

The third Pare is cituate under the econd, mall and thick, which Vealius would have to be the fourth part of the former Mucle. It is inerted into the hindermore Root of the Proceus mammillaris Its Ue is, lightly to bring the Head backwards; and if but one act, to bring it backwards to one ide.
The fourth pare is called Rectum majus, being mall, flehy and lean. It aries from the econd Vertebra of the Neck; ends into the middle of the Occiput.
The fift pare called Rectum minus, lies concealed under the former pare. Its Rie is from the firt Vertebra of the Neck, its inertion and Ue is as of the third and fourth.

The ixt is the Obliquum uperius, which lies alo beneath. It ries according to ome, out of the middle of the Occiput, and decending is inerted athwart, into the points of the Procees of the Neck. But others among whom Velingus do rightly think it aries from the Proces of the firt Vertebra, and ends into the Occiput
by the outward ide of the Recti.
The eventh called Obliquum inferius, aries from the econd Vertebra of the Neck, and is inerted into the tranvere Proces of the firt Vertebra.
The Ue of the two oblique Mucles, is to bring the Head about to the Sides.

The eighth called Matoides, aries long and round in the forepart of the Neck, for the mot part double, from the upper part of the Bret-bone and the Clavicula: it is inerted with a flehy and thick End, into the Mammillary Proces, which it embraces. Its Ue is to turn the Head.

A ninth pare is added by Fallopius, under the Throat, in the forepart of the Neck, lying near the firt pare of the Neck. It aries nervous from the Ligaments of the Vertebra's of the Neck; and is inerted into the Bais of the Head, which it turns in like manner with the former.

div.head: Chap. 6. Of the Mucles of the Neck
div.p: THe Mucles of the Neck are on each ide four. The two firt extend, the two others do bend the ame.

I. The two LONG ONES lye hid under the Oeophagus or Gullet, ariing from the firt Vertebra of the Chet, with a beginning flehy and harp, they acend into the extuberant Proces of the firt Vertebra, with an acute tendon, and ometimes are inerted into the Occiput, near its great Hole.
Its Ue is, to bend the Neck right forwards and the Head withal: and if but one act, it turns it on the one ide.

The SCALENI o called, which ome count Mucles of the Chet, have a peculiar Hole, through which Veins and Arteries enter into the Arms. They arie flehy, at the ide of the Neck, from the firt Rib; they are inerted inwardly into all the Vertebra's for the mot part of the Neck, and epecially into their tranvere Procees.

III. The TRANSVERSALES duo, eated in the back, do rie from the ix Vertebra's of the Chet which are uppermot and outmot: they are inerted externally into all the tranvere Procees of the Vertebra's of the Neck. And between thee Nerves go out. Their Ue is, to extend or to bend backwards, but if one act alone, to move obliquely.

IV. The two SPINATI poes the whole Neck between the Spinae, and are long and large. They arie from five Spines of the Vertebra's of the Neck, and even of the Chet. They are trongly implanted into the whole lower part of the Spine of the econd Vertebra. Their Ue is the ame as of the third pare.

div.head: Chap. 7. Of the Mucles of the Back and Loins.
div.p: THe Spine of the Back or Back-bone is moved forward, backward, to the right and to the left, and circularly. Yea, and in tumblers we may ee infinite motions of the Back. For tendons are brought to all the Vertebra's, as though the Mucles were many and infinite; which tendons nevertheles many Anatomits do refer to ome one great Mucle, and ay that one Mucle hath many tendons. But commonly, they make four pare of Mucles of the back: where it is to be oberved, if only one act, the back-bone is moved ide-wayes, if the pare acts, it is either bended or extended.

The firt pare is termed QUADRATUM, adhering to the tranvere Procees of the Vertebra's of the Loins;
