inwardly from the Bones Ilium and Sacrum, broad and flehy. Riolanus would rather bring them from the tranvere Apophyes of the two lower Vertebra's of the Back, and the lat Rib, that it might with the oblique decending Mucles and the right ones, agitate and move forwards the Fabrick of the Oa Ilij. Howbeit, eeing that Hypotheis is as yet uncertain, and himelf confees with Gajus, that the buines is to be undertood, of the bowing of the Loins, and the frame of the Ilian Bones; according to the Original by me aigned, the Ue of this Mucle is rather to bend the Vertebra's of the Loins.

The econd being called LONGISSIMUM, aries with an acute and trong Tendon, without tendinous, within flehy, from the end of Os acrum, the Vertebra's of the Loins, and the Os Ilij; having the ame beginning with the Sacrolumbus, wherewith it is in a manner confounded, til in the Progres it is eparated the refrom, by the lowet Vertebra of the Back. And it is joyned afterward to each tranvere proces of the Vertebra's of the Loins and Back, unto which it affords tendons like Clapes, and at length ends omtimes into the firt Vertebra of the Chet, omtimes at the mammillary procees, near the Temples-bone. Its Ue is, to extend the Chet, Loins, and their Vertebra's.

The third under this, is that which is called SACRUM, becaue it aries from the Os acrum behind, being flehy, and ends into the Spina of the twelfth Vertebra of the Chet (or as others ay, into the Spines alo, and oblique procees of the Vertebra's of the Loins) with undry tendons. The Ue is as of the former.

The fourth the SEMISPINATUM, ariing where the former ends, and embracing all the Spines of the Vertebra's of the Chet, and giving them tendons; and it ends into the Spine of the firt Vertebra of the Chet. Its Ue is to rear up the Chet.

If all eight act, they hold the Back traight, and do as it were utain a man. Nor are there any mucles of the Loins, ave thee, and what have been explained before, which I have omitted, as Riolanus objects, or whereof I have been ignorant.

div.head: Chap. 8. Of the Mucles of the Cubitus and Radius.
div.p: THe Mucles of the CUBIT, accordingAn Order in Diection. to the arbitrary Method of Diection follow. Yet I do advie the Diector, that the Mucles of the Radius are not to be hewed immediately after thoe, but lat of all; but after the Mucles of the Cubit, thoe of the fingers, thumb and writ; becaue the Mucles of thee parts being hewn and removed, the Inertions of the Mucles of the Radius, are more couveniently dicerned. Otherwie the Brachium may follow next after the demontration of the Mucles of the Cubitus and Radius, by an Order free for any one to follow.
The Mucles of the Cubit are four, and of the RADIUS as many.
There are two Benders of the Cubit, as the Biceps and Brachiaeus: two Extenders, viz. the Longus and the Brevis.
There are two Pronators of the Radius, the Rotundus and the Quadratus, and two Supinators, the Longior and Brevior.
For the proper Motion of the Cubit is flexion and extenion. But the Radius makes the whole Arm prone or upine.

The firt of the Cubit is termed BICEPS; becaue of its double ditinct Beginning, which is from the Scapula, the one tendinous and round, from the upper lie of the Acerabulum, the other broader and les tendinous, from the Proceus ancoriformis. And it is inerted with the Head of the Radius, and poees the inner part of the Arm with its Body. The tendon of this Mucle ought in Blood-letting to be taken heed of.

The econd lying under this, and pred out upon the bone it elf, being hort, is called BRACHIAEUS; 'tis all flehy, les then the former; artes from the middle bone of the Brachium, and is before inerted into the common beginning of the Cubitus and Radius, and the Ligament of the Joynt.
The third is the EXTENDENS primus and LONGUS, it aries with a double beginning, from the lower Rib of the Scapula, is ended being flehy in the Olecranum.

The fourth is the EXTENDENS ecundus and BREVIS; it aries from the Neck of the Humerus, is behind mixed with the precedent, and occupies the Os Humeri; and it ends into the part of the Olecranum on which we lean.

Caerius adds a fift called tertius extendens, which others count a portion of the fourth Mucle; but he counts it a ditinct Mucle, as later Anatomits Riolanus and Velingus do, which they term Anconeus. But he would have it to be a portion of his Brachiaeus, becaue it ticks ometimes cloe to the flehy Extremity thereof, and to anwer to the Poplitaeus, that an equality may be maintained between the foot and the hand. It prings out of the hinder extremity of the Shoulder, by the end of the fourth and third Mucle, and paing beyond the Joynt of the Cubir, it is alo inerted by its hinder and lateral part, yet not above a fingers bredth beyond the Olecranum, into the Os Cubiti.

Moreover Galen eems to add a ixt, which is the fourth Extender, viz. a flehy Lump hudled up of the two former, which Riolanus calls Brachiaeus externus, to difference it from the Brachiaeus intern is flectens, becaue being pred out upon the outide of the Brachium, it is placed under the two former.

The firt Mucle of the Radius is termed ROTUNDUS, or Teres; from the inner Apophyis of the Arm by a trong and flehy beginning, it ends obliquely very near into the middle of the Radius, with a flehy end, and likewie a membranous tendon, which Spigelius writes, does go again to the middle of the Radius, and is knit to the outward ide of the aid Radius.

The econd QUADRATUS, reaching from the lowet part of the Cubita, into the lowet of the Radiu • s, wholly flehy, every where two fingers broad; it goes above that Ligament common to the Radius and Cubitus. Thee are the Manus pr • natores.
The third is the SUPINATOR PRIMUS, from the lower part of the Brachium growing harp, till it reach into the lower part of the Radius, flehy, where it is inerted with a tendinous End.
The fourth is the SUPINATOR ALTER, growing from the outward Apophyis of the Arm, flehy, membranous without, flehy within, and is inerted into the middle wel-near of the Radius.

Among the Mucles of the Radius Caerius once found two little ones, and very mall, about the Joynt Cubit, and proceeding in an oppoite fahion, and moving the Radius Prone and Supine like a Pulley. Howbeit, I found them not as yet. I have omtimes een in their place, in a muculous man, one triangular
Mucle, ariing from the top of the Shoulder, and ending about the middle of the ame, with a flehy and narrow end, nor was it the portion of any Mucle, all which we had before diligently eparated.

div.head: Chap 9. Of the Mucles of the Writ and Fingers.
div.p: TO the Mucles of the WRIST and the Hollow of the Hand, is the Muculus PALMARIS referred, ariing from the inner Apophyis of the Arm, with a round and tendinous beginning, pred almot over all the Mucles of the Hand, it is tretched out over the Hollow of the Hand, and cleaves exceeding fat to the Skin: where under the Skin in the hollow of the hand is a broad Tendon; whence proceeds that exquiite Sene which is in that part: and it ends into the firt Intervals between the Joynts of the Fingers: it eems to have been made, that the Hand might take the better hold, when the Skin of the Palm is wrinkled.

To this they add the Membrana carnoa which they will have to open the Palm of the Hand when it is contracted; alo a four qua e Parcel of Fleh growing out of that Membrane, reembling certain Mucles; either to extend the Palm when the Hand is open, as Spigelius conceives, or to make it hollow, which Riolanus would have.
The Mucles of the Writ or CARPUS are four; two Benders which are internal; two Extenders, which are external.

The firt Bender (which Riolanus calls Cubiteus internus, to whom we are beholden for thee Names) ariing from the internal Apophyis of the Arm, and being tretched over the Elbow, it is implanted with a thick Tendon, into the fourth Bone of the Writ.
The other, Radius internus becaue it is drawn along the Radius, ariing from the ame beginning, ends into the firt Bone of the Metacarpium, under the forefinger.

The Extenor primus, or Radius externus, aries with a broad Beginning, from the external Apophyis of the Arm, and then growing more flehy and pred out
The Explication of the FIGURE.
This TABLE hews the ret of the Mucles, which are viible in the Hinder-part of the Body, thoe which lay by them or over them being removed.

upon the Radius, and ends into a double Tendon, at the firt and econd Bone of Os Metacarpi.
The other, Cubiteus externus, from the ame beginning, through the length of the Cubit, goes with one Tendon into the fourth Bone of the Metacarpe under the little Finger.
The FINGERS are bended, extended, drawn to, and drawn away.
Bended by the Mucles Sublimis and Profundus.

The former from the inner Apophyis of the Arm, before it comes to the Writ, is divided into four Tendons, incloed in a Ligament, as it were in a Ring: they are inerted into the econd Joynting of the Fingers, a Cleft being firt made, which the Tendons of the following Mucle do pas through, whence it is termed Perforatus, the bored Mucle.
The later pred out under the former and like unto it, is inerted through the Clifts of the former Tendons, into the Joynting. And therefore it is called Perforans, the Borer.

Concerning thee Ligaments of the Fingers, it is to be oberved. 1. That by an elegant Workmanhip of Nature, a long lit is made in each of them, that the Ligaments of the third Joynting may pas through
them as through an Arch. 2. That the membranous heath does traitly embrace and keep in the aid Tendons, leat in the bending of the hand; they hould be removed out of their place. 3. That a trong membranous Ring does in the writ bind together all the Tendons internal and external, which being cut aunder, they are eaily removed out of their places.

Iacobus Silvius reckons the Extenores for one Mucle; and calls it Tenor Digitorum, whereas both their Originals and Inertions do vary. They are two and arie commonly from the external Apophyfis of the Arm, and the ring-fahioned ligament, and with their bored ligaments, being firt collected, they are then inerted confuedly into the econd and third joynt.

The Fingers are drawn to by four mucles called Lumbricales or Vermiculares worm-fahioned mucles, from their hape and mallnes. They arie from the tendons of the Muculus profundus, and being drawn out along the ides of the fingers, they are obliquely carried unto the third joynting. Spigelius and Vetingus will have them to be inerted by a round tendon only into the firt joynting, whom I have omtimes found to be in the right, their tendon being mixed with the membranes of the interjuncture.

The Abductores interoei are ix, in the paces of the Metacarp, three external and three internal, which joyning with the vermiculary do go along the outides and inides of the fingers, and tretch their tendons to the three inter-joyntings. They erve in ome meaure for extenion. The External ret upon the Palm, the Internal upon the hollow of the Hand, between the bones of the Metacarp.
The Mucles which bend the Thumb are two.
The firt ariing from the upper part of the radius is inerted into one of the joynts.
The other ariing from the writ bone, under the Thumb, is inerted into the middle of the aid Thumb. It lies wholly under the former.

There are two Extendentes or tretchers out, which arie from the Cubit. The firt reaches unto the third Interjuncture, the other unto the econd, and the ret, with many tendons; ometimes one, ometimes two, and otherwhiles three.

The Abducentes are three; two ariing from the Metacarpium, and the third from the bone of the Metacarp, which looks towards the forefinger: which Riolanus calls Autithenar, as the other the former of the bringers to, Hypothenar Pollicis.
The Abducentes or drawers away are three nameles mucles, ave that the aid Riolanus calls one of them Thenar.

The Forefinger has two proper mucles, which ome confound, the firt is the Abductor, ariing from the firt Interjoynting of the Thumb, and terminated into the bones of the Forefinger, wherewith the aid Forefinger is drawn from the ret of the Fingers, towards the Thumb.

The other is the Indicis extenor the tretcher of the Forefinger which Riolanus calls Indicatorem the pointer, as alo Velingus, though he confound it with the Abductor. It aries from the middle and external part of the Cubit, and ends with a double tendon, into the econd interjointure of the forefinger.

There are alo two mucles proper to the mallet finger, the Abductor and Extenor. The former may be parted into many: It aries in the hollow of the hand from the third and fourth writ bones of the econd rank, and ends externally into the ide of the firt joint of the aid finger. Aquapendent and others that have ince followed him, do hold that it draws the little finger outwardly, from the ret. Extenor proprius, which Riolanus exactly eperates from the great one, ariing from the upper part of the radius, and carryed along Cubitus and the Radius, is externally inerted into the finger, with a double tendon,

div.head: Chap 10. Of the Legg and Thigh in generall.
div.p: PES the Leg and Thigh, is all betweenPes what? the Buttocks and the Toes of the Feet: Others call it magnus pes, the great Foot, and Crus. It is divided into its parts, as the Arm, in a manner not unlike, viz. Into the Fem • , Tibia, and Parous Pes.
Again the Parous Pes is divided into Pedium, Metapedium, and Digiti.

The Ue of the Leg and Thigh, is to be the Intrument of walking: which is performed by tirring and itting. For one Leg being firmly et upon the ground, we move and bring about the other, and our Foot being firmly fixt, keeps us from falling: and o we come to walk. The etting therefore of our Leg is the Motion of the whole Body, but the motion proceeds from the Leg, which the length or hortnes of the Leg does either help or hinder; and therefore birds becaue they were to flie, that their bulk might not hinder them, they have a hort Thigh and long Feet, which makes the going be low. But Men go lower then Dogs, bcaue the ucceive putting on of their Foot from the Heel to the Toes, lackens their motion; whereas Dogs with one motion of their little Feet do pas along. Some do conceive that the length of a womans Leg helps to generation. Now there i • an Inciion made into our knees and heel, that we might not go leaping.
This Motion is variouly made by the mucles of the Thigh, Leg and Foot. We are therefore now to treat of the Mucles of the whole Leg.

div.head: Chap 11. Of the Mucles of the Thigh.
div.p: THe Thigh is bended by two Mucles.

The firt is in the Belly, and is termed Poa or the Muculus Lumbaris it aries with a flehy beginning from the upper Vertebraes of the Loins, and is inerted into the forepart of the mall Trochanter, with a round and trong tendon.

The other mucle called Poas minor I found in a trong flehy body at Hafnia, 1651. differing from that which Riolanus brags to have een. For the greater part i •• ay under, but outwardly inclined more to the ides. The beginning was flehy, and the whole mucle was three fingers broad. It was inerted flehy, into the upper brim of Os Ilij backwards, where the Iliacus internus aries. I conceived that its ue was to pread as a pillow under the greater mucle, becaue the Os Ilij is of it elf immoveable, or to hold the Os Ilij upright, that it might not burthen a man too much when he tands. Michael Lyerus a mot expert Anatomit can witnes the ame with me.
The Ilia us ecundus is inerted in the ame place, with a tendon which grows to the tendon of the precedent mucle, ariing from the whole internal cavity of the Os Ilij, by a mall and flehy beginning.
The Thigh is extended by three mucles of the Buttocks termed Glutaei.
I. Is the Major, externus & ampliimus, beginning at the Crupper, the pina of Os Ilij, and the Os acrum; and ends into the Os Femoris, under the great Trochanter.
II. The other is the medius or middlemot in Scituation and Magnitude. It aries from the inner ide of the Spina of Os Ilij, ending into this great Trochanter with a broad and trong tendon.
III. The third called minimus the mallet, lies concealed under the middlemot; It aries from the back of Os Ilij near the Acetabulum with a broad and trong tendon, and Ends into the great Trochanter.
Thee three do make up the flehy Subtance of the Buttocks.

The Thigh is drawn to, and wheeled about inwards by three mucles, which many do reckon for one, and call it triceps triple headed, becaue of its threefold beginning. 1. Is from the upper joynting of the Os pubis. 2. Is from the lowet joynting of Os pubis. 3. Is from the middle part of the aid bone. They are inerted firt of all into the inner head of the Thigh bone, near the Ham, with a round tendon or into the rough line of the Thigh. 2. To the upper, partly. 3. Partly to the lower, at the Rorator minor. Riolanus has other inertions: For he will have the firt to be inerted into the middle of the Thigh, the econd to be produced with a very trong Tendon as far as to the End of the Thigh, the third below the neck of the Thighbone.

To thee Spigelius and Velingus do add one which they call Lividus ariing at the joyning of Os pubis, near the Gritle, and implanted with a hort tendon, into the inner ide of the thigh: but they grant that this is a portion of the Triceps. But they do ill to reckon it among the bending Mucles. But Riolanus calls it Pectineus and reckons it for a bender, yet acknowledges that it is the uppermot and fourth portion of the triceps, which with Fallopius he divides into four Mucles, and indeed it eems to have o many parts.
It is drawn away and turned about outwards by ix Mucles the Quadrigemini and the two Obturatores.

The Quadrigemini are in a manner one like another, and little, placed as it were athwart, ariing from the lower and outer part of the Os Sacrum, the bunch of Os Ichij, and the Appendix of the Hip-bone. They are inerted into that pace which is between the two Trochanters. The firt Quadrigeminus is called Pyriformis Pear-fahioned, becaue of its hape, and Iliaeus externus from its Scituation; the ret want names, ave the fourth, which is called Quadratus.

The Obturatores toppers, take up the wide hole between the Os pubis and Os Iehij. And they are external or internal, the former ariing from the outer Circle of the hole of the hare: the latter from the inner and they are inerted into the great Trochanter: the inner may be termed Buralis or pure-fahioned becaue it hides the fourfold tendons in a flehy pure as it were, nearly haped by the third and fourth quadrigeminal Mucles.

div.head: Chap. 12. Of the Mucles of the Legg.
div.p: THe Leg is bent by the four muculi potici.

One of them has two Heads, termed Bioeps, the firt from the joyning of the Os pubis, the econd from the outer part of the thigh, and both of them are inerted with one tendon, the flehy ubtance being firt increaed in the middle, into the hinder part of the Leg.
The econd called Semimembranous aries from the welling of the Ichium, and is inerted into the inner ide of the Leg, backwards.

The third is the Seminervous, and has the ame beginning and the ame end with the former, ave that in the hinder parts it is carried little forward obliquely, before it terminates at the inide of the Leg.
The fourth is the Gracilis, which is inerted into the ame place, and aries from the joyning of the harebone.
Four Mucles extend the Leg.
The firt is the Rectus, ariing with an acute tendon from the outer and lower Spine of the Ilium.

The econd and third are the two Vati, the external ariing from the whole root, the great Trochanters, and the bone of the Thigh which lies under: the Inner from the mall Trochanter: they are terminated on each hand at the ide of the Rectus.
The fourth is the Crureus, fixed to the Thigh bone, as the Brachiaeus is to the Brachium.
Thee four Mucles, are terminated into one tendon, which embracing the ubtance of the fleh into it elf, it is inerted before into the beginning of the Leg, and is there intead of a Ligament for it.
Two Mucles, pul it to, inwards.

The firt is the longus, facialis or artorius which Spigelius and Velingus reckon among the benders, on which Tailors or Borchers ret themelves when they it cros-leg'd. It is well nigh the longet of all mucles, ariing from the former Spina of Os Ilij, and decending obliquely unto the inner and fore-part of the Leg.
The other is the Popliteus ariing from the lower and outer extuberancy of the Thigh, and being inerted four-quare into the inner and upper part of the leg obliquely.
The Abductor is one, which is called Membranous and facia lata.
It aries flehy from the Spina of Os Ilij, and is carried obliquely, into the outer part of the Leg, and with its mot broad and long tendon, invets well-near all the Mucles of the Thigh.

div.head: Chap. 13. Of the Mucles of the Feet.
div.p: THe Foot is bended and extended. Two mucles bend it forwards.

The firt is termed tibiaeus anticus, affixed to the Leg ariing from the upper proces thereof, it is inerted into the Os Pedij, before the great Toe, with a tendon which at the end is divided into two.

The other is Peroneus biceps, which others count for two mucles, one head ariing from the upper Epiphiis of the Fibula, the other from the middle of the Perone. It has a double tendon the leer carried into the bone of the little toe; and the greater going obliquely under the ole of the Foot, is inerted into the Os pedij jut againt the great toe.

'Tis extended backwards by the four Potici, duo gemelli, the internal and the external, called Gatrocnemij, becaue they contitute the ankle, and arie from the inner and outer head of the thigh under the Ham. The third being cal'd oleus is added to thee beneath,
ariing from the hindermore appendix of the fibula. Thee three mucles are terminated into a mot thick and trong tendon, to be inerted into the beginning of the Heel and Pterna, by which beats being killed, are uually hung up. Hypocrates did term it chorda: where by reaon of the fracture of the Heel, he ayes that hiccuping and convulive feavers do follow.

The lat is called plantaris and anwers to the palmaris in the hand; it is lean and meagre, and degenerates into a long tendon, and covering the whole ole of the foot, it aries from the outward head of the Thigh bone, under the Ham: and is inerted into the five toes, and has the ame ue here which it has in the Hand: though the comparion of one to the other holds not out very exact. Velingus has oberved that this mucle has ometimes been wanting.
The Tibiaeus poticus mut be added to thee, which Spigelius reckons amongt the oblique movers, and Riolanus among the extenders.

div.head: Chap. 14. Of the Mucles of the Toes.
div.p: THe Toes of the foot are moved by mucles, as well as the fingers of the hand.

Two mucles bend the Toes, the Magnus which anwers to the profundus, ariing from the upper Epiphiis of the Tibia, under the ole is divided into four tendons, which boreing through the minor, they are implanted into the third Articulation of the four toes. The Minor anwering to the ublimis, is the midt of the ole of the foot, ariing from the lower part of the pterna or heel bone, it is carried into the econd articulation of the four toes, to which before it comes it is bored thorough, that it may tranmit the tendons of the foremot Mucle: and therefore this is called perforatus, the other perforans.

One mucle extends the four toes of the foot, which is by ome divided into two; ariing from the upper and outer part of the tibia, and having four tendons, which are inerted into the econd and third Interjuncture.
The four wormfahioned Mucles do draw them to, anwering to thoe in the Hand, ome fleh being interprinkled from the Heel: They are fatned by o many tendons to the firt interjoynting.

The ten Interoei do draw them away, ariing from the bones of the pedium, and falling the void paces of the Metapedium, they are external or internal, the former with a broad tendon do arie by the ides, to the firt interjoynting of the toes by the ides; the latter at the econd interjoynting: but the ninth erves for the drawing-to of the great Toe, the tenth for the drawing to of the little toe.
The great Toe has peculiar mucles.
It is bent by one only, proceeding from the upper part of the fibula, and inerted into the third interjointing (Riolanus ayes the firt) of the great toe.
It is extended by another, ariing from the middle of the Fibula (or as ome ay from the outide of the tibia, where it recedes from the Fibula) which is oftentimes divided into two tendons.
It is brought to, with one, inwardly fatned to the greatet bone of the pedium.
It is drawn away by one ariing flehy from the inner part of the heel, and entring extrinecally into the firt bone of the great toe.

Now there is a new mucle found out above the Interoeans, the firt Inventor whereof is Caerius; who calls it tranveralis, becaue of its ituation. Velingus call it the Adductor pollicis minor, which ue nature eems to have intended.

It aries nervous and broad, from the ligament of the firt interjuncture of the little Toe, and ometime from one of the toes next the little toe; and by and by becoming flehy and o continuing, it is carried athwart over the firt joints of the fingers, and with a hort and broad tendon, it is implanted into the firt joynt of the Great-toe, a little inwards.

The Ue hereof is, to ecure our walking, when we pas through rough wayes, full of round flints, or over any other mall, lippery, or rowling paage. For by help of this mucle, the foot does accommodate it elf, to the figure of the Bodies we tread on, and layes hold thereon as it were, that it might make its paage more tead-fat.
The Abductor of the little toe, ticking in the outide of the foot broad and vat, ariing from the ame part of the heel, is inerted into the outide of the firt Interjuncture.
I have oberved a peculiar bender of the little toe, long, round, ariing from the head of the Tibia, and divided with two tendons about the inertion of the toe.

Finally a flehy mas is to be oberved in the ole of the foot, as well as in the Palm of the hand, wherewith our footing is fatened as with a cuhion, and the tendons of the mucles do lie hidden, in a oft Pillow.

div.head: THE FIRST MANUAL Concerning the Veins, Anwering to the FIRST BOOK OF THE Lower Belly.
div.p: ABove, in the Proaem of this Anatomical work, I promied four Books, and four little Books or Manuals. Four Books touching the three Cavities and the Limbs; Four Manuals, viz. touching the Veins, Arteries, Nerves and Bones. Now every Manual anwers to its Book. Becaue from the lower Cavity, namely, the principal part thereof, the Liver arie the Veins; from the Heart in the middle Cavity the Arteries; from the Marrow in the third Cavity the Nerves, and to the Limbs the Bones do anwer. And even as the Bones joyned together do make a peculiar Fabrick or Skeleton, repreenting the form of the whol Animal; o alo do the Veins, Arteries and Nerves. And Gulielmus Fabricius Hildanus a Famous Chyrurgeon hath uch a Frame of all the Veins of the Body artificially eparated; and at Padua by the Intruction of Ad. Spigelius, and John Velingius, and John Leonicenus uch Frames of the Veins Arteries and Nerves eperated from the body, are commonly to be een at Padua; and the like is to be een here at Hafnia acurately made, and explained in four very great Tables, in the Cutody of the renowned D. D. Henricus Fuiren my Coin Germane.
The Veins, Arteries and Nerves are Organs or common veels of the Body, through which ome pirit, with or without Blood, is carried from ome principal member, into undry parts of the Body.

div.head: Chap. 1. Of a Vein in General.
div.p: AVein is a common Organ, round, long,What a Vein is? hollow like a channel or Conduit pipe, fit to carry or bring back Blood and Natural Spirit.

The term Vein was by the Ancients given both to Veins and Arteries; but they cal'd the Arteries puling Veins, and the Veins not puling Veins, and ome called Vein, the greater Vein, and an Artery the leer Vein and the Aorta.
The Efficient of a Vein, is the proper vein-making power or faculty.
The Matter according to Hippocrates is a clammy and cold portion of the Seed. And this is the principle of a Veins Original.

But the Principle of Dipenation'Tis proved againt Aritotle that the Liver, not the Heart is the Original of the Veins. from whence the Veins arie, is the Liver (not to peak of ome ancient triflers, who would derive the Veins from the Brain) and not the Heart, as Aritotle would have it. For,

list.item: 1. Blood is made in the Liver. AndBlood is not made in the Heart. therefore 'tis like the original and rie of the Veins is there and that the firt anguiication is not made in the Heart is apparent, becaue there are no paages to conveigh the Chylus to the Heart; again there are no receptacles for the Excrements of the firt concoction placed by the Heart. But all thee requiites are found in the Liver.

2. Blood is carried from the Liver to the Heart, but not from the Heart immediately to the Liver. For Blood cannot go out of the Heart into the Liver, becaue of the Valves; though mediately when it runs back out of the Arteries, it may be carried thither.
3. Fihes have no right Ventricle in their Hearts, in which they would have Blood to be made; and out of which they would have the Veins to arie, and the Fihes have both Veins and Blood.

4. The Vena portae touches not the Heart but the Liver, which the Cava alo touches: which two Veins are the greatet in the whole body. But according to Aritotle
all Veins ought to be continued with the Heart. You wil ay; the Vena arterioa does not touch the Liver. I anwer, neither ought if o to do: becaue it hath the ubtance of an Artery, and therefore aries from the Heart. But Arteria Venoa, is a Vein in ubtance and ue, and in the Child in the womb, was continued with the Cava.
5. In the Child in the womb, the Navil-vein with Blood goes into the Liver, not into the Heart.
6. If the Veins hould arie from the Heart, they would pule as the Arteries do, for the whole Heart pules.
7. Sanguification is never hurt, but when the Liver is hurt, as in a Dropie, &c.

div.p:
Thee are the chief reaons for this Opinion: but many other reaons of other men againt Aritot ••
I reject as weak and eaily refuted, as alo many weak reaons of the Peripateticks, againt this Opinion which we aert, which any one may eaily anwer, if he be at leat but lightly skilled in Anatomy.
The End and e of a Vein is,

I. According to the Opinion of the Ancient •
The e of the Veins. According to the Ancients. to carry Blood and Natural Spirit with the Natural faculty, from the Liver into all parts of the Body to nourih the ame.

But Nature hath revealed otherwie to their Poterity: for neither do the VeinsAccording • o later Authors the Primary e. carry any thing from the Liver to nourih the parts with, nor is the Venal Blood ueful for nutrition. But they bringback all the Blood, only to the Heart by Circulation, either mediately by the • iver, as the Mearaick Veins, or immediately, as the Cava; and that either from the whole body, from the mallet branches to the greatet, by the upper and lower branch; or from the Liver whether it be there generated, or is derived from the Mearaicks and Arteries.
And that they bring the Blood to the Heart as to the Centre, and that they bring it from the mallet parts as from the Circumference, is evidently provided by ocular Inpection, Experiments, and Reaon.

list.item: 2. Without Blood-letting, the Veins being preed with the finger hew as much: for if in an Arm either hot, or whoe Veins naturally well, you force the blood downwards with your finger towards the fingers, there follows no blood in the upper part of the Vein, but it appears empty. Contrariwie, if you force the blood from the Fingers-ward upwards, you hall preently ee the Veins full, more blood following that which you forced up.

3. If you hall plunge your Arms and Legs into cold Water or Snow, being firt bound, when you unbind the ame, you hal perceive your Heart offended and made cold, by the cold blood acending thereunto; and it will be warmed if you put your Legs or Arms as aforeaid into hot water. Nor is it any other way by which cordiall Epithems applied to the Writs and Privities do good.

4. In perons that are hanged, their Heads and Faces become red, the Veins being ditended, becaue the recoure of the Blood into the Heart i • hindred as in opening of the Veins of the Head, the upper parts in the Head well, the other parts towards the Heart being empty. But the Halter being looed from the dead body, the welling and rednes of the Face does fall by little and little, unles the Blood which is forced into the mallet Veins cannot run back again becaue of the coldnes of the parts.

5. In Diections of Live-Animals, the matter is mot evident. For in what part of the body oever you bind a Vein, it appears lank and empty on that ide of the Ligature next the Heart, and on the other ide it wels where it is furthet from the Heart, and neeret the extream parts of the Body.

6. In a living Anatomy, if you lift up a Vein and open it being tied, beyond the Ligature plenty of Blood flows out, on this ide nothing at all, which you hall find true in the crural and jugular Veins of any Creature whatoever, though you cut the Veins quite in under, as I have often experimented with the great Walaeus, and Harvey was not ignorant thereof.

7, The Valves of the Veins do conpire to this end, which are o contrived, that they tand all wide open towards the Heart, and afford an eaie paage from the mallet Veins to the greatet, and from thence to the Heart. But from the Heart and great Veins, being hut they uffer nothing to go back, no not Water driven by force, or a Probe, unles being hurt they gape.

8. The Liver ends only to the Heart; the Heart only to the Lungs, and all the Arteries; as hath been already demontrated concerning the Heart. Seeing therefore the Blood by continual pulation is ent in o great quantity in all parts, and yet cannot be repaired by Diet, nor can return back to the Heart by reaon of the Miter-fahioned Valves of the Aorta, nor abide til in the Arteries which are continually driving the ame, nor finally is there o much pent by the parts to be nourihed; it follows, that what remains over and above is brought back again to the heart, and enters the Veins by Circulation. Whereof although ome dark Footteps are extant in the writings of the Ancients, as I have proved in my Book de Luce Animalium, and Walaeus and Riolanus do afterward declare the ame at large; yet it hath been more ••• erly manifeted in this Age of ours to that mot ingenious Venetian Paul Sarpias Fulgentius as relates from his papers, and oon after to Harvey an Englihman, to whom the commendations and praie of firt publihing the ame to the World and proving i • by many Arguments and Experiments, are jutly due, finally to Walaeus and others approving the ame.

div.p: The Primary End therefore of the Veins is to carry and recarry Blood unto the Heart the econdary ends may be thee following.
II. A little to prepare the aid Blood,Their econdary e. as do the Rami Lactei, or to finih and perfect the ame, as a mall portion of Vena Cavae between the Liver and the Heart.

III. To pererve the Blood, as the proper place preerves that which is placed therein, as much as may be in a peedy paage, and to retain it within its bounds. For extravenated Blood, or Blood out of its natural place, viz. Veins and Arteries, curdles and putrefies. Alo in the Veins themelves, when they are ill affected, and the coure of the Blood is topped, omtimes the Blood is found congealed, witnes Fernelius: omtimes a fatty ubtance is found intead of Blood, as in the Nerves, which Bontius aw among the Indians.
IV. Some would have the red veins to make Blood, and the milkie veins to make Chyle, but they are quite mitaken.
The Form of the Veins is taken from undry Accidents.
Its Figure is that of a Conduit pipe.Figure.

Its Magnitude varies. For the Veins are great in the Livet, as in their Original; in theMagnitude. Lungs becaue they are hot, oft, and in perpepetual motion, and thereote they need much nourihment, becaue much of their ubtance pends; but epecially becaue all the Blood in the Body paes this way, out of the right into the left Venrricle of the Heart, as hath been proved already. In the Heart by reaon of its heat, and becaue it is to furnih the whole Body with Arterial Blood, received in and ent out by continual pulings. Alo the emulgent Veins are great, by reaon of plenty of blood and eroities, which is brought back from the Kidnies to the Vena Cava. But where the ubtance of a part is lating, and is not eaily diipated, by reaon of the mal quantity of Heat, the Veins are leer as in the Brain, where the Veins do not alwaies eaily appear, and in the Bones, where they never manifetly appear, though the Animal be great.

In all parts towards the ends they are very mall, and are divided into Capillary Veins, prinkled into, & commonly confounded with the fleh, that the uperfluous Blood may be better received into them; which is one way, by which the Arterial Blood is mediately paed through the porous fleh to the Veins, which way alo Blood made of Chyle in the Liver, is infued into the little branches of the Venae Cava. The other is, by the Arteries immediately. For,

The Connexion is uch with the Arteries, that every Vein is for the mot part attendedConnexion. with an Artery, over which it lies and which it touches. Gale •
tels us a a Vein is eldom found without Arteries; but no Artery is ever found without a Vein.

But there is in the Body a mutual Anatomois of Veins and Arteries: thatAnatomois of Veins and Arteries. they may conpire together, and the Veins receive out of the Arteries Spirit & Blood; which is apparent from reaon, becaue, 1. If the Veins be quite emptied, the Arteries are empty alo. Moreover out of a Vein opened in the Arm or Hand, all the Blood in the Body may be let out, which, becaue it cannot be contained or generated in the Hand, it mut necearily come out of the Arteries beneath and round about, by means of the Anatomoes: whereof this alo is a token, that if the Vein and Artery of the Arm be tied very hard, the Blood ceaes running and the pule tops it beating, til the band be lackned. 2. They are neceary in repect of the Circular motion of the blood, eeing the pores of the Fleh are not ufficient, ave in a low coure, and ubtile Blood.

Moreover they may be demontrated in many places to the Eye-ight, where the Conjunctions of the Veins with the Arteries are viible, viz. in the Brain, in the Plexus Chorides, the Cavities, in the Lungs of the Vena Arterioa. and the Arteria Venoa, with the Branches of the Apera Arteria or Weand. Of the Thoracick branches decending, with the intercotal Veins. Alo the Hypogatrick Veins and Arteries, with the Mammary veels are joyned mouth to mouth under the Muculi Recti in the Abdomen. But the Anatomoes or mutual conjunction of the mouths of the Cava and Portae in the Liver, and of the Veins and Arteries in the Spleen, are in a pecial manner manifet; o in the Veins of the Womb, the eminary veels, the Navil-trings, and the extemities of the Hands and Feet.

Though the Anatomoes or conjunctionsAnatomoes of the Veins in the Liver. of veels, are in reaon neceary, and manifet to the Eye-ight, yet are they not all manifetly dicernable by the Sight.. I made experiment in the Liver of an Ox and of a Man, diligently eparating all the ubtance from the veels; yet could I not either with a Probe, or a Knife, or a pair of Bellows find the Anatomoes of Vena Cavae and Vena Porta open, but all blind, in dead bodies, though it is not to be doubted, but that they are open in in living bodies, where all the paages are inlarged by Heat.

div.p: I found them to be of divers kinds. The firt Paralel when the utmot twigs are joynedOf undry kinds. one to another in right lines. The econd is of Trunk with Trunk, a tranvere veel going between. The third is cros-fahion'd, when either the Branches go over the Trunk, or the Trunk go over the Branches cros-wie, or the Branches over the Branches in the ame manner. The fourth is mixt of the Crosfahion'd and the oblique. The fit is oblique or angular, when the Branches are mutually inerted obliquely. I have before explained the Anatomoes of the Navilveels. Now the Anatomoes between the Veins and Arteries, are either in the Trunks or the Capillary Veels.

The Veins are omtimes inveted with a common Membrane, or ome externalWhy the Veins are in ome places inveted with Coats, in others not. thick one, borrowed from the Neighboring parts, when either they are upended and carried a long way, and are without the Bowels and Mucles; or when they ret upon hard bodies. This happens in the lowet Belly, to the Veins and Arteries from the Peritoneum, and in the Chet from the Pleura.

But where a Vein is inerted either into ome Bowell or a Mucle, it needs not this common coat, becaue 1. It is otherwie ufficiently uteined. 2. Otherwie the ready weating through of the blood would be hindred. 3. And the laying down of the Excrements of the Vein. 4. It would not o oon be enible of the force of the ubtance of any Bowell. 5. It would more hardly imbibe the Blood which is uperfluous after the nourihment of the parts.

Now the Veins being o compaed with Membranes do not feel (unles they have Nerves neer them) of themelves and by their own Nature, neither the acrimony of the Humors contained, nor cutting or burning. And therefore Aritotle aies in his third Book de Hitoria Animalium chap. 5. A Nerve cannot endure the Fire, but a Vein can. And Galen in his ixt de uu partium chap
•• . aies that if Veins and Arteries be cut, burnt, or tied, they feel it not at all.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Subtance of the Veins and of the Valves.
div.p: THe Subtance of the Veins is Membranous, that they may more eaily tretch and hrink in again.

They have only one Coat, which is proper to them (the Arteries have two) being thin and rare; becaue through it the blood is to be received after the parts are nourihed. it carries not back uch tirring and hot blood as the Arteries carry; becaue it is grown cold and returns quietly to the Heart without any beating of the Pule that it may be there again perfected.

Some conceive that a Vein is interwovenWhether the Veins have Fibres. with a triple kind of Fibres: but they ad, that thoe fibres are there obcurely, and only potentially, nor can be moved out of their place, by reaon of the mot trait contexture. But I rather conceive with Vealius, that others imagin Fibres to be there, which are no more there than in Leather. for when we pull the ubtance of the Reins all in pieces, no fibres are there to be een. But ome Authors attribute fibres to the Veins, becaue they have praeconceived this opinion, that Attraction, Expulion and Retention are performed by undry orts of fibres, whenas the fibres if they have any are to trengthen them.

Harvey and W •… do upect that the Blood in the Veins is driven to the Heart, by the fibres, which nevertheles I conceive to be done, by the motion and contraction of the Mucles, with which the Veins are mingled, they not reiting. Yea, and it may be driven by the blood continually following, from the parts and Arteries moved by the Pule. But others alleadge attraction to be made by heat, without the fibres.

Within the Veins are found certainWho firt oberved the Valves in the Veins. Valves or little folding Gates, which Bauhine aies are mentioned by Avicenna, under the name of Cells. Aquapendens aies himelf was the finder of them in the year 1574. to whom Paulus Servita or Sarpi the Venetian gave the firt hint though it eems apparent by his Iagoge, that Jacobus Silvius had alo ome knowledg of them. But after him or with him mention was made of thee Valves by Salomon Albertus, Axc •• ng • l • s Pi • holhomineus, and Caper •• Bauhinus; Laurentius doth hardly once peak of them.

The occaion of Aquapendents finding of them was this: he oberved thatHow the Valves of the Veins were found. if he pret the Veins, or by rubbing endeavored to force the Blood downwards, its coure did eem to be topped. Alo in the Arms of perons bound to be let Blood, certain knots apper to well by reaon of the Valves; and in ome perons, as Porters and Plough-men, they are een to wel in their Thighs like the Varices.

And here eems to conit the Caue of the Varices; becaue thick Blood and byThe Caue of the Varices. its heavines unapt to move upwards, being long retained in the Valves, makes a dilatation of the aid Valves: for without the Valves the Veins would wel uniformly and all of an equal Bignes, and not in the manner of Varices.
And becaue this Doctrine of the Valves in the Veins, is known to few, I hall propound the ame more exactly, according to my manner of handling rare ubjects.

Thee Valves are mot, thin little Membranes (thicker in the Orifices ofThe Valves of the Veins what? of the Veins of the Heart) in the inner Cavity of the Veins; and certain particles as it were of the coat of the Veins; becaue there the body of the Veins is mot thin, where th • e Membranes do go from it.

They are eated in the Cavity of theWhere they are not found at the original of the Veins? Veins, but epecially in the Veins of the Limbs, viz. of the Arms and Legs, after the Kernels of the Arm-pits and and Groyns. Beginning preently after the rie of the Branches, not in the Ries themelves. Now there are two found in the inner orifice of the jugular Vein, looking from above downwards; the ret look from below upwards, as many in the Cephalica, the Bailica, and in the Veins of the Legs and Thighs.

No Valves are found in the Trunk of Cava, becaue the Valves placed inWhy Valves are not found in the Trunk of Cava, the jugulars, the external mall Veins, nor in the Arteries? the Divarications do ufficiently hinder the regres of the Blood, nor doth the Trunk make any delay. nor are there any in the Jugulars (beides thoe aforeaid in the Orifice of the inner Veins) becaue the venal Blood of it elf heavy, doth hardly acend upwards, nor doth it there need any top. In like manner there are none in the external mall Veins; becaue in regard of their mallnes, they needed none, nor is there any danger of the Bloods regres, by reaon of the neernes of the parts and Arteries which drives the ame. We alo with Harvey have found Valves in the emulgents, and in the Branches of the Meentery, looking towards the Venae cava and Porta. Nature endeavored the ame in the Milkie Veins; alo Dogs and Oxen have them in the diviion of the crural Veins. Alo there are none in the Arteries, becaue in them there alwaies is and ought to be

a Flux of pirituous Blood, which begins ucceively and ends with the Sytole and Diatole of the whole Body; nor is there any thing to urge a Reflux; moreover the the Arteries are of themelves ufficiently trong. Yet I have ometimes oberved the footteps of a Valve in the Artery of the Arm, and it may be to tay the Blood running in the Arteries in that ubject, that it may not return, as we ee in the beginning of the Aorta, and the Vena Arterioa.

Now the Valves are o ituate, that they have their Orifices upwards towards the roots of the Veins, and are hut beneath, and alwaies look towards the Heart. And the workmanhip of Nature is remarkable in their ituation, in that they have their potures looking the ame way one following another, as knots in the Branches and Stalks of Plants. that is to ay, they are not in a right line one againt another, or placed on the ame ide, leat the whole Blood hould flow treight in through the free part of the veel. So the lower Valves do top, what the upper have let lip: and if all the doors of the Valves had been dipoed in one right line, there had been little or no delay made in the regres.

Moreover they are ituate at Ditances, according to the length of the veel, ometimes two, three, four, or five fingers ditance; that if the Blood by ome default hould be compelled to flow backwards, and hould pas the upper Valves, falling on upon the other Valves following, it might be topped and hindered.

As to their Magnitude they are greater where by reaon of the plenty of BloodTheir Magnitude. the Recoure is mot vehement, and therefore greater inconvenience was to be feared to happen, either to the parts which would be too much oppreed, or to the Heart leat it hould be detitute of Blood; as we ee in the Bailica and in the Crar •• Vein at the Groyns.
The Number of all the Valves varies,In what Perons there are mot Valves. as alo their ditances; for there are more Valves in thoe

list.item: 1. Who abound with melancholly Blood, or contrarily with very cholerick and thin Blood; becaue both thoe humors do not only eaily reit the Driver, but when they are driven, by their weight and tenuity, they eaily flow back.
2. In great or more flehy Bodies and conequently having more Veins.
3. In uch as have the broadet veels.
4. In uch who have long and treight Veins; for in uch as are oblique, the crookednes of the veels gives ome top to the running back of the Blood.

div.p:
Moreover, the number of Valves in one and the ame place doth not exceed two. For they are eated at ditances, omtimes one, otherwhiles two at mot; not a • any time three, as we find in the Veels of the Heartt becaue in the Heart a greater orifice is to be hut, and the Ventricle underneath is larger, yea and the greate • violence of the Blood in the hot Heart, did require more tops, But in the progres of the Veins, their Branching diminihes their Magnitude, and the blood is lower in
motion. Therefore where the Veins are yet pretty big, and there is danger from the plenty of Blood, there are two doors, but otherwie but only one.
Its Figure likens the Nail on a Mans finger or the horned Moon, uch as you ee inIts Figure. the igma-hap'd Valves of the Heart.

Its Subtance is exceeding thin, but withallSubtance. very compact, let they hould break by a trong incoure of the blood. And this is apparent from the Varices, where they can contein the blood a very long time.
The e is I. To trengthen the Veins, whereas the Arteries are otherwie made trong by the e. doublenes of their coats.

II. The chief ue according to Aquapendent and mot Anatomits following him, is to top the motion of heavy and fluid Blood, which runs violently into the Arms and Thighs, and Legs, becaue of their downward poition; but epecially in mot vehement motion and exercie, where through the power of exceeding heat, the Blood would ruh impetuouly into the Limbs, and o 1. The inner and more noble parts would be defrauded of their nutriment. 2. The Veins of the Limbs would be too much tretched, and in danger of breaking, and conequently the Arms and Legs would be alwaies welled.

But this ue is rejected by Harvey, becaue 1. In the Jugulars they look downwards. According to Harvey. 2. In the emulgent and Meenterick branches, they look towards the Porta and Cavae. 3. There are none • o the Arteries. 4. Dogs and Oxen have the ame, in the diviion of the crural Veins, in whom becaue of their going downwards, there is no uch thing as aforeaid to be feared. 5. The Blood of its own accord is lowly enough driven, out of the greater Veins into the leer Branches, and out of hotter into colder places. And therefore according to his principles, and the principles of Circulation, the ue of the Valves is,

III. Let the Blood hould move out of the great veins into the little ones and o tear them; or from the Centre of the Body into the outmot parts, but rather from the extremities to the Centre. And therefore they do the ame thing in the Veins, which the Sigma and Miterhap'd Valves do in the Heart.

But in the Orifice of the Jugular Vein internal they perform the ame Office, leat in the bowing back of the Head, the Blood hould return into the Brain, and like a Flood oppres the ame, diturb the Animal Functions, and breed a anguine Apoplexy.

div.head: Chap. 3. Of the Diviion of the Veins of the Body, and of the Vena Portae and the Venae Lacteae.
div.p: ALL the Veins of the whole Body are referred unto two as their Mothers; viz. the Vena Portae and the Vena Cava, to which is joyned a third kind of veels found out by Aellius viz, the Milky Veins, of which we hal peak by and by.
The Ven • Portae its Original and Root is the Vena Umbilicalis, of which I pake in the firt Book, the firt of all the Veins, ariing from the Seed.

Now it is termed Vena Portae, or Quae ad Portas et, the Gate-vein, andThe Vena Portae, why o called. Vein at the Gates, and Vena otiaria, the Door-vein; becaue through the roots thereof, or, as others wil have it, its branches, viz. the Mearaick Veins, the Chyle being u • t out of the Stomach and Guts was anciently thought to be carried, as it were by Gates into the Liver. The Arabians cal'd it Vena Lactea, becaue they thought it drew the Chyle, white like Milk.
This is the greatet Vein in the Body next the Cava, and is commonly aid to arie out of the hollow part of the Liver. And it is not o compact as the Cava, but more looe and oft.
It is divided into the Trunk and Branches.
The Branches are upper and lower: The Branches of the Portae in the Liver, termed Roots. and ome call the former Roots, others the latter.

They call the former Roots becaue this Vein is aid to have its original out of the Liver: the latter, becaue as Roots uck matter out of the Earth, and carry it into the Trunk of the Tree: even o alo the Venae Me • raicae, which are the lower branches of Portae, do uck Chyle like Roots (according to the Ancients, but according to out late opinion blood out of the Meentery) and carry it to the Liver by the Trunk and upper Branches; and therefore the Meeraick Veins are termed the Livers Hands. We may therefore call them all, both branches and roots, in a different repect.

The upper Branches, four or five of them are pred up and down the hollow part of the Liver, which afterwards, beneath and without the Liver, grow into one Trunk. Touching thee and their Anatomoes, ee above, in the Chap. of the Liver, Book the 1.
The Trunk before it is divided into lower Branches, ends two mall Veins to the Gall-bladder which are termed Cyticae gemellae; another Vein to the Stomach, which is therefore cal'd Gatrica dextra.
Afterward the Trunk inclining to the left hand, it is divided into two remarkable lower Branches: the one higher and leer, going towards the left ide; the other lower and larger on the right ide.

The former is called Splenicus, becaue itThe Spleen-Veins of the Stomach. goes into the Spleen, & before it is divided it preads from it elf two upper Branches to the Stomach, the Gatrica minor and Gatrica major, the larget of all the Stomach Veins, which afterwards contitutes theCall. Pancreas. the Coronaria. Then it ends lower branches to the Call and one to the Pancreas.

Thee being thus contituted, the Truncus Spleen. Splenicus is divided, into the upper and lower Branch. The • o mer produces theCall. Vas breve and other little branches carried into the Spleen. The latter producesStomach. two Veins for the Call and Stomach which are termed Epiplois initra and Gatroepiplois initra. Finally, the ret of its mall branches, are pent up and down in the Spleen.

The Ramus dexter of the Vena portae, before it is divided, produces two Veins,Of the Stomach. Call. Guts. 1. To the right ide of the Stomach and Call. 2. To the Guts, viz. the middle of Duodenum, and the beginning of the Jejunum: whence certain capillary twigs go through the Pancreas and Call upwards.

Afterwards an whole large Branch goes into the Meentery, and being carried betweenOf the Meentery. the two coats thereof, it is ditributed into three notable Branches, called Rami meenterici, the Meenteric branches.

The right-hand meenteric branch is two-fold, which pends it elf into fourteen nameles branches, and thee again into innumerable Off-prings of Veins termed the Mearaick Veins in the Guts, Iejunum, Ileon and Caecum and part of Colon. The Meeraick Veins. whoe

Ue is, 1. According to the Ancients, to uck the Chylus out of the Guts, and toTheir Ue. carry it by the Trunk of Vena port •
into the Liver. but the milkie juyce of the Chylus is

page 307 never found in thee, they being alwaies full of Blood. Moreover the finding out of the Milkie Veins is repugnant to this Ue. Howbeit in time of neceity when the milkie veins are totally obtructed, Riolanus grants that the Chylus is carried by thee without any Argument. For they do not open themelves into the Guts, for then blood would be poured into them, and in my judgment, nutrition hould rather ceae, as we ee in the Lientery, when they are obtructed.

Harvey to refute the milkie veins, and withall to maintain his Circulation in theAccording • o Harvey. Meentery, does uppoe that as the Navilveins draw in alimentary juyce from the Liquors of the Egg, and carry it to nourih and increae the Chick •… even o the Mearaick Veins do uck Chyle out of the Guts, and carry it into the Liver, even in a grown peron. But then they hould carry Chyle and Blood together, and o divers juyces would be jumbled together, uch as were digeted with thoe that are indigeted. And what need is there to confound Veels that Nature hath ditinguihed. And every one knows, that the ue of the Navil-veels, is different in a Child in the womb and, grown peron.
2. According to the ame Antients, to prepare the aid Chyle in ome meaure, and to give it the rudiments of Blood. which would be true if the Hypotheis were true.

3. According to the aid Ancients, to carry the Blood back from the Liver, to nourih the Guts. But o a contrary

Page 308 motion would happen the ame way, at the ame time, viz. of the Chyle to the Liver, and of the Blood back again to the Guts, and thoe humors being confounded would hinder the motion of one another. I forbear to ay, that this blood not being perfected in the Heart, is unfit for nourihment.

4 According to others and my Father Bartholinus amongt the ret, to carry thick blood made in the Spleen from thence to the Guts to nourih them. which were true did not the Circulation teach otherwie, which hath been found out ince his time. And that ame blood would be more fit to nourih, by reaon of the abundance of Arteries in the Spleen. The Veels being changed, this Opinion would be abolutely true.

5. Aellius, who rightly aigns the milkie veins to carry Chyle to the Liver, hath hewn that thee common mearaick Veins do erve to no other intent, then to bring blood out of the Liver to nourih the Guts. which ue, being before refuted, he is therein to be excued, who was likewie ignorant of the true motion of the blood.

6. Their true Ue is to bring the Blood back after the the nutriment of the Guts, into the Liver, which had bin carried to the Guts, by the mearaick Arteries. This is apparent by Ligatures in living Creatures, which Walaeus practied, in which they well towards the Liver, but are empty towards the Guts. The Valves hew as much, which were by Harvey found out in the mearaick veins, looking towards the Cava and the venae portae, which Columbus alo oberved, and which hinder the blood of vena portae from paing into the Guts. Nor does the Conflux of humors out of the Body about the Guts hinder, whither the Humors flow thither of their own accord or provoked by medicaments; becaue this paage of the Humors is certainly through the meenterick Arteries which neither Spigelius denies, nor thoe that maintaine the Circulation of the Blood.

The left Meenterick branch is pread abroad into the left and middlemot part of the Meenterie, and part of the Colon from the left ide of the Stomach, and to the Inietinum rectum. Hence aries the Vena Haemorrhoidalis interna o called, of which in the following and proper Chapter.

This Age of ours being clearer ighted then the former, has foundThe Hitory of the Milkie Veins. out the milkie Veins in the Meentery o called, from the white colour of the Chyle in them, which beides the Mearaicks, make a fourth kind of veels, through which the Chylus is carried into the Liver. Eraitratus in Galen had a glimpe of thee veins, but after him, the firt that dicovered them was Capar Aellius an Anatomit of Ticinum, in the diection of a living dog well fed, on the twenty third of July in, the yeer 1622. In whoe footteps accurate Anatomits treading, who pried nothing more then truth, have found by tetimony of their eyes, that thoe ame veels full of a milkie juyce, are peculiar paages different from the Mearaicks. For in living Creatures they are allwayes to be een, if they be diected about four hours after they have been well fed, viz. when the Chylus is ditributed: for after that time they are not to be een, howbeit, though empty, they alwaies appear like little fibres which have deceived ome, making them to take thee veels for nervs: but they are out, becaue nervs neither have uch a Chyle as this, nor Valves nor any cavity. Nor are the Meentery and Guts o enible, although they have a few nervs from the ixt
Conjugation. Some have conceived thee veels to be Arteries, but contrary to ene, which acknowledges here a imple coat, and no motion. Only the not knowing of their Trunk, does keep ome learned men as yet in upene, which if it could be demontrated to be in the Liver, they would be of out mind. But although their Trunk and Original be unknown yet no man hould doubt of the exitency of thee Veins any more then the Inhabitants about Nilus doubt of the Exitency of that River, whoe Head is unknown. And others account it no impoible thing, that they may by their twigs be implanted into the Liver without any Trunk. Yea and it eems not improbable to the renowned Kyperus and Regius, that the milkie veins being confounded with the Mearaicks in the Pancreas or great kernel, do there empty their Chyle into the Vena Portae, and o it is carried by the Veins into the Liver, that it may be mixed with the Fermentum brought from the Spleen, and o receive the Rudiments of Blood. But I hal by and by hew that the milkie veins have branches which reach into the Liver, where they are inerted.

But I will briefly relate the Hitory of thee milkie veins, following the guidanceThe Hitory of the Vena Lacteae. of Aellius and others, and mine own Experience, who have diligently viewed them, in live Animals, and Men newly hanged and choaked.

Thee veels are termed Lactes or Lactea Their Name. Vaa alo Venae lacteae either from Lacio a word out of date, ignifying Allicio, I draw, or a lacte from Milk, which they reemble in whitenes, oftnes and fatnes; even as the Ancients and later Writers have given the ame name, to the mall Guts, the mearaick Veins, and the Meentery, for the ame caue, though the agreement and verity be not the like.

They were quite unknown to the Ancients, if you except Eraitratus, who in Kids that had lately ukt, aw certain obcure Arteries which were oon filled with milk, yet mot Ancients were ignorant, that there were one ort of veels to carry the Chyle, and others to carry the Blood. But they may be eaily excued, by indifferent Cenurers, becaue they commonly diected Animals that had been trangled, in which bodies, unles they • e tied, they uddenly diappear. Galen who had made more than ix hundred live Anatomies, did without doubt take them for Nerves.

Their Situation is in the lower Belly, where they are for the mot partTheir Situation. accompanied with Fat, which cherihes that Heat which is neceary for the attraction and preparation of the Chylus.

They are carried through the Meenterium, from the Guts, by an oblique paage, between its two coats, partly eparate from the other veels, partly together with them, omtimes treight along, otherwhiles going over the ame, and cutting them croswie as it were, through many Kernels, placed chiefly at the parting of the branches; they are carried, I ay as far as to the Pancreas. In the Pancreas or great kernel of the Meentery, which Aellius after Fallopius calls Pancreas, they are wreathed and wrought together like a Lattice, this way and that way, into very many and thoe inexplicable wreathings and Labyrinths.

From thence again, having ent greater branches by the ides of Vena portae, and omtimes alo twigs to the Vena Cava, they enter with mall Branches into the Cavity of the Liver. From thence, being carried to the Liver it elf, and plit into very mall fibres, they are o long pred up and down into the fleh thereof, every way, til they are at length quite obliterated.

But into what part of the Liver, either the Trunk or Branches are inerted,Their Inertion in the Liver. I have not found by any as yet determined, by reaon of the udden Efflux of the Humors. I, in the diection of the fih cal'd Orbis, by our Country-men Steenbud, by G •
• er Sea-Hare, by Cluius the frog-mouth'd Orbis, by the Ilanders Roemaffue from the color of its Belly; both Male and Female here at Hania frequently repeated, in the preence of the mot learned Wormius, Sperlingerus, Simon Pauli, Fuerinus, and others, have found and demontrated not only many daies after, great plenty of milkie veins, full of the white milkie humor, but alo the true place of their Inertion. which was the third Lobe of the Liver, that ame little oft one decribed by Spigelius, into which there entred a milkey branch ufficiently great, from the large kernel eated not far off, and welling with the milkey humor, unto which kernel, the mot of the milky veins out of the Meentery, and the appurtenances of the Stomach, had their Coure. Nor is it to be doubted, but that the ame betides in men and other Creatures Nature o haring the buines, that to each Lobe its Trunk may be aigned. Now from this they go further, with the branches of Vena portae, inwardly to the ret of the Lobes, and their Parenchyma. And it is to be oberved, that about this third Lobe, where the milkey veins are inerted, the Gall-Bladder is placed, either to ait Concoction which begins there, or to receive the cholerick Excrement, which in the Concoction of the Chylus is eparated therefrom.

Now they are inerted into all the Guts, vea even the Duodenum, but epecially into the maller Guts, not o many into thick ones, nor are any of them carried to the Stomach or the Spleen. And leat the Chylus once received hould lip back again into the Guts, they are furnihed with Valves which look from within outward, which wil not admit the Chyle though driven back with Violence.

Its Subtance is of a Vein, which it reemblesIts Subtance. in tructure and all things ele, excepting the milkie juyce. Of which there are th ••• compounding parts, Fibres, a Membrane, and Fleh. They have but one ingle Membrane, wherein they differ from Arteries, neither are they here cloathed with o thick a coat, no more than in other remote parts, though in the Meentery they receive from it another external coat. Aellius doth attribute to them all kinds of fibres, Right, Tranvere, Oblique, for Drawing, Retaining, and Expelling; though Walaeus by Ligature do teach, that the Chyle is rather thrut in them to the Liver, by the Guts contracted and driving the ame; and others conceive that it is drawn by the Liver it elf.
The Fleh which grows to the Membrane, fils up the paces between the fibres, whoe ue beides is, to prepare the Chyle before it comes to the Liver.

As for Quantity they grow continuallyTheir Quantity. one to another, being all of one Trunk though their magnitude be not equal, ome being greater others leer. Now they are mall, leat the thick and unprofitable parts of the Chyle, hould go into them together, and leat ditribution hould be made too uddenly and tumultuouly, which Frambearius oberves.

They are infinite in Number, diperedNumber. through the Liver, Guts, Meentery and Pancreas, and o much more in number than the vulgar Meenterick Veins, that their plenty may make amends for their mallnes.

As to the firt active Qualities, they are colder than ordinary Veins, becaue the Chyle which they carry is colder than Blood. In repect of the paive qualities, they are dry, yet moiter than the common Veins.

In repect of the econd Qualities, they are thin and exceeding ubtile, where they enter into the body of the Liver; Tender, Smooth, Rare, Rough by reaon of the Fibres within them. From thee qualities follows their colour which is white, partly becaue they were made of cold eed, partly becaue of the white Liquor which they carry, For
