Their Action and properTheir Ue. Ue is 1. To deliver up the Chylus to the Liver, not by the Mearaicks as hath been hitherto believed, by which neither the Chylus acends to the Liver, nor the blood decends to the Guts, as was aid be • ore. Nor let the abundance of the aid Mearaicks trouble us, which the cold and bloodles Guts do not need; becaue doubtles they need • ore of Heat and much nourihment, adminitred by the abundance of mearaick Arteries, and therefore plenty of Veins ought to anwer the plenty of Arteries, that they might carry back the uperfluous blood to the Liver.

II To render the Chyle more fit to receive the form of Blood in the Liver. But they are deceived who do aigne to them the blood-makeing faculty, for the Chylus is not at all changed in colour till it come unto the Liver, where it begins by little and little to grow reddih or paleih.

III They much conduce to facilitate the Art of Phyick. For 1 They dicover a ready way for ditribution of the Chylus, which has hitherto bin very much controverted, without any fear of a contrary motion or confu •• on. 2 They hew that the Blood is made in the Liver and its fleh, and not in the veins. 3 That the ucking of the Veins is no caue of Hunger, becaue none are carried to the Stomach.

IV They declare the Caues of ome Dieaes of the Body which were before obcure, viz. of the chylous flux of the Guts; of pineing away of the Body, for want of N •… , by reaon of the kernels of the Meentery <…> with •… s wellings, of intermitting Agues •… d in the Mear • um, Hypocondriacal Melancholy &c.

V The learned Gaendus conceives that by the milkie Veins the white juyce contained in them is carried over the whole Body, to breed Fat; and that the true Chylus is brought the neeret way by the Porus biliarius, out of the Stomach unto the Liver; But neither of thee may be granted. Not the former, becaue of the reaons brought before, Book the 7 againt Folius, touching the matter of Fat which Riolanus approves and commends; nor the latter, becaue the Chyle would be infected by meeting with bitter Choler, though that renowned man allows in cae of neceity, the Jejunum being obtructed, it may o be done.

And o much may uffice touching the Hitory o the Venae Lacteae, to which there is hardly any thing remainning to be added, unles the caue of their udden diappearing, which is ufficiently controverted which is not to be imputed to the piritual dipoition of the Chylus which uddenly vanihes away, as Aellius did at firt beleive, becaue the Chylus being drawn out of the Veins does keep its colour a very long time, not vanihing away, but becoming waterih. But to that which did afterward eem probable to Aellius viz. the trong drawing of the Liver, in o great Anxiety of the Ainmal, all
this may be attributed, by which the pirits being conumed, they need new Blood and Chyle peedily to be digeted. And hence a reaon may be rendred, why the Venae lacteae in a man hang'd at Amterdam cut up by Dr. Tulpiu • , remained viible many daies after; uch as have bin divers times • en by Velingius at Padua, and Folius at Venice: For by reaon of the pains broke off by choaking, there could be no drawing of the Liver. For whereas in a Girle ten months old, Velingus found thee Veins welling: I acribe that to a like weaknes of the Liver, or the thicknes of the milkie humor. I alo aw at Hafnia the lat yeer, the milkey veins in Sueno Olai of Vardberg (who was immediately choak'd with a peice of neats-tongue, having before eaten and drank plentifully) viible in the Meentery, becaue repiration being hindred by the bit of tongue, and his heart being uffocated, there was no neceity for the Liver to draw any Chylus. But P. Laurembergius as a man ignorant of this Anatomy does vainly imagine with himelfe, that thee veins do diappear, becaue of the recoure of the Chylus to the Guts, the Valves being looe and flaggie: for, 1 Do all you can, you hall never bring the Chylus back, in dead bodies into the Guts. 2 If a vein be tied in the middle, o that a paage is left open on both ides, both towards the Liver and the Guts: where it looks to the Liver it is emptie, but it wells exceedingly towards the Guts, and if it be left in that poture for ome daies together the Chyle will not lip back into the Guts.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Haemorrhoid Veins.
div.p: THe Haemorrhoidal Veins are thoe which are in the Fundament,The Haemorrhoid Veins what? or Intetinum rectum, and are alo extrinecally viible, which in ome men at et times do open of their own accord, and void forth dreggie Blood, which evacuation does much conduce to Health.

Thee Veins are not of one kind, as the Ancients and manyThe Error of other Anatomits. later writers have Imagined: But ome are termed internal, which arie from the Vena portae, others external, from the Cava, with which the haemorrhoidal Arteries are aociated, through which the Humors to be evacuated, are carryed.

The Ancients knew only the Internal ones, as being commended in melancholick and pleenetick dieaes: and they may be opened about the fundament, or leeches may be applied to them, whereas otherwie no branches of the Vena portae which lies concealed within, do go out to the skin, which can be opened.
The internal and external Haemorrhoid Veins differ one fromThe Differences between the internal and external Haemorrhoides. another.

I In their Original. For the Internal aries as was aid before, From the Vena portae, and decends along the end of the Colon, under the right gut, the end whereof or Fundament, it circularly embraces with certain mal twigs. It aries ometimes from the Ramus plenicus, from whence is the Vas breve. But eldome which Caerius once oberved, from the Spleen it elf. Velingus oberved it twice or thrice, and therefore Robert Flud is out, who condemns the opening of the Haemorrhoid Veins, becaue they void not from the Spleen but rather from the Meenterie, to the great dammage of the Guts and Stomach.
But the external Haemorrhoides arie from the Hypogatri • k branch of the Cava.

II By their Inertion For the internal is inerted into the ubtance of the Intetinum rectum, which is membranous, and required thick Blood made in the Spleen, and communicated by the Arteria Coeliaca or Splenica.
The external are inerted into the Muculous Subtance of the Fundament, which required purer Blood, elaborated in the Heart, and brought hither by the branches of the Arteries.
III In Number, the Internal is one in number, the external is threefold.
IV In the Quality of the Blood contained. The Blood of the inner is thick and black, the Blood of the outer is thinner and redder.

V In their Ue The internal empty the Vena port • ucceively, but firt the Spleenick Arteries, and help the Obtructions of the Spleen: the external empty the Vena Cava, the Liver by accident, but primarily the great Arterie, and the Heart; yea their evacuation cures dieaes pringing from Blood, of the Head, Chet, &c. Which Hippocrates hints in his Aphorimes, and therefore the internal are aid to cure the Cacochymia, or badnes of Humors, the external the Ple • horia or fullnes of good Blood.
VI In the plentiful profuion of Blood. The flux of the internal ones is not o plentiful; that of the external is ometimes o large, that men die by the extremity thereof, or fal into greivous dieaes.

VII In the Evacuation of the external ones, there is no Paine nor Gripeing of the Eelly; and ome times alo no paine in the Fundament; but in the flux of the inner Haemorrhoides, there is greivous paine.
VIII The Internal do alone decend, unaccompanyed with the Arteries, howbeit either the Arteries are hidden, or they depend of Arteries in the upper-more.
The external decend with the Arteries to the Mucles of the Fundament, manifetly; and therefore the external are more properly called Vaa Haemorrhoidalia, to include the Arteries with the Veins.

div.head: Chap. V. Of the acending Trunk of Vena Cava, epecially of the Vena ine pari.
div.p: VEna Cava called alo Vena magna The Vena Cava what? and maxima, the great vein and the greatet vein, by the Ancients, becaue of its exceeding largnes, and by Aurelianus, Venae craa the thick Vein, is the larget Vein in our whole Body, and the Mother of all other Veins which do not proceed from the Vena Portae; coming out of the bunching or convex ide of the Liver, and therefore by Hippocrates termed the Liver vein, haveing pread many Veins through theIts diviion into great Trunks. upper part of the Liver, which about the top are collected into one Trunk it is preently divided into the upper or acendent, and the lower and decendent Trunks.

The Acendent Trunk peirces the Midrif,The acendent Trunk what? is pread about through the Chet, Neck, Head and Arms. Now it is carried undivided, as far as to the Jugulum. Mean while four branches arie there from.

1 Phreni •• s or the Midrif vein, onThe Vein of the Midrif pericardium and mediatinum. each ide one, whence alo branches are ent to the Pericardium and Mediatinum. That Quittor in uch as have the Empyema, is carried by this Vein to
the Kidnies and Bladder M. A. Severinus ingeniouly proves, becaue 1. The quittor mut needs ret at the bottom of the Midriff. 2. By the motion of the Septum it is eaily made thin. 3. By the ame motion the mouths of the veels are opened. which may more truly be aid of the Arteries, which carry Blood to the Kidnies by their emulgent Branches, and with the Blood undry excrements, as quittor, Serum &c.

Afterwards the Vena cavae acends by the Septum, and boring its paage through the Pericardium, it goes a little towards the left hand, and infinuates it elf into the right Ventricle of the Heart, with a large hole, where it is joyned on all ides to the left Ear-let: and there is made,

2 The Vena Coronaria, which is omtimes double, compaing the Bais of the Heart, at the Rie whereof a little Valve is placed, not uffering the Blood to return into the Trunk. For it is joyned with a continued paage to the Artery, that it may therefrom receive blood, which is to return to the Cavae.

Afterwards the acendent Trunk does at lat, bore its way through the Pericardium, and taking the former hape, it had under the Heart, but maller, thorugh the middle diviion of the Lungs (no more upon the Vertebra's of the Chet, where now the Gullet and Weand ret) it acends to the Jugulum. Mean while there is bred

3. A remarkable Vein above the Heart called Ayzgos, ine pari, the Vein without a fellow, becaue in a Man and a Dog, it is commonly but one, quartering on the one ide, without another on the other ide. But there are two in ome Creatures which chew the cud, as Goats, and in Swine &c. And in the Body of Man I have often een two, once I found none at all, intead whereof on each ide there decended a Branch from the Vena Subclavia.

It aries from the hinder part of the Cava but more towards the right hand, and decends through the right Cavity of the Chet: but in Sheep contrariwie, it aries from the left ide of the Cavae, and decends through the left. In a Man after its Beginning, which is between the fourth and fit Vertebra of the Chet, it bends a little back towards the right ide and outwardly, unto the eighth or ninth Vertebra of the Chet; where it begins to poes the very middle pace. Howbeit, I have oberved it preently after its rie, to decend right forward, above the middle of the Back-bone, and to end out branches on each ide.

This Truncus ine pari, for the pace of eight lower Ribs, ends out on each hand Intercotal branches, which are omtimes here and there joyned by way of Anatomois, with the branches of theAnatomois. Thoracica inferior which aries from the Bailica, and with the Intercotal Arteries. And therefore a Vein is not alwaiesThe Error of Vealius. to be opened in a Pleuriie of the right ide, as Vealius would have it.
Neer the Eighth Rib, it is divided into two Branches.

The one being omtimes the greater, acends under the Diaphragma to the left ide, and is inerted omtimes into the Cavae above or beneath the Emulgents, omtimes into the Emulgent it elf. This way, according to the vulgar Doctrine, pleuritickHow pleuritick perons are purged by Urine. perous, are many times critically purged by Urine, and void out that way abundance of Quittor: which matter may more truly be aid to be purged out by the emulgent Arteries, by mediation of the Heart.

The other on the right hand, goes to the Cavae and is joyned thereto, eldom to the Emulgent, omtimes bove, the Emulgent. Often times it is implanted into the lat omtimes into the firt lumbal Veel; for which caue, in the beginningWhy the Ham-vein is profitably opened in a Pleuriie. of a Pleuriie, the Ham-vein may be opened, to draw away the Blood, which would otherwie acend out of the Arteries and mall Veins, into this Vein.

And whereas Hollerius and Amatus dream that this Vein hath Valves in itsThe Error of Amatus Luitanus and Hollerius touching Valves. Beginning, it is fale. and therefore fale it is, that the Cavae being evacuated, the Vena ine pari is not evacuated, becaue the Regurgitation is hindred by the Valves. Fallopius denies them, becaue he aw both Wind and Blood regurgitate from thence.
4. The Intercotalis uperior, on each ide one, which is ent to the Intervals of the four upper Ribs, when the Azygos hath not ent branches to all the Intervals of the Ribs.

div.head: Chap. 6. Of the Vena ubclavia and its Branches, and the Jugulars.
div.p:
THe Branches aforeaid being contituted,The Error of other Anatomits. the Cavae acends to the Claviculae, underpropped with the Thymus, where it is commonly thought to be divided, and in many Anatomical Tables is o repreented, into four parts, on either ide into an upper part and a lower. whence a common Error ofAn Error of Practitioners in Blood-letting. Practitioners aries who crupulouly open the Bailica Vein, in parts affected beneath the Neck; the Cephalica in Dieaes of the Head. But at the Claviculae
• channelbones the truncus vena cavae is divided not into four branches but two only, on each ide one, the right and left, which are termed Subclavij and by ome Axillares.

Wherefore it matters not in Dieaes below the Neck, whether you open theThe mot apparent Vein is to be opened. Bailica or Cephalick Vein: for the Trunk of Vena Cavae is alike emptied, for the Cephalica and Bailica proceed from one root. The Chyrurgeon ought to cut that which of the two is mot apparent.

Howbeit in Dieaes of the Head (if the Circulation did not perwade the contrary) the opening of the Cephalick Vein would help a little more, becaue there is a branch inerted thereinto proceeding from the external jugular; which I have oberved more than once in divers Bodies. But the Cae is all one, becaue the Carotick Arteries exclude all this Difference.
From the Subclavian Veins there arie both upper and lower Veins; and the lower both before and after diviion: before the diviion, four.

list.item: 1. The Mammaria (whoe original doth notwithtanding many times vary) on each ide one, omtimes without a fellow, decending into the Duggs, of which I have made frequent mention. This by way of Anatomois, is omtimes joyned to the Epigatrica under the right Mucles of the Abdomen.
2. The Mediatina which comes to the Mediatinum and the Thymus.
3. Cervicalis for the Mucles which lie upon the Vertebra's and for the Marrow of the Neck.
4. Mucula inferior, for the lower Mucles of the Neck and the upper of the Breat. and this alo aries omtimes, from the external Jugular.

div.p:

Bailica, as hal be aid in the following Chapter touching Veins of the Head.
From the Axillary after its diviion from the Trunk of the Bailica arie two Veins.
1. Thoracica uperior pent into the Mucles pred upon the Chet, and into Womens Dugs.

2. Inferior which omtimes grows out of
the uperior creeping all over the ide of the Chet, whoe branches are joyned byAnatomo • s. way of Anatomois with the Branches of Vena ine pari which proceed out of the Chet.
From the upper part of the ubclavian trunk, there firt aries mucula uperior, pread out near the jugularis externa, into the skin, and mucles of the hinder-part of the Neck. And afterwards,
The jugular Veins, o called, becaue they acend in the Jugulum at the ides ofJugular veins why o called. the Neck; and they are internal or external.

External, which ometimes, either in its original, or in the middle of its paage, is twofold, creeping upwards under the Skin, and provides for the external parts of the Head, Face, Neck, and Fauces. For under the root of the Ear, it is divided into the internal and external branch. The internal goes unto the mucles of the Mouth, Fauces, Hyoides, &c. The exterior being under the Ear propped with kernels, is divided into two parts; one part is caried into the fore-parts of the Face, the Noe and Cheeks, and in the middle of the Forehead being joyned with a Branch of the other ide, it makes the Vein of the Forehead which is uually opened. The other is carried through the ides, the Temples, and the Occiput. This the wie Severinus opens with very great uccee, in the Head-ach, Hoarnes, Shortnes of Breath, Pleuriie, pain of the Spleen, Tetters, Squinzy, and which I was preent and aw, in Varices of the Face. Mean while thee branches are variouly mingled in the Head and the Crown of the Head.

The internal Jugular in men is the greater, becaue of their abundance of Brains, but in Beats it is contrarywie Tis called Apaplecta, and does acend to the ide of the Trachea, to which it ends branches. Reaching to the Bais of the Skull in its hinder-part, it is divided into two branches. The one which is the greater, is carryed backwards with the leer branch of the Carotick Arterie, through the hole of the Os Occipitis, which is made for the ixt Pare of Nerves, and enters into the cavity of the dura mater. The other being leer, entring at the hole of the third and fourth pare, is pent into the Dura Mater.

div.head: Chap. 7. Of the Veins of the Arms and Hands.
div.p: THe axillary Vein as we have oberved in the foregoing Chapter, is divided at the beginning of the Arm, into two remarkeable Branches: the upper and leer, or the Vena Cephalica, and the lower and greater or Eailica.

The upper is called Vena humeraria Cubiti inferior, Cephalica or Capitalis, the Head-vein, becaue it is wont to be opened in Dieaes of the Head, by the Ancients, and by later Surgeons alo either out of Ignorance or Supertition.
In Brutes it aries from the external Jugular, in Men allwaies from the axillary, yet o that from the external Jugular a hort twig may be inerted into the Cephalica.
It is carried in the Surface of the Body, between the flehy Membrane and Coat of the Mucles.

Its external branch termed Funis Brachii, at the middle of the writ, in the lower part, is joyned to a branch of the Bailica, and afterwards ariing into the outer ide of the writ, paing along between the ring finger and the little finger, it is called Salvatella, which is that which the Arabians term Siele, who as others at this day, commend the opening thereof in the left hand, againt melancholick dieaes, acute Fevers, and tertian Agues, but in vain, and upon no ground at all. As Joh. Bap • . Sylvaticus has proved in a ditinct Treatie, and Severinus lately, whatever Spigelius may dipute touching Anatomoes of the Arteries, in the extream parts, wherewith the Spleen abounds: For the Spleen is more remote, and any other part may be as wel opened for there are Anatomoes in a manner every where.
They make that the inner branch of the Cephalica which contitutes the mediana.

Bailica by ome call'd Cubiti interior, Epatica, Jecoraria, &c. the Liver vein, becaue in dieaes of the Liver it is uually opened: but in the left ide tis termed Lienaris the Spleen vein becaue the opening thereof is commended in Dieaes of the Spleen, upon no ground at all.

But let Surgeons take heed when they open this Vein, leat theyA Caution in opening the Bailica or Liver vein. wound a Nerve of the third and fourth pare, which lies neer the ame, whence follows great pain, a Feaver, Convulion, and Death. Alo Arteries lie beneath the ame, which being hurt, caues au Aueurima and effuion of Blood.
This Vein is divided into more Boughes then the Head vein. Under the tendon of the pectoral mucle it is divided into three Branches.
I The firt goes along with that Nerve of the Arme, which they cal the fourth.

II The next is termed Medius and Profundus, beneath the Elboe Joynt divided into an external and an internal branch, eparated but a little way one from another. The former provides for the Thumb, Forefinger, and Middlefinger; as alo for the external mucles of the Hand. The latter being tretched along the middle bone of the Cubit, ervs the Middlefinger, the Rinfinger, and the little finger, as alo the internal Mucles of the Hand.

III The Subcutaneus is divided at the inner welling of the Arm, is divided into a foremore and hindermore Branch: The latter decends under the Ulna by the little finger, where it is joyned to a Branch of the Cephalica. The former as it paes along the Cubit, produces another remarkeable Vein, which proceeds ometimes directly, otherwhiles with various turnings unto the writ. And then as it is carried along the Cubit, with the inner Branch of the Cephalica, it makes a common Vein which is called

Mediana by Avicen nigra, tis cald the mediana or middle Vein becaue of its Sitnation in the midt of the Arm. It is frequently opened without danger, becaue there is no Nerve beneath it, but only the Tendon of a Mucle. From this or rather from that part of the Bailica, whence this aries, a branch is ent forth, which being divided above the Radius, produces an exteriour branch, between the Thumb and the Forefinger, which ome cal Cephalica, others Occularis, and ome again as Mundinus, Salvatella, and another more inward, betwixt the middle finger, and the Ring finger, which ome as Rhais count the Sielc or rather Seilem of Avicenna.

But touching the Ditribution of all thee Veins it is to be oberved, thatThe Variation of the Veins of the Arm. they differ in everal Bodies, and are eldome in one man, as they are in another; yea the right ide of the ame man does rarely agree with the let; and in like manner they varie in Magnitude, in everal perons.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the Trunk of Vena cava decending as far as to the Thighes.
div.p: THe lower Trunk of Vena Cava proceeding out of the Liver, called the decendent Trunk, is more narrow then the upper or acendent (which ervs very many parts) and proceeds undivided accompanied with with a great Arterie, as far as to the fourth Vertebra of the Loyns. Mean while it ends forth thee folowing Boughes.

list.item: I The Vene adipoae which ervs the Coat of the Kidneyes and their Fat, the left of which, is commonly higher then the right.
II The emulgent Veins, decending to the Kidneyes by a hort and crooked paage, ometimes with a threefold Rie, bringing back the wheyih Blood being purified from the Kidnyes into the Vena Cava.
3. The Spermatick Veins of which in the firt Book.

4. The Lumbaces or Loyn-veins omtimes two, omtimes three, which are carried betwixt the four Vertebra's of the Loyns. From thee ome write that they have oberved two Veins acending, within the Vertebra's, on each hand to the ide of the pinal marrow in the Brain, which makes them conjecture, that a portion of the eminary matter is brought from the Brain.

div.p: Thee being thus contituted, the Trunk going towards Os acrum, at the fourth Vertebra of the Loyns, it goes under the Aorta, which before was under it, and is divided into two equal Branches, termed Rami Ilij or Iliaci, becaue they go over the Os Ilij and Os pubis unto the Thighes.

About the diviion it elf, there arie two Veins; the Mucula uperior erving the Peritonaeum and the Mucles of the Loyns and Belly, and the Sacra, omtimes ingle, otherwhiles double, for the Marrow of Os acrum.
Afterward the Ramus Iliacus is forked out on each ide into the external greater, and the internal leer.

From the inner two Veins prout; the Mucula media without, erving the Mucles eated on the outide of the Hip, and the skin of the Buttocks; and the Hypogatrica which is remarkable, omtimes double, erving very many parts of the Hypogatrium, as the Mucles of Intetinum rectum, whence are the Haemorhoides externae; the Bladder and its Neck, the Yard, the lower ide and neck of the womb. whence are thoe Veins by which mentrual Blood is many times thought to be purged in Virgins and Women with Child; which nevertheles eldom happens, when the Venae Hypogatricae do cumulate thick Blood, and end it not back unto the Trunck, then they may be opened, but otherwie, they are indeed uppreed; but they acend unto the Heart by the Vena Cavae, and caue palpitations and other ymptomes. But when they are right, the Coures are naturally voided by the Arteries, which appears by their florid color, and the common Office of the Arteries, which is to carry unto the parts of body. Walaeus proves this alo by other tokens in his Epitles. This branch when it is joyned with the crural branch internal, doth ceae.

From the outer, three: two before it goes out of the Peritoneum, and one afterward: the firt is the Epigatricae (which eldom aries from the crural) to erve the Peritoneum and Mucles of the Belly; the chief part acends, under the right Mucles to the Mammariae, to which they are often joyned about the Navil.
2. The Vena pudendae, which erves the Privy Parts in Men and Women; it goes athwart to the middle of Os pubis.
3. Mucula inferior, going over the ide of the Hip-joynt, to erve the Mucles and skin of that part.
Afterwards its Branches are termed Crurals.

div.head: Chap. 9. Of the Crural Veins.
div.p: THe Venae Crurales, as alo the Arteries and Nerves paing along, are in the bending of the Thigh interwoven with frequent kernels, for firmnes ake. Afterwards there arie from the crural Ve •• ix branches.

list.item: 1. Saphaeda (o cal'd becaue of its apparency more than other foot-Veins) or Venae m • leoli the Anckle-vein, is long and remarkable, it is carried along in the Inide of the Thigh, with a Nerve tretched by it, between the Skin and Membran • Carnoa to the Knee, and along the inner part of the Leg, it goes to the inner Anckle. And it is variouly ditributed into the upper parts of the Foot, towards the Toes, epecially the great Toe. This is opened about the Ankle, in Dieaes of the Womb, epecially when the Coures are topt, and in the Gonorrhaea to evacuate or revell the Blood which otherwie would acend too plentifully unto the Womb and Genitals. Now it mut be opened where it is mot apparent, whether it be on the Back or ide of the Foot.
2. Ichias minor is oppoite to the former. for it is a hort outer branch, pringing from the crural: it is carried outwardly and athwart into the skin of the Hip, and the Mucles of that place.
3. Mucula, aries from a Trunk, which lies hid among the Mucles: it is a double and remarkable Branch, ditributed among the Mucles eated in the Thigh.

4. Poplitea the Ham-vein, is made of a double Crural branch mingled together, and runs treight along under the Skin, behind, through the midt of the bending of the Ham, as far as to the Heel, omtimes to the Skin of the Outer Ankle. This Vein is commonly uppoed to have been frequently open'd by the Ancients, under the Knee, and Paulus Magnus a Chyrurgeon of Rome, did once open it. But becaue it lies exceeding deep, and cannot be een, we mut uppoe it cannot be opened: and perhaps this is not the Venae poplitea of the Ancients, epecially eeing Galen is exceeding various in his decription thereof, and calls it omtimes the Vein in the Ham, omtimes about the Ham, omtimes at the Knee, otherwhiles under the Knee; peradventure he meant the Ankle-vein, which decends to the inner bunching of the Leg, and is indeed conpicuous enough under the Knee.

5. Is cal'd Suralis, which is a great Vein; and is divided into the external and leer, and the internal and greater branch, and each of them again into exterior and interior. It is ditributed amongt the Mucles of the calf of the Leg. On the back of the Foot, being mixed with the branches of the Poplitea, it makes that ame various texture of Veins, which is apparent under the Skin.
6. Ichias Major gives a part to the Mucles of the Calf, and then pends it elf into ten branches, betowing a couple upon each Toe.

div.p: Touching all thee it is to be noted:

list.item: 1. That all thee branches, do end divers tigs outwards to the Skin, which are termed Skin-veins.
2. That all thee branches are diverly dipoed in different men, as was aid in the Arms; nor is there alwaies the ame carriage of Veins, in both the Legs of the ame peron.
3. That there is alo no great choyce to be made in opening the Veins of the Feet; eeing they are all derived from one Trunk, and the Blood acends from the extream parts and Arteries.

div.head: THE SECOND MANUAL Of the Arteries, Anwering to the SECOND BOOK Touching the Middle Cavity or Chet.
CHAP. 1. Of the Arteries in General.
div.p: ARteria an Artery o called from containingThe name Artery. and preerving Air or pirit; was by the Antients Hippocrates, Plato and Aritotle the name of the Wind-pipe, which alo Hippocrates calls Arteria magna. Galen makes a ditinction and cals the Wind-pipe Apera Arteria the rough Artery, and thoe whereof we are now to treat Arteriae leves the mooth Arteries, which Hippocrates cals Arterias parvas, Aritotle omtimes Venam Aortam, otherwhiles imply Aorta.

Now an Artery properly o called, is a common Organ, round, long, hollow like aWhat an Artery is. pipe; coniting of a double Coat, proceeding from the Heart, fit to carry Blood and vital pirits to all parts.
The Efficient is the proper Artery-making faculty, which may be called Artoropoietice.
The matter whereof it is made, is a clammy and cold part of the eed, according to Hippocrates. And this is the Beginning of its Generation.

The Beginning of its Dipenation, is not the Brain, as Pelops Galen's Mater would have it, but the Heart by the Conent of all Philoophers and Phyitians. And indeed the Arteries proceed out of the left Chamber or Ventricle of the Heart, not the middlemot, which Aritotle eigns to himelf, and would have the Aorta to proceed therefrom. And therefore the Arteria magna proceeds from the Heart, as alo the Venoa Arteria, and the Vena Arterioa, but thee out of the right Ventricle; of which we have poken already in the econd Book.

Their End or Ue is, 1. Inamuch asThe End of the Arteries. they are Conduit-pipes, they carry the Blood and vital or arterial pirit made in the Heart (for Spirit alone without Blood is not contained in the Arteries) to all parts of the Body. 1. To communicate life or vital faculty, that the vital pirit implanted in the parts, and their Native heat may be utained and cherihed. 2. That animal pirit may be bred, in the noble Ventricle of the Marrow. 3. For the nourihment of all the parts, which are nourihed by thee only and their Blood and not by the venal Blood or Veins. 4. To carry the Excrements of the Body and the Blood therewith mingled, either to the outer parts of the body to the Kidnies, or the Meentery, or the Womb, or the haemorrhoid Veins, &c.

II. Inamuch as they are moved andWhy the Arteries pule. pule perpetually; they afford this benefit. 1. That the heat of the parts is fanned, cooled and tempered, and o a ymmetrie or due proportion of Heat is preerved. which is caued, not o much by the Airs being drawn in, when the Artery is widened, to avoid Vacuum, as by the arterial Blood continually flowing in, impregnated with Air. 2. That this nourihing arterial Blood, may be continually poured into the mallet Arteries, and from thence into the parts of the Body. For in the firt place, the Heart by continuall puling, drives the Blood into the greater Arteries, which becaue they cannot let it return becaue of the Valves, and are too trong to break, it mut needs be driven to to the very mallet Arteries and the parts of the Body. And thoe parts not being nourihed with all that is forced in, do end back that which is uperfluous into the Veins, that o it may be circulated. Moreover, an Arterie being bound in any part of the Body, it is filled towards the Heart, otherwie than the Veins; contrariwie towards the mallet Arteries and the parts it is emptied. Thirdly, In Blood-letting, the Arm being indifferently
hard bound and the pule remaining, the Arm is filled, and a Vein being opened below the band, Blood plentifully iues, which becaue it cannot come out of the Veins which lying higher are topped by the Ligature, it mut needs be brought from the Arteries beneath. Fourthly, in live-Creatures diected, this Tumor of the Arteries is oberved neer their Original, and a lanknes towards the extream parts of Body, into which they go; and when they are opened, there is a mighty flux of blood, on this ide the band, none beyond it. Latly, the ame is to be een by an Aneurima. 3. Leat the Blood of the Veins to which they are joyned, hould be til, and putrifie like tanding waters, and that the Heart may not be detitute of Blood in its continual expulion, by the driving Arteries it is continually filled again through the Veins.

This Motion of the Arteries called the Pule, is caued, either by the faculty alone,The Pule how caued. whether eated in the Arteries themelves, as Praxagoras would have it, or flowing from the Heart by the coats of the Arteries, as Galen and infinite Phyitians after him have taught, epecially by reaon of a little Reed put into the Arteries, under which they are not mov'd, by reaon of the Intercepton of their coat, til it be taken away. again, becaue as the Heart is contracted and widened, o are the Arteries, as appears by laying one hand to the region of the Heart, and the other to the Writ, and by wounds in the Heart and Arteries: or by the Blood either boyling according to Aritotle, or rarefied according to Des Cartes, or meerly ditending as Harvey hath proved: or from both the Blood filling, and the faculty directing, which is my opinion. For that the Arteries are moved and ditended by the Blood, I prove. 1. The Heart by its perpetual puling, expels great tore of Blood, as I have demotrated in my Chapter of the Heart. 2. That the ame Blood doth fill and move the Arteries, the Artery it elf hews, being laid bare, into which at every pule, you hall feel with your fingers the Blood driven in to flow down, with which it is dilated. 3. When an Artery is opened, Blood leaps out, at every pule, as out of the Heart. 4. Harvey aw a portion of the decendent Artery with two crural branches a pan long taken out of the Body of a Gentleman, which was turned into a fitulous hollow bone, and nevertheles the Blood which when he was living, decended through the the Cavity thereof into his Legs, did move the Arteries beneath, by its impule. The ame hath been oberved by others in the Arteria Aorta 5. In an Aneurima the fleh is manifetly een to pule, as formerly the Artery being ound was wont to do by the afflux of Blood. 6. The waving, Worm-creeping pule, do argue the ame, in the judgment of Walaeus. 7. Harvey gives us another rare experiment, made with the Guts of a Dog, Wolf or other Creature dried, blown up and filled with Water. For if we mite one end with our Finger, and lay our fingers to the other end, we may cleerly perceive every troak, and the difference of the motion. Howbeit I conceive the faculty ought to be joyned hereto, communicated to the Coats from the Heart, by help whereof, they are contracted and widned; becaue, 1. Otherwie the Flux of the Blood would be inordinate, and the pule alwaies unequal. 2. All the Arteries are dilated or contracted in one moment, but the Blood alone fils the Arteries ucceively and moves them part after part. Indeed, Gloves being blown into, all the fingers are puffed up at once, which Harvey objects, and in a Bain the blow and motion are at once in both ends: but corporeal blood is of another Nature, which cannot be moved like pecies or Winds. 3. The Faculties or Irradiation of vital light, may run through all parts in the twinkling of an Eve, like the Light of the Sun. See more of this in the Chapter of the Heart. 4. Hence within Galen his Reed the Artery is obcurely moved, becaue the wift motion of the Blood ceaes when the Faculty is hindred. Howbeit, Harvey and Walaeus argue differently about this difficult Experiment.

Now all the Arteries are widenedWhether the Arteries are dilated together with the Heart or no. when the Heart is contracted, and contracted when the Heart is widened, which is certain from the diection of an Artery and the Heart, and from Ligatures, nor was it o long ago unknown to Eraitratus, and reaon confirmes the ame, becaue when the Heart expels, then are the the Arteries filled with its Blood. Yet have they not contrary pules, as we find by laying our hand to the writ and the Region of the Heart, at one and the ame time, for the pule of the Heart is perceived by us in its Sytole, but that of the Arteries in the Diatole, when they are filled, becaue the two motions, are at one and the ame time. The mallet capillary Arteries are not perceived to pule, becaue there is not o much force in them, and therefore we can hardly dicern them from the Veins. alo they have thin Coats, o that the Blood is een through them, as through the Veins.
The Form is apparent from the Accidents; howbeit the form of an Arterie is the Subtancial Soul, as it is of the whole Body beides.

Its Situation is deep, allwaies under the Veins, that they might be more afe, and that not only in the external, but the internal parts alo, if you except the Belly, a little below the Kidneies: For after that the Vena Cava and the Aorta, decending from the Diaphragma, have paed the Region of the Kidneies, the Cava hides it elf under the Aorta through all that region, til they pas out of the Abdomen; for then the Arterie does again ide it elfe under the Cava. The Caue whereof Plempius conceives to be this; that otherwie there would have bin danger, leat the bending of the Body often happening in that place, the Vena cava having but a ingle Coat, would have reited the aid motion.
Its Magnitude is ufficiently great, butIts Magnitude. the decending part of the Arterle is greater, the acendent leer, becaue the Number of the internal parts is greater then of the external.

The Number of the Arteries is fewer then of the Veins, becaue the paage of the Blood is quick through the Arteries, low through the Veins, and therefore there are many receptacles provided for that Blood which is collected by certain pules. Yet there are more Arteries then we think, or can be dicerned by us, becaue the capillary Arteries are exceeding like to Veins.
Their Shape is like a Pipe or Channel, mooth, round, and long.

As to their Paages. Some Arteries are terminated into the Guts, by which expulion of Excrements is caued; ome have their mouths terminated into the Skin, through which the external air is attracted (in Tranpiration which is performed alo by the Veins) and ooty teams expelled. Platerus denies that they are inerted into the Bones, but Spigelius oberved at Padua, in a great corruption of the O • Tibiae, that the ubtance of the Bone was bored through by an Arterie. which perhaps Aritotle had likewie een, becaue he ayes that Arteries end into a olid Subtance.

They are compaed (like theWhether the Arteries do feel. Veins) ometimes with a membrane thick and common, from the Neighbouring parts, when they are without the B • wels and the Mucles; and uch Arteries as have a membran • joyned to them with Nerves in it, do feel; whence Galen aid the Pule was inflamed, alo that an Arterie did feel, and was pained, which one at Padua found in his inner parts, who dying with a mighty pain in his Loyns, Stones like a Mans Nailes were found in his Lumbal Arteries. But other Arteries are without Sene.

The Subtance of the Arteries is membranous,Their Subtance. o that they may be ditended and compreed more then the Veins. Fallopius thought
their Subtance to be gritly, becaue he oberved that it did degenerate into a boney nature; which alo Vetingus, aw, as well as Harvey, in the great Arterie above the Valves, near the Heart of an old Man. But that many things are changed into a boney ubtance, which were not grileyHow many Coats an Arterie hath. Columbus teaches in the eptum Cordis. Now an Arterie conits of two peculiar Coats.
The Exterior is thin, oft, rare, as the Coat of a Vein is.

The interior is compact, hard, and very thick, viz. five times thicker then the Coat of the Veins: And therefore Herophilus aid, that the Arteries were ix times thicker then the Veins, for this Caue, that they might be trong in their perpetual motion, and that their thin Blood hould not oon vanih and fly away, being pirituous and vaporous. And therefore in the opening of an Arterie, the inciion mut be made deep, with a broad and harp Lancet, becaue of the deep Situation of the Arterie, and thicknes of the Skin. The opening of an Arterie is allowed of by theeWhether an Artery may be opened, and how. ancients Oribaius, Aegineta, Aetius, Actuarius, Aurelianus, Abenina. With good ucces Galen practied it, in a dieae of the Eyes proceeding from hot Blood, ful of vapors, and in pains of the Hips. Panarolus at Rome ues the ame kind of remedie in a Phrenzie, and Alpinus writes that it is frequent in Aegipt, which Paraeus did likewie exercie in France, M. Aurelius Severinus at Naples, and Paulus Moth with us, excellent Phyitians and Surgeons, do happily open them, to the great good of their Patients, epecially in dieaes of the Head; in which nevertheles, the opening of an Arterie may eem ules, becaue 1 Vaporous and hot Blood is as well carried by the inner carotick Arteries unto the Brain, from the Bais to the plexus retiformis, as wel as by the external ones, which are opened. 2 The ame Blood returnes through the jugular Veins, according to the ure Laws of Circulation. But eeing it did certainly profit the Patients, I conceive it was practied rather by way of preervation, then of Cure. For the antecedent caue being omewhat evacuated by the outer Arteries, the conjunct caue is eaily extruded by the jugular Veins. More over, ome external Vein or Arterie may be obtructed, o that neither the latter can end, nor the former receive, unles they be opened.
Galen ads a third Coat, in their inner Surface, like a Cobweb for Thinnes, appearing in great Arteries about the Original.

div.head: Chap. 2. Of the acendent Trunk of the great Arterie.
div.p: THe ditribution of the Arteries which alwaies in a manner, accompany the Veins, wil be more eay and hort; becaue the deemination of the Veins is already undertood from what has bin aid before.

The Arteria magna or craa, the great or thick Artery the mother of the other Arteries, comes out of the left Ventricle of the Heart with a gapeing Orifice or vvide mouth; where within the Pericardium or Heart-Bag, it breeds from it elf the Arteria
Coronaria, compaing the Bais of the Heart ometimes ingle, ometimes double, afterward, going out of the Heart-bag, tis divided into the leer Trunk acending, and the greater Trunk decending.

The leer and upper Trunk reting upon the Weand, does provide for all parts quartered above the Heart: and is divided into the Subclavius Ramus dexter, which is higher and much the larger, and the initer, riing more low and going obliquely to the Arm.
Afterward the whole Trunk utained by the Thymus, divides it elf into two Carotides or Sleep-arteries unequal, which go right upwards.

The Arteriae ubclaviae before they go out of the Chet (for then they are termed Axillares when they are out) from their lower part, do produce the Intercotales uperiores to the Intervals of three or four of the upper Ribs; from their upper part. 1. The Mammariae. 2. The Cervicales. 3. The Muculae.

From the Axillaris before it comes to the Arm, in the lower part, doth arie the Thoracica uperior, Thoracica inferior, and Scapularis: in the upper part, the Humeraria. The remainder, goes from the Axillary on each ide to the Arm.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Arteria Carotides.
div.p: THe Arteriae Carotides do acend upwards right to the Head by the ides of the Weand, being knit unto the internal Jugulars: for the internal Veins do not accompany the Arteries. When they come to the Fauces, before they enter the Skul, they give branches to the Larynx and the Tongue: and then a diviion is made into the outer and inner branch.

The outer being the maller, furnihes the Cheeks and Mucles of the Face; and then at the root of the Ears, 'tis divided into two branches; the one is ent to the hinder parts of the Ear, whence arie two branches entring the lower Jaw, to furnih the Lip, and the roots of all the lower Teeth: the other goes to the Temples, the Forehead, and the Mucles of the Face.

The inner at the addle of Os Sphaenodes under the dura mater, makes the Rete mirabile, and then paes through the dura mater, and ends forth two branches. 1. The leer with the Nerve optick to the Eyes. 2. The greater acending to to the ide of the Glandula pituitaria, and ditributed through the pia maior and the ubtance of the Brain.

div.head: Chap. 4. Of the Arteries of the whole Hand.
div.p: THe Axillary Arterie, is carried along through the Arm, decending between the Mucles, with a Vein and Nerve of the Arm which they count to be the fourth.
Under the bending of the Elbow, it is divided into two fair branches; the upper and the lower.

The upper goes right on through the middle to the Writ, where Phyitions feel the Pule; afterward proceeding under the ring-hap'd Ligament, it betows branches upon the Thumb, Fore-finger, and Middlefinger.

The lower running through the Ulna to the Writ; furnihes the Mid-finger Ring-finger and little finger: and o it proceeds to the Writ, whence we feel the motion of the Pule beneath, epecially in lean perons, or uch as have a great Pule. But we better perceive the puling of the former branch, becaue it is les obcured and hid by Tendons.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the decending Trunk of the great Arterie.
div.p: THe Trunk of the Aorta or great Arterie decending is greater, becaue it ends out branches from it elf, into the middle and lower belly, as alo into the Thighes.
In the Chet or middle Bellie, two Arteries proceed from the greater Trunk.

I The Intercotales inferiores which go unto the Intervalls of eight Ribs, and the neighbouring Mucles. For it eldom happens, that the Vein ine pari, has to accompany it an Arterie ine pari, arieing from the Trunk. By thee intercotals if we beleive Spigelius, quittor and water collected in the Chet, are received into the great Arterie, and thence by the emulgent Veins carried into the Bladder, which has alo reaon to back it, becaue the congeted matter is more eaily hurried through the Arteries, and the way is horter. I add that quittor more readily follows the natural motion of the Arterial Blood then of the venal.
II. The Phrenica to erve the Midriff and Pericardium, or Heart-bag.

The ret of the Trunk peirces through the Clift of the Septum, and preads branches through the lower Belly, ome of which accompany the branches of vena portae, others the Branches of Vena Cava. Thoe which accompany the Branches of vena portae are three;

The Caeliaca, o called becaue it ends many branches unto the Stomach, proceeds foreward from the Aorta, being under propped by the Call, and is divided into the Ramus dexter which is the maller, and the Siniter Ramus which is the larger, which under the hinder region of the Stomach, are knit to the Vena Portae in the Pancreas.

The Dexter acending to the Cavity of the Liver, and proceeding a little forwards, on the higher ide produces Gatrica dextra, and the Cyticae gemellae; from its lower part, Epiploe dextra, Intetinalis, and Gatroepiploïs dextra, in imitation of the Vena portae. therefore let what was aid there, be here repeated. The Remainder from the Ramus dexter goes into the hollow urface of the Liver.

The Siniter or Arteria Splenica, is greater than the Dexter, leat it hould be eaily obtructed by thick juyces, and that it may pour ufficient vital blood, into the Spleen. This Artery drawn out into the Vena Splenica, by a bending and crooked Coure goes to the Spleen, and then preads branches after the ame manner as the Vena Splenica.

The Meenterica uperior is ditributed welnigh into the whole Meentery, and contitutes the Arteriae Mearaicae, in the Gut Jejunum, Ileon and part of Colon: whoe ue is, 1. To communicate native heat into the neighbouring parts, and thoe whereinto they are inerted. 2. In a ickly tate to receive the Excrement- of the whole body, as the Mearaick Veins do, to empty them into the Guts, which ue was firt found out by Spigelius. 3. Some conceive the Mearaick Arteries draw Chyle. 1. Becaue of their Carriage. 2. Becaue of their Ends. 3. Of their Contents. 4. The Authority of Galen in his 4. de uu partium and in his Treatie An in Arteria it anguis ch. 5. whom Hofman follows. But they cannot draw Chyle, becaue Chyle was never een in them, and the Arteries receive nothing from the parts, but communicate omewhat to thoe parts whereinto they are inerted. Nor do they draw to the Heart, as Varolus would have it, for the valves hinder: and the Chyle is not natural to the Heart. Nor to the Liver or Spleen, as others uppoe, becaue only the Splenick Arteries do carry vital Blood to the Spleen, and there is only one little Artery implanted in the Liver. Nor is it returned out of the Arteries into the Veins, as Spigelius imagins, for o there would be labour in vain; Nor do they carry this Chyle to the Caeliaca: becaue nothing acends by the Arteries, but all decends by them to the parts. Therefore 4. The true ue of the Mearaick Arteries according to the Principles of Walaeus is, to carry Arterial blood to the Guts, for their nutriment. Which motion of the Humors, Ligatures do hew in live-Anatomies. For the Mearaick Arteries being bound, do well towards the Trunk and the Heart, and are empty towards the Guts, which uck in the blood, and end back what is uperfluous, through the mearaick Veins to the Liver.

For the Blood is alo circularlyWhether the Blood of the Belly be circulated. moved in the Abdomen, out of the coeliac and meenterick Arteries, into the Vena portae, notwithtanding Riolanus his denying the ame, by his motion through the Trunks, becaue

list.item: 1. There is the ame Neceity which is in the Heart and other parts, the ame Profit and the ame Urgency.

2. Seeing there is an impule of Blood without intermiion, into the Meeraic and Coeliack Arteries, of neceity, they mut either break, or Tumors and other Dieaes mut arie in the Meentery, or it mut run back again to the branches of the Portae
3. Ligatures demontrate the ame here, as in other places.
4. The Valves oberved by Harvey in the Ramus plenicus, permit the Blood to run back by the Vena portae.

div.p: As to the contrary reaons it is to be oberved.

list.item: 1. That the Blood of the Vena portae is not o impure, if it be compared with that of the Cava, but that it is omtimes purer than it; and though it be more dreggy, there is the more need for it to run back, to be made more pure by the Liver and Heart.
2. That there are in the Liver Anatomoes either of the Vena portae and Vena cava (though they are not o apparent in a dead body) or uch as open into the parenchyma of the Liver.

3. Somtimes there is a remarkable palpitation of the Arteria coeliaca in hypochondriacal diorders, which alo Mercatus and Fernelius have oberved, without any mutation of the Pule, viz. the Hypochondrium being ill affected with Wind, or with ome ditemper, whereby the ame Blood coming from the Heart, may be changed in this Region: but that by the Palpitation of the lower parts, the Heart is many times changed, Tulpius hath an Example. See alo other Arguments, learnedly reuted by Slegelius.

div.p: The Meenterica inferior, is ditributed into the lower part of the Meentery, and the left ide of Colon.

But the other Arteries which accompany the Branches of Cava, are thee following, excepting the Meenterica inferior. For in this order the branches break forth from the Arteria magna, in the lower Belly. 1. Caeliaca. 2. Meenterica uperior. 3. The Emulgent. 4. The Spermatick. 5. The Meenterica inferior. 6. The Lumbares; from which two Arteries are thought to accompany two Veins of the Brain. 7. Mucula uperior.

Afterwards the Aorta at the beginning of the Osacrum, goes above the Vena Cava and no longer under, leat miting againt ome Bone in its perpetual motion, it hould be hurt; alo that the fore-parts, the hops of generation, becaue of their need of Heat, might be neer the great Artery. And in this place it is called
Iliaca, where it is divided like the Cava into the two Iliac Trunks, and each of them into the inner and and leer branch, and the outer and greater which go to the Thigh.

But before they become crural, they end out on each
ide ix branches. The Sacra preently after the bipartition: from the inner Trunk the Mucula inferior, the Hypogatrica and
• mbilical Arteries: from the Epigatrica and Pudenda; The ret of the Artery is carried into the Thigh • nd makes the Crural Arteries.

div.head: Chap. 6. Of the Crural Arteries.
div.p: OF the Crural Arteries, on each ide, are contituted thee following Arteries.

Above the Ham, for the exterior parts of the Trunk, Mucula curalis externa, to the foremore Mucles of the Thighs, from the inner, the Mucula crutalis interna, to the inner Mucles of the Thigh; and this is mingled at the Knee, with a mall branch or twig of the Hypogatrica.
Under the Ham arie three branches:

list.item: 1. The Popliteus, into the hinder Mucles of the Thigh.

2. The Suralis, which is divided into the Tibicus exterior, the poterior altus and poterior humilis,
••• the Mucles of the Leg.
3. The ret is pent upon the Foot and its • oes

div.head: THE THIRD MANUAL Of the Nerves, Anwering to the THIRD BOOK OF THE HEAD.
CHAP. I. Of the Nerves in General.
div.p: BY the Term Nervus the Ancients didThe ignifications of the term Nervus. ometimes ignifie a Ligament or Band, hence the Comaedian aies, He will come to the Halter, in Nervum ibit: but it properly ignifies a common Organ, which together with animal pirits, carries the faculty of moving and feeling, wherefore Aurelianus calls the Nerves eauales vi • .
A Nerve therefore is a common Organ long and round, to carry the Animal facultyA Nerve what. lodged in the Animal pirit, into the parts of the Body.
The Efficient is the Nerve-making faculty.
The Matter according to Hypocrates, is a clammy and cold part of the Seed, heated but not burnt: and Galen aies 'tis a matter white, thick and roapie. And this is the Beginning of its Generation.

The Beginning of the Dipenation of Nerves or the part whence the Nerves immediatelyThe Beginning of the Nerves. arie, is the Medulla oblongata, partly as it is within the Skull, and partly as it is in the Back-bone. Within the Skull arie thoe which are commonly aid to arie from the Brain, viz. the even pair of Nerves: and in the Back-bone thirty. And this mot true opinion is confirmed, not only by the imilitude of the Marrowie and Nervie Subtance, but alo by ocular experience.
Aritotle would have them arie from the Heart, who is followed by Alexander, Averroes The Error of Aritotle. and Apo • eais, who nevertheles ay it comes by mediation of the Brain.

Others would have the Nerves to be nothing ele but the Veins and Arteries continued, and degenerating into Nerves: as Praxagoras of old, in our daies Cealpinus, Reunerus, Hofmannus, and Martianus, but they are out; eeing 1. In the Brain there is no Conjunction of Arteries and Nerves by Anatomoes. 2. An Artery being hurt or cut in the Head, no Convulion follows. 3. The ditinct Rie of the Nerves in the Brain is apparent, as of the Arteries in the Heart.
Eraitratus did conceive they came from the Dura Mater.
At this day many Phyitians conceive with Galen, that ome Nerves arie from the Brain, others from the Spinal Marrow: who are all confuted by Ocular inpection.
Their End and Ue is, to carry the Animal faculty with the Animal pirit, from the Brain, like conduit pipes, into the parts.

list.item: 1. Senory, as the Eyes, Ears, &c.
2. Motive, as the Mucles.
3. All in a manner, that they may in general perceive and undertand what caueth pain.

div.p: And therefore the Nerves inerted into the parts, do give to the aid parts either Sene alone, or Motion alone, or both Sene and Motion: nor is there any voluntary motion or ene without the help of a Nerve; and therefore a Nerve being cut, that part is preently deprived of Sene and Motion.

The Nerves therefore, I ay, do afford Whether the moving Nerves and the enitive differ. to the parts either Sene or Motion, according as they are dieminated into uch and uch parts, becaue the Nerves of themelves are not enitive or motive. So that if they be implanted into Mucles the Organs of Motion, they are termed motive Nerves; if into the Intruments of ene, enitive. Many times alo according to the Nature of the Parts, one pare of Nerves affords both ene and motion. As the ixt pare of the Nerves of the Brain, commonly o called, is communicated to the Bowels of the middle and lower Belly to caue the Sene of Feeling; and when it becomes recurrent, it betows
motion upon the Mucles of the Larynx. The optick pare o called, gives only ene, becaue implanted into the Eyes only. But the other pare which is termed motorium par • , the moving pare, and aries from the marrow as well as the former, caues motion becaue it is implanted into the Mucles of the Eyes.
The Situation of the Nerves, for ecurities ake, is more profound and deep than that of the Arteries.

The Magnitude is various, according to the condition of the Organs and dignity of the Actions, their Aiduity and Magnitude. The optick Nerves are great, becaue the action of the Eyes is o; alo thoe Nerves are mot thick which are ent to remote and many parts, as the Limbs; indifferent in the enory parts; for becaue they were to be oft, they could not be very mall: the Nerves of the neeret parts are mallet of all, as in the Mucles of the Face.

The Nerves are commonly aid to be even and thirty pare in number; even pareA new opinion of the Author touching the number of the Nerves. from the Brain, which I ay arie not from the Brain, but from the Medulla oblongata within the Skull, and thirty from the Marrow in the Back-bone. But I ay that indeed & in truth, thoe even pare, are ten pare, as hal be made apparent in the following Chapter: and o I make forty pare of Nerves: ten ariing within the Skull, and thirty without in the Back-bone.
The former were indeed by the Ancients reckon'd to be only even in number, and to arie from the Brain, which they comprehended in this vere.

l.hi: Optica prima, Oculos movet altera, tertia gutat

Quarta
que Quinta audit, vaga exta et, eptima linguae.
Firt ees, next moves the Eyes; third, fourth do tat,
Fit hears, ixt roams, eventh moves the Tongue too fat.

div.p: But the melling pare was by them omitted, and that which they make the third pare, is double and ditinct; o the fit is double; one pare of which duplicity, ome have made to be an eighth pare, for Archangelus reckon'd eight pare, Columbus nine, and I ten, as tall be aid hereafter.
Now the thirty pare of the Marrow of the Back are o divided, that even are of the Neck, twelve of the Chet or Back (others ay eleven) five of the Loyns (ometimes four) and ix of the Os acrum.

All thee Nerves do prout out of both ides, and therefore they are termed Pares of Nerves, Suug •••
conjugations or coupling of Nerves. And it is neceary for a Phyitian to know their originalsThe ue of this Doctrine in Phyick. and ditinctions, that he may undertand to which part of the Back-bone Topicks are to be applied, when motion or ene, or both are impaired in the Face, Neck, Hands, Mucles of the Belly, Yard, Fundament, Womb, Bladder, &c.
Moreover as to number, you mut know that every Nerve hath its mate or Companion,The Nervus ine pari. except the lat or lowet proceeding from the pinal Marrow.

The figure of the Nerves is long, round, andWhy the Nerves are not hollow. mooth like Conduit pipes; but without any hollownes as the Veins and Arteries have: becaue the later with Spirit were to carry Blood, but the Nerves carry only Spirit.

Riolanus the Father excepts the Nerves of the Privity manifetly hollow, which nevertheles his Son excues to have been meant of the hollow Ligaments of the Privity, who is better vert in Anatomy than his Father was, and o alo Laurentius poke. Severinus in his Zootome, aies, the Nerves of a Bulls pizzle are hollow. Galen alo adds the Optick Nerves,Whether the Optick Nerves are hollow. which he will have to be hollow and perforated, enibly and manifetly: for the dicerning whereof he conceives three things are neceary, viz. That 1. The Animal be great. 2. That it be cut up as oon as killed. 3. That the Air be cleer and bright. Plempius doth alo require three things more, that the Nerve be cut aunder with a mot harp Knife, that it be not queezed nor tretched, and that it be cut beyond the growing together of the two Nerves. Cornclius Gemma ubcribes to Galen, who attributes rather a paage to be een like a prick in the inner ubtance of the Nerves.

Others conceive the poroity is better een in the optick Nerves being boiled. Fallopius aies that Galen thought thus, becaue in the Bodies of Apes which he diected, all Nerves are pervions. Howbeit Spigelius admits only certain paages in the beginnings of Nerves, where they grow together, and oon after towards the Eyes it vanihes. I alo aw a Cavity and Publickly did hew the ame in a dead body, after they were joyned, and before they entred into the Eye.
But Vealius, Eustachius, and Coiterus, deny thee Nerves to have any Cavity againt Galen, and o do others, and produce experiments which ucceed not, unles the conditions aforeaid be oberved.

All the ret of the Nerves do want a manifet Cavity, but they have Pores, through which the ubtile pirit • pa • s, leat we hould grant penetration of bodies which is impoible. Thee pores are double according to Hogeland, leer and greater, through the former ubtil aerial bodies pas to move the parts; by the later, bodies les ubtil. Neither of them is dicernable to the Sene. Nor are there two orts of Spirits in the Brain. I am rather apt to believe that according to the Indigence of every part and the pleaure of the will and the Imagination, ometimes more pirit paes through the greater, ometimes les through the leer, which the more plentiful or canty influx of the Spirit doth make.

Moreover all the Nerves do conit, none excepted, of many nervous fibres or filaments which grow mutually together by little Membranes. I my elf, with Johannes Leonicenus, a right diligent Anatomit, have oberved the Trunk of Nerves neer the Hips, if it be diected, to hew a Cavity as it were, coniting of an infinite contexture of fibres, like little Worms, whereas elewhere it is one continued body, with cohaering and continued fibres.

The Subtance of the Nerves is thought to be threefold: the internal, white, and marrowih (by which as the Centre the action is performed) from the marrow of the Brain, but more compact and thickned; and an external, being a twofold coat; the outer harder, proceeding from the Dura Mater; the inner finer, from the Pia Mater. Which Membranes do the ame for the Nerves, which the Dura and Pia Mater do for the Brain. Howbeit this ditinction of Subtances, is to be earcht out, rather by Reaon than by Sene.

p.U: uppoes that there are Valves in the Nerves, which top the Spirit that it may not flow back, otherwie the parts cannot be moved. But it eems to me, the Spirits may not be retained in the parts, which the Soul that directed the Spirit as far as to the Valve, hall direct it into the very parts. For no Anatomit as yet hath oberved any Valves. Nor can ubtile Spirits be topped by Valves. Nor would Apoplexies or Palies o eaily happen, if the Spirits could be detained in the parts by Valves.

div.p: Beides Valves H. Regius introduces likewie a circulation of the animal Spirits in the Nerves. For after they are ditributed from the Brain to the whole Body, he conceives part is diipated by inenible Tranpiration, and part being ininuated into the Veins, is mingled with the Blood, and returns with it into the Heart, and thence again into the Brain and Nerves. He proves this by the example of a Snail encloed in a glas, in which the pirits through its tranparent Body, are een to move and pas from the Tail through the Belly, to the Head; and from the Head through the Back, to return to the Tayl, and from thence to the Head again
But ome doubts with-hold me from aenting to this witty conjecture, becaue

list.item:
1. Walaeus earching out the Motion of the Animal pirits with all his diligence, could finde nothing but the motion and ditention of the Mucles. For the Nerves being bound, do not well, nor are ditended, and being cut •
onder, they hew no other motion, but that they are contracted into themelves.
2. There is no need that the pirits hould run back to the Veins, becaue being ubtile they are eaily conumed, and by his own Confeion do inenibly exhale.
3. New pirit is evermore upplied from the Brain, which may upply the Defect of that which is conumed.
4. The Veins need none, becaue they poes that pirit which is proper to the Blood, nor are they moved with animal motion.

5. The Nerves themelves are not moved by Sytole and Diatole, nor of themelves as was aid, becaue it appears not when they are bound, and they move with a voluntary motion by the Mucles, and not by the arteries becaue they are maller and go not into them: finally the Nerves are unfit for uch a motion becaue of their Slipperines.
6. In a Snail the Spirit aforeaid is intead of Blood, which Snails have not.

7. I have een thoe who had their enes perfect, and the motion of all their parts free to the lat gap, whoe Pule did nevertheles intermit for certain daies, where there was no regres of the Spirits to the Veins, freely paing nevertheles from the Brain to the parts of the Body, as long as there was any left.

div.p: It is now to be oberved that all the Nerves are not alike hard or oft; whence Galen reckonsNerves hard or oft. ome Nerves oft, others hard: the former he calls enitive, the later motive. Now the Nerve become harder,

list.item: 1. Becaue of their Production, as being to go a great wav • or through ome hard Body, or by a crooked way. And by how much they are further from the Brain, by o much the harder they are. Hence the hort Nerves, as thoe of the Sight. Tate, Hearing are oft, and thoe of the Smelling oftet of all.

2. For ue, for hard Nerves are held to be fitter for motion, oft ones for ene. And therefore the Organs of the Senes have received oft Nerves, that they might be the ooner affected by a enible object occurring. Now all parts which have voluntaryWhy the moving Nerves are hardest. motion have hard Nerves, becaue that which is hard is fittet to act, that which is oft to uffer.

div.p: The • e therefore of all the Nerves is,

list.item: 1. To carry animal Spirits to all parts for ene and motion, which appears when they are hurt. For if they are obtructed in the beginning or totally, they both perih and an Apoplexy is caued: or in part, and then one part of the Body is deprived of ene and motion. If they are cut aunder, the motion of that part is lot, into which they were inerted.

2. To diffue Animal light into the parts. For the animal Spirits could not o oon be taken away, either in a Ligature, or Obtruction of the Nerves, but that thoe Spirits which remain in the part, might caue motion or ene. Therefore the direction of the Brain proceeds from ome what ele, which being taken away, the parts preently ceae from performing their functions, even as the Hammer is by the Hand directed unto the Anvil, and a Staff is directed when it is hurled, which others endeavour to explain by ome hot Acci • ent beide the Animal Spirit. But I uppoe thee things are done by a light which irradiates from the Brain, with the pirits, which being intercepted, the parts are immediately deprived of Sene and Motion, as the light of the Sun is taken away by a Cloud, and the light of a Candle, by holding a mans hand before it. For,
1. No other influent caue, can low in o uddenly, and be withdrawn o uddenly.
2. Light is the caue of all motion wellnear in the Univer • and nothing is wifter than it is.

3. Sometimes it remains after interception, but not long, as light received into the Bononian Stone, and a Stick by me violently darted, and broken in the middle way, does fly yet further, by the motion impreed from my hand.

3. The Temper of the Body follows the Figure and Temper of the Nerves, and therefore Jo • . Damacenus in the eventh Aphorime to his Son, advies, in giving of Medicaments to avoid uch as diolve the force of the Nerves.

div.head: Chap. 2. Of the ten Pare of Nervs, which arie within the Skull, from the Medulla Oblongata, and their progres.
div.p: I Make the firt Pare to be Par Olfactorium the Smellingpare, whoe procees are termed Mammillares. And thee procees have been ufficiently known to all: but the Nerves, to which they are fatned behind, and well near continued, to none or very few.

Thee Nerves lip out of the Marrow aboutWhether there be any melting Nerves. the Saddle of the Sphaenoides, near the foremore Ventricles, and have the carriage, colour, and ue of Nerves, and therefore I reckon them for Nerves.

For they mut not therefore be robbedA Praeocupation of the Name of Nerves, becaue they pas not without the Skul, and Dura Mater, and are not afterward inveted herewith, for then all the other Nerves as long as they are within the Skull, mut not be called Nerves, which were aburd.
To thee Nerves are adjoyned two thickProceus Mammillares. portions or procees called Proceus Mammillares, papillares: the Teat-like procees.
They are in Number, two, white, oft, broad, longih, in men thin and ruall, in Brutes greater, epecially in Dogs, and other Creatures that have an exquiite Smell.
For,
The ue of thee Procees, is to be the trueThe Organ of Smelling. Organs of Smelling and not the Noe nor its coat.
Thee Procees are placed in the fore-part of the Brain, behinde the Colander-bone, and to it being covered with the Dura Meniax they put a face. Through the Colanderbone the Odours acend.

The Second Pare, which others count the firt, is the Optick or eeing pare, becaue it carries the eeing Spirits to the Eyes, or the repreentations of viible objects to the Brain, but not humours from the Brain to the Eye to nourih it, which is the fiction of Caealpinis. Hicro • hilus calls them poros opticos or meatus, the optick pores or paages, becaue they are thought to be hollow.
Thee Nerves, of all the ten pare, are the greatet and thicket, but ofter than the ret.

They arie, not as the common Opinion is,The Error of others about the rie of the Optick Nerves. from the fore-part of the Bais of the Brain; for their original mut be ought further, towards the hinder part of the Head, where they are carried between the Brain, and the beginning of the pinal Marrow, and arie out of the beginning of the firt Trunks of the Medulla
oblongata, growing out of the Brain. But Riolanus demontrates, that they are turned round about thoe great Eminencies of the Brain, which G •••
c •• s Thata • os nervorum opticorum, which reach unto the foremore Ventricles, that they may fetch optick pirits from thence.

And having proceeded a while, they are neer the middle way united aboveThe Union of the optick Nerves and the true Caue thereof. the addle of Os Sphaeno • des, not by a imple touch or interection, in Mankind, but a total confuion and mingling of their Subtances, that they might uffer the les, in the middle of a long paage, by reaon of their oftnes. Vealius, Aquapendens and Valverda have oberved that they have omtimes continued divided, in their whole Coure. Vealius alo oberved that in a Woman they were joyned only by mutual Contact, whoe right Eye had been withered from a Child; becaue the right Nerve was maller than the left, beyond the Conjunction. But in mot bodies the inner ubtance of the Nerves is confounded, as I have oberved by accurate Inquiition.

The growing together of the optick nerves, was therfore contrived by Nature, either left the enible object being received in by both Eyes hould eem double, or that the Viive pirit might, if need were, be all conveighed into one Eye which are the conjectures of Galen, or finally for trength and tability here neceary, leat in Concuions of the Brain they might hap to be broken or ditorted, or leat through the oftnes and moitnes of the Brain and optick Nerves, by reaon of ditillations and other Excrements they might become flaggie, and o driven out of their right tation; which is the opinion of Plempius.
Soon after being eperated they go out of the Skull into the Centre of the Eyes in Mankind, but much lower in Beats, becaue they look more idewaies.

Within the Skull they are cloathed only with the Pia mater; but from the holes, which pas to the Eyes, they are covered with the dura mater. Afterward it preads the latter to the Sclirotica tunica, the former to the Tunica choroïdes, and its inner marrowy ubtance to the Retina.
The third pare, which others count the econd, is the motorium oculorum, the Eye-mover, next unto the former.

This pare is thought by vulgar Anatomits to arie from the Brain,The Error of others about the Rie of the Eye-movers. neer the original of the firt pare. But it reaches to the middle of the Head, goes beneath the Opticks cros-wie, and

Aries at the inmot part of theWhy one Eye being moved, the other moves alo. Beginning of the medulla oblongata, where in their Rie, thee two motive-nerves are o united as to touch one another, yea to become one continued Body, which is the caue, that when one Eye moves, the other is moved alo.

This Pare is leer and harder than the former and tretched out by the viiveWhy omtimes when the temporal mucle is hurt, the Eye is hurt likewie. pare; goes out of the Skull at other holes to the Mucles of the Eyes and Eylids. It ometimes though eldom ends a branch to the temporal Mucle; and that is the Caue that the aid Mucle being hurt, the Eye is hurt, and the Eye being hurt that is hurt.

The Fourth, Fift and Sixt pares are much confounded by Anatomits. For ome make the fourth and fift Pare one, and call it the third Pare, coniting of two roots; the leer of which ome do make the third pare, and they themelves do make the fift and ixt pare one, viz, the fourth pare by them o called. But thoe who reckon it for one, they count the fourth pare, according to my reckoning, for the leer root of the third pares and the ixt pare for the fourth. whereas we ditinguih all thee pares.

The fourth pare therefore, which others as Bauhin •
count the third; others as Fallopius the eighth pare; others badly, the leer root of the third pare: for it hath nothing common with the following pare, is not joyned to it, either in the Beginning or the Progres, and grows out of the order of other pares • according to ome

From the ide of the Beginning of the Medulla oblongata; according to others it grows with a very mall Nerve, out of the lowet and hinder eat of the Medulla Cerebri or marrow of the Brain: then it is carried forwards, and fatned to the econd pare, it goes with it out at the common hole, enters the ocket of the Eye and ends one from it elf branches

Into the fat of the Eye, the fift Mucle, and by a peculiar hole of the Bone of the Fore-head, it goes out to the Skin of the Fore-head, and the upper Eye-lid. And thee are furnihed by its firt branch.
The econd furnihes the Mucles of the upper Lip, and ome of the Noe, and the Lip it elf and Gums.
The third by the Cavity of the Notrils erves the coat of the aid Notrils.

The fourth erves the inner part of the temporal Mucle. All which branches Fallopius doth attribute to the two following Conjugations: but my ditribution is propounded by Vealius, Columbus, P • uerus, and Bauhinus.
The fift Pare, which others count the thicker root of the third pare; is commonly thought to furnih the Tongue with the ene of Tating.

This aries neer the following Conjugation, out of the ides of the Medulla oblongata, and preently after its paage through the Os phenoïdes, a writhen branch comes out like a tendrel of a Vine (which ome think is done to make it harder) and is united with two little twigs of the auditory Nerve.

It furnihes the Mucles of the Face, the Temporal Mucle, the chewing Mucle of the Cheeks, the Skin of the Face, the Gums and Teeth (for by their means the Teeth have all the ene they have) the Mucle that lies concealed in the mouth and the lower Lip.
The ixt pare, which ome call Quarta Conjugatio, others the maller root of the fourth Conjugation,
Hath a maller Original, next the former, and omwhat harder than it.

It goes through a common hole withWhether the ixt pare be the ame with the fift. the former, and yet it doth not therefore become one pare with the former: for the third, fourth, and eventh pare, as I reckon them, do alo pas through one and the ame hole.
It is carried into the Palate. Others would have this pare alo to erve the ene of Tating.

The eventh pare, which others count the eighth, others the ninth, others the maller portion of the fift pare, when as in the mean while it is a peculiar pare maller and harder than the fift, alo ditinct therefrom in its original and progres:

For it aries a little before the fift commonly o called, in the middet of the Medulla oblongata, and going over the third pare, and cutting the ame, it proceeds along between the third and fourth pare, where it is carried upwards and forewards, towards the ides.

It goes out of the hole with the third and fourth pare, and is commonly quite pent upon the Muculus abducen •
of the Eye. But that is a quetion, which others ay, that it is carried into the temporal Mucle, and into that which lies concealed in the Mouth.

The Eighth pare which others count the fift, which is called Auditorium, the Hearing pare, aries cloe by the ides of the former, only a little below. It enters the Os petroum, and is divid • d into the greater branch, which being pred out, they wil have to make the Drum, and the leer broad below, as if it would accompany the ixt Conjugation.
