div.p: It ends branches through the firt andWhy we cough when the Earp • cker goes far into our Ear. econd Vertebra to the proper Muces of the Larynx: and therefore it is that picking our Ears too deep, a dry Cough is caued. It is thought omtimes to end branches to the Arm, with the fourth, fift and ixt of the Arm; and omtimes into the whole Foot, with the Nerves of the Back-bone, after it hath accompanied the Spinal Marrow going downwards.

The ninth pare which others call par extum and vagum, the fixt and roaming or wandring pare; becaue it furnihes very many parts here and there, yea and all the internal parts eated in the middle and lower Bellies, which receive branches for ene, eeing they are oft bodies, nor can away with the harder ort of Nerves pringing from the pinal Marrow. And becaue of the long way they go, they are cloathed with trong Membranes, and are carried united to the neighboring parts.
This Pare aries a little beneath the foregoing, undry fibres being preently united.

It goes out through the hole of the Occiput, through which the Ramus major jugularis internae had acended: and not fa • from its egres it provides for the Mucles eated in the Neck, epecially the Cucularis. Then the Trunk decends, and is knit with the lat pare, the Carotick Artery, and Jugular Vein; and ends branches ath • art, through the Membrane and Mucles of the Larynx, alo the Mucles of the Hyoides and the Fauces, as alo to the Tongue.
Then decending between the Carotick and Jugularis, to the ide of the Weand above the Jugulum, it is divided on each ide into the exterior and interior branch.

The Exterior contitutes the recurrent The Recurrent Nerves. Nerves or vocal Nerves o called, becaue they being wounded the living Creature looes ••• voyce; o that if one be cut aunder, half the Voyce is lo •
if both, the animal becomes dumbe. they are alo termed reverivi or recurivi, running-back; for firt they decend, and they turn afterwards back again as it were about an Axle-tree on each ide, the right about the Arteria axillaris, the left about the decending Trunk of the Artery: and afterward they acend as high as the Mucles of the Larynx, to which they give numerous branches which recurion was to be made, becaue th • Mucles of the Larynx have their Heads, not above but beneath.

And therefore the Exterior dexter of the ixt pare, preently after the diviion, furnihes the Mucles ariing from the Breat-bone and Clavicula; then the right Recurrent being contituted for the mot part of three little twigs bended back and united, it decends obliquely under the Jugulum, and in its paage hoots out little branches for the Coat of the Lungs, the Pleura, the Pericardium and the Heart; and then makes the right tomachic, under the Gullet joyned to the let; and paing through the Septum, it goes into the right Ventricle of the Stomach to the let branch.

The Exterior Siniter, furnihing the Parts in the ame manner as the former, and contituting the left Recurrent, it ends forth the Stomachicus • initer which with its fellow compaes the orifice of the Stomach and the remainder goes to the Pylorus and hollow of the Liver.

The Interior dexter firt of all gives a Branch of it elf, at the roots of the ribs, to every intercotal Nerve; and then with the great Arterie it paes through the Septum, and furnihes the whole lower Belly, till it reach as far as to the Os Sacrum. And then it goes into three Branches.

list.item: I. Goes to the Call, from whence arie other three twigs, 1 To the Colon,How Hoar-nes comes after the Cholick. hence after a long Colick comes hoarnes. 2 the mallet carely viible, to the beginning of the Guts. 3 To the right ide of the Bottom of the Stomach, the upper Membrane of the Call, the Coat of the Liver, and the Gall-Bladder.
II. The inferior to the right Kidney. Hence they aigne the caueWhy Vomiting in the tone of the Kidney. of Vomiting, in fits of the Stone in the Kidney.
III. The greatet to the Meentery, Guts, and right ide of the Bladder.

div.p: The Interior initer in its ide is ditributed after the ame manner, ave that in tead of the Liver part thereof goes unto the Spleen. But from both the interiors, ometimes Branches are ent unto the Womb.
This is the ditribution of the ixt Pare according to the vulgar computation, the Ninth according to my account.

div.p: The tenth and lat pare of Nerves, ariing within the kul in the hind part of the Head, out of the Medulla oblongata when in is ready to lide into the Back-bone, is as others reckon the eventh pare.

This is harder then the ret, and it prings from divers roots afterwards united, and goes out of the Skul at a crooked hole propper to it elf. And oon after it is with trong membranes joyned, not mixed with the precedent pare, for afe-gaurd ake. And then it is eparated again, and goes the greatet part of it into the tongue, and ome mall part into the Mucles of Os hyoïdes and the Larynx.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Nerves which proceed from the pinal Marrow, and firt of the Nerves ariing from the Neck, and o of the Nerves of the whole Arm.
div.p: ANd o much for thoe ten pare of Nerves, which proceed from the Medulla oblongata within the skul: the other pares do now follow, which are thirty in number, omtimes nine and twenty, from the ame beginning, viz. the Medulla oblongata being paed out of the Skull into the Back-bone: where it is termed Medulla pinalis or Doralis, the Marrow of the Back. Now the little Nerves proceed out of the holes of the Back-bone, in a continued coure bending themelves inward, from the uppermot to the lowermot.
Out of the Marrow, while it is in the Neck, there arie even pare of Nerves as ome reckon, eight pare as others count, dieminated into the whole outward Head and the neighbouring Mucles.

The firt and econd pare have this peculiar above all the ret, that they proceed not from the ides, but from the fore and hinder part, by reaon of the peculiar Articulation of the firt and econd Vertebra.

Now the firt pare aries between the hinder-part of the Head and the firt Vertebra. Joh. Leonicenus of Padua, a dextrous Anatomit in taking out of the Nerves, denied that there was any uch pare as this, becaue he could neither ee it, nor can •• come out of the firt Vertebra having no hole, and ticking cloely to the econd Vertebra and the Occiput.
The econd pare aries between the firt and econd Vertebra, and o of the ret in order.
The firt and econd pare are dieminated into the Mucles of the Head, and to the Ears.
The third and fourth into the Mucles of the Cheeks, alo thoe which are common to the Head and Neck.

The fift with the branches of the fourth and ixt, do make the remarkable midrif Nerves: and the fift with the foreaid, ends a part backwards, and a part forward into the Mucles bowing the Head; thoe of the Arms, Shoulderblades, and the Skin there.
The ixt to the Arms and the hollow of the Shoulderblades.
The eventh is joyned with two of its Neighbours, viz. the ixt of the Neck and firt of the Chet, whoe greatet part goes to the Arms and as far as the Hands.

For there are carried into the Arms five or ix pare of Nerves, viz. from the fift, ixt, and eventh pares of the Neck, alo from the firt and econd pares of the Chet. which when they firt break forth, they are all mixed and united, nor are eparated without dammage, and oon after they are everally divided into the foreaid Pares; to the End haply, that by that light concoure, a collection might be made of animal pirits. Hence Topick Medicaments, in a Palie, or Convulion of the Arm, the upper part of the Arm being affected mut be applied on the ide of the upper part of the Back and the Neck, from whence the Nerves proceed, not directly in the middle, either of the Back or Neck, unles by reaon of the common beginning of the Nerves.
The firt Pare, from the fift pare of theThe Nerves of the whole Arm. Neck, goes chiefly into the Deltoides Mucle, and the Skin of the Arm, leaving a part which accompanies the Vena humeraria.

The econd being thicker, is carried through the Middle and Forepart of the Cubit, where it furnihes the Muculus biceps, whereupon it is joyned with the third Nerve, and afterwards going downwards, it alutes the Supinator longior with a twig: but at the bending of the Cubit, it is divided omtimes into Two, otherwhites into three branches.

list.item: 1. The upper and leer, goes along the outide of the Arm, to the outer part of the firt or econd Interjuncture of the Thumb.
2. The middle and thicker decends obliquely within the Cubit to the Writ.
3. The lower, being tretched along by the inner branch of the Bailica, is pent into the Skin of the Cubit and Hand.

div.p: The third is joyned with the former, under the Mucle Biceps, it provides for the Brachiaeus and the inide of the Hand.

The fourth being the thicket, goes along with the Vena profunda and the Artery, Afterwards is variouly divided. Now it furnihes the Mucles which extend the Cubit, the Writ, the Thumb, the fore and the middle Finger, and the Mucles which tretch the Fingers out.

The fift tretcht along by the former, between the Mucles of the Cubit, which it furnihes decending through the lower and hinder part of the Cubit (where when we trike againt any thing or compres the Nerve, we feel a nummednes in our fingers) in the middle thereof it is divided into two.

One branch goes externally through the Ulna to the Middle Finger, Ring-finger, and little Finger. On the Inide of the Fingers for ecurities ake, that they may give place in laying hold of any thing, for there Wounds are more pernicious than in the middle.
The other goes inwardly through the Ulna betwixt the Finger-bending Mucles as far as the Writ, and ends branches to the ame parts as the former ent to.
The ixt is pent into the Skin of the Cubit, going betwixt the Skin and the Membrane.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Nerves of the Chet, the Back and Loyns.
div.p: FRom the Marrow of the Back arie twelve pare, or as ome reckon eleven all and every of which after thir Egres are divided into the greater and leer branches: the one of which is carried forward, the other backward, being bowed backwards.

The foremore branches, are ent into all the Intercotal paces, the internal and external ones (both which I have omtimes een divided into two branches) for the Mucles which lie upon the Chet, alo for the oblique decendent of the Belly.

The hindermore and leer branches go backwards to the pines of the Back, betwixt the Mucles which grow to the Vertebrae, into which they are partly conumed, and partly into thoe which grow from thee points of the Spines, as into the Rhomboides, Cuculares, &c.

Out of the pinal Marow when it is in the Vertebrae of the Loyns, there arie omtimes five, omtimes four pare of Nerves: which pares are greater than thoe of the Back. And each of thee is divided into the foremore and hinder branches, which are dieminated, partly into the Mucles of the Loyns and Hypogatrium, and partly into the Thighes. For

list.item: 1. This Pare gives a branch to the flehy parts of the Midriff; and then provides for the Mucles of the Belly and Loyns.
2. It affords branches to ome of the Mucles of the Thigh and Leg, and as many uppoe, a branch to the Spermatick Veels.
3. It goes to the Knee and its Skin, and part accompanies the Saphaena, and part goes to the Mucles which ret upon the Loyns.
4. Among the Lumbal ones, it is the greatet, proceeding to the fore Mucles of the Thigh and Leg, as far as to the Knee.
5. I paes through the hole, which is betwixt the Hipbone, the Share and Flank bones, and betows branches upon ome of the Mucles of the Thigh, Yard, neck of the Womb and Bladder.

div.p: But the greatet branches go from thee three parts, unto the Thighs as hal be aid in the following Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Nerves which proceed from the Marrow of Os acrum, and of the Nerves of the whole Foot.
div.p: OUt of the pinal Marrow contained in the O acrum, there aries five pare of Nerves, or as ome reckon them ix pare, out of the four, uppermot of which, and the three lowet of the Loyns, arie the crural Nerves, decending between the Feet, which being in their Rie joyned like a little Net, do oon after prinkle three branches from themelves, as hall be aid by and by touching the Nerves of the Feet.

Now the firt par •
of Nerves of Os acrum, is divided like the Lumbal Nerves, into a foremore and hindermore branch. But the five following Pares otherwie. For before they go out, they are on each ide double, and on each ide one Nerve goes into the fore parts, another into the hinder parts. The hindermore branches are diminated like the hinder Lumbals, viz, into the hindermore neighbouring parts.
The three foremore which are uppermot, do go into the Thigh, the two lower to the Mucles of the Fundament and Bladder; and ome to the Interfoemineum and Scrotum.

Moreover, the end of the Marrow of theThe Nerve Sine par • . Back, doth produce only one branch out of it elf which is therfore termed Sine pari, without a Ma • e or fellow; yet omtimes it hath a fellow. It pends it elf into the Skin, between the Buttocks and the Fundament, and into certain Mucles of the Thigh.
Now follow the Nerves which go into the Thigh, which before were aid to be four in number.
The firt and third are horter, and reach only to the Thigh, the econd is longer, and goes alo to the Leg, the fourth is longet of all.

The firt being made up of the third and fourth pares of the Loyns, decending to the mall Trochanter, pends it elf into the Skin and Mucles of the Thigh, and ome of the Leg, and is ended above the Knee.

The econd ariing from the ame place, decends with the Vein and Artery to the Thigh through the Groyns, it goes to the foremore Mucles of the Thigh, and is pread about the Knee. But it ends a remarkable branch inwardly with the Saphaena to the Ankle.

The third aries in the Articulation of the fourth and fift Vertebra, paes through the hole of Os pubis, to ome upper Mucles of the Thigh and Yard, ariing out of the Os pubis; and to the Skin of the Thigh in the Groyn.

The fourth is the thicket, longet, hardet and driet in the whole body, made up of four pare of the Os acrum; it furnihes the Skin of the Thigh, and certain Mucles thereof, as alo of the Log and Foot. I have omtimes oberved this to have a double rie, and a double progres, the one External the other Internal.
But that ame great Trunk under the Ham, is divided into an external and an internal Branch.
The external goes to the Ham, the outide of the Foot, the Muculi peronaei, and the outer Ankle.
The Internal and greater goes along the Leg to the Mucles of the Feet and Foes; the inner Ankle, the great Toe and ole of the Foot: and betows two twigs upon each Toe.
All the Nerves therefore well-neer, which go into the whole Leg and Foot, do arie from the only greatet crural Nerve.

div.head: THE Fourth and lat Manual OF THE BONES And alo of the Gritles and Ligaments Anwering the FOURTH BOOK Of the Limbs.
div.p: IN the lat place, I hall briefly (as IThe reaon of the Authors Method. Why he treats lat of the Bones. have done other things) explain the Doctrine of the Bones.

In the lat place, I ay, becaue when all things ele are removed and eparated, then only the Bones come in view, and are ubject to examination. The mot diligent Riolanus treats in two places of his Enchiridion, of the Bones, once as they appear in the dead Carkas, when the Mu¯cles are cut off, and again as they are dried in a Skeleton. But this Otentation is uperfluous in a compendium. For by the ame reaon we hould make a new Anatomical dicoure, of the Veins, Arteries, Nerves, Guts, Stomach, Womb, and other Parts taken out, and dried, and commonly hung up for hew in the Anatmoical Theatres. There is no ue of the latter Doctrine of the Bones, unles to help the Memory, nor is it perfectly undertood without the former. And therefore other Anatomits, with the parts demontrate the Bones lying beneath them, in the dead body. I hal therefore only buie my elf with the firt, and therewith.
Joyn the Doctrine of Gritles and Ligaments.

1. Becaue of the imilitude of their ubtance: for thee three imilarWhy he treats of the Gritles and Ligaments with the Bones. parts are very neer of kin, A Bone, a Gritle, and a Ligament, o that they eem to differ only gradually in repect of more and les one from another. For a Bone is the hardet, a Gritle, a little ofter, yet o as that it may turn to a Bone, as we ee in the tender Bones of Infants, which at firt were grity. A Ligament is yet ofter than a Gritle, which alo it elf omtimes turns to a Bone, as in decrepit Perons. Hence many attribute the ame matter to a Bone, a Gritle, a Ligament, yea and a Tendon.

2. Becaue of the Nearnes of Place; for a Bone, a Gritle, and a Ligament do for the mot part accompany one another, and are found joyned together. For the Bones are tied with the Ligaments, and where they are tied, they are covered about their Heads, with a Gritly Crut or Cover.

div.head: CHAP. I. Of the Bones in General.
div.p:
THe Nature of the Bones is eaily known, if we hal but orderly propound their Caues and Accident •
or Adjuncts.

The Ma ••• out of which the Bones are bred in the Womb, according to Hippocrates, is an earthy Excrement, with Fat and Moiture added thereto. Aritotle alo calls it Excrementum eminale, an excrement of the Seed. Galen aies it is the thicker and harder part of the Seed dried.

Now ome Bones are perfectly generated in the Womb, as thoe in the Ear which erve the Sene of Hearing, being the mallet in the whole body; others imperfectly, as the Teeth and all the ret of the Bones, in which at firt omwhat is wanting either a proces, o • an Appendix, &c.

Moreover, all other Bones ave the Teeth have a certain determination of their growth: but the Teeth grow continually, for if one Tooth be removed, that jut againt it grows longer: which Nature therefore ordained, becaue they are alwaies wearing through grinding and chewing the Meat.

Their remote nutritive Matter, is thought to be the thicker and more earthy part ofWhether the Marrow be the Nutriment of the Bones. the Blood, and that which is as it were excrementitious, flowing in through the Veins into the Marrow, where in the Caverns of the Bones it may be digeted, for Platerus denies that the Bones have Arteries, wherein Spigelius contradicts him: if there be Veins, there will doubtles be Arteries, which are as inconpicuous to the ight as the Veins are. Hence it is, that in the Cavities of the Bones of Animals newly brought forth, the Marrow is as yet bloody.

The Immediate nutritive Matter of the hollowed Bones, according to Hippocrates and Galen, is the Marrow contained in the aid Bones (who are contradicted by Aritotle and other Peripetaticks, who will have the Marrow to be rather the excrement of the Bones) as in Gritles that ame notty matter which lies round about them, is their immediate nutritive Matter; and in Ligaments, Membranes and Nerves, that ame clammy humor hed in amongt them.

Of the olid Bones not hollowed, the immediate Nutritive matter, is thick Blood ent in through the pores; becaue 1. Being broken they are joyned with a Callus, bred of the Remainders of the alimentary Blood. 2. They are liable to Impothumation in their Subtance, the uperfluities of the nourihment putrifying in the pores. Hofman allows that they are nourihed with Blood contained in the Marrow, and that the Marrow erves the Blood, by carrying the olid part.
The Efficient is the Vis o •• ifica, or Bone-making faculty, or the innate faculty, acting by the Aitance of Heat.

The Form of a Bone is the Soul, as of the whole, and in the next place the ratio¯ formalis whereby a Bone is a Bone and no other thing, 2. de Gen. Anim. cap. 1. And therefore the Bones of dead perons are not properly but equivocally Bones. The Accidents or Adjuncts of Bones, are their undry Figures, Solidity, Strength, &c. of which hereafter.
The End or Ue of the Bones, is,

list.item: 1. To be the Foundations and Supporters of the whole Body, like Pillars or Foundations in Houes.
2. To be as a Safeguard for ome parts, as the Skull aveguards the Brain.
3. To erve for going, as is apparent in the Thighes and Legs. and therefore Serpents,Why creeping things cannot go. Worms and other Creepers, which have no Legs, cannot go, but are forced to crawl.
4. There are ome private ues of divers Bones, of which in the pecial Hitory of Bones.

5. Certain Medicinal Ues there are of Bones. Their Pouder cures a Cancer, Fevers, any Fluxes. Their Oyl is good for the Gout, the Magitery of a Mans Skull is good againt the Falling-icknes, as alo the triangular Bones of the Occiput, &c.

div.p: The Situation of the Bones is deep, becaue they are the Foundations and Upholders of the Body.

They vary in Magnitude according to the variety of their Utilities. Great are the Bones of the Leg, Thigh, Arm, Shoulder, &c. Small thoe of the Ear erving for Hearing, the Seamoidean Bones, the Teeth, the Writbones, &c.
They are many in number and not one only, becaue of the varietyWhy many Bones in a living Creature. of motions; and let that one being hurt, all hould be hurt.
Now a montrous thing it is for a Child to be born without Bones, uch an one as Hippocrates peaks of, being a Boy, four fingers big, but not long-liv'd the like to which Foretus alo aw.

The Number of all the Bones of the Body, is not the ame in all Perons. For in Children they are more, which by degrees grow together and become fewer. Others may number the Epiphyis by themelves as ditinct Bones, and o make a mighty number. Others may omit the Seamoidean and other mall Bones, or uch as are eldom found, as in the Carotick Arteries: and o doth Archangelus who reckons but two hundred forty nine: others make commonly three hundred and four. Others as many as there are daies in the year.
They vary in Figure ome are round, others flat, ome harp, others blunt, &c. as hal be hewed when we come to peak everally of the particulars.
The Colour in uch as are naturally contituted, is white, mixt with a very little red.

They are all of them externally incloed (not internally) with the Periotium, excepting the Teeth, eamoidean Bones, and the ides of the other Bones where they are mutually joyned one to another. And the Periotium is exquiitely enible:The Periotium feels, but not the Bones. The Sene of the Teeth. but the Bones themelves want the ene of Feeling, excepting the Teeth, to whom we may attribute ome Sene, eeing they feel exceeding cold Air or Water, yea with their Ends: epecially when the Teeth are on Edge, before it reach to the little Membranes and Nerves, by help wherof they are thought to Feel.

The Connexion of the Bones is various. But the mutual and artificial hanging together of all the Bones is by the Greeks cal'd Skeleton, as if you would ay a dried Carcas from Skellein to drie. Being compacted partly with the natural Ligaments dried with the Bones, & partly with artificial ones, omtimes bolt upright, otherwhiles in the poture of itting; which doth not properly belong to Anatomy, but the other Natural Oteology, framed by Nature, and adorned with its own moit Ligaments.
And this natural Cohaerence or Connexion, according to Galen, is made either Cat' árthron by way of Joynting; or catà umphuin, by way of growing together.

He makes Arthron a Joynt to be double; viz. Diarthrois or by way of Diarticulation or joynting, uch as are Enárthrois, Arthrodia and Gigglumos: or Sunarthrois, uch as he reckons Suture, Harmonie and Gomphois
Moreover Symphyis or growing together, is aid to be with or without a Medium.
But I hall thus divide the Connexions of the Bones.
The Bones are fatned together either by Articulation or Joynting; or by Symphyis or growing together.

Articulation or Joynting is with motion, and that either obcure (which others cal neuter or doubtful Articulation) as that of the Ribs with the Vertebrae, alo of the Bones of the Writ and Pedium; or evident looe and manifet, and it is called
Diarthrois, of which there are three orts:

list.item: I. Enarthrois Inarticulation, which is when there is a great quantity both of the Cavity of the Bone receiving, and of the Head of the Bone which is received: as in the Articulation of the Thigh with the Huckle-bone.
II. Arthrodia, is where the Cavity receiving is uperficial, and the Head received flat: as is that of the lower Jaw with the Bone of the Temples.

III. Gigglumos, when the ame Bone both receives, o that contiguous bones do mutually enter one into another. And it is done three manner of waies:
1. When the ame bone is received by one bone which receives the ame again mutually; as we ee in the Articulation of the Shoulder-bone with the Cubit.
2. When one bone receives and is received of another, as in the Vertebrae. For the Vertebra being placed in the middle, receives the upper and is received by the lower.
3. In manner of a wheel, as that of the econd Vertebra of the Neck with the firt; where upon the Axel-tree as it were of one Vertebra, another is turned and wheeled about,

div.p: By Sumphuis or growing together, Bones are fatned, when the Connexion is without motion, and two Bones do only touch one another, or approach mutually one to another, as in the former.
And this growing together is either without a medium or with it.

list.item: 1. Rhaphé a Suture as in the Skul.
2. Harmonia, which is a joyning of Bones by a ingle Line, treight, oblique, or circular: as in bones of the upper Jaw and the Noe. And o all Epiphyes in a manner are joyned.
3. Gomphois that is to ay Nailing, when one Bone is fatned into another as a Nail in a Pot, as the Teeth in the Jaw-bones.

div.p: Thee three orts Galen and others following him, have comprehended under Synarthrois as the Genus or kind. But they are out: becaue Bones thus joyned have no motion yet peradventure they may ome waies pertain to Synarthrois, becaue of the firmnes they afford to the parts of the body.
With a Medium there is alo a threefold growing together of the Bones, by reaon of a threefold body coming between as the Medium:

list.item: 1. A Gritle and the conjunction is called Sunchondrois. as in the Bones of the lower Jaw, and the Sharebones.
2. A Ligament and it is termed Sunneurois, as is een in the Union of the Huckle-bone with the Thigh bone.
3. Fleh or a Mucle, and it is called Suarcois, as in the Os hyoides with the Scapula.

div.p: The Subtance of the Bones is hard, but not with drines in an healthy State, but with a hining fattines. to which others joyn an acid or harp pirit and a volatil Salt, in which regard they eaily take fire and are burnt intead of Wood, as the Rogus of the Romans or their Funeral-fires did witnes [and our Englih Bonefires, for anciently (and yet in theA Bonefire properly what. North) they kept their Bones of Beef &c. til an occaion of Triumph, and then brought them out for joy to make Bone-fires] otherwie they would eaily be broken, as we ee in calcined Bones, and in that old Woman, whoe Members would break at the leat touch, as Nic. Fontanus relates in his Obervations. And Galen tels of ome bones that would turn to Sand and Dut, like rotten wood, which is the effect of drines.
The Les this Hardnes of the Bones is, the better do broken bones grow together and unite.

But in Perons that are come to years, they do not truly grow together, nor are regenerated, but are as it were glewed together, by the coming between of another ubtance like Glue, which they term Callus. Galen cals it Porus. Now a Callus omtimes happens beide the Intent of Nature, through overgreat plenty of Aliment and bad Nutrition: viz. when by a boney callus, the three upper Vertebra's of the Neck are o glewed together as they eem to be but one bone: or when the firt Vetebra is glewed to the Skul; and uch perons cannot expres their conent or dient, by moving their Head forwards or backwards as the manner is.

There is a greater hardnes in ome Bones than in others, as the Thigh, &c. But other Bones are ofter, as of the Os Spongioum, the lat bones of the Fingers &c. Fernelius, Ruellius, Hollerius have found all the bones o preternaturally oft, that they might be bowed like Wax, and that chiefly by the venereal Pox, witnes M. Donatus. The Cartilago iniformis proves omtimes o oft and flaggie, that it falls, of which ee Codronchius.

The parts of the Bones are olid or Hollow, yet Plinie tels us, that there were ome that lived whoe bones were olid, without any hollownes, who are by him called Cornei, and that uch perons are known, in that they never weat nor thirt. which Salinus avouches of one Lyddanus a Syracuian. But both thee Authors can omtimes drop leaings.

The Cavities are either within where the Marrow is, which cavities nevertheles are not every where conpicuous; or without at the joyntings; which hollownees if they are deep, they are called Cotúlai or Cotulides (not co • ul • dones) alo Acetabula, Sawcers. Cotyle was among the Ancients, a meaure of Liquors, containing as much as their Hemina; alo a kind of Drinking Cup, as ome uppoe If the Cavities are hallow, they are called Glênai and Glenoeideîs from the form of the Eyes hollownes when the Eye-lids are hut.
The olid parts of the Bones are three.
The firt and principal is called Os, and is the hardet part, eated commonly in the middle.

The econd is by the Greeks called Apophyis, alo they term it Probolen and Ecph • e • in &c. the Latines call it Proceus, Productio, Projectura, Extuberantia &c. It is a part of a bone, not only touching as Epiphuis, but continued bunching out beyond the plain urface of the Bone: uch as many are in the Vertebra's of the Back, alo in the lower Jaw-bone.
Its chief Ue is for the original and Inertion of parts, as Mucles.

The third is Epiphuis, or Appendix, Adnacentia, Additamentum; being a bone growing upon a bone, by a imple and immediate Contact, though not with o very plain a Surface, but a little mutual Ingres of Heads and Hollows, like Ginglumus, though without motion.

The Subtance of the Epiphyes is rare and looe, being at firt for the mot part gritly; but in perons grown to years, it is hardned, and turns to a bone: yea in elderly perons, the Epiphyis is o united to the bone, as if they were but one contined bone,
At the Ends of the Epiphyis a Gritle is placed.

But all Bones have not thee Epiphues growing to them: yet there are divers of them; as in the Scapula, on the Bones of the Tibia and the Fibula, viz. on each ide, at the Tree and Foot &c. Alo the Tooth of the econd Vertebra, the Rotator magnus, the Appendices Styloydes, are Epiphyes.
The Ue of Eppiphyes.

list.item: 1. In oft bones they are intead of covers, that the Marrow may not run out.
2. They erve for firmnes, for that Bais is mot firm which is broadet and larget.
3. That from them Ligaments may arie.
4. According to Pavius, that they might be as it were an intermediate matter, to be inerted betwixt a bone and Ligaments, as the Membranes betwixt the Brain and Skull.

div.p: The Apophyis are in ome places called Capita Heads; in other places, Cervices Necks; in other places Tubercula bunches; in ome place Spina thorns; in other places Mucrones harp points. But the parts which at the round of the Cavities, tick out and hang over like Lips, are called Supercilia Brows, and Labra Lips.

div.head: Chap. II. Of Gritles in General.
div.p: GRitles next to Bones are the hardet imilar parts and almot jut of the ame Nature with Bones, for uch Beats as have no Bones, have Gritles intead of Bones according to Aritotle.

But they differ, becaue they are ofter than Bones, though harder than Ligaments: and though very many Gritles are in proces of time turn'd into Bones [as Cardan
hews by the example of a Thief of Milaine, whoe weand was become boney. Alo many Sceletons of my Kinman Henry Fuirenus declare, that the Cartilago cutiformis, or heid-fahion'd Gritle, is changed into the hard ubtance of a Bone, which I alo have oberved in Diections] yet all Gritles are not o, as the Eniformis, that of the Share, of the Spines of the Back, of the Notrils and Ears: which nevertheles omtime, in aged perons are turned into Bones. Moreover a Gritle hath no Marrow, no Cavities nor Caverns.
The Efficient is the Gritl-making power or faculty.

The Matter according to Aritotle is the ame with that of the Bones, from wich he wil have them to differ only gradually. According to Galen it is an earthy but withall moit part of the Seed, partly clammy and glewih, partly fat: but more clammy than fat.
Its Ue

list.item: 1. Is principally to render motion more eaie and lating in the Joynts, whiles it anoynts the parts of the Bones, leat by mutual rubbing one againt another, they hould wear and fret. Hence in ome Joynts are found Gritles which crutover two bones joyned together.

2. To defend the parts from external injuries. For they are not eaily bruied and broken, becaue they are hard and not friable, nor are they eaily cut and queezed as the oft and flehy parts. Hence the extream parts of the Noe are gritly. Hence Gritles are joyned to the Breatbone and Ribs, to defend the Heart and Lungs, and the Gritle Eniformis, to defend the Midriff and the mouth of the Stomach.
3. To make uch a Connexion of the Bones as is termed Sunchondrois.
4. To hape parts prominent or hollow; as appears in the Ears, Larynx and Weand.
5. To fill up hollownees, epecially in the Joynts, as is een in the Knee.
6. To erve for a cover, as in the Epiglottis.
7. To be as an underpropper to utain omwhat, as the Gritles of the Eyelids bear the Hairs.

div.p: Their Situation is various, for Gritles are found in undry parts, in the Eye-lids, Noe, Ear, Larynx, Wezand, Spine, Chet, Ear-lets, of all and every of which in their places.
Their Magnitude alo varies: o alo
Their Figure is divers, as ring-fahion'd, Sheild-hap'd, Sword-like, &c.

As to their Connexion. Some Gritles contitute parts of themelves, as that of the Noe, Xyphoidis, the Coccyx: others grow to bones, which knit them together, either without any other medium, as in the Share and Breatbones, or by common Ligaments coming between, as in the Connexion by Diárthrois.

In Subtance, ome are harder, as thoe which in time become boney; others are ofter, fatning the Joynts, and reembling the Nature in a manner of Ligaments, and are therefore called Chondro-yndumoi, Gritly Ligaments.
Now though their Subtance be hard, yet it is flexible and tough becaue les cold and dry than a bone, and becaue compaed with a notty matter.

And this Subtance of theirs is void of ene; becaue it hath no acquaintance with Nerves nor Membranes. Nor was it requiite that it hould feel, leat in motion when the Gritles rub and trike one againt another, pain hould be caued.
In other things they agree with Bones.

div.head: Chap. III. Of Ligaments in General.
div.p: LIgamentum a Band or Tie, is by the Greeks called Súndemos. The Ancients, as Hippocrates, Aritotle and Galen omwhere, call it Nervum and Nervum colligatum a Nerve, and a twited Nerve or Nerve tied together; becaue in hape and colour it counterfets a Nerve: and otherwie the term Ligament, may in a large ignification be applied to any part, which fatens divers parts together. Alo Galen calls the beginning of a Mucle Ligamentum, part whereof is thought to turn to a Tendon. All thee are improper acceptations. I hall now decipher a Ligament properly o called.
Its Efficient is the Ligament-making Power.
Its Matter is a clammy roaping part of the Seed.
Its Ue is, like a cord to bind together the parts of the body, epecially the Bones, and o to keep them together, in the Head, Chet, Back, and Limbs, that they may not be dilocated or dipointed.

Becaue of its mot trong cleaving thereunto, a Ligagament is aid to arie (though it be indeed made of the Seed) from the Bone primarily, omtimes from a Gritle, gritly bone or Membrane: and its aid to be inerted into a Bone, Gritle, Mucle, or ome part. Or if you would rather have it o; Ligaments grow among the Bones, of in the Bones.
Their Situation. Some are without among the Bones, as the grily Ligaments o called, which are thick and commonly round: others are wound externally about the bones which are thin and membranous.

As to Figure: ome are broader which Anatomits term membranous Ligaments, as hath been aid; others are longer, which are called Nervous Ligaments. And they call them o becaue of their reemblance, not as if a Ligament were truly membranous or nervous. So they are called membranous, which being broad and thin do compas the Joynts, alo which are wrapt about Tendons and Mucles.
Its Subtance is olid, white, bloodles, ofter than a Gritle, harder than Nerves and Membranes: for it is as it were of a middle Nature betwixt a Gritle and a Nerve.

It is without Cavity, Sene or Motion. It was to be without Sene, leat it hould be alwaies pained in Motions; when as the Ligaments are made omtimes longer and horter, that is to ay, are contracted and extended. Some nevertheles wil have membranous Ligaments to feel, but they mut grant it to be o, by means of membranes and not of their own proper ubtance.
For this ubtance of theirs is as Galen tels us diviible into fibres viible to the ight, which experience alo confirms.

Now this Subtance is in ome places ofter and more membranous than in others, as in all Ligaments wel-neer, which go round about the Joynts; and among thee, it is ofter about the Joynt of the Shoulder, than about that of the Hip; and yet ofter where it goes about the interjoyntings of the fingers. But in other places the ubtance is harder and as it were in part gritly, and therefore they are in uch places termed gritly Ligaments; and they are uch as lie concealed among the Bones, as that which goes from the Head of the Thigh, into the Hip-joynt.

div.head: Chap. IV. Of the Skull in General.
div.p: WE divide all the Bones of the SkeletonThe diviion of the Skeleton. into the HEAD, TRUNK, and LIMBS; and them into the Arms & Legs.
The whole tructure of the Bones of the Head is termed CRANIUM the Skul, becaue it is as it were Crános an Helmet; ome term it Calva and Calvaria.
Its Situation and Magnitude follow the Brain and correpond thereunto.
Its Figure is natural or non-natural and depraved.

Its natural figure is round, that it may hold the more, yet a little longih towards the fore and hindparts, where it branches forth, that it may contain the Brain and Brainlet;
on the ides it is flatted, but more towards the foreparts; and therefore the hind-part of the Head is of greater capacity than the forepart: of which Albovinus King of the Longbeards or Lombards made a Drinking Cup for Fetival daies, as Diaconus relates in his Hitory.
The depraved and non-natural Figure thereof is manifold.Depraved hapes of the Head eleven in number.

list.item: 1. When the foremore protuberancie of the Head is wanting; and uch perons are counted foolih and mad, for want of Brain, which ought to be mot plentiful in the forepart of the Head.
2. When the Hinder Protuberancy or bunching forth is wanting.
3. When both are wantings o that the Head is round as a Ball, uch as the Heads of the Turks and Greenlanders are thought to be. And thee three depraved figures Hippocrates doth acknowledg.
4. The fourth Figure Galen adds, which he conceives may be imagined but not really found, when the length is changed into breadth. But Vealius aies he aw uch an one at Venice, and at Bononia.

item.p: 5. The fift way may be added alo out of Hippocrates, an acuminated or oval Figure, when the Head ries up like a Sugar-loaf: which hape in ome Nations Hippocrates tels us had a great reputation of Gentility, and may be formed by Midwives, when they wathe the Childs Head into uch a hape and o preerve it; and at lat Nature transfers uch kind of Heads from Parents to Children. The ame Hippocrates in his Epidemicks, brings in two kinds of thus hap'd Heads, one with the trength of the parts, the other with weaknes of the aid parts. And uch a figure of Heads, is at this day more frequent in ome Countries than in others.
But now I wil add other figures which I have oberved in many Skuls, epecially in Italy.

list.item: 6. When the right ide branches out.Other hapes of the Head oberved by the Author.
7. When the left ide ticks out.
8. When the right part of that bunchines which naturally hould be before is wanting, and the left ticks out very much, in ome more. others les.
9. When the left ide of the aid Protuberancy is wanting, and the right ticks out more than ordinary.
10. When the right part of the Hinder Prominency is away.
11. When the left part of the aid hinder Protuberancy is away.

div.p: And thus I make twelve hapes of the Head in all, one natural and eleven depraved,

The Subtance of the Skul is boney, to ecure the oft Brain. But in Children new born it is ofter then ordinary, and in ome places cartilaginous and membranous, epecially about the Sutures, and mot of all in the middle and upper region of the Head: and all thee for the making the Birth more eaie, that it might give a little way when it is preed. But the Subtance of the Skul is.

list.item: 1. Thick, not thin, that it may more trongly reit external injuries.
2. Rare not compact. 1. Leat it hould weigh too much. 2. That it might contain Juyce for nourihment,
3. That vapors may exhale.

div.p: Now this Subtance of the Skul doth conit as it were of a double boord or plate. It is eldom imple and ingle without a Meditullium or middle matter, as I found it in the Diection of a certain peron, and eldomer hath it three boords, But for the mot part two as hath been aid. ome call them Diploas, the outer whereof being unhurt, the inner may be hurt. And each of thee plates is commonly polihed within and without, mooth and thick. Hence it appears how thick the Skul is, eeing it is every where in a manner double.

I ay in a manner or wel-neer, which others do not oberve: for in ome places the Skul is ingle, thin and tranparent. without any ditance of plates. And therefore ome ChirurgeonsThe Error of Chirurgeons are deceived, who in taking away the firt Plate do think they mut o long cut and prick, til blood comes out. The external Plate is omtimes eaten off by the Venereal Dieae, and omtimes it prouts forth Gums by force of the aid Dieae.

But the rarity or light compoure of the Skul appears from that middle ubtance between each Plate, which they call meditullium. This Subtance, I ay, is rare or light, lax, and receives little Veins: which alo Hippocrates knew, who therefore warns us that the Skul is very eaily inflamed, and therefore when the Trepan is ued, the Iron mut divers times be dipt in Milk and Water.
The Surface of the Skul, is external or internal.
The upper External is mooth and even; the lower or Bais, is rough and uneven, by reaon of undry Appendices and Procees.
The upper Internal is hollow, mooth; ave that it hath the Marks of Veins, and certain Cavities, wherein the dura mater grows: the lower is very uneven by reaon of divers protuberancies.

And every where there are frequent holes in the Skull, very mall and placed without order, through which mall Veins and Arteries pas, to the inner Cavity of the Bones, and the dura Menynx. But omtimes they are not to be found.

At length, that we may come to the parts of the Skull, we mut know that the Skul doth not conit of one only Bone, leat by one wound the whole Skul hould be broken in pieces; but of divers: which are fatned together by the Sutures, of which in the following Chapter.
And ome are Bones of the Skull, others of the Jaw.

The Bones of the Skull in perons grown to ripe years are eight. whereof two are common to the Skul, with the upper Jaw-bone, viz. the cundiforme and the pongioum. But there are ix proper bones, which make up the Skul it elf: One of the Forehead (in new born Children two) two of the Forepart of the Head, one of the Hind-part (in an Infant four) two of the Temples. And there lie hid in the Auditory paages, other ix bones, on each ide three little ones: the Hammer, the Anvil, and the Stirrup, to which a fourth is added called Orbiculare.
And thus there are perpetually in the Skull fourteen or ixteen Bones.
The Ue of the Skul:

list.item: 1. To be the Manion and Bulwork of the Brain, which of it elf is oft.
2. That through it Vapors may pas.

div.p: To the former ue, its thicknes and hardnes is ubervient; to the latter its rarity and Sutures.

On the Skul of a Man omtimes Horns grow, one whiles oft, another while hard like Rams Horns; ometimes fixed to the Skul, otherwhiles to the Skin, and they proceed from a thick, clammy and melancholick humor. There are examples hereof in Paraeus, Thuanus, Hildanus, Renodaeus, Zacutus, Severinus, and others; I alo aw two horns, one at Padua in a Nunn, another at Purmeraem in Holland in an old Woman, which was ufficiently long and hard: I have dicoured of thee Horns in my new Obervations de Unicornu, of the Unicorn.

div.head: Chap. V. Of the Sutures of the Skull.
div.p: A Suture is a ort of connexion reembling the putting together of two Saws, tooth within tooth, or the making up of a Garment of many torn patches.

Such Sutures there are many in a mans Head: for an Head is eldom found without any Suture, uch as Aritotle
aw, and at Helmtadt and theAn Head without Sutures. Monatery of Heilbrun in France uch an one is hewed (as a Rarity) and is every where to be met with.

And uch perons have not their Heads o liable to external injuries, but very much to inward Infirmities, becaue tranpiration is thereby made more difficult. By which ditinction, Falopius and Columbus do reconcile Celus and Robertus Contantinus, the former of whom wrote, that the Head which had no Sutures was mot liable to icknes, the latter that the Head without Sutures was more ubject.

Somtimes through Age and Drines, the Sutures do o grow together in aged perons, that they are carce to be een; whereas they are in the mean eaon, more viible in young perons. Somtimes the coronal uture is only een obliterated; but the temporal do hardly vanih, except all the other be firt defaced.

The Number and Situation of the Sutures, is the ame in a Woman and in a Man, contrary to what Aritotle thought; nor doth it vary in repectThe Error of Aritotle. of figures, as Hippocrates and Galen would have it, unles very rarely. For M. A. Severinus oberved between the aggiteal and Lambdafahion'd uture, another over and above of a triangular hape, and neer the end of the aid Sutures in another Skul, a new oval Suture.

Moreover, the Sutures of the Head of a certain Fool, did vary in figure, which all tuck up with one Hillock as it were. which I aw in three Epileptick Children at Naples, epecially in the coronal Suture, which did ugget a new Caue and Cure of the Epilepie or Falling-icknes.
The Sutures which knit the Bones of the Skul, are ome of them called true and proper, others fale and Batard Sutures.

They are termed true, which meet together like the teeth of Combs, or like Saws, put together, which I have omtimes een after Contuion movable, which alo in mot Skuls that are over dried in the Earth is common. They are alo looe in Children, and therefore they open in Hydrocephalic or Water-headed Children, as I aw in a Boy at Hafnia, like to that which Severinus pictures out in his Treatie of Impothumes, and Donatus decribes.

The batard Sutures are joyned like Scales and Tiles on an houe-top, and therefore they are termed Squamoae conglu • inationes, Scaley-conjunctions, and may rather be termed joynings, eeing they are more like to an Harmonia then a Suture.
There are three true ones.

list.item: 1. Is the foremore, and is called Coronalis. 1. Becaue the Ancients woreThe coronal Suture why o called. Crowns on that part of their Heads.
2. Becaue it hath ome reemblance to a Crown or Circle:

div.p: For from the Temples it acends on both ides, athwart, to the top of the Head. The Arabians call this uture Arcualis and Puppis.

Its Ue is to joyn the Fore-head bone with the bones of the Hinder-head, and to ditinguih them therefrom. The place of the coronal Suture is ound out in a living peron, either by carrying the hand upwards from the Writ along the Noe, or by drawing a Thred out from Ear to Ear, and another cros the ame from the end of the Noe.

2. That which is oppoite to this, is behind and in the Occiput or Hinder-head. 'Tis called Lamdoeidès the Lamda-hap'd, from the Greek letter A. ome call it hupiloïdes from the letter upilon, alo prorae utura.

This acends obliquely, from the Bae of the Hinderhead, to each Ear, grows into an Angle. Somtimes when the Hinder-head is large or otherwie, 'tis divided by a tranvere uture, imple, or double: omtimes there is a double triple Suture as if a greater triangle did contain one or two leer Triangles within the ame: where the Bones o comprehended,The triangular Bones of the Skul. are termed oicula triangularia, the little three-cornerd bones, commended, in the Falling-icknes.

Beides thee triangular bones, Olaus Worm a rare man, found others in the Lambda-like Suture, which perforated both the Boards of the Skull, oberved as yet by very ew. Three for the mot part on the right, as many on the left ide, differing in magnitude, figure and ituation, which alo are accurately dicerned and ditinguihed in Infants. The lowet is een at the Proceus mammillares, the middlemot a little higher, carce half a Fingers breadth, the third a little further ditinct from the econd. Pavius found only two like to thee, circumcribed with their little Sutures or eams, which he doubts whether he hould refer them to the Bones of the Occiput or the Bregma.

In Shape they are Various, Triangular, Oblong, Oval. omtimes in living perons I have oberved them to grow o high, that I could Feel them with my Fingers, as if they had been Epiphyis or omewhat growing upon the Bone.
All are larger on the left ide. but the greatet exceeds not the Nail of a Mans thumb.
They appear more ditinct on the inner & Concave ide of the Skul, than in the outward and convex, and therefore they are all more cleerly dicern'd when the Skul is taken away,

We are nevertheles to oberve that thee bones of Worm do in divers Skuls vary, both in Number, Magnitude, Figure, Situation; o that omtimes there are four, omtimes two, and in a Right line only, omtimes in the very Juncture of the Sagittal with the Lambda-hap'd; ometimes alo in the Scaley temporal Sutures.
Their Ue, I believe, is 1. That the Sutures being inlarged thereabouts, might afford a more free paage for Excrements.
2. That the Skul being made up of more bones, might be more afe in Blows and Contuions.
The Ue of this Lambda-like Suture, is to ditinguih the bone of the Occiput or Hinder-head, from the bones of the Temples, and the forepart of the Head.
3. In the middle betwixt thee two is the Suture ter • red Sagittalis or Arrow-hap'd, becaue it runs in a treight line all along the Head, like an Arrow, betwixt the Coronal and Lambda-hap'd Sutures.

Somtimes it proceeds through the middle of the Coronal Suture and the middet of the Fore-head, as far as to the Noe, epecially in Infants: in ome alo it cuts part of the Bone of the Occiput or Hinder-head. I remember it hath been omtimes wanting.
This Suture is termed Virgata and Recta.
Its Ue is to ditinguih and joyn together the two bones of the Sinciput or Fore-part of the Head.

Thoe two Suture are commonly calledWhy ome Sutures are like Scales. Nendoae or Batard utures, which are wont to be called Squamoae Scalie, Corticales and Temporales, becaue they circumcribe the Bones of the Temples. Now this Connexion like Scales was neceary, becaue the Temple-bones, being in the lower part very thick would have been to heavy, if they had not been made by little and little thinner in their upper part, and joyned to the bones of the Sinciput atenuated by little and little like Scales.
Now there are many purious SuturesA great number of Sutures. every where in the Skul, alo many harmonies, where the bones are joyned together: in the Palate bone a peculiar Suture is een.
The Ue of the Sutures.

1. They erve for the free tranpiration of fuliginous vapors. And therefore Hippocrates pronounces, that they have oundet Heads, who have mot Sutures: and thoe that have their Heads without Sutures, are troubled with

page 341 an inveterate Head-ach. And Galen aw o great an Inflammation caued by over trait binding of the Head, whereby the Sutures were hut up, and the Excrements kept in, that the Patients Eyes came out of their holes.

list.item: II. That by them the Dura mater may be tied and held up, leat it hould queez the inner parts of the Brain.
III. That the aid dura mater might by them end out fibres to contitute the Pericraneum and the Perioteum.

IV. That Veels may go in and out, to nourih and in
• iven the parts; which Veels are by Fallopius cal'd Venae puppis.

V. That one Bone being broken the others might remain whole. And therfore Galen, Paulus, Guido and Fallopius, denie that there can be any contra • iure or Countercleft, ave in a olid Head without Sutures: Hippocrates writes the Contrary, and cals it a Misfortune, as alo Celus and others, and Fallopius himelf, Paraeus and Pavius relate examples, and before them Soranus, taking a imilitude from a Glas Bottle, which oftentimes, being truck on the one ide, is crakt on the oppoite part.
VI. That Topical Medicines being outwardly applied, may more eaily penetrate.

div.head: Chap. 6. Of the proper Bones of the Skull in particular.
div.p: THe firt Bone is the OS FRONTIS, the Forehead bone, which ome call Coronale, Inverecundum, Os puppis: which hath
A Figure imperfectly circular; more perfect where it is circumcribed with the Coronal Suture, more imperfect neer the Eyes.
Its Subtance is thinner than that of the Os occipitis or Hinder-head bone, and thicker than the Oa incipitis, or bones of the foremore part of the Head.
It is twofold in Children new-born, ditinguihed by the agittal Suture: alo framed of a twofold Plate, an external and internal.

At the top of the Noe above the Eyebrows, there are large Cavities commonlySee Tab. 4. Fig. 1. two in number, between the two plates, omtimes cloathed with a green Membrane and eparated, containing a certain oft and marrowih body. But thee Cavities are not 1. In Children til they are a year old. 2. In uch as have a flat and Saddle-face. 3. In uch whoe Fore-head is divided.
The aid Cavities have holes which end into the wide paces of the Notrils: and another which ends into the Skul, above the Septum of the Os pongioum to ditinguih the Organs of Smelling.

list.item: 1. To make the Voyce Melod •••• and Sounding; becaue they are not in uch who have a bad Speech.
2. Some conceive they erve for the Air to be elaborated in, to generate animal pirits.

3. That they may contain the Air which is drawn into the Notrils and brings the mels of things along with it, from whence it paes leiurely to the Organs of Smelling, and to the Brain to alter the • ame, and reduce it to its natural State, when it is diordered. And therefore it is that many times an whole day together a mel is perceived in the top of the Notrils.
4. Others uppoe, they erve to collect Excrements, not only thick but watry, which being carried to the Glandula lachrymalis, do make Tears.
5. ome conceive that the marrowy matter therein contained, doth pas through the hole of the greater Corner of the Eye, and moiten the Eye make it glib and lippery, that it may move the Eaier.

div.p: This Bone hath Procees: one at the greater Corner of the Eye, another at the leer, to contitute the upper pare of the Eye-hole or Socket. There are alo two cornerd Eminencies or riings on each ide o • e, towards the Temples, which are termed Horns; by Albucais, Dionyici the Author of the Definitions and Heliodorus the Phyitian; and if that boney Tumor be only on one ide Ingrasias calls it Dionyicus.

It hath three holes; one more inward of which before, which ends into the Skul: two outward, at the middle of the Eye-brows, for the thorough-fare, of the Nerves of the third Conjugation to the Forehead.

The Second and Third are the two Bones of the Sincipu •
or Vertex, which ome call Parietalia, others Arcualia, Nervalia, Rationis or Cogitationis, of reaon or thought: the Greeks Brég • a • os o •• â, becaue the mot moit and ofe Brain, is placed under them.
In Shape they are four quare and unequal.

Their Subtance is more rare and infirmWhy the wounds of the Sinciput are deadly. then of other Bones, becaue the Head in this part, wants very much evaporation: and therefore the Wounds of the Sinciput are deadly.

div.p:
In Infants, that part which is at the Conjunction of the coronal and Sagittal Sutures is found Membranous, and oft, and among all the Bones of the Head, it lat receives a boney hardnes, then when the Child begins to peak ditinctly and intelligibly while it remains Membranous and oft, it is not o thick as afterwards, but tranparent. Hence in Children there is oberved in that place a Gap or Chink, which ome term Fontanella and
• ons pulatilis; where alo they are wont to make Iues in deparate Catarrhs. I have once oberved this part in a peron grown up, to have been not yet boney, but membranous as in Children, viz. in a man of years of Age. <…> Woman of twenty ix years old, found it re •… open.

There are within uperficial Cavities, being the in •…
ions of Veins, and without certain mall holes.

The fourth Bone of the Occiput which ome call <…>
Os prorae, Os memorioe, Os pixidis, the G •… doth contitute almot the whole hinde •… part of the Skul.

Which in grown perons is commonly b •…
double or treble; in Children it con •… part of four eldom of five bones
Its Figure is of a Sphaetical triangle

Its Subtance is the thicket and mot compact of all the ret (becaue there the noble Ventricle is eated, and there the Nerves arie as from a Fountain) epecially at the Bais of the Skul, ave at the ides of the great hole, where it is mot thin (and therefore in this repect Aritotle did well ay, that this was the thinnet Bone of all, which Columbus taxes) and therefore for afeties ake, there is in the middle thereof a long Prominency.

It hath five holes, one which is the greatet neer the firt Vertebra, through which the Medulla oblongata paeth forth; the ret are leer erving for the going out of Nerves and the entrance of Veins and Arteries.
It hath nine Cavities, even within and two without.

It hath before two broad Procees at the Bais (in Children they are Epiphyes) covered with a Gritle, within more eminent, inerted into the Cavities of the firt Vertebra, for the motion of the Head. There is another mall Proces behind, joyned to the firt Vertebra.

In the Hinder-head of Dogs, there is another mall bone between the BrainThe triangular bone in Dogs. and the Brainlet, which is triangular: that it may as a Prop utain their going with their heads downwards.
The fift and ixt, are the Temple Bones, by the Ears; ome call them Lapido • , Petroa, Sa • ea, Squamiformia Mendofa, and others Parietalia and Aercualia.

Their Shape is uneven (but rather circular than three quare) becaue of their manifold Subtance, which is like Rocks and craggy Clifts; for which caue they are alo called Oa petroa the rocky bones. But in their upper part they are attenuated, o as to be tranparent, where they lie under the temporal Mucles, and are joyned to the bones of the Sinciput, like Scales.
They have ix holes without, two within the firt external hole is large, viz. The Auditory paage; the ret are mall, for Veels to pas thorough.
They have two Cavities. The outer is covered with a Gritle, and receives the lower Jaw-bone. The inner is longih, common to the Os occipitis.

div.p: It hath a certain Appendix, harp, long and mall, and therefore called Styloi¯des, Belenoïnes, Graphioïdes, Plectrum, &c. It is oon broke off, and therefore it is not in all Skuls, epecially uch as are dug out of the ground. In grown perons 'tis hony, in Infants Gritly. It is a little crooked, like a Cocks Spur.
It hath three Procees.

list.item: 1. Is external and obtue, thick, hort and cavernous, id et, having holes like a Spunge in it; its cal'd from its hape, Mammillaris, Dug like.
2. Is External alo, and a portion of Os jugale.

For the Os jugale or Lygomatis, eated under the Eye, is not a peculiar bone, but is made up of the Procees of two bones; the one is that newly mentioned, the other is that of the Jaw, joyned by an oblique Suture, making as it were a Bridg: whoe ue is to defend the Tendon of the temporal Mucle, the Skul being otherwie but thin in that place.

3. Is Internal with a long protuberancy, wherein there is a threefold Cavity: the Drum, the Labyrinth, the Cochlea, alo the bones which erve the Hearing. But if the outer paage before the Membrane of the Tympanum be reckoned, there wil be four Cavities of the Auditory paage. The Ancients makes mention but of one Cavern.

div.p: I. The firt Cavity, which is the Tympanum or Concha, or as ome call it Pelvis, The Cavities in the Oa petroa. and by Aritotle termed Cochlea, is ituate preently after the little Membrane of the Tympanum (about which goes a boney circle, eaily eparable in Infants, in elderly perons hardly) wherein is the Congenit or inbred Air, alo four little bones, a Ligament and Mucles, little Windows and a water-paage; and from this Cavity a Channel goes into the palate of the Mouth. It doth not tranmit the Congenit Air, which Nature tudies to retain.

The Fenetrae or Windows, are two little holes in this Cavity: the one oval, is in the middle of the Cavity, more towards the fore-part, and higher, upon which the Bais of the Stapes or Sti • rups rets, and in a great meaure huts the ame: in the hinder part, it opens it elf into the Cochlea with a large overture, and joyns it elf alo to the hinder hole which is lower in mankind, leer and narrower? and this is divided into two channels, divided by a very thin bony Scale: with the one it goes, together with the oval window unto the Cochlea, with the other to the Labyrinth; and the hindermore channel is called Aquae-ductus, alo Meatus cochlearis, Tortuous, Caecus, Capreolaris, by reaon of the crooked winding paage, through which the greater part of the Auditory Nerve is carried with the Artery.

II. The econd being round and les than the former, is called Cabyrinthus and fodina the Maze and Mettal-mine or Cole-mine, becaue of its crooked manyfold turnings: behind the Fenetra ovals, it joyns it elf to the following Cavity. From this, many waies run out which they call Semicirculos oe • s excavatos, hollowed boney Half-circles, or funiculos little Ropes, three for the mot part, large at the beginning, and then by little and little growing narrower, cloathed with a little thin Membrane, that the ounds may become more acute, and being by little and little broken may o acend unto the Brain. It hath four holes beides the oval, and a fift which is terminated into the Cochlea.

III. The third is termed Cochlea becaue of its wreathed turning, others call it Cavitas cochleata, Buccinata, An
• rum buccinoum, &c. for it hath three or four windings (thoe who are thick of Hearing have only one or two) mutually receiving one another, and is cloathed with a very exceeding thin and mot oft Membrane, and is adorned with infinite little Veins, which being twined about the wreathings of the Cochlea, doth by many branches creep into the ecret turnings of the Labyrinth.

div.head: Chap. 7. Of the Bones which erve the Sene of Hearing.
div.p: THere follow eight other Bones of the Head, which are leat of all, on each ide four, being the Bones ubervient to the ene of Hearing, called from their hapes, Malleus the Mallet or Hammer, Incus the Anvil, Stapes the Stirrup, and the Orbicular bone: all which were unknown to the Ancients. The two firt were found out by Jacobus Carpus, who was afterwards followed by Maa, Jacobus Sylvius, and Vealius: and he being admonihed by Fallopius, at lat made mention of the third, whoe firt finder out was Ingrasias; although Eutachius and Columbus do arrogate the Invention hereof unto themelves.

The fourth Auditory Bone, was found out and hewed to me by Francicus Sylvius, being round and mall, and by N. Fontanus likened to the Scale of a Pike: annexed by a mall Ligament to the Stirrup ide, where it is joyned to the Anvil; which you hall more eaily find in the boyled Calves Heads, in which they are bigger than in the Heads of Men: howbeit in a Man it is viible enough. Pavius found in the Head of an Ox a year old, one like this, of a eamoidean hape.
They are ituate in the firt Cavity or Concha.

They have a Subtance hard and dene, hollow within, that they might be lighter, and might contain in them, Marrow for their nourihment, without any Perioteum about them: alo that they might make the Ai • drie • , and carry it along, like thoe Ropes which are fatened to doors to make them open and hut again of themelves. They are as perfect in new-born Children as in thoe that are grown up; though not o hard, but more moit, for which caue Infants are dull of Hearing.

The Connexion. The Hammer by its proces ticks fat to the Membrane of the Drum, beyond the middle, like a tail turned back; the head whereof is articulated into the Cavity of of the Anvil, having a mall Proces, that the Tendon of the Muculus rotundus may be applied thereto; it hath alo a longer Proces, but maller, firt oberved by Caecilius Folius, to which another Mucle is fatened, which belongs to the external Ear. It rets athwart upon the bony circle, with which perhaps it grows together in perons that are of years, for commonly in Children it is only viible, in others it is eaily broken becaue of its finenes, when the bones are taken out.

The Anvil reembling a grinding Tooth, lies under the Hammer, having beneath two procees; the one horter reting upon the Os quamoum, the other longer, utaining the top of the Stirup or triangular bone, which rets upon the Cochlea, till it is unk into the broad Bais of the Fenetra ovalis, or oval window, to which it is fatned by a looe Ligament, o that it may be lightly raied, but not moved upwards and downwards.
Thee three little bones, are joyned with a very fine Ligament, which is tretched over the whole Membrane, as the trings over the bottom of a Drum.

The Ue of thee little bones is not to make a ound, but that the pecies of ound being received, may pas to the lower parts, and that there may be a paage for the excrements of the Ears. For the Stirrup hutting the oval or upper window, is moved by the Anvil (whereupon the window is opened, that the pecies or repreentation of Sounds may pas into the Nerve, and the Anvil being mitten by the Hammer, and the Hammer by the Membrane of the Drum, through the impule of the external Air (which the Hammer hinders from being driven too far forwards) which while it is in doing, the membrane of the Drum is droven inwards and becomes bunching out, whereby the inbred Air is affected, which wandring through the Cochlea caues, that the branches of the Auditory
Nerve, do receive the pecies of ounds, brought in by the windows, and communicate the ame to the Brain. And thus the Hammer is moved only inwards. But in the recoure, it is moved outwards, with the Membrane of the Drum, by that very little Mucle found out by Caerius.

div.head: Chap. VIII. Of the Bones common to the Head and upper Jaw, viz. Os cuneiforme and Os pongioum.
div.p: THe Os Sphaenoides or Cuneiforme, or Wedg-fahion'd Bone, o called becaue as they ay, it hath the hape of a Wedg; was by the Ancients called Polumorphos or many-form'd, by reaon of undry procees within and without whereby it is made rugged and uneven: others call it Os Paxillare, Os Colatorij, Os Palati, &c.
'Tis eated in the middle of the Bais of the Head, and is placed under the Brain as a foundation, o that it touches well-neer all the Bones of the Head and upper Jaw.
It is one Bone in grown perons: but it is at firt made of four which are afterwards united.
The Procees are undry.

Outwardly there are two remarkable ones, at the ides of the palate, cal'd Pterigoeides, aliformes, Wing-fahion'd, becaue they reemble the wings of Batts or Flittermice, and are furnihed with a longih Cavity.

Inwardly there are four little ones, on each ide two, having the hape of a Turkih Saddle. and therefore this proces is termed Sella Sphaenoidis, the addle of Os Sphaenoïdes; in which proces being quare and broad, there is a Cavity to hold the Glandula pituitaria.

At the Saddle, there is a Cave full of little holes, that the inbreathed Air, may be elaborated to make Spirits, and that flegmatick excrements, may ditill through the funnel, out of the Ventricles of the Brain.
It hath undry holes for the paage of the Veels this way and that.

OS SPONGOIDES, pongioum or Spongiforme, the pungelike bone, being eated in the middle bais of the Forehead, and filling the Cavity of the Notrils, is alo called ethmoeïdes, Cribriforme or Cribroum, the Seive-fahion'd bone: becaue

Its inner ide, where it joyns to the Head, is pierced through with many holes like a Sieve, winding and turning, but not treight; and this part properly is, and ought to be called Cribro • , Sieve-fahion'd.

It hath in its middle a harp Proces, reembling a Cocks comb, by which as a Partition this bone is divided into two parts: And to this upper proces another is oppoed below, ditinguihing the Notrils, where the outer part of this bone is, which is contained in the Cavity of the Notrils without the Skul, being light and pungie, and therefore there properly o called.
It hath alo another part thin, olid and mooth, where it is joyned to the ocket of the Eye, a mall portion whereof it contitutes, but it is not a part of the upper Jaw-bone, as Vealius would have it.
The Ue of the pongie part is, to alter the Air drawn in with Smels.
The chief Ue of the Sieve-fahion'd part is,

list.item: 1. To admit the Air for Animal pirits.

2. That the Species of odours may with the Air be carried to the mammillary procees, the Organs of melling, which end into thee holes. And therefore in the Dieae Co • yza, this bone being obtructed, the melling is lot.

div.p: A econdary ue, is the purging of the Brain for flegm is not only voided by the Glandul • pituitaria into the Palate, but it drops down alo into the Os cribroum and the Notrils, if the upper Ventricles of the Brain o called, do abound with too much Flegm. Howbeit, this Flux is preternatural.

div.head: Chap. IX. Of the Bones of the Jaw in General.
div.p: THe Jaw-Bones are the foundations of the whole Face, the upper above the mouth the lower beneath.

For the upper, which Celus calls Mala, is the boney part of the Face, comprehending the lower and lateral parts of the Eye-ocket, the Notrils, the Cheeks, the Palate, and the whole row of the upper Teeth.

And this Jaw-bone in Mankind, is horter and rounder than in Brutes, for Beauties ake, alo it is immoveable as it is in Beats, aving the Parrot, the Phaenicopterus, and the Crocodile as wel that which lives in the water, as the Land-Crocodile; yet do they not move the upper Jaw only, but their whole Head withall being traitly faten'd thereto, as Vipers do, and the like is to be aid of the Parrot.

But the lower Jaw-bone in Mankind and other Creatures, is only movable, ave in the Crocodile, which hath it o united to the Bones of the Temples, that it can no waies be tirred; but the Parrot moves both.

The Connexion is without motion in the upper Jaw, by a Suture or Harmonie whereby it is joyned with many bones of its own, of which it is compoed, and other bones placed round about; in the lower by way of Sunchondrois, which is in the middle of the Chin. But in grown perons, the Gritle is o turned into a Bone, that the lower Jaw eems to be one only bone, whereas before it conited of two.

In the Brim or Circuit of each Jaw-bone, which place Galen calls Ph •••• an, we meet with Cavities, wherein the Teeth are faten'd, which Galen terms Bóthria, the Latines Alveolos, Loculos, Foulas, Praeepiola, Mortariola.

Thee holes according to the nature of the teeth in them, are omtimes ingle, otherwhiles threfold: omtimes they are obliterated and hut up, the Teeth being fallen or pluckt out. Somtimes they breed anew, by freh Teeth breaking out. In old Age, frequently thee holes are obliterated, the Teeth being lot, and the Gums become harper and harder, o that old folks chew their meat with them intead of Teeth.

div.head: Chap. X. Of the Bones proper to the upper Jaw.
div.p: THe Bones proper to the upper Jaw, are eleven on each ide five, and one without a fellow.
The firt being in a manner triangular, doth make up the lower part of the ocket of the Eye, the leer Eye-corner and part of the Os jugale and of the Cheek-bone.
The econd makes the greater Eye-corner where there is an hole which paes into the Notrils, by which a Caruncle is placed.
Here thoe Impothumes are made which they call aegilopas, which if they be unskilfully or negligently handled, they pierce to the Bone, and caue the Fitula Lachrymalis.
This is a little Bone, and the leat among the upper Jaw-bones, Thin, Tranparent, Looly, Adhereing, o that it is eaily broken and lot: and therefore 'tis eldom found in Skuls dug out of the Earth.

The third is a very great one, by which are contituted the large region of the Palate, and the great lower ocket
containing the Teeth. It hath large Cavities (and holes through which veels pas) on both ides remarkable, both for to make it lighter, and that it might contain Marrow to nourih the Bones and the upper Teeth. Others ay to help to frame the Voyce. In Children they are not hollowed til after ome years, and they are then cover'd with a very thin Membrane.
The fourth with its companion, doth contitute the upper and more eminent boney part of the Noe.
It is thin, hard, olid and quadrangular.
And thee two external bones of the Noe are divided with a Suture. Within they are rough, that the Gritles of the Noe, may be the better fatened.
There is another inner bone (which is the third of the Noe) cleaving to the proces of the Os pongioum, which is called Septum narium becaue it ditinguihes the Notrils.

The fift is eated at the end of the Palate, where the holes of the Notrils go into the Throat or Fauces. They
