are ditinguihed one from another by the middle Suture of the Palate, and make the hinder part of the Cavity of the Palate and Notrils, they are thin, olid and broad.
To thee ten Columbus ads the eleventh, like a Plough, the inmot and middlemot above the Palate, hutting the lower part of the Notrils, like a partition wall.

div.head: Chap. XI. Of the lower Jaw-bone.
div.p: THe lower Jaw-bone in grown perons, conits of one Bone only, in Children till even year old of two, which are joyned together by way of Sunchondrois.
Its Figure is that of the Greek letter u or like a Bow.
Its Subtance is exceeding hard and trong, that it may hold out in biting and chewing; within hollow, where Marrow is contained to nourih it and the teeth.
It hath two Holes on each ide, which go quite through the Jaw-bone like a Pipe, o that a britle put in at one hole will come out of the other.
The one is more inward, hindermore and greater, receiving in a part of thoe Nerves which we reckon to be the fift pare, to the Roots of the teeth, with a little Vein and Artery.
The other is more outward, les round, by which a Branch of the foreaid Nerve received in, is ent out to the lower Lip.
It hath undry Aperities and Cavities for the Riings and Inertions of Mucles.
Alo on each ide two Procees called Horns, carried upwards.

One goes out forwards broad and thin, whoe point or harp end is called Corone, into which the Tendon of the Temporal Mucle is implanted. And therefore Hippocrates counts the Luxation of the lower Jaw-bone deadly.
The other hindermore, is carried backwards; repreenting a little bunch and is called condulodes, having a little Head coverd with a gritly crut, under which there is a longih Neck.

By this Proces the Articulation is made with the Temple bones, where yet another Gritle is placed between the Cavity and the gritly head, to facilitate the motion. Alo a common membranous Ligament doth cover this Articulation.

div.head: Chap. XII. Of the Teeth in General.
div.p: THe Teeth are called DENTES as if you would ay Edentes, Eaters, and by the Greeks odontes as it were edôuntes Eaters; and they are Bones properly o called, hard and olid, mooth and white, like other Bones.
They have ome things peculiar which other bones have not, which neverthelesHow the Teeth do differ from other Bones. doth not exclude them from the number of Bones.

list.item: 1. They are harder than other Bones, that they may bite and chew hard things; and they are little les harder tha Stones, nor can they eaily be burnt in the Fire, and whereas in the Sarcophagus or Fleheating Stone, the whole body is conumed in forty daies, the Teeth remain unimpaired and therefore Tertullian writes that in them is the Seed of our future Reurrection.
2. The Teeth are naked without any Perioteum, leat they hould pain us when we chew.

3. Yet they have a Sene, but more of the firt than of the econd Qualities, and epecially rather of what is cold than what is hot contrary to the Nature of fleh, according to Hippocrates. and hence they are o an • to be et on edg.

But the whole Tooth doth not feel of it elf, but the inner, ofter and moreWhich part of the Tooth feels. marrowy part; which is covered over with an hard external part, which is not pained, neither by Fire, nor Iron, as in a Sword under the mot hard rind of the Steel, an Irony marrow les hard lies within, and the Skin through the enles Skar-skin doth feel, o the inner part of the Tooth feels through the outmot, into which inner part being hollow, little oft Nerves enter and little cloathing Membranes. Hereupon a certain Nun at Padua cauing a very long Tooth hee had above all the ret to be cut off to avoid the Deformity thereof, hee preently fell down into a Convulion and Epileptick fit. Now in the part of her Tooth which was cut off, there appeared the tokens of a Nerve.
4. Hence, they receive Nerves into their Cavity which other bones do not.

5. They grow longer than any other of the Bones, almot all a mans life, becaue they are dayly worn, by biting and grinding; asGutta cavat lapidem non vi ed aepe cadendo.
The hardet Stone a dropping Houe-Eve hollows,
Caue drop upon drop, drop after drop till follows,
But not by force.

div.p: And look how much they wear away, o much are they till augmented which hence appears; in that if any Tooth fall out and grow not again, the oppoite Tooth grows o much the longer, as the empty pace of the former Tooth comes to.
Fallopius conidering the praemies, and how new Teeth are thought to breed, he collects that the formative faculty remains alive in the Teeth to extream old age.

Helmont counts the matter of the Bone not to be meerly boney, but as it were of a middle nature betwixt Bone and Stone; becaue the Teeth turn to Stone whatever kind of food ticks long to them, be it Bread, Fleh, Herbs, Fih, Apples, Beans, or Peae, &c. But there is no petrification or turning to Stone, unles the things eaten be of a tartareous Nature, but only a drying, the moiture being conumed by the Spittle; nor are the Teeth made bigger by that addition, which omtimes is craped off, omtimes turne to clammy filth.

The Teeth are bred in the Womb, afterThe Teeth are bred in the Womb. the Generation of the Jaw-bones, twelve in each Jaw, or a few more, as I hall peak hereafter touching their number, four Cutters, two Dog-teeth, ix Grinders: which lie omwhat imperfect and concealed within the Jaws (for it is rare for an Infant to be born toothed) leat the child as it ucks hould hurt the Nipple. And therefore in an Abortion, or a young Infant, mall teeth may be pulled out

They break out of the Gums ooner in Brutes (though Varro be otherwie minded as touching Hores) becaue they are ooner capable of olid meat; in mankind at the eventh month or later, after the Child is a year old: and the upper ooner than the lower, yet in ome the lowet firt, and among the ret,
The fore-teeth in the firt place, becaue

list.item: 1. They are mot harp.
2. They are les then the ret.
3. Becaue the Jaw-bone is there thinnet.
4. Becaue there is mot need of them both to peak with and to cut and bite the meat.

div.p: And at that time when the TeethWhy Children are ick of Teeth-breeding. of Infants hoot forth, Hippocrates tels us that Feavers, Convulions, Fluxes of the Belly arie, epecially when the Dog-teeeth come forth: becaue when the Teeth make their way through the Gums, they torment more than pricks in the Fleh.
Thee Teeth have a Subtance boney, hard, and hollow where they break out, but in their hinder part they have a oft ubtance, covered with a thin and tranparent Membrane.

And about the eventh and fourteenth yeer, other Teeth are wont to break out (theWhy and when young ones looe their Teeth. former falling away) in both the Jaws ten, four Cutters, two Dog-teeth, and four Grinders. And the former fall out in the fourth, fift, and ixt year. becaue the holes grow wider, and therefore the Teeth being at that time oft, do grow looe and fall out. Nicephorus in his Interpretation of Dreams aies, that for a man to dream he looes a Tooth another comes in the Rome, betokens gain and unexpected Joy. If their Teeth do not hed, the latter Teeth come out at new holes, the upper commonly on the outide, the lower on the inide, as there were new ranks of Teeth. More frequently they pring out on the ides and augment the number.

But thee Teeth are not bred anew without the Womb: for then likewieWhether new Teeth are bred out of the womb? Membranes, Nerves, Veels and Ligaments might be bred anew: but the eeds of them lie within the Jaws. For Eutachius and Riolanus have oberved ome maller Teeth at the back of the ret which fall out, a very thin partition being removed which is found between the two orts of Teeth. But a rare cae it is for Teeth to breed again, after many years and in old age. As Thuanus relates of a man that was an hundred yeer old: in our Fionia a man of an hundred and forty years of age, had new Teeth. Helmont aw an old Man and Woman of ixty three yeers of age, whoe Teeth grew again with uch pains as Children have when breed they teeth, which was no token of their long living, for both of them died that yeer. Sir Francis Bacon hath the like Example touching an old Man.
But now let us peak of the Teeth in grown perons.

The Teeth are eated in the Compas of the two Jawbones, in Mankind, hut up within his mouth; in a Boar they tick out, as alo in the Whale-fih cal'd Narhual in our Greenland; which ends out an exceeding long wreathed Tooth, • ut of the left ide of his upper Jaw, which is commonly taken for the Unicorns horn, and is yet of great value among Noble Men and Princes.
In Magnitude they come hort of the Teeth of other Animals, becaue of the mallnes of Mans mouth. And in Mankind ome have greater, others les.

They vary in Figure. In Man they are of a threefold figure: Cutters, Dog-teeth, and Grinders, as hall be aid in the following Chapter; ave that Fontanus oberved in a certain Man, that they were all Grinders which he had. In Creatures that chew the Cud they are double; Cutters and Grinders. In Fihes they are in a manner all perfectly harp, excepting one kind of Whale, which the Ilanders call Springwall, whoe teeth are blunt, but broad.
The Surface is mooth and even.
The Colour white, and hining, unles negligence, Age, or icknes hinder.

The Number is not the ame in all Men, for to let pas rarities, viz. that ome men are born with one continued tooth in their upper Jaw-bone (which they relate of Pyrrhus, and a certain Groenlander brought hither in the Kings Ships) alo of a double and tripple row of teeth, uch as I have een in ome Fihes, and uch as Lewis the thirteenth King of France had, and which Solinus writes of Mantichora, and is known of the Lamia, which hath five ranks, trangely ordered, and among them exceeding harp teeth, reembling the tones called Gloopetrae, and therefore Columna took the teeth of a Lamian turned to tone, to be the Gloopetrae or precious Stones of Malta o called, of which I have poke elwhere. In a Sea-wolf, I have oberved a double rank, the former of harp teeth, the inner of grinders, cloe joyned together, which poes the lower part of the Palate. A man hath ordinarily but one rank in each Jaw-bone, and twenty eight in all, omtimes thirty, in the upper Jaw ixteen, in the lower fourteen; but for the mot part thirty two, ixteen in each Jaw.

But this number is eldom changed, ave in the grinders, which omtimes are on each ide five, omtimes our; otherwhiles five above, four beneath, or five on the right, and four on the left ide, or contrarily.

A great number of teeth argues lengthMany teeth argue long life. of life, few teeth a hort life, according to Galen and Hippocrates. And rightly. For the rarity and fewnes of teeth is bad as a Sign and a Caue: for it argues want of matter, and the weaknes of the formative faculty. As a Caue: becaue few teeth cannot well prepare the meat, and o the firt digetion is hurt, and conequently the econd. But we mut undertand that this prediction holds for the mot part, but not alwaies, as Scaliger well diputes againt Cardan in his 271. Exercitation. For Augutus who lived eventy ix years, is aid to have had thin, few, and calie teeth; and o likewie Foretus who lived above eighty years.

Their Connexion is by way of Gomphois, for they eem to be fixed in their holes as nails in a pot. Alo they are tied by trong Bands unto their nets, which bands tick to their roots; and then the Gums compas them, of which before.

The outer Subtance is more olid and hard, not feeling; the inner is a little more oft, endued with ene, by reaon of the neighborhood of a Nerve and Membrane, and hath in it a Cavity, larger in Children then Elder perons, and compaed about till they be even years old, with a thin Scale like the Combs of Bees, and full of notty matter; in grown perons the humor being dried up, it is diminihed.

This Cavity is cloathed with a little Membrane The Dieaes and Pains of the Teeth, how caued? of exquiite Sene, which if it imbibes ome Humor flowing from the Brain, extream Tooth-ach follows. In this begin Eroions, Putrefactions, and mot painful Rottennes; and herein omtimes grow the mallet ort of worms, which exceedingly torment men.
Veels are carried to this Cavity, by the holes of the Roots of the Teeth.

As Veins to carry back the blood after nutrition and continual augmentation. Which are not een o apparently in Mankind (as neither the Veins of the adnata tunica of the Eyes) but they are manifetly een in Oxen, and are gathered from the prinkling of blood in the Cavity.

Little Arteries to afford Natural Heat and Blood for Nutrition and Alteration. And therefore upon an Inflamation, a pulative pain of the teeth is omtimes caued which Galen experimented in himelf. Hence much lightful, hineing blood, comes omtimes from a tooth that has an hole made in it, and omtimes o as to caue death.

Little Nerves tender and fine, are carried to them from the firt pare, according as we reckon, which go through the Roots into the Cavity, where they are pred abroad within, and by mall twigs mingled with a certain mucilaginous Subtance ound in the middle of the teeth.
The Ue of the Teeth

list.item: In the firt and chiefet place, is to chew and grinde the meat. And therefore uch as have lot their teeth are fain to content themelves with uppings; and therefore Nicephorus reckons that it is bad to dream of a mans teeth falling out, and aies it ignifies the los of a Friend.

2. They erve to form the voice (and therefore Children do not peak, till their mouths are full of teeth) epecially the fore teeth which help the framing of ome certain Letters. Hence thoe that have lot their teeth, cannot pronounce ome Letters, as for Example T. and R. in the peaking whereof, the tongueSpeech him. being widened, • ought to ret upon the foreteeth. Alo the los of the grinders hurts the Explication or plain Expreion of the Words, according to Galen,
o that the Speech becomes lower, and les clear and eaie. Let therefore uch as have lot their teeth, procure artificial ones to be et in, and with a golden wire to be firmly fatned.
3. For Ornament. For uch as want their teeth are thereby deformed.
4. Homer conceives the teeth are an edg to the tongue and Speech, to keep in a mans words, and prevent prating.
5. In Brutes they erve to fight withal, in which cae a man ues his hands.

6. In the aid Brutes, alo to hew their Age. For the Age of an Hore is known, by looking into his Mouth, where before he is four years old that tooth to be een which they term Gnomon, when he is four year old, there is another tooth een with an hole in it that will hold a Peae, which every year grows les and les, till at eight years the tooth is filled up, becomes mooth, and no hole to be een therein.

div.head: Chap. XIII. Of the Teeth in Particular.
div.p: IN repect of their threefold Shape, their Situation, and Office, there are in Mankind three ort of Teeth: The Fore-teeth, the Dog-teeth, and the Grinders.
The Fore-teeth, from their Office which is to cut the meat, are termed Inciores and Inciorij Cutters, alo Geláinoi the laughing teeth, becaue in laughing they are firt dicovered.

They are placed before, in the middle of the ret, in each Jaw four (ome have only two in a Jaw, as large as four) broad and harp like Swords, horter then the Dogteeth, and fixed in their Sockets with ingle Roots; and therefore they fall the ooner out, epecially the uppermore. After thee follow on either ide

The Dog-teeth, o called, becaue of their harpnes, hardnes, and ue; for what the former cannot cut thee do bruie and grind. They are commonly termed the Eye-teeth, not as ome think, becaue they do almot touch the circumference of the Eye, eeing they hardly reach the lower part of the L • ps of the Notrils, but becaue a portion of that Nerve which moves the Eye, is carried unto them, and they are deeply rooted, and therefore it is counted dangerous to draw them, alo when they are pained, the Eye-lids do pant a little.

Thee teeth are two in each Jaw, on each ide one, broad and thick in their bais, andWhy Men have few dog teeth. harp above. For a Man did not need many of thee kind of teeth, eeing he is a gentle Creature, and hath hands to defend and offend.
They are fatned with imple Roots as the Fore-teeth are, but they are more deeply and firmly rooted: for their Roots exceed all the other teeth in depth, and they are longer then the upper teeth.

The remaining hindermore teeth are called Molares, both from their hape reembling Mill-tones and their ue, becaue they grind the meat after it is cut, they are rough and great, hard and broad. The Germans call them the Cheek-teeth.
In men they are more in number then the Cutters; but the contrary holds in fierce Beats, which ue their harp alo to fight with.
They are commonly twenty, on each hand in both the Jaws ive, although the number varies, as was aid beor.

The two lat of thee are termed Dentes Sapientiae, the Teeth of Wiedom, alo the teeth of Sene and Undertanding, becaue they do then firt break out (omtimes with very great pains, and otherwailes without any pain) when men begin to be wie, about the twenty eighth or thirtieth year of their Age, and omtimes when they are very old; Aritotle aw them break out in ome when they were fourcore, and Walaeus at the Age of eighty three years. Somtimes they hardly appear, and otherwhiles they are carce created; the Latins call them Genuinos.

Thee Teeth are fatned by divers roots,Why the upper Grinders have more roots then the lower? either two and three, as the lower Jawteeth, or with three and four, as the upper Jaw-teeth, which have more roots then the other: Becaue,

list.item: 1. They hang of themelves, otherwie then the lower teeth which are fatned partly by their own heavines.
2. Becaue the Subtance of the upper Jaw is more rare and oft.

div.p: And o much for the firt part of theA Tranition. Skeleton, viz. the Head: Now follows the econd Part, or Trunk.

div.head: Chap. 14. Of the Back-bone and its Vertebra's in General.
div.p: IN the Trunk or other Part of the Skeleton, all the Vertebrae of the Back-bone are to be examined, alo the Oa Ichij, the Ribs, the Breat-bone, the Chennel-bones, and the Shoulder-blades.

All that is termed the Spina or Backbone,What the Spina is? which reaches from the firt Vertebra of the Neck to the Os coccygis, or Crupper-bone. It is called Spina the Thorn, becaue the • inder part therof is all along harp-pointed like a thorn branch.
The Parts of the Spine or Back-bone are termed Sponduloi in Greek, in Latin Vertebrae Whirl-bones, or Turningbones, becaue by means of them the Body is turned everal waies.
And thee Bones of the Spina are divided into even Vertebrae of the Neck; twelve of the Back; five of the Loins, and five or fix of the Os acrum; to which is added the Crupper-bone.

All the Vertebrae are hollowed, to contain the Spinal Marrow, they were to be many, not one, both for Motion which ought to be made forward and backward; alo that the hurting of one might not draw the whole Spine into conent. The Father of Nic. Fontanus aw five Vertebrae or Whirle-bones of the Spina in a cluter like a round ball, in the Body of a Porter that carried burthens. And Pavius hath oberved that in decrepit old people thee Vertebrae grow together into one, the moiture being dried up, and the intermediate Ligaments hardned, which he repreents by a Picture. Tulpius aw the Backbone in a Boy divided into two parts, and Salmuth hath een it broke aunder in perons that were hanged.

The Figure of the whole Back is, that omtimes it inclines inwards, as the Vertebrae of the Neck, to utain the Gullet and apera Arteria; and thoe of the Loins, for the Trunk of the Aorta and the Cava decending. Somtimes outwards, as of the Back, and a little of the Os acrum; that there may be a larger pace for the Heart, Lungs, Bladder, Fundament and Womb.
And thee Parts do bend more outwards in Women, for the ake of the Child in the Womb.

The Figure of each Vertebra above and beneath, is plane and broad, that luxation may not eaily be caued, round within, convex and bunching out; but in the neck broader and more even, by reaon of the Wezand and Gullet reting thereupon. On the outer or Back-point, the Vertebrae are furnihed with many prominencies.
For there are three kind of Procees in every Vertebra.

list.item: I. Four oblique ones, two on the upper part acending, two in the neither part decending.

II. Two tranvere, for the Original and Inertion of the Mucles. And they are in the Vertebrae of the Neck broad and bored through; in the Back thick, olid and round, excepting the eleventh and twelfth.
III. One harp one, in the hinder part, which is properly called the Spine or Thorn, and is wanting in the firt Vertebra.

div.p: They have five Appendixes. Two above and beneath at their Body; as many at their tranvere Procees, and one at the extremity of the Spine.

There is a mot wide hole in the middet of each Vertebra for to keep the Spinal Marrow in. Alo there are other holes in the ides, which are leer, to let the nerves out, which John Leonicenus affirm to go out only at the joyntings of the Vertebrae.

The Subtance of each Vertebra, is thicker and more pungie in the inide: to which grow the Epiphyes and Gritles. For the extream Parts of the Vertebrae, excepting the firt of the Neck, are furnihed with Appendixes, between which there come thick and oft Gritles, that they may be more eaily moved; o that above and beneath, they have Gritles, which in the Os acrum are harder and drier, becaue this Bone is immoveable.
The Vertebrae are knit together by Articulation in the hinder part, viz. by the way of Ginglumos, but in the fore part by way of Symphyis, and that by very trong Ligaments or Bands.
Now the Ligaments of the Vertebrae are twofold.
Some do knit the Vertebrae above and beneath, and are haped like the half Moon, thick, trong, fibrous, and nottie.
Others arie from the Epiphyes, as well the tranvere as the harp ones, which are membranous, by which the Procees are more trongly tied.

div.head: Chap. XV. Of the Vertebroe or Whirl-bones of the Back in Particular
div.p: THe Vertebrae of the Neck are commonly even. In Brutes for the mot part ix only, and Busbequius relates that the Hyena hath none, who is confuted by the Skeleton of that Beat in the cutody of P. Catellus. Thee Vertebrae of the Neck, have ome Peculiarities, whereby they differ from the ret.

list.item: I. Some of them have their tranvere Procees cleft in two.
II. Alo they have them bored, for the cervical Veins and Arteries, acending into the Brain.
III. They have a cloven Spine or thorny Point.

div.p: The two firt are joyned by Ligaments to the hinderpart of the Head, that they may tick mot cloe to the Head, and have omwhat peculiar to themelves, which the other five have not.

I. Is termed Atlas, becaue it eems to bear the Head up, which rets upon theWhy the firt Vertebra has no Spine? two hollows thereof. Some call it Epitropheus, though more give that Name to the econd. It hath no Spine or harp Point, leat the two mall Mucles of the Head which arie from the econd Vertebra, hould be hurt when the Head is tretched out.
It hath a thinner, but more compact Subtance. It receives, and is not received: and therefore it hath its Cavity covered with a Cartilage, to receive the tooth of the following Vertebra.

II. Is called Epitropheus from turning: for out of the middle of its Body, there ries an Appendix (others call it a Proces) round and oblong, like a Dogs tooth, about which the Head with the firt Vertebra is turned.

Hence that Appendix is called a tooth; yea and the whole Vertebra is by Hippoerates An incurable Squinzie by Luxation of the Tooth. o called, by the Luxation whereof, he conceives an incurable Squinzie, is often caued.

The Surface of the Tooth is in ome ort rough, becaue thence proceeds the Ligament, wherby it is bound to the Occiput or hind-part of the Head, about which alo is wound a olid and round Ligament, like a Nerve in hape, wonderous artificially twited, that the Marrow may not be compreed and hurt.
Now this econd Vertebra is joyned with the firt, by a broad Ligament, turned round.
The lat does more agree with the Vertebra's of the Chet, and hath its lat Proces not alwaies cloven.
The Vertebrae of the Back are commonly twelve in number; to which o many Ribs on each ide are articulated: eldom one is wanting; and there is eldomer one more.
They are thicker then thoe of the Neck; les olid, and full of little holes, for the paage of the nourihing Veels.

list.item: I. Is by the Ancients called Liphiá, becaue it is higher, and ticks out more then the ret.
II. Is termed Machaliter Axillaris the Arm-pit Vertebra.

div.p: The ret are called Cotales the Rib-vertebrae.
The eleventh is termed Arrhep • s, becaue the Spine or harp point thereof is traight.
The twelfth is called Diazotér the Girder.
The five of the Loins are the thicket and greatet, being full of little holes, whoe motion is looer then that of the Back, that we may more eaily toop to the ground.
The tranvere Procees are longer, but thinner, excepting the firt and fift; but the Spines are thicker and broader, to which the Mucles and Ligaments of the Back are fatned.
1. Is termed Nephrites, from the Kidneys which re • thereupon.
The lat, is by ome called Aphalites, the tabliher or underpropper.
The ret agree with the others aforeaid.

The Os acrum or holy Bone follows, oThe Os acrum why o called. called, becaue it is the bigget of the Spine or Back-bone, for the Ancients termed that which was great, Sacred. Or becaue it lieth under the obcaene or privy Parts, which Nature herelf covers and hides: For Sacrum did alo ignifie execrable, as Servius hews from Petronius, commenting upon that Expreion of Virgil; Auri acra fames: the cured thirt of Gold.
It is broad and immoveable, being the Bais or Foundation of the Back.
Its Figure is commonly triangular. It is in its fore-part hollow, mooth and even; behind it is bunching and rough.

Its Vertebrae o called, not in regardOs acrum properly hath no Vertebrae. of ue but imilitude, are five, omtimes ix, in young Children eaily eparable, in grown perons o glewed together, that they eem to be but one Bone. Solomon Albertus and Pavius have omtimes oberved them to be even in Number.
Galen makes the Os acrum to conit of three Bones; becaue he comprehends the other Bones of Os acrum under the Crupper-bone, and calls that an Epiphyis, which others call Os Coccygis.
The Holes are not in its ides, as thoe of the former, but in the fore-part (which are greater, becaue there are greater Nerves) and the hinder-part: becaue at the ides in the Os Ilion or Flank-bone.
In the three upper Cavities are engraven, where the Oa Ilij cleave • o it.

OS COCCYGIS the Cockow-bone, o called from the Shape it hath of a Cuckows-bill, is under the former, coniting of three or four Bones, and two Gritles. But I conceive there was a greater number of Bones and Gritles in that Danih Boy, who had a Tail growing out at his Rump.
Their Connexion is looe, and in Women looer then in Men, that theyThe Os coccygis may be looned. may give way.
1. In the Voidance of large Excrements.

2. In the time of Womens Travel, that the cavity may be more wide. And therefore ome conceive that this Bone only gives way in the Birth, though Pinaeus be againt it, and that the Pains of Women in Travel depend upon the Concoure of little Nerves in that place. Afterwards in itting it comes forwards, and of its own accord returns into its place.
This Bone in Men bends more inward to utain the Intetinum rectum; in Women outwards, becaue of the Neck of the Womb, and that the Cavity might be wider.

This Bone being hurt or broken, exceeding great, pains are raied, as the Stories related by Amatus and Donatus, do witnes. Hofman believes it is of no ue, but is only the mark of a tail, as the Nipples in Men are only the igns or marks of Duggs. But the contant Doctrine of Galen is, that all Parts of the Body are made for ome Ue.

div.head: Chap. 16. Of the Nameles Bone, or Os Innominatum.
div.p: THe OS INNOMINATUM or NAMELESS BONE, which ome term OS COXAE or ILIUM, the Flank-bone, conits of three Bones, Ilium, Pubis, and Ichium joyned together by Gritles, till the eventh year it appears ditinguihed by a threefold Line, but in grown perons tis one.

The Os Ilion o called, becaue it contains the Gut Ilium, is the firt part, which is the uppermore and broadet, knit to the Os acrum, by a common membranous and mot trong Ligament, although a Gritle alo comes between.
Its emicircular and uneven Circumference, is termed Spina Ois Ilij, whoe inner part hollow and broad, is termed Cota, the Rib; the outer part formed with unequal Lines, is termed Dorum, the Back.

This Bone is larger in Women, and its Spine is drawn more out idewaies, thatWhy the Os Ilium is larger in Women? the Womb of a Woman with Child may better ret upon it. And therefore women with Child do a little complain of this Part, as if it were pulled aunder from the Os acrum and other neighbouring Parts to which it cleaves.

Os pubis or Pectinis, the Share-bone, is the econd middlemore and foremoreThe Share-bones are looned in Child-birth. Part; which Bone is joyned to the Bone of the other ide, by way of Sunchondrois, that is to ay, by a gritle coming between; which in Women is twice as thick and looe or wide as in Men, that thee Bones in Childbirth may be (not dilocated or disjoynted, but) looned and made to gape, when the Child trives to come forth. But now and then when the Childs greatnes, or the narrownes of the place requires, the Share-bones are pulled aunder, as, beides the Authority of the Ancients, Paraeus and Riolanus have oberved in the Diections of Childing-women, &c. and it is largely proved in the Anatomical Controveries of my Father Bartholinus: But this is not alwaies o, namely when the Child is oft and apt to bend it elf and comply with the traitnes of the place when the way is lippery, the Bones much widened, &c. for then the looning of the Gritle does uffice.

But whether the Share-bones are moved is another quetion. Joh. Cajus affirms they are moved by help of the right Mucle of the Belly. Spigelius alo aies they are moved after a peculiar manner upwards, whiles the Body roules in the bed, the Legs being lifted upwards Riolanus proves that the Share-bones are moved, not alone, but with the Hip-bone, by help of the ame Mucles, this I ay he proves by the Venereal Embracements, in which thee Parts are moved; by the going of uch whoe Legs are cut off, and latly by dancing.
But ome doubts do as yet make me cruple this Motion.

list.item: 1. Becaue Cajus himelf confees, that the Share-bones (I add the ret) are not moved of their own Nature, but by the bending of the Back-bone.
2. Thee Bones being joyned together by Symphyis, can have no motion, which Riolanus himelf confees.
3. I have aigned another Ue for the right Mucles, above in Book the firt.

4. Thee eeming Motions of the Bones, are not proper to them, but are motions of the Thigh or Back, whoe motion they follow. For in the Examples alleadged, any man may experiment in himelf, that both his Thighs and Back are moved; alo he may by his hand perceive, that both the Mucles of the Thigh called Glutaei, and the other adjacent Mucles are moved.
5. They ought to be immoveable, becaue the upper Parts ret upon them as on a Foundation, and we ret by itting upon this Part.

div.p: In Women that have been lately delivered, thee bones may be eparated with the back of a thin knife, which they cannot be in others. Moreover, though the Share-bones are joyned by a Gritle, yet they have likewie two
Ligaments 1. compaes them about circularly. 2. Is membranous, which poees the hole.

They are thin, and for highnes akeWhy there are great Holes in the Sharebones. furnihed with very great Holes, which in women are more large and capacious, becaue of the Womb and Child, for the inner and lower Procees do bunch more outwards.
With the Os acrum they contitute that Cavity which is termed Pelvis theThe Share-bones larger in women. Bain or Bowl, wherein are eated the Bladder, the Womb, and Part of the Guts.

OS ISCHION or the Hip-bone is the third part, which is lower and more outward, wherein is a large and deep Cavity, (they call it Acerabulum, the Saucer, and Pixis the Box) to receive the large Head of the Thigh-bone, which if it fall out, either by reaon of ome internal humore, or outward chance, a Luxation or Semiluxation is thereby caued. The gritley Proces of this Cavity, is termed Supercilium, the Brow.
The lowet Parts of this Bone are more ditant in women then in men, and therefore their Pelvis or Bain is larger then that in men.

This Bone is knit to the Os acrum, with a double Ligament, growing out of the Os acrum: The one is inerted into the harp Proces of the Hip, the other behind, into its Appendix, that the Intetinum rectum and its Mucles may be thereby utained.

div.head: Chap. 17 Of the Ribs.
div.p: AS the Os Innominatum or Nameles Bone, is at the ides of the Os acrum, o at the ides of the Vertebrae of the Back, are the RIBS. And therefore, acending in the Explication of the Skeleton, thee are now to be explained, as being the lateral Parts of the Chet.

div.p: The Situation of the Ribs in the Sides, and the Greeks call them pleurai, becaue they form the Sides.

In Shape they reemble a bow, or the leer Segment of a Circle, that the Chet might be the larger. Johan. Fontanus found a forked Rib; and my elf at Hafnia hewed the third Rib of the leftide, as thick as two Ribs, joyned to the Breat-bone with two hanks.

At their rie they are narrower and rounder, but the nearer they come to the Breat, the broader they grow. In their upper part they are thicker. And the upper Ribs are more crooked, and alo horter; the middlemore are longer and broader; the lower are cut again horter.

The external Surface is rough, where they are fatned to the Vertebrae, becaue the Ligaments which tie them do thence proceed: And there they are furnihed with two little knobs: 1. Is articulated to the hollow of the Vertebra. 2. Is joyned to the tranvere Proces of the Vertebra. But the five lower are joyned by a imple knob.
The inner ide is mooth, becaue of the Membrane Pleura.
In the lowet part there are Cavities according to the length of the Ribs, for the Vein, Artery, and Nerve; which appears the more, by how much they are nearer the Vertebra's.

Where let Chirurgeons oberve in the opening of the Chet, which is made betweenAn Admonition for Chirurgeons. the fift and ixt Rib, the Section mut be made from the top towards the bottome, but not contrariwaies leat thee Veels hould be hurt.
The Ribs have Connexions; one with the Vertebrae of the Back, another with the Gritles of the Breat-bone.
The Subtance of the Ribs, is partly bony, and partly gritly.The Gritles of the Ribs.
1 That the Chet may more eaily be contracted and ditended.
2 That a Fracture may not eaily happen.
'Tis bony in the part near the Back, and the lateral part.
Its gritly near the Breat-bone to which they are joyned.

For all the Ribs in the forepart, have Gritles like Epiphyes, which in women (not in men unles very old) through tract of time, do grow hard as bones, that they may more trongly utain the Bulk of the Dugs reting upon them.

The Gritles of the upper Ribs are harder, becaue they are coupled with the bones of the Sternon or Bret-bone; thoe of the lower are ofter, becaue they are joyned to Gritles. Moreover in its hinder part each hath a Gritle, which is articulated with a Vertebra.

The Ribs are many in Number, that the Chet may be more eaily moved. Pa •
amas Why the Ribs are many is number? in his Relations of Athens, tell us, that Protophanes Magneius, had his Ribs fatned one to anothers from his houlders to his batard Ribs. Nicholas Fa • tanus aw three united and uneparable. For the mot part they are on each fide twelve, both in men and women. Seldome thirteen, more rarely eleven. But often there is only one uperfluous. Tis therefore likely that in one ideHow many Ribs Adam had. of Adam there were thirteen ribs, one of which Jehovah took out with the muculous fleh growing thereto and turned into Eve; or he had twelve ribs on one ide, and eleven on the other.
The Ribs are divided into true, genuine and legitimate; and batard, adulterate and illegitimate ribs.

The true are the even upper ones, o called, becaue they do more perfect theHow many true Ribs there are. Circle, and touch the Bret-bone, wherewith they have a perfect Articulation; and with the Vertebrae by a double knob as was aid before.
The two uppermore are called antitrophoi, retortae, turned backwards.
The two following are termed tertai, olidae, the olid Ribs.
The remaining three are cal'd ternitides, the Pectoral Ribs.

The five lowet are called batard Ribs, becaueThe batard Ribs. they are leer, ofter, horter, not do they reach to the Breat-bone (that dilatation may be there better made, at the beginning of the lower Belly) nor have they a perfect Articulation therewith, but being knit only to the Vertebrae, as if ome part of them were cut off, they end into longer Gritles than the true ones: Which being turned back upwards, do tick one to the other, as if they were glewed together, the lat excepted, which is the leat, and ticks to none, and therefore tis truly purious, that a larger pace may be for the Liver, Spleen, and upper Guts being ditended. Howbeit, the eleventh ometimes and the twelfth, are tied to the Septum tranverum: Sometimes, the lat grows to the oblique decendent Mucle of the Belly, without the Midriff; ometimes it hath the Circumcription of its proper Mucle, which pulls it from.
The Ue of the Ribs is:

list.item: 1. [Epecially of the true ones] to defend the Breat and Bowels therein contained, as the Heart, &c.
2. To utain the Mucles that erve for Repiration, and ome others of the Belly.
[3. Of the batard one,] to erve the Natural parts contained in the Belly.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of the Sternon or Breat-bone.
div.p: THe Bone of the Breat, which in the fore-part of the Chet rets upon the Ribs, and is pread thereupon (whence they uppoe tis call'd Sternum) is by Hypocrates termed Stethos: which Word nevertheles ometimes ignifies.

list.item: 1 The whole forepart of the Chet.
2 Its Pain.
3 The Breat-bone as in this place.
4 The Orifice of the Stomach.
5 The Sword-fahion'd Gritle.

div.p: Others call this bone Os Gladiale or Eniorme the Swordbone or Sword-fahion'd bone, becaue of the hape of a Sword or rather uch a Dagger as was ued by the Ancients: for it is convex, long and broad.
Its Subtance is partly bony, but fungous and red, partly Gritly.

It conits of divers bones, not of one, as is commonly een in old Men, the diverity of its bones appears, when you remove its Membrances. In Infants it is wholly gritly, excepting its firt bone. Moreover, the upper bones are ooner made than the lower, and the middle parts, than the outmot: o that in concluion, eight bones are found in the Breat of a Child, which after even years grow together, and become fewer, o that in grown perons there are ometimes three, ometimes four, ometimes more bones. But the firt and lat remain in grown perons as in Children; but the middle ones growing together, the number of bones comes to vary in that place.
Thee Bones are ditinguihed by tranvere lines, and are knit together by Sanchondrois; for the Gritles are interpoed like Ligaments.

The firt and uppermot bone, is large and thick, plain and uneven, of an Halfmoon fahion above, repreenting the joyning of a Dagger blade into the haft, ome term it Jugulum the Throat-pit, others call it Furculam the little fork.

It hath on each ide an hollownes in the upper part, to
receive the Heads of the Claviculae or Channel-bones, in which copulation Gritles come between.
And another Hollownes within engraven in the middle, that it may give way to the decending Trachea or Weand.
The econd is more narrow and hath many hollownees on each ide to receive the Gritles of the Ribs.

The third is yet les, but broader than the econd, and ends into the GritleThe Cartilago Eniformis. which is termed Kup • o idès Sword-fahion'd, and Mucronata pointed, becaue towards the end it is harp like the point of a Sword. The Arabians term it, the Pomegranate; Avicen calls it Epiglottalis, and the common name is Scutiformis Shield-fahioned.
This Gritle is triangular and oblong, ometimes round at the End, and ometimes broad, otherwhiles cloven, whence ome call it Furc • lla the little fork; 'tis eldome double.

Sometimes 'tis perforated, for the Dug-veins and Arteries, which are accompanied by a Nerve. Sometimes in aged perons, it attains a bony Subtance, Vetingus hath found it a Fingers length not without great hurt to the Stomach, and trouble when a man bows himelf. Pavius alo aw here a bony Subtance, in a peron troubled with extream hortnes of breath.

This if it be too much preed and bowed inwards, the parts beneath it are hurt, viz. the Liver and Stomach, and the Infants perih for want of Nutriment: of which ee Condronchius and Septalius, Zacutus, Wilhelmus Pio. This Dieae is by ome Women cal'd, the Hearts compreion.
Folius hath oberved two Mucles placed on the ide hereof, by which this Gritle is lightly moved downwards and inwards.
The Cavity appearing outwardly in this place, is called Fovea, or Scrobiculus Cordis.
The Ue of the Sternum or Breat-bone,

list.item: 1. Like a hield to defend the Heart from external dangers.
2. To utain the Mediatinum.
3. To collect the Ribs and faten themelves one to another.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of the Channel-bones and Shoulder-blades.
div.p:
THe Channel-bones are called Claviculae, Cle • des in Greek, that is the Keyes; becaue they hut up the Chet, and like Keyes do lock the Shoulder-blade to the Breat-bone, or becaue they reemble the Keyes ued by the Ancients, which Spigelius aw in an old houe at Padua. Celus calls them Jugula a jungendo from joyning, others call them Ligulas, Os furcale, Furcalem uperi
• rem.
They are eated athwart under the lower part of the Neck, on the top of the Breat, on each ide one.

They have the Shape of a long Latine S, that is to ay, of two Semicircles, et one to another contrariwie, at the Throat externally they are convex, inwardly a little hollowed, that the velelsAn •• llow • e • about the channel
•• nt. carried that way may not be compreed. But in Men they are more crooked, that the motion of their Arms may be les hindred, in Women les, for beauties ake, eeing the hollows in that place are not o viible in Women as in Men, and therefore Women are not o nimble to throw Stones as Men are.
Their Subtance is thick, but fitulous and fungous; and therefore they are often broken.
Their Surface is rough and uneven.

They are knit to the upper proces of the Shoulderblade (by a Gritle, which nevertheles grows not thereto, that it may give way a little in the motions of the Shoulder-blade and Arm, only it is detained by Ligaments embracing the Joynt) by a broad and longih head, and with the Sternon or Breat-bone, it is joyned, by another little head, as was aid before.

Its Ue is to erve the undry motions of the Arm, which becaue it rets upon this bone as on a prop, therefore it is more eaily moved upwards and backwards. And therefore it is that Brutes have no channel-bones, excepting the Ape, Squiril, Moue, and Hedge-hog or Urchin.

Os Scapulae the Shoulder-blade is by the Greeks termed Omoplá • e¯
becaue it makesWhat the Scapula is. the breadth of the Shoulder, thoe that peak barbarouly calls it Spatula. It is a bone broad and thin, epecially in the middet, but in its procees thick, on each ide one, reting upon the upper Ribs, behind, like a Shield.
Its Figure is in a manner triangular.

Its Parts are undry. The Internal is hollow, the other part (which hath both a corner and an upper and lower Rib) is gibbous, which is termed Tetudo the Tortoie, alo the Back of the Shoulder-blade. There is alo a certain Spine or harp-point, looking above and beneath the cavities which are termed Intercapulia.
It hath three Procees.

list.item: I. Is the extream part of the Spine lately poke of, and is called Aoro¯miom the Shoulder-tip, or Summus Humerus, whereby 'tis joyned to the Clavicula or Channelbone.

II. Is leer, lower and harp, and from its likenes to a Crows bill, 'cis cal'd Coracoeid • s; alo A • churod • s from the likenes it hath to one part of an Anchor, alo Sigmo • idés and by this proces, the Shoulder bone is contained in its place.

III. The hortet is termed Auchè cervix, the Neck; in the end whereof there is a uperficial cavity, whereunto the Head of the Shoulder is inerted, which that it may not eaily lip cut, the deepnes of the Cavity is encreaed by a thick Gritle, compaing the Lips. And by this proces and Cavity, the Shoulder-blade is joyned with the Arm.

div.p: It hath five Epiphyes, three at the inide, and at the Bais near the carriage of the Spina. Two of them produce Ligaments, which joyn its head to the Shoulder, and the Shoulder-tip to the Clavicula. But common Ligaments thin and Membranous, do compas the Joynt of the Shoulder-blade and Arm.

p.hi: Ue of the Scapula or Shoulder-blade.

list.item: 1. It erves to trengthen the Ribs.

2. For the Articulation of the Shoulder and Channelbones, and for their ecurity. And therefore the Shoulder is eldome (without very great violence) dilocated or disjoynted upwards, or to one ide, but for the mot part downwards, where no Shoulder-blade hinders.
3. For the implantation of Mucles.
4. Primarily for the action of laying hold according to Hofman, to which they are ubervient, by inarticulation partly, and partly by the explanation of certain Mucles of the Arm.
5. Secondarily to cover the Heart.

div.head: CHAP. XX. Of the Bones of the whole Arm and Hand.
div.p: THe Bones of the Arm and Hand, are divided into the Brachium or Arm peculiarly o called, Cubitus the Cubit, and Extrema manus the Hand.

The Os Brachii or Arm-bone, is a ingle Bone, great and trong, long, round, and uneven. In its upper part it hath an Appendix or great Head, growing to it, which is round, covered with a Gritle, and articulated with the Scapula by Diárthrois.
