div.p: The lower part is articulated to the Cubitus and Radius, where there are two procees; the External which is les and cruted with a Gritle; the Internal having two Hollows; repreenting a Pulley, whereby the Cubit being joyned by way of Ginglymos, may be bent to a mot acute angle, but not extended beyond a right line.
The Boats of the Cubit are two, horter than the Shoulder, and having Appendixes on either ide, reting mutually one upon another, and joyned one to another by a Membranous Ligament.
The firt being lower, greater and longer than the other, is termed Ulna, Cubitus, by the barbarous Writers focile majus; the other being upper and leer, is termed Radius, or focile minus.

The Ulna or Ell, o called for ome reemblance it hath to the Drapers Metwand termed an Ell, in its upper part is articulated with the Shoulder by Ginglymos, and therefore it hath there Procees, and Hollows.

The Procees are two, longwie haped, and as it were triangular, rough, that the Ligaments might trongly cloe upon the Joynt and compas the ame fat. They are termed Co • d • ai, that is Beaks, Bills or Acorns. The foremore and uppermore is les, and goes into the hollow of the Shoulder: the later is thicker and larger and ends in an obtue angle, and goes into the hinder hollow of the Shoulder. Galen calls it Olecranum, Hippocrates Ancona, the Latines Gibberum.

In the middet of thee is a great Cavity or Hollow, like an half Circle, whence 'tis called Sigmocides from the letter Sigma o hap'd of old by the Greeks. It hath as yet another mooth external lateral Cavity, for the head of the Radius.

In the lower part it is articulated with the Writ, both by a Gritle going between, as alo by an acute proces therefore termed Styloides, Bodkin-like; whence a Ligament aries, which fatens the Cubit to the Writ-joynt.

The other Bone cal'd Radius is more oblique or crooked, and is a little ditant from the other in the middle, where a thin Ligament comes between: but above, the Ulna receives the Radius; beneath, the Radius receives it.
The upper part thereof is articulated with the outward part of the Brachium, by way of Diarthrois, whence proceeds the forward and backward motion.
The lower is articulated with an Appendix with the Writ-bone, at the greatet Finger.
The upper part of this, is thinner, the lower thicker; contrary to what is in the former.
The Hand hath four orts of Bones: thoe of the Carpus, Brachiale or Writ; thoe of the Matacarpus or pot brachiale, the After-writ; thoe of the Fingers and the Seamus-eedbones.
The Carpus or Writ, which the Arabians call Raetta, hath eight ditinct nameles Bones, very unequal, differing in Shape and Magnitude.
At their firt original they are Gritles, afterwards they become Spungie Bones.
They are covered with very trong Gritly Ligaments and withall o fatned together, as if they were but one Bone.
And thee Ligaments ariing from the lower procees of the Radius and Cubitus, do erve for Articulation.

But there are other Ligaments, which are tranvere and haped like rings, for to trengthen and afely to carry along the Tendons, the internal, containing the tendons of the Mucles which bend the Fingers; and the external, containing the Tendons of the Mucles which extend the Fingers, which Ligaments or Bands, though they eem to be one, may be divided into many.
The bones of the Writ are dipered in a certain order: for above, there are four, articulated with the Radius and the Cubitus: beneath as many, knit to the four bones of the Metacarpus or After-writ.
The Metacarpium, After-writ, or Palm, hath four bones (others ay five, reckoning the firt of the Thumb amongt them) haped longwie and mall.
They are joyned to the Writ by a Connexion of obcure motion, and by Gritly Ligaments: with the Fingers by way of Ginglymos.
Thee Bones are fitulous containing Marrow, hollow within, boie without.

They have Appendixes on each ide, which neer the fingers are round and longih heads, going into the hollownes of the Fingers. In the middle they gape one from another, where the Mucles cal'd Inner ••
• i do lye conceal'd.
The bones of the Fingers are fiftee • , in each Finger three. For the firt of the Thumb is reckon'd in this number, becaue it hath a looer articulation than the pot-brachialia.
The row of Fingers on a hand the Greeks call Phalangas becaue they reemble a rank of Souldiers in battle array.
Each of the Fingers have Ligaments on their inides, according to their length like Channels, whereby they are fatned one to another.

The bones of the Finger differ in Magnitude. For in every Finger, the firt is greates than the econd, the econd than the third: and they are all thicker at the Joynt, where their knobs are termed
•… duloi, • odi, kno • .
Without they are bunching, within hollow and plain the better to lay hold.
They have Procees above and beneath, beides the bones of the third Interjuncture, which they did not need above where they are joyned to the Nails.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. Of the Bones of the whole Leg, Foot and Thigh.
div.p: THe Pes or Leg (taking the word in a large ence) is divided into three pa • ts, as the Arm was: viz. into Femur the Thigh, Tibiam the Shank, and E • tr • mum pedem the Foot.

• emur (the Thigh) is o termed a ferendo from bearing, becaue it bears and holds the Creature up, it conits of one only Bone, but the greatet and longet in the whole body, whoe fore and external part is more bunching, the inner and hinder, more Saddle-hap'd.
For it decends obliquely inwards unto the Knee; which Chirurgeons are to oberve,A Memento for Chyrurgions. let in the Fracture thereof they come to diorder this ituation.
The upper part hath three Procees, which are rather Epiphyes, and are eaily epaarated in young Children.

I. Is a mot great and round Head, made of an Appendix, which is inerted into the Acetabulum or hollow Sawcer of the Coxendix, and is by a double Ligament fatned to the aid Coxendix or Hip-bone: the o • e common, broad, membranous, but thick enough, compaing the Joynt round about; the other, round, as it were a Gritle (as if it were a Gritly Nerve) betwixt the head of the Thigh and the Depth of the Cavity, leat the head of the Thigh fall out.
The Neck hereof hath a double proces furnihed with an Appendix, which Appendixes are eaily pluckt aunder in Infants, but not in grown perons.
II. Is external, which is called Magnus Trochanter or Rotator, the great whirler or wheeler about, having hollows, Impreions, and Lines.
III. Is internal, cal'd parvus Rotator.
Whoe Ue is, for the original and Inertion of thoe Mucles by which the motions are caued •• and therefore alo it is, that they are called Trochanteres, Wheelers of Whirlers about.

The lower part is articulated or joynted with the hank by way of Ginglymos. For at the Knees, with a double head, the inner more thick, the outer more broad and flat, it enters the Cavity of the Tibia; between which heads there is a large pace, of a Thumbs-breadth, through which the veels do pas unto the Thighs with a Nerve of the fourth pare; and wounds in this part are dangerous, by reaon of Convulions.

p.U: o called from its likenes to a mill-tone; is a round and broad Bone; it is in this place put upon the joynting of the Thigh and Shank, where the Knee is compas'd with a membranous Ligament, all ave the Mola; others call it Rotula, Patella, Mola, Scutum, Os cutiforme, &c. the Kneepan, becaue it contitutes the Knee.

div.p: Its Subtance for ome months in young Children, is Gritly, in grown perons it becomes bony.
Its hap'd like a Buckler, for in the middle, one part thicker than the ret, bunches out.
It growe to, and is fatned by certain thick Tendons, of ome Mucles of the Thigh.
It is movable, and for to make the motion more eaie, inwardly at the Thigh-bone, 'tis cover'd with a lippery Gritle.

Its Ue is: I. To trengthen the joynt in that part, let the Thigh hould lip and be dilocated inwards, and o a man hall fall, epecially walking downwards, and much bending his Knee. 'Tis reported, that in Nova Zembla, Men bend their Knees as well backwarde as forwards.
II. To defend the Tendons of the Mucles.
Tibia the hank, being that part which is between the Kne • and the Ankle, conits of two Bones, as the Cubitus or lower half of the Arm.

The one being inner and greater, is called by the name of the whole, Tibia, C •• me; by ome focile majus, canna major, &c. In an Elephant alone of all Creatures (as Bonitus informs us) there is a bending or joynting in the middle of the Shanks, beides the other ordinary bendings common to all Creatures.

In the upper part it hath a Proces in the middle received by the Cavity of the Thigh-bone, and two cavities framed long-wie, for the Heads of the Thigh-bone; the depth of whoe Hollows is encreaed by a Gritle, fatned thereto by Ligaments, which is movable, oft, lippery, and meared with an Oyly moiture, thick in its circuit, th •• towards it Centre, and therefore termed Lunata, Moonhap'd.
A knob growing there, doth eparate the two Cavities, from the top whereof a trong Ligament proceeding, it is fatned into the hollow of the Thigh-bone.
But from the fore and rough ide come two Ligaments, which encreae the Moon-fahion'd Gritles.

Its foremore part which is harp and long, is termed Spina, where the hape of the Bone is as it were triangular, and o acute that it is like the edge of a Knife, and therefore if the Bone of the Tibia or hank be trucken on this forepart, it caueth exceeding pain, becaue the neighbouring Skin and the Perioteum are cut by this harp Bone as it were with a Knife.

In the lower part there is a Proces void of fleh, ticking out with a bunch, near the Foot, and 'tis cal'd malleolus internus, the inner Ankle-bone; as the proces of the Fibula is termed malleolus externus, the outer Ankle-b • ne.

Fibula pe ••• e, the Button, becaue it eems to button together and joyn the Mucles of the hank; is alo cal'd Sura the Calf, Canna minor, Focile minus, &c. and it is a maller and lanker bone, drawn along before the Tibia without, as the Radius before the Cubit.
In the Upper part, its round head doth not touch the Knee, but it ubits beneath: but with its lower •• rt, it goes beneath the Tibia, and therefore 'tis as long a bone as the Tibia is.

In the middle the Tibia and Fibula hold a gaping ditance one from another, by reaon of the Mucles of the Feet there placed, in which pace a thin broad Ligament joyns thee Bones together, according to their longitude, 'tis joyned alo to the Tibia, by a common Ligament, above and beneath.
Beneath, the Head becoming harp, hath an Appendix, which growing thick, begets a proces called Malleolus externus the outer Ankle-bone which is lower than the inner Ankle-bone.
The Bones of the Foot are divided as the Bones of the Hand, into three parts: into the Tarus, Metatarus, and the Toes.
The Bones of the Tarus are even, though ome number only the lat four to be in the Tarus, becaue the three firt have no Bones in the Hand anwering to them.
I. It's cal'd Atrágalos, in Latine Talus, and commonly Os Balitae the Sling-bone, alo Quatrio, becaue of its four ides.

'Tis placed beneath the hank bones as a Bais or foundation: for it is joyned with the Appendix of the Tibia by way of Ginglumos; wherefore they have upon a long Neck, on high, round, and mooth Head, covered over with a Gritle, in the middle whereof is a mooth Cavity: whereupon it comes to have on each ide a brim or brow, like a pully or little wheel on which a Rope runs.

At the ides it receives on each hand the Ankle-bones: it's alo joyned with the Os naviculare; alo below to the Heel, with a double joynt, where its lower part is uneven, twice hollowed, and thrice bunched. It receives the Head of the Heel-bone.

In the middet of thee Joynts a Cavity is to be oberved (to which the hollow of the Heel anwers) wherein is contained fat and a limy ubtance, to moiten the gritly Ligaments, which knit the Talus to the Bone leat in their motion they hould be dried. Hence I have oberved as often as there is carity of this moit and fat Subtance or none at all, either by means of a wound in that place, or any other caue, that there is a noie in a mans Foot when he walks, by the knocking of the two bones one againt another, yet without pain becaue there is no enitive part within, but only Bones, Gritles and Ligaments.

II. Is the greatet and thicket in the Foot, as being the chiefet tability thereof (as the Talus is chief for motion) and therefore 'tis joyned by many Ligaments to the Talus or Ankle, and other adjacent Bones

'Tis called P • er ••
• alx; C • lcaneum, pedis cal ••• , the Spur of the Foot or Heel-bone into which the greatet and tronget Chord or Tendon in the whole Body is fatned, being made up of the Tendons of three Mucles of the Foot.
Its lower part is omewhat broad, where it turns backwards, that the Foot may more firmly be etled and trengthned, otherwie a man would eaily fall backwards.
In its upper part, it hath a large head, going into that hallow cavity which receives the knob of the Talus. But it is alo joyned to the Os Cubiforme or Die-fahion'd bone with its flat head.
III. Is called Os naviculare, Scaphoeid • s from the imilitude of a Boat: 'tis knit to the Talus and the three hindermore bones

IV. From the form of a Die or four quare olid body called a Cube, is termed Cubo-eides cube-fahion'd, alo Os t • erae, the Dice-bone, by the Arabians Gran li •• um, by ome others
<>
many hap'd or many-fac'd. Being greates than the ret, 'tis placed before the Heel, joyned by an uneven Surface; with its other ide 'tis joyned to the fourth and fift bone of the Pedium; but within, to the eventh bone of the Tarus.

The other three, anciently without names, cal'd by Fallopius, Calcoide • , Cuneiformia, wedg-hion'd, are articulated to the Naviculare or Boat-fahion'd-bone: and they are a greater or middleiz'd, and a leer from a broad Bais growing by little and little maller and maller.

The Bones of the Metatarus or Sole, are five knit to the Bones of the Tarus; thoe of the Toes are fourteen; becaue the great Toe is made up only of two Bones, and the Interjunctures are horter than in the Hand, but thoe of the great Toe, thicker than in the Hand.
The other are like the Bones in the Hand which anwer to them; as the Ligaments alo commonly anwer.

But under the ole of the Foot, the Skin and Fat being removed, there is a Ligament broad and trong; and from the lowet Bone of the Heel Seamoidean little bones are inerted into all the ranks of Toes, for the greater firmnes of the whole Foot.

div.head: Chap. XXII. and lat. Of the Seamoidean Bones.
div.p: IN the Interjunctures of the Hands and Feet are found certain very little Bones called Seaminis or Seamoidea becaue they anwer in likenes to Seamus Seeds and alo in their mallnes.
They are round and a little flat.Their hape. Magnitude.
They are les in the Feet th ••• in the Hands, excepting in the great Toe, becaue it is greater than the Thumb is. In ancient perons they are greater and a little plane.

They grow to the Tendons of the MuclesSituation. which move the Toes, under which they lie concealed wrapt up in the Ligaments, o that they come away with them in the clening of the Bones unles great Care be ued.
Sometimes they are gritly, as in Children, in which they are not very conpicuous; otherwhiles bony, covered with Gritles, and inwardly Spungy and porous.

They are commonly twelve in number in each Foot and Hand, but ometimes ixteen, nineteen, twenty and more: ometimes there are only ten. They are more in number, greater and harder, in the inide of the hand than without, in which Riolanus
• a • es there are none. Their number therefore is uncertain: for many are o mall that they are not oberved: and Nature herein as in a matter of mall moment, ometimes abounds, and ometimes again comes hort.

But thoe two are chiefly remarkable for their greatnes which are joined to the firt Joynt of the great Toe, at the Head of the Bone Metatarus; one which is the greater, placed under the Nervous part of that Mucle, which bends the firt Bone of the great Toe, and the form and Size thereof, is like the half of a great Peae, the white skin being taken off: which little bone is by the Arabians called Albadara. Some Ancient Philoophers held that a Man hould grow up again at length from this bone, as from a Seed, which Corn. Agrippa from the tradition of the Hebrews calls Luz. But another much les, is placed under the econd Joynt of the great Toe.
And though mot commonly thee ame very mall bones are found in the Interjunctures of the Fingers and Toes, yet are they to be een alo in other places.

As ometimes in the outide of the Hand, where the eighth Bone of the Writ is fatned to the bone of the Metatarus which utains the little Finger there is one which fills • n hollow place there: and after the a • ie manner here is the like Bone in the Tarus of the Foot, at the outide of the articulation of the • i • t Bone of the Metacarpus which utains the little Toe, with the Os cubiforme, or Diefahion'd bone: alo two little bones in the Ham by the Os fem • ri • , which grow not in the Tendons, but in the Beginnings of the two firt Feet-moving Mucles, which are found in old Men and in dry Creatures, as Deer, Dogs, and Hares. Hereunto they refer that bony part in aged people, which is placed againt the
<> .
Their Ue is.

list.item: I. To defend the Tendons, and by their hardnes to retain them in their motion, leat they hould fall from the Joynt when it bunches out.
II. To trengthen the Joynt and preerve it from Luxation.

III. To fill up empty paces. And while thee things are performed by the aid little Bones, the Hands do thereby lay firmer and afer hold upon any; and the Feet can tand and go more teadily, epecially on rough ground.

div.p: To God our Creator be Praie, Honour and Glory, who hath form'd and fahion'd us o wonderfully.

div.head: TWO EPISTLES OF Johannes Walaeus Concerning the Motion of the Chyle And the BLOOD. To Thomas Bartholinus The Son of CASPAR BARTHOLINUS.

THE FIRST EPISTLE Concerning the Motion of the Chyle and Blood, TO Thomas Bartholinus the Son of Capar.
To PARIS.
div.p: THe chief men in Church and Commonwealth have in all Ages contended about Primacy: but learned Men have in no Age more ambitiouly triven who hould eem mot learned, then at this preent time. And to attain their deire very many are not afraid to ait themelves by Calumnies and other wore Arts. No man can publih in Print, or communicate to his Friend any writing, which ome account excellent, but he preently meets with a Detractor who will prick, cut, and tear him mot cruelly. Now for a man to eek nothing ele by his Cares and Labours, but Envy and Vexation of Mind, is extream madnee.

Thee Caues have (I confes) hindred me from atisfying your frequent Requet; and beides, becaue I am not willing to determine of thoe things, which long experience of years cannot either prove, or ufficiently limit. Howbeit you continue your Requet, and I am much ahamed, alwaies to deny you. Alo a certain learned Man hath impoed a neceity upon me, in a manner, to dicover to others my opinion concerning the Motion of the Blood. For certain Thees having been diputed concerning the Motion ofThe occaion of this writing the Blood, my elf being Preident of the Dipute; though the Defendant truly profeeth in his aid Thees, that they are his own, yet he hath undertaken to tax and blame them, as if they were mine. And although that young man need not be ahamed of thoe Thees, yet I would not have another mans Thees, though diputed when I was Preident, to be accounted mine. Neither can he be ignorant of the Reaon, who is acquainted with my Liberty in Diputing, or the Cutome of our Univerity.
Now therefore take my Opinion of the Motion of the Blood, as follows.

That ome hot blood which leaps out of the great Arteries being opened isWhat Blood it is which is moved? thinner, more rare and of a more bright colour, than that which flows out of the Veins when they are opened: yet, I will not therefore ay, that the Arterial Blood differs formally from the Venal, Blood: for the Arterial Blood may differ as aforeaid from the Venal, becaue it comes reaking hot as it were from the fire, and abounds with greater tore of Spirits, as we ee boyling Milk differs from it elf being cooled, for the ame reaon: for that Blood which is in the maller Arteries, and o farther from the Heart, is oberved to differ les from the venal Blood. And when we have taken Blood out of the greater Arteries, yea, out of the Heart it elf of a living Creature, and from the ame Creature, have taken ome out of the Veins, and have let then, both grow cold and congeal, we could never oberve any difference betwixt them. So that we can ee no other, but that the Arterial Blood is of the ame kinde with the Venal.

Some few will have, that the venal Blood is of two kinds, one which is contained in the Vena cava, another in the Vena porta. But we cannot ee any difference of thee Bloods either when they are included in their veels, or when they are let out: and that Reaon doth teach as much we hall ee anon.

Beides thee, we may likewie conceive another ort of Blood, which being made of Chyle in the Liver, hath not received any further perfection in the Heart. And we are little concerned to know the Nature thereof, becaue we ee it continues uch but a very little while. So that we are to enquireThat it is only one kinde of blood. into the motion of only one ort of Blood.
Now the Blood may be moved either in that part of the Vein or Artery wherein it is contained, or out of that part into another.

In one part of a Vein or Artery, the Blood is not dicerned to move up andIt is not moved up and down in the Veels like boiled water. down, like boyling water, neither when it is received into a Veel, nor when let out of a living and hot Body; nor yet in the Artery it elf, if it being on either hand tied, hall be opened in the upper part betwixt the two Ligatures. Ye • , when we have many times cut off the point of a living Heart, and et it upright, we have found the Blood to be hot, but never to boyl.

But that the Blood is moved from one part of an Artery or Vein into another, isBut it is moved o • e of one part into another. a thing very manifet. For Blood is contained in the Veins of the furthet parts of the Body, which eeing it is not bred there, it mut needs come from ome other place. And it is evident enough, that in living Creatures, the Blood flows out of the Vena Cava into the Heart and out of the Heart into the Aorta.

But that this ame whole Motion of the Blood may be by us the better undertood,Which motion perfectly to undertan • , the motion of the Chylus mut be ought into. I conceive our bet way will be to begin at the very Fou • tain, and Original thereof.

I have often een olid Meat in Dogs hold the ame order in the Stomach, jut as it was eaten by the Beats; unles the Stomach being ditended with too much Drink, did make the Meat to float, and o to change its order and ituation.

The Meat which the Stomach receives, although it be but two ounces,That meat which is firt eaten hath the firt place in the Stomach. it evidently imbraces the ame round about; jut as we ee folded pures contract themelves about a Bullet or round Ball within them, alo the upper and lower Orifice are both hut: whichThe Stomach cloely embraces the ame. by making an hole near the ame, and putting in your little finger, it is eaie to try. But the lower Orifice notwithtanding, when we finde it perfectly hut, eems rather to be fallen together, than traitly cloed, that upon the mallet preure it may let the Chylus pas by. Alo many times when the Stomach and its Orifices are weak, they fail in their natural cloenes, and upon earching are found looer.

The meat retained in the Stomach, as thoroughly moitened with the LiquorIt is moitned with the moiture of the Stomach. of our food, Drink and Spittle: and it quickly becomes porous and Spungie: becaue as is mot likely the aid Liquor hath drawn out and uckt into it elf ome of the ubtance of the Meat.

A while after it is cut and torn as itIt is cut and minced by an acid humour. were into very mall particles, both that of thin and that of gros Subtance, yea, in Dogs the very hells themelves of Eggs: which doth quetionles proceed from ome acid harp humour that hath in it a diolving power. So we finde by experience that the Stomach burthened with the quantity or grones of meat, doth find it elf eaed, by taking a little Vinegar, Juice of Citrons, Oyl of Sulphur, or Vitriol. Nor let any man aign the Caue thereof to Spittle or Choler belching back into the Stomach, when he hall ee Bread teeped ome hours in hot Spittle or the Gall of an Ox, by them not diolved, moreover in an hundred Dogs or more which I have cut up on purpoe alive, I found Choler flowed back into the Stomachs of onely two of them, one of which had eaten nothing for three daies, and in his Stomach, which was wonderful to behold, there was a Cholerick froath o thick and full of bubbles, as that we ee on the Suds of uch as wah in Lye.

Now I conceive this acid humor comes from the Spleen into the Stomach, becaueWhich comes from the pleer. there is no other part in the body which we can perceive to be harp or acid: and becaue upon wallowing a bit of boyled Spleen epecially of a • ow, heavines of the Stomach proceeding from the Quantity or grones of Meats, is thereby holpen.

Thus the Meat being mixed in itsAfterward it is changed into Cream. mallet particles with the Liquor, in tract of time by concoction it comes to the conitence of thin Barley-cream: which when it hath attained, then at lat it is thrut into the Guts.

Howbeit all Meat doth net receiveTom. e • 3. • , •• nt •• t • r. this change in the Stomach in the ame
pace of tim • ; it is ooner performed in the day time, with a little meat thin of Subtance and well chewed; it requires a longer pace in the night, where there is tore of it, the meat is gros, and wallowed down in great bits: o that the meat which is well grinded with the Teeth, begins to be turned into Cream, when that continues yet olid, which was wallowed down in great bits.

Milk and Broaths in the day time are perfectly digeted in an hours pace orHow oon or late it is concoctèd and ditributed. ooner, and if omewhat ele hinder not, they are then alo ditributed; which the voiding of Urin alone, after them, doth evidently hew, without any Diection: Herbs are more lowly changed. Bread in repect of Digetion eems to be of a midling Subtance, we finde in the firt hour and half very little changed; in the following hour it is rare and light, jut like a wet Spunge; when that hour is pat, it is divided into very mall particles, and mixt o with the Drink, that all appears liquid, and oon after it is mot of all digeted, and at lat as much of the Braad as is digeted, between the fourth and fift hour after its eating, is by the Stomach forced through the Pylorus, into the Guts. But ome of the aid Bread taies behind, which by little and little is pertectly digeted, as alo if any other meat were eaten with the Bread of harder digetion than it: which meats I have oberved to be digeted in this order. Firt Beans and Peae, then Fih, then Fleh which is perfectly digeted and thrut out of the Stomach between the ixt and eventh hour: Beef between the eventh and eighth: yea, and the membranous parts of the Animals are longer in digetion, as alo the hells of Egs; I have een Bones that have abode in the Stomach unto the third day, during which pace they were become like Gritles.

Yea, and in the parts of thee very meats, oft times great variety is een, asAll at once or by piecemeal. of Bread and Fleh, though they eem whole in the Stomack, yet ome portion though very little, is ditributed ometimes the firt hour, unto the Milky Veins.

So that whatever is digeted, doth not at all expect the digetion of the ret, nor is taid by that which is undigeted, but preently lips out, and is carried into the Guts: yea, and you hall eldome finde a Dogs Stomach empty, although he have not eaten in ixteen hours before.
Now I could eaily make all thee Obervations in Dogs, which I cut up alive, at everal ditances after they had eaten their Meat.

In the Guts the Chyle is of an Ahcolour, and is eldome coloured by the yellownesBeing digested it is ditributed into the Guts and milky Veins. of Choler: and preently now from the Duodenum it begins to enter the milky Veins of Aellius, nor doth this entrance ceae in any of the Guts as long as any Chyle remains in the aid Guts, o that the Intetinum rectum or Are-gut it elf, is endued with milky veins, which are many times een to look white by the afflux of Chyle. And that we may not think that ame milkieSee the Figure of the milky Veins, pag. 563. juyce comes elewhere than from the Guts, I have bound thee milky Veins inerted into the Body of the Guts, and oberved that from the Cavity of the Guts to the Ligature they are evidently full and woln, but from the Ligature towards the Meentery they wax empty and fall in.

But the Chyle hath never been oberved to enter into any Vein in the body ofNot through the Meeraick veins the Stomach, nor any Meeraick Vein, nor yet the Blood being by the binding of Vena porta (whereof the reaon hall hereafter appear) exceedingly augmented in the Meeraick Veins, hath ever been • een to enter into the milky Veins. So that I cannot ee otherwie, but that Nature hath ord • ined the milky Veins only to carry Chyle, and the Stomach and Meeraick Veins only to carry Blood.
The Chyle in the milky Veins is alwaies though it proceed from Ah-colour'dAlwaies white. Chyle in the Guts or uch as is dyed yellow by Choler.

By thee Milky Veins the Chyle goesBy one Continued paage of the milky veins. upwards, after what manners, is not very eaie to ay. This eems to me mot probable, which I oberved in great and lean Greyhounds; that ome of the milkie Veins do go right on, to the Ramus Meentericus, ome into the Vena porta it elf, others into the hollow parts of the Liver, and very few do ometimes end in the Vena cava, near the Emulgents. For thee Animals have not that ingle kernel in the beginning of the Meentery, which Aellius hath termed Pancreas, and which is wont to obeure the paage of thee Veins; but they are furnihed in that place with maller kernels, for the mot part five in number, which being ditant by a man fet pace one from another, through that pace they afford free paage to ome milky Veins. But eeing that above thee kernels, there are fewer branches of the milky Veins (and ome of them greater) than beneath, I am apt to believe, that neer thoe kernels, the milky Veins are divided into branches, and that the aid kernels erve, as elewhere in the body, to accomodate the divarication or branching of Veels.
Sometimes alo I have been hewed milky Veins, which entred into theNot to the Spleen. Liver, but when in the preence of the Shewers, I accurately examin'd the matter, we found them to be Nerves.

The Chyle being carried throughBut to the Liver. thee milky Veins is mixed with the Blood in the Ramus Meentericus, in the Vena porta, and in the very Liver alo it elf: for in what place oever you tie the milky Veins, they alwaies well, becaue they are hindred from paing the Chyle to thee parts, and the Ligature being looed, they manifetly infue the ame into thoe parts.

The Branches of the Vena Porta in the Liver although in undry places they are knit to the branches of Vena Cava, yet are they never opened into a great branch of Vena Cava, but the mallet branches of Vena porta do transfue this Chyle mixt with Blood into the mallet branches of the Vena cava; as is eaie to oberve in the Liver blown up when the Fleh is taken off, and it wims in water. And that the ame happens to the ret of the Chyle mingled with the Blood, will be hereafter manifet. Out of the little branches of the Vena Cava in the Liver,Gut of the Liver into the Vena Cava. the Blood is in the Judgement of all men poured into the Vena Cava: and when in live Anatomies it is tied above the Liver, it manifetly wels with blood flowing in.

Out of the Vena Cava it enters intoOut of the Vena cava into the heart. the right Ventricle of the Heart, and either part of the Vena Cava being tied, either that which is eared above, or that which is below the Heart, I have many times oberved, epecially in an Eell, that it is quickly emptied towards the Heart which alo Harvey hath oberved chapter tenth of his Book.
Out of the right Ventricle of theOut of the right Ventricle of the Heart into Vena arterioa. Heart, it enters manifetly enough into the Vena arterioa, and by it into the Lungs.

But I dare not ay that any of the blood paeth out
of the right Ventricle of the Heart, by the partition wall, <…> the left Ventricle thereof, eeing I find open paages elwhere, but none in this place. Purut Gaendus a General ScholarBut not through the Sep •••• inter
•… tium or partition of the Heart and of a candid Spirit, in his Exercitations upon Fluds Philoophy part 3. chap. 1 • . relates how he had een Payanus hew the Partition wall of the Heart to be tranpaable, by undry crooked and turning paages: and that they might be found out, if putting a Probe gently into one of the pits, you hall mot leafurely thrut it upwards and downwards and to one ide, and till eek a further paage till you meet with the end thereof. And the truth is I have divers times found it to ucceed as he aies; but I have withall oberved, that thoe waies and turning paages, were not at all made by Nature, but by the Probe or point of a Penknie, while we open a way already made, and eek one farther: for the Fleh of the Heart is o tender and withall o conitent, that with the mallet touch of any thing that can bo • e, it is preently broken, and leaves a Cavity; o that we may alo after this manner, find paages through the ides of the Heart.

That the Blood being entred by the Vena arterioa into the Lungs, doth returnO •• of the Vena arterioa into the Arteria venoa and the left Ventricle of the Heart. through the Arteria Venoa unto the Left Ventricle of the Heart, I do hereby collect, in that having bound the greater branch of the Arteaia Venoa (in a live Anatomy) neer the Pericardium or Heart-bag, we have een it grow hard and well towards the circumference of the Lungs, that part being emptiod and falling in which looks towards the Heart, and when the Ligature was looed, we aw the Blood move to the left Ventricle of the Heart: and this is very eaily oberved in Rabbies. Now this Blood, becaue it can come from no other place, mut needs come from the Vena arterioa hither.

Leonardus Botallus a mot learned Man, at the end of his Book de Catarrho, uppoeth he hath found another way, by which the Blood may continually goe, out of the right, into the left Ventricle of the Heart. A little above the coronal Artery (aith he) I found a paage viible enough, nèar the right Earlet, which • goes immediately and right forth into the left Earlet.

This paage unles it be the progres of the Vena cava to the Vena arterioa, But not through the foramen ovale. which we call Foramen ovale, or another paage which I have omtimes found in a Sheeps Heart, as big as a Wheat traw, going with a crooked paage from one Earlet to another; unles, I ay, it were one of thee, I know not what for a paage it was.

And as for that Ovale foramen Eg-fahion'd-hole, it is not every where alike hut up, and oftentimes there is a very thin and tranparent little Membrane growing in the middle thereof, which with the mallet touch of a Probe is eaily broken, but it is very eldom upon any occaion found open, in grown perons. And the Blood flowing through the Arteria Venoa out of the Lungs, doth faten the Membrane placed before that hole, o that even when it doth not grow to, hardly any thing can pas that way.

But that ame oblique paage which I have een in a Sheeps heart, doth many times pierce deep into the ubtance of the Earlet, but is very eldom carried into the other Earlet. And I conceive it was given the Earlet for its Nutrition, it not being wont to receive branches from the Coronaria.

Now from uch things as eldom happen, we cannot conclude any thing touching thoe things that contantly come to pas: for Nature frequently ports her elf in the Fabrick of the Heart. So in the Septum Intermedium or partition wall of an Oxes Heart, in the upper part according to the length of the Heart, ometimes I have found a Cavity, opening at the left Ventricle, about the point, which was as long and large as a mans Fore-finger. The like whereunto poibly Aritotle aw, when in his 3. de partibus Chap. 4. he aith the greater ort of Animals have three Ventricles in their Heart. For the greatet Animals that are, have but two Ventricles, as I oberved in the Diection of a young Whale.
So that the Blood cannot be thought to go ordinarily any other way, then through the Lungs into the left Ventricle of the Heart.

The Blood being thus caried into theAnd thence into the Heart, the Arteria aorta, and the ret of mall Arteries. left Ventricle of the Heart, goes from thence to the Arteria aorta, the middle and mallet Arteries: for they being bound in living Anatomies, do wonderfully well towards the Heart, and towards the extream parts they fall in, and the Ligature being looed, they evidently end the Blood to the remoter parts of the Body.

The Blood out of the maller ArteriesOut of the Arteries the Blood by commen mouths. may enter into the Veins; for the Arteries have a way open into the Veins, by the common mouths of one opened into another,. And to the intent we might be ure that Blood may pas by thoe mouths, we have freed the Vein and Artery in the Foot of a dead Dog, from uch things as are wont to hinder their being een, and we emptied the greater crural Vein, and bound it in the flank, leat any Blood might flow in that way, and in the Knee we bound both this Vein and its neighbouring Artery: and then with our fingers we forced the Blood in the Iliack Arteries, as far as to the Knee, and o we emptied the crural Artery, but the crural Vein we aw manifetly replenihed; and eeing into the Vein tied above and beneath nothing could come or a very little out of its branches and yet it was much filled, and the Artery quite emptied; we did gather that the Blood wherewith the Vein was filled, was driven by the little mouths out of the emptied Arteries, into the aid Vein.

And that this Opinion is not new Galen Known to the Ancients. himelf hews in his 5. chap. de Uu pulus. The Conjunctions of the mouths of the Veins and Arteries are not viible to our Eyes: and if you hall jutly refue to believe them as not credible enough, you may be brought by other reaons dellvered by the Ancients to believe there are uch things: and not a •• l • by this plain token, that in cae a Man hall take any of thoe Creatures in whom the Veins and Arteries are manifet, as an Ox, an Hog, an As, an Hore, a Sheep, a Bear, a Libard, an Ape • or a Man himelf, and open many large Arteries in the aid Creature, he may draw all the Blood in its Body out through the aid Arteries. I have divers times experimented the ame, and finding alwaies that the Veins are emptied with the Arteries, I did perwade my elf that the Opinion was true concerning the common mouths of the Veins and Arteries, and of the common paage of the Blood from one to another. Yea it is a received and common opinion, that the Arterial blood doth naturally enter into the mallet Veins, to the end that the part might be nourihed with arterial and venal Blood.
And that indeed and in truth theGoes into the Veins. Blood doth naturally pas in living Creatures, out of the Arteries into the Veins by thoe little mouths, thee igns do cleenly witnes.

He that in living Diections hallAs the tore of Blood ent into the parts doth h •• . conider that Quantity of Blood, which by the Arteries is conveighed to the parts and Veins, can hardly perwade himelf to think, that it is all conumed in nourihing the parts: epecially if he hall conider that the Arterial Blood is thick enough, and not a fourth part thinner than the Venal blood, as I have often ob ••• ed when I have uffred both of them to grow cold and <…> whence
we may jutly conclude with Harvey, that the Blood which is communicated from the Arteries to the Veins and Parts, does a great part of it, return back again to the large Veins.

Moreover, when we open a vein in a bound Arm, if you pres thatThe preing a Vein below the orifice in Blood-letting. part of the welling Vein with your Thumb which is neer the orifice, betwixt it and the Hand, or if you make uch a ligature as the former betwixt the Hand and the Orifice, you hall ee that no blood will come forth; whence it eems to follow, that the blood comes from the Hand, which flows from the orifice. And eeing ome pounds of Blood are drawn away by uch a Blood-letting, and o much cannot be contained in the lower part of the Veins of the Arm, it mut needs come thither from the Arteries, which are not topped by that Ligature above the orifice, as their Pule remaining entire doth tetifie.

But that we might ee the ame with our Eyes, we have divers times inThe Ligature of a vein in living Anatomies. great living Dogs, freed the large Vein and Artery in the groyn, from uch things as did hinder their ight; which may be eaily done if they lie not beneath the Mucles: and we bound the aid vein with a thred, and we oberved that part of the Vein which looked towards the Vena cava to empty and fall in, and the other part towards the Foot exceedingly to wel, o that in regard of its fullnes, it eemed harder than the Artery it elf; but the ligature being looed, the Blood preently moved upwards, and the fullnes and hardnes of the Vein was very much abated. And the Artery being bound, that part thereof did wonderfully well, which was nearet Aorta, and the other part more remote did fall in through emptines: nor did the Vein then bound evidently well. And this we did many times and the effect was till the ame.

And that we might have no cruple remaining, and might oberve withall,Diection of a Vein in living Creatures. what was done within in the Vein, we did lift up the Vein and Artery being thus made bare, and under them we firmly bound the Thigh it elf, that the Blood might not move upwards or downwards, by any other Vein • ave that which we had lift up. The • the Vein being held up, and alo hut with a Thred, as is expreed in this Figure, we opened it above and below the Thred with a mall orifice. Now immediately from that part of the Vein which was farthet from the Heart, the Blood flew out violently plentifully, and in a full tream. but that part of the Vein which was on the other ide of the thred towards the Heart, did only drop out a few drops. whence it eemed to us to be a cleer cae, that the Blood did not come downwards from the greater Veels, but upwards out of the maller Veels into the greater. Epecially when having made another Ligature upon the ame Vein further from the Heart, betwixt the foreaid Orifice and the Foot of the Beat, we aw no blood at all come from that Orifice, whence before it iued with uch violence. For we conceived thoe drops which ell from the Orifice neer the Heart, might proceed from Blood which poibly was in the Vein when it was opened, or which it might continually receive from ome mall Branch of the crural Vein ituate above the thred; but this caue will anon appear more evidently.

It is eaie to make this experimentThe emptying of the Veins appearing in the Skin. without any opening of a Vein in uch perons as have the Veins of their Arms very Conpicuous: In whom if you top the Vein near the Hand with one Finger, and with your other hand force the blood upwards, and the whole Vein wil appear empty •
which wil oon after be filled, when you take away your lower Finger, but not if you take only your upper; as Harvey alo oberved in the 13. Chapter of his Book. For the upper Blood goes into the greater Veins, and the Valve hinders it from decending, which will hardly let anything pas by, unles the vein be o far widened, that a great pace remain between it and the Valves.

Seeing therefore the Blood comes out of the Hands and Feet, and they do not breed new Blood, o as to upply the whole Body therewith, we doubt not but that the Blood in thoe parts continually and naturally goes into the Veins, and out of the leer Veins into the greater.

div.p: Nor do I fear that the Arterial Blood cannot be contained in the ingle coat of a Vein, which I ee contained in the mallet little Arteries, and in an Aneurima, where the Artery hath but one coat. And whereas the Arteries neer the Heart have a double Coat, that might be o contrived, leat by violence of the Blood iuing out of the Heart, the Artery might be looned; as we ee it looened by a trong palpitation of the Heart.

But doth not the Blood flow as out of the Arteries, o out of theBut the Blood doth not come out of the greater Veins into the leer. greatet Veins into the leer? This that kind of Blood-letting eems to argue, which is ordained for Revulion ake: for the Vein of the Arm being opened in a Pleuriie, that Blood eems to be revelled or drawn back, which flowed out of the Vena cava into the Azygos, and out of the Azygos into the Pleura. But there is noSevulory Bloodletting doth not argue it. token that the blood is o revelled; for the Bailica Vein being opened the blood may be drawn out of the Arteries of the Arm; the Arteries of the Arm draw out of the axillary Artery, the Axillaris out of the Aorta, by whoe intercotal branches it had flowed into the Thigh, and not by the twigs of Azygos, as we hall ee by and by. And doubtles, except in the Pleuriie, the blood hould be revelled through the Arteries, there were no reaon to be given why we hould for Revul • ions ake rather open the Vein of the ide affected, then that on the right ide alwaies; ince the Azygos aries from the right ide of the Vena cava, and that a Vein to be opened for Derivation is to be opened on that ide through which the blood flows into the part affected.

But what hal we ay? Doth not the Arm after a ort grow lean and fall awayNor the Arms falling away occaioned by a Ligature. (and o other parts) when it is bound, as in thoe who have it hollowed in a Fitula? becaue the Vein being bound, the blood cannot decend as it ought, unto the lower parts of the Arm? There is no neceity that it hould be o. For all that may happen becaue the Artery is bound. And really, this is an Argument that it is o, in that many times that Arm in which there is an Iue, is perceived to pule les and more faintly than the other; the influx of the blood and pirits, being in ome meaure hindred, by the the binding of the Iue. Yet ome part may peradventure fall away by binding of a Vein alone; becaue Nature cannot plentifully infue new blood through the Artery, eeing it cannot freely go back by the Veins. And though the Veins and Arteries do then contain tore of Blood, yet is it peradventure not very fit to nourih the parts as they hould be, but this wil better appear hereafter.

It is nevertheles manifet, that in uch as have the Varices o called, theNor the Varices. blood decends from the Vena cava to the greater, and out of the greater into the leer Veins. For that is eaie to ee in a Varix of the Thigh and Foot, and in the Haemorrhoids. But that motion of Blood may happen beides Nature, becaue the Veins being weakned do not end the Blood upwards, but gather the ame; and becaue the humors by that weight, do reit the Natural motion upwards, and decend, and therefore being collected in great Quantity in the lower Veins, new Blood till coming out of the Arteries; they caue their dilatation and conequently a Varix. Thus artificial Fountains about thoe places from which they acend, are mot frequently oberved to make clefts, being at lat drawn aunder and torn by the Heavines of the Water, which ought nevertheles according to the Nature of Fountains to acend upwards. And it is altogether mot likely that Varices are caued after this manner: becaue humors in uch as have Varices, do not inlarge the Vein, when they are violently moved in exercie, but when they have reted after exercie; becaue the humors can reit a maller motion and decend by their own weight.

So that thee are not tokens, that theBut it flows ••• of the maller veels into the Vena cava. Blood goes out of the greater Veins into the leer, but they argue rather that the Blood goes out of the Arteries into the Veins, and out of the leer Veins into the greater, and the Vena cava it elf.

We aid before that the Blood goesOut of the Vena cava to the Heart again. out of the Vena cava into the right ventricle of the Heart. But what! Doth that very elf ame Blood, which a little before had come out of the Vena cava into the Heart, and out of the Heart was hed into the Arteries, and from thence had returned into the Veins, doth that enter again into the Heart? or doth that alone which being newly bred in the Liver doth the firt time enter into the Vena cava, and hath never yet pat through the Heart? Truly both.

For that may eaily be done, eeingYea that Blood which hath already pat the Heart. both are alike near to the Heart: and it ought to be done; eeing that which is returned out of the Arteries into the Cava, is more plentifull than that, which is all of it conumed in the nourihment of the Vena cava, and that is not carried to the leer Veins. Doubtles it is a ign that this is o, in that a Vein being tied nea • the Heart, is not only a little but very much emptied, and ends all the Blood it hath, and not only ome to the Heart.

Alo the Heart eems to hed moreBecaue the Meat affords not o much Blood as the Heart paeth through. Blood into the Arteria aorta, then the Liver can upply it withall, at leat not in ome daies fating. For I have divers times experimented that in many perons the Heart pules above three thouand times in an hour. And the Heart as long as it hath any vigour left, expels omwhat at every pulation: for the Arteria aorta being bound near the Heart, between the Heart and the Ligature, I opened the aid Artery, and I aw ome Blood come out at every pule; till the Heart grew quite to languih, for then omwhat came away after three or four pules only: becaue o little was thrut from the Heart, that it could not be moved upwards till ome quantity of it was collected, nor pas out at the upper orifice of the Artery.

Alo I cut off the tip of an Heart and etting the ame upright, I oberved though the Ventricles were not full, at every pule omwhat was hed forth; which alo Harvey notes in his 2. Chapter. Yea and when the Heart is cut through the middle, there ceaed not to come omwhat out, till either the Beat died, or the Blood congealed o in the upper part, as to make a kind of mall Skin, o that the Blood could flow no more that way. And certainly omwhat mut needs come out of the Heart at every pule, becaue there in the Heart is alwaies made more trait, as hall afterward appear.

Now, how much comes from the Viz. about half an ounce at every pule. Heart at every pule, we cannot determine. this I can witnes, that out of the Heart of a Rabbit there hath come at every pule half a dram of blood, and out of the Heart of a great Water-paniel half an ounce: yet I conceive more comes out, when a live Creature is Diffected, than when it is in health. And if a man would determine by conjecture from what we have een, how much may come out of the Heart of a Man in health at every pule, I hall not be againt them who ay that out of the Heart of a Man at every pule half an ounce of Blood is hed into the Arteria aorta.

Butlet us uppoe it is but a cruple; eeing the Heart makes above three thouand pules in one hour, there mut above ten pound of blood pas every hour through
the Heart, which is more than we eat, and more than the Liver can upply the Heart withall.

So that mut needs be, that the Blood which hath once pat theSo that the Blood <> circularly. Heart, mut flow thither again, and from it return again into the Arteries. So that there is a circular motion of the Blood, from the Vena cava into the Heart, from the Heart into the Arteries, from the Arteries into the Veins, out of which it returns again into the Heart, and thence into the Arteries.

Truly, I cannot ufficiently wonder, that in o many Ages pat, thisWhich motion of the Blood was not unknown to the Ancients. motion of the Blood hath been unknown, eeing I find undry, and thoe no mall intimations thereof in the ancient Writers.

In the Volume of the Works of Hippocrates, The Author of the firt Book de Victus ratione, attributes three circular motions to our Heat and Humors, whereby they are moved inward and outward from divers parts.

Hippocrates in the middle of his Book de Oium Natura, The Veins
To Hippocrates in Foëtins Edi •• on pag. 344. (under which he comprehends the Arteries) being pred aith he, through the Body, do caue a fluxion and motion, ending many branches from one. And pag. 277. this one, whence it hath its original and where it ends I cannot find. For it keeps in a circular coure, o that you can find no beginning. and it will appear plainly to him that examins the place, that he undertands this Circle to be chiefly in the ditribution of the Humors.
As alo in the End of his Book de Na • ura humana. The great Veins do mutually afford pag. 229. nourihment one to another the internal to the external, and then again to the internal.

And more plainly the Author of the Book de alimen •• . There is one beginning of all that nourih, and one end of all and the ame is the beginning and the End: and therefore a little after he ubjoyns thee words: The Aliment <> into the Hair and Nails, and from the inner parts into the outer Surface; from the external parts the nourihment comes from the outer urface to the mot inward parts: there is one conflux, one conpiration and one conent of all.

And Diogenes Apolloni •• a eems not toTo Diogi ••• Apolloniata. have differed from this Opinion, in Aritotle his 3 de Hitoria Animalium chap. 2. The mut thick Blood is ucks by the flehy parts, and that which redounds into thee places viz. the greater <> , becomes thin, hot, and fro •• hy.
