div.p: Yea and thoe things which Plato in his Timaeus delivers concerning the Blood, areTo Plato. more utable to this Opinion than the common.

Aritotle himelf may eaily be drawn toTo Aritotle. this Opinion. For thus aith he in his Book de Somno chap. 3. Every i • ability of Sene is not leep, but that only which is caued by the v • poration of Meats, for that which is rarified, mut needs after a ort be lifted up, and afterward return and flow back like an Euripus: for the Heat of every Animal, mut needs naturally move upwards, and when it is come aloft, it oon after circulates and dicends again.

It is to be feared, that thoe Writers which followed the former did not ufficiently tudy the motion of the blood, yea that they ob • cured the ame, becaue what the former attributed to their Veins, that is to ay the Veins and Arteries, thee later attributed to the Veins in oppoition to, and as ditinct from the Arteries. And eeing Galen a mot excellent Phyitian, was not able to reform all things perfectly: and the later Greeks, Arabians, and Latines, have too cloe followed or trancribed him, hence I uppoe it is, that this motion of the blood hath remain'd concealed till this preent Age.

Wherein that incomparable Paulus Servita the Venetian, did acuratelyBut in this Age found out •… h by Paulus Servita. oberve the Fabrick of the Valves in the Veins, which Obervation of his that great Anatomit Fabritius ab Aquapendente afterwards publihed, and out of that contitution of the Valves and other Experiments he collected this motion of the Blood, and aerted the ame in an excellent Treat e, which I undertand is preerved to this very day amongt the Venetians.

The mot learned William Harvey being taught by the foreaid Paulus Servita, did more accurately earch into this motion of the Blood, augmented the ame with Inventions of his own, proved it trongly, and publih'd it to the World in his own name.
Such hath been the Invention and uch the Fate of this motion of the Blood.

And let us now further enquire, whether through all the Veins and Arteries Publih'd in Print by William Harvey. the Blood hath this Motion or whether in ome others it hath ome other motion? Concerning which thing, that I might be more certainly informed, I contemplated the motion of the Blood in many Veins and Arteries of liveing Creatures, and I have found, beides what hath been already aid of the Veins and Arteries of the Arms and Legs, that theNow this motion is made through all the Arteries and Veins of the Body. blood is moved through the Spermarick Arteries to the Stones; through the Veins from the Stones to the left Emulgent or Vena cava in the right ide: through the Meenterick Arteries, to the Guts: through the Veins to the
• am • s meentericus: through the Caeliack Arteries to the Spleen; through the Ramus plenicus of Ve • a porta forthwith to the Liver: through the branches of the Arteria caeliaca, which anwer to the following Veins to the Stomach and Call; through the Gatrick and Epiploick Veins, to the Ramus plenicus: that the hort Arterial and Venal Veels, are branches of the caeliacal Artery and the Vena plenica, which when they are come unto the middle pace, betwixt the Stomach and the Spleen, are divided into two branches one of which goes to the Stomach, the other to the Spleen; by this branch of the Artery the Blood goes to the Spleen, and by the branch of the Stomach to the Stomach; and by the venal branches to the Trunk of Vas breve, from the Stomach and the Spleen it is moved through the emulgent Arteries to the Vena cava: by the coronal Artery of the Heart into the Vein; out of the coronal vein of the Heart, into the Vena cava: by the Intercotal Arteries into the Pleura; out of the
<>
by the Veins into the Azygos, and thence into Vena cava And this I found by binding the Veins and Arteries <> live Anatomies; which did well in that part which di • look towards thoe parts, from which we have hewed the coure of Blood to come, and the other parts did not only grow empty but quite ettle and fall in. And I was very careful, not to bind an Artery with a Vein, for then the Artery welling towards the Heart, would have ra ed the Vein above it, and o it would have eemed that the Vein was filled on both ides the Ligature.

Now in the Head and Neck I aw, and that in a live Gooe mot eailyYea of the Head. and in an Hen, that the jugular being tied, did well from the Head towards the Ligature, and was emptied from the Ligature towards the Cava, o that it is there alo man fet, that the Blood returns from the Head through the Veins into the Heart. But if it hould come to the jugular veins I cannot determine, ince by reaon of the hardnes of the Skull, I could not accurately diect the living Brain, but that the Beat would firt die: but credible it is nevertheles, that it flows through the carotick and cervical Arteries unto the four Ventricles of the Brain, for they have paages open to the aid Ventricles, For thoe mot learned Men Francicus Sylvius and Franc. Vander Shagen, have told me, that the fibrous ubtance being pul'd away which frequently is found congealed in the Veins and Arteries of dead bodies; when it was drawn back in the carotick Artery, it dicovered a certain motion, as far as to the third Ventricle of the Brain, and veri • y, ince the blood out of the Ventricles, through the jugular veins, flows back into the Heart, the Ventricles cannot receive it elewhere, then from the Arteries. But whether the Arteries do hed it immediately into the Ventricles, or into the branches which arie from the Ventricles, is not very eaily dicerned becaue the Arteries, are hardly ditinguihed from thoe little branches, eeing the Arteries alo have only one Coat in the Brain: but I am apt to beleive, that the Arteries empty their blood, into thoe little branches of the Ventricles, rather then into the Ventricles themelves; becaue I have oberved thoe veels which are inerted into the Ventricles to be greatet near the ventricles, as branches are wont to be at their Original.

And thus it is in grown perons; but in the Child in the Womb, the CirculationYea in the Child in the Womb. eems to be omewhat otherwie, and thus I conceive it is. The Blood out of the Mothers Womb, does not go into the Umbilical Arteries, which according to the Obervation of Arantius, are not joyned to the Womb; but it enters into the Umbilical Vein, and from thence into the Liver, the Vena cava, and right Ventricle of the Heart; for the Heart beats in the Child though it be imperfect. Out of the right Ventricle it goes into the Vena arterioa; but becaue the Lungs do not breath, and therefore are not opened, they cannot receive the blood plentifully, no • end it to the Arteria venoa; and therefore it goes out of the Vena arterioa by a peculiar paage into the Aorta, and likewie by a peculiar paage or hole of the Vena cava getting into the Arteria venoa, 'tis poured into the left Earlet of the Heart, and into the left Ventricle thereof. Out of the left Ventricle of the Heart, jut as that out of the Vena Arterioa, it enters into the Arteria Aorta; o that in the Womb-child Nature ueth the two Ventricles for one, leat in the Child in the womb, which ought to have much but no intene heat, and which mut not be dry, the Blood being twice boyled hould be burnt, being detitute of the cooling and Fanning action of the Lungs. Out of the Art •• ia Aorta the Blood-goes to the Umbilical Arteries; for they being bound, the part towards the Child, doth pule and well: the other part towards the Womb is void of pulation. Out of the Umbilical Arteries it goes to the Placenta or Womb-cake; where the
Arteries are joyned to the Veins by manifet. Anatomoes, and by thoe Anatomoes the blood entring into the Vein, is again carried through all the forementioned journey.

Thee are the Veels by which the blood flows from the Heart. But fromIt goes out of the Arteries into the Veins. the Veel of the Arteries it goes into the Veins after a double manner; firt and mot uually by Anatomoes, by which the Arteries are joyned to the Veins,By Anatomoes. which Anatomoes are ometimes great and in the greater Veels as about the Spleen, in the Bladder, in the Womb, in the Womb-liver. And the mot accurate B • lerus oberves the like Anatomois of the Arteria Aorta into the Vena cava of the Belly, but I could never yet be o happy as to finde it in the Body of Man or Beat. And therefore they are not all in the extream parts of the Body, but ome in the middle parts: and therefore we ee in a Cripple whoe limbs are cut off, the ame motion of the blood continued out of the Arteries into the Veins. Secondly it eems alo poible that Blood may pas out of the Arteries intoAnd through the Fleh. the Veins, through the fleh it elf: for we ee when a Vein is opened till the colour change, Inflamations fall, becaue the Blood hed out of the Veels, is drawn out of the Fleh. But I conceive the paage of the Blood this way is but eldome and in mall quantity.

So that it is now, I conceive, clear, what the motion of the Blood is, and byAnd that motion of the Blood. what waies it is accomplihed: it follows that we enquire, what kind of motion it is, and how it is performed.

I have oberved that this Motion ofIs continual. the Blood out of the Heart into the Veins, from the Veins into the Heart, is continual never cleaing, nor once topped or interrupted for a moment of time. And the truth is, eeing the aid motion is made, as we hall ee anon, becaue the Heart receives and tranmits, and eeing this motion lats perpetually all the life long, the aid motion of the blood, cannot but naturally be continuall.

Alo the motion of the Blood is quick, for an Artery or Vein being bound compreed, it immediatelyQuick. wells and grows round and hard: and when the ligature and compreure are taken away, the blood is een to be wiftly moved.

But how oon the blood performs its Circuit from the Heart and toSo that the whole Circuit or round is performed in les than a quarter of an hour. the Heart again, I cannot preciely determine. We oberve it is done ooner by an Anatomois near the Heart, than by one off; nor will I be much againt him that hall ay the greatet Circuit from the remotet parts of the body is performed in les than a quarter of an hour; for the blood paeth with exceeding celerity. Howbeit it goeth not o wiftly, as we ee it leap out when a vein or Artery is opened, becaue then it is moved in the free and open Air; but within the body it is compreed to lift up its veels, and to thrut on the foregoing blood.
And therefore we ee an Artery being cut open epecially if near the heart, is ooner emptied than the heart can upply it with new blood.

But if this be true, why do Feavers return once in a quarter of an hour,Nor do the Fits of Agues argue any other. eeing the Fit eems then to happen, when the corrupt matter comes to the heart? whereas now ome fits come every day, others every third, and ome every fourth day. Truly, I will not deny, that it may fall out, that when the Corrupt matter comes to the heart, the Fit may happen, as Harvey hath an example thereof, in the 16 chapter of his Book. But I do not think it is neceary, for ome portion may lip out of the corrupt Seminary, or ome ooty tream may arie, and go into the heart and o raie the Feaver, as mot Feavers are een to arie from the Inflammation of the Parts, which the Impothume being opened and the Quittor removed, do ceae. And as uch kinde of ymptomatick Feavers, even o alo may ome intermitting Feavers and Agues happen, by reaon of • ome matter hut up, within or without the Veels, which by putrifying every day, every third day, or every fourth day, regurgitating or fuming into the large Veels, may bring the Fit.

In continual Feavers I confes, whoeNor the Exacerbations of Feavers. matter is to tick to the larger veels, it is harder to hew a reaon why there hould not be a Fit or Exacerbation at every Circuit of the blood. But I conceive I may alledg the ame caue which is vulgarly given, why continual Feavers are not allwaies alike feirce; becaue, though the matter be ufficiently near the Heart, yet it doth not caue a Paroxim till it have attained a certain degree of putrifaction: and that the Fit lats o long, till that putrid matter be evacuated, which touches the Heart, or ends its Fumes thereto. But I uppoe no man, becaue of the reaon of the return of Ague-fits, which is altogether abtrue and unknown, will deny the motion of the blood to be very quick, which is a very manifet thing.

Beides wiftnes, the blood hath vehemence in its motion, which appearsThis motion is alo vehement. from what we have aid touching the Hardnee and Tenion or tretching, which the Veins and Arteries acquire when they are bound: for nothing can be ditended by a liquid Subtance into an extream hardnes epecially upwards, unles it be vehemently driven thereinto or retained therein. But this vehemence, of motion is chiefly near the Heart,Not of like vehemence in the Arteries and Veins. removed from which it grows by degrees leer and leer, o that the little Arteries in the remote parts, do not pule, unles ome impule of blood greater than ordinary do happen, as we oberve to happen in Feavers, therefore it is that the Veins are not een to pule, becaue the impule of the Blood is les in them than it is in the mallet Arteries; and becaue the Veins • oyned to the Arteries by Anatomois, when they go from them, divide themelves into more little branches and twigs than the Arteries do, for when Rivers are divided into divers Arms the force of the waters motion is abated. And therefore when ome Arms of a Vein are hut, either by omething preing them, as in certain Tumors, or omewhat which tops them, as in the Varices, the blood lipping back by its own weight, the force of the bloods motion is then again oberved, and the Veins are een to pule: for I have often oberved in the Veins which are tranparent through the Skin, that mot of thoe palpitations in the parts, which are thought to proceed from Winds, are nothing ele but the puations of the veins.

And becaue the motion is more vehementYet the ame Quicknes in both. in the Arteries than in the Veins, it eems at firt ight to be wifter alo in the Arteries than in the Veins jut as Men, Hores, and other Animals which move themelves with great labour, and through mitake judged many times to make the greater peed. For the Blood forced through the Arteries cannot all pas through the Anatomoes, becaue it comes out of a wide place into a narrow, and therefore it is accumulated in the Arteries, they are dilated, in which dilation they perit a mall time, wherefore in the middle of the dilation and in the whole time of the ret, that ame force doth very little further the quicknes of the bloods motion, which motion is in the mean time
more free in the veins, becaue it comes out of a trait into a wide place, and is performed by more wayes. Now Reaon doth teach us in this Cae, that in this motion of blood, the wiftnes hereof mut be alike in the Arteries and the Veins; for as much blood as the Liver ends to the heart made of new Chyle, and as much nourihment as the Arteries give to the parts, mut be repayed, or the Heart will at lat be void of all moiture, which thing alo ene confirms, for the Vena cava pules o often, in that whole Tract from the Liver to the Jugulum, and therefore drives into the heart, as the Artery is oberved to pule and therefore to receive from the heart. But we hall hereof peak more anon.

Howbeit in the Arteries themelves, the blood is moved moreYet of greater quicknes when the Heart beats. aimbly when the Heart drives it; from which Quicknes it departs by little and little, when the Heart begins to ret and is afterwards dilated. Yea and in the Veins themelves, the motion of blood is more vehement and quick when the Heart pules; which as we have oberved in live Anatomies, o have we often noted the ame, when a Vein hath been opened in the Arm, in which the Veins were not much ditended with the Ligature. Alo the foreaid palpitations of the Veins, eem to proceed from no other caue then that the Veins being traitned by the Blood liding back, or by ome other means, when the blood cannot by its force make it elf way, it lifts the Vein up, which falls again, when that forcible endeavour is abated or the Vein gives a freer paage to the Blood flowing through the ame.

But I do not conceive that the blood which is once carried, forOne portion of blood doth not allwayes go the ame way. examples ake to crural Veins, is continually carried the ame wayes, but that when it is returned to the Heart, it is mixt with that blood which comes out of other parts, and is o promicuouly ditributed to the parts of the Body: for o the parts may be the better nourihed, if they have alwayes new blood, out of which they may draw, that which may bet erve to nourih and trengthen them: o Plants do bet grow, when they are tranplanted into new Soils.
This is the whole Manner of the Bloods motion: and alo ofThe Vital Spirits are moved with the Blood. the motion of the Vital Spirits, eeing they are mingled with the Blood.

I have often endeavoured toThe Animal Spirits motion through the Nerves cannot be oberved. earch out the motion of the Animal Spirits, but I could not eiewhere oberve it ave in the Mucles, which eemed to them to be ditended broadwayes and deepwayes, and being cut aunder to tremble and pant. For the Nerves being bound neither well nor are they extended, and being cut in under they hew no other motion, ave that they contract themelves. And it is a very eaie matter to bind the Nerves of the ixt pare, which freely wander through the Chet.

But the motion of the Chyle through the milkie Veins, is motBut the motion of the Chylus eaily through the milkie Veins. manifet. Now it is not o continual as that of the Blood, becaue there is not alwayes a upply of Chylus. And when it wandersWhat kind of motion that i • . out of the Guts through the milkie Veins, it goes quicker than the Blood it elf, and the Veins being bound do well immediately. And therefore they do not long appear in live Anatomies, nor are they found in dead Carcaes; unles ome obtacle do hinder the motion of the Chyle. And in that being bound they do not o well as to grow hard, it eems to be a Sign that the motion of the Chyle, i • not o vehement as that of the Blood: peradventure becaue • h • Chyle is to be moved through a maller pace, the • ike violence of motion was not requiite.
But it is now time to enquire intoThe Caue of the Bloods motion. the Caues of thee motions, and firt of the motion of the Blood.
Whatever the Caue is, either it mut be moved by •• inbred vertue of faculty, or by ome motion which mut •• referred to carrying, drawing, or thruting.

That the Blood is moved in this manner by its own proper Vertue, weIs not an i • b ••• power thereof. cannot oberve, either from the Blood received in a Bain or hed into the body, which that it hould be in a moment corrupted is hard to ay: nor can we ee uch a pontaneous motion •• any inanimate thing. And whereas Harvey relates Chap. 4. that when the Earlet was till, he oberved the motion of the Blood; I likewie have oberved the ame, and likewie when the Heart was quiet; but withall, that motion was imparted to the Blood from the Vena ca •• , and that in the Heart from the Earlet, as we hall ee anon.

That the Blood is here carried by theNor is the blood carried by the Spirits. Spirits cannot by any Argument be proved: and they by their lightnes hould move the Blood upwards, which we ee here to be moved downwards and idewayes.
And therefore it remains that either the blood mut be drawn or thrut.

That the blood is thrut forwards,Nor is it voided by reaon of rar •
faction only. Men of excellent wits do conceive, becaue the Hearts heat immeaurably rarifying the ame, it requires a greater place, and that therefore it dilates and lifts up the Heart; and eeing it cannot be contained in the dilated Heart, it is poured with uch violence into the Vena Anterioa, and the Arteria Aorta, that it ditends all the Arteries and makes them pule. And they bring this Argument for their Opinion, that the Heart of an Eel or any other Animal when it leaves puling, if it be warmed by Fire held under it, it is een to pule again. But whether may not that pule happen, becaue the Spirit being by that heat made more luty, can better ait that caue which moves the pule in the Heart; jut as, when the Guts and Mucles are heated in a live Diection, in which nevertheles there is no ebullition, the motion eem to be retored. For there is indeed only a certain light Rarifaction proceeding from a certain warmth in the Heart; no ebullition or udden diffuion. And truly I have often een in trong Do • s, that the Blood doth n •• leap out of the Heart by reaon of Rarifaction; wh ••• Heart the tip being cut off; when through the Efflux of blood it was not half filled, being et upright, it was nofilled by rarifaction: but the Contriction following, that portion of blood which was left in the Heart, was pirt •• out above four Foots ditance, o that my elf and others by me (for many were preent) were bepattered there with, whence it is manifet, that the blood is driven by the part.

It is alo driven becaue the blood being o changed, is troubleome to the Heart and thoe parts. For if the whole Hearts or the tip thereof living and Diected, or other greater particle, be pricked with a Pen-knife or •• Pin; as often as it is pricked, o often it will move it elf as by Natural motion, though it eem long ago to have lot all motion.

And that the Blood is driven by thePut it is drive: by the Vena cava into the Earl • t. Vena cava into the right Earlet of the Heart, I have manifetly een in the diection of live Creatures: for in all motions of the Heart, the firt beginning of Motion is • or no, becaue the Cava was knit to the Earlet and the Heart, we • ut-the Heart and the Ea • let quite off i •
<…> D •• s, •• the Vena
<…> , and we oberve, that <…>
the Vana cava did a very little pule, and at every time did end forth a little Blood. And therefore the Vena cava hath certain flehy fibres, for the mot part, about the Heart, which elewhere you hall not find in the Vena cava: but they may be een very evidently in the Vena cava of a Man, an O • , a Dog. Now the motion of the Vena cava is mot evident neer the Heart, yet for the mot part I have oberved it alo in live Dogs, all along that paage from the Liver and from the Jugulum, as far as to the Heart.

The right Earlet drives that Blood which it receives, by a certain tenion andOut of it into the Heart. contriction into the right Ventricle of the Heart.: for alo in the Earlet the motion or contriction is a little ooner than it is in the Heart. And the right Ventricle of the Heart being cut open as far as to the Earlet, at every contriction there manifetly appeared omwhat to be droven out of the Earlet into the Heart, which alo Harvey oberves in his fourth Chapter.

So that the Blood comes chiefly by pulion, into the right Ventricle of the Heart.Yet is it drawn alo? But is it not alo drawn both into the Earlet, and the right Ventricle? I conceive o: for with part of that Blood which they receive, they ought to be nourihed within: now that which mut nourih, mut be drawn, to the end the part may receive that Blood which is mot ueful to it; for by pulion alo that which is unprofitable is ent away, as Galen excellently (according to his wonted manner in other Caes) doth infer in his 1, 2, and 3. Books de N •• . fac. Now this drawing is not only of that blood which is near, but alo of that which is far off, as all parts have that faculty, leat they hould be oon detitute of nourihment.

But doth not the Heart alo draw, becaue it is widened, to avoid Vacuum, as we are wont to ay? It is not likely, becaue in its dilatation there can be no fear of Vacuum, as hall hereafter more evidently appear.

As the Blood comes to the right Ventricle of the Heart, o alo it comes to the The caue of the motion into the left Ventricle, is the ame. left, ave that we could not oberve the impule of the Blood, when the Lungs fall, to be o trong out of the Arteria Venoa into the left Earlet, as out of the Vena cava; yet there is manifetly ome.

But the Impule into both Earlets andA • d happens in both places at one moment. into both the Ventricles, happens at one and the ame moment of time: ave in Creatures ready to dye, in which we have oberved, that both Earlets and both Ventricles do not pule at one and the ame time.

But when the Blood is thus driven into the Ventricles of the Heart; the Heart hath no motion evident to the Eye, but putting our Finger upon the Heart, we perceive omewhat to enter into the Heart, and that the Heart becomes fuller, which alo Harvey hath oberved, in his 4. Chapter. Yea, we have oberved that the Earlet hath puled eventy, ometimes an hundred pules, before any motion of the Heart followed.
So that we ee how the Blood is moved into the Heart. Let us now ee how it is moved into the Arteries.

The Blood is moved into the Arteries by way of pulion or driving: The Blood is driven out of the Heart into the Arteries when the Heart is contracted. for • an hole being made in the Heart, we aw Blood come forth, when the Heart contracted it elf; alo the Aorta or Vena Arterioa being cut off from the Heart, we aw Blood poured forth when the Heart did traiten it elf; the tip of the Heart being cut off and the Heart er upright, we aw the Blood expelled and leaping out of the Heart; the Heart being cut a thwart in the middle, we aw the Blood expelled in the Sytole, but we never aw it go out in the Diatole. And whereas ome ay they have een in live Diections the Blood come out in the Diatole, I conceive they were deceived, by taking that to be a Diatole, which is indeed the Sytole, which alo that rare Anatomit Columbus, oberved in his 14. Book de Re Anatomica.
For in the motion of the Heart, we mut exactly ditinguih betwixt the Contriction, Quiet, and Dilatation thereof.

In the Contriction or Sytole of theThe Caue, of the Contriction of the Heart. Heart, the point of the Heart draws near to the Bais, and therefore it becomes a little broader. And in his Animals in which the Aorta is inferred not into the Bais of the Heart, but a little towards the middle, as in Rabbits, E • ls and uch like, the Bais alo of the Heart draws towards the point. Now the ides of the Heart, eated againt the right and left Ribs, do come one nearer to another, o that if you hall cut off the tip of either ide, o that it may hang, in the contriction it will return unto the ound ide and as it were into its place. But the ide of the Heart againt the Breat-bone, is lifted up, and epecially towards the Bais: and o the whole Heart is bent and tretched on all ides, and that part mea • the Bais being lift up, eems mot of all to mite the breat, and to make that beating which we feel; although the point alo may do it, which that great Anatomit Riolanus oberved, in the ixth Book of his Anthropologia Chapter, 12.

And that I might be the better aured, that this motion of the Heart now decribed, is the Contriction thereof. I have ometimes cut off the tip of the Heart, and ometimes cut it aunder athwart through the middle; And I manifetly aw, when it made the foreaid motion, that the Cavity of the Ventricles became les, and my Finger being put into the hole, I felt the Ventricles contract themelves to • y Finger. And the elf ame motion which I have hewed in the Heart makes externally when it contracts it elf, it hews alo inwardly; ave that there eems to be no motion in the Septum intermedium: peradventure, leat the Septum to traiten the left Ventricle, hould come nearer the left ide of the Heart, it hould leave the right Ventricle wider.

This is the • enion and ContrictionWhich is performed by help of the fibres. of the Heart, whereby the Blood is forced out of the Ventricles of the Heart, into the Vena Arterioa and the Aorta. And when it is languihing, it is made only by the help of thoe fibres wherewith the fleh of the Heart is furnihed; but to make a tronger contriction, thoe greater fibres concur, which are een in the Ventricles of the Heart, as I have often oberved, in Diecting the Ventricles of the Heart in live Anatomies.

Now thoe fibres in the Ventricles and in the ubtance of the Heart it elf, do manifetly caue the Contriction, becaue they are on all ides ditended broadwie, and therefore they are abbreviated as to length; jut as all the muculous parts of our Body, do in like manner perform their motion: and therefore when we would chew ou • meat we feel our temporal Mucle well and grow hard. By reaon of this welling the Cavity of the Ventricles of the Heart, is made more irait. And this Turor of the Fleh and greater fibres begins at the Bais, and proceeds gradually unto the • ip. In regard of which Motion if Hypocrates in the Beginning of his Book de Corde, cal'd the Heart a trong Mucle, he did truly after an elegant manner expres the manner of its Motion.

When the Heart by its ContrictionThe Heart after its Contriction returns to its Natural tate. hath forced the Blood into the Arteries, it returns to its, Natural tate. For the point returns from the Bais, as alo the Bais from the point, in thoe Animals which have no paage into the Aorta, in their bais; but the left and right ide of the Heart, extends it elf towards the Ribs, and that ide which looks towards the Breat-bone falls in, epecially
there where it anwers to the Orifice of the Aorta, and then the whol Heart rets and is found looe and oft.

And unles that upper ide did ettle and fall in, the Heart would be dilated in this return hereof to its naturall tate, as is eaie to ee and feel, when the heart is diected. But that upper ide mut needs fall in, leat the heart being emptied by foregoing contriction hould admit a Vaccuum. But when out of Vena Cava and the Arteria Venoa, new blood is forced into the heart, and the Blood contained therein is rarified by heat, then the upper ide ries: and the other ides, as we aid before, remain extended. And o theAnd then it is dilated. heart is then in its dilatation; nor is there any other dilatation of the heart ave this, to be oberved.

In the Particles of a live heart diected and taken out of the Bodie, there is no other dilatation then a remiion or lackening from Contriction. Indeed in thoe particles where contriction is ceaed, there remains a eeing kind of Palpitation; but that is another kind of motion proceeding from the pirit conteined in the fleh and eeking its way out; uch as may alo frequently be een in the mucles whole or diected, in Creatures diected preently upon their death.

So that the Dilatation and Contriction of the heart happens after the ame manner as that of other parts, the Stomach, Gutts, Bladder, Womb, which are ditended by what is ent into them, which when they have voided, they return to their naturall tate.

Now we cannot better oberve this motion of the Heart, then in thoe Beats which have only one ventricle in their Hearts, or if they have two, when the Animals begin to languih, otherwie when the Creatures are trong, the motion is hardly dicerned becaue of its Switnes; alo becaue the two ventricles preent thoe motions doubled; and becaue the Cone of the right ventricle, eeing it is les high then the left, when it is drawn back to the Bais, it makes an oblique motion.

But let us return to our buines, and let us ee further how the bloodThe Blood is driven out of the greater into the leer Arteries. out of the Arteries near the Heart, is pread through the Arteries of the whol Body, now it is done by a manifet Impule or driveing or any Artery being bound, at the Ligature it wels very much, and is tretched to an extream hardnes.
Notwithtanding the Heavines of the Blood furthers its motion downwards, and therefore the Heart eems to have been placed neerer the Head then the Heels.
It is alo likely that the Blood is drawn into all the Arteries, to the end that theyYet it is drawn withall. and their neighbouring parts may be nourihed with convenient Blood.

But that the Arteries hould draw byNot necearily by dilatation of the Artery. being widened, there eems no neceity: for the Blood may be driven forward only by impule, and the Arteries may drive the ame: for an Artery being broke and an Aneurima made in the Fleh, the Aneurima in the fleh, is perceived to pule after the ame manner as the Artery; wherein manifetly the fleh doth not draw the blood by dilatation, but the blood is driven into the ame. A mierable example whereof we latlely aw in the mot expert Dr. Johannes Elemannus, in whom an Artery breaking, the Aneurima poeed a fourth part of his Chet. And the like was oberved by Riolanus in the 6. Book of his Anshropologia chap. 12. And that indeed the pule of the arteries is caued by the Impule of Blood, the waving, creeping, pimire pules eem to hew, and many others which manifetly imitate the motion of the Blood in the artery.

True it is indeed, in that Book of Galen whether blood be contained in the
Nor doth Galens experiment hew any other thing.
Arteries, in the lat words it is aerted that an hollow Reed being thrut into the arteries, and the artery tied above the Reed, the artery doth not pule beyond the ligature, though the blood may be driven through the Reed. But I upect that place is mained and wants omwhat, becaue after the manner there decribed, the operation can very rarely and hardly ucceed for a free artery is there precribed to be opened out of which when it is open, every body knows what a world of blood leaps out, o that either the Creature will die, or through its weaknes, no arteries at leat not thoe more remote can pule.

But uppoe the place is perfect, and that the operation hall ucceed as it is there decribed, it may happen that the Creature quite languihing becaue of the flux of Blood, the pule might be felt on this ide the Reed, becaue the Reed being thrut in, rendring the artery more narrow, might in part top the blood, o that it might eaily fill the artery and lift it up. So I have many times een, arreries which hewed either a languihing or no pule, manifetly puling, when they were compreed not very far from the Heart. But Galen oberved no pule beyond the Reed, becaue through the Reed much narrower than the artery, the artery received little blood. And that uch a thing might eaily happen, I have oberved in a Rabbit, into the Aorta whereof, it being tied on each ide we thrut a little Reed, but becaue the ligature being looed the Beat died, we thought it not worth the while to bind the artery above the Reed and we thought we aw ome pule as far as to the Reed, but we could perceive none beyond the Reed.

Moreover we could never make that experiment ucceed, becaue it is not eaie to find a convenient Artery, and when it is found and duly opened, the Creature mot peedily dies, either becaue of Bloodhed, or (which may eem trange) by Convulions.

So that we can ee no other, but that the Blood being forced may pas through the Arteries, and that by it alo the Arteries may be ditended nor eems it neceary to call any other Caue to make the Arteries pule, eeing the forealleadged Caue may uffice. Yet Nature is wont frequentlyYet Galen hath certain tokens that the dilatation of the Arteries helps their motion. De uu pul. cap. 5. An anguis in Art. c. 8. to call more aitances to the performance of her works then do indeed to us eem neceary, who cannot alwaies dive into her Secrets. So here, ome tokens are oberved by Galen, that beides that dilatation they receive from the impule of the Blood, the Arteries do alo endeavor their own dilatation. That all the Arteries of the body both in ound perons and Creatures, and in live Anatomies, do pule in one and the ame moment: but nothing that is moved to ditance, can be every where at one moment; and therefore not at the ame moment make ditention every where. The Guts when blown up by Anatomits, or Pudding-makers, are een to be ditended in the parts neer the Blower firt, before the remoter parts are ditended. True indeed it is, that the Arteries are not empts as the Guts, but they are ditended being partlyfilled with blood: yet, eeing that blood which comes out of the Heart mut thrut forward that which is next it, and that again that which is next it, and o forward untill the Arteries be filled and ditended every where, it doth not eem, though the motion be performed out of a wide into a narrow place, that it can be performed in one moment jut as we ee twenty tones which the Boys et in a row, the greatet firt; when the firt is beaten down, all the ret do not fall in one moment. And therefore we may upect, that the Diatole of the Arteries, is caued by the impule of blood, and by their own proper dilatation: and that both thee caues contribute to the bloods motion.

Hence alo it appears, that this ameBut the impule i here caued only by the Hart. impule of the Blood is made only by
the Heart, nor does one part of the Arteries drive it into another: for that part which drives by contriction, that cannot in the ame moment be dilated, but all the Arteries are dilated in a moment.

And thus the blood is moved through the Arteries; and out of theOut of the Arteries into the Veins, out of the maller Veins into the greater Arteries into the Veins, out of the leer Veins into the greater and the Vena cava it elf, the blood is moved alo by Impule. For any Vein being bound in living Creatures, it falls in, and growes lank towards the Heart, and it is filled in that part which is more remote from the Heart,

And this ame Pulion to the Heart, eems to happen from any part of aIt is driven. Vein, for a Vein bound or compreed in a living Arm it is not only ttretched in the part remoter from the Heart, butBy every Particle of the Vein. alo in the ret there of nearer the Heart it falls in and is emptied; which nearer part if you alo tie that alo will be ditended beyond the Ligature, and will well. Now this Pulion is caued by the Fibres whereof the Veins are contituted.

We conceive nevertheles that the veins do alo draw, leat they hould receiveAnd drawn. the blood without choice, and that they may draw to themelves that which is mot ueful: howbeit they eem to receive the blood more by Pulion then by traction or drawing, becaue the veins being bound, are wonderfully ditended.
In the Vena cava there is a certain Store-houe of Blood, wherein blood is treaured up for future Ues, when it is more plentiful then that all of it need be ent unto the Heart.

And all thee are Caues of the Natural motion of the blood. To whichSo alo by Pulion the Chyle is moved out of the Stomach. the caues of the motion of the Chyle, are not unlike: for the Stomach contracting it elf by its Fibres, queezes out as much Chyle as is digeted, And by that preure it eems alo to open the Pylorus: for there eems not to be any pontaneous motion in the Pylorus, uch as is in the Stomach or the Guts.

The Chyle taies not long in the Guts, but is preently driven out by the contriction Through the Guts. of the tranvere Fibres: and while many fibres, and which mutually follow one another, do act, the Chyle is preed, nor can it all lip downwards, whereupon ome of the preed chyle lips into the milkie Veins; yet leat that the Chylus hould lip too oon to the Fundament, it is topped by the contriction of the lower tranvere Fibre: and being thus hut, and compreed above and beneath, it is preed through the wrinkled Coat of the Gut, as it were through a trainer into the milkie Veins. Now this ame contriction of the tranvere Fibres, happens in all the thin or mall Guts, and in all the thick or round Guts, in a certain order, and at certain ditances of time.
That the Chyle is moved through the milkie Veins into the Veins of the Portae,By the milkie Veins. into the Liver, and omtimes alo into the Vena cava by pule, a Ligature does hew.
It is alo likely that Chyle is drawn out of the Guts and milkie Veins, for it isAnd alo drawn. moved more wiftly out of them, then the Guts or Venae lacteae do eem to drive or force the ame.
The Chylus in the Ramus meentericus, Vena partae and Vena cava, being mingled with the blood, is moved by the ame caue, which there as we have aid, does move the blood.

Now the Chylus is carried by peculiarWhy not through the mearaick Veins. Veins, rather then by the Mearaicks which contain blood, becaue the Mearaicks being to admit blood, were to have their mouths opened into the Guts, through which the blood would eaily have lipt into the Guts. Nor could the drawing Faculty prevent that inconveniency, which is here much obcurer and much weaker then the expulive Faculty.
As this Motion of the Chylus, o alo the circular motion of the blood hath its ues and conveniences, of which the principal eem to be thee.

That by the continual paage therofThe motion of the blood erves for the utility of the parts. through the Heart, the blood is alo continually heated, and whiles om blood goes through eldomer, other blood oftner, there is found in the Veins blood of all Qualities: which while it is carryed into all parts, and Nature unlocks, and offers all the treaure to them, they may be the better heated, and receive that Nourihment, which may be mot convenient to feed and trengthen them.
But this motion does alo contributeAnd that it may be preerved. much to the preervation of the blood in its integrity, free from corruption or putrefaction: for
which is alo mot true of the blood, as we may daily ee when the Veels are obtructed.

It contributes alo to the perfectionAnd to perfect the Blood. of the Blood, whilet by continual motion, it is rarified and attenuated. But it makes chiefly towards it perfection, in that the blood is omtimes attenuated, grows hot, and is rariied in the Heart, and omtimes again it is condened and congeales as it were in the Habit of the Body. For no part in the Body is horter then the Heart, and none les hot then the Habit of the Body. And therefore there happens a certain Circulation as it were, not unlike to that whereby the Chymits make their Spirits mot ubtile and perfect. For the blood which is attenuated by heat, after it is condened by cold, is able to perit in that thinnes, nor does it return to its old thicknes: from which degree of thinnes in tract of time it attains to a greater by means of heat, in which being again condened by cold, it comes to continue; and o at lat it becomes mot fit for the making of vital Spirits.

For this end the blood is movedThe blood which is carried to nourih the part, is not moved circularly. circularly; but hath it not therefore elewhere another motion? Out of the mallet Arteries the blood is carried right out into the fleh, that it may contitute the nameles humor, the Ros, Gluten, and Cambium, nor does it return hither from whence it came, leat the blood flowing through the leat, hould hinder thee humors from being gleued and aimilated to the parts.

It flows alo omtimes chiefly, becaue it is driven out of the Arteries into the fleh: and frequently alo the chief moving caue is attraction: for the bones cannot without attraction receive the thicker part of the humor for their nourihment, and leave the remaining thinner part thereof, unfit to nourih them in the Veels.
