div.p: Some alo there areNor is there any other motion of the Blood, whereby the Valves of the Heart are hut. who uppoe, that the blood being carried out of the Heart does go back, and return again by the Arteries into the Heart. Which they are therefore moved to think, that they may be able to give a mechanick caue, why the Valves of the Heart in the Orifice of the Arteries, do fall down and are cloed up. I truly have alwaies eteem that a rare deign of Eraitratus, to explain all things that happen in our Body mechanically, but I account it a rah thing in him to meaure the Widom of God by his own Widom. And thee are to be counted Engins, which evident reaon, and epecially Sene do hew to be uch. Here contrariwie our Senes oberve, that the blood goes through the Arteries from the Heart not to the Heart; and in a rare and languihing Pule, that the Artery does not well lat, where it is knit to the Heart, as it hould do if that Opinion were true, but firt of all. Alo that the Valves are not hut by the blood running back, we have this ign, that in cae the Artery be bound two fingers from the Heart, and it be o opened betwixt the Ligature and the Valves, that the blood may freely pas forth, and therefore go neither backwards nor forwards; yet the Valves may be divers times well atned, the Heart ordinarily moved, and o as not to • ed forth the blood, ave in its contriction. And therefore if I would here allow of any mechanical Motion, I hould admit the common Opinion, which aies, that the hutting, as of the heart, o of the Valves, is performed by contraction of the Fibres. For that ame contraction of the fibres in the Heart, is every where obvious to the Eye-ight.

But we have truly no ign or • okenNor in Paion • of the Mind. that the Blood is any other waies directly moved through the Veins from the Heart, or through the Arteries to the Heart. In Joy, truly, the Humors move outwards; but this may be betide by the Arteries alone. And in Sadnes, the Humors may be moved inwardly through the Veins alone: and they mut needs do o, for eeing the Pule does not ceae in Sadnes, and by the Pule there goes continually omwhat through the Arteries outwards, hardly can any thing be moved through the Arteries inwards, and to the Heart.

Howbeit, praeternaturally the humors have another motion beidesYet there is another praeternatural motion thereof. that which we have here decribed, whilet by their lightnes or other activity, they mount upwards, or by their weight decend downwards, as is manifet in uch as have the Varices o called. Alo that way being hut up, by which they were wont to be moved, they are compelled to eek another. So in a Duck I have divers times een in the Veels of the Breat, the blood parti-coloured, ome whiteih, ome reddih, which the Artery being contracted, was moved to and from the Heart, in divers ides of the Artery:
but that motion lated not long, nor did the blood ever enter into the Heart by that motion.

And thus (mot worthy Friend Bartholine) I conceive I have anwered your Quetion touching the motion of the Blood. Whereinto I did enquire more crupulouly, that I might better know the Nature of the Humors, and their Deflux: from which Flux of Humors innumerable Dieaes arie. I did alo believe that I might more exactly undertand how good or bad blood was generated, if I knew thoe Parts by which the Humor paing along might be changed. Alo I conceived that I hould be better able to judg, how very many Dieaes ought to be cured, if I knew which Vein being opened, would evacuate uch and uch parts, and through what parts the Remedy ought to pas, before it can come to the part affected? Alo innumerable things came into my mind, diffued through our whole Art, as the Doctrine of Pules, of Feavers, of Inflammations, their Generation and Cure, and other things, which made me deire to be acquainted with this Motion of Blood.

And the Experiments whereby I was brought into this Opinion, are o evident, that I doubt not to affirm, that learned and dicreer Phyitians will henceforwards, allow of this Motion of the Chyle and Blood. Howbeit in ome Caues and in certain circumtances of this Motion, I cannot promie the like Agreement: for undry men are Naturally inclined by a diparity of their Judgments, to embrace different Opinions.

Touching the truth of thee Experiments, you cannot (my Bartholine) make Quetion, who have your elf een many of them: and there were frequently preent mot learned Doctors of Phyick not unknown to you, Francicus Sylvius, Johannes Van Horn, Ahauerus Schmitnerus mot accurate Diecters; and thoe perons of olid Learning Francicus vander Schagen, and Antonius Vocketaert: nor were they only preent, but they alo afforded their Counels and Handiwork to help make the aid Experiments: to whom in that repect I am very much obliged. And o farewel mot learned Bartholine, and perit to love me. Dated at Leyden the 10. of the Kalends of October, Anno 1640.

div.head: THE SECOND LETTER OF THE Motion of the Blood, To the aid BARTHOLINUS.
div.p: SUch is the Fate of Writers, that they are comcompelled to write when they are unwilling: that o they may anwer their Adveraries, unles they would rather be wanting to themelves, or the caue which they defend. A certain learned Man would needs extort this from me, being buied about far otherThe occaion of this econd Letter. matters. For thoe Thees which he had before objected againt, he hath endeavored now lately by a peculiar Writing to refute. In which Writing there are many witty and learned Paages: but I find that fault in the Author, which the Ancients found in Albutius the Rhetoritian, who made it his Buines in every Caue he pleaded, not to ay all that hould be aid, but all that he was able to ay. Alo that Motion of the Blood which is evident in live Diections, he hath never labored to oberve: jut as if the matter might better be conceived by the Mind, then he could ee it with his Eyes. But thee and other things concerning thoe Thees, I leave to theAnwer to the Objections. Care of Roger Drak who is now a Doctor of Phyick at London, a Man of an acute Wit and olid Learning: I hallThat in Blood letting the Vein does wet at the binding. only meddle with uch things as hall eem to oppoe the circular Motion of Blood. And in the firt place, what it is that Blood-letting does teach us in this Cae, concerning which thatNot through Pain. learned Man hath oberved things worthy of Conideration.

A Surgeon being to open a Vein,Not by training the Vein; makes a Ligature upon the Arm, that the Vein may well. The Vein that wells, not on this fide the Ligature towards the heart, but on that ide the Ligature, which is furthet from the Heart. Now the Caue of that Tumor is not Pain, caued by binding the part: for oftentimes little, and commonly no pain in the part bound. And when the Arm is pinced or pained by Burning or otherwie, it hath its Veins for the mot part les wollen, then upon a imple and bare Ligature.

Nor is it more likely, that the Veins well upon the Ligature, becaue through the Veins which are traiter becaue they are bound, greater pienty of Blood comes and with more wiftnes from the Liver; as about Bridges and in other places, Rivers being traitned do run more wiftly. For the Water of a River being gathered
together in a narrow place, is manifetly lifted up into a welling, from which when it falls, it goes the fater: but the arm being bound the contrary happens; for they are not the Veins nighet the Liver, from which blood hould come, but thoe farthet from the Liver which are mot ditended.

It remains therefore, that the Veins well beyond the Ligature, becaueBut becaue the motion of the Blood is topped. the motion of the blood running from the mall veins into the Heart, is topped by the Ligature, and being there gathered together, ditends the Vein. But to the end I might be more certain hereof, I bound the jugular and crural branch, in living Creatures very trongly with a threed, o that no blood might pas by; and I opened that part of the Vein which was more remote from the Heart, it bled plentifully, wiftly, vehemently, oon after I looed the band, and cut the Vein aunder through the middle, and the part thereof farthet from the Heart being drawn out of the body upwards, preently and wiftly fell a bleeding: whilt in the mean time the part of the Vein nearet the heart, being omewhat elevated, leat the Creature trugling with pain hould eaily force out the Blood; firt it voided but little, and afterwards no blood at all. whence it eemed to me apparent, that the blood came out of the veins far from the heart, into thoe near the ame, and not out of the greater Veins into the leer; unles haply ome neighbouring blood finding a way might lip away. Any one may eaily try as much in opening a vein in the Arm: for if he force the blood above the Ligature upwards with his finger, o that the vein appear empty, yet hall he ee the blood iue out as fat as ever below the Ligature; which could not come through the upper branch being at preent empty.

But if the Vein be thus ditended with blood, which is moved from the mallerNor doe the Arteries wel becaue of the Ligature. veins to the Heart, how can the artery be ditended upon the ligature, which divers excellent Phyitians relate to have been o ditended, that it has been opened intead of a vein; the truth is, the Artery doth not well upon the Ligatures being made, unles where it is neer the Heart, but farther off it falls in omewhat, and is diminihed, as I have an hundred times and oftener experimented in the Diections of living Anatomies. But I do not think it was any of the authors, meaning thar the remoter part of the Artery was ditended by means of the Ligature, but that their meaning only was, where the Vein did not appear which was to be opened, that there the place where it lay was to be ought by feeling; and that by a pit, by motion and welling of the Blood it was to be found: and when we feel a welling, or otherwie dicover the ame, we hould not preently conclude that there was the Vein; for it might be an Artery which by reaon of the hard binding had lot its pule, and which by reaon of the thicknes of the Coates not quite falling in, might counterfeit a certain tumor and puffingup as it were.

But moreover if the Vein wels by reaon of the Blood returning to theBut the Veins wel alo with two Ligatures, and wherefore. Heart, why does the vein alo wel and if opened, why void Blood, when there is a Ligature made below as well as above the place phlebotomized? which Blood cannot be thought poibly to come from the lower parts, by reaon of the Ligature made below the Orifice. But this does not alwayes o happen, but but ometimes, only when the Arm is tied at a certain ditance, and then the greater Veins in the place between thoe two Ligatures do receive that blood from the maller Veins, which maller Veins receive from the maller Arteries, which are joyned to the mal veins by way of Anatomois. And that indeed the blood which flows out betwixt the two Ligatures, does come by way of Anatomois out of the Arteries, this is a ign and in that it flows more hotter and with more violence, and more eaie and ooner a Lipothymia or fainting fit follows the efflux hereof. And this Ligature I am wont to make ue of, when I have igns that pirituous and hot blood is in fault, and I bid the Chirurgeon eek out thoe Anatomoes, by his Ligature: for if the Ligature be made above the Anatomois, it tops the motion of the blood; but beneath it does not top it, but the blood leaps out hotter to the feeling of the Patient.

When a Vein is opened and theWhy in bloodletting they unbind the Arm, when the blood does not run apace. blood runs out, as oon as it begins to top or come away paringly, or if it did o at firt, we looe the Ligature, that the blood might run out fater. Now the Ligature eems not therefore to be lacked, to the intent the blood may come from the Liver through the Veins. For though there be little or no blood above the Ligature, yea only a pit appear in the Vein, yet will the coure of the Blood be increaed by looening the Ligature, which cannot poibly come out of an empty Vein. But by the looening of the band, the Blood may the better decend by the Arteries, and pas out of them into the Veins; becaue the Arteries being compreed by the Ligature, by looening the aid Ligature become more free. Now that the Arteries are not alwayes ufficiently at Liberty when the arm is bound, the patient himelf can witnes, who oft perceives the pule of the Artere at the Ligature, which perception the compreed Arterie caues, when it mites againt the fleh. And the Phyitian if he examine the matter, hall often find a les pule in the bound a • m then in the free. And I can tetifie that I have divers times applyed my fingers to the Patients writ, when the band was to be looed, and oberved, that when by looing the Ligature Blood came in more plentifully, the Pule became greater.

But if that Blood which flowsWhy much blood may be taken away. out when a vein is opened, comes out of the Arteries into the veins, how can it be plentifully taken away? for all the Arteries pule equally, and therefore they eem to afford blood to the Veins in one and the ame meaure: and if o be theret of the arteries afford o much to their veins as the arteries of the Arms do to theirs and is drawn out, hall not the heart be oon detitute of all blood? There is truly no danger at all: For we have aid the blood comes as fat unto the heart, as it is driven thence

Yet I cannot conceive the Blood enters all veins alike, although the Arteries eem to pule equally; for all Liquors flow more eaily and wiftly into an empty place, in which there is nothing to drive and force them, and moreover in this cae the Blood is more forcibly drawn by the empty Veins then by the full ones.

Now more tore of Blood iuesAnd more out of the Arm then out of the Hand. from a vein opened in the cubit, then in the Hand, becaue all that blood, which comes to the Veins through all the Anatomoes of the Cubit of the Hand, mut return through the Cubit Veins;
but les runs through the Veins of the Hand, and that only, which comes through the Anatomoes of the Hand.

Out of a wounded Arterie, indeed the blood preently flowes, althoughWhy it flows out of a wounded Arterie not bound. it be not bound. But that happens becaue the Blood is carryed with greater vetiemence, though the arteries then through the Veins; by which vehemency, it fills the Arterie, lifts up and ditends the Coat, and if it be opened, necearily flies out.

Our of a Vein opened when Blood has flowed ufficiently, weThe Ligature being looed, the blood tops, and ometimes it runs, and why? top it by untieing the Ligature, becaue the Blood may be carried again its old way, now it is at Liberty and the way free. But if it o happen, that too much blood being gathered about the Ligature, the Veins cannot give it a free paage; or o large an orifice be made that the Blood may now go right out that way, by which it went, when it was hut in, ometimes the Band being looened, the blood runs out in a full tream.

Which our Chyrurgeons at this very day, that they may effectually top, they frequently compres the vein with their Thumbs a little below the Orifice, and o they top theBut is topped by holding the finger in the Vein below the Orifice. blood; leat if they hould compres it above the orifice, the blood contained therein hould preently curdle, and hinder the healing up of the Vein. And they that deny that the blood may thus be topped, I know not wherein we hould credit them who would abue us in a thing obvious to the Senes. And eeing the Blood is topped by compreing the lower part of the Vein, it is truely manifet that the Blood acends from the lower parts.

But in cae it hould happen, not in Blood-letting, but by ome otherAlo when the Vein is cut aunder in the middle and wherefore, michance, that a Vein hould be o wounded, that the Blood could not be topped, the Vein is cut aunder in the middet: Whereupon, the Vein being no longer trerched out as before, the parts cut aunder are drawn upwards and downwards into the fleh, by which fleh the mouths of the Veins are compreed and hut, and that o much the more eaily becaue the Blood can move its elf o much the more eaily through the neighboring veins which are extended and open, the former being hut up, and therefore for the very ame caue a mall Arterie being cut aunder athwart, neither Bleeding nor Inflammation do follow.
Which things being o, I conceive it is evident to all Men, that uch things as happen in Blood-letting, do either prove the Circular motion of the Blood, or at leat are not againt the ame.

But eeing other Things are objected againt us, we mut anwerNo parts receive Blood by the veins excepting the liver. them alo. And firt whereas they prove that the Blood comes through the Veins, not out of the Arteries, but from the Liver; becaue ome parts receive Blood, and have Tumors ariing from the Afflux of the Blood, which parts have no Arteries, amongt which they reckon the Pleura. But it does not follow, if the parts have not Arteries, that their veins do not receive their blood from the Arteries, but from the Liver; for as we aid, the blood out of the Meenterick and Celiack Arteries does not enter the Meenterick and Splenick Veins, through which it is carried to the Liver: even o other veins may receive blood from the Arteries, which they may carry into a part more remote from Arteries. Howbeit there is no part of the Body of any bulk, wherein the Anatomits do not rightly acknowledge Arteries to be. And infinite Arteries do not as yet lie concealed from their knowledge, becaue the mallet Arteries dipered through the fleh, have only one Coat as the Veins have. Yea, and in the Liver it elf, there are o many branches of the Arteria Celiaca, as there are Branches of the Vena Porta, and as many branches alo there are of the Ductus Cholidocus, all which have bin by Anatomits hitherto reckoned for Branches of Vena Porta. becaue thoe three kinds of Veels are in the Liver incloed in a common Coat. At leat no man will ever deny the Arteries of the Pleura, that has once een the Chet of a living Creature opened; for whilt the Chet is diected, Blood is wont to leap out of the Arteries of the Pleura.

Moreover they prove that Blood does not come out of the Arteries into the Veins, becaue the Arm being o bound, that the Arteries may till pule, the arm is not immeaurably welled below the ligature, whereas it ought to be o wollen and ditended, if by reaon of the Ligature nothing can flow back into the greater Veins, and at every pule, the Arteries drive omewhat into the lower veins, at every contraction, of which Contractions there are more then three thouand performed every hour. Nevertheles, it may come to pas that the Arm is not extended to uch a bulk when it is bound; becaue the veins are not totally hut up, and the blood may by ome creeping holes pas under the ligature, and go into the greater veins: as we ee a part being cloely bound to repel Humors, for divers months or years, is nevertheles nourihed by the blood which flows through; alo it may come to pas that o little Blood is forced in through the Arteries of the bound Arm, as that it cannot ditend, or Swell the ame under a long time, for that Blood only is forced in, the veins being tretched with fullnes, which is in the Arteries from the Ligature unto the Hand; for that which is above the Ligature, can enter more eaily into the veins, by open Anatomoes. Yea it may come to pas, when the veins being ditended, do no longer permit the Blood to be forced into them by the Arteries, that the pule of the Arteries is topped, or that the Blood regurgitates upwards, and enters the Veins above the Ligature, through the Anatomoes: the like whereto I aw in a Duck, as I formerly related. Unles one of thee things happen, the Arm would preently wel after it is bound, and a uffocation of the innate Heat, by the Abundance of Blood driven in would follow. For I have often bound mine own and others Armes above the Writ, and I alwayes aw the veins ditended, and the Fleh to well omewhat and grow red; and oftentimes though not alwayes, the arteries abated by little and little of their pule, yea and ometimes intermitted; and afterward the red colour of the bound Arm was changed into black and blew: and therefore I preently undid the Ligature, being frighted with this Example. A certain Country-man being wounded in the inide of his Arm about the Cubit, when the Village Chirurgeon could not top the blood, he bound the Arm extream cloe about the Wound, whence followed an exceeding Inflammation of the lower part of his Arm, and uch a welling, that deep pits were een in the place of his fingers joynts, and within eighteen hours, the lower part of his Arm was gangrena • ed and phacelated, which Chritianus Regius an expert Chirurgeon did cut off, in the preence of my
elf, and E • aldus Screvelius an excellent Phyitian.

Moreover they object, if the venal Blood comes out of the Arteries,How and why the venal blood differs from the arterial. how can the arterial Blood differ o much from the venal? But we mut know that it differs les from the venal Blood, then mot men imagine, who from the violence wherewith the arterial Blood leaps forth, do collect the great plenty of Spirits therein, and the great rarity or thinnes thereof: whereas that Leaping proceeds from the Force wherewith the Heart drives the Blood through the arteries; for an Arterie being opened below or beyond the ligature, the Blood comes out only dropping. And the difference between thee two bloods is caued by the greater or les quantity of Heat and Spirits, according as the Blood is more or les remote from the Heart the fountain of Heat. For the Blood which is near the Heart differs much from that which is far off, in the mallet arteries, which you can hardly ditinguih from that which is in the mall veins. And the maller veins have more thin and hot Blood, then the great ones; which any one may eaily try in opening veins of the Arm and Foot. Yea, and if the Vein be opened with a double Ligature on each ide the orifice, as I aid before, the Blood will come out hotter then with a ingle Ligature.

Now that the Blood does not go out of the maller veins into theHow mentrual Blood is collected about the womb. greater, they endeavour to prove by womens monthly purgations, which according to their judgment, are gathered one whole month together in the Veins about the Womb; and if they are carried from the Womb unto the Head, they conceive that they do not pas through the Vena cava and the Heart. Howbeit, the common and true opinion is, that about the time of the uual flux, the blood begins to be moved to the Womb, from which motion of the humors, pains of the ides and loines are wont to arie about that time, And I know by Experience, that about the time of the mentrual Flux, if the Pule of the Heart and arteries can be made greater, the Coures will flow the better, becaue the Blood will through the arteries be driven more forcibly into the Womb. It may nevertheles fall out, that the Coures may be collected and make an Obtruction in the Womb, and that then the Blood may not return into the greater veins, that motion being topped: but that is beides nature.

And when the mentrual blood is carried out of the Womb intoHow they are carried out of the Womb into the Head. the Head, the way is not inconvenient, through the Vena cava, the Heart, and the acending branch of the Arteria Aorta, and that they do indeed pas through the Heart, thoe palpitations and light faintings do eem to argue, which are wont to attend upon the Coures topped.

But hould we not conceive it to be a dangerousHow it comes that the Humors paing through the Heart, do not caue great Inconveniences. thing, if all the ill humors in our bodies mut pas into and through the Heart. But we mut know, that our bodies are o framed, as that they may be mot convenient for us when we are in Health, and not when we are ick. Moreover the Humor which putrifies by reaon of obtruction and is very bad, comes not to the Heart, becaue its way is topped up. Nor is the Heart o weak as to be corrupted by an evil Humor, which tayes not long therein: for thoe great Phyitians Galen, Hollerius, Laurentius have oberved that the Quittor of uch as have an Empyema, and other harp and tinking Humors, do critically and without any bad ymptomes, pas through the left ventricle of the Heart which many times makes for the good of the ick Perons, in whom that bad Humor paing through the Heart, is often vanquihed by the Vigour and Vertue hereof.

The other Objections which theyThe Objections againt circumtances. make, do only repect the Caues of this motion or certain Circumtances, wherein men are wont more freely to dient, yet let us breifly conider whether or no they have in them any weight, wherewith to burthen our Opinion.

They ay that at every contractionNothing hinders, but that half an ounce of Blood may be forced out of the Heart, at every pule. of the Heart, the blood is not driven out by half ounces, nor by drams, nor by cruples, out of the Heart of a Man, for three Caues: firt becaue that blood is too pirituous, but I have already hewed that it is not o pirituous as men imagine commonly: econdly becaue thoe little Valves of the Heart, do only gape a little, and then are cloe hut again, which alo doth not agree with experience: for an Arteric being cut off from the heart, great treams of Blood do iue from the Heart. Thirdly that the Arteries are too full then to be able to admit half an ounce, a dram, or a cruple of Blood. But that is too inconiderately avouched; for when the Heart contracts it elf, all the arteries in the body are enlarged, and that on all ides, as I have divers times perceived with my hand, holding the naked arterie betwixt my fingers. And who will now ay, that all the Arteries of the Body being dilated, cannot admit of a Scruple, a Dram, yea half an Ounce of blood, more then they have?

Alo they deny that in the childNothing hinders but that the Blood may be circularly moved in the child in the Womb. in the Womb, the blood out of the Vena Cava, does through the Veels of the heart united enter into the Arteria Aorta, and go from thence out of the umbilical Arteries into the umbilical Vein, and return back by it into the Heart: becaue they think this great aburdity will follow, that one Vein hould carry the mothers blood and withal o much blood as the two umbilical arteries do bring in. As if Rivers did not frequently carry as much water in one Channel, as many Brooks are able to bring in. And here the umbilical Vein when it is but one, is much greater then the Arterie. There is often but one arterie or there are two veins; that the arteries may as much as may be anwer to the veins. In brute Beats (ayes Fallopius a rare Anatomit) there are allwayes two Veins and two Arteries, which with the Vrachus or pi-pipe do reach as far as the Navil, and the Veins do preently grow into one before they enter into the Abdomen which does reach to the Gates of the Liver, as I have oberved in all Sheep, Goats, and Cows, whoe young ones I have diected, But if they peak of the Child in a Womans Womb, I avouch that ometimes I have not een the two umbilical Arteries, but only one Arterie and one Vein acending together with the Vrachus to the Navil: where the Arterie is again divided into two, which afterwards go unto the ides of Os acrnm. And that indeed thoe Veels of the Heart are united in a Child in the Womb, that the blood may pas that way out of the Vena Cava into the Aorta, Waterfowl,A ign that it is o indeed. as the Duck, Gooe, and uch like do eem to teach us;
which becaue they cannot often breath under the water no • dilate their Lungs, nor conequently admit the blood that way, they have thoe unions of the veels of the Heart, when they are grown up. Which alo Harvey notes in his 6. Chapter.

Alo they deny the frequent AnatomoesThough there be Anatomoes of the Veins & arteries yet Tumors may arie. of the Veins and Arteries, for if uch there were, they ay tumors would not arie by Fluxion and Congetion of Humors. As if Rivers though they have outlets, receiving over-great plenty of water, may not overflow the neighbouring fields; nor can the blood hed out of the Veels, becaue it congeals, eaily return into them again. Moreover Tumors are many times caued, for as much as by reaon of Obtruction, the bloods paage is topped; and becaue by heat and pain it is drawn into the fleh.

Now thoe Tumors eem rather to favour the Doctrine of the bloods circular motion, becaue they happen through cold, bruiing, and all toppage of the paages of the Body; and becaue with Aqua vitae or ome uch medicine, the Humors and the Tumors being often made fluid, it is by this motion of the blood drawn into the Veins; and the Tumor by that means ooner cured then by repulion, revulion, concoction or diipation.

Touching the Caue of the Bloods motion, difficulties do alo preent themelvesNot by Rarifaction. unto us; and when we deny that the blood according to the Coure of Nature, is o uddenly and vehemently rarified in the Heart, as to be able to move the Heart, the blood of the whole Body, and the Arteries themelves; thoe famous men the Ring-leaders of this opinion, do uppoe that they do hereby prove it, In that while we are cold, all the Veins of our Body are contracted, and can hardly be een, where as afterwards when we grow hot, they do o well, that the blood contained in them, eems to take up ten times o much pace as before it did.

As for me, this truly is my Opinion, and thus I perwade my elf, that eeing they have now divers times, o diligently endeavored in Publick to perwade men to embrace this their Opinion of Rarifaction; and have diffected and lookt into the Hearts of Living Creatures, nor have yet dared to ay, that they could enibly perceive any uch Rarifaction of the blood in the Heart; I ay, my Opinion is, that they could not indeed and in truth oberve any uch Rarifaction of the blood in the Heart, and as they would in this place maintain And it will be eaie for him that is a little vert in live Diections, to ee that there is no uch rarifaction. And therefore though it might be proved, that uch a Rarifaction of the blood, does ometimes happen praeternaturally, yet ought not the caue of the Natural motion of the Heart, Blood and Arteries be therefore attributed thereunto.

Yet in the Example which they propound, I do not ee what certainty there is that the blood by reaon of its Rarifaction does poes ten times more pace then before. For might not that ame Tumor of the external Veins eaily arie, becaue whereas before the veins were contracted and traitned through cold, they could not receive much blood, and therefore they could not well: Which cold and traitning of the veels being afterwards taken away, and the Veins being looned by heat, they might admit much blood, which is driven into them by the heart, and o appear full and welling. That this is not the leat caue of the tumor of the Veins, perons that are feauerih eem to teach us, who if they thrut their arms into the cold, have not their Veins o welling, but if they keep them warm under the cloaths, they have them very full and wole, which tumor if it came from Rarifaction, it ought to be in both caes alike, eeing that in them, the bloods Rarifaction proceeds from an internal caue.

Nor do I conceive that it is alo void of Quetion and undoubted, that when we are firt cold, and afterwards grow hot, the inner Veins as well as the outer do well. For it is much to be upected, that the inner parts do poes les blood and heat before; becaue by that cold wherewith before they were not hurt, if when we are o heated we drink cold drink, they are wonderfully weakened. Doubtles as the inner veins are oftentimes the treaury of the blood, wherein the blood is tored up for future ues, o may the external Veins be the like treaury, and they appear to be when they o well as aforeaid.

Thee men themelves when theyBut by contriction of the heart the blood is driven in the Arteries. oberved that this alo was much againt their Opinion, that we aerted that the blood was manifetly poured out, at the contriction of the Heart; they avouch that that is not the contriction, but the dilatation of the heart which we mean. But that we were deluded by a certain appearance, becaue in our contriction, there was a contriction only at the Bais, but about the tip a true Dilatation; which Invention when others aw that it could not hold, leat they alo hould eem to deert their caue, they invented that there is a contriction indeed, in the Cavity of the whole Ventricle, but in the pits and paages of the ides, epecially in Dogs, there is a certain kind of Extenion and true Dilatation.

But truly, the upper part of the Heart is not een to be dilated, when the lower is contracted; ave when the Creature is dying, and that the waving motion of the Heart is caued by the impule of the blood. Nor can we oberve one Dilatation or Contriction of the Pits, another of the • avity of the Ventricles. Only a certain progreive motion is oberved in a large Heart, becaue the Dilatation or contriction doth evidently begin at the bais, and enibly proceeds to the tip, although 'tis performed all welnear in a moment. And that I might be perfectly aured, that the Heart was contracted within likewie, on all ides, having cut off the tip of each Ventricle, • put my thumb and fore-finger into the living heart of a Dog and a Rabbit; and I manifetly felt the ides of the Heart to pres my fingers to the middle partition, equally in the middle, tip and Bais; and that the pits in greater Beats, became to Sene, not bigger but leer. And oon after the Contriction abating, that the ides of the heart above, beneath and in the middle were looned, and the pits did feel evidently larger. But in the Septum or partition wall it elf, no motion is felt, ave that the Spirits eeking egres make a kind of Palpitation, when in Creatures at the lat gape, the motion of the right Ventricle ceaes, the Septum follows the motion of the right Ventricle.

Now they would have it neverthelesNot in the dilatation, though ometimes blood go out therein. that naturally the blood is poured out in the widening of the heart, and not in the Contriction or traitning thereof, becaue in the wounded Heart of Living Creatures, the blood is een to come out when the Heart is dilated. And this is ometimes true; but that which they thence collect, our very Senes teach us to be untrue. For either the Dog or other creature is placed with its Head and breat elevated, and
the belly low, and o the wound is inflicted into the Heart, in which cae, eeing the blood which enters through the Vena cava and Arteria venoa into the Heart, is higher then any wound of the Heart, it, as oon as it is entred, which is at the beginning of the Dilatation, flows out, not becaue of the Pule, but of its own heavines, and therefore it is not by any force made to flie out to ome ditance, as it happens in the Pule of the Arteries. But if as it ought to be, the dog be laid on his back, his head and belly reting on the ame plane, and the wounded Heart be raied with a mans fingers, as long as there is any trength in the Heart, it ooner by Contriction cats out the blood it hath received, at a ditance, then the whole Heart is filled or widened. But when the trength of the heart decayes, and that it eldom traitens it elf or not at all, becaue the Earlets are more trong, and do till continue puling, even when the Heart quite gives over; the blood being driven by the Earlets enters the heart, is there collected, and when more is come in then the Heart can contain, it goe out at the wound, not with violence, as it mut do to caue Pulation, but with a gentle motion, drop after drop. So that our Sene can perceive no trong motion of the blood, ave in the Hearts Contriction.

Now they will have the blood to return through the Veins into theAnd being driven by all parts of the Veins, it returns to the Heart. Heart, only becaue the blood being forcibly driven to the Parts, as water poured into an horn, does regurgitate or abound back upwards, and o is carried back unto the Heart. But I have already hewed tokens, that the blood is either drawn, or driven by all the parts of the Veins: beides which I have alo thee following: in that the Heart being taken out of the body, the motion of the blood, and that wift enough, is till een in the Veins. And if a Vein, yea a milkie one, be tied in two places, that ame Ligature being only looned, which is nearet the Heart, while the parts are yet hot, the Chvle will till be moved to the Liver, the blood unto the Heart, which could neither by any tep be driven from the Heart through the Arteries, nor from the Guts through the Venae lacteae; nor would it by its own fluidity more rather upwards then downwards.

But let us anwer the remaining objections:By this motion the Veins and Arteries may be nourihed. They uppoe, if the blood hould be moved o wiftly, that the Veins and Arteries could not conveniently be nourihed. But a dog can quench his thirt, drinking at the River Nilus and running as he drinks; but here the parts tay at the brook ide: and whatever they have drawn from the blood, they treaure up in their own ubtance, leat it hould be wahed away, by the running by of the humor.

Alo they conceit this Motion is not ueful for the blood. Seeing it mayAnd the blood ventilitated better. ufficiently be conerved (ince it abounds with native heat) by repiration and tranpiration. Yet mot certain it is, that the blood is yet more ventilated, if it be peedily moved, and its mallet Particles alo agitated with this motion. So the water of a lake or tanding pool, though it be gently moved and fanned on the Surface, yet is it corrupted; when in the mean while Rivers that are totally and in all parts agitated, are found to continue mot uncorrupt and wholom.

Thee are the things (mot excellent Bartholine) which I thought fit to joyn to the former, that I might atisfie thoe who cannot receive a new opinion, wherin they oberve any difficulty or obcurity; who many times have neither mind nor time to enquire exactly into the bowels thereof. But in my Judgment, we ought not to deny things manifet, although we cannot reolve uch as are difficult.

But I never was dipoed to contend and quarrel with any man about words. There are very many excellent things about which time may be pent; which many times alo is not ufficient for our neceary occaions. Alo from a Scoffer that eeks after her, Knowledge does hide her elf away, but to him that is tudious of the truth, he comes to meet, and preents her elf to his view. Farewel mot Learned Bartholine. From the Univerity of Leyden in Holland, the Kalends of December 1640.
